在我说这些话的时候，他一直看着我，而在这之前，他甚至都没有往我这边看过。 He looked at me when I said this; he had hardly turned his eyes in my direction before.
“我觉得倒是你应该好好呆在家吧，”他说道，“如果你就在这附近住的话，你是从哪儿来的？” “I should think you ought to be at home yourself,” said he, “if you have a home in this neighbourhood: where do you come from?”
“就从山下来的，有月亮的晚上我一点都不害怕在外面久呆。如果你愿意，我乐意为你去海伊村跑一趟，我也正好要去那里寄一封信。” “From just below; and I am not at all afraid of being out late when it is moonlight: I will run over to Hay for you with pleasure, if you wish it: indeed, I am going there to post a letter.”
“你就住在山下——你是说那个有城垛的房子吗？”他指着桑菲尔德府。灰白色的月光洒在桑菲尔德府上，使它在树林里格外的显眼苍白，但在西天的映衬下，又成了一块阴影。 “You live just below—do you mean at that house with the battlements?”pointing to Thornfield Hall, on which the moon cast a hoary gleam, bringing it out distinct and pale from the woods that, by contrast with the western sky, now seemed one mass of shadow.
“是的，先生。” “Yes, sir.”
“那是谁的房子呢？” “Whose house is it?”
“罗切斯特先生的。” “Mr. Rochester’s.”
“你认识罗切斯特先生吗？” “Do you know Mr. Rochester?”
“不认识，我从未见过他。” “No, I have never seen him.”
“这样说来，他不住那里？” “He is not resident, then?”
“嗯。” “No.”
“那你能告诉我他住在哪里吗？” “Can you tell me where he is?”
“我不知道。” “I cannot.”
“当然了，你不是府里的仆人。那么你是——”他顿住了，打量着我和往常一样朴素的穿着。一件黑色美利奴羊毛披风和一顶黑色水獭皮帽，没有哪件甚至及得上太太们贴身女仆衣服一半好。他似乎无从得知我的身份，我决定帮他一把。 “You are not a servant at the hall, of course.You are—” He stopped, ran his eye over my dress, which, as usual, was quite simple: a black merino cloak, a black beaver bonnet; neither of them half fine enough for a lady’s maid.He seemed puzzled to decide what I was; I helped him.
“我是家庭教师。” “I am the governess.”
“啊，家庭教师！”他重复了一遍。“见鬼，我怎么就把这个忘了呢！家庭教师！”然后他又打量起我的穿着。两分钟后他从台阶上站起身，刚一动，脸上就露出痛苦的表情。 “Ah, the governess!”he repeated; “deuce take me, if I had not forgotten!The governess!”and again my raiment underwent scrutiny.In two minutes he rose from the stile: his face expressed pain when he tried to move.
“我不能让你去找人帮忙，”他说道，“但你或许可以帮点小忙，如果你乐意的话。” “I cannot commission you to fetch help,” he said; “but you may help me a little yourself, if you will be so kind.”
“好的，先生。” “Yes, sir.”
“你带雨伞了吗？如果带了的话，我可以当拐杖用一下。” “You have not an umbrella that I can use as a stick?”
“我没带。” “No.”
“那你试着抓住缰绳，把马领过来。你害怕吗？” “Try to get hold of my horse’s bridle and lead him to me: you are not afraid?”
一个人的时候我是不敢碰马的，但既然他让我这么做，我也就欣然从命了。我把暖手筒放在台阶上，走向那匹马。我试着去抓缰绳，但这匹马性子很烈，不肯让我靠近它的头部。我试了又试，都以失败告终。同时我还生怕被它的前腿给踢着了。那位行人边等边看，最后笑了起来。 I should have been afraid to touch a horse when alone, but when told to do it, I was disposed to obey.I put down my muff on the stile, and went up to the tall steed; I endeavoured to catch the bridle, but it was a spirited thing, and would not let me come near its head; I made effort on effort, though in vain: meantime, I was mortally afraid of its trampling forefeet.The traveller waited and watched for some time, and at last he laughed.
“我看出来了，”他说，“大山永远不会被移到穆罕默德跟前，所以你能做的就是帮助穆罕默德走到大山跟前了。请你过来吧。” “I see,” he said, “the mountain will never be brought to Mahomet, so all you can do is to aid Mahomet to go to the mountain; I must beg of you to come here.”
我走了过去。“不好意思，”他继续说道，“只能请你帮忙了。”他把一只沉重的手搭在我肩上，极力倚着我，一瘸一拐地朝那匹马走去。他刚一抓住缰绳，马就立即被制服了。然后他跳上马鞍，用力时痛得龇牙咧嘴，因为扭伤的地方又被拉了一下。 I came.“Excuse me,” he continued: “necessity compels me to make you useful.”He laid a heavy hand on my shoulder, and leaning on me with some stress, limped to his horse.Having once caught the bridle, he mastered it directly and sprang to his saddle; grimacing grimly as he made the effort, for it wrenched his sprain.
“现在，”他松开了咬紧的下唇，说道，“把鞭子递给我吧，就在树篱下面。” “Now,” said he, releasing his under lip from a hard bite, “just hand me my whip; it lies there under the hedge.”
我找了一下，找到了。 I sought it and found it.
“谢谢你，赶紧去海伊村寄信吧，快去快回。” “Thank you; now make haste with the letter to Hay, and return as fast as you can.”
带马刺的靴跟将马一碰，马惊得竖起前腿，然后便疾驰起来。那只狗紧随其后，接着三者都不见了。 A touch of a spurred heel made his horse first start and rear, and then bound away; the dog rushed in his traces; all three vanished,
“像荒野上的石南被一阵狂风卷走了。” “Like heath that, in the wilderness, The wild wind whirls away.”
我戴上暖手筒，继续赶路。对我来说，这件事情发生了，又结束了。它既不重要，又不浪漫，也不有趣，但它标志着单调生活中有一小时发生了变化。有人需要并请求我的帮助，我也给予了帮助，能有所为总是让人高兴的。尽管这事微不足道，转瞬即逝，然而毕竟是积极的行动，我已经厌倦了所有消极的事物。这张新面孔，像一幅新画一样被收进了我的记忆长廊。这张新画又跟其他挂在那里的不同：首先，这是一位男性；其次，他又黑又壮又严厉。到达海伊村后，我将信塞进邮筒，那张脸依然停留在脑海。在我匆匆下山回家的路上，这张脸也始终萦绕在我的脑海。再次走到那台阶时，我驻留了片刻。我环顾四周并用心聆听，心想马蹄声或许会再次在小径上响起，一位披着披风的骑士和一条盖特阿什般的纽芬兰狗或许会再次出现。然而我眼前只有树篱和一棵削去树梢的柳树，直立而挺拔地伸向月光。我能听到的也只有一里外桑菲尔德府四周的树木间阵阵清风吹过。顺着清风的方向俯瞰下去，越过府邸的正面，有一扇窗户亮着光。这提醒我时辰已经不早了，我便加快了脚步。 I took up my muff and walked on.The incident had occurred and was gone for me: it WAS an incident of no moment, no romance, no interest in a sense; yet it marked with change one single hour of a monotonous life.My help had been needed and claimed; I had given it: I was pleased to have done something; trivial, transitory though the deed was, it was yet an active thing, and I was weary of an existence all passive.The new face, too, was like a new picture introduced to the gallery of memory; and it was dissimilar to all the others hanging there: firstly, because it was masculine; and, secondly, because it was dark, strong, and stern.I had it still before me when I entered Hay, and slipped the letter into the post office; I saw it as I walked fast downhill all the way home.When I came to the stile, I stopped a minute, looked round and listened, with an idea that a horse’s hoofs might ring on the causeway again, and that a rider in a cloak, and a Gytrash-like Newfoundland dog, might be again apparent: I saw only the hedge and a pollard willow before me, rising up still and straight to meet the moonbeams;I heard only the faintest waft of wind roaming fitful among the trees round Thornfield, a mile distant; and when I glanced down in the direction of the murmur, my eye, traversing the hall front, caught a light kindling in a window: it reminded me that I was late, and I hurried on.
我不想再进桑菲尔德府了。踏进门槛就好像跨入了一潭死水。穿过寂静的大厅，走上黑暗的楼梯，找到我那孤独的小房间，然后再去见安详的费尔法克斯太太，同她度过漫长的冬夜。费尔法克斯太太能做的就是彻底平息我内心被旅途所唤醒的淡淡激情——无形的牢笼使我的感官闭合，带给我单调和再宁静不过的生活。而对于这种平安轻松生活，我却已经变得无动于衷了。那时候，若能在风云不定的苦海里挣扎颠簸，若能在艰难困苦的经历中学会渴望我现在所抱怨的平静生活，那对我来说该有多大的好处！是的，这好处就像一次远足给一个厌倦整日坐在“安乐椅”上的人所能带来的乐趣；而在我当前所处的状况下，我渴望激情的心情跟安乐椅上的人渴望远足一样的天经地义。 I did not like reentering Thornfield.To pass its threshold was to return to stagnation; to cross the silent hall, to ascend the darksome staircase, to seek my own lonely little room, and then to meet tranquil Mrs. Fairfax, and spend the long winter evening with her, and her only, was to quell wholly the faint excitement wakened by my walk,—to slip again over my faculties the viewless fetters of an uniform and too still existence; of an existence whose very privileges of security and ease I was becoming incapable of appreciating.What good it would have done me at that time to have been tossed in the storms of an uncertain struggling life, and to have been taught by rough and bitter experience to long for the calm amidst which I now repined!Yes, just as much good as it would do a man tired of sitting still in a “too easy chair” to take a long walk: and just as natural was the wish to stir, under my circumstances, as it would be under his.
我在门口徘徊，在草坪上停留，在石子路上踱来踱去。玻璃门上的护窗板已经关上了，我看不到里面的情形。我的眼睛和灵魂离开了灰暗的大宅——这个在我看来不见天日、牢房般的灰色洞穴——被眼前铺展开来的苍穹所吸引——万里无云的蓝色海洋。月亮正庄严地冉冉升起。月亮离开她刚刚藏身的峰顶，远远地抛下这群山，她那圆弧好像抬头仰望并憧憬着，一心要奔赴那无边无际的黑色天空。看着追随在月亮身后的灿灿群星，我的心颤动着，热血沸腾。一些小事就能将我们唤回尘世，大厅的钟响已经足够。告别了月亮和群星，我打开一面侧门，走进府邸。 I lingered at the gates; I lingered on the lawn; I paced backwards and forwards on the pavement; the shutters of the glass door were closed; I could not see into the interior;and both my eyes and spirit seemed drawn from the gloomy house—from the grey hollow filled with rayless cells, as it appeared to me—to that sky expanded before me,—a blue sea absolved from taint of cloud; the moon ascending it in solemn march;her orb seeming to look up as she left the hilltops, from behind which she had come, far and farther below her, and aspired to the zenith, midnight dark in its fathomless depth and measureless distance; and for those trembling stars that followed her course; they made my heart tremble, my veins glow when I viewed them.Little things recall us to earth; the clock struck in the hall; that sufficed; I turned from moon and stars, opened a side door, and went in.
大厅里并不黑，唯一一盏高挂的铜灯没有点亮，然而有暖暖的灯光笼罩着大厅和橡树楼梯下面的几层台阶。这红光是从大餐厅射过来的，那边的两扇门都开着，炉火正旺，照着大理石的炉床和黄铜炉具，紫色的帷幔和闪亮的家具都罩上一层悦目的光辉。火光还照亮了壁炉架旁的一群人。在我没有看清这些人，听清那里欢快喧闹的声音之前，门就关上了。我隐约听到阿黛尔的声音似乎夹杂其中。 The hall was not dark, nor yet was it lit, only by the high hung bronze lamp; a warm glow suffused both it and the lower steps of the oak staircase.This ruddy shine issued from the great dining room, whose two leaved door stood open, and showed a genial fire in the grate, glancing on marble hearth and brass fire irons, and revealing purple draperies and polished furniture, in the most pleasant radiance.It revealed, too, a group near the mantelpiece: I had scarcely caught it, and scarcely become aware of a cheerful mingling of voices, amongst which I seemed to distinguish the tones of Adele, when the door closed.
我连忙去费尔法克斯太太的房间。那里也点着火，但却没有蜡烛，费尔法克斯太太也不在屋子里。相反，我却看到一只黑白相间、毛发很长的大狗孤零零地卧在地毯上，一脸严肃地凝望着炉火，正如路上看到的盖特阿什一样。它们太像了，于是我走过去喊了声“派洛特”，它站了起来，走上来嗅嗅我。我抚摸着它，它摇晃着大尾巴。不过单独跟它在一起，它的样子还挺吓人的，而且我也不知道这家伙哪来的。我摇了铃，想要根蜡烛，也想打听打听这位客人的来历。利厄进来了。 I hastened to Mrs. Fairfax’s room; there was a fire there too, but no candle, and no Mrs. Fairfax.Instead, all alone, sitting upright on the rug, and gazing with gravity at the blaze, I beheld a great black and white long-haired dog, just like the Gytrash of the lane.It was so like it that I went forward and said—“Pilot” and the thing got up and came to me and snuffed me.I caressed him, and he wagged his great tail; but he looked an eerie creature to be alone with, and I could not tell whence he had come.I rang the bell, for I wanted a candle; and I wanted, too, to get an account of this visitant.Leah entered.
“这只狗是哪来的啊？” “What dog is this?”
“跟主人一起来的。” “He came with master.”
“跟谁？” “With whom?”
“跟主人——罗切斯特先生——他刚到。” “With master—Mr. Rochester—he is just arrived.”
“原来如此！费尔法克斯太太现在跟他在一起吗？” “Indeed!and is Mrs. Fairfax with him?”
“是的，阿黛尔小姐也在，他们都在餐厅呢。约翰去请大夫了，因为主人发生了点意外，马摔了个跟头，把他的脚踝扭伤了。” “Yes, and Miss Adele; they are in the dining room, and John is gone for a surgeon; for master has had an accident; his horse fell and his ankle is sprained.”
“那匹马是在海伊村的小路上摔倒的吗？” “Did the horse fall in Hay Lane?”
“是的，下山的时候在冰上滑倒了。” “Yes, coming downhill; it slipped on some ice.”
“啊！利厄，帮我拿根蜡烛过来好吗？” “Ah!Bring me a candle will you Leah?”
利厄拿来了蜡烛，她的后面跟着费尔法克斯太太。费尔法克斯太太又把主人摔伤的消息重复了一遍，还说卡特大夫已经到了，现在正跟罗切斯特先生一起呢。然后她就又急忙去吩咐人上茶，我上楼去脱掉出门的衣服。 Leah brought it; she entered, followed by Mrs. Fairfax, who repeated the news; adding that Mr. Carter the surgeon was come, and was now with Mr. Rochester: then she hurried out to give orders about tea, and I went upstairs to take off my things.
第十三章 CHAPTER XIII
那天晚上，罗切斯特先生大概受医生的嘱咐，早早上床休息了。第二天早上也并没早起。他一下楼便要处理些事情，他的代理人和几位佃农来了，等着跟他谈话。 Mr. Rochester, it seems, by the surgeon’s orders, went to bed early that night; nor did he rise soon next morning.When he did come down, it was to attend to business: his agent and some of his tenants were arrived, and waiting to speak with him.
我和阿德拉现在不得不退出藏书室，把它用作接待室，天天接待访客。楼上有个房间点了炉火，我把我们的书搬到那里，整理好，那里就是我们以后的教室了。我早上发现桑菲尔德府变了样，不再是教堂般的沉寂，每隔一两个小时便能听到敲门或是打铃的回响。还时常有脚步声穿过大厅，楼下响起不同腔调的陌生声音。一条小溪从外面的世界流经桑菲尔德府，这里有了主人。对于我，也更喜欢这里了。 Adele and I had now to vacate the library: it would be in daily requisition as a reception room for callers.A fire was lit in an apartment upstairs, and there I carried our books, and arranged it for the future schoolroom.I discerned in the course of the morning that Thornfield Hall was a changed place: no longer silent as a church, it echoed every hour or two to a knock at the door, or a clang of the bell;steps, too, often traversed the hall, and new voices spoke in different keys below; a rill from the outer world was flowing through it; it had a master: for my part, I liked it better.
阿德拉那天并不好教，她无法专心，不停地跑到门口扶着栏杆张望，以求能看到罗切斯特先生一眼。然后她编造各种理由下楼去，据我敏锐的观察，不过是去藏书室，而我知道那里并不需要她。如果我有些生气，命令她静静坐着时，她就喋喋不休地说着她的“朋友，爱德华·费尔法克斯·罗切斯特先生。”她是这样称呼的（之前我并不知道他的教名），并猜想着他到底给她带了什么礼物。因为他头天晚上暗示说，行李从米尔科特运来后，会找到一个她感兴趣的小箱子。 Adele was not easy to teach that day; she could not apply: she kept running to the door and looking over the banisters to see if she could get a glimpse of Mr. Rochester; then she coined pretexts to go downstairs, in order, as I shrewdly suspected, to visit the library, where I knew she was not wanted;then, when I got a little angry, and made her sit still, she continued to talk incessantly of her “ami, Monsieur Edouard Fairfax DE Rochester,” as she dubbed him (I had not before heard his prenomens), and to conjecture what presents he had brought her:for it appears he had intimated the night before, that when his luggage came from Millcote, there would be found amongst it a little box in whose contents she had an interest.
“这就是说，里面有一件给我的礼物，也许还有给你的呢，小姐。 “Et cela doit signifier,” said she, “qu’il y aura le dedans un cadeau pour moi, et peut-etre pour vous aussi, mademoiselle.
先生问过你，问起过我家庭教师的名字，还问她是不是长得很矮小，很削瘦，而且面色苍白。我说是的，因为的确这样呀，对吗，小姐？”像往常一样，我跟我的学生在费尔法克斯太太的客厅里用餐。下午外面风雪交加，我们就一直呆在教室里。天黑时我允许阿德拉放下课本和作业跑下楼去。因为下面相对安静了些，门铃声也没响起来，我猜测罗切斯特先生此时大概有空闲了。现在只剩我一人了，我走到窗前，但什么都看不见。黄昏和雪花让空气变得厚重混沌，草坪上的灌木丛都被藏了起来。我拉下窗帘，回到炉边。 Monsieur a parle de vous: il m’a demande le nom de ma gouvernante, et si elle n’etait pas une petite personne, assez mince et un peu pale.J’ai dit qu’oui: car c’est vrai, n’est-ce pas, mademoiselle?”I and my pupil dined as usual in Mrs. Fairfax’s parlour; the afternoon was wild and snowy, and we passed it in the schoolroom.At dark I allowed Adele to put away books and work, and to run downstairs; for, from the comparative silence below, and from the cessation of appeals to the doorbell, I conjectured that Mr. Rochester was now at liberty.Left alone, I walked to the window; but nothing was to be seen thence: twilight and snowflakes together thickened the air, and hid the very shrubs on the lawn.I let down the curtain and went back to the fireside.
在明亮的余烬中，我想象着一幅场景，身处莱茵河畔的海德尔堡的城堡，这时费尔法克斯太太进来了，她的到来打破了我不停拼凑的火焰镶嵌图，也驱散了在我的孤寂中开始蔓延的恼人想法。 In the clear embers I was tracing a view, not unlike a picture I remembered to have seen of the castle of Heidelberg, on the Rhine, when Mrs. Fairfax came in, breaking up by her entrance the fiery mosaic I had been piercing together, and scattering too some heavy unwelcome thoughts that were beginning to throng on my solitude.
“罗切斯特先生会很高兴的，如果今晚你跟你的学生和他一起在休息室用茶的话。”她说，“他整天都在忙，一直没有时间见你。” “Mr. Rochester would be glad if you and your pupil would take tea with him in the drawing room this evening,” said she: “he has been so much engaged all day that he could not ask to see you before.”
“他什么时间用茶呢？”我问道。 “When is his teatime?”I inquired.
“喔，六点钟，他在乡下一直早睡早起。你最好换件衣服，我会跟你同去，帮你扣扣子。这里是蜡烛。” “Oh, at six o’clock: he keeps early hours in the country.You had better change your frock now; I will go with you and fasten it.Here is a candle.”
“有必要换衣服吗？” “Is it necessary to change my frock?”
“嗯，最好还是换吧。罗切斯特先生在的时候我每晚都换礼服。” “Yes, you had better: I always dress for the evening when Mr. Rochester is here.”
这个额外的仪式似乎有些过于正式了，但是我还是回到屋里做准备。在费尔法克斯太太的帮助下，脱掉黑色连衣裙，换上一件黑色丝裙，这是我最好的也是唯一的一件额外的衣服，除了淡灰色的那件以外。而根据我的洛伍德穿衣观念，那件灰色的太漂亮了，只有一流的场合才配得上。 This additional ceremony seemed somewhat stately; however, I repaired to my room, and, with Mrs. Fairfax’s aid, replaced my black stuff dress by one of black silk; the best and the only additional one I had, except one of light grey, which, in my Lowood notions of the toilette, I thought too fine to be worn, except on first-rate occasions.
“你需要一个胸针，”费尔法克斯太太说。我只有一个小的珍珠挂饰，那是坦普尔小姐的临别赠礼。我把它戴上，然后一起下楼了。我一向怕生，现在穿得如此正式去见罗切斯特先生，简直是个大考验。我们穿过厅堂时，我让费尔法克斯太太走在前面，我在她身后的阴影中，穿过拉下帷幔的拱门，进入另一头雅致的套间。 “You want a brooch,” said Mrs. Fairfax.I had a single little pearl ornament which Miss Temple gave me as a parting keepsake: I put it on, and then we went downstairs.Unused as I was to strangers, it was rather a trial to appear thus formally summoned in Mr. Rochester’s presence.I let Mrs. Fairfax precede me into the dining room, and kept in her shade as we crossed that apartment; and, passing the arch, whose curtain was now dropped, entered the elegant recess beyond.
两支蜡烛立在桌上，还有两支在壁炉架上，派洛特在熊熊炉火的光和热里卧着——阿德拉跪在它旁边。罗切斯特先生半靠在沙发上，一只脚撑在地毯上。他注视着阿德拉和派洛特，炉火映射着他的整个脸庞。我认识这位旅人，长着浓浓的粗眉，方正的额头在横梳的黑发映衬下更显得方了。我认出了他坚毅的鼻子，与其说漂亮，不如说更突显个性；他的大鼻孔，我想表明他易怒；他严酷的嘴唇、下巴和下颚——对，这三者都十分严厉，一点儿都不错。他脱去了披风，身材在我看来与其方方正正的长相很相称，我想这就是体育术语中说的好身材吧——胸宽腰细，虽然他不高大也不优雅。 Two wax candles stood lighted on the table, and two on the mantelpiece; basking in the light and heat of a superb fire, lay Pilot—Adele knelt near him.Half reclined on a couch appeared Mr. Rochester, his foot supported by the cushion; he was looking at Adele and the dog: the fire shone full on his face.I knew my traveller with his broad and jetty eyebrows; his square forehead, made squarer by the horizontal sweep of his black hair.I recognised his decisive nose, more remarkable for character than beauty; his full nostrils, denoting, I thought, choler; his grim mouth, chin, and jaw—yes, all three were very grim, and no mistake.His shape, now divested of cloak, I perceived harmonised in squareness with his physiognomy: I suppose it was a good figure in the athletic sense of the term—broad chested and thin flanked, though neither tall nor graceful.
罗切斯特先生一定注意到我和费尔法克斯太太的到来，但是他看起来完全不想理会我们，因为我们进来时他一直没有抬起头来。 Mr. Rochester must have been aware of the entrance of Mrs. Fairfax and myself; but it appeared he was not in the mood to notice us, for he never lifted his head as we approached.
“这是爱小姐，先生。”费尔法克斯太太平静地说道。他点了点头，还是没有把眼神从狗和孩子身上移开。 “Here is Miss Eyre, sir,” said Mrs. Fairfax, in her quiet way.He bowed, still not taking his eyes from the group of the dog and child.
“让爱小姐坐下吧。”他说。我想这勉强生硬的点头，不耐烦但是正式的语调里有些画外音，好像要说：“爱小姐在不在这儿跟我何干呢？现在我可不想跟她打招呼。” “Let Miss Eyre be seated,” said he: and there was something in the forced stiff bow, in the impatient yet formal tone, which seemed further to express, “What the deuce is it to me whether Miss Eyre be there or not?At this moment I am not disposed to accost her.”
我毫不尴尬地坐下了。恭恭敬敬地接待反而会让我不安，因为无法温文尔雅地回应对方。但是粗鲁任性则让我没有拘束，相反，这种古怪举止下合乎礼仪的沉默，反倒给了我优势。这种怪异的做法也很刺激，我饶有兴趣地看他如何继续。 I sat down quite disembarrassed.A reception of finished politeness would probably have confused me: I could not have returned or repaid it by answering grace and elegance on my part; but harsh caprice laid me under no obligation; on the contrary, a decent quiescence, under the freak of manner, gave me the advantage.Besides, the eccentricity of the proceeding was piquant: I felt interested to see how he would go on.
他继续像雕塑一样，既不说话也不动弹。费尔法克斯太太似乎觉得应该有人表示一下友好，于是开始讲话。还是那样慈祥，还是那老一套——先是对他一天的操劳表示慰问，说他的扭伤一定很痛，然后赞叹他对疼痛的忍耐力和毅力。 He went on as a statue would, that is, he neither spoke nor moved.Mrs. Fairfax seemed to think it necessary that some one should be amiable, and she began to talk.Kindly, as usual—and, as usual, rather trite—she condoled with him on the pressure of business he had had all day; on the annoyance it must have been to him with that painful sprain: then she commended his patience and perseverance in going through with it.
“太太，我想喝点茶。”这是对她唯一的回答。她赶忙去打铃，托盘上来后，她开始布置茶杯、汤匙等等，殷勤利落。我跟阿德拉来到桌前，但是主人还是没有离开沙发。 “Madam, I should like some tea,” was the sole rejoinder she got.She hastened to ring the bell; and when the tray came, she proceeded to arrange the cups, spoons, &c., with assiduous celerity.I and Adele went to the table; but the master did not leave his couch.
“能把茶杯递给罗切斯特先生吗？”费尔法克斯太太对我说，“阿德拉没准儿会弄洒。” “Will you hand Mr. Rochester’s cup?” said Mrs. Fairfax to me; “Adele might perhaps spill it.”
我照办了。当他从我的手中接过杯子，阿德拉认为这是为我争取要求的好时机，于是喊道—— I did as requested.As he took the cup from my hand, Adele, thinking the moment propitious for making a request in my favour, cried out—
“先生，你的小箱子里不是有件礼物要送给爱小姐吗？” “N’est-ce pas, monsieur, qu’il y a un cadeau pour Mademoiselle Eyre dans votre petit coffre?”
“谁提起礼物的？”他冷冰冰地回道，“你期待礼物吗，爱小姐？你喜欢礼物吗？”他打量着我的脸庞，目光阴暗、恼怒、刺人。 “Who talks of cadeaux?” said he gruffly.“Did you expect a present, Miss Eyre?Are you fond of presents?” and he searched my face with eyes that I saw were dark, irate, and piercing.
“我不知道，先生，我对礼物没什么经验，通常大家都会喜欢礼物的吧。” “I hardly know, sir; I have little experience of them: they are generally thought pleasant things.”
“通常都会？但是你怎么想的呢？” “Generally thought?But what do YOU think?”
“我想我不得不花点时间，先生，想出一个您满意的答案。礼物有很多方面，对不对？在宣布对礼物性质的看法前，必须要全盘考虑。” “I should be obliged to take time, sir, before I could give you an answer worthy of your acceptance: a present has many faces to it, has it not?and one should consider all, before pronouncing an opinion as to its nature.”
“爱小姐，你不像阿德拉那样直率，她一见到我就大声喊着想要礼物，而你却拐弯抹角。” “Miss Eyre, you are not so unsophisticated as Adele: she demands a ‘cadeau,’ clamorously, the moment she sees me: you beat about the bush.”
“因为我不如阿德拉那么有信心会得到礼物。她可以向她的老朋友提出要求，而且这也是惯例，因为她说你总是送她各种玩具。而若非要我证明会收到礼物，我则有些迷惑了，因为我是个陌生人，所谓无功不受禄。” “Because I have less confidence in my deserts than Adele has: she can prefer the claim of old acquaintance, and the right too of custom; for she says you have always been in the habit of giving her playthings; but if I had to make out a case I should be puzzled, since I am a stranger, and have done nothing to entitle me to an acknowledgment.”
“哦，不要让谦虚来帮忙！我考过阿德拉，发现你在她身上下了不少功夫，她并不聪明，也没什么天赋，但是在这么短的时间里却进步颇大。” “Oh, don’t fall back on over modesty!I have examined Adele, and find you have taken great pains with her: she is not bright, she has no talents; yet in a short time she has made much improvement.”
“先生，您现在已经给了我‘礼物’，非常感谢您。这正是老师最期待的东西——自己学生的进步得到夸奖。” “Sir, you have now given me my ‘cadeau;’ I am obliged to you: it is the meed teachers most covet—praise of their pupils’ progress.”
“哼！”罗切先生哼了一声，默默喝茶。 “Humph!” said Mr. Rochester, and he took his tea in silence.
“来炉边坐吧。”主人说道，托盘已被拿走，费尔法克斯太太拿着针线活儿去角落里，阿德拉正拉着我满屋子转，给我看蜗脚桌和书柜里包装精美的书籍和装饰。主人的命令我们就得服从，我们坐过去了。阿德拉想坐在我腿上，却被打发去跟派洛特玩了。 “Come to the fire,” said the master, when the tray was taken away, and Mrs. Fairfax had settled into a corner with her knitting; while Adele was leading me by the hand round the room, showing me the beautiful books and ornaments on the consoles and chiffonnieres.We obeyed, as in duty bound; Adele wanted to take a seat on my knee, but she was ordered to amuse herself with Pilot.
“你在我家里住了三个月了？” “You have been resident in my house three months?”
“是的，先生。” “Yes, sir.”
“你来自——？” “And you came from—?”
“洛伍德学院，某郡。” “From Lowood school, in-shire.”
“哦！一所慈善学校。你在那里呆了多久？” “Ah! a charitable concern.How long were you there?”
“八年。” “Eight years.”
“八年！你的生命力一定极其顽强。我还以为在那种地方只要一半的时间就足以摧毁任何事物了！难怪你神情好像来自另一个世界。我本还惊叹你这张脸来自何方。昨晚在海村道上你向我走来时，我不禁想到了童话故事，还寻思要问你是不是对我的马施了咒语，现在也不甚确定呢。你父母是谁？” “Eight years! you must be tenacious of life.I thought half the time in such a place would have done up any constitution!No wonder you have rather the look of another world.I marvelled where you had got that sort of face.When you came on me in Hay Lane last night, I thought unaccountably of fairy tales, and had half a mind to demand whether you had bewitched my horse: I am not sure yet.Who are your parents?”
“我没有父母。” “I have none.”
“从没有过，我猜。你还记不记得他们？” “Nor ever had, I suppose: do you remember them?”
“不记得。” “No.”
“我想也记不得了。所以你是坐在台阶上等人咯？” “I thought not.And so you were waiting for your people when you sat on that stile?”
“等谁，先生？” “For whom, sir?”
“等绿衣仙人，有月亮的夜晚对他们再适合不过了。是不是我打破了你们的舞圈，你才把该死的冰块放在路上？” “For the men in green: it was a proper moonlight evening for them.Did I break through one of your rings, that you spread that damned ice on the causeway?”
我摇头。“绿衣仙人在一百多年前就抛弃了英格兰，”我同样一本正经地说道，“就是海村道上，或是周围的地方，你都不可能发现他们的踪迹。我想无论夏天、秋天还是冬天，月亮都不会再照到他们狂欢的影子。” I shook my head.“The men in green all forsook England a hundred years ago,” said I, speaking as seriously as he had done.“And not even in Hay Lane, or the fields about it, could you find a trace of them.I don’t think either summer or harvest, or winter moon, will ever shine on their revels more.”
费尔法克斯太太放下针线活，皱起眉头，似乎在纳闷这是什么对话。 Mrs. Fairfax had dropped her knitting, and, with raised eyebrows, seemed wondering what sort of talk this was.
“好吧，”罗切斯特先生接着说，“若你没有父母，那一定有亲戚吧，叔叔婶婶之类？” “Well,” resumed Mr. Rochester, “if you disown parents, you must have some sort of kinsfolk: uncles and aunts?”
“不，我一个也没见过。” “No; none that I ever saw.”
“那你的家呢？” “And your home?”
“我没有家。” “I have none.”
“你的兄弟姐妹住在哪里？” “Where do your brothers and sisters live?”
“我没有兄弟姐妹。” “I have no brothers or sisters.”
“谁推荐你到这里来的？” “Who recommended you to come here?”
“我发了广告，费尔法克斯太太给了我回复。” “I advertised, and Mrs. Fairfax answered my advertisement.”
“是的，”慈祥的太太说道，她现在终于知道我们在谈什么了，“我感谢主让我做了这个选择。爱小姐是我难能可贵的伙伴，也是阿德拉和蔼认真的老师。” “Yes,” said the good lady, who now knew what ground we were upon, “and I am daily thankful for the choice Providence led me to make.Miss Eyre has been an invaluable companion to me, and a kind and careful teacher to Adele.”
“别忙着夸她了，”罗切斯特先生回道，“赞扬是不会影响我的，我有自己的判断。她先是让我的马摔了跟头。” “Don’t trouble yourself to give her a character,” returned Mr. Rochester: “eulogiums will not bias me; I shall judge for myself.She began by felling my horse.”
“先生？”费尔法克斯太太说道。 “Sir?” said Mrs. Fairfax.
“这扭伤我得谢谢她。” “I have to thank her for this sprain.”
这位寡妇甚为不解。 The widow looked bewildered.
“爱小姐，你在城里住过吗？” “Miss Eyre, have you ever lived in a town?”
“没有，先生。” “No, sir.”
“与人交往多吗？” “Have you seen much society?”
“只有洛伍德的学生和老师，现在便是桑菲尔德府的人们。” “None but the pupils and teachers of Lowood, and now the inmates of Thornfield.”
“你读书多吗？” “Have you read much?”
“碰到什么书就读什么书，数量不多，学的也不深。” “Only such books as came in my way; and they have not been numerous or very learned.”
“你过着修女的生活，不用说，宗教方面肯定受过严格训练，——布罗克赫斯特，我知道他掌管洛伍德，是位牧师吧？” “You have lived the life of a nun: no doubt you are well drilled in religious forms;—Brocklehurst, who I understand directs Lowood, is a parson, is he not?”
“是的，先生。” “Yes, sir.”
“你们女孩子应该很崇拜他吧，就像修道院的修女总会崇拜她们的院长。” “And you girls probably worshipped him, as a convent full of religieuses would worship their director.”
“哦，不。” “Oh, no.”
“你很冷静啊！不！什么！见习修女竟不崇拜她的牧师！这听起来有些亵渎神灵。” “You are very cool!No!What! a novice not worship her priest!That sounds blasphemous.”
“我不喜欢布罗克赫斯特先生，也不是只有我一个人这样感觉。他十分冷酷，又自以为是，爱管闲事。他剪掉我们的头发，为了省钱，还买坏的针线给我们，根本没法用。” “I disliked Mr. Brocklehurst; and I was not alone in the feeling.He is a harsh man; at once pompous and meddling; he cut off our hair; and for economy’s sake bought us bad needles and thread, with which we could hardly sew.”
“这样省钱很划不来。”费尔法克斯太太评价道，她现在又跟上了我们的谈话。 “That was very false economy,” remarked Mrs. Fairfax, who now again caught the drift of the dialogue.
“这就是他的首要罪状吗？”罗切斯特先生问道。 “And was that the head and front of his offending?” demanded Mr. Rochester.
“在委员会任命之前，他全权负责伙食供应，总是让我们饿肚子。每周都让我们忍受他冗长的说教，还要每晚读他自己写的书，都是关于猝死和审判的东西，吓得我们都不敢睡觉。” “He starved us when he had the sole superintendence of the provision department, before the committee was appointed; and he bored us with long lectures once a week, and with evening readings from books of his own inditing, about sudden deaths and judgments, which made us afraid to go to bed.”
“你去洛伍德的时候几岁？” “What age were you when you went to Lowood?”
“大约十岁。” “About ten.”
“你在那里呆了八年，那么你现在十八岁了？” “And you stayed there eight years: you are now, then, eighteen?”
我表示同意。 I assented.
“你看，算术是很有用的，没有它的帮助，我很难猜出你的年龄。对你这样五官和神情不相称的人来说，要推断年龄是很困难的。你在洛伍德都学了些什么？会弹钢琴吗？” “Arithmetic, you see, is useful; without its aid, I should hardly have been able to guess your age.It is a point difficult to fix where the features and countenance are so much at variance as in your case.And now what did you learn at Lowood?Can you play?”
“一点点。” “A little.”
“当然，大家都这么回答。到藏书室吧——我是说，要是你乐意的话。——（请原谅我命令的语气，我一向都说，‘这么做’，然后就有人做了。对于新人我也没办法改掉这老习惯。）——那么，去吧，去藏书室，拿着蜡烛，门开着就好，坐在钢琴前，弹首曲子吧。” “Of course: that is the established answer.Go into the library—I mean, if you please.—(Excuse my tone of command; I am used to say, ‘Do this,’ and it is done: I cannot alter my customary habits for one new inmate.)—Go, then, into the library; take a candle with you; leave the door open; sit down to the piano, and play a tune.”
我离开了，按照他的指示。 I departed, obeying his directions.
“可以了！”几分钟后他喊道。“你果然会一点，我明白了，跟其他英国女学生一样，也许比某些人强，但并不好。” “Enough!” he called out in a few minutes.“You play A LITTLE, I see; like any other English schoolgirl; perhaps rather better than some, but not well.”
我合上钢琴回来了。罗切斯特先生继续说道——“阿德拉今天早上让我看了几幅素描，她说是你画的。我不知道是否全部出自你手，可能有老师帮过你？” I closed the piano and returned.Mr. Rochester continued—“Adele showed me some sketches this morning, which she said were yours.I don’t know whether they were entirely of your doing; probably a master aided you?”
“不，的确没有！”我突然插嘴。 “No, indeed!”I interjected.
“哦！刺伤了自尊。好吧，去拿你的画夹来，如果你能证明里面都是你自己画的。但是不能确定就别乱保证，我可认得出那些拼凑的东西。” “Ah! that pricks pride.Well, fetch me your portfolio, if you can vouch for its contents being original; but don’t pass your word unless you are certain: I can recognise patchwork.”
“那我无话可说，您可以自己判断，先生。” “Then I will say nothing, and you shall judge for yourself, sir.”
我从藏书室拿画夹过来。 I brought the portfolio from the library.
“把桌子移过来。”他说道，我把桌子移到他的沙发前。阿德拉和费尔法克斯太太也凑过来看。 “Approach the table,” said he; and I wheeled it to his couch.Adele and Mrs. Fairfax drew near to see the pictures.
“别挤，”罗切斯特先生说道，“等我看完再从我手里接过去，但不要把脸往我这凑。” “No crowding,” said Mr. Rochester: “take the drawings from my hand as I finish with them; but don’t push your faces up to mine.”
他仔细看完每一张素描和油画。有三张放到了一边，其余的看完就推开了。 He deliberately scrutinised each sketch and painting.Three he laid aside; the others, when he had examined them, he swept from him.
“把这几张拿到另外一张桌子上，费尔法克斯太太，”他说道，“跟阿德拉一起看吧，——你”（他扫了我一眼）“回位子上坐吧，回答我的问题。我相信这些画出自同一个人的手，是你的吗？” “Take them off to the other table, Mrs. Fairfax,” said he, “and look at them with Adele;—you” (glancing at me) “resume your seat, and answer my questions.I perceive those pictures were done by one hand: was that hand yours?”
“是的。” “Yes.”
“你哪来的时间画的呢？这需要很多时间，需要一些思考。” “And when did you find time to do them?They have taken much time, and some thought.”
“这是我在洛伍德度过的最后两个假期里画的，那时我没有其他事情忙。” “I did them in the last two vacations I spent at Lowood, when I had no other occupation.”
“哪来的摹本呢？” “Where did you get your copies?”
“从我自己脑子里。” “Out of my head.”
“就是你肩膀上的这个脑袋？” “That head I see now on your shoulders?”
“是的，先生。” “Yes, sir.”
“里面还有别的类似的东西吗？” “Has it other furniture of the same kind within?”
“我想是有的，我希望——还有更好的。” “I should think it may have: I should hope—better.”
他把面前的几幅画铺开，又开始一张张地细看。 He spread the pictures before him, and again surveyed them alternately.
趁着他忙，我想告诉你，读者呵，都画了些什么。首先，我要说他们没什么了不起的。题材的确都活生生地在脑海中升起。在画之前，它们都是我的心灵之眼的所见，超凡脱俗。但是手却不随人愿，每一张画出来的都是自己思绪苍白的写照。 While he is so occupied, I will tell you, reader, what they are: and first, I must premise that they are nothing wonderful.The subjects had, indeed, risen vividly on my mind.As I saw them with the spiritual eye, before I attempted to embody them, they were striking; but my hand would not second my fancy, and in each case it had wrought out but a pale portrait of the thing I had conceived.
这些都是水彩画。第一张是乌云低沉，在汹涌澎湃的大海上翻滚着，所有的远景和近景都暗淡无光，或者说最前面的巨浪是如此，因为画中没有陆地。一线光芒照亮了半落的桅杆，上面有只鸬鹚在栖息，又大又黑，双翼上缀满泡沫，嘴里叼着一只镶嵌着宝石的金手镯。这是我用调色板上最鲜艳的颜色画成的，并尽可能用画笔勾画得清晰夺目。在鸬鹚和桅杆之下的绿色海水里，沉着一具溺水的尸体，只有美丽的胳膊清晰可见，金手镯就是从这只手上冲掉或叼走的。 These pictures were in water-colours.The first represented clouds low and livid, rolling over a swollen sea: all the distance was in eclipse; so, too, was the foreground; or rather, the nearest billows, for there was no land.One gleam of light lifted into relief a half submerged mast, on which sat a cormorant, dark and large, with wings flecked with foam; its beak held a gold bracelet set with gems, that I had touched with as brilliant tints as my palette could yield, and as glittering distinctness as my pencil could impart.Sinking below the bird and mast, a drowned corpse glanced through the green water; a fair arm was the only limb clearly visible, whence the bracelet had been washed or torn.
第二幅画的前景只有一座昏暗的山峰，青草树叶好像被微风吹斜。如暮色时刻般深蓝的天空在远处和头顶铺展开，一个女人的半身像向天际升起，我尽量调成幽暗柔和的色调。朦胧的前额的皇冠上有一颗星，下面的轮廓好像穿过一阵雾气。她眼眸乌黑明亮而狂野，头发阴影般飘散，就像无光的云朵，被暴风雨或闪电撕裂。脖子上有一抹月光般的苍白的反光，相同的淡淡光亮点缀着单薄的云彩，从那里升起这位垂着头的晚星美人。 The second picture contained for foreground only the dim peak of a hill, with grass and some leaves slanting as if by a breeze.Beyond and above spread an expanse of sky, dark blue as at twilight: rising into the sky was a woman’s shape to the bust, portrayed in tints as dusk and soft as I could combine.The dim forehead was crowned with a star; the lineaments below were seen as through the suffusion of vapour; the eyes shone dark and wild; the hair streamed shadowy, like a beamless cloud torn by storm or by electric travail.On the neck lay a pale reflection like moonlight; the same faint lustre touched the train of thin clouds from which rose and bowed this vision of the Evening Star.
第三幅画是冰山一隅，直冲冬日天空的极点，一簇北极光举起它们昏暗的长矛，在地平线密密麻麻地排列着。将这些抛远，前景中又升起一个头颅——巨大无比，像冰山倾斜，靠在了上面。一双瘦削的手，在前额下面支撑着它，拉着一块黑色面纱，遮住下半部的脸庞。毫无血色的额头，如白骨一般，只见一双空洞的眼睛，目光呆滞而绝望。双鬓上面，黑色缠头的褶皱缝隙中，依稀可见一道白光在迷雾间闪现，镶嵌着红彤彤的火花。这道新月形的白光就是“王冠的象征”，戴王冠的便是“无形的形体”。 The third showed the pinnacle of an iceberg piercing a polar winter sky: a muster of northern lights reared their dim lances, close serried, along the horizon.Throwing these into distance, rose, in the foreground, a head,—a colossal head, inclined towards the iceberg, and resting against it.Two thin hands, joined under the forehead, and supporting it, drew up before the lower features a sable veil, a brow quite bloodless, white as bone, and an eye hollow and fixed, blank of meaning but for the glassiness of despair, alone were visible.Above the temples, amidst wreathed turban folds of black drapery, vague in its character and consistency as cloud, gleamed a ring of white flame, gemmed with sparkles of a more lurid tinge.This pale crescent was “the likeness of a kingly crown;” what it diademed was “the shape which shape had none.”
“你画这些的时候开心吗？”罗切斯特先生随即问道。 “Were you happy when you painted these pictures?” asked Mr. Rochester presently.
“我很投入，先生。是的，十分开心。简单说，画画的时光对我来说是最大的享受。” “I was absorbed, sir: yes, and I was happy.To paint them, in short, was to enjoy one of the keenest pleasures I have ever known.”
“这并不能说明什么。你的乐趣，据你自己的描述，本来就很少。但是我敢说你在调制这些奇怪的色彩时，一定沉浸在艺术家的梦里。你每天都坐着画很久吗？” “That is not saying much.Your pleasures, by your own account, have been few; but I dare say you did exist in a kind of artist’s dreamland while you blent and arranged these strange tints.Did you sit at them long each day?”
“放假了，我也没有其他事情做。便从早上坐到中午，从中午坐到晚上，仲夏白昼很长，刚好可以利用。” “I had nothing else to do, because it was the vacation, and I sat at them from morning till noon, and from noon till night: the length of the midsummer days favoured my inclination to apply.”
“你对自己热切劳动的成果满意吗？” “And you felt self-satisfied with the result of your ardent labours?”
“很不满意。我为我的构思和作品之间的反差感到痛苦，每次我想像的一些东西都无力表达出来。” “Far from it.I was tormented by the contrast between my idea and my handiwork: in each case I had imagined something which I was quite powerless to realise.”
“也不尽然，你已经画出了你思想的影子。也许也只能如此。你没有艺术家的技巧和学识来充分表达你的思想，但是对于女学生而言，这些已经不同凡响了。至于想法，有些恶作剧。这双晚星的眼睛你一定在梦里见过吧。你怎么可以刻画得如此清晰却毫不耀眼？因为额上的星星淹没了它们的光芒。这深沉的目光有什么涵义呢？还有谁教你画风的？那片天空刮着大风，拂过山尖。你在哪见过拉莫斯山的？因为那就是拉莫斯山。好啦！把这些画收起来吧！” “Not quite: you have secured the shadow of your thought; but no more, probably.You had not enough of the artist’s skill and science to give it full being: yet the drawings are, for a schoolgirl, peculiar.As to the thoughts, they are elfish.These eyes in the Evening Star you must have seen in a dream.How could you make them look so clear, and yet not at all brilliant? for the planet above quells their rays.And what meaning is that in their solemn depth?And who taught you to paint wind.There is a high gale in that sky, and on this hilltop.Where did you see Latmos?For that is Latmos.There! put the drawings away!”
还没等我把画夹的绳子系好，他看了看表，突然说道—— I had scarce tied the strings of the portfolioo, when, looking at his watch, he said abruptly—
“已经九点了，你还在这干什么，爱小姐，让阿德拉呆到这么晚？带她去睡觉。” “It is nine o’clock: what are you about, Miss Eyre, to let Adele sit up so long?Take her to bed.”
阿德拉离开之前走过去亲他，他接受了这种亲吻，但却不比派洛特更欣赏它，或者说还不如派洛特呢。 Adele went to kiss him before quitting the room: he endured the caress, but scarcely seemed to relish it more than Pilot would have done, nor so much.
“大家晚安。”他说，手朝门口方向一挥，表示他已经厌倦了我们的陪伴，想打发我们走。费尔法克斯太太收拾好针线活儿，我拿起画夹，我们向他行屈膝礼，他僵硬地点头回礼，然后我们就这样退下了。 “I wish you all goodnight, now,” said he, making a movement of the hand towards the door, in token that he was tired of our company, and wished to dismiss us.Mrs. Fairfax folded up her knitting: I took my portfolio: we curtseyed to him, received a frigid bow in return, and so withdrew.
“你说罗切斯特先生并不十分乖僻，费尔法克斯太太。”这时我已经送阿德拉上床睡觉，又折回她的房间。 “You said Mr. Rochester was not strikingly peculiar, Mrs. Fairfax,” I observed, when I rejoined her in her room, after putting Adele to bed.
“好吧，他奇怪吗？” “Well, is he?”
“我想是的，他变化莫测，粗鲁无礼。” “I think so: he is very changeful and abrupt.”
“的确如此，对于陌生人是这样的，但是我已经习惯了他的这种态度，从来不会多想。而且，他脾气古怪也情有可原。” “True: no doubt he may appear so to a stranger, but I am so accustomed to his manner, I never think of it; and then, if he has peculiarities of temper, allowance should be made.”
“为什么？” “Why?”
“一部分是因为他天性如此——天性难移，我们皆如此。还有一部分是因为他有心事烦着，毫无疑问，很多事情让他不得安宁。” “Partly because it is his nature—and we can none of us help our nature; and partly because he has painful thoughts, no doubt, to harass him, and make his spirits unequal.”
“什么事呢？” “What about?”
“家庭琐事就是之一。” “Family troubles, for one thing.”
“但是他没有家人啊。” “But he has no family.”
“现在没有，但是他曾经有过——至少，有些亲戚。几年前他失去了哥哥。” “Not now, but he has had—or, at least, relatives.He lost his elder brother a few years since.”
“他的哥哥？” “His ELDER brother?”
“是的。现在的罗切斯特先生继承遗产并不久，只有九年。” “Yes.The present Mr. Rochester has not been very long in possession of the property; only about nine years.”
“九年时间够长了。他这么爱他的哥哥，现在还无法抹平失去他的悲伤啊？” “Nine years is a tolerable time.Was he so very fond of his brother as to be still inconsolable for his loss?”
“啊，不——也许不是。我相信他们之间有些误会。罗兰·罗切斯特先生对爱德华先生不大公平，并且还使他父亲对他有偏见。那位老绅士很爱钱，一心想保存家产完整。他不想分家，但又要让爱德华先生也有一份家产好保存家族的名声。在他刚成年不久，他们就采取了一些不公平的手段，结果造成了很大的麻烦。老罗切斯特先生和罗兰先生联手将爱德华先生置于了很痛苦的境地，目的是为了帮他赚一笔钱，到底是怎么回事我也不知道，但是他的精神无法承受那种折磨。他不肯原谅他们，与家人决裂，这么多年一直漂泊不定。我想他从没在桑菲尔德府住上过两周，他哥哥死前没有遗嘱，于是他成了房产的主人，也难怪他现在老躲开这个老家。” “Why, no—perhaps not.I believe there were some misunderstandings between them.Mr. Rowland Rochester was not quite just to Mr. Edward; and perhaps he prejudiced his father against him.The old gentleman was fond of money, and anxious to keep the family estate together.He did not like to diminish the property by division, and yet he was anxious that Mr. Edward should have wealth, too, to keep up the consequence of the name; and, soon after he was of age, some steps were taken that were not quite fair, and made a great deal of mischief.Old Mr. Rochester and Mr. Rowland combined to bring Mr. Edward into what he considered a painful position, for the sake of making his fortune: what the precise nature of that position was I never clearly knew, but his spirit could not brook what he had to suffer in it.He is not very forgiving: he broke with his family, and now for many years he has led an unsettled kind of life.I don’t think he has ever been resident at Thornfield for a fortnight together, since the death of his brother without a will left him master of the estate; and, indeed, no wonder he shuns the old place.”
“他为什么要躲着呢？” “Why should he shun it?”
“也许他觉得太压抑了。” “Perhaps he thinks it gloomy.”
这个回答含糊其辞。我想要更明确的答案，但是费尔法克斯太太不能，或是不想告诉我有关罗切斯特先生苦难的起源和性质更明确的信息。她说这对她是个谜，她知道的也不过是自己的推测。显然，她想让我放下这个话题，我也就不再多问。 The answer was evasive.I should have liked something clearer; but Mrs. Fairfax either could not, or would not, give me more explicit information of the origin and nature of Mr. Rochester’s trials.She averred they were a mystery to herself, and that what she knew was chiefly from conjecture.It was evident, indeed, that she wished me to drop the subject, which I did accordingly.
第十四章 CHAPTER XIV
接连着好几天，我都没怎么见到罗切斯特先生。早上他似乎都公务缠身，下午则有米尔科特或附近的先生们来访，有时他们还会留下来与他共进晚餐。伤势恢复到可以骑马时，他便常常骑马外出，大约是回访，因为往往要到深夜才回来。 For several subsequent days I saw little of Mr. Rochester.In the mornings he seemed much engaged with business, and, in the afternoon, gentlemen from Millcote or the neighbourhood called, and sometimes stayed to dine with him.When his sprain was well enough to admit of horse exercise, he rode out a good deal; probably to return these visits, as he generally did not come back till late at night.
在此期间，就连阿德拉也极少被叫到他面前。而我同他的所有接触，也仅限于在大厅里、楼梯上或走廊上的偶然相遇。他有时高傲冷漠地从我身边走过，仅远远地微微点头或冷冷一瞥，而有时却极具绅士风度，亲切地鞠躬或微笑。他情绪的变化无常并没有让我不愉快，因为我知道这与我无关。情绪的高涨或低落都源于与我丝毫无关的原因。 During this interval, even Adele was seldom sent for to his presence, and all my acquaintance with him was confined to an occasional rencontre in the hall, on the stairs, or in the gallery, when he would sometimes pass me haughtily and coldly, just acknowledging my presence by a distant nod or a cool glance, and sometimes bow and smile with gentlemanlike affability.His changes of mood did not offend me, because I saw that I had nothing to do with their alternation; the ebb and flow depended on causes quite disconnected with me.
有一天，他有客人来吃饭，便差人取来我的画夹。毫无疑问，他是要向别人展示里面的画。先生们走得很早，费尔法克斯太太告诉我，他们是要去米尔科特参加一个公众集会。但由于当晚有雨，天气恶劣，罗切斯特先生便没有同行。客人刚走，他便摇铃，传话让我和阿德拉下楼。我给阿德拉梳好头发，打扮整齐，确认自己象往常一样，如贵格教徒一样整齐规矩，无须修饰——一切都合身朴素，包括编成辫子的头发，没有一丝凌乱的痕迹——我们便下楼去了。阿德拉猜想着是不是自己的小箱子终于到了。因为不知哪里出了差错，那个小箱子一直迟迟未到。我们一走进餐厅，便看到餐桌上摆了一个小纸箱，她满意了。她好像直觉早就知道一般。 One day he had had company to dinner, and had sent for my portfolio; in order, doubtless, to exhibit its contents: the gentlemen went away early, to attend a public meeting at Millcote, as Mrs. Fairfax informed me; but the night being wet and inclement, Mr. Rochester did not accompany them.Soon after they were gone he rang the bell: a message came that I and Adele were to go downstairs.I brushed Adele’s hair and made her neat, and having ascertained that I was myself in my usual Quaker trim, where there was nothing to retouch—all being too close and plain, braided locks included, to admit of disarrangement—we descended, Adele wondering whether the petit coffre was at length come; for, owing to some mistake, its arrival had hitherto been delayed.She was gratified: there it stood, a little carton, on the table when we entered the dining room.She appeared to know it by instinct.
“我的盒子！我的盒子！”她大嚷着朝它跑去。 “Ma boite!ma boite!”exclaimed she, running towards it.
“是啊，你的小箱子终于来了。拿去一边吧，你这个地道的巴黎女儿，掏出里面的东西玩去吧。”罗切斯特先生的声音从壁炉旁一个巨大的安乐椅的深处传来，声音低沉而颇含讽刺。“记住，”他接着说，“别拿解剖过程的细枝末节来烦我，也不需要向我报告内脏的情况，自己安安静静地做手术，安静点，懂了吗，孩子？” “Yes, there is your ‘boite’ at last: take it into a corner, you genuine daughter of Paris, and amuse yourself with disembowelling it,” said the deep and rather sarcastic voice of Mr. Rochester, proceeding from the depths of an immense easy chair at the fireside.“And mind,” he continued, “don’t bother me with any details of the anatomical process, or any notice of the condition of the entrails: let your operation be conducted in silence: tiens-toi tranquille, enfant; comprends-tu?”
阿德拉似乎并不需要提醒，她早就抱着自己的宝贝躲在沙发里，忙着解开系在盒盖上的绳子。解除这个障碍，拿掉银色包装纸，她几乎大叫出来—— Adele seemed scarcely to need the warning—she had already retired to a sofa with her treasure, and was busy untying the cord which secured the lid.Having removed this impediment, and lifted certain silvery envelopes of tissue paper, she merely exclaimed—
“哦，天啊！这太漂亮了！”然后便继续沉醉在兴奋中。 “Oh ciel!Que c’est beau!” and then remained absorbed in ecstatic contemplation.
“爱小姐来了吗？”主人现在发话了，说着欠起身子，朝门边打量，我就站在那里。 “Is Miss Eyre there?” now demanded the master, half rising from his seat to look round to the door, near which I still stood.
“哦，好的，过来，这边坐。”他拉过身旁的一把椅子。“我可不喜欢小孩的叽叽喳喳，”他接着说道，“我这样的老单身汉对他们的叽叽喳喳可没什么兴趣。若是让我整晚跟个小鬼面对面，我可受不了。别把椅子挪远了啊，爱小姐。就坐在我放的地方——当然，如果你愿意的话。该死的礼仪！我总是忘记。我也不怎么喜欢头脑简单的老妇人。顺便说一句，我可不能忘了我的那一位。她可怠慢不得。她是费尔法克斯家族的一员，或者说嫁了这个家族的成员，不都说血浓于水嘛。” “Ah! well, come forward; be seated here.”He drew a chair near his own.“I am not fond of the prattle of children,” he continued; “for, old bachelor as I am, I have no pleasant associations connected with their lisp.It would be intolerable to me to pass a whole evening tete-e-tete with a brat.Don’t draw that chair farther off, Miss Eyre; sit down exactly where I placed it—if you please, that is.Confound these civilities!I continually forget them.Nor do I particularly affect simple-minded old ladies.By-the-bye, I must have mine in mind; it won’t do to neglect her; she is a Fairfax, or wed to one; and blood is said to be thicker than water.”
他摇铃遣人去请费尔法克斯太太，很快她就到了，手里还拿着编织篮。 He rang, and despatched an invitation to Mrs. Fairfax, who soon arrived, knitting basket in hand.
“晚上好，太太。我请您来是来做善事的。”我不许阿德拉跟我唠叨礼物的事，她现在肚子里一堆话，不吐不快。你就行行善事，听她说说话，跟她谈谈，也算是功德无量了。 “Good evening, madam; I sent to you for a charitable purpose.I have forbidden Adele to talk to me about her presents, and she is bursting with repletion: have the goodness to serve her as auditress and interlocutrice; it will be one of the most benevolent acts you ever performed.”
而阿德拉呢，一见到费尔法克斯太太，便邀她去自己的沙发旁，把她那个小箱子里的瓷器，象牙，和蜡制品都一股脑倒出来堆在腿上。同时用自己那蹩脚的英语不时地解释着，表达自己的开心。 Adele, indeed, no sooner saw Mrs. Fairfax, than she summoned her to her sofa, and there quickly filled her lap with the porcelain, the ivory, the waxen contents of her “boite;” pouring out, meantime, explanations and raptures in such broken English as she was mistress of.
“我现在可算是尽了地主之谊了吧，”罗切斯特先生接着说，“让客人们互相招待取悦。现在我也可以自己找乐子了。爱小姐，把你的椅子往前挪一挪，你还是坐得太远了。我坐在这个舒服的椅子里，要看到你还需要调整姿势，可我不想动。” “Now I have performed the part of a good host,” pursued Mr. Rochester, “put my guests into the way of amusing each other, I ought to be at liberty to attend to my own pleasure.Miss Eyre, draw your chair still a little farther forward: you are yet too far back; I cannot see you without disturbing my position in this comfortable chair, which I have no mind to do.”
我照吩咐做了，尽管我喜欢呆在阴影里。但罗切斯特先生一直以来就是直接下命令，而立刻服从他的命令仿佛也就成了理所当然的事。 I did as I was bid, though I would much rather have remained somewhat in the shade; but Mr. Rochester had such a direct way of giving orders, it seemed a matter of course to obey him promptly.
我前面已经交代过，我们是在餐厅里。为晚餐而点上的枝形吊灯此时把整个屋子照得如节日般光亮，熊熊炉火也通红透亮。在高大的窗户和更为高大的拱门上悬挂着紫色帷幔，华贵宽大。除了阿德拉压低声音的交谈（她不敢大声说话），和谈话间歇冬雨敲窗的声音，一切都是那么安静。 We were, as I have said, in the dining room: the lustre, which had been lit for dinner, filled the room with a festal breadth of light; the large fire was all red and clear;the purple curtains hung rich and ample before the lofty window and loftier arch; everything was still, save the subdued chat of Adele (she dared not speak loud), and, filling up each pause, the beating of winter rain against the panes.
罗切斯特先生坐在锦缎面的椅子上面，和我以前看到的不大相同——不那么严厉，也没那么阴沉。他嘴角挂着笑容，眼睛也闪着光彩，是不是喝了酒的缘故，我不确定，但看起来很可能如此。总之，他正在餐后的兴头上。比往常更亲切。较早晨的冷漠呆板，也更放纵自己。不过，他看起来依然严厉。硕大的头靠在椅子隆起的靠背上，炉火的光亮照在他那如花岗岩镌刻出来的面容上，照进他黑亮的大眼睛里。他有双又黑又亮的大眼睛，并且很漂亮——有时眼眸深处也并非没有变化。如果那不是柔情，至少也可以让你联想到那种感觉。 Mr. Rochester, as he sat in his damask covered chair, looked different to what I had seen him look before; not quite so stern—much less gloomy.There was a smile on his lips, and his eyes sparkled, whether with wine or not, I am not sure; but I think it very probable.He was, in short, in his after dinner mood; more expanded and genial, and also more self-indulgent than the frigid and rigid temper of the morning; still he looked preciously grim, cushioning his massive head against the swelling back of his chair, and receiving the light of the fire on his granite hewn features, and in his great, dark eyes;for he had great, dark eyes, and very fine eyes, too—not without a certain change in their depths sometimes, which, if it was not softness, reminded you, at least, of that feeling.
他一直盯着炉火，足足看了两分钟，而我也盯着他看了那么久。突然，他回过头来。而我的目光还定在他的脸上，被抓了个正着。 He had been looking two minutes at the fire, and I had been looking the same length of time at him, when, turning suddenly, he caught my gaze fastened on his physiognomy.
“你在审视我，爱小姐，”他说道，“你觉得我英俊吗？” “You examine me, Miss Eyre,” said he: “do you think me handsome?”
如果我仔细考虑一下，就会按照常理用含糊之词礼貌地回答，但还没等我意识过来，答案便脱口而出了——“不，先生。” I should, if I had deliberated, have replied to this question by something conventionally vague and polite; but the answer somehow slipped from my tongue before I was aware—“No, sir.”
“啊！我敢打赌，你这人有些特别。”他说道，“你的神态就像个小修女，优雅沉静，严肃单纯。你坐着的时候两手放在前面，眼睛总是朝下看着地毯（顺便说一句，像刚才那样尖刻地直视我的脸的情况除外）；若有人问你问题，或说了你不得不回答的话，你则会突然直言不讳地回答，虽算不上生硬，但有些唐突。你那么说是什么意思？” “Ah!By my word! there is something singular about you,” said he: “you have the air of a little nonnette; quaint, quiet, grave, and simple, as you sit with your hands before you, and your eyes generally bent on the carpet (except, by-the-bye, when they are directed piercingly to my face;as just now, for instance); and when one asks you a question, or makes a remark to which you are obliged to reply, you rap out a round rejoinder, which, if not blunt, is at least brusque.What do you mean by it?”
“先生，我太直白了，请您原谅。我刚才应该回答说，与容貌相关的问题，不好立刻给出答案；个人品味不同；外貌美丽并不重要；或者诸如此类的回答。” “Sir, I was too plain; I beg your pardon.I ought to have replied that it was not easy to give an impromptu answer to a question about appearances; that tastes mostly differ; and that beauty is of little consequence, or something of that sort.”
“你当然不应当如此回答。美丽并不重要，的确如此。你看似是想抚平我刚才的震怒，使我平静下来，其实又狡猾地在我耳朵下刺了一把小刀！讲下去，请问你还能挑出来我什么毛病，请问？我想我和别人一样四肢，五官都很周全吧。” “You ought to have replied no such thing.Beauty of little consequence, indeed!And so, under pretence of softening the previous outrage, of stroking and soothing me into placidity, you stick a sly penknife under my ear!Go on: what fault do you find with me, pray?I suppose I have all my limbs and all my features like any other man?”
“罗切斯特先生，请允许我收回我的第一个回答。我没有意有所指，只是无心之过。” “Mr. Rochester, allow me to disown my first answer: I intended no pointed repartee: it was only a blunder.”
“就是这么回事，我想是的，而你必须为此负责。你就挑我的毛病吧，我的额头不讨你喜欢吗？” “Just so: I think so: and you shall be answerable for it.Criticise me: does my forehead not please you?”
他撩起横在额前的波浪似的黑发，露出一块坚硬的智力器官，但是却缺乏任何应有的，仁慈敦厚的痕迹。 He lifted up the sable waves of hair which lay horizontally over his brow, and showed a solid enough mass of intellectual organs, but an abrupt deficiency where the suave sign of benevolence should have risen.
“怎样，小姐，我是个傻瓜吗？” “Now, ma’am, am I a fool?”
“绝对不是，先生。如果我反过来问您，您是不是个慈善家，您也许会觉得我无理吧？” “Far from it, sir.You would, perhaps, think me rude if I inquired in return whether you are a philanthropist?”
“又来了！一面假装拍拍我的头，另一面又捅我一刀。不就是因为我说我不喜欢跟小孩和老妇人呆在一起吗（要小声点说！）。不，年轻的小姐。我不是一般意义上的慈善家，可我还有良知。”他说着，就指了指那据说是代表良知的突起的地方，幸好对他来说，那地方很显眼，从而使他头的上半部分有明显的宽度。“此外，我以前也有一颗充满原始柔情的心。我像你这么大的时候，也充满同情心。总是对那些羽翼未丰，无人养育和不幸的人充满怜悯。但从那时起，命运就一直打击我，甚至用它的指关节揉搓我。而现在，我自认已经如同一只印度皮球一般冷酷和坚韧。当然，通过一两处空隙还可穿透，中间还有敏感的地方。是的，这使我还有希望吧？” “There again!Another stick of the penknife, when she pretended to pat my head: and that is because I said I did not like the society of children and old women (low be it spoken!).No, young lady, I am not a general philanthropist; but I bear a conscience;” and he pointed to the prominences which are said to indicate that faculty, and which, fortunately for him, were sufficiently conspicuous; giving, indeed, a marked breadth to the upper part of his head: “and, besides, I once had a kind of rude tenderness of heart.When I was as old as you, I was a feeling fellow enough, partial to the unfledged, unfostered, and unlucky; but Fortune has knocked me about since: she has even kneaded me with her knuckles, and now I flatter myself I am hard and tough as an India rubber ball; pervious, though, through a chink or two still, and with one sentient point in the middle of the lump.Yes: does that leave hope for me?”
“什么的希望，先生？” “Hope of what, sir?”
“有希望终能由印度橡皮球变回血肉之躯。” “Of my final retransformation from India rubber back to flesh?”
“他肯定是喝多了。”我想。我不知道怎么回答他这奇怪的问题。我怎么知道他能不能转变？ “Decidedly he has had too much wine,” I thought; and I did not know what answer to make to his queer question: how could I tell whether he was capable of being retransformed?
“爱小姐，你看起来很迷惑。虽然你并不漂亮，就像我也不英俊一样。但这种迷惑的神情同你十分相称。另外，也很方便。这样可以使你那双搜寻的眼睛从我的相貌上移到别处，忙着去看地毯上的绒花。所以，接着疑惑吧。年轻的小姐，今晚我爱热闹，话也很多。” “You looked very much puzzled, Miss Eyre; and though you are not pretty any more than I am handsome, yet a puzzled air becomes you; besides, it is convenient, for it keeps those searching eyes of yours away from my physiognomy, and busies them with the worsted flowers of the rug; so puzzle on.Young lady, I am disposed to be gregarious and communicative tonight.”
说完他便从椅子上起身站了起来，一只胳膊倚着大理石炉台。这个姿势使他的身材和面部一样可以看得一清二楚。他的胸膛异常宽阔，几乎与四肢的长度不成比例。我敢肯定大多数人会觉得他长相丑陋。但是他的举止中有一种明显的，不自觉的高傲。他行为从容自若，对自己的外貌也毫不在意。他非常自信地依赖来自外部的或内在的其他品质的力量，以此弥补自身魅力上的不足。看他一眼，便会不自觉地被他那种淡然的气质所感染，甚至会盲目地片面地对他那种自信表示信服。 With this announcement he rose from his chair, and stood, leaning his arm on the marble mantelpiece: in that attitude his shape was seen plainly as well as his face; his unusual breadth of chest, disproportionate almost to his length of limb.I am sure most people would have thought him an ugly man; yet there was so much unconscious pride in his port; so much ease in his demeanour; such a look of complete indifference to his own external appearance;so haughty a reliance on the power of other qualities, intrinsic or adventitious, to atone for the lack of mere personal attractiveness, that, in looking at him, one inevitably shared the indifference, and, even in a blind, imperfect sense, put faith in the confidence.
“我今晚爱热闹，话也多，”他又说了一遍，“所以我才找你来，炉火和吊灯都不足以陪伴我，派洛特也不行，他们都不会说话。阿德拉倒是强点，不过还是远低于标准。费尔法克斯太太也一样。而我相信，你只要乐意，是可以胜任的。第一天晚上我邀请你下来，你就使我迷惑不解。那次以后我都快把你给忘了。脑子里尽想着其他的事情，把你给抛之脑后了。但是今晚我决定安闲自在些，抛开那些烦人的事情，想些愉快的事情。让你开口说话，多了解了解你，是件开心的事情。所以你就说说吧。” “I am disposed to be gregarious and communicative tonight,” he repeated, “and that is why I sent for you: the fire and the chandelier were not sufficient company for me; nor would Pilot have been, for none of these can talk.Adele is a degree better, but still far below the mark; Mrs. Fairfax ditto; you, I am persuaded, can suit me if you will: you puzzled me the first evening I invited you down here.I have almost forgotten you since: other ideas have driven yours from my head; but tonight I am resolved to be at ease; to dismiss what importunes, and recall what pleases.It would please me now to draw you out—to learn more of you—therefore speak.”
我没有说话，反而笑了，既不得意，也不顺从。 Instead of speaking, I smiled; and not a very complacent or submissive smile either.
“说话啊！”他催促道。 “Speak,” he urged.
“说些什么呢，先生？” “What about, sir?”
“随便你想说什么。想说什么，怎么说，都随你便。” “Whatever you like.I leave both the choice of subject and the manner of treating it entirely to yourself.”
结果，我端坐着一句话不说。我想：“如果他指望我为了说话而说话，为炫耀而说话，那他会发现自己找错人了。” Accordingly I sat and said nothing: “If he expects me to talk for the mere sake of talking and showing off, he will find he has addressed himself to the wrong person,” I thought.
“你是哑巴吗，爱小姐？” “You are dumb, Miss Eyre.”
我仍旧一言不发。他向我微微低头，匆匆投来一瞥，好像要从我的眼睛里探究出来点什么。 I was dumb still.He bent his head a little towards me, and with a single hasty glance seemed to dive into my eyes.
“固执？”他说道，“还是被惹恼了。哦！是太坚持了。我提要求的方式过于荒谬蛮横了。爱小姐，我请求您的原谅。事实上，我只说这一次：我从来不愿把你当下人看待。也就是说“（他纠正自己），”如果我真的有强过你的地方，那也一定是因为我年长你二十岁，阅历多了一百年而已。这是合理的，就像阿德拉会说的那样，我坚持这点。正是因为这种优越感，也仅仅因为如此，我希望你现在行行好和我谈一会儿，帮我把心从苦苦纠缠的一件事中转移出来，它像一颗生锈的钉子一样，正在烂掉。” “Stubborn?” he said, “and annoyed.Ah! it is consistent.I put my request in an absurd, almost insolent form.Miss Eyre, I beg your pardon.The fact is, once for all, I don’t wish to treat you like an inferior: that is” (correcting himself), “I claim only such superiority as must result from twenty years’ difference in age and a century’s advance in experience.This is legitimate, et j’y tiens, as Adele would say; and it is by virtue of this superiority, and this alone, that I desire you to have the goodness to talk to me a little now, and divert my thoughts, which are galled with dwelling on one point—cankering as a rusty nail.”
他屈尊降格地做了解释，几乎算是道歉。我对他的屈尊道歉并没有无动于衷，也不想显得如此。 He had deigned an explanation, almost an apology, and I did not feel insensible to his condescension, and would not seem so.
“先生，如果我可以，我乐意让您开心，十分乐意。但我找不到话题，因为我怎么知道您对什么感兴趣呢？所以，您问我问题吧，我愿意尽力回答。” “I am willing to amuse you, if I can, sir—quite willing; but I cannot introduce a topic, because how do I know what will interest you?Ask me questions, and I will do my best to answer them.”
“那好，第一个问题。你是否赞同我在有些时候，有权稍稍专横，唐突，也许有时严厉一些。理由就像我刚才说过的，我的年龄足可以做你的父亲，我有着多样的人生阅历，和来自许多国家的许多人打交道，漂泊了大半个地球。而你呢，却只静静呆在一所房子里，只见过一种人？” “Then, in the first place, do you agree with me that I have a right to be a little masterful, abrupt, perhaps exacting, sometimes, on the grounds I stated, namely, that I am old enough to be your father,and that I have battled through a varied experience with many men of many nations, and roamed over half the globe, while you have lived quietly with one set of people in one house?”
“您爱怎么说都可以，先生。” “Do as you please, sir.”
“这可不算回答。或者说你的答案含糊其辞，很令人恼火。回答清楚一些。” “That is no answer; or rather it is a very irritating, because a very evasive one.Reply clearly.”
“先生，我不认为您仅仅因为比我年长，或是阅历丰富，就有权命令我。您是否可以拥有优越感取决于您怎样使用自己的时间和阅历。” “I don’t think, sir, you have a right to command me, merely because you are older than I, or because you have seen more of the world than I have; your claim to superiority depends on the use you have made of your time and experience.”
“哼！回答得倒还挺快。但我可不承认，这和我的情况根本就不符合，因为我对这两大优势的利用，虽谈不上坏，但却不够好。好，抛开优越感不谈，你必须同意偶尔听候我的吩咐，别因为我命令的口吻生气或伤心。可以做到吗？” “Humph!Promptly spoken.But I won’t allow that, seeing that it would never suit my case, as I have made an indifferent, not to say a bad, use of both advantages.Leaving superiority out of the question, then, you must still agree to receive my orders now and then, without being piqued or hurt by the tone of command.Will you?”
我笑了。我暗自思忖道: 罗切斯特先生真奇怪——他好像忘记了,他每年付我30英镑，就是要我听从他的命令的。 I smiled: I thought to myself Mr. Rochester is peculiar—he seems to forget that he pays me 30 pounds per annum for receiving his orders.
“笑得好，”他立刻抓住了我转瞬即逝的表情，“但是你还是得开口说话。” “The smile is very well,” said he, catching instantly the passing expression; “but speak too.”
“我在想，先生，很少会有主人会费心去问他们雇来的下属，会不会因为他们的命令而生气伤心吧。” “I was thinking, sir, that very few masters would trouble themselves to inquire whether or not their paid subordinates were piqued and hurt by their orders.”
“雇来的下属！什么！你是我雇来的下属吗？哦，是的，我已经忘了薪水这事了！那好，就基于这个理由，你肯让我耍点威风吗？” “Paid subordinates!What! you are my paid subordinate, are you?Oh yes, I had forgotten the salary!Well then, on that mercenary ground, will you agree to let me hector a little?”
“不，先生，不以这个为理由。但是由于您忘记了雇佣关系，您关心下属对自己的从属地位是否感到愉快，我从内心愿意听从您偶尔的吩咐。” “No, sir, not on that ground; but, on the ground that you did forget it, and that you care whether or not a dependent is comfortable in his dependency, I agree heartily.”
“你是否会同意我省去很多繁文缛节，而不会认为这种省略是出于傲慢无礼呢？” “And will you consent to dispense with a great many conventional forms and phrases, without thinking that the omission arises from insolence?”
“当然不会，先生，我决不会把不拘礼节错当成傲慢无礼。我比较喜欢不拘礼节，而傲慢无礼是任何一个自由人都不会屈从的，即使是为了一份薪水。” “I am sure, sir, I should never mistake informality for insolence: one I rather like, the other nothing freeborn would submit to, even for a salary.”
“胡扯！为了一份薪水，多少自由人什么都愿意放弃。因此，只谈你自己吧，不要妄谈普遍现象，你什么都不懂。不过，虽然你的答案并不准确，但就冲着它，我从内心与你握手言和。同样，还因为你说话的态度和内容。你态度诚恳坦率，并不常见。不，恰恰相反，坦率正直所得到的报答通常是矫揉造作，或者冷漠无情，或者是愚蠢粗俗的误解。三千个刚出校门的家庭女教师，也找不到三个能像你刚才那样回答我的问题。但我可不是在恭维你。如果你与芸芸大众不是从一个模子里造出来的，这并不是你的功劳，是造化使然。再说了，我的结论毕竟下得过早。据我目前所知，你也许并不比其他人强多少，你或许有些难以容忍的缺点，来抵消你那本来就无几的长处。” “Humbug!Most things freeborn will submit to anything for a salary; therefore, keep to yourself, and don’t venture on generalities of which you are intensely ignorant.However, I mentally shake hands with you for your answer, despite its inaccuracy; and as much for the manner in which it was said, as for the substance of the speech; the manner was frank and sincere; one does not often see such a manner: no, on the contrary, affectation, or coldness, or stupid, coarse minded misapprehension of one’s meaning are the usual rewards of candour.Not three in three thousand raw school-girl-governesses would have answered me as you have just done.But I don’t mean to flatter you: if you are cast in a different mould to the majority, it is no merit of yours: Nature did it.And then, after all, I go too fast in my conclusions: for what I yet know, you may be no better than the rest; you may have intolerable defects to counterbalance your few good points.”
“你估计也一样吧。”我心里道。这想法掠过脑际时，我的目光与他的相遇。他似乎读懂了我眼神的含义，即刻做了回答，仿佛我的想法不仅仅在脑海里，而且已经说出口了—— “And so may you,” I thought.My eye met his as the idea crossed my mind: he seemed to read the glance, answering as if its import had been spoken as well as imagined—
“是的，是的，你说的对，”他说，“我自身也有很多缺点，这我知道，而我也无意掩饰这一点，我向你保证。上帝知道我不应该对他人过分苛责。我应该反省我过去的经历，一连串的行为和生活方式，从过去的生活中我可以收回对邻居的嘲笑与责备而留给自己。我开始，或者说（像其他有过失的人一样，我喜欢把一半罪责推给厄运和逆境）我在二十一岁的时候被抛入歧途，至今没有回归正途。否则，我可能会是个完全不同的人，可能会像你一样善良——比你更聪明——几乎和你一样纯洁无暇。我嫉妒你平静的心境，清白的良心，纯净的记忆。小姑娘，没有污点或不被污染的记忆一定是一大珍宝——是令人神清气爽的不竭源泉，不是吗？” “Yes, yes, you are right,” said he; “I have plenty of faults of my own: I know it, and I don’t wish to palliate them, I assure you.God wot I need not be too severe about others; I have a past existence, a series of deeds, a colour of life to contemplate within my own breast, which might well call my sneers and censures from my neighbours to myself.I started, or rather (for like other defaulters, I like to lay half the blame on ill fortune and adverse circumstances) was thrust on to a wrong tack at the age of one and twenty, and have never recovered the right course since: but I might have been very different; I might have been as good as you—wiser—almost as stainless.I envy you your peace of mind, your clean conscience, your unpolluted memory.Little girl, a memory without blot or contamination must be an exquisite treasure—an inexhaustible source of pure refreshment: is it not?”
“先生，您十八岁的时候过得怎么样？” “How was your memory when you were eighteen, sir?”
“那时还好。无忧无虑，十分健康，没有滚滚污水把它变成臭水潭。十八岁时的我和你不相上下——完全一样。总的来说，上天是要我做个好人的，爱小姐，较好那类中的一个，而你看到了，我不是。也许你会说你并不这么认为，但至少，我敢说我在你的眼里读出了这层信息（顺便说一句，你要小心你的眼睛传达的信息，我是很善于解读的）。那么记住我的话——我不是个恶棍，你千万不要这样认为——不要把这个恶名加诸我的身上。但我的确相信，由于环境而不是本性的原因，我变成了一个普通的罪人，沉浸在那一切可怜的小小放荡上面。很多有钱却无人生目标的人都以此来过活。是不是很奇怪我为什么要向你坦露心迹？要知道，在你未来的人生道路上，你常常会发现自己不由自主地被当作知己，去聆听熟人的隐私。和我一样，人们凭直觉就会发现，你的长处不在于谈论自己，却在于聆听别人的谈论。他们还会感受到，你聆听的时候并不会对他们的行为不端怀有恶意的蔑视，而是有一种发自内心的同情。由于这种同情表现方式谦逊，同样能给人鼓励和抚慰。” “All right then; limpid, salubrious: no gush of bilge water had turned it to fetid puddle.I was your equal at eighteen—quite your equal.Nature meant me to be, on the whole, a good man, Miss Eyre; one of the better kind, and you see I am not so.You would say you don’t see it; at least I flatter myself I read as much in your eye (beware, by-the-bye, what you express with that organ; I am quick at interpreting its language).Then take my word for it,—I am not a villain: you are not to suppose that—not to attribute to me any such bad eminence; but, owing, I verily believe, rather to circumstances than to my natural bent, I am a trite commonplace sinner, hackneyed in all the poor petty dissipations with which the rich and worthless try to put on life.Do you wonder that I avow this to you?Know, that in the course of your future life you will often find yourself elected the involuntary confidant of your acquaintances’ secrets: people will instinctively find out, as I have done, that it is not your forte to tell of yourself, but to listen while others talk of themselves;they will feel, too, that you listen with no malevolent scorn of their indiscretion, but with a kind of innate sympathy; not the less comforting and encouraging because it is very unobtrusive in its manifestations.”
“您怎么知道？———您怎么猜到这一切的呢，先生？” “How do you know?—how can you guess all this, sir?”
“我相当了解，所以我谈起来无拘无束，就像是把自己的思想记录在日记中一样。你会说，我本应战胜环境的，我是应该——是应该，但是你看，我却没有。当命运亏待我时，我没有足够的智慧保持冷静，我变得绝望，随后堕落了。现在，要是一个可恶的傻瓜企图用卑鄙的下流话激怒我的话，我不认为自己会比他好些。我不得不承认我们是彼此彼此而已。我真希望自己当初能够保持坚定——上帝知道我多么希望。爱小姐，若你也被诱惑犯错误，要视后悔为畏途，后悔是生活的毒药。” “I know it well; therefore I proceed almost as freely as if I were writing my thoughts in a diary.You would say, I should have been superior to circumstances; so I should—so I should; but you see I was not.When fate wronged me, I had not the wisdom to remain cool: I turned desperate; then I degenerated.Now, when any vicious simpleton excites my disgust by his paltry ribaldry, I cannot flatter myself that I am better than he: I am forced to confess that he and I are on a level.I wish I had stood firm—God knows I do!Dread remorse when you are tempted to err, Miss Eyre; remorse is the poison of life.”
“据说忏悔是治疗的良药，先生。” “Repentance is said to be its cure, sir.”
“忏悔没用的。改过自新也许还行，我能改——我还有力量这么做——如果——但是既然我已经受到阻碍，负荷沉重，遭受诅咒了，想这些还有什么用呢？而且，既然我已经被无可挽回地剥夺了幸福，我有权从生活中寻找快乐，无论付出什么代价，我都一定要得到。” “It is not its cure.Reformation may be its cure; and I could reform—I have strength yet for that—if—but where is the use of thinking of it, hampered, burdened, cursed as I am?Besides, since happiness is irrevocably denied me, I have a right to get pleasure out of life: and I WILL get it, cost what it may.”
“这样您会继续堕落的，先生。” “Then you will degenerate still more, sir.”
“也许吧。但是，如果我能得到新鲜甜蜜的欢乐，为什么会更堕落呢？也许我得到的，正如蜜蜂从荒原里采摘来的蜜糖一样新鲜甜蜜。”“它会蜇人的——而且也苦涩，先生。”“你怎么知道？——你又没有试过。看起来多么严肃——你看起来多么一本正经啊。你对这种事情一无所知，就如同这个浮雕头一般（从壁炉上拿下来一只）。”“你还没有权利对我说教，你这个新入教的。你还没有跨过生活之门，显然也并不了解它的秘密。” “Possibly: yet why should I, if I can get sweet, fresh pleasure?And I may get it as sweet and fresh as the wild honey the bee gathers on the moor.”“It will sting—it will taste bitter, sir.”“How do you know?—you never tried it.How very serious—how very solemn you look: and you are as ignorant of the matter as this cameo head” (taking one from the mantelpiece).“You have no right to preach to me, you neophyte, that have not passed the porch of life, and are absolutely unacquainted with its mysteries.”
“先生，我只是提醒您自己说过的话而已。您说错误带来悔恨，还说悔恨是生活的毒药。” “I only remind you of your own words, sir: you said error brought remorse, and you pronounced remorse the poison of existence.”
“现在谁谈论错误了？我不认为刚才闪过我脑际的想法是个错误。我认为那不是诱惑，而是启发，非常亲切，令人欣慰——这我知道。它又来了！它不是魔鬼，我向你保证。即使是魔鬼，那也披上了光明天使的长袍。我想若是这样一位美丽的客人要进驻我的内心的话，我应该欢迎才是。” “And who talks of error now?I scarcely think the notion that flittered across my brain was an error.I believe it was an inspiration rather than a temptation: it was very genial, very soothing—I know that.Here it comes again!It is no devil, I assure you; or if it be, it has put on the robes of an angel of light.I think I must admit so fair a guest when it asks entrance to my heart.”
“不要相信它，先生。那不是真正的天使。” “Distrust it, sir; it is not a true angel.”
“我再问一遍，你怎么知道？你凭什么直觉可以假装分辨出一个堕落入深渊的天使和一个来自永恒宝座的使者——一个引路人和一个诱惑者？” “Once more, how do you know?By what instinct do you pretend to distinguish between a fallen seraph of the abyss and a messenger from the eternal throne—between a guide and a seducer?”
“我是根据您的神情判断的，先生。您说您又冒出了这种想法时，一脸不安。我确定，如果您听从了这种想法，它将会给您带来更多不幸。” “I judged by your countenance, sir, which was troubled when you said the suggestion had returned upon you.I feel sure it will work you more misery if you listen to it.”
“绝对不会——它会带来世上最好的消息。至于别的，你又不是我良心的监护人，所以你不必为此不安。嘿，进来吧，美丽的流浪者！” “Not at all—it bears the most gracious message in the world: for the rest, you are not my conscience keeper, so don’t make yourself uneasy.Here, come in, bonny wanderer!”
他说这话时仿佛是在同一个除了自己谁也看不到的幻影交谈。然后他把伸出去一半的双臂收回来放在胸前，似乎是把那看不到的人抱在胸前。 He said this as if he spoke to a vision, viewless to any eye but his own; then, folding his arms, which he had half extended, on his chest, he seemed to enclose in their embrace the invisible being.
“现在，”他接着说，再次转向了我，“我深信，我已经接受了这个朝圣者，乔装打扮的神。它已经为我做了好事。我的心以前是一个停尸所，现在将要成为神龛了。” “Now,” he continued, again addressing me, “I have received the pilgrim—a disguised deity, as I verify believe.Already it has done me good: my heart was a sort of charnel; it will now be a shrine.”
“说实话，先生，我一点也听不懂您的话。我不能继续和您交谈了，因为它已经超出了我理解的深度。我只知道一件事，您说您不如您应该的那样好，并为这个不完美感到遗憾；——有件事我可以理解，您说被玷污了的回忆是永恒的祸根。在我看来，只要您努力过，您会发现有朝一日变成您欣赏的那种人也是有可能的；如果从今天开始您就下定决心修正自己的行为和思想，几年之后就会积累起许多崭新的、没有污点的回忆，供您快乐地去回味。” “To speak truth, sir, I don’t understand you at all: I cannot keep up the conversation, because it has got out of my depth.Only one thing, I know: you said you were not as good as you should like to be, and that you regretted your own imperfection;—one thing I can comprehend: you intimated that to have a sullied memory was a perpetual bane.It seems to me, that if you tried hard, you would in time find it possible to become what you yourself would approve; and that if from this day you began with resolution to correct your thoughts and actions, you would in a few years have laid up a new and stainless store of recollections, to which you might revert with pleasure.”
“思维清晰，表达恰当。爱小姐。此时此刻，我正在使劲给地狱铺路。” “Justly thought; rightly said, Miss Eyre; and, at this moment, I am paving hell with energy.”
“先生？” “Sir?”
“我正在用良好的意愿铺路，相信它像燧石一样耐久。当然，今后我所交往的人和追求的事情将和以前不同。” “I am laying down good intentions, which I believe durable as flint.Certainly, my associates and pursuits shall be other than they have been.”
“是比以前更好？” “And better?”
“会更好——就像纯粹的矿石比污秽的残渣要好的多。你好像在怀疑我。我并不怀疑我自己。我知道自己的目的和动机所在。此刻，我通过了一项不可更改的法律，就像玛代人和波斯人的法律一样，两者都是正当的。” “And better—so much better as pure ore is than foul dross.You seem to doubt me; I don’t doubt myself: I know what my aim is, what my motives are; and at this moment I pass a law, unalterable as that of the Medes and Persians, that both are right.”
“先生，如果还需要一条新的法规将其合法化的话，它们不可能是正当的。” “They cannot be, sir, if they require a new statute to legalise them.”
“爱小姐，尽管它们需要一个全新的法规，但它们完全成立。没有先例的复杂情况需要没有先例的法规。” “They are, Miss Eyre, though they absolutely require a new statute: unheard-of combinations of circumstances demand unheard-of rules.”
“这听起来是个危险的格言，先生。因为马上就会发现这容易造成滥用。” “That sounds a dangerous maxim, sir; because one can see at once that it is liable to abuse.”
“善用格言的圣人！的确如此。我以家神的名义发誓决不滥用。” “Sententious sage! so it is: but I swear by my household gods not to abuse it.”
“你是人，是人难免犯错误。” “You are human and fallible.”
“我是人，你也一样。那又怎样呢？” “I am: so are you—what then?”
“人难免出错，不应该冒用本应赋予神明和完人的权力。” “The human and fallible should not arrogate a power with which the divine and perfect alone can be safely intrusted.”
“什么权力？” “What power?”
“对任何奇怪的，未经许可的行为说——‘算它对好了。’” “That of saying of any strange, unsanctioned line of action,—‘Let it be right.’”
“‘算它对好了’——就是这几个字，你已经说出来了。” “‘Let it be right’—the very words: you have pronounced them.”
“那就但愿它对吧。”我说着站起来，觉得已经没有必要继续这番自己感到糊里糊涂的对话。另外，我发现自己无法摸透对方的性格，至少目前还无法摸透。还有一种不确定感，一种朦胧的不安全感，并觉得自己很无知。 “MAY it be right then,” I said, as I rose, deeming it useless to continue a discourse which was all darkness to me; and, besides, sensible that the character of my interlocutor was beyond my penetration; at least, beyond its present reach; and feeling the uncertainty, the vague sense of insecurity, which accompanies a conviction of ignorance.
“你要去哪里？” “Where are you going?”
“送阿德拉睡觉。已经过了她睡觉的时间了。” “To put Adele to bed: it is past her bedtime.”
“你怕我，因为我说话像斯芬克斯。” “You are afraid of me, because I talk like a Sphynx.”
“先生，您的话不可捉摸。但尽管我已经被弄糊涂了，但我根本不怕。” “Your language is enigmatical, sir: but though I am bewildered, I am certainly not afraid.”
“你是害怕的——你的自爱心理使你怕犯错。” “You ARE afraid—your self-love dreads a blunder.”
“如果是那样的话，我确实觉得有些担忧——我可不想胡说八道。”“就算你说了胡话，你那总是板着脸孔，一本正经的神态也会让我误以为你说得在理呢。你从来没有笑过吗，爱小姐？你不用回答——我知道你几乎不笑。但是请相信我，你不是天生严肃，就如同我也天生不是恶人一样，你也可以笑得很开心。洛伍德的束缚至今在仍在你身上留下了些印记，控制着你的神态，压抑着你的嗓音，束缚了你的手脚。所以你害怕在一个男人，或是兄长——或是父亲，或是主人，随你怎么说——面前开怀大笑，害怕讲话自由，或动作太快。但是，我认为你迟早会学会在我面前自然一些，就像我也觉得在你面前不可能遵守那些繁文缛节一样。那时，你的神态和动作就会比现在流露出来的更生动，更多彩。透过木条禁锢的鸟笼，我不时地看看一只好奇的鸟投来的目光。那是一个充满活力，躁动不安，不屈不挠的俘虏。一旦获得自由，便会翱翔云端。你还坚持要走吗？” “In that sense I do feel apprehensive—I have no wish to talk nonsense.”“If you did, it would be in such a grave, quiet manner, I should mistake it for sense.Do you never laugh, Miss Eyre?Don’t trouble yourself to answer—I see you laugh rarely; but you can laugh very merrily: believe me, you are not naturally austere, any more than I am naturally vicious.The Lowood constraint still clings to you somewhat; controlling your features, muffling your voice, and restricting your limbs; and you fear in the presence of a man and a brother—or father, or master, or what you will—to smile too gaily, speak too freely, or move too quickly:but, in time, I think you will learn to be natural with me, as I find it impossible to be conventional with you; and then your looks and movements will have more vivacity and variety than they dare offer now.I see at intervals the glance of a curious sort of bird through the close-set bars of a cage: a vivid, restless, resolute captive is there; were it but free, it would soar cloud high.You are still bent on going?”
“表已经敲过九点钟了，先生。” “It has struck nine, sir.”
“没关系——再等一下。阿德拉还没打算去睡觉呢。爱小姐，我的位置背靠火炉，面朝房间，最有利于观察。跟你说话的时候，我也不时地看看阿德拉（我有充足的理由把她当成一个我好奇的研究对象——至于理由，我有可能，不，我以后会告诉你的）。差不多十分钟前，她从小箱子里拿出一件粉色丝绸小上衣，一打开便喜笑颜开。轻浮之气在她的血液里流淌，融进她的大脑，给她的骨髓养分。‘我应该试试！’她喊道，‘立刻就去！’说着就冲出了房间。她现在正跟索菲一起，忙着试装呢。不几分钟她就会进来。我知道我将看到什么——塞莉纳·瓦伦的缩影，就像当年她站在舞台上一样，帷幕开启——算了，不提了。然而，我最温柔的情感将为之震动，这就是我的预感。呆着别走，看看我的预言是否会实现。” “Never mind,—wait a minute: Adele is not ready to go to bed yet.My position, Miss Eyre, with my back to the fire, and my face to the room, favours observation.While talking to you, I have also occasionally watched Adele (I have my own reasons for thinking her a curious study,—reasons that I may, nay, that I shall, impart to you some day).She pulled out of her box, about ten minutes ago, a little pink silk frock; rapture lit her face as she unfolded it; coquetry runs in her blood, blends with her brains, and seasons the marrow of her bones.‘Il faut que je l’essaie!’cried she, ‘et e l’instant meme!’ and she rushed out of the room.She is now with Sophie, undergoing a robing process: in a few minutes she will reenter; and I know what I shall see,—a miniature of Celine Varens, as she used to appear on the boards at the rising of—But never mind that.However, my tenderest feelings are about to receive a shock: such is my presentiment; stay now, to see whether it will be realised.”
没多久，我就听见阿德拉轻快的步子走过大厅。她走进门，如她的监护人所预见到的一样，完全变了个样子。一条玫瑰色的缎子裙代替了原先穿的棕色上衣。裙子很短，裙摆不能再大了。她头上戴着玫瑰花蕾编织的花环，脚上穿着丝袜和小小的白缎子便鞋。 Ere long, Adele’s little foot was heard tripping across the hall.She entered, transformed as her guardian had predicted.A dress of rose-coloured satin, very short, and as full in the skirt as it could be gathered, replaced the brown frock she had previously worn; a wreath of rosebuds circled her forehead; her feet were dressed in silk stockings and small white satin sandals.
“我的衣服合适吗？”她一边大声问道，一边向前跑，“我的鞋呢，袜子呢？看啊，我都觉得想跳舞了！” “Est-ce que ma robe va bien?” cried she, bounding forwards; “et mes souliers? et mes bas?Tenez, je crois que je vais danser!”
她展开裙子，用快滑步穿过房间，来到罗切斯特先生面前，在他面前踮起脚尖轻盈地转了一圈，然后一个膝头跪地，在他脚边，叫道—— And spreading out her dress, she chasseed across the room till, having reached Mr. Rochester, she wheeled lightly round before him on tip-toe, then dropped on one knee at his feet, exclaiming—
“先生，非常感谢您的好意，”然后起身继续说道，“就像妈妈做的一样。不是吗，先生？” “Monsieur, je vous remercie mille fois de votre bonte;” then rising, she added, “C’est comme cela que maman faisait, n’est-ce pas, monsieur?”
“的——确——像！”他回答道，“而且，‘像极了’，她的魅力骗走了我英国裤袋里的英国钱。爱小姐，我也曾年轻过——唉，青草一般的年纪啊。一度使我生机勃勃的青春色彩并不亚于现在的你。但我的春天已经过去，却给我留下了这朵法国小花，可我有时真想摆脱它。我并不珍重生出它的根，又发现它只有金土才可以灌溉，所以就愈发不喜欢它了，尤其当它像刚刚那样做作的时候。我收留它，养育它，多半是按照罗马天主教教义，要用一件好事来赎无数大大小小的罪孽。我改天再给你解释这一切。晚安。” “Pre-cise-ly!”was the answer; “and, ‘comme cela,’ she charmed my English gold out of my British breeches’ pocket.I have been green, too, Miss Eyre,—ay, grass green: not a more vernal tint freshens you now than once freshened me.My Spring is gone, however, but it has left me that French floweret on my hands, which, in some moods, I would fain be rid of.Not valuing now the root whence it sprang; having found that it was of a sort which nothing but gold dust could manure, I have but half a liking to the blossom, especially when it looks so artificial as just now.I keep it and rear it rather on the Roman Catholic principle of expiating numerous sins, great or small, by one good work.I’ll explain all this some day.Goodnight.”
第十五章 CHAPTER XV
后来有一次，罗切斯特先生的确对此事做了解释。那是个午后，他在庭院里恰巧碰到我和阿德拉。趁着阿德拉正逗弄着派洛特，玩着板羽球的时候，他请我和他一起去一条长长的，布满山毛榉的林荫道上散步，从那里还可以看得见阿德拉。 Mr. Rochester did, on a future occasion, explain it.It was one afternoon, when he chanced to meet me and Adele in the grounds: and while she played with Pilot and her shuttlecock, he asked me to walk up and down a long beech avenue within sight of her.
他告诉我阿德拉是法国歌剧演员塞莉纳·瓦伦的女儿，用他自己的话说，他曾一度对塞莉纳怀有“非常强烈的情感”。塞莉纳曾声称要以更加火热的情感回报他的爱情。他认为自己尽管外貌丑陋，却是她的偶像。他相信，正如他所说，比起贝尔维德尔·阿波罗的优美，她更喜欢自己“运动员的身材”。 He then said that she was the daughter of a French opera dancer, Celine Varens, towards whom he had once cherished what he called a “grande passion．”This passion Celine had professed to return with even superior ardour.He thought himself her idol, ugly as he was: he believed, as he said, that she preferred his “taille d’athlete” to the elegance of the Apollo Belvidere.
“爱小姐，这位法国美女竟然钟情于一位英国侏儒，我简直受宠若惊。于是我给她在酒店里安排了住处，给她配齐了仆役和马车，送给她山羊绒，钻石，花边，等等。总之，我开始像任何一个痴情汉一样，用惯常的方式毁灭自己。我似乎缺乏独创性，没法开创出一条通向羞辱和毁灭的新路，而是傻傻地严格遵循着旧道，一步都不肯偏离别人踏平的中心。我拥有了——我活该如此——与所有其他痴情汉一样的命运。一晚，我拜访塞莉纳，她不知道我要去，我发现她不在家。那晚天气很暖和，我因步行穿过巴黎，已有些疲倦，就在她的房间里坐了下来，愉快地呼吸着她刚走时留下的圣洁的空气。不——我有点夸大了。我从来不认为她身上有神圣的美德。那是她走时留下的一种香锭的香气，是麝香和琥珀的味道，才不是什么圣洁的香气。暖房里的鲜花和洒在空气中的香水味使我有些窒息，于是就想打开窗户走到阳台上去。这时月色朗照，汽灯闪亮，十分静谧。阳台上摆着一两把椅子，我坐了下来，掏出一支雪茄——你不介意吧，我现在就要抽一支。” “And, Miss Eyre, so much was I flattered by this preference of the Gallic sylph for her British gnome, that I installed her in an hotel; gave her a complete establishment of servants, a carriage, cashmeres, diamonds, dentelles, &c.In short, I began the process of ruining myself in the received style, like any other spoony.I had not, it seems, the originality to chalk out a new road to shame and destruction, but trode the old track with stupid exactness not to deviate an inch from the beaten centre.I had—as I deserved to have—the fate of all other spoonies.Happening to call one evening when Celine did not expect me, I found her out; but it was a warm night, and I was tired with strolling through Paris, so I sat down in her boudoir; happy to breathe the air consecrated so lately by her presence.No,—I exaggerate; I never thought there was any consecrating virtue about her: it was rather a sort of pastille perfume she had left; a scent of musk and amber, than an odour of sanctity.I was just beginning to stifle with the fumes of conservatory flowers and sprinkled essences, when I bethought myself to open the window and step out on to the balcony.It was moonlight and gaslight besides, and very still and serene.The balcony was furnished with a chair or two; I sat down, and took out a cigar,—I will take one now, if you will excuse me.”
说到这里他停顿了一下，拿出一支雪茄点燃。放到唇间，把一缕哈瓦那云雾喷进寒冷阴沉的空气中，继续说道—— Here ensued a pause, filled up by the producing and lighting of a cigar; having placed it to his lips and breathed a trail of Havannah incense on the freezing and sunless air, he went on—
