她真的饿了，所以鸡肉和馅饼暂时分散了她的注意力。幸亏我刚去弄了食物，否则她和我还有索菲——我把我们的饭分给了索菲一些——很有可能吃不到晚饭，楼下的人都忙得顾不上想起我们。甜点在九点后才上。十点时，仆人还端着托盘和咖啡杯跑来跑去。我允许阿德拉比往常晚睡，因为她说楼下的门开开关关，人声鼎沸，她不可能睡得着。另外，她还说如果罗切斯特先生派人送来口信而她已经换了衣服，“该有多遗憾呀！” She was really hungry, so the chicken and tarts served to divert her attention for a time.It was well I secured this forage, or both she, I, and Sophie, to whom I conveyed a share of our repast, would have run a chance of getting no dinner at all: every one downstairs was too much engaged to think of us.The dessert was not carried out till after nine and at ten footmen were still running to and fro with trays and coffee cups.I allowed Adele to sit up much later than usual; for she declared she could not possibly go to sleep while the doors kept opening and shutting below, and people bustling about.Besides, she added, a message might possibly come from Mr. Rochester when she was undressed; “et alors quel dommage!”
只要她愿意听故事，我就讲给她听。然后我变换了一下方式，带她到走廊里去。大厅里灯火通明，阿德拉很开心地靠在栏杆上看仆人来回穿行。夜深了，音乐声从客厅里传出，钢琴之前就移到了那里。阿德拉和我坐在楼梯顶上听着。一个声音与钢琴圆润的声音交错在一起，是一个女士在唱歌，声音非常甜美。独唱后，一曲二重奏接上，接着是一首无伴奏的重唱曲。换曲时的空暇充满了愉快低沉的谈话声。我一直听着，突然我发现自己完全将听力集中于分析混在一起的声音，想从中分辨出罗切斯特先生的声音。不久，我就听出了他的声音，但由于离得太远了，我还要艰难地从他含糊不清的调子中猜出歌词。 I told her stories as long as she would listen to them; and then for a change I took her out into the gallery.The hall lamp was now lit, and it amused her to look over the balustrade and watch the servants passing backwards and forwards.When the evening was far advanced, a sound of music issued from the drawing room, whither the piano had been removed; Adele and I sat down on the top step of the stairs to listen.Presently a voice blent with the rich tones of the instrument; it was a lady who sang, and very sweet her notes were.The solo over, a duet followed, and then a glee: a joyous conversational murmur filled up the intervals.I listened long: suddenly I discovered that my ear was wholly intent on analysing the mingled sounds, and trying to discriminate amidst the confusion of accents those of Mr. Rochester; and when it caught them, which it soon did, it found a further task in framing the tones, rendered by distance inarticulate, into words.
钟表敲响了十一点。我看了看倚在我肩膀上的阿德拉，她的眼皮越来越下垂，于是我把她抱起来，送到床上。快到凌晨一点时，绅士们和女士们才开始回到他们的卧室。 The clock struck eleven.I looked at Adele, whose head leant against my shoulder; her eyes were waxing heavy, so I took her up in my arms and carried her off to bed.It was near one before the gentlemen and ladies sought their chambers.
第二天和前一天一样晴朗。来宾们借此良日要到附近的某个地方去远足。他们上午很早就出发了，一些人骑着马，其他的坐在车里。我看着他们出发，又看着他们返回。英格拉姆小姐像之前一样，是唯一一位女骑手，罗切斯特先生也像之前一样在她旁边策马奔驰。两人与其他人有一些距离。我指着这个情景对和我一起站在窗户边的费尔法克斯太太说—— The next day was as fine as its predecessor: it was devoted by the party to an excursion to some site in the neighbourhood.They set out early in the forenoon, some on horseback, the rest in carriages; I witnessed both the departure and the return.Miss Ingram, as before, was the only lady equestrian; and, as before, Mr. Rochester galloped at her side; the two rode a little apart from the rest.I pointed out this circumstance to Mrs. Fairfax, who was standing at the window with me—
“你说他们不太可能会结婚，”我说，“但是你看，与其他女士相比，罗切斯特先生明显更喜欢她。” “You said it was not likely they should think of being married,” said I, “but you see Mr. Rochester evidently prefers her to any of the other ladies.”
“是呀，我敢说他无疑很仰慕她。” “Yes, I daresay: no doubt he admires her.”
“而且她对他也一样，”我接着说，“看她把头凑到他跟前，好像秘密地说些什么；我要能看到她的脸就好了，我一眼还没见过她呢。”“你今晚就能见到她啦。”费尔法克斯太太回答说。“我碰巧跟罗切斯特先生说了阿德拉有多希望见到那些女士们，他说：‘哦，让她晚饭后来客厅吧，让爱小姐陪她来。’” “And she him,” I added; “look how she leans her head towards him as if she were conversing confidentially; I wish I could see her face; I have never had a glimpse of it yet.”“You will see her this evening,” answered Mrs. Fairfax.“I happened to remark to Mr. Rochester how much Adele wished to be introduced to the ladies, and he said: ‘Oh! let her come into the drawing room after dinner; and request Miss Eyre to accompany her.’”
“嗯，他一定是出于礼貌才那样说，我确定我不需要去。”我回答说。 “Yes; he said that from mere politeness: I need not go, I am sure,” I answered.
“哎，我告诉他你不太习惯在人群里出现，我觉得你不会喜欢参加这样热闹的宴会——全是陌生人。但他像往常一样快速的回了一句——‘胡说！如果她不愿来，就告诉她这是我特别要求的；如果她还拒绝，告诉她要是她一直倔强下去我会自己去叫她的。’” “Well, I observed to him that as you were unused to company, I did not think you would like appearing before so gay a party—all strangers; and he replied, in his quick way—‘Nonsense!If she objects, tell her it is my particular wish; and if she resists, say I shall come and fetch her in case of contumacy.’”
“我不会让他那么麻烦的。”我回答，“如果只能这样，我会去的；但是我不喜欢。你会去吗，费尔法克斯太太？” “I will not give him that trouble,” I answered.“I will go, if no better may be; but I don’t like it.Shall you be there, Mrs. Fairfax?”
“不会，我恳请他不要让我去，他同意了。我告诉你如何避免一次正式入场的尴尬，那是最让人不自在的地方。你一定要在女士们离开晚餐桌，客厅里没人的时候进去，选一个你喜欢的角落坐下。绅士们进去后一会儿你就可以走了，除非你还想呆在那儿。只要让罗切斯特先生看到你去了就行，然后就偷偷溜走——没有人会注意到你的。” “No; I pleaded off, and he admitted my plea.I’ll tell you how to manage so as to avoid the embarrassment of making a formal entrance, which is the most disagreeable part of the business.You must go into the drawing room while it is empty, before the ladies leave the dinner table; choose your seat in any quiet nook you like; you need not stay long after the gentlemen come in, unless you please: just let Mr. Rochester see you are there and then slip away—nobody will notice you.”
“你觉得这些人会在这儿常住吗？” “Will these people remain long, do you think?”
“也许两三周，肯定不能再长了。复活节假期后，最近刚当选为米尔科特议员的乔治·林恩爵士要去赴任。我敢说罗切斯特先生一定会陪他去。他在桑菲尔德呆这么长时间已经让我觉得奇怪了。” “Perhaps two or three weeks, certainly not more.After the Easter recess, Sir George Lynn, who was lately elected member for Millcote, will have to go up to town and take his seat; I daresay Mr. Rochester will accompany him: it surprises me that he has already made so protracted a stay at Thornfield.”
我意识到我要到客厅去完成任务的时间渐渐逼近，心里一阵焦虑。阿德拉听到晚上可以见那些女士们的消息后，一整天都很兴奋，直到索菲开始给她穿衣打扮，她才平静下来。穿衣打扮这个过程的重要性很快使她平静了，她的卷发很顺地排在一起，向下垂着。穿上了粉红色的绸缎外套，系上了长长的腰带，戴好了蕾丝手套，一切准备停当后，她看起来像法官一样严肃。毋庸提醒她不要弄乱了装束，因为她穿好后，就端庄地坐在她的小椅子上；坐下之前还小心地掀起绸缎裙子，怕压出褶来。而且她还向我保证在我准备好之前，她一定会安静地呆着。我迅速地穿上了我最好的裙子（一件银灰色的裙子，是为出席坦普尔小姐的婚礼而买的，但那次之后就没再穿过）；很快地梳好头，我唯一的首饰——一个珍珠胸针也很快戴好。我们下楼了。 It was with some trepidation that I perceived the hour approach when I was to repair with my charge to the drawing room.Adele had been in a state of ecstasy all day, after hearing she was to be presented to the ladies in the evening; and it was not till Sophie commenced the operation of dressing her that she sobered down.Then the importance of the process quickly steadied her, and by the time she had her curls arranged in well smoothed, drooping clusters, her pink satin frock put on, her long sash tied, and her lace mittens adjusted, she looked as grave as any judge.No need to warn her not to disarrange her attire: when she was dressed, she sat demurely down in her little chair, taking care previously to lift up the satin skirt for fear she should crease it, and assured me she would not stir thence till I was ready.This I quickly was: my best dress (the silver-gray one, purchased for Miss Temple’s wedding, and never worn since) was soon put on; my hair was soon smoothed; my sole ornament, the pearl brooch, soon assumed.We descended.
幸运的是，我们不用穿过宾客正在用餐的餐厅，因为客厅还有另外一个入口。客厅里空无一人。熊熊火光正在大理石壁炉里安静地燃烧着，蜡烛孤寂地闪着光亮，周围是用来装饰桌子的花朵，精致美丽。拱门前悬挂着深红色的帷幔，把这个房间与旁边的餐厅隔开，虽然隔层不厚，但客人们的声音很低，所以他们的谈话听起来只是柔和的低喃声，一个字也听不清。 Fortunately there was another entrance to the drawing room than that through the saloon where they were all seated at dinner.We found the apartment vacant; a large fire burning silently on the marble hearth, and wax candles shining in bright solitude, amid the exquisite flowers with which the tables were adorned.The crimson curtain hung before the arch: slight as was the separation this drapery formed from the party in the adjoining saloon, they spoke in so low a key that nothing of their conversation could be distinguished beyond a soothing murmur.
阿德拉看起来依然神情严肃，我指着一个脚凳，让她坐在那儿，她一言不发地坐下了。我坐在一个靠窗的位子上，从旁边的桌子上取了一本书，努力看进去。阿德拉把她的凳子搬到我跟前坐下。不久，她碰了一下我的膝盖。 Adele, who appeared to be still under the influence of a most solemnising impression, sat down, without a word, on the footstool I pointed out to her.I retired to a window seat, and taking a book from a table near, endeavoured to read.Adele brought her stool to my feet; ere long she touched my knee.
“阿德拉，怎么啦？” “What is it, Adele?”
“小姐，我可以从那些漂亮的花儿中拿一朵吗？这样我的装束就更美了。” “Est-ce que je ne puis pas prendrie une seule de ces fleurs magnifiques, mademoiselle?Seulement pour completer ma toilette.”
“阿德拉，你太注意你的打扮啦，但是你可以要一朵花。”我从花瓶里取出一支玫瑰花，系在她的腰带上。她舒了口气，有种不易察觉的满足感，就像她的幸福之杯现在已经满了一样。我转过脸，想要掩饰我的忍俊不禁，这个法国小姑娘对装束诚挚、与生俱来的钟爱有点可笑，又有点可怜。 “You think too much of your ‘toilette,’ Adele: but you may have a flower.”And I took a rose from a vase and fastened it in her sash.She sighed a sigh of ineffable satisfaction, as if her cup of happiness were now full.I turned my face away to conceal a smile I could not suppress: there was something ludicrous as well as painful in the little Parisienne’s earnest and innate devotion to matters of dress.
这时，一阵离席的柔声传来，拱门上的帷幔拉开了，餐厅出现在眼前，长桌上摆满丰盛的甜点，屋里的亮光映照在银器和玻璃杯上。一群女士站在门口，她们进来了，帷幔在她们身后落下。 A soft sound of rising now became audible; the curtain was swept back from the arch; through it appeared the dining room, with its lit lustre pouring down light on the silver and glass of a magnificent dessert service covering a long table; a band of ladies stood in the opening; they entered, and the curtain fell behind them.
她们只有八位，但不知为何，她们簇拥进来时，看起来好像远远不止八人。她们中有些人身材高挑，大都身着白色衣服。她们的晚服都摆幅较大，这样使整个人也显得大了一些，就像月亮在迷雾中显得大了一些一样。我起身向她们行礼，有一两位女士对我点头以示回礼，其他的只是盯着我看。 There were but eight; yet, somehow, as they flocked in, they gave the impression of a much larger number.Some of them were very tall; many were dressed in white; and all had sweeping amplitude of array that seemed to magnify their persons as a mist magnifies the moon.I rose and curtseyed to them: one or two bent their heads in return; the others only stared at me.
她们在房间里分散开来，轻盈欢快的动作让我想起了一群白羽翩翩的鸟儿。她们有些半倚在沙发或软垫椅子上，有些俯身看桌子上的花和书，其余人围着火炉坐在一起谈论，声音低却清晰。她们似乎对此习以为常。我后来才知道她们的名字，但现在可以先提一下。 They dispersed about the room, reminding me, by the lightness and buoyancy of their movements, of a flock of white plumy birds.Some of them threw themselves in half reclining positions on the sofas and ottomans: some bent over the tables and examined the flowers and books: the rest gathered in a group round the fire: all talked in a low but clear tone which seemed habitual to them.I knew their names afterwards, and may as well mention them now.
首先是埃希顿太太和她的两个女儿。显然，她以前一定很漂亮，现在也风韵犹存。她的大女儿埃米身材娇小，从相貌和举止上看都很幼稚、天真，非常活泼开朗。她白色的平纹细布裙子和蓝色的腰带相得益彰。小女儿路易莎，身材更高，也更优雅，容貌秀美，正如法语中所说的“少女娇媚的脸庞”，两姐妹都像百合一样俊俏。 First, there was Mrs. Eshton and two of her daughters.She had evidently been a handsome woman, and was well preserved still.Of her daughters, the eldest, Amy, was rather little: naive, and childlike in face and manner, and piquant in form; her white muslin dress and blue sash became her well.The second, Louisa, was taller and more elegant in figure; with a very pretty face, of that order the French term minois chiffone: both sisters were fair as lilies.
林恩女士大约四十岁，身材高大肥胖，身板笔直，看起来很傲慢。她身着盛装，穿了一件大放异彩的绸缎礼服。她头上戴了一个宝石头箍，暗色的头发在一支天蓝色羽毛的掩映下闪闪发亮。 Lady Lynn was a large and stout personage of about forty, very erect, very haughty looking, richly dressed in a satin robe of changeful sheen: her dark hair shone glossily under the shade of an azure plume, and within the circlet of a band of gems.
登特上校太太没那么引人注目，但我觉得她更贤淑高贵。她身材瘦小，脸色苍白文雅，发色金黄。她黑色的绸缎裙子，鲜艳、具有异国风情的蕾丝披肩以及她的珍珠饰物，比那位有爵位的贵妇彩虹般光彩照人的形象更让我感到愉悦。 Mrs. Colonel Dent was less showy; but, I thought, more ladylike.She had a slight figure, a pale, gentle face, and fair hair.Her black satin dress, her scarf of rich foreign lace, and her pearl ornaments, pleased me better than the rainbow radiance of the titled dame.
但是，最与众不同的三个人——也许是因为她们是这些人中个头最高的——是遗孀贵妇英格拉姆太太和她的女儿布兰奇和玛丽。她们三个算是女士中个子最高的了。英格拉姆太太大约四五十岁，身材还很苗条，头发（至少在烛光下）依然乌黑，牙齿显然还很完美。大多数人会觉得她是这个年龄中的大美女。无疑，从外形来看，她确实很美。但她的举止神情中有一些让人难以忍受的傲慢。她的面容酷似罗马人，双下巴连向柱子似的脖颈。在我看来，她这副嘴脸不仅因为骄傲显得臃肿、暗淡，而且还皱纹满面。同样，她骄傲挺起的下巴挺直地有些不可思议。她的眼睛同样尖刻严厉，让我想起了里德太太的眼眸。她说话时总是装腔作势，音调深沉，语句夸张，口气专横——一句话，让人无法忍受。深红色的天鹅绒袍子和由含金的印度织物制成的披肩式头巾为她注入了（我想她这么觉得）一种真正的皇家尊贵。 But the three most distinguished—partly, perhaps, because the tallest figures of the band—were the Dowager Lady Ingram and her daughters, Blanche and Mary.They were all three of the loftiest stature of women.The Dowager might be between forty and fifty: her shape was still fine; her hair (by candlelight at least) still black; her teeth, too, were still apparently perfect.Most people would have termed her a splendid woman of her age: and so she was, no doubt, physically speaking; but then there was an expression of almost insupportable haughtiness in her bearing and countenance.She had Roman features and a double chin, disappearing into a throat like a pillar: these features appeared to me not only inflated and darkened, but even furrowed with pride; and the chin was sustained by the same principle, in a position of almost preternatural erectness.She had, likewise, a fierce and a hard eye: it reminded me of Mrs. Reed’s; she mouthed her words in speaking; her voice was deep, its inflections very pompous, very dogmatical,—very intolerable, in short.A crimson velvet robe, and a shawl turban of some gold wrought Indian fabric, invested her (I suppose she thought) with a truly imperial dignity.
布兰奇和玛丽体型相当——像白杨一样高大挺直。玛丽有些偏瘦，但布兰奇却宛如月亮女神戴安。我看着她，当然，带着更特殊的兴趣。第一，我想看看她的相貌是否与费尔法克斯太太的描述相符；第二，我想看看她是否与我为她画的精美画像相像；第三——就要知道真相了——她是否像我想的那样符合罗切斯特先生的品位。 Blanche and Mary were of equal stature,—straight and tall as poplars.Mary was too slim for her height, but Blanche was moulded like a Dian.I regarded her, of course, with special interest.First, I wished to see whether her appearance accorded with Mrs. Fairfax’s description; secondly, whether it at all resembled the fancy miniature I had painted of her; and thirdly—it will out!—whether it were such as I should fancy likely to suit Mr. Rochester’s taste.
就外表来看，她的相貌与我笔下的画像和费尔法克斯太太的描述都很相符。丰满的胸部，瘦削的肩头，优雅的脖颈，深色的眼睛和乌黑的发卷，样样具备——但是，她的脸庞呢？她的脸像她母亲的一样，只是更年轻，没有皱纹而已。同样低低的额头，同样的高调的五官，同样的傲气。然而，她的傲气却并不沉默寡言！她不停地笑着，笑声里夹杂着讽刺，她习惯性弯起高傲的嘴唇，这个表情也同样带着讽刺的意味。 As far as person went, she answered point for point, both to my picture and Mrs. Fairfax’s description.The noble bust, the sloping shoulders, the graceful neck, the dark eyes and black ringlets were all there;—but her face?Her face was like her mother’s; a youthful unfurrowed likeness: the same low brow, the same high features, the same pride.It was not, however, so saturnine a pride!she laughed continually; her laugh was satirical, and so was the habitual expression of her arched and haughty lip.
人们常说天才是自知自觉的。我不确定英格拉姆小姐是否是个天才，但她是自知自觉的——非常自知自觉。她与文雅的登特太太谈起了植物学。登特太太似乎没有研究过这门学问，但她说自己喜欢花，“特别是野花。”英格拉姆小姐却学过，她卖弄地讲起植物学的词汇。我发现她（用地方话说）正对登特太太“围追堵截”，即玩弄她的无知——也许她的做法很聪明，但肯定没安好心。她弹琴，技法精湛；她唱歌，音色优美；她单独给她母亲讲法语，讲得很好，流利且口音纯正。 Genius is said to be self-conscious.I cannot tell whether Miss Ingram was a genius, but she was self-conscious—remarkably self-conscious indeed.She entered into a discourse on botany with the gentle Mrs. Dent.It seemed Mrs. Dent had not studied that science: though, as she said, she liked flowers, “especially wild ones;” Miss Ingram had, and she ran over its vocabulary with an air.I presently perceived she was (what is vernacularly termed) TRAILING Mrs. Dent; that is, playing on her ignorance—her TRAIL might be clever, but it was decidedly not good-natured.She played: her execution was brilliant; she sang: her voice was fine; she talked French apart to her mamma; and she talked it well, with fluency and with a good accent.
玛丽比布兰奇面相更温柔也更开朗，她五官的轮廓更柔和，肤色也更白（英格拉姆小姐的肤色黑得像西班牙人）——但是，玛丽不够有生机，面无表情，眼神呆滞。她不善言谈，坐下后就像壁龛里的一尊雕像一样纹丝不动。两姐妹都穿的一身雪白。 Mary had a milder and more open countenance than Blanche; softer features too, and a skin some shades fairer (Miss Ingram was dark as a Spaniard)—but Mary was deficient in life: her face lacked expression, her eye lustre; she had nothing to say, and having once taken her seat, remained fixed like a statue in its niche.The sisters were both attired in spotless white.
现在我还觉得英格拉姆小姐是罗切斯特先生会选择的对象吗？我不知道——我不知道他在女性美方面的品位。如果他喜欢高贵，那么她恰好属于这一类——而且她颇有才艺，活泼可爱。我想大部分绅士都对她心怀仰慕，罗切斯特先生也的确仰慕她，我似乎已经找到了证据，要消除最后一片疑云，只需看看他们在一起的样子了。 And did I now think Miss Ingram such a choice as Mr. Rochester would be likely to make?I could not tell—I did not know his taste in female beauty.If he liked the majestic, she was the very type of majesty: then she was accomplished, sprightly.Most gentlemen would admire her, I thought; and that he DID admire her, I already seemed to have obtained proof: to remove the last shade of doubt, it remained but to see them together.
读者朋友，你可不能认为阿德拉此时正一动不动地坐在我脚旁的凳子上。不是的，女士们进来时，她起身迎上去，恭敬地行了个礼，一本正经地说—— You are not to suppose, reader, that Adele has all this time been sitting motionless on the stool at my feet: no; when the ladies entered, she rose, advanced to meet them, made a stately reverence, and said with gravity—
“女士们好。” “Bon jour, mesdames.”
英格拉姆小姐低头嘲讽地望着她，喊道：“噢，小玩偶！” And Miss Ingram had looked down at her with a mocking air, and exclaimed, “Oh, what a little puppet!”
林恩女士说：“我想这个小东西就是罗切斯特先生的被监护对象——他提到过这个法国小姑娘。” Lady Lynn had remarked, “It is Mr. Rochester’s ward, I suppose—the little French girl he was speaking of.”
登特太太善意地拉起她的手，吻了一下。 Mrs. Dent had kindly taken her hand, and given her a kiss.
埃米和路易莎·埃希顿异口同声地惊叫——“多可爱的小孩！” Amy and Louisa Eshton had cried out simultaneously—“What a love of a child!”
然后，她们就让她坐到沙发上，她现在就在那儿，坐在她们中间，交替着用法语和结结巴巴的英语唠叨呢。她不仅吸引了年轻女士的注意力，而且引起了埃希顿太太和林恩女士的注意，心里溢满了受宠的满足。 And then they had called her to a sofa, where she now sat, ensconced between them, chattering alternately in French and broken English; absorbing not only the young ladies’ attention, but that of Mrs. Eshton and Lady Lynn, and getting spoilt to her heart’s content.
终于，咖啡端进来了，绅士们聚集到了一起。我坐在阴影下——如果这个灯火明亮的房间里有阴影的话。窗帘遮住了我的半个身子。拱门的帷幔再次掀起，他们进来了。和先前女士们进来时一样，绅士们的集体亮相也气势恢宏。他们都身着黑装，多数都身材高大，有的还很年轻。亨利和弗雷德里克·林恩的确是非常浮华的花花公子，登特上校有着杰出军人的气质。这个地区的官员埃希顿先生很有绅士修养。他的头发已经花白，但眉毛和胡须还是黑的，这使他看起来有点像“剧院里尊贵的老人”。英格拉姆勋爵像他的姐妹一样，个子很高，也很帅气。但是，他的神情和玛丽一样冷漠、无精打采。似乎他虽四肢修长，却缺乏血气方刚的生命力或脑力。 At last coffee is brought in, and the gentlemen are summoned.I sit in the shade—if any shade there be in this brilliantly lit apartment; the window curtain half hides me.Again the arch yawns; they come.The collective appearance of the gentlemen, like that of the ladies, is very imposing: they are all costumed in black; most of them are tall, some young.Henry and Frederick Lynn are very dashing sparks indeed; and Colonel Dent is a fine soldierly man.Mr. Eshton, the magistrate of the district, is gentlemanlike: his hair is quite white, his eyebrows and whiskers still dark, which gives him something of the appearance of a “pere noble de theatre.”Lord Ingram, like his sisters, is very tall; like them, also, he is handsome; but he shares Mary’s apathetic and listless look: he seems to have more length of limb than vivacity of blood or vigour of brain.
罗切斯特先生在哪呢？ And where is Mr. Rochester?
后来，他终于来了。我并没有看向拱门，但我知道他进来了。我努力把精力集中于针孔，我正编织的网眼钱包——我希望心里想的只有手里的活计，放在腿上的珠子和银线。然而，我清楚地看到了他，自然而然地回忆起我上次见到他时的情景。就在我给了他，他所谓的重要帮助后，他握着我的手，低头看着我的脸，注视着我，眼中流露出满得要溢出的深情，我当时也沉浸在这种感情里。那一刻，我离他有多近呀！但之后又发生了什么，让他和我的相对位置发生了变化？而现在，我们之间又是多么生疏，多么冷淡！这种遥远的距离感使我不期望他走过来与我交谈。我并不奇怪，他看都没看我一眼，就在房间的另一边坐下，开始与一些女士们谈话。“带阿德拉去上床，过了她睡觉的时间了。”我一看到他全身心地聊着，知道可以不引起注意地注视他，我的目光就本能地落到他的脸上。我无法控制，眼皮抬起，眼珠就定格在了他的身上。我看着他，从中体会到了敏锐的快感——一种珍贵而尖刻的快感，如纯金一般，又有着尖刻的痛苦，这种快感就像一个行将渴死的人，虽然他明知自己爬向的是下了毒的泉水，但还是会义无反顾地俯身畅饮这神圣之水。 He comes in last: I am not looking at the arch, yet I see him enter.I try to concentrate my attention on those netting needles, on the meshes of the purse I am forming—I wish to think only of the work I have in my hands, to see only the silver beads and silk threads that lie in my lap; whereas, I distinctly behold his figure, and I inevitably recall the moment when I last saw it;just after I had rendered him, what he deemed, an essential service, and he, holding my hand, and looking down on my face, surveyed me with eyes that revealed a heart full and eager to overflow; in whose emotions I had a part.How near had I approached him at that moment!What had occurred since, calculated to change his and my relative positions?Yet now, how distant, how far estranged we were!So far estranged, that I did not expect him to come and speak to me.I did not wonder, when, without looking at me, he took a seat at the other side of the room, and began conversing with some of the ladies.“To put Adele to bed: it is past her bedtime.”No sooner did I see that his attention was riveted on them, and that I might gaze without being observed, than my eyes were drawn involuntarily to his face; I could not keep their lids under control: they would rise, and the irids would fix on him.I looked, and had an acute pleasure in looking,—a precious yet poignant pleasure; pure gold, with a steely point of agony: a pleasure like what the thirst perishing man might feel who knows the well to which he has crept is poisoned, yet stoops and drinks divine draughts nevertheless.
“情人眼里出西施”，的确如此。主人那苍白的、橄榄色的脸，又大又方的额头，宽阔浓黑的眉毛，深沉的眼睛，凸显的五官，坚挺冷酷的嘴——充满了能量、果断、意志——按一般的标准，他的面貌并不帅气；但在我看来，他已经超越了帅气，成了一种可以将我控制的兴趣和影响力——使我无力掌控自己的感情，而是为他的力量所羁绊。我不想爱上他，读者都知道我已经努力将对他的爱之萌芽驱逐出我的灵魂，但现在，当我再见他时的第一眼，那些嫩芽便自动出现，又绿又茁壮！他无须看我一眼，就使我爱上了他。 Most true is it that “beauty is in the eye of the gazer.”My master’s colourless, olive face, square, massive brow, broad and jetty eyebrows, deep eyes, strong features, firm, grim mouth,—all energy, decision, will,—were not beautiful, according to rule; but they were more than beautiful to me; they were full of an interest, an influence that quite mastered me,—that took my feelings from my own power and fettered them in his.I had not intended to love him; the reader knows I had wrought hard to extirpate from my soul the germs of love there detected; and now, at the first renewed view of him, they spontaneously arrived, green and strong!He made me love him without looking at me.
我将他与其他客人比较。与他天真的本性和真正的力量相比，林恩兄弟的殷勤优雅，英格拉姆勋爵的儒雅之气——甚至登特上校独特的军人气质又有什么呢？我丝毫不为他们的外貌，他们的表情所动，但是我可以想象大多数在场的人都会认为他们很有魅力、帅气、不可抗拒，而会立即认为罗切斯特先生粗犷忧郁。我看着他们轻轻微笑、放声大笑——这些都无所谓；烛光的灵魂都可与他们的微笑相比，叮当的铃声也充满他们大笑的意味。我看着罗切斯特微笑——他坚硬的脸柔和了，眼睛闪动着亮光，更温柔了，眼神敏锐而甜美。他正在和路易莎和埃米·埃希顿讲话。她们平静地看着那张让我穿透我心扉的脸，这让我有些不解。我以为会看到她们眼睛低垂，脸颊羞红，但我很高兴发现她们根本无动于衷。“她们对他的感觉和我对他的感觉不同，”我想，“他和她们不是同一类人。我相信并确定他和我是同一类人——他让我感到亲切——我懂他的一颦一笑和一举一动。虽然我们的等级和财富相差甚远，但我的心中和思想中，血液中和神经中有一种东西让我在精神上将我与他同化。我几天前不是说过，除了接受他的薪水外与他毫不相干吗？我不是让自己只把他当作我的雇主，禁止对他有别的想法了吗？真是亵渎天性！我所有美好的、真实的、强烈的感情都不可抵挡地围绕在他周围。我知道我必须隐藏自己的感情，必须抹杀希望；必须记住他不会那么在乎我。因为我说我们是同一类人时，并不是指我也有他的影响力和吸引人的魅力。我只是想说我们的某些品位和感情相似。所以，我必须不停地重复，我们永远都是被隔开的——但是，只要我还活着，还能思考，我就一定爱他。” I compared him with his guests.What was the gallant grace of the Lynns, the languid elegance of Lord Ingram,—even the military distinction of Colonel Dent, contrasted with his look of native pith and genuine power?I had no sympathy in their appearance, their expression: yet I could imagine that most observers would call them attractive, handsome, imposing; while they would pronounce Mr. Rochester at once harsh featured and melancholy looking.I saw them smile, laugh—it was nothing; the light of the candles had as much soul in it as their smile; the tinkle of the bell as much significance as their laugh.I saw Mr. Rochester smile:—his stern features softened; his eye grew both brilliant and gentle, its ray both searching and sweet.He was talking, at the moment, to Louisa and Amy Eshton.I wondered to see them receive with calm that look which seemed to me so penetrating: I expected their eyes to fall, their colour to rise under it; yet I was glad when I found they were in no sense moved.“He is not to them what he is to me,” I thought: “he is not of their kind.I believe he is of mine;—I am sure he is—I feel akin to him—I understand the language of his countenance and movements: though rank and wealth sever us widely, I have something in my brain and heart, in my blood and nerves, that assimilates me mentally to him.Did I say, a few days since, that I had nothing to do with him but to receive my salary at his hands?Did I forbid myself to think of him in any other light than as a paymaster?Blasphemy against nature!Every good, true, vigorous feeling I have gathers impulsively round him.I know I must conceal my sentiments: I must smother hope; I must remember that he cannot care much for me.For when I say that I am of his kind, I do not mean that I have his force to influence, and his spell to attract; I mean only that I have certain tastes and feelings in common with him.I must, then, repeat continually that we are for ever sundered:—and yet, while I breathe and think, I must love him.”
咖啡端上来了。绅士们进来后，女士们开始变得如百灵鸟般活跃，谈话更活泼愉快。登特上校和埃希顿先生在争论政治问题，他们的太太在听着。林恩太太和英格拉姆太太这两位高傲的遗孀正在互诉心声。乔治爵士——顺便说一下，我忘了描述他了——是一位身材高大、精神饱满的乡绅。他站在沙发前，手里端了一杯咖啡，不时插上一两句话。弗雷德里克·林恩先生在玛丽·英格拉姆身边坐下，正向她展示一本装帧精美的书上的图画。她看着，时而微笑，但显然说话不多。高大冷淡的英格拉姆勋爵双臂交叉抱在胸前，倚着埃米·埃希顿的椅背。娇小活泼的埃米正看着他，像鹪鹩一样喋喋不休。与罗切斯特先生相比，她更喜欢英格拉姆勋爵。亨利·林恩在路易莎脚旁坐下，与阿德拉共用一个脚凳。他正试着用法语与阿德拉交谈，一出错就遭到路易莎的嘲笑。布兰奇·英格拉姆和谁在一起呢？她正独自站在桌子前，优雅地俯身看一个相册。她似乎在等别人主动找她，但不愿久等，就为自己选了个伴儿。 Coffee is handed.The ladies, since the gentlemen entered, have become lively as larks; conversation waxes brisk and merry.Colonel Dent and Mr. Eshton argue on politics; their wives listen.The two proud dowagers, Lady Lynn and Lady Ingram, confabulate together.Sir George—whom, by-the-bye, I have forgotten to describe,—a very big, and very fresh looking country gentleman, stands before their sofa, coffee cup in hand, and occasionally puts in a word.Mr. Frederick Lynn has taken a seat beside Mary Ingram, and is showing her the engravings of a splendid volume: she looks, smiles now and then, but apparently says little.The tall and phlegmatic Lord Ingram leans with folded arms on the chair back of the little and lively Amy Eshton; she glances up at him, and chatters like a wren: she likes him better than she does Mr. Rochester.Henry Lynn has taken possession of an ottoman at the feet of Louisa: Adele shares it with him: he is trying to talk French with her, and Louisa laughs at his blunders.With whom will Blanche Ingram pair?She is standing alone at the table, bending gracefully over an album.She seems waiting to be sought; but she will not wait too long: she herself selects a mate.
罗切斯特先生和埃希顿们谈话结束后，独自站在壁炉旁，像布兰奇一样无人陪伴。于是，她过去与他搭话，站到壁炉的另一边。 Mr. Rochester, having quitted the Eshtons, stands on the hearth as solitary as she stands by the table: she confronts him, taking her station on the opposite side of the mantelpiece.
“罗切斯特先生，我以为你不喜欢孩子呢？” “Mr. Rochester, I thought you were not fond of children?”
“我不喜欢。” “Nor am I.”
“那么你为什么要照顾那个小玩偶呢？”（她指着阿德拉。）“你从哪儿捡的？” “Then, what induced you to take charge of such a little doll as that?” (pointing to Adele).“Where did you pick her up?”
“不是捡的，别人把她交给了我。” “I did not pick her up; she was left on my hands.”
“你应该把她送学校去。” “You should have sent her to school.”
“我付不起费用，学费太贵了。” “I could not afford it: schools are so dear.”
“呃，我想你给她请了家庭教师。我刚才看到她身边有个人——她走了吗？噢，没有！她还在那儿呢，在窗帘后面。你当然要付给她工资，我想这样同样很贵——甚至花得更多，因为你还要养活她们两个人。” “Why, I suppose you have a governess for her: I saw a person with her just now—is she gone?Oh, no! there she is still, behind the window curtain.You pay her, of course; I should think it quite as expensive,—more so; for you have them both to keep in addition.”
我怕——或者该说，我希望？——布兰奇提到我后，罗切斯特先生会往我这边看，就不自觉地向阴影处挪了挪，但他根本没有转移视线。 I feared—or should I say, hoped?—the allusion to me would make Mr. Rochester glance my way; and I involuntarily shrank farther into the shade: but he never turned his eyes.
“我还没考虑过这个问题。”他漠然地说，直直地望着前方。 “I have not considered the subject,” said he indifferently, looking straight before him.
“对，你们男人从来不考虑花费和常理。你应该听我母亲是如何看待家庭教师问题的，我和玛丽，我想，一共请了至少一打家庭教师，一半都很令人讨厌，剩下的都很不可理喻。她们都是妖魔——是不是，妈妈？” “No, you men never do consider economy and common sense.You should hear mama on the chapter of governesses: Mary and I have had, I should think, a dozen at least in our day; half of them detestable and the rest ridiculous, and all incubi—were they not, mama?”
“你刚刚说什么，我的宝贝？” “Did you speak, my own?”
这位被遗孀称作自己专有财产的年轻小姐，又重复了一遍自己的问题，还解释了一番。 The young lady thus claimed as the dowager’s special property, reiterated her question with an explanation.
“我最亲爱的宝贝，别提家庭教师了，我听到就心烦。她们不称职又任性，我真是受够了。谢天谢地，我现在不用与她们打交道了！” “My dearest, don’t mention governesses; the word makes me nervous.I have suffered a martyrdom from their incompetency and caprice.I thank Heaven I have now done with them!”
登特太太俯身在这位虔诚的夫人耳边轻声说了些什么。根据后面的回答，我想登特太太是在提醒她，房间里有一位就来自她正诅咒的人群。 Mrs. Dent here bent over to the pious lady and whispered something in her ear; I suppose, from the answer elicited, it was a reminder that one of the anathematised race was present.
“算啦！”这位尊贵的太太说，“我希望这能对她有些好处！”接着，她放低了声音，但我依然可以听见，“我看到她了，我会看面相。从她的面相里我可以看到她那一类人所有的缺点。” “Tant pis!”said her Ladyship, “I hope it may do her good!”Then, in a lower tone, but still loud enough for me to hear, “I noticed her; I am a judge of physiognomy, and in hers I see all the faults of her class.”
“什么缺点，夫人？”罗切斯特先生大声地问。 “What are they, madam?”inquired Mr. Rochester aloud.
“我等私下里再告诉你。”她回答说，还意味深长地把头巾摇了三下。 “I will tell you in your private ear,” replied she, wagging her turban three times with portentous significancy.
“但到那时我的好奇心就会没胃口了，它现在就需要食物。” “But my curiosity will be past its appetite; it craves food now.”
“问布兰奇吧，她离你更近。” “Ask Blanche; she is nearer you than I.”
“噢，别让他问我，妈妈！对于那类人，我只有一句话，她们很讨厌。她们并没让我受多少委屈，我是注意扭转局面。我和西奥多曾经如何玩弄威尔逊小姐和格雷太太，还有朱伯特夫人来着！玛丽经常犯困，没精神和我们一起谋划。最有趣的是捉弄朱伯特夫人，威尔逊小姐是个可怜的病秧子，哭哭啼啼的，还无精打采，总之就是不值得费劲儿折腾她。格雷太太粗俗不堪又麻木不仁，对什么打击都毫无反应。但可怜的朱伯特夫人！我现在还记得我们把她逼到极限时，她大发雷霆——弄洒我们的茶，捣碎我们的面包和黄油，把我们的书往天花板上扔，折腾尺子、桌子、火炉围栏和用具等等。西奥多，你还记得那些快乐的日子吗？” “Oh, don’t refer him to me, mama!I have just one word to say of the whole tribe; they are a nuisance.Not that I ever suffered much from them; I took care to turn the tables.What tricks Theodore and I used to play on our Miss Wilsons, and Mrs. Greys, and Madame Jouberts!Mary was always too sleepy to join in a plot with spirit.The best fun was with Madame Joubert: Miss Wilson was a poor sickly thing, lachrymose and low-spirited, not worth the trouble of vanquishing, in short; and Mrs. Grey was coarse and insensible; no blow took effect on her.But poor Madame Joubert!I see her yet in her raging passions, when we had driven her to extremities—spilt our tea, crumbled our bread and butter, tossed our books up to the ceiling, and played a charivari with the ruler and desk, the fender and fire irons.Theodore, do you remember those merry days?”
“是——啊，我当然记得，”英格拉姆勋爵慢吞吞地说，“那个可怜的老东西常常哭喊‘噢，你们这些淘气的孩子！’——然后我们就教育她一番，说她自己那么无知还想来教我们这些聪明的小姐公子。” “Yaas, to be sure I do,” drawled Lord Ingram; “and the poor old stick used to cry out ‘Oh you villains childs!’—and then we sermonised her on the presumption of attempting to teach such clever blades as we were, when she was herself so ignorant.”
“我们的确是这样。而且，西多，我还帮你告发（或是迫害）你的老师，面如乳清的瓦伊宁先生——我们当时叫他‘病鬼牧师’。他和威尔逊小姐胆敢坠入爱河——至少我和西多这么认为；我们看到他们各种柔情对视和叹息，并将其理解为‘爱情’，当然了，大家很快就从我们的发现中受益了。我们把这当作将这两个负担驱逐出家门的杠杆。亲爱的妈妈，她觉察到一点蛛丝马迹，就发现这违背道德。是不是，我的母亲大人？” “We did; and, Tedo, you know, I helped you in prosecuting (or persecuting) your tutor, whey faced Mr. Vining—the parson in the pip, as we used to call him.He and Miss Wilson took the liberty of falling in love with each other—at least Tedo and I thought so; we surprised sundry tender glances and sighs which we interpreted as tokens of ‘la belle passion,’ and I promise you the public soon had the benefit of our discovery; we employed it as a sort of lever to hoist our deadweights from the house.Dear mama, there, as soon as she got an inkling of the business, found out that it was of an immoral tendency.Did you not, my lady mother?”
“当然了，我最好的女儿。根据后面发生的事，我是正确的。有成千上万的理由证明在守规守矩的家里，家庭女教师和男教师的私通不可容忍。首先——” “Certainly, my best.And I was quite right: depend on that: there are a thousand reasons why liaisons between governesses and tutors should never be tolerated a moment in any well regulated house; firstly—”
“噢，天哪，妈妈！别再让我们听您的列举啦！再说，我们都明白，会为纯洁的童年树立危险的坏榜样；双方会分散注意力，结果导致玩忽职守——互相结成同盟战线，激发自信和傲慢——会发起反抗和冲突爆发。请问英格拉姆庄园的英格拉姆男爵夫人，我说的对吗？” “Oh, gracious, mama!Spare us the enumeration!Au reste, we all know them: danger of bad example to innocence of childhood; distractions and consequent neglect of duty on the part of the attached—mutual alliance and reliance; confidence thence resulting—insolence accompanying—mutiny and general blowup.Am I right, Baroness Ingram, of Ingram Park?”
“我的百合花，你说的对，你一直是对的。” “My lily flower, you are right now, as always.”
“那么就不用再说这个了，换个话题。” “Then no more need be said: change the subject.”
埃米·埃希顿或是没有听到或是没有留意这个命令，用她温柔稚嫩的声音说：“我和路易莎也曾考验我们的老师，但她实在太好了，什么都能承受，怎么做都不生气。她从来不对我们发火，是吧，路易莎？” Amy Eshton, not hearing or not heeding this dictum, joined in with her soft, infantine tone: “Louisa and I used to quiz our governess too; but she was such a good creature, she would bear anything: nothing put her out.She was never cross with us; was she, Louisa?”
“不，从不。我们可以为所欲为。我们从她的桌子上和针线盒里任意劫掠，还把她的抽屉翻了个底朝上，但她脾气很好，不管我们要什么，她都给我们。” “No, never: we might do what we pleased; ransack her desk and her workbox, and turn her drawers inside out; and she was so good-natured, she would give as anything we asked for.”
“我想，现在，”英格拉姆小姐翘着嘴唇讽刺地说，“我们要给现存的所有家庭女教师写个回忆录的摘要了。为了避免这个灾难发生，我要再次提议引入一个新话题。罗切斯特先生，您同意我的提议吗？” “I suppose, now,” said Miss Ingram, curling her lip sarcastically, “we shall have an abstract of the memoirs of all the governesses extant: in order to avert such a visitation, I again move the introduction of a new topic.Mr. Rochester, do you second my motion?”
“小姐，我赞成您的观点，您的任何观点。” “Madam, I support you on this point, as on every other.”
“那么我就负责把我们的谈话继续下去吧。爱德华多阁下，你今晚可以唱歌吗？” “Then on me be the onus of bringing it forward.Signior Eduardo, are you in voice tonight?”
“比央卡小姐，只要您下令，我就唱。” “Donna Bianca, if you command it, I will be.”
“那好，阁下。我下令你清一清你的肺和其他发音器官，因为我要它们为我这个女王效劳。” “Then, signior, I lay on you my sovereign behest to furbish up your lungs and other vocal organs, as they will be wanted on my royal service.”
“有这样一位神圣的女王玛丽，谁不愿意当里丘呢？” “Who would not be the Rizzio of so divine a Mary?”
“里丘有什么了不起！”她叫道，甩着满头的卷发向钢琴走去。“我觉得提琴手戴维一定是个平淡的家伙；我更喜欢皮肤黝黑的博斯·威尔。我认为，一个男人若没有一点邪恶，那他就一无是处。不管历史如何评判詹姆斯·赫伯恩，我自有主张。他正是那种我愿意以身相许的野性、凶狠、恶棍式的英雄。” “A fig for Rizzio!” cried she, tossing her head with all its curls, as she moved to the piano.“It is my opinion the fiddler David must have been an insipid sort of fellow; I like black Bothwell better: to my mind a man is nothing without a spice of the devil in him;and history may say what it will of James Hepburn, but I have a notion, he was just the sort of wild, fierce, bandit hero whom I could have consented to gift with my hand.”
“听听，绅士们！你们谁最像博斯·威尔？”罗切斯特先生大喊道。 “Gentlemen, you hear!Now which of you most resembles Bothwell?” cried Mr. Rochester.
“我觉得你最像。”登特上校回答。 “I should say the preference lies with you,” responded Colonel Dent.
“啊，我的荣幸，我对您感激不尽。”罗切斯特先生答道。 “On my honour, I am much obliged to you,” was the reply.
英格拉姆小姐带着女王的气势拎起她雪白的裙子，优雅骄傲地在钢琴前坐下，开始了一曲技艺高超的序曲，同时还讲着话。她今晚显得趾高气扬，言语和气场不仅志在赢得听众的赞美，而且还要让他们感到震惊。显然，她要用自己的活泼和勇气来感染他们。 Miss Ingram, who had now seated herself with proud grace at the piano, spreading out her snowy robes in queenly amplitude, commenced a brilliant prelude; talking meantime.She appeared to be on her high horse tonight; both her words and her air seemed intended to excite not only the admiration, but the amazement of her auditors: she was evidently bent on striking them as something very dashing and daring indeed.
“噢，现在的年轻人真让我厌烦！”她弹着琴大喊道。“可怜软弱的东西，不能离开爸爸庄园大门一步，没有妈妈的准许和保护也不行！他们把全部精力都放到保养漂亮的脸蛋、白嫩的双手、小巧的双脚，好像男人和美有什么关系一样！好像可爱不是女人的专权——她合法的领域和遗产一样！我承认一个丑陋的女人是造物主完美脸上的一个污点，但是让男士就只热衷于拥有力量与勇气吧，让打猎、射击、搏斗成为他们的座右铭吧，其他的都微不足道。我要是男人，就会谨遵这些规则。” “Oh, I am so sick of the young men of the present day!” exclaimed she, rattling away at the instrument.“Poor, puny things, not fit to stir a step beyond papa’s park gates: nor to go even so far without mama’s permission and guardianship!Creatures so absorbed in care about their pretty faces, and their white hands, and their small feet; as if a man had anything to do with beauty!As if loveliness were not the special prerogative of woman—her legitimate appanage and heritage!I grant an ugly WOMAN is a blot on the fair face of creation; but as to the GENTLEMEN, let them be solicitous to possess only strength and valour: let their motto be:—Hunt, shoot, and fight: the rest is not worth a fillip.Such should be my device, were I a man.”
她停顿了一下，没有人插话，就又接着说：“我要是结婚的话，我一定要让我的丈夫成为我的陪衬，而非对手。他不能和我竞争‘王位’，我要享有不可分割的尊敬，他对我的忠诚，不能与他镜中看到的那个人分享。罗切斯特先生，现在唱歌吧，我为你伴奏。” “Whenever I marry,” she continued after a pause which none interrupted, “I am resolved my husband shall not be a rival, but a foil to me.I will suffer no competitor near the throne; I shall exact an undivided homage: his devotions shall not be shared between me and the shape he sees in his mirror.Mr. Rochester, now sing, and I will play for you.”
“一切遵命。”罗切斯特先生回答。 “I am all obedience,” was the response.
“那就唱首海盗歌。要知道我最喜欢海盗歌了，所以要唱地精神饱满。” “Here then is a Corsair song.Know that I doat on Corsairs; and for that reason, sing it con spirito.”
“出自英格拉姆小姐的命令可以让一杯牛奶或一杯水都精神抖擞。” “Commands from Miss Ingram’s lips would put spirit into a mug of milk and water.”
“那要小心了，如果你唱得不如我意，我就要展示应该怎么唱，让你丢尽颜面。” “Take care, then: if you don’t please me, I will shame you by showing how such things SHOULD be done.”
“这是对无能的一种奖赏，现在我要努力失败了。” “That is offering a premium on incapacity: I shall now endeavour to fail.”
“认真听着！如果你故意出错，我会设定相应的惩罚。” “Gardez-vous en bien!If you err wilfully, I shall devise a proportionate punishment.”
“英格拉姆小姐要心存仁厚，因为她有能力施加常人难以承受的责罚。” “Miss Ingram ought to be clement, for she has it in her power to inflict a chastisement beyond mortal endurance.”
“哈！解释清楚！”英格拉姆小姐命令道。 “Ha! explain!” commanded the lady.
“请原谅，小姐。不需要有什么解释，您完美的理智会告诉自己，您的眉头皱一下，就足够抵得上死刑。” “Pardon me, madam: no need of explanation; your own fine sense must inform you that one of your frowns would be a sufficient substitute for capital punishment.”
“唱吧！”她说，开始用钢琴气宇轩昂地伴奏。 “Sing!”said she, and again touching the piano, she commenced an accompaniment in spirited style.
“现在我该溜走了，”我想，但是接下来听到的调子切断空气，紧紧抓住了我。费尔法克斯太太说过罗切斯特先生有一副好嗓子，的确是这样——他将自己的感情和力量融入圆润有力的男低音中，使这种声音穿过耳朵进入人的内心，奇特地唤醒人的感情。等到最后一个深沉饱满的颤音结束——等到消失了片刻的谈话又重新开始。我这才离开了隐身之处的角落，从侧门出去，很幸运离得很近。我走过一条通向大厅的狭窄通道时，发现我的凉鞋鞋带松了，于是我停下来，跪在楼梯口的垫子上系鞋带。我听到餐室的门开了，一位绅士从中走出。我匆忙站起身，他就在我对面，是罗切斯特先生。 “Now is my time to slip away,” thought I: but the tones that then severed the air arrested me.Mrs. Fairfax had said Mr. Rochester possessed a fine voice: he did—a mellow, powerful bass, into which he threw his own feeling, his own force; finding a way through the ear to the heart, and there waking sensation strangely.I waited till the last deep and full vibration had expired—till the tide of talk, checked an instant, had resumed its flow; I then quitted my sheltered corner and made my exit by the side door, which was fortunately near.Thence a narrow passage led into the hall: in crossing it, I perceived my sandal was loose; I stopped to tie it, kneeling down for that purpose on the mat at the foot of the staircase.I heard the dining room door unclose; a gentleman came out; rising hastily, I stood face to face with him: it was Mr. Rochester.
“你怎么样？”他问。 “How do you do?” he asked.
“我非常好，先生。” “I am very well, sir.”
“在屋里时你为什么不来和我说话呢？” “Why did you not come and speak to me in the room?”
我想我可以反问他这个问题，但我不愿那么放肆。我回答道—— I thought I might have retorted the question on him who put it: but I would not take that freedom.I answered—
“您看起来很忙，先生，我不想打扰您。” “I did not wish to disturb you, as you seemed engaged, sir.”
“我不在的时候你都做了什么？” “What have you been doing during my absence?”
“没什么特别的，像往常一样辅导阿德拉。” “Nothing particular; teaching Adele as usual.”
“你的脸色比之前更苍白了——我一眼就看出来了。怎么回事？” “And getting a good deal paler than you were—as I saw at first sight.What is the matter?”
“没什么，先生。” “Nothing at all, sir.”
“你差点淹死我的那天晚上受凉了吗？” “Did you take any cold that night you half drowned me?”
“一点也没有。” “Not she least.”
“回到客厅去，你离开得太早了。” “Return to the drawing room: you are deserting too early.”
“我累了，先生。” “I am tired, sir.”
他看了我一会儿。 He looked at me for a minute.
“还有些忧郁，”他说，“怎么了？告诉我。” “And a little depressed,” he said.“What about? Tell me."
“没事——没什么，先生。我没有忧郁。” “Nothing—nothing, sir.I am not depressed.”
“但是我确定你很忧郁，而且忧郁到几句话都能让你掉眼泪的程度——的确，你的眼泪正在眼眶里打转，闪亮的泪珠；一滴泪已经从睫毛上滑下，落到地上了。要是我有时间，要不是怕碰上哪个多嘴的仆人路过，我一定要弄个究竟。好吧，今晚我就原谅你。但你要明白，只要我的客人还在，你每晚都要到客厅去。这是我的愿望，不要无视它。你走吧，让苏菲来带走阿德拉。晚安，我的——”他停下了，咬着嘴唇，突然走开了。 “But I affirm that you are: so much depressed that a few more words would bring tears to your eyes—indeed, they are there now, shining and swimming; and a bead has slipped from the lash and fallen on to the flag.If I had time, and was not in mortal dread of some prating prig of a servant passing, I would know what all this means.Well, tonight I excuse you; but understand that so long as my visitors stay, I expect you to appear in the drawing room every evening; it is my wish; don’t neglect it.Now go, and send Sophie for Adele.Goodnight, my—” He stopped, bit his lip, and abruptly left me.
第十八章 CHAPTER XVIII
桑菲尔德的这些天既是欢乐的又是忙碌的，与我初来时在这儿度过的长达三个月的寂静、单调、孤独的日子是何等地不同！所有的悲伤情绪似乎都被从这个房子里驱逐出去了，所有的忧郁也都已经遗忘到脑后了，处处都是生机，每天都熙熙攘攘。现在，只要一穿过曾经空寂的走廊，或是进入曾经空荡的卧室区，就会遇上一个灵巧精明的侍女或是穿着时髦的随从。 Merry days were these at Thornfield Hall; and busy days too: how different from the first three months of stillness, monotony, and solitude I had passed beneath its roof!All sad feelings seemed now driven from the house, all gloomy associations forgotten: there was life everywhere, movement all day long.You could not now traverse the gallery, once so hushed, nor enter the front chambers, once so tenantless, without encountering a smart lady’s maid or a dandy valet.
厨房、备膳室、仆人的饭厅以及门厅也同样人头攒动。客厅只有在宜人春日里的蓝天以及和煦的阳光召唤客人到室外活动时，才会变得空荡幽静。即使天气不好，阴雨连绵长达数日，也不会使欢乐失色。不能到户外游乐只会让室内的娱乐更活泼、更多样。 The kitchen, the butler’s pantry, the servants’ hall, the entrance hall, were equally alive; and the saloons were only left void and still when the blue sky and halcyon sunshine of the genial spring weather called their occupants out into the grounds.Even when that weather was broken, and continuous rain set in for some days, no damp seemed cast over enjoyment: indoor amusements only became more lively and varied, in consequence of the stop put to outdoor gaiety.
他们第一个晚上提议要换一种娱乐形式时，我感到很迷惘。他们提到“猜字游戏”，但无知的我对此毫无了解。他们让仆人们进来，移走了餐室的桌子，重新布置了灯光，把椅子在拱门对面围成了一个半圆。罗切斯特先生和其他的绅士在指挥仆人忙活这些变动时，女士们正在楼上楼下跑来跑去，打铃使唤她们的侍女。费尔法克斯太太受命进来报告房子里披肩、裙子和各种布料的情况；三楼的一些衣橱也经过了一番搜寻，侍女们把锦缎加箍的裙子、缎子宽松上衣、黑色的时装、蕾丝垂饰等等抱下楼。然后经过一番挑选后，选中的服饰都送到了客厅里的化妆室。 I wondered what they were going to do the first evening a change of entertainment was proposed: they spoke of “playing charades,” but in my ignorance I did not understand the term.The servants were called in, the dining room tables wheeled away, the lights otherwise disposed, the chairs placed in a semicircle opposite the arch.While Mr. Rochester and the other gentlemen directed these alterations, the ladies were running up and down stairs ringing for their maids.Mrs. Fairfax was summoned to give information respecting the resources of the house in shawls, dresses, draperies of any kind; and certain wardrobes of the third storey were ransacked, and their contents, in the shape of brocaded and hooped petticoats, satin sacques, black modes, lace lappets, &c., were brought down in armfuls by the abigails;then a selection was made, and such things as were chosen were carried to the boudoir within the drawing room.
同时，罗切斯特先生又将女士们都召唤到身旁，从中选择自己的组员。“英格拉姆小姐当然是我这组，”他说。然后，他又点了埃希顿家的两位女士和登特太太。他看了看我，我当时恰好在他附近，正为登特太太扣上松开了的手镯钩子。 Meantime, Mr. Rochester had again summoned the ladies round him, and was selecting certain of their number to be of his party.“Miss Ingram is mine, of course,” said he: afterwards he named the two Misses Eshton, and Mrs. Dent.He looked at me: I happened to be near him, as I had been fastening the clasp of Mrs. Dent’s bracelet, which had got loose.
“你要玩吗？”他问道。我很怕他会坚持要我参加，所幸他没有。他允许我悄悄回到自己的老位子上去。 “Will you play?” he asked.I shook my head.He did not insist, which I rather feared he would have done; he allowed me to return quietly to my usual seat.
他和他的帮手退到了帷幔后面，以登特上校为首的另一组在围成半月形的椅子上坐下。埃希顿先生看着我，好像在提议邀请我加入他们，但英格拉姆夫人立即否定了这个提议。 He and his aids now withdrew behind the curtain: the other party, which was headed by Colonel Dent, sat down on the crescent of chairs.One of the gentlemen, Mr. Eshton, observing me, seemed to propose that I should be asked to join them; but Lady Ingram instantly negatived the notion.
“不行，”我听她说，“她看起来那么笨，肯定玩不了这种游戏。” “No,” I heard her say: “she looks too stupid for any game of the sort.”
不久，铃声响了，帷幔揭开。拱门里，只见罗切斯特先生挑中的大个子乔治·林恩爵士裹着一个白床单，他面前的桌子上放着一本打开的书。埃米·埃希顿站在他旁边，穿着罗切斯特先生的斗篷，手里拿着本书。一个不见身影的人欢快地摇响了铃铛，然后阿德拉（她坚持要和他的保护人一组）跳到前面，胳膊上挎了一个花篮，把花都散到身旁。接着出场的是华丽的英格拉姆小姐，一身雪白，头戴一块长长的面纱，额头绕着一圈玫瑰花环，罗切斯特先生在她身旁，两人并排走向桌子。他们跪了下来；此时登特太太和路易莎·埃希顿也各自一袭白衣出现，在他们俩身后站定。接着是一个哑剧形式的仪式，明显是一个婚礼的哑剧。结束时，登特上校和他的组员轻声讨论了两分钟，然后上校高声叫道—— Ere long a bell tinkled, and the curtain drew up.Within the arch, the bulky figure of Sir George Lynn, whom Mr. Rochester had likewise chosen, was seen enveloped in a white sheet: before him, on a table, lay open a large book; and at his side stood Amy Eshton, draped in Mr. Rochester’s cloak, and holding a book in her hand.Somebody, unseen, rang the bell merrily; then Adele (who had insisted on being one of her guardian’s party), bounded forward, scattering round her the contents of a basket of flowers she carried on her arm.Then appeared the magnificent figure of Miss Ingram, clad in white, a long veil on her head, and a wreath of roses round her brow; by her side walked Mr. Rochester, and together they drew near the table.They knelt; while Mrs. Dent and Louisa Eshton, dressed also in white, took up their stations behind them.A ceremony followed, in dumb show, in which it was easy to recognise the pantomime of a marriage.At its termination, Colonel Dent and his party consulted in whispers for two minutes, then the Colonel called out—
“新娘！”罗切斯特先生鞠了一躬，帷幔落下。 “Bride!”Mr. Rochester bowed, and the curtain fell.
过了好一会儿，帷幔才又拉开。这一次的表演比上一次场景准备得更精妙。之前我已经注意到客厅比餐室高出两个台阶，在上面一个台阶靠后一两码的地方，放了一个大大的大理石盆——我认出这个盆是暖房里的一个装饰品——在它以往的位置，盆四周摆着外来植物，盆里面养的是金鱼——从它的大小和重量判断，这个盆一定是费了不少劲儿才运到了这里。 A considerable interval elapsed before it again rose.Its second rising displayed a more elaborately prepared scene than the last.The drawing room, as I have before observed, was raised two steps above the dining room, and on the top of the upper step, placed a yard or two back within the room, appeared a large marble basin—which I recognised as an ornament of the conservatory—where it usually stood, surrounded by exotics, and tenanted by gold fish—and whence it must have been transported with some trouble, on account of its size and weight.
罗切斯特先生坐在这个盆旁边的地毯上，披着披肩，头上缠着头巾。他深色的眼睛、黝黑的皮肤和异教徒的长相与这身装束颇为相配，看起来很像一位东方世界的酋长，一个执行绞刑者或遭受绞刑者。这时，英格拉姆小姐走上前。她也一副东方人士扮相,一个深红色的围巾缠在腰间当作腰带；刺绣的手绢在太阳穴处打了一个结；她优美的手臂裸露着，一只手优雅地高举过头顶，做托水罐状。她刻画的体型容貌、肤色神态都给人以宗法社会时期某位以色列公主的暗示，这无疑正是她要代表的人物。 Seated on the carpet, by the side of this basin, was seen Mr. Rochester, costumed in shawls, with a turban on his head.His dark eyes and swarthy skin and Paynim features suited the costume exactly: he looked the very model of an Eastern emir, an agent or a victim of the bowstring.Presently advanced into view Miss Ingram.She, too, was attired in oriental fashion: a crimson scarf tied sash like round the waist: an embroidered handkerchief knotted about her temples; her beautifully-moulded arms bare, one of them upraised in the act of supporting a pitcher, poised gracefully on her head.Both her cast of form and feature, her complexion and her general air, suggested the idea of some Israelitish princess of the patriarchal days; and such was doubtless the character she intended to represent.
她走到盆前，弯腰像是要把水罐里装满水。之后，她又把水罐高举到头顶。盆边的那个人似乎在招呼她并提出了一个请求：——“她急忙拿下头上的水罐，让他喝水。”他从怀里取出一个匣子，打开后是精美绝伦的镯子和耳环。她显出震惊和爱慕。他跪下来把珠宝放在她的脚下，她的神情举止表现出疑惑和惊喜。陌生人给她戴上手镯，佩上耳环。是以利以谢和利百加的故事——只是缺少了骆驼。 She approached the basin, and bent over it as if to fill her pitcher; she again lifted it to her head.The personage on the well brink now seemed to accost her; to make some request:—“She hasted, let down her pitcher on her hand, and gave him to drink.”From the bosom of his robe he then produced a casket, opened it and showed magnificent bracelets and earrings; she acted astonishment and admiration; kneeling, he laid the treasure at her feet; incredulity and delight were expressed by her looks and gestures; the stranger fastened the bracelets on her arms and the rings in her ears.It was Eliezer and Rebecca: the camels only were wanting.
负责猜谜的那一组又凑到一起讨论。显然，他们对于这个场景表达的词语或音节不能达成一致。作为那组的发言人，登特上校要求对方展示“完整场景”，于是帷幔又一次落下了。 The divining party again laid their heads together: apparently they could not agree about the word or syllable the scene illustrated.Colonel Dent, their spokesman, demanded “the tableau of the whole;” whereupon the curtain again descended.
帷幔第三次升起时，客厅只有一部分显露在外，余下的部分隐藏在一块粗糙的暗色布后面。那个大理石盆不见了，取而代之的是一个松木桌子和一把厨房里的椅子。所有的蜡烛都熄灭了，只是借着一个角形灯发出的微弱光芒，才看得清上述物品。 On its third rising only a portion of the drawing room was disclosed; the rest being concealed by a screen, hung with some sort of dark and coarse drapery.The marble basin was removed; in its place, stood a deal table and a kitchen chair: these objects were visible by a very dim light proceeding from a horn lantern, the wax candles being all extinguished.
一个男人坐在这暗淡的场景中，攥着的双手放在膝盖上，眼睛盯着地面。虽然他面孔肮脏，衣衫凌乱（他的外衣松松地搭在一个胳膊上，像是在一场混战中给撕了下来。），绝望和愤怒的神情和蓬乱直立的头发也加大了辨认的难度，但我知道这个人是罗切斯特先生。他一挪动，一条链子就发出铿锵之声，他的双手也戴上了手铐。 Amidst this sordid scene, sat a man with his clenched hands resting on his knees, and his eyes bent on the ground.I knew Mr. Rochester; though the begrimed face, the disordered dress (his coat hanging loose from one arm, as if it had been almost torn from his back in a scuffle), the desperate and scowling countenance, the rough, bristling hair might well have disguised him.As he moved, a chain clanked; to his wrists were attached fetters.
“监牢！”登特上校叫道，猜中了这个谜语。 “Bridewell!” exclaimed Colonel Dent, and the charade was solved.
过了好长一段时间，这些表演者才换上他们的日常服饰，再次回到客厅。罗切斯特先生引英格拉姆小姐进来，她正恭维他的演技。 A sufficient interval having elapsed for the performers to resume their ordinary costume, they reentered the dining room.Mr. Rochester led in Miss Ingram; she was complimenting him on his acting.
她说：“你知道吗？你扮演的这三个人物中，我最喜欢最后那个了。噢，你要是早生几年，会是个多么英勇侠义的拦路大盗呀！” “Do you know,” said she, “that, of the three characters, I liked you in the last best?Oh, had you but lived a few years earlier, what a gallant gentleman highwayman you would have made!”
“我脸上的煤灰都洗净了吗？”他脸转向她问道。 “Is all the soot washed from my face?”he asked, turning it towards her.
“唉！都洗掉了，这才是可惜之处呢！没什么比恶棍脸上的胭脂更适合你的肤色了。” “Alas! yes: the more’s the pity!Nothing could be more becoming to your complexion than that ruffian’s rouge.”
“那么你是喜欢拦路大盗了？” “You would like a hero of the road then?”
“英国的拦路大盗比意大利强盗逊色一点，而我最喜欢的还是黎凡特的海盗。” “An English hero of the road would be the next best thing to an Italian bandit; and that could only be surpassed by a Levantine pirate.”
“好吧，不管我是谁，你要记住你是我的妻子。我们一小时前结了婚，在场的人都是我们的证婚人。”她咯咯笑了，脸上泛起红晕。 “Well, whatever I am, remember you are my wife; we were married an hour since, in the presence of all these witnesses.”She giggled, and her colour rose.
他继续说道：“登特，现在该你们了。”另外一组人离开后，他和组员在空下的座位上坐下。英格拉姆小姐坐在了罗切斯特先生的右手边，其余的猜谜者在他们的左右坐下。我没有看表演者，也不再饶有兴趣地等待帷幔升起。我的注意力完全集中到了观众身上，我刚才还在注视着拱门，现在眼睛就不可抗拒地转移到那排半圆形的椅子上。登特上校和他的组员表演了什么谜，选了什么字，怎么表演的，我都不记得了。但我还记得每幕之后的讨论——我看到罗切斯特先生转向英格拉姆小姐，英格拉姆小姐也转向他。我看到她把头凑向他，乌黑的卷发几乎触到了他的肩膀，扫过他的脸颊。我听到了他们的低语声，看到了他们互换眼色，那情景在我脑海里激起的感情让我至今无法忘怀。 “Now, Dent,” continued Mr. Rochester, “it is your turn.”And as the other party withdrew, he and his band took the vacated seats.Miss Ingram placed herself at her leader’s right hand; the other diviners filled the chairs on each side of him and her.I did not now watch the actors; I no longer waited with interest for the curtain to rise; my attention was absorbed by the spectators; my eyes, erewhile fixed on the arch, were now irresistibly attracted to the semicircle of chairs.What charade Colonel Dent and his party played, what word they chose, how they acquitted themselves, I no longer remember; but I still see the consultation which followed each scene: I see Mr. Rochester turn to Miss Ingram, and Miss Ingram to him;I see her incline her head towards him, till the jetty curls almost touch his shoulder and wave against his cheek; I hear their mutual whisperings; I recall their interchanged glances; and something even of the feeling roused by the spectacle returns in memory at this moment.
读者啊，我已经告诉你我学会爱罗切斯特先生了。我现在不能不爱他，仅仅因为发现他不再注意我——我在场数小时，他却从不朝我这儿看一眼——仅仅因为我看到一位高贵的女士捕获了他所有的注意力。而这位女士从我身边走过时裙边都不屑于碰我一下，气势凌人的深色眼睛偶然一看到我，就像看到了卑贱地不值一看的物体一样立刻将目光移开。我不能不爱他，仅因为我确信他很快就会迎娶这位女士——仅因为我每天都看出她骄傲地确定他对自己的心意——仅因为我每时每刻都看到他的求爱，不拘小节，像是等待别人发现而非主动出击；然而，就是这种不拘小节让人神魂颠倒，就是这种骄傲心态让人无法抗拒。 I have told you, reader, that I had learnt to love Mr. Rochester: I could not unlove him now, merely because I found that he had ceased to notice me—because I might pass hours in his presence, and he would never once turn his eyes in my direction—because I saw all his attentions appropriated by a great lady, who scorned to touch me with the hem of her robes as she passed; who, if ever her dark and imperious eye fell on me by chance, would withdraw it instantly as from an object too mean to merit observation.I could not unlove him, because I felt sure he would soon marry this very lady—because I read daily in her a proud security in his intentions respecting her—because I witnessed hourly in him a style of courtship which, if careless and choosing rather to be sought than to seek, was yet, in its very carelessness, captivating, and in its very pride, irresistible.
在这种情况下，虽然很容易使人绝望，但却无法冷却或摒弃爱情。读者朋友，你或许会认为这也极易引起嫉妒——如果我这种地位的女人可以冒昧地嫉妒英格拉姆小姐这等人物的话。但是我不嫉妒，或极少嫉妒——我所承受的痛苦是不能用嫉妒二字可以解释清楚的。英格拉姆小姐不值得我嫉妒，她太低级，不足以激起我的感情。请原谅这种看起来矛盾的逻辑，事实就是这样。她非常爱炫耀，却没有内涵；她身材优美、多才多艺，但头脑简单、心灵贫瘠——没任何花朵在那片土地上自动绽放；除非外力相助，没有任何非外力的自然果实会从这片土地的新鲜中取悦。她并不优秀，也没有原创能力——她只是重复书本上的词句，从未提出，也从未拥有过自己的观点。她高调地谈论感情，却不懂同情与怜惜。她根本没有温柔和真情。她对小阿德拉心怀厌恶的无端发泄，常将此缺点暴露无遗。她碰巧走到阿德拉身边时，总要用侮辱性的称谓称呼她并将其推开，有时还命令她离开房间，对她的态度也总是冷淡尖刻。其他人也像我一样注意到了她表现出的性格特点——他们仔细、热切、敏锐地看着她的举动。是的，未来的新郎罗切斯特先生自己也在不停地注视着他意中人的行为。正是这种睿智——他的警觉——对所爱之人的缺点完美而清楚的意识——对她显而易见的激情匮乏，给我带来了痛不欲生的苦楚。 There was nothing to cool or banish love in these circumstances, though much to create despair.Much too, you will think, reader, to engender jealousy: if a woman, in my position, could presume to be jealous of a woman in Miss Ingram’s.But I was not jealous: or very rarely;—the nature of the pain I suffered could not be explained by that word.Miss Ingram was a mark beneath jealousy: she was too inferior to excite the feeling.Pardon the seeming paradox; I mean what I say.She was very showy, but she was not genuine: she had a fine person, many brilliant attainments; but her mind was poor, her heart barren by nature: nothing bloomed spontaneously on that soil; no unforced natural fruit delighted by its freshness.She was not good; she was not original: she used to repeat sounding phrases from books: she never offered, nor had, an opinion of her own.She advocated a high tone of sentiment; but she did not know the sensations of sympathy and pity; tenderness and truth were not in her.Too often she betrayed this, by the undue vent she gave to a spiteful antipathy she had conceived against little Adele: pushing her away with some contumelious epithet if she happened to approach her; sometimes ordering her from the room, and always treating her with coldness and acrimony.Other eyes besides mine watched these manifestations of character—watched them closely, keenly, shrewdly.Yes; the future bridegroom, Mr. Rochester himself, exercised over his intended a ceaseless surveillance; and it was from this sagacity—this guardedness of his—this perfect, clear consciousness of his fair one’s defects—this obvious absence of passion in his sentiments towards her, that my ever torturing pain arose.
我知道他会为了家庭，或许政治原因娶她，因为她的社会地位和社会关系适合他。我觉得他并不爱她，她也不够资格得到他宝贵的爱。就是这一点触我心弦——使我对他的狂热不能停止，而且愈加强烈：她无法迷住他。 I saw he was going to marry her, for family, perhaps political reasons, because her rank and connections suited him; I felt he had not given her his love, and that her qualifications were ill adapted to win from him that treasure.This was the point—this was where the nerve was touched and teased—this was where the fever was sustained and fed: SHE COULD NOT CHARM HIM.
如果她立即就成功地俘获他的心，他甘愿受降，真诚地拜倒在她的石榴裙下，我会以手掩面，转向墙壁，（象征性地）对他们死心。如果英格拉姆小姐优秀高贵，拥有力量、热情、善良、理智，我会与两只老虎做一番搏斗——嫉妒和绝望。我的心会被撕裂，被吞噬，我也会羡慕她——承认她的优秀卓越，平静地度过余生。而且她越出众，我对她的景仰也会越深——我的内心也会越平静。但事实是，看着英格拉姆小姐用心良苦地努力迷住罗切斯特先生，却不断地失败——虽然她自己意识不到这些失败，还自负地幻想自己百发百中，自恋地炫耀成功，骄傲和自满使她离想要吸引的东西越来越远——看着这些，我同时陷入无穷尽的兴奋和残酷的克制中。 If she had managed the victory at once, and he had yielded and sincerely laid his heart at her feet, I should have covered my face, turned to the wall, and (figuratively) have died to them.If Miss Ingram had been a good and noble woman, endowed with force, fervour, kindness, sense, I should have had one vital struggle with two tigers—jealousy and despair: then, my heart torn out and devoured, I should have admired her—acknowledged her excellence, and been quiet for the rest of my days:and the more absolute her superiority, the deeper would have been my admiration—the more truly tranquil my quiescence.But as matters really stood, to watch Miss Ingram’s efforts at fascinating Mr. Rochester, to witness their repeated failure—herself unconscious that they did fail; vainly fancying that each shaft launched hit the mark, and infatuatedly pluming herself on success, when her pride and self complacency repelled further and further what she wished to allure—to witness THIS, was to be at once under ceaseless excitation and ruthless restraint.
因为她失败时，我看出她本应使用的成功之道。我知道，如果那些一次又一次从罗切斯特先生胸膛滑落、毫无伤害力地掉到他脚边的箭由更有把握的手射出，一定会准确地插进他骄傲的心，并颤抖不已——让他坚毅的眼睛里充满爱，嘲讽的表情注入温柔；或许更好的话，根本无需武器就能不动声色地征服他。 Because, when she failed, I saw how she might have succeeded.Arrows that continually glanced off from Mr. Rochester’s breast and fell harmless at his feet, might, I knew, if shot by a surer hand, have quivered keen in his proud heart—have called love into his stern eye, and softness into his sardonic face; or, better still, without weapons a silent conquest might have been won.
“既然她有幸接近他，为什么不能加深对他的影响呢？”我问自己。“肯定是因为她不能真心喜欢他，或者没有投入真情实意！否则，她就不用这样过分地强颜欢笑，坚持不懈地抛媚眼，做作地摆架子和各种故作风雅。我觉得她只要静静地坐在他身边，不需很多言语和眼神，就能靠近他的心。我曾经见过他的表情，与她热切地引诱他时的坚硬脸色截然不同。那种表情是自然流露，而不是靠华丽庸俗的计谋和处心积虑的算计得来的。你只要接受它——坦诚地回答他的问题，需要时毫不做作地与他讲话——他的表情就会越来越和蔼，越来越柔和，像哺育万物的阳光般温暖人心。她怎么在婚后让他开心呢？我觉得她做不到，但她应该做到。我坚信，他的妻子会是世界上最幸福的女人。” “Why can she not influence him more, when she is privileged to draw so near to him?”I asked myself.“Surely she cannot truly like him, or not like him with true affection!If she did, she need not coin her smiles so lavishly, flash her glances so unremittingly, manufacture airs so elaborate, graces so multitudinous.It seems to me that she might, by merely sitting quietly at his side, saying little and looking less, get nigher his heart.I have seen in his face a far different expression from that which hardens it now while she is so vivaciously accosting him; but then it came of itself: it was not elicited by meretricious arts and calculated manoeuvres;and one had but to accept it—to answer what he asked without pretension, to address him when needful without grimace—and it increased and grew kinder and more genial, and warmed one like a fostering sunbeam.How will she manage to please him when they are married?I do not think she will manage it; and yet it might be managed; and his wife might, I verily believe, be the very happiest woman the sun shines on.”
我还从未对罗切斯特先生要为利益和关系而结婚的计划发表任何微词。我最初发现他的意图时吃了一惊——我曾以为他不太可能在选择配偶中受这种陈腐的动机影响。但是我越思考双方的地位、教育等等因素，越觉得不应当评论责怪他或英格拉姆小姐，无疑，他们只是顺从了从小就耳濡目染的思想和原则。他们那个阶层的人都奉行这些原则，我想其中的缘由或许是我无法揣摩的。我想如果我是一位像他那样的绅士，我只愿迎娶一个我爱的妻子。但这样做对显然会对丈夫的幸福有利，我确信一定有我不知道的理由使这无法实现。否则，我相信世界上所有的人采取的行动都会与我的愿望相符。 I have not yet said anything condemnatory of Mr. Rochester’s project of marrying for interest and connections.It surprised me when I first discovered that such was his intention: I had thought him a man unlikely to be influenced by motives so commonplace in his choice of a wife;but the longer I considered the position, education, &c., of the parties, the less I felt justified in judging and blaming either him or Miss Ingram for acting in conformity to ideas and principles instilled into them, doubtless, from their childhood.All their class held these principles: I supposed, then, they had reasons for holding them such as I could not fathom.It seemed to me that, were I a gentleman like him, I would take to my bosom only such a wife as I could love;but the very obviousness of the advantages to the husband’s own happiness offered by this plan convinced me that there must be arguments against its general adoption of which I was quite ignorant: otherwise I felt sure all the world would act as I wished to act.
但是从其他方面来看，我也开始对我的主人变得非常宽容——我忘了他所有的错误，那些曾让我高度警惕的错误。我曾经试图了解他性格的各个方面——好坏皆察，并衡量两者形成公正的判断。现在，我看不到坏的方面了。曾经令人厌恶的冷嘲热讽和曾让我吃惊的严厉尖刻现在就像一道精致菜肴里的浓烈的调味品——有了辛辣刺鼻，没有却又索然无味。至于那种模糊的神情——是凶恶还是悲伤，是城府还是沮丧？——细心观察的人有时会发现他眼神中流露出这种朦胧的神情，但不等人深入探究这种部分显露的奇特就又消失了。这种神情曾让我感到恐惧畏缩——像是在火山似的山中迷路，突然感到大地颤动，看到缝隙裂开。我现在有时还能看到他的这种神情，但却是感到砰然心动，而非神经麻痹。我不再想躲避，而是渴望斗胆上去——去探索它。我认为英格拉姆小姐是幸福的，因为有一天她可以从容地探看这个深渊，探索其中的秘密，分析其本质。 But in other points, as well as this, I was growing very lenient to my master: I was forgetting all his faults, for which I had once kept a sharp lookout.It had formerly been my endeavour to study all sides of his character: to take the bad with the good; and from the just weighing of both, to form an equitable judgment.Now I saw no bad.The sarcasm that had repelled, the harshness that had startled me once, were only like keen condiments in a choice dish: their presence was pungent, but their absence would be felt as comparatively insipid.And as for the vague something—was it a sinister or a sorrowful, a designing or a desponding expression?—that opened upon a careful observer, now and then, in his eye, and closed again before one could fathom the strange depth partially disclosed;that something which used to make me fear and shrink, as if I had been wandering amongst volcanic looking hills, and had suddenly felt the ground quiver and seen it gape: that something, I, at intervals, beheld still; and with throbbing heart, but not with palsied nerves.Instead of wishing to shun, I longed only to dare—to divine it; and I thought Miss Ingram happy, because one day she might look into the abyss at her leisure, explore its secrets and analyse their nature.
那时，我的心思都放在我的主人和他未来的新娘身上——眼里只看到他们，耳朵只听到他们谈话，只考虑他们举动的涵义——而其他人都沉浸在各自的兴趣和欢乐之中。林恩女士和英格拉姆太太继续郑重地交谈，互相点着头巾帽。根据她们闲话内容的变化，各自的双手都忙着做种种手势：惊讶、神秘、恐惧，像是两个放大了的木偶。温和的登特太太正和善良的埃希顿太太交谈，她们有时跟我讲一两句客气话，或是对我笑一下。乔治·林恩爵士，登特上校和埃希顿先生在谈论政治，或是郡里的事务，或者司法事宜。英格拉姆勋爵在调戏埃米·埃希顿；路易莎正和一位林恩家的先生一起弹琴唱歌。玛丽·英格拉姆正无精打采地听着林恩家的另一位先生高谈阔论。有时他们所有人会不约而同地停下配角戏，以观看和倾听主演。因为毕竟罗切斯特先生和与之关系密切的英格拉姆小姐是这群人的生命和灵魂。如果他离开一小时，可以看出客人就变得精神不振、沉闷无聊；而他重新进来，就一定会为谈话注入清新的活力。 Meantime, while I thought only of my master and his future bride—saw only them, heard only their discourse, and considered only their movements of importance—the rest of the party were occupied with their own separate interests and pleasures.The Ladies Lynn and Ingram continued to consort in solemn conferences, where they nodded their two turbans at each other, and held up their four hands in confronting gestures of surprise, or mystery, or horror, according to the theme on which their gossip ran, like a pair of magnified puppets.Mild Mrs. Dent talked with good-natured Mrs. Eshton; and the two sometimes bestowed a courteous word or smile on me.Sir George Lynn, Colonel Dent, and Mr. Eshton discussed politics, or county affairs, or justice business.Lord Ingram flirted with Amy Eshton; Louisa played and sang to and with one of the Messrs Lynn; and Mary Ingram listened languidly to the gallant speeches of the other.Sometimes all, as with one consent, suspended their by-play to observe and listen to the principal actors: for, after all, Mr. Rochester and—because closely connected with him—Miss Ingram were the life and soul of the party.If he was absent from the room an hour, a perceptible dulness seemed to steal over the spirits of his guests; and his reentrance was sure to give a fresh impulse to the vivacity of conversation.
一天，他因公事去了米尔科特，并要很晚才能回来。这天，大家对他增添活力的依赖也尤其地显现出来。下午天下了雨。客人们原本决定步行去参观一个不久前刚在海村的一片公地上驻扎的吉普赛营地，结果也被迫推迟了。几位绅士去了马厩。一些年轻的绅士和女士在台球室里打台球。英格拉姆和林恩两位遗孀从安静的纸牌游戏中寻求慰藉。登特太太和埃希顿太太力邀布兰奇·英格拉姆加入她们的谈话，她却傲慢地以缄默的方式拒绝了。她伴着钢琴哼出了一些伤感的旋律和曲调，然后又从书房里取了本小说，百无聊赖又傲慢地歪倒在沙发上，打算用小说的魔力打发这无人相伴的乏味的几个小时。房间和整座房子里都是寂静的，只有楼上打台球的人时而发出快乐的笑声。 The want of his animating influence appeared to be peculiarly felt one day that he had been summoned to Millcote on business, and was not likely to return till late.The afternoon was wet: a walk the party had proposed to take to see a gipsy camp, lately pitched on a common beyond Hay, was consequently deferred.Some of the gentlemen were gone to the stables: the younger ones, together with the younger ladies, were playing billiards in the billiard room.The dowagers Ingram and Lynn sought solace in a quiet game at cards.Blanche Ingram, after having repelled, by supercilious taciturnity, some efforts of Mrs. Dent and Mrs. Eshton to draw her into conversation, had first murmured over some sentimental tunes and airs on the piano, and then, having fetched a novel from the library, had flung herself in haughty listlessness on a sofa, and prepared to beguile, by the spell of fiction, the tedious hours of absence.The room and the house were silent: only now and then the merriment of the billiard players was heard from above.
天快黑时，钟声提醒已经到了要换衣服吃晚饭的时间。忽然，跪在我身边窗台上的小阿德拉大叫起来—— It was verging on dusk, and the clock had already given warning of the hour to dress for dinner, when little Adele, who knelt by me in the drawing room window seat, suddenly exclaimed—
“看，罗切斯特先生回来了！” “Voile, Monsieur Rochester, qui revient!”
我转身看到英格拉姆小姐从沙发上弹跳起来，其他人也都停下各自的活动，抬头观望，因为此时可以听到车轮嘎吱嘎吱的声音和马蹄踏过潮湿的碎石路上时溅起的水声。一辆驿马车正往这边行驶。 I turned, and Miss Ingram darted forwards from her sofa: the others, too, looked up from their several occupations; for at the same time a crunching of wheels and a splashing tramp of horse hoofs became audible on the wet gravel.A post chaise was approaching.
“他怎么用这种方式回来呀？”英格拉姆小姐说。“他走的时候不是骑着梅斯罗（那匹黑马）吗？随行的还有派洛特——他把它们弄哪去了？” “What can possess him to come home in that style?” said Miss Ingram.“He rode Mesrour (the black horse), did he not, when he went out? and Pilot was with him:—what has he done with the animals?”
她边说边使劲往窗边靠，高挑的身材和宽大的外衣使我不得不使劲往后仰，脊柱几乎就要断了。她急切地往外看，开始时没注意到我，但一看到我后，她就翘起了嘴唇，到另外一个窗户边去了。驿马车停下了，车夫摇响了铃，一位旅行装束的绅士下了车。但他不是罗切斯特先生，是一位体型高大，相貌时尚的陌生男子。 As she said this, she approached her tall person and ample garments so near the window, that I was obliged to bend back almost to the breaking of my spine: in her eagerness she did not observe me at first, but when she did, she curled her lip and moved to another casement.The post chaise stopped; the driver rang the doorbell, and a gentleman alighted attired in travelling garb; but it was not Mr. Rochester; it was a tall, fashionable looking man, a stranger.
“真是气死人了！”英格拉姆小姐喊道：“你这个无聊的家伙！”（指阿德拉），“谁让你到窗座上谎报消息的？”她生气地看了我一眼，好像是我的错一样。 “How provoking!” exclaimed Miss Ingram: “you tiresome monkey!” (apostrophising Adele), “who perched you up in the window to give false intelligence?” and she cast on me an angry glance, as if I were in fault.
大厅里传来一阵谈话声，不久，新到的那个人就进来了。他向英格拉姆女士鞠了一躬，仿佛觉得她是在场的年龄最年长的女士。 Some parleying was audible in the hall, and soon the newcomer entered.He bowed to Lady Ingram, as deeming her the eldest lady present.
“我好像来的不是时候，夫人，”他说，“我的朋友罗切斯特先生正好不在家。但我从很远的地方过来，与他又是亲密的老朋友，所以我想冒昧地呆在这儿，等他回来。” “It appears I come at an inopportune time, madam,” said he, “when my friend, Mr. Rochester, is from home; but I arrive from a very long journey, and I think I may presume so far on old and intimate acquaintance as to instal myself here till he returns.”
他言谈举止彬彬有礼，讲话的口音却有些奇怪——不是完全的外国口音，但也不完全是英国口音。他年龄大概与罗切斯特先生相仿——三四十岁。他若不是脸色黄得出奇，就真是个美男子了，尤其是第一眼看上去的时候。再仔细看他，就会发觉他脸上一些令人不快，或不讨人喜欢的地方。他五官端正，但太松散了——大大的眼睛很美，但流露出沉闷和空洞的神色，至少我这么认为。 His manner was polite; his accent, in speaking, struck me as being somewhat unusual,—not precisely foreign, but still not altogether English: his age might be about Mr. Rochester’s,—between thirty and forty; his complexion was singularly sallow: otherwise he was a fine-looking man, at first sight especially.On closer examination, you detected something in his face that displeased, or rather that failed to please.His features were regular, but too relaxed: his eye was large and well cut, but the life looking out of it was a tame, vacant life—at least so I thought.
提醒换衣服吃晚饭的铃声响起，大家就散开了。直到晚饭后我才又见到了那个人，他似乎很轻松随意。但我对他相貌的喜欢程度比刚才更低了。我觉得他既不沉稳又没有生机活力。他的眼睛毫无意义地四处张望，这使他看起来很诡异，我从来没见到过这种奇怪的模样。这位帅气且并非不友善的男子让我感到非常厌恶——椭圆形的脸上皮肤光滑，却毫无力量；鹰钩鼻和樱桃小嘴毫无坚毅；低平的前额上毫无思想；空洞的褐色眼睛里毫无威严。 The sound of the dressing bell dispersed the party.It was not till after dinner that I saw him again: he then seemed quite at his ease.But I liked his physiognomy even less than before: it struck me as being at the same time unsettled and inanimate.His eye wandered, and had no meaning in its wandering: this gave him an odd look, such as I never remembered to have seen.For a handsome and not an unamiable-looking man, he repelled me exceedingly: there was no power in that smooth skinned face of a full oval shape: no firmness in that aquiline nose and small cherry mouth; there was no thought on the low, even forehead; no command in that blank, brown eye.
我像往常一样坐在角落，看着他。在壁炉架上明亮在的烛光环绕着他,因为他坐在离壁炉很近的一个扶手椅里。可他还不断地向火边蜷缩，好像自己很冷一样。我将他与罗切斯特先生进行比较。我想（带着敬意地评判）他们之间的差别比一只肥胖的雄鹅和一只凶猛的猎鹰、一只温顺的绵羊和一只毛发粗糙、眼神犀利的狗之间的差别更大。 As I sat in my usual nook, and looked at him with the light of the girandoles on the mantelpiece beaming full over him—for he occupied an armchair drawn close to the fire, and kept shrinking still nearer, as if he were cold, I compared him with Mr. Rochester.I think (with deference be it spoken) the contrast could not be much greater between a sleek gander and a fierce falcon: between a meek sheep and the rough coated keen eyed dog, its guardian.
他说过罗切斯特先生是他的一位老朋友。他们的友谊一定很古怪，事实上，可以用那句古老的格言来作为例证——“两个极端的碰撞”。 He had spoken of Mr. Rochester as an old friend.A curious friendship theirs must have been: a pointed illustration, indeed, of the old adage that “extremes meet.”
两三位绅士在他旁边坐下，我在房间的这边偶尔能听到他们谈话的一些内容。起初，我不太明白我听到的内容，因为离我更近的路易莎·埃希顿和玛丽·英格拉姆的谈话搅乱了与我时而听到的一些只言片语。她们正谈论那个陌生人，都把他叫做“美男子”。路易莎说他是“可爱的人”，她“喜欢他”；玛丽例举他“漂亮的小嘴，好看的鼻子”，称之为她心中白马王子的完美形象。 Two or three of the gentlemen sat near him, and I caught at times scraps of their conversation across the room.At first I could not make much sense of what I heard; for the discourse of Louisa Eshton and Mary Ingram, who sat nearer to me, confused the fragmentary sentences that reached me at intervals.These last were discussing the stranger; they both called him “a beautiful man.”Louisa said he was “a love of a creature,” and she “adored him;” and Mary instanced his “pretty little mouth, and nice nose,” as her ideal of the charming.
“他的额头显示他脾气一定很好！”路易莎叫道，“那么平滑，没有一点我讨厌的蹙眉之态，而且眼神平静，笑容温和！” “And what a sweet tempered forehead he has!” cried Louisa,—“so smooth—none of those frowning irregularities I dislike so much; and such a placid eye and smile!”
后来亨利·林恩先生叫她们到房间的另一边去商量被迫推迟了的海村公地远足，我终于松了口气。 And then, to my great relief, Mr. Henry Lynn summoned them to the other side of the room, to settle some point about the deferred excursion to Hay Common.
我现在终于可以把注意力集中到壁炉旁那群人上了，听到那位新来的先生名叫梅森，刚刚从一个炎热的国家来到英格兰。这无疑是他脸色发黄，紧挨壁炉，在屋里还穿着外套的原因。牙买加、金斯敦、西班牙城这些词表明他住在西印度群岛。不久，我又很惊讶地听到，他和罗切斯特先生就是在那儿第一次见面并相识的。他提起他的朋友罗切斯特先生对当地酷热、飓风和雨季的厌恶。我知道罗切斯特先生经常旅行，这一点费尔法克斯太太曾说过。但我以为他旅行的地方局限于欧洲大陆，在此之前，我从没听说过他到更远的地方去过。 I was now able to concentrate my attention on the group by the fire, and I presently gathered that the newcomer was called Mr. Mason; then I learned that he was but just arrived in England, and that he came from some hot country: which was the reason, doubtless, his face was so sallow, and that he sat so near the hearth, and wore a surtout in the house.Presently the words Jamaica, Kingston, Spanish Town, indicated the West Indies as his residence; and it was with no little surprise I gathered, ere long, that he had there first seen and become acquainted with Mr. Rochester.He spoke of his friend’s dislike of the burning heats, the hurricanes, and rainy seasons of that region.I knew Mr. Rochester had been a traveller: Mrs. Fairfax had said so; but I thought the continent of Europe had bounded his wanderings; till now I had never heard a hint given of visits to more distant shores.
我正在沉思中，突然一件预料之外的事打断了我的思绪。有人碰巧开了下门，梅森先生冷得发抖，叫人再往壁炉里加些煤。因为虽然大片灰烬仍闪着红光，但已没有了火焰。仆人加了煤出去时在埃希顿先生椅边停了一下，低声说了些什么，我只听到“老女人”——“很讨厌”。 I was pondering these things, when an incident, and a somewhat unexpected one, broke the thread of my musings.Mr. Mason, shivering as some one chanced to open the door, asked for more coal to be put on the fire, which had burnt out its flame, though its mass of cinder still shone hot and red.The footman who brought the coal, in going out, stopped near Mr. Eshton’s chair, and said something to him in a low voice, of which I heard only the words, “old woman,”—“quite troublesome.”
“告诉她再不离开就给她戴上枷锁。”这位法官回答说。 “Tell her she shall be put in the stocks if she does not take herself off,” replied the magistrate.
“不——停住！”登特上校插嘴道。“埃希顿，别把她送走。我们或许能从中获益，最好还是和女士们商议一下吧。”他大声继续说道：“女士们，你们之前说要去海村公地参观吉普赛营地。萨姆说有一位邦奇妈妈现在正在仆人的大厅里，坚持要见见这里的‘贵人’，给他们算命。你们想要见她吗？” “No—stop!” interrupted Colonel Dent.“Don’t send her away, Eshton; we might turn the thing to account; better consult the ladies.”And speaking aloud, he continued—“Ladies, you talked of going to Hay Common to visit the gipsy camp; Sam here says that one of the old Mother Bunches is in the servants’ hall at this moment, and insists upon being brought in before ‘the quality,’ to tell them their fortunes.Would you like to see her?”
英格拉姆女士大声说：“上校，你一定不会纵容这个低贱的骗子吧？想办法让她立即走人！” “Surely, colonel,” cried Lady Ingram, “you would not encourage such a low impostor?Dismiss her, by all means, at once!”
“可是女士，我怎么劝说，她都不肯走，”那个仆人说，“仆人们都劝不走她。费尔法克斯太太正恳请她离开，但她拿张椅子坐在了烟囱角落里，还说除非让她来这儿，否则她说什么也不走。” “But I cannot persuade her to go away, my lady,” said the footman; “nor can any of the servants: Mrs. Fairfax is with her just now, entreating her to be gone; but she has taken a chair in the chimney comer, and says nothing shall stir her from it till she gets leave to come in here.”
“她想要干什么？”埃希顿太太问。 “What does she want?” asked Mrs. Eshton.
“夫人，她说她要给上流人士算命，还发誓说一定要算，非算不可。” “‘To tell the gentry their fortunes,’ she says, ma’am; and she swears she must and will do it.”
“她长什么样？”埃希顿家的小姐齐声问道。 “What is she like?” inquired the Misses Eshton, in a breath.
“小姐，她长得出奇的丑，像煤烟一样黑。” “A shockingly ugly old creature, miss; almost as black as a crock.”
“这样呀，那她真是一个女巫！”弗雷德里克·林恩叫道。“我们当然要让她进来。” “Why, she’s a real sorceress!” cried Frederick Lynn.“Let us have her in, of course.”
“一定的，”他兄弟应和着，“要是错过这么好玩的机会真是要后悔极了。” “To be sure,” rejoined his brother; “it would be a thousand pities to throw away such a chance of fun.”
“亲爱的孩子们，你们想要干什么呀？”林恩太太大声说。 “My dear boys, what are you thinking about?” exclaimed Mrs. Lynn.
“我绝对不可能支持这种反复无常的行事方法。”英格拉姆遗孀插话道。 “I cannot possibly countenance any such inconsistent proceeding,” chimed in the Dowager Ingram.
“是不该变来变去，但妈妈，你可以——也应该支持这个提议，”布兰奇坐在钢琴旁边的凳子上，转身高傲地叫道。刚才她一直静静地坐在那儿，好像是在研究各类乐谱。“我很好奇我的前途如何。所以，萨姆，让那老太婆进来吧。” “Indeed, mama, but you can—and will,” pronounced the haughty voice of Blanche, as she turned round on the piano stool; where till now she had sat silent, apparently examining sundry sheets of music.“I have a curiosity to hear my fortune told: therefore, Sam, order the beldame forward.”
“亲爱的布兰奇，想想——” “My darling Blanche! recollect—”
“我想了——你想说的我都想过了，我就是要这样做——萨姆，快去！” “I do—I recollect all you can suggest; and I must have my will—quick, Sam!”
“对——对——对！”青年男女齐声喊道。“让她进来——一定好玩极了！” “Yes—yes—yes!” cried all the juveniles, both ladies and gentlemen.“Let her come—it will be excellent sport!”
仆人还没有动。“她看样子很粗暴，”他说。 The footman still lingered.“She looks such a rough one,” said he.
“快去！”英格拉姆小姐厉声喝道，那个仆人去了。 “Go!” ejaculated Miss Ingram, and the man went.
在场的人立即兴奋起来，互相插科打诨。萨姆回来了。 Excitement instantly seized the whole party: a running fire of raillery and jests was proceeding when Sam returned.
“她现在又不肯来了，”他说，“她说她的责任不是去见‘一群俗人’（这是她的原话。）。我必须领她到一个房间去，想要让她算命的人一个一个去见她。” “She won’t come now,” said he.“She says it’s not her mission to appear before the ‘vulgar herd’ (them’s her words).I must show her into a room by herself, and then those who wish to consult her must go to her one by one.”
英格拉姆女士说道：“看啊，我的布兰奇女王，她得寸进尺了。听我劝吧，我的天使女儿——再说——” “You see now, my queenly Blanche,” began Lady Ingram, “she encroaches.Be advised, my angel girl—and—”
“当然，把她带到书房去，”“天使女儿”打断她。“我的职责也不是在一群俗人面前听她算命，我就是要和她单独见面。书房里生火了吗？” “Show her into the library, of course,” cut in the “angel girl.”“It is not my mission to listen to her before the vulgar herd either: I mean to have her all to myself.Is there a fire in the library?”
“生了，小姐——但是她看起来真像个乞丐。” “Yes, ma’am—but she looks such a tinkler.”
“少废话，蠢人！按我说的做。” “Cease that chatter, blockhead! and do my bidding.”
萨姆又出去了。神秘、兴奋、期待又一次在人群中蔓延。 Again Sam vanished; and mystery, animation, expectation rose to full flow once more.
“她准备好了，”仆人又进来说，“她想知道谁愿意第一个去。” “She’s ready now,” said the footman, as he reappeared.“She wishes to know who will be her first visitor.”
“我想我还是在女士们去见她之前先去会她一会，”登特上校说道， “I think I had better just look in upon her before any of the ladies go,” said Colonel Dent.
“萨姆，去告诉她一位绅士马上到。” “Tell her, Sam, a gentleman is coming.”
萨姆出去一会儿又回来了。 Sam went and returned.
“先生，她说她不为男士算命，也不劳驾你们去见她。”他艰难地忍着笑，接着说，“只见年轻的单身女士。” “She says, sir, that she’ll have no gentlemen; they need not trouble themselves to come near her; nor,” he added, with difficulty suppressing a titter, “any ladies either, except the young, and single.”
“天呀，她的品位还真不错！”亨利·林恩惊呼。 “To put Adele to bed: it is past her bedtime.”
英格拉姆小姐郑重地起身，说：“我第一个去。”她的语调像是一位孤注一掷的领头人要带着先锋部队去打开一个突破口。 Miss Ingram rose solemnly: “I go first,” she said, in a tone which might have befitted the leader of a forlorn hope, mounting a breach in the van of his men.
“噢，我的宝贝！噢，我最亲爱的！等一下——再想想！”她母亲叫道。但是她平静庄严地从她身边掠过，走出敞开的门口——登特上校正扶着门——我们听到她走进了书房。 “Oh, my best! oh, my dearest! pause—reflect!” was her mama’s cry; but she swept past her in stately silence, passed through the door which Colonel Dent held open, and we heard her enter the library.
紧接着是相对的安静。英格拉姆女士认为这种“情况”下应该扭绞双手，于是她也这样做了。玛丽小姐说她觉得自己绝对不敢冒这样的险。埃米和路易莎·埃希顿轻声窃笑，像是有点害怕。 A comparative silence ensued.Lady Ingram thought it “le cas” to wring her hands: which she did accordingly.Miss Mary declared she felt, for her part, she never dared venture.Amy and Louisa Eshton tittered under their breath, and looked a little frightened.
时间过得很慢，十五分钟后书房的门才打开。英格拉姆小姐从拱门进来。 The minutes passed very slowly: fifteen were counted before the library door again opened.Miss Ingram returned to us through the arch.
她会一笑了之吗？她会把这当作一个笑话吗？所有人都好奇期盼地看着她，她显出了拒绝和冷漠的神情。她看起来既不激动也不开心，呆板地走回她的座位，一言不发地坐下。 Would she laugh?Would she take it as a joke?All eyes met her with a glance of eager curiosity, and she met all eyes with one of rebuff and coldness; she looked neither flurried nor merry: she walked stiffly to her seat, and took it in silence.
“怎么样，布兰奇？”英格拉姆勋爵问。 “Well, Blanche?” said Lord Ingram.
“姐姐，她说什么？”玛丽问。 “What did she say, sister?” asked Mary.
“你怎么想？感觉怎么样？——她真是个算命的吗？”埃希顿姐妹也问道。 “What did you think?How do you feel?—Is she a real fortuneteller ?” demanded the Misses Eshton.
“好啦好啦，好人们，”英格拉姆小姐回答道，“别逼我了。你们的好奇心和信任就这么容易给激发了。你们所有人——包括我妈妈在内——都认为这件事很重要，百分百地相信来了一个真正的巫婆，还与恶魔有什么亲密的同盟关系。我见到的是一个吉普赛流浪者，她用常见的方法给我看手相，告诉我一些这类人会讲的话。我现在没什么好奇的了。我想埃希顿先生最好还是明天早上给她戴上枷锁，就像刚才威胁她的一样。” “Now, now, good people,” returned Miss Ingram, “don’t press upon me.Really your organs of wonder and credulity are easily excited: you seem, by the importance of you all—my good mama included—ascribe to this matter, absolutely to believe we have a genuine witch in the house, who is in close alliance with the old gentleman.I have seen a gipsy vagabond; she has practised in hackneyed fashion the science of palmistry and told me what such people usually tell.My whim is gratified; and now I think Mr. Eshton will do well to put the hag in the stocks tomorrow morning, as he threatened.”
