“夫人自己身体不好也有一阵子了，她发胖得很厉害，但是一点儿都不结实；家产的亏败和对贫穷的恐惧快把她压垮了。约翰先生的死以及他死法的消息来得太突然：以至于她中风了。她三天都没有说一句话；不过上个星期二，她似乎好了很多：她似乎想说什么，不断地跟我妻子打手势，嘴里还轻声咕哝着。不过直到昨天早上，贝茜才弄清楚她是在念你的名字，最后终于明白了她的话，‘把简带来——去把简·爱找回来：我有话对她说。’贝茜不确定夫人是否神志清醒，也不知道她那些话是否是真的；不过她告诉了里德小姐和乔治亚娜小姐，建议她们派人找您回去。年轻的小姐们一开始把这事儿搁置着没办，不过她们的母亲变得异常焦躁不安，并且叫了很多次‘简，简’，她们最后终于同意了。我昨天离开了盖茨黑德。如果您能收拾好，小姐，我很愿意明天一早就带您回去。” “Missis had been out of health herself for some time: she had got very stout, but was not strong with it; and the loss of money and fear of poverty were quite breaking her down.The information about Mr. John’s death and the manner of it came too suddenly: it brought on a stroke.She was three days without speaking; but last Tuesday she seemed rather better: she appeared as if she wanted to say something, and kept making signs to my wife and mumbling.It was only yesterday morning, however, that Bessie understood she was pronouncing your name; and at last she made out the words, ‘Bring Jane—fetch Jane Eyre: I want to speak to her.’Bessie is not sure whether she is in her right mind, or means anything by the words; but she told Miss Reed and Miss Georgiana, and advised them to send for you.The young ladies put it off at first; but their mother grew so restless, and said, ‘Jane, Jane,’ so many times, that at last they consented.I left Gateshead yesterday: and if you can get ready, Miss, I should like to take you back with me early tomorrow morning.”
“是的，罗伯特，我会准备好的，看来我的确应该去一趟。” “Yes, Robert, I shall be ready: it seems to me that I ought to go.”
“我也是这样想的，小姐。贝茜说她确定您不会拒绝的，不过我想您离开之前得请个假吧？” “I think so too, Miss.Bessie said she was sure you would not refuse: but I suppose you will have to ask leave before you can get off?”
“是的，我现在就去。”我把他领到仆人们的房间，拜托约翰的妻子照顾他，也告诉了约翰先生本人。接着我就去找罗切斯特先生。 “Yes; and I will do it now;” and having directed him to the servants’ hall, and recommended him to the care of John’s wife, and the attentions of John himself, I went in search of Mr. Rochester.
楼下任何房间都没在；他不在院子里，不在马厩中，也不在庭园里。我问费尔法克斯夫人是否见到他了——是的，她认为他正和英格拉姆小姐玩弹珠游戏。去弹珠室时我加快了速度。弹珠的咔哒声和喧闹嘈杂的说话声在那儿回响着。罗切斯特先生、英格拉姆小姐、两位埃希顿小姐，还有他们的仰慕者们，全都在忙着玩游戏。打搅如此兴致盎然的聚会需要一些勇气，可是我得干的事是不能拖延的，所以我走向了主人，他正站在英格拉姆小姐身边。当我接近的时候她转过了身，高傲地看着我：她的眼睛似乎在询问，“这个偷偷摸摸溜进来的家伙现在想做什么？”当我轻声喊了句“罗切斯特先生”，她做了个手势，似乎是在试着赶我走。我记得她当时的样子——非常高雅，惹人注目：她穿着一件有着天蓝色褶皱的晨袍；头上系着蔚蓝薄纱围巾。她玩游戏玩得兴致勃勃，即使是自尊受挫、被激怒了，也丝毫没有损害她脸部那高傲的神情。 He was not in any of the lower rooms; he was not in the yard, the stables, or the grounds.I asked Mrs. Fairfax if she had seen him;—yes: she believed he was playing billiards with Miss Ingram.To the billiard-room I hastened: the click of balls and the hum of voices resounded thence; Mr. Rochester, Miss Ingram, the two Misses Eshton, and their admirers, were all busied in the game.It required some courage to disturb so interesting a party; my errand, however, was one I could not defer, so I approached the master where he stood at Miss Ingram’s side.She turned as I drew near, and looked at me haughtily: her eyes seemed to demand, “What can the creeping creature want now?”and when I said, in a low voice, “Mr. Rochester,” she made a movement as if tempted to order me away.I remember her appearance at the moment—it was very graceful and very striking: she wore a morning robe of sky-blue crape; a gauzy azure scarf was twisted in her hair.She had been all animation with the game, and irritated pride did not lower the expression of her haughty lineaments.
“那个人想找你吗？”她询问罗切斯特先生。罗切斯特先生转过身来看看“那个人”是谁。他做了个好奇的鬼脸——他那奇怪又含糊的表达方式之一——扔下了他的球杆，跟我出了房间。 “Does that person want you?” she inquired of Mr. Rochester; and Mr. Rochester turned to see who the “person” was.He made a curious grimace—one of his strange and equivocal demonstrations—threw down his cue and followed me from the room.
“怎么了，简？”他一边说着，一边关上了教室门，靠在上面。 “Well, Jane?” he said, as he rested his back against the schoolroom door, which he had shut.
“如果您允许，先生，我想请一两个星期的假。” “If you please, sir, I want leave of absence for a week or two.”
“做什么？——去哪儿？” “What to do?—where to go?”
“去看一位病重的女士，她派人来找我了。” “To see a sick lady who has sent for me.”
“什么病重的女士？——她住在哪儿？” “What sick lady?—where does she live?”
“在盖茨黑德，在某郡。” “At Gates head; in—shire.”
“某郡？那儿离这有一百英里！她是谁，让你跑到那么远的地方去看她？” “—shire?That is a hundred miles off!Who may she be that sends for people to see her that distance?”
“她姓里德，先生——里德夫人。” “Her name is Reed, sir—Mrs. Reed.”
“盖茨黑德的里德？在盖茨黑德有过一个姓‘里德’的，做过地方法官。” “Reed of Gateshead?There was a Reed of Gateshead, a magistrate.”
“是他的寡妇，先生。” “It is his widow, sir.”
“你跟她有什么关系？ “And what have you to do with her?
你是怎么认识她的？”“里德先生是我的舅舅——我母亲的哥哥。” How do you know her?”“Mr. Reed was my uncle—my mother’s brother.”
“见鬼了，他是你舅舅！你以前从来没跟我说过，你总是说自己没有亲戚。” “The deuce he was!You never told me that before: you always said you had no relations.”
“没有一个亲戚愿意收养我，先生。里德先生已经去世，他的妻子就把我赶出来了。” “None that would own me, sir.Mr. Reed is dead, and his wife cast me off.”
“为什么？” “Why?”
“因为我很穷，是个累赘，而且她不喜欢我。” “Because I was poor, and burdensome, and she disliked me.”
“里德留下孩子了吗？——你一定有表兄妹吧？乔治·林恩爵士昨天提到了一位盖茨黑德的里德先生，说他是镇上绝对的流氓；英格拉姆也谈到那地方有一位乔治亚娜·里德，一两个社交季以前在伦敦很多人仰慕她的美貌。” “But Reed left children?—you must have cousins?Sir George Lynn was talking of a Reed of Gateshead yesterday, who, he said, was one of the veriest rascals on town; and Ingram was mentioning a Georgiana Reed of the same place, who was much admired for her beauty a season or two ago in London.”
“约翰·里德死了，先生：他毁了自己，也差不多毁了他的全家，据说他是自杀的。这个消息对他母亲的打击很大，结果中风了。” “John Reed is dead, too, sir: he ruined himself and half-ruined his family, and is supposed to have committed suicide.The news so shocked his mother that it brought on an apoplectic attack.”
“那你去又能帮她什么呢？胡闹，简！要是我，我绝对不会想要跑一百英里去见一位老太太，或许在你到之前她就死了，而且你说她还把你赶走了你。” “And what good can you do her?Nonsense, Jane!I would never think of running a hundred miles to see an old lady who will, perhaps, be dead before you reach her: besides, you say she cast you off.”
“是这样的，先生，不过那是很久以前的事了，那时她的情况很不同。现在，我要是不理睬她的愿望，就无法安心。” “Yes, sir, but that is long ago; and when her circumstances were very different: I could not be easy to neglect her wishes now.”
“你要呆多长时间？” “How long will you stay?”
“我会尽量呆得短一些的，先生。” “As short a time as possible, sir.”
“答应我只呆一个星期——” “Promise me only to stay a week—”
“我最好还是不要答应您：可能我不得不违背诺言。” “I had better not pass my word: I might be obliged to break it.”
“不论发生什么事情你都要回来。你不会被任何借口引诱着永远和她住在一起吧？” “At all events you WILL come back: you will not be induced under any pretext to take up a permanent residence with her?”
“噢，不会的！如果一切顺利的话我当然会回来。” “Oh, no!I shall certainly return if all be well.”
“那谁跟你一起去？你不能自己一个人走一百英里的路。” “And who goes with you?You don’t travel a hundred miles alone.”
“不会的，先生，她让她的马车夫过来接我了。” “No, sir, she has sent her coachman.”
“是个能信任的人吗？” “A person to be trusted?”
“是的，先生，他在那个家庭呆了十年了。” “Yes, sir, he has lived ten years in the family.”
罗切斯特先生沉思了一会儿。“你希望什么时候走？” Mr. Rochester meditated.“When do you wish to go?”
“明天一大早，先生。” “Early tomorrow morning, sir.”
“那，你一定得带一些钱；出门可不能没有钱，我敢说你没有多少钱：我还没给你发工资呢。你现在有多少钱，简？”他笑着问道。 “Well, you must have some money; you can’t travel without money, and I daresay you have not much: I have given you no salary yet.How much have you in the world, Jane?”he asked, smiling.
我拿出钱包，它瘪瘪的。“五先令，先生。”他拿过钱包，把里面的积蓄倒在手掌上，朝着它们轻声笑了笑，好像因为它们太少，把他逗乐了。他马上拿出了自己的皮夹：“给，”他说着，递给我了一张支票；是50英镑的，而他不过欠了我15英镑的工资。我告诉他我没有零钱找。 I drew out my purse; a meagre thing it was.“Five shillings, sir.”He took the purse, poured the hoard into his palm, and chuckled over it as if its scantiness amused him.Soon he produced his pocketbook: “Here,” said he, offering me a note; it was fifty pounds, and he owed me but fifteen.I told him I had no change.
“我不用你找，你知道的。把你的工资拿去。” “I don’t want change; you know that.Take your wages.”
我拒绝接受超过我应得的那部分钱。他一开始沉下了脸；后来又像想起了什么似的，他说—— I declined accepting more than was my due.He scowled at first; then, as if recollecting something, he said—
“好吧！好吧！最好现在不要给你所有的钱：如果你有50英镑的话你可能会在外面呆上三个月。这是10英镑，够不够？” “Right, right!Better not give you all now: you would, perhaps, stay away three months if you had fifty pounds.There are ten; is it not plenty?”
“够了，先生，不过现在您欠我五英镑。” “Yes, sir, but now you owe me five.”
“那就回来拿吧。把你的40英镑存在我这儿。” “Come back for it, then; I am your banker for forty pounds.”
“罗切斯特先生，趁我现在有机会，我还要跟您谈谈另外一件重要的事。” “Mr. Rochester, I may as well mention another matter of business to you while I have the opportunity.”
“重要的事？我很想听听。” “Matter of business?I am curious to hear it.”
“您其实已经告诉我了，先生，您很快就要结婚了？” “You have as good as informed me, sir, that you are going shortly to be married?”
“对。那又怎么了？” “Yes; what then?”
“那样的话，先生，阿德拉应该去学校上学。我相信您能理解这个必要性。 “In that case, sir, Adele ought to go to school: I am sure you will perceive the necessity of it.”
“让她不要碍我新娘的事儿，要不然，谁能无所顾忌地欺负她呢？这个建议的确有道理，毫无疑问。阿德拉，就像你说的，必须去上学；而你，当然得直接奔向——魔鬼？” “To get her out of my bride’s way, who might otherwise walk over her rather too emphatically?There’s sense in the suggestion; not a doubt of it.Adele, as you say, must go to school; and you, of course, must march straight to—the devil?”
“我希望不会这样，先生，不过我得上哪儿找另一份工作了。” “I hope not, sir; but I must seek another situation somewhere.”
“真是时候！”他大声喊着，带着浓重的鼻音，脸部扭曲了一下，表情既迷人又可笑。他看了我几分钟。 “In course!” he exclaimed, with a twang of voice and a distortion of features equally fantastic and ludicrous.He looked at me some minutes.
“那个里德夫人，或者小姐们，她的女儿们，你会请求他们帮你找到一个新地方，是不是？” “And old Madam Reed, or the Misses, her daughters, will be solicited by you to seek a place, I suppose?”
“不会的，先生。我和我的亲戚们没有那么好的关系，他们不会帮我的忙——不过我会登广告的。” “No, sir; I am not on such terms with my relatives as would justify me in asking favours of them—but I shall advertise.”
“你还能爬上埃及的金字塔呢！”他咆哮着说。“如果你贴广告你就得小心点儿了！我希望我只给了你一英镑，而不是十英镑。把那九英镑还给我，简。我有用。” “You shall walk up the pyramids of Egypt!” he growled.“At your peril you advertise!I wish I had only offered you a sovereign instead of ten pounds.Give me back nine pounds, Jane; I’ve a use for it.”
“我也有用，先生，”我回道，把手和钱包都背在身后。“不管什么原因我都不会把这些钱分给你。” “And so have I, sir,” I returned, putting my hands and my purse behind me.“I could not spare the money on any account.”
“小气鬼！”他说，“跟你要点儿钱都不肯！给我五英镑，简。” “Little niggard!” said he, “refusing me a pecuniary request!Give me five pounds, Jane.”
“五先令都不会给的，先生，五便士也不行。” “Not five shillings, sir; nor five pence.”
“那就让我看看那些钱。” “Just let me look at the cash.”
“不行，先生。您不可信。” “No, sir; you are not to be trusted.”
“简！” “Jane!”
“先生？” “Sir?”
“答应我一件事。” “Promise me one thing.”
“如果我有可能做到，我会答应您任何事的，先生。” “I’ll promise you anything, sir, that I think I am likely to perform.”
“不要贴广告，把找工作的事儿交给我。我会及时给你找到一个工作的。” “Not to advertise: and to trust this quest of a situation to me.I’ll find you one in time.”
“我很高兴这么办，先生，如果您反过来也能答应我：在您的新娘住进来以前，我和阿德拉会平安地搬出房子。” “I shall be glad so to do, sir, if you, in your turn, will promise that I and Adele shall be both safe out of the house before your bride enters it.”
“好的！好的！我发誓我会做到。那你明天走，是吧？” “Very well! very well!I’ll pledge my word on it.You go tomorrow, then?”
“是的，先生，明天一大早。 “Yes, sir; early.”
“晚饭后你还来客厅吗？” “Shall you come down to the drawing-room after dinner?”
“我来不了了，先生，我得准备一下行李。” “No, sir, I must prepare for the journey.”
“那你和我就得暂时告别了？” “Then you and I must bid good-bye for a little while?”
“我想是的，先生。” “I suppose so, sir.”
“人们是怎样进行那种告别仪式的，简？教教我，我不太会做。” “And how do people perform that ceremony of parting, Jane?Teach me; I’m not quite up to it.”
“他们会说再见，或者用别的他们喜欢的方式。” “They say, Farewell, or any other form they prefer.”
“那就说吧。” “Then say it.”
“再见，罗切斯特先生，暂时小别。” “Farewell, Mr. Rochester, for the present.”
“我应该说什么？” “What must I say?”
“说一样的话，如果您愿意的话，先生。” “The same, if you like, sir.”
“再见，爱小姐，暂时小别；这就完了？” “Farewell, Miss Eyre, for the present; is that all?”
“是的吧？” “Yes?”
“这听起来很吝啬，对我来说，而且很生硬，很不友好。我希望有点儿别的东西：这个仪式得添点儿什么。比如说握握手什么的。不——那也没法让我满足。所以除了说再见以外，你不会再做什么别的了，简？” “It seems stingy, to my notions, and dry, and unfriendly.I should like something else: a little addition to the rite.If one shook hands, for instance; but no—that would not content me either.So you’ll do no more than say Farewell, Jane?”
“这就够了，先生：只要衷心的话，一句抵得上千万句。 “It is enough, sir: as much good will may be conveyed in one hearty word as in many.”
“很有可能。但是它既空洞又冰冷——‘再见。’” “Very likely; but it is blank and cool—‘Farewell.’”
“他到底要在那扇门上靠多久？”我问自己，“我想开始收拾我的行李了。”晚饭的铃声响了，他突然走开了，没有再说一句话。那一天我再也没有见到他，早上在他起床前我就离开了。 “How long is he going to stand with his back against that door?”I asked myself; “I want to commence my packing.”The dinner-bell rang, and suddenly away he bolted, without another syllable: I saw him no more during the day, and was off before he had risen in the morning.
差不多是五月第一天下午的五点钟，我到了盖茨黑德那座宅子的门房。进府之前我先到这儿看了看。门房里既干净又整洁：装饰性的窗边挂着小小的白色窗帘；地板一尘不染；壁炉和火钩被擦得锃亮，炉火正明亮地燃烧着。贝茜坐在炉旁，正给最小的孩子喂奶，罗伯特和他妹妹在角落安静地玩耍。 I reached the lodge at Gateshead about five o’clock in the afternoon of the first of May: I stepped in there before going up to the hall.It was very clean and neat: the ornamental windows were hung with little white curtains; the floor was spotless; the grate and fire-irons were burnished bright, and the fire burnt clear.Bessie sat on the hearth, nursing her last-born, and Robert and his sister played quietly in a corner.
“上帝保佑你！——我知道你会来的！”我进来的时候，利文夫人喊道。 “Bless you!—I knew you would come!” exclaimed Mrs. Leaven, as I entered.
“是的，贝茜，”吻了她一下之后说道，“我想我来得不太晚吧。里德夫人怎么样？——还活着，我希望。” “Yes, Bessie,” said I, after I had kissed her; “and I trust I am not too late.How is Mrs. Reed?—Alive still, I hope.”
“是的，她还活着，而且比之前更清醒、更镇定了。医生说她还能拖个一两个星期，不过他不认为她能完全康复。” “Yes, she is alive; and more sensible and collected than she was.The doctor says she may linger a week or two yet; but he hardly thinks she will finally recover.”
“她最近提到我了吗？” “Has she mentioned me lately?”
“她只在今天早上说到了你，希望你会来，不过她现在睡着了，或者说是十分钟以前我在楼上的时候她还睡着。每天下午她差不多都是昏昏沉沉地睡着，大概六七点钟才醒。你能在这儿休息一个小时吗，小姐，然后我跟你一起上去。” “She was talking of you only this morning, and wishing you would come, but she is sleeping now, or was ten minutes ago, when I was up at the house.She generally lies in a kind of lethargy all the afternoon, and wakes up about six or seven.Will you rest yourself here an hour, Miss, and then I will go up with you?”
这个时候罗伯特进来了，贝茜把睡着了的孩子放进摇篮，然后过去迎接他。后来她非要让我摘下帽子，用点儿茶，因为她说我看起来既苍白又劳累。我很乐意地接受了她的好意，顺从地脱下了旅行穿的衣服，就好像以前还是孩子的时候，乖乖地由她给我脱衣服一样。 Robert here entered, and Bessie laid her sleeping child in the cradle and went to welcome him: afterwards she insisted on my taking off my bonnet and having some tea; for she said I looked pale and tired.I was glad to accept her hospitality; and I submitted to be relieved of my travelling garb just as passively as I used to let her undress me when a child.
看着她忙来忙去的，旧日的时光飞快地涌上我的心头——她把她最好的瓷器摆上茶盘，切开面包和黄油，烤了个小茶点，在这期间还偶尔敲敲或者推推小罗伯特和简，就像她过去对我做的一样。贝茜仍然是急性子，走起路来同样轻快，面容依旧美丽。 “To put Adele to bed: it is past her bedtime.”Bessie had retained her quick temper as well as her light foot and good looks.
茶好了，我正准备走近桌子，她却要我静静地坐着，仍用着她以前说话的那专横的老调子。她说，我要呆在炉边，让她服侍。她在我面前放了一个圆圆的小茶几，上面放着我的杯子和一盘烤面包，就好像以前，她总是把一些自己私拿的美食放在保育室的椅子上让我吃一样。我笑着，像以往一样顺从了她。 Tea ready, I was going to approach the table; but she desired me to sit still, quite in her old peremptory tones.I must be served at the fireside, she said; and she placed before me a little round stand with my cup and a plate of toast, absolutely as she used to accommodate me with some privately purloined dainty on a nursery chair: and I smiled and obeyed her as in bygone days.
她想知道我在桑菲尔德府过得开不开心，还有那儿的女主人是什么样子的。当我告诉她那儿只有一位男主人时，她又问他是不是位善良的绅士，以及我喜不喜欢他。我告诉她他长得很丑，不过的确是一个绅士；还说他对我很好，我很满意。然后我接着向她描述那些最近住在宅子里的快乐的客人们，对这些细节贝西听得兴致勃勃：这一切正和她的胃口。 She wanted to know if I was happy at Thornfield Hall, and what sort of a person the mistress was; and when I told her there was only a master, whether he was a nice gentleman, and if I liked him.I told her he rather an ugly man, but quite a gentleman; and that he treated me kindly, and I was content.Then I went on to describe to her the gay company that had lately been staying at the house; and to these details Bessie listened with interest: they were precisely of the kind she relished.
我们这样聊着，一个小时很快就过去了：贝西给我重新戴好帽子等等，陪着我离开了门房，向大厅走去。差不多九年以前，同样是她，陪着我走下了这条我现在往上登的小道。那是一月一个黑暗、浓雾笼罩、冰冷刺骨的早晨，我带着一颗绝望而痛苦的心，离开了这座充满了敌意的宅子——怀着被排斥甚至抛弃的心情——去寻找洛伍德那冰冷的庇护港，那遥远而未知的目的地。同一座充满敌意的宅子现在再一次耸立在我面前：我的未来依然混沌未知，心里依然疼痛不已。我依然感觉自己像个在世间漂泊的流浪者，不过对于自己和自己的力量已经更有信心，对于压迫的退缩和恐惧也少了。冤枉委屈留下的巨大伤口也已愈合，仇恨的怒火已然熄灭。 In such conversation an hour was soon gone: Bessie restored to me my bonnet, &c., and, accompanied by her, I quitted the lodge for the hall.It was also accompanied by her that I had, nearly nine years ago, walked down the path I was now ascending.On a dark, misty, raw morning in January, I had left a hostile roof with a desperate and embittered heart—a sense of outlawry and almost of reprobation—to seek the chilly harbourage of Lowood: that bourne so far away and unexplored.The same hostile roof now again rose before me: my prospects were doubtful yet; and I had yet an aching heart.I still felt as a wanderer on the face of the earth; but I experienced firmer trust in myself and my own powers, and less withering dread of oppression.The gaping wound of my wrongs, too, was now quite healed; and the flame of resentment extinguished.
“你应该先去早餐室，”贝茜说着，并带我穿过大厅，“小姐们会在那里。” “You shall go into the breakfast-room first,” said Bessie, as she preceded me through the hall; “the young ladies will be there.”
没一会儿我就在那间屋子里了。这里的每一件家具，看起来就跟我第一次被介绍给布洛克赫斯特先生的那天早上一样。他站着的那块地毯仍然铺在炉边。看了一眼书柜，我想我能辨认出比伊克的两卷《英国鸟类史》，还在第三层书架它的老地方，《格列佛游记》和《一千零一夜》摆在它们正上方。无生命的事物没有改变，而有生命的东西却面目全非。 In another moment I was within that apartment.There was every article of furniture looking just as it did on the morning I was first introduced to Mr. Brocklehurst: the very rug he had stood upon still covered the hearth.Glancing at the bookcases, I thought I could distinguish the two volumes of Bewick’s @British Birds@ occupying their old place on the third shelf, and @Gulliver’s Travels@ and the @Arabian Nights@ ranged just above.The inanimate objects were not changed; but the living things had altered past recognition.
两位年轻的女士出现在我面前。一位个子高高的，就像英格拉姆小姐一样——还很瘦，脸色蜡黄，神情严肃。她的表情里有一种苦行者的意味，那一身极为朴素的打扮更加凸显了这一点：直挺的黑套装，浆过的亚麻衣领，头发从太阳穴向后梳去，修女似的装饰品——一串黑檀木的珠子和一个十字架。我肯定这就是伊莉莎，尽管在这张瘦长的的暗淡无光的脸上，我几乎找不到与往日的她的丝毫相近之处。 Two young ladies appeared before me; one very tall, almost as tall as Miss Ingram—very thin too, with a sallow face and severe mien.There was something ascetic in her look, which was augmented by the extreme plainness of a straight-skirted, black, stuff dress, a starched linen collar, hair combed away from the temples, and the nun-like ornament of a string of ebony beads and a crucifix.This I felt sure was Eliza, though I could trace little resemblance to her former self in that elongated and colourless visage.
另一个一定是乔治亚娜了，但已经不是我记忆中的乔治亚娜了——那个苗条的像个小仙女的十一岁姑娘。这是一个成熟而又丰满的女孩，就像蜡像一样精致，有着美丽匀称的五官，含情脉脉的蓝色眼睛，金色卷曲的头发。她的衣服也都是黑色的，不过样式跟姐姐的大有不同——飘逸得多，也合身得多——看起来非常时髦，就像另一位的服装看起来如清教徒一般朴素。 The other was as certainly Georgiana: but not the Georgiana I remembered—the slim and fairy-like girl of eleven.This was a full-blown, very plump damsel, fair as waxwork, with handsome and regular features, languishing blue eyes, and ringleted yellow hair.The hue of her dress was black too; but its fashion was so different from her sister’s—so much more flowing and becoming—it looked as stylish as the other’s looked puritanical.
她们两个身上都有一个她们母亲的特征——而且仅此一个。瘦弱苍白的姐姐有着母亲烟水晶般的眼睛，娇艳华丽的妹妹有着母亲的嘴和下巴——可能更柔和一些，不过仍然给那本来丰满健美的面部增加了一种难以言说的僵硬。 In each of the sisters there was one trait of the mother—and only one; the thin and pallid elder daughter had her parent’s Cairngorm eye: the blooming and luxuriant younger girl had her contour of jaw and chin—perhaps a little softened, but still imparting an indescribable hardness to the countenance otherwise so voluptuous and buxom.
我走向前时，两位小姐都起身迎接我，并都称呼我为“爱小姐”。伊莉莎用一种简短突兀的声音跟我打招呼，没有一点儿笑容。然后她又坐了下去，眼睛盯着炉火，好像忘记了我一样。乔治亚娜加了一句“你好吗？”，还有一些关于旅行、天气等等之类的寒暄。她拖着长腔慢吞吞地说着，还从各个侧面打量着我，从头到脚——视线一会儿扫过我浅褐色的美利奴精纺毛纱大衣的褶皱，一会儿又在我农家小帽朴素的饰边上停留。年轻的小姐们有着高超绝妙的手段，根本不用说出来就能让你知道，她们觉得你是个“怪人”。一种傲慢的眼神，冰冷淡然的态度，漠不关心的语调，都充分表达出了她们在这个问题上的看法，甚至都无需利用言行上的粗鲁明示。 Both ladies, as I advanced, rose to welcome me, and both addressed me by the name of “Miss Eyre.”Eliza’s greeting was delivered in a short, abrupt voice, without a smile; and then she sat down again, fixed her eyes on the fire, and seemed to forget me.Georgiana added to her “How d’ye do?” several commonplaces about my journey, the weather, and so on, uttered in rather a drawling tone: and accompanied by sundry side-glances that measured me from head to foot—now traversing the folds of my drab merino pelisse, and now lingering on the plain trimming of my cottage bonnet.Young ladies have a remarkable way of letting you know that they think you a “quiz” without actually saying the words.A certain superciliousness of look, coolness of manner, nonchalance of tone, express fully their sentiments on the point, without committing them by any positive rudeness in word or deed.
然而现在，不管是明嘲还是暗讽，都不再能像以前那样对我产生那么大的影响了：当我坐在我的表姐妹中间，我惊讶地发现，对于一位完全的忽视以及另一位半带讽刺的殷勤，我竟感觉到相当自在——伊莉莎没有让我感到羞辱，乔治亚娜也没有令我生气。实际上，我还有别的事情需要考虑。最近的几个月里，我的感情被汹涌地激起，比她们任何一个所引发的都要强烈——那种痛苦与欢乐，比她们能施加和赐予的尖锐得多，剧烈得多——她们的态度丝毫不能影响我，不能让我更快乐，也不会让我难过。 A sneer, however, whether covert or open, had now no longer that power over me it once possessed: as I sat between my cousins, I was surprised to find how easy I felt under the total neglect of the one and the semi-sarcastic attentions of the other—Eliza did not mortify, nor Georgiana ruffle me.The fact was, I had other things to think about; within the last few months feelings had been stirred in me so much more potent than any they could raise—pains and pleasures so much more acute and exquisite had been excited than any it was in their power to inflict or bestow—that their airs gave me no concern either for good or bad.
“里德夫人怎么样了？”很快我就问了，平静地看着乔治亚娜。她觉得理应对这直接的说法表示愤怒抗议，好像这是一种出人意料的放肆行为。 “How is Mrs. Reed?”I asked soon, looking calmly at Georgiana, who thought fit to bridle at the direct address, as if it were an unexpected liberty.
“里德夫人？啊！你是说妈妈。她情况非常不好，我怀疑你今晚是否能见她。” “Mrs. Reed?Ah! mama, you mean; she is extremely poorly: I doubt if you can see her tonight.”
“如果，”我说，“你能上楼告诉她我来了，我会非常感激你的。” “If,” said I, “you would just step upstairs and tell her I am come, I should be much obliged to you.”
乔治亚娜几乎跳了起来，把她的蓝眼睛睁得又圆又大。“我知道她特别希望见我，”我补充说，“并且我不会把顾及她愿望的事情推迟，除非是绝对必要。” Georgiana almost started, and she opened her blue eyes wild and wide.“I know she had a particular wish to see me,” I added, “and I would not defer attending to her desire longer than is absolutely necessary.”
“妈妈不喜欢晚上被人打扰。”伊莉莎说道。我马上站了起来，未经邀请就一声不响地摘下我的帽子和手套，说我要出去见贝茜——我想她肯定在厨房里——并且让她弄清楚里德夫人今晚是否愿意见我。我去了，找到了贝茜并让她帮我跑个腿，我打算开始采取进一步的行动了。此前，在傲慢面前畏缩一直是我的习惯。今天受到的这种待遇，如果是一年以前，我肯定决定在第二天早晨就离开盖茨黑德。现在，我突然一下子明白了那会是个很愚蠢的计划。我走了一百英里的路来看望我的舅妈，就应该陪着她，直到她好起来——或者离世。而对于她女儿们的傲慢或是愚蠢，我应该放在一边，让自己不要受到影响。所以我叫了管家，让她给我找一间房间，告诉她我大概要在这里暂住一两个星期，要她把我的行李箱搬到屋子里来，并跟着一起进了屋。我在楼梯平台上见到了贝茜。 “Mama dislikes being disturbed in an evening,” remarked Eliza.I soon rose, quietly took off my bonnet and gloves, uninvited, and said I would just step out to Bessie—who was, I dared say, in the kitchen—and ask her to ascertain whether Mrs. Reed was disposed to receive me or not tonight.I went, and having found Bessie and despatched her on my errand, I proceeded to take further measures.It had heretofore been my habit always to shrink from arrogance: received as I had been today, I should, a year ago, have resolved to quit Gateshead the very next morning; now, it was disclosed to me all at once that that would be a foolish plan.I had taken a journey of a hundred miles to see my aunt, and I must stay with her till she was better—or dead: as to her daughters’ pride or folly, I must put it on one side, make myself independent of it.So I addressed the housekeeper; asked her to show me a room, told her I should probably be a visitor here for a week or two, had my trunk conveyed to my chamber, and followed it thither myself: I met Bessie on the landing.
“夫人醒了，”她说，“我告诉她你在这儿，来吧，让我们瞧瞧她能不能认出你。” “Missis is awake,” said she; “I have told her you are here: come and let us see if she will know you.”
我不需要指引就能走到那间熟悉的房间，以前我太多次被叫到那儿接受严惩和训斥了。我急走两步到贝茜前面，轻轻地打开了门：一盏带着灯罩的台灯放在桌子上，现在天快黑了。依然是这张四个柱子的大床，挂着琥珀色的床帘。依然是这梳妆台，扶手椅，垫脚凳，我被数百次在这凳子上罚跪，为我从未犯过的错误请求原谅。我看向一个附近的角落，有点儿期待会看到那个我曾经害怕极了的鞭子的瘦削轮廓，以前它就潜伏在那里，等待着像个小恶魔似的跳出来，绑住我颤抖的手掌和畏缩的脖子。我走近床，打开床帘，凑近了那高高堆起的枕头。 I did not need to be guided to the well-known room, to which I had so often been summoned for chastisement or reprimand in former days.I hastened before Bessie; I softly opened the door: a shaded light stood on the table, for it was now getting dark.There was the great four-post bed with amber hangings as of old; there the toilet table, the armchair, and the footstool, at which I had a hundred times been sentenced to kneel, to ask pardon for offences by me uncommitted.I looked into a certain corner near, half-expecting to see the slim outline of a once dreaded switch which used to lurk there, waiting to leap out imp-like and lace my quivering palm or shrinking neck.I approached the bed; I opened the curtains and leant over the high-piled pillows.
我很清晰地记着里德夫人的脸，并急切地想寻找到熟悉的形象。我很高兴，因为时间已平息了复仇的渴望，使愤怒与厌恶的冲动镇静下来。我曾经在痛苦与仇恨中离开这个女人，而现在我回到了她身边，心中只有对她可怕遭遇的同情，以及一种忘记并且原谅一切伤害的强烈渴望——渴望着重归于好，握手言和。 Well did I remember Mrs. Reed’s face, and I eagerly sought the familiar image.It is a happy thing that time quells the longings of vengeance and hushes the promptings of rage and aversion.I had left this woman in bitterness and hate, and I came back to her now with no other emotion than a sort of ruth for her great sufferings, and a strong yearning to forget and forgive all injuries—to be reconciled and clasp hands in amity.
那张熟悉的脸就在那儿：严厉的，无情的，就像以前一样——那一切都无法感动的古怪的眼睛，还有那微微扬起的，傲慢专横的眉毛。那双眼睛曾经多少次俯视着我，带着威胁和仇恨！此时我追溯着它严酷的线条时，那些童年恐惧悲伤的记忆是怎样强烈地苏醒过来！然而我仍然俯下身来，亲吻了她，她正看着我。 The well-known face was there: stern, relentless as ever—there was that peculiar eye which nothing could melt, and the somewhat raised, imperious, despotic eyebrow.How often had it lowered on me menace and hate! and how the recollection of childhood’s terrors and sorrows revived as I traced its harsh line now!And yet I stooped down and kissed her: she looked at me.
“是简·爱吗？”她说。 “Is this Jane Eyre?” she said.
“是的，里德舅妈。您怎么样了，亲爱的舅妈？” “Yes, Aunt Reed.How are you, dear aunt?”
我曾经发誓我永远也不会再叫她舅妈。我想现在忘记并违背这个誓言并不是一种罪过。我的手指抓紧了她搭在被单外的手。要是她也慈祥地握紧我的，在那一刻我将体会到多么真实的快乐啊。但是冷酷的本性没那么快改变，天生的厌恶也没那么容易消除。里德夫人抽出了她的手，并且转过脸不看我，说晚上很暖和。然后她又一次如此冰冷地注视着我，我马上感觉到了她对我的看法——她对我的感情——没有变化，也无法改变。我明白了这一点，通过她那石头般的眼睛——温柔无法穿透，眼泪溶解不了——我明白了她最终仍然决定把我认定成一个坏人，因为相信我是好人不能给她慷慨的快乐，只能带来羞辱的感觉。 I had once vowed that I would never call her aunt again: I thought it no sin to forget and break that vow now.My fingers had fastened on her hand which lay outside the sheet: had she pressed mine kindly, I should at that moment have experienced true pleasure.But unimpressionable natures are not so soon softened, nor are natural antipathies so readily eradicated.Mrs. Reed took her hand away, and, turning her face rather from me, she remarked that the night was warm.Again she regarded me so icily, I felt at once that her opinion of me—her feeling towards me—was unchanged and unchangeable.I knew by her stony eye—opaque to tenderness, indissoluble to tears—that she was resolved to consider me bad to the last; because to believe me good would give her no generous pleasure: only a sense of mortification.
我感到痛苦，又感到愤怒，接着就萌发了一种制服她的决心——不管她的天性和意愿如何，都要去控制她。就像在童年时一样，我的眼泪涌了上来。我命令它们回到它们的源头去。我把一把椅子搬到床头，坐了下来，靠近枕头。 I felt pain, and then I felt ire; and then I felt a determination to subdue her—to be her mistress in spite both of her nature and her will.My tears had risen, just as in childhood: I ordered them back to their source.I brought a chair to the bed-head: I sat down and leaned over the pillow.
“您让人来找我，”我说，“我现在在这儿，我希望留下来，看看您的情况如何。” “You sent for me,” I said, “and I am here; and it is my intention to stay till I see how you get on.”
“哦，当然！你见过我的女儿们了吗？” “Oh, of course!You have seen my daughters?”
“是的。” “Yes.”
“好，那你可以告诉她们，我希望你能留在这里，直到我可以告诉你一些我脑子里的事情。今晚太晚了，而且要回忆起来那些事情很困难。不过我有些话要说——让我想想——” “Well, you may tell them I wish you to stay till I can talk some things over with you I have on my mind: tonight it is too late, and I have a difficulty in recalling them.But there was something I wished to say—let me see—”
那游离的神态和变化了的语调说明她曾经精力充沛的身体已经严重损毁。焦躁不安地转过身，她把被单扯来想裹住全身。我的胳膊肘正好搭在被子角上，压住了它，她马上发怒了。 The wandering look and changed utterance told what wreck had taken place in her once vigorous frame.Turning restlessly, she drew the bedclothes round her; my elbow, resting on a corner of the quilt, fixed it down: she was at once irritated.
“坐直！”她说，“不要把被单压紧，惹我生气。你是简·爱吗？” “Sit up!” said she; “don’t annoy me with holding the clothes fast.Are you Jane Eyre?”
“我是简·爱。” “I am Jane Eyre.”
“那个孩子给我带来了太多麻烦，多得超过任何人的想象。这么大的负担压在我这里——而且她还带给我那么多麻烦，几乎每天每小时，她的个性让人无法理解，还常常突然发起脾气，老是古怪地注视别人的行动！我肯定有一次她像个疯子一样跟我说话，或者说像个魔鬼——没有一个孩子会像她那样说话或者看人。我很高兴把她弄出了这个宅子。在洛伍德他们对她做了什么？那儿爆发了伤寒，很多学生都死了。不过，她却没死。但我说她死了——我希望她死了！” “I have had more trouble with that child than any one would believe.Such a burden to be left on my hands—and so much annoyance as she caused me, daily and hourly, with her incomprehensible disposition, and her sudden starts of temper, and her continual, unnatural watchings of one’s movements!I declare she talked to me once like something mad, or like a fiend—no child ever spoke or looked as she did; I was glad to get her away from the house.What did they do with her at Lowood?The fever broke out there, and many of the pupils died.She, however, did not die: but I said she did—I wish she had died!”
“真是奇怪的愿望，里德夫人。您为什么这么恨她？” “A strange wish, Mrs. Reed; why do you hate her so?”
“我一向不喜欢她的母亲，因为她是我丈夫唯一的妹妹，而且是他最宠爱的人：当她下嫁给一个下等人的时候，是他反对全家跟她解除关系；她去世的消息传来的时候，他哭得像个傻瓜。他要去把那个婴儿接回来，尽管我恳求他宁可出钱把她送给保姆养大。第一眼看到那孩子的时候我就讨厌她——一个病怏怏的、总是哭闹的、瘦弱的小东西！她会整晚上都在摇篮里哭——不像其他孩子那样痛快地放声大哭，而是呜咽和呻吟。里德可怜她，他照顾她、关注她，就像她是自己的孩子一样。甚至自己的孩子在那样的年纪他都没有那样关注过。他试着让我的孩子们对那个小乞丐友好一些，可是亲爱的们根本忍受不了她，当孩子们表现出讨厌她时，他就很生气。他病重的时候，不断让人把她带到病床前，在他死前的一个小时他还一定要我发誓会抚养那个小东西。我倒宁愿养一个济贫院里的穷孩子。不过他很懦弱，天生的懦弱。约翰一点儿都不像他的父亲，这一点让我很高兴：约翰像我和我的兄弟们——他是个典型的吉普森家的人。噢，我希望他不要再写信要钱来折磨我了。我没有更多的钱给他了：我们越来越穷了。我必须辞掉家里一半的仆人，关掉一部分房间，或者租出去。我不可能甘愿做这些——可是不这样，我们又将怎样活下去呢？我三分之二的收入都用来付他那些抵押的利息了。约翰赌博赌得很厉害，而且总输——可怜的孩子！他被骗子给困住了。他跌下去了，堕落了——他看起来非常可怕——我看到他的时候觉得很羞耻。” “I had a dislike to her mother always; for she was my husband’s only sister, and a great favourite with him: he opposed the family’s disowning her when she made her low marriage; and when news came of her death, he wept like a simpleton.He would send for the baby; though I entreated him rather to put it out to nurse and pay for its maintenance.I hated it the first time I set my eyes on it—a sickly, whining, pining thing!It would wail in its cradle all night long—not screaming heartily like any other child, but whimpering and moaning.Reed pitied it; and he used to nurse it and notice it as if it had been his own: more, indeed, than he ever noticed his own at that age.He would try to make my children friendly to the little beggar: the darlings could not bear it, and he was angry with them when they showed their dislike.In his last illness, he had it brought continually to his bedside; and but an hour before he died, he bound me by vow to keep the creature.I would as soon have been charged with a pauper brat out of a workhouse: but he was weak, naturally weak.John does not at all resemble his father, and I am glad of it: John is like me and like my brothers—he is quite a Gibson.Oh, I wish he would cease tormenting me with letters for money?I have no more money to give him: we are getting poor.I must send away half the servants and shut up part of the house; or let it off.I can never submit to do that—yet how are we to get on?Two-thirds of my income goes in paying the interest of mortgages.John gambles dreadfully, and always loses—poor boy!He is beset by sharpers: John is sunk and degraded—his look is frightful—I feel ashamed for him when I see him.”
她越说越激动。“我觉得我现在还是离开她为好，”我对贝茜说，她正站在床的另一边。 She was getting much excited.“I think I had better leave her now,” said I to Bessie, who stood on the other side of the bed.
“可能这样更好，小姐，不过她夜里总是这样说话——早上她会安静些。” “Perhaps you had, Miss: but she often talks in this way towards night—in the morning she is calmer.”
我站起身来。“站住！”她大声喊道，“还有件事我要说。他威胁我——他不断地用自杀，或者杀死我来威胁我，我有时候会梦到看见他入殓，他喉咙上有一个巨大的伤口，或者是脸庞又黑又肿。我来到了一个陌生的路口，我有那么多的麻烦。应该怎么做？应该怎么弄到钱？” I rose.“Stop!” exclaimed Mrs. Reed, “there is another thing I wished to say.He threatens me—he continually threatens me with his own death, or mine: and I dream sometimes that I see him laid out with a great wound in his throat, or with a swollen and blackened face.I am come to a strange pass: I have heavy troubles.What is to be done?How is the money to be had?”
贝茜现在正尽力劝她服一剂镇定剂，她费劲心思总算是做到了。不一会儿，里德夫人越来越安静，并且开始昏昏欲睡。之后我离开了她。 Bessie now endeavoured to persuade her to take a sedative draught: she succeeded with difficulty.Soon after, Mrs. Reed grew more composed, and sank into a dozing state.I then left her.
十多天过去了，我没有再跟她有过一次对话。她仍然是要么神志不清，要么昏昏沉沉。医生禁止一切有可能刺激到她、让她痛苦的事情。同时，我尽全力与乔治亚娜和伊莉莎友好相处。开始的时候，她们的确非常冷漠。伊莉莎会花上半天的时间缝纫、阅读或者写作，跟我或跟她妹妹都不说一句话。乔治亚娜会跟她的金丝雀一小时一小时地闲扯，根本不理我。不过我决定不要让自己看起来一副无所事事、没有乐趣的样子。我带了画画儿的工具，它们既能让我有事做，又能给我带来快乐。 More than ten days elapsed before I had again any conversation with her.She continued either delirious or lethargic; and the doctor forbade everything which could painfully excite her.Meantime, I got on as well as I could with Georgiana and Eliza.They were very cold, indeed, at first.Eliza would sit half the day sewing, reading, or writing, and scarcely utter a word either to me or her sister.Georgiana would chatter nonsense to her canary bird by the hour, and take no notice of me.But I was determined not to seem at a loss for occupation or amusement: I had brought my drawing materials with me, and they served me for both.
带着一盒铅笔和一些纸，在远离她们的地方坐下来，靠近窗户，忙着画些幻想的小插图，把那现身在我飘移不定、瞬息万变的想象中的任何一个一闪而过的场景表现出来：两块礁石中的大海的一瞥；正在缓缓上升的月亮，一只船驶过它的圆盘；一簇芦苇和香蒲，水中仙女的脑袋，从莲花的簇拥中探出来；一个精灵坐在树篱中麻雀的巢里，山楂树的花环下面。 Provided with a case of pencils, and some sheets of paper, I used to take a seat apart from them, near the window, and busy myself in sketching fancy vignettes, representing any scene that happened momentarily to shape itself in the ever-shifting kaleidoscope of imagination: a glimpse of sea between two rocks;the rising moon, and a ship crossing its disk; a group of reeds and water-flags, and a naiad’s head, crowned with lotus-flowers, rising out of them; an elf sitting in a hedge-sparrow’s nest, under a wreath of hawthorn bloom.
一天清晨我开始画一张脸。它将会是一张什么样的脸，我不在意，也不知道。我拿起一只黑色的软铅笔，笔留得很粗，然后开始画。没一会儿，我便在纸上画出了一个突出的宽额头和一张方形脸庞垂下的轮廓。这轮廓让我很愉快，我的手指继续忙着给它添上五官。前额下面应该画上浓重的直直的眉毛；然后自然要跟着一个轮廓清晰的鼻子，挺拔的鼻梁和大大的鼻孔；接着是一张柔软灵活的嘴，绝对不小；还有一个坚定的下巴，在中间有个明显的凹痕；当然，还需要一些黑色的络腮胡，还有一些乌黑的头发，簇生于鬓角，波浪般覆盖了前额。现在轮到眼睛了。我把它们留在最后，因为它们需要最认真细心的描绘。我把它们画得很大，轮廓清晰：睫毛绘得又长又忧郁，眼珠大大的，闪烁着光芒。“很好！不过并不太像，”我想到，并考察了画的效果：“它们需要更多的力量和神采。”然后我把阴影雕饰得更加黑暗，光亮部分必须闪烁得更加耀眼——恰当的一两笔勾勒就保证了成功。瞧，我眼下出现了一位朋友的脸庞，那些年轻的小姐们不理睬我又有什么大不了呢？我看着它，这显而易见的相似让我微笑，我觉得又着迷又满足。 One morning I fell to sketching a face: what sort of a face it was to be, I did not care or know.I took a soft black pencil, gave it a broad point, and worked away.Soon I had traced on the paper a broad and prominent forehead and a square lower outline of visage: that contour gave me pleasure; my fingers proceeded actively to fill it with features.Strongly-marked horizontal eyebrows must be traced under that brow; then followed, naturally, a well-defined nose, with a straight ridge and full nostrils; then a flexible looking mouth, by no means narrow; then a firm chin, with a decided cleft down the middle of it: of course, some black whiskers were wanted, and some jetty hair, tufted on the temples, and waved above the forehead.Now for the eyes: I had left them to the last, because they required the most careful working.I drew them large; I shaped them well: the eyelashes I traced long and sombre; the irids lustrous and large.“Good! but not quite the thing,” I thought, as I surveyed the effect: “they want more force and spirit;” and I wrought the shades blacker, that the lights might flash more brilliantly—a happy touch or two secured success.There, I had a friend’s face under my gaze; and what did it signify that those young ladies turned their backs on me?I looked at it; I smiled at the speaking likeness: I was absorbed and content.
“这是你认识的人的肖像吗？”伊莉莎问道，我根本没注意到她走近了我。我回答说这只是一张想象中的头像，并且迅速把它埋在其他纸张的下面。当然，我撒谎了。其实，这完全是一张罗切斯特先生的逼真的画像。不过这画像对她来说，对除了我以外的任何人来说，又有什么意义呢？乔治亚娜也走过来看。别的画儿她很高兴，不过那张画却被她称为“一个丑男人。”她们俩似乎都对我的绘画技巧很吃惊。我主动要求给她俩画肖像画，两人轮流坐下来让我用铅笔画了素描。接着乔治亚娜拿出了她的画册。我答应再添上一张水彩画，她听到了以后顿时高兴起来。她提出我们去院子里散步。我们一起出去不到两个小时，就已经完全互相信任地在交谈了。她赏脸跟我描述了她两个社交季以前在伦敦度过的美好冬天——人们对她的倾慕——她所受到的关注，她甚至跟我暗示她曾经征服的一些有贵族头衔的人。在下午以及傍晚，这些暗示进一步增多了。她跟我报道了那些丰富多彩的温柔对话，展示了一些极为感性的场景。简单来说，那天她为我临时拼凑了关于上流社会时尚生活的一卷小说。这种交谈每天都在更新着。它们总是关于同一主题——她自己，她的爱情，还有她的痛苦。令人奇怪的是她从来没有一次谈到过她母亲的病，或者她哥哥的死，亦或是现在家里惨淡未来。她的脑子似乎被过去快乐时光的回忆，以及对未来放荡生活的憧憬完全占据了。她每天在她母亲的病房里最多只逗留五分钟。 “Is that a portrait of some one you know?” asked Eliza, who had approached me unnoticed.I responded that it was merely a fancy head, and hurried it beneath the other sheets.Of course, I lied: it was, in fact, a very faithful representation of Mr. Rochester.But what was that to her, or to any one but myself?Georgiana also advanced to look.The other drawings pleased her much, but she called that “an ugly man.”They both seemed surprised at my skill.I offered to sketch their portraits; and each, in turn, sat for a pencil outline.Then Georgiana produced her album.I promised to contribute a water-colour drawing: this put her at once into good humour.She proposed a walk in the grounds.Before we had been out two hours, we were deep in a confidential conversation: she had favoured me with a description of the brilliant winter she had spent in London two seasons ago—of the admiration she had there excited—the attention she had received; and I even got hints of the titled conquest she had made.In the course of the afternoon and evening these hints were enlarged on: various soft conversations were reported, and sentimental scenes represented; and, in short, a volume of a novel of fashionable life was that day improvised by her for my benefit.The communications were renewed from day to day: they always ran on the same theme—herself, her loves, and woes.It was strange she never once adverted either to her mother’s illness, or her brother’s death, or the present gloomy state of the family prospects.Her mind seemed wholly taken up with reminiscences of past gaiety, and aspirations after dissipations to come.She passed about five minutes each day in her mother’s sick-room, and no more.
伊莉莎仍然很少说话。很明显她没有时间说话。我从未看到过像她看起来那样忙碌的人，可是又很难说她到底在做什么，或者说，很难发现她勤劳工作后的成果。她有一只闹钟，用来叫她早起。我不知道早饭以前她做什么，不过饭后她会把自己的时间划分有序的部分，每个小时都有被分配好的任务。一天中她会三次学习一本书，据我仔细观察发现那是本《公祷书》。我问过她一次那本书有什么巨大的吸引力，她说是“《仪式规程》。”三个小时她用来编织，用金线给深红色的方形布料做饰边，这块布大得几乎足够用来做地毯。我询问这件物品是做什么的，她回答我说这是在盖茨黑德附近新建的一家教堂里盖祭坛的。两个小时她用来写日记，还有两个小时她会在菜园里工作，再有一个小时她要管理账目。她似乎不需要同伴，也不需要交谈。我相信她自得其乐。她很满足这些例行日程，任何一件迫使她改变这种机械式常规模式的事都会让她最为恼怒。 Eliza still spoke little: she had evidently no time to talk.I never saw a busier person than she seemed to be; yet it was difficult to say what she did: or rather, to discover any result of her diligence.She had an alarm to call her up early.I know not how she occupied herself before breakfast, but after that meal she divided her time into regular portions, and each hour had its allotted task.Three times a day she studied a little book, which I found, on inspection, was a @Common Prayer Book@.I asked her once what was the great attraction of that volume, and she said, “@the Rubric@.”Three hours she gave to stitching, with gold thread, the border of a square crimson cloth, almost large enough for a carpet.In answer to my inquiries after the use of this article, she informed me it was a covering for the altar of a new church lately erected near Gateshead.Two hours she devoted to her diary; two to working by herself in the kitchen-garden; and one to the regulation of her accounts.She seemed to want no company; no conversation.I believe she was happy in her way: this routine sufficed for her; and nothing annoyed her so much as the occurrence of any incident which forced her to vary its clockwork regularity.
一天傍晚她比平常更愿意交谈，她告诉我约翰的行为，以及这个家面临的毁灭，是让她深深痛苦的根源。不过现在，她说，她已经安定下来，并且下了决心。她把自己的财产保管得很安全，等到她母亲去世——她平静地说，她完全不可能康复或者继续拖着——她将做一件她长久期望的事情：寻找到一个自己按时作息的习惯永远不会被打扰的的隐居之所，并且在她和轻浮世界之间建起安全的壁垒。我问乔治亚娜是否会陪着她。 She told me one evening, when more disposed to be communicative than usual, that John’s conduct, and the threatened ruin of the family, had been a source of profound affliction to her: but she had now, she said, settled her mind, and formed her resolution.Her own fortune she had taken care to secure; and when her mother died—and it was wholly improbable, she tranquilly remarked, that she should either recover or linger long—she would execute a long-cherished project: seek a retirement where punctual habits would be permanently secured from disturbance, and place safe barriers between herself and a frivolous world.I asked if Georgiana would accompany her.
“当然不会。乔治亚娜跟她一点儿共同点都没有，也从来没有过。任何情况下她都不会被同伴拖累。乔治亚娜应该走她自己的路，她，伊莉莎，亦是如此。” “Of course not.Georgiana and she had nothing in common: they never had had.She would not be burdened with her society for any consideration.Georgiana should take her own course; and she, Eliza, would take hers.”
乔治亚娜不向我倾诉她心事的时候，大部分时间都躺在沙发上，为家里的无聊而焦躁，一遍遍地期望着她的吉普森阿姨会邀请她去镇上。“那样会好得多。”她说，只要她能避开一两个月，直到一切都结束。我没有问她“一切都结束”是什么意思，不过我觉得她是指她母亲意料之中的去世，以及接踵而至的阴郁的葬礼仪式。伊莉莎几乎不去理睬妹妹的懒惰和抱怨，就好像没有这样一个絮絮叨叨，虚度光阴的人站在她眼前。不过有一天，她放下她的账本，打开了她刺绣的活计，突然向她发难了—— Georgiana, when not unburdening her heart to me, spent most of her time in lying on the sofa, fretting about the dulness of the house, and wishing over and over again that her aunt Gibson would send her an invitation up to town.“It would be so much better,” she said, “if she could only get out of the way for a month or two, till all was over.”I did not ask what she meant by “all being over,” but I suppose she referred to the expected decease of her mother and the gloomy sequel of funeral rites.Eliza generally took no more notice of her sister’s indolence and complaints than if no such murmuring, lounging object had been before her.One day, however, as she put away her account-book and unfolded her embroidery, she suddenly took her up thus—
“乔治亚娜，拖累这世界的生物中，不会再有一个比你更自负更荒唐的了。你没有权利出生，因为你浪费生命。你没有做到一个理智的人该做的，为自己生活，而只是想把自己的软弱加在别人的力量上。如果你发现没有人愿意给她或者他自己找这样一个肥胖懦弱，臃肿而又没用的负担，你就哭喊着抱怨自己被不公正地对待，自己被忽视，正过着凄惨的生活。同样的，生活对你来说必须是一种不断变幻、充满兴奋的场景，要不然世界就成了一个地牢。你必须被人仰慕，必须被人献殷勤，必须被人恭维——你必须有音乐，舞蹈以及社交——要不然你就失去了活力，逐渐衰弱。你就从来没意识到应该想个办法，能让你不依赖别人所有的努力和意愿，而只依靠自己的？把一天拿来分成几个部分；每个部分都分配自己的任务：不要留下任何毫无目的、未被利用的时间，一刻钟，十分钟，五分钟——包括所有时间；有条理有方法地做每一件事，按照严格的规律。在你意识到一天开始之前，它恐怕就几乎快结束了。你不应该感谢任何帮你摆脱一个空闲时段的人。你必须努力在没有别人的陪伴与交谈，缺少他人的同情与耐心的情况下生活。简单地说，你必须像一个独立的生物应该的那样生活。接受这个建议吧：这是我会给你的第一个也是最后一个建议，之后不论发生什么，你都不再需要我或者其他任何人。忽视这个建议——仍然像以前一样生活，空想奢求，怨天尤人，无所事事——你将会承担你的愚蠢带来的后果，无论它们何等地糟糕或无法克服。我清楚地告诉你，请听好：因为虽然我不会再重复我现在说的话了，我还是会坚定地贯彻的。我母亲去世以后，我跟你的关系一刀两断：从她的灵柩被抬到盖茨黑德教堂墓室的那一天起，你跟我就会分道扬镳，就好像我们从不认识一样。你不要以为我们碰巧是同样的父母所生，因而我就会被你即使是最卑微的请求所拖累。我可以告诉你——如果整个人类，除了我们之外，都被大水冲走，而只有我们俩地站在大地上，我会把你留在旧世界，然后自己前往新世界。” “Georgiana, a more vain and absurd animal than you was certainly never allowed to cumber the earth.You had no right to be born, for you make no use of life.Instead of living for, in, and with yourself, as a reasonable being ought, you seek only to fasten your feebleness on some other person’s strength: if no one can be found willing to burden her or himself with such a fat, weak, puffy, useless thing, you cry out that you are ill-treated, neglected, miserable.Then, too, existence for you must be a scene of continual change and excitement, or else the world is a dungeon: you must be admired, you must be courted, you must be flattered—you must have music, dancing, and society—or you languish, you die away.Have you no sense to devise a system which will make you independent of all efforts, and all wills, but your own?Take one day; share it into sections; to each section apportion its task: leave no stray unemployed quarters of an hour, ten minutes, five minutes—include all; do each piece of business in its turn with method, with rigid regularity.The day will close almost before you are aware it has begun; and you are indebted to no one for helping you to get rid of one vacant moment: you have had to seek no one’s company, conversation, sympathy, forbearance; you have lived, in short, as an independent being ought to do.Take this advice: the first and last I shall offer you; then you will not want me or any one else, happen what may.Neglect it—go on as heretofore, craving, whining, and idling—and suffer the results of your idiocy, however bad and insuperable they may be.I tell you this plainly; and listen: for though I shall no more repeat what I am now about to say, I shall steadily act on it.After my mother’s death, I wash my hands of you: from the day her coffin is carried to the vault in Gateshead Church, you and I will be as separate as if we had never known each other.You need not think that because we chanced to be born of the same parents, I shall suffer you to fasten me down by even the feeblest claim: I can tell you this—if the whole human race, ourselves excepted, were swept away, and we two stood alone on the earth, I would leave you in the old world, and betake myself to the new.”
她停止说话了。 She closed her lips.
“你完全不必费劲说这种长篇大论，”乔治亚娜回答。“每个人都知道你是所有活着的生物中最自私、最无情的。而且我之前就了解你对我恶意的仇恨：在埃德温·维尔勋爵那件事上你就跟我耍了花招。你无法忍受我比你爬得高，得到贵族头衔，被你根本不敢露面的交际圈所接受，所以你扮作间谍和告密者，永远毁了我的前途。”在那之后乔治亚娜拿出她的手绢擤了一小时的鼻子；伊莉莎冷冷地坐着，无动于衷，极为勤勉地努力工作。 “You might have spared yourself the trouble of delivering that tirade,” answered Georgiana.“Everybody knows you are the most selfish, heartless creature in existence: and I know your spiteful hatred towards me: I have had a specimen of it before in the trick you played me about Lord Edwin Vere: you could not bear me to be raised above you, to have a title, to be received into circles where you dare not show your face, and so you acted the spy and informer, and ruined my prospects for ever.”Georgiana took out her handkerchief and blew her nose for an hour afterwards; Eliza sat cold, impassable, and assiduously industrious.
确实，慷慨大度不会被一些人太重视，不过这里的两种人格，一个缺了它刻薄得令人无法忍受，另一个缺了它则乏味得可鄙。缺乏判断的感情的确是平淡无味，不过没有被感情调和过的判断实在过于苦涩粗硬，让人难以下咽。 True, generous feeling is made small account of by some, but here were two natures rendered, the one intolerably acrid, the other despicably savourless for the want of it.Feeling without judgment is a washy draught indeed; but judgment untempered by feeling is too bitter and husky a morsel for human deglutition.
那是一个风雨交加的下午。乔治亚娜阅读一本小说时在沙发上睡着了。伊莉莎出门去参加新教堂的圣徒纪念日仪式——因为在宗教方面她是一个严肃的正统教徒：没有什么天气能阻碍她履行这种她所认为的虔诚义务。不论天晴下雨，她每个星期天都会去教堂三次，如果有祷告的话她平时也会去得这么频繁。 It was a wet and windy afternoon: Georgiana had fallen asleep on the sofa over the perusal of a novel; Eliza was gone to attend a saint’s-day service at the new church—for in matters of religion she was a rigid formalist: no weather ever prevented the punctual discharge of what she considered her devotional duties; fair or foul, she went to church thrice every Sunday, and as often on weekdays as there were prayers.
我想应该上楼去看看那个病危的女人怎么样了，她就躺在那里，几乎没有任何人照顾。那些仆人们对她也是忽冷忽热，雇来的保姆没有人管着，随时都能溜出房间。贝茜很忠实，不过她有自己的家庭要照顾，只能偶尔来一下正宅。就像我预料的一样，我发现病房没有人看管：保姆不在那儿，病人静静地躺着，看起来昏昏沉沉，她青灰色的脸庞陷在枕头里。壁炉里的火正在逐渐熄灭。我添了一些燃料，重新整理了被单，注视了一会儿那个现在无法看着我的人，然后挪到了窗户边。 I bethought myself to go upstairs and see how the dying woman sped, who lay there almost unheeded: the very servants paid her but a remittent attention: the hired nurse, being little looked after, would slip out of the room whenever she could.Bessie was faithful; but she had her own family to mind, and could only come occasionally to the hall.I found the sick-room unwatched, as I had expected: no nurse was there; the patient lay still, and seemingly lethargic; her livid face sunk in the pillows: the fire was dying in the grate.I renewed the fuel, re-arranged the bedclothes, gazed awhile on her who could not now gaze on me, and then I moved away to the window.
雨狠狠地敲打窗户，狂风肆虐。“一个人躺在这里，”我想，“马上就可以超脱尘世间的争斗了。那个灵魂——现在正挣扎着想要脱离她物质的躯壳——将去往何处，当她最终得到解脱的时候？ The rain beat strongly against the panes, the wind blew tempestuously: “One lies there,” I thought, “who will soon be beyond the war of earthly elements.Whither will that spirit—now struggling to quit its material tenement—flit when at length released?”
思索着这巨大的神秘之事，我想起了海伦·伯恩斯，回忆起了她临死前的话——她的信仰——她关于出窍的灵魂皆平等的信条。我仍然倾听着心中记忆深刻的她的声音——仍然在心里描绘着她苍白而又有灵性的神态，憔悴的脸庞以及庄严的目光。她平静地躺在临终的病榻上，低语着期望能够回到圣父的怀抱中——此时一个虚弱的声音从后面的床上低声传来：“是谁？” In pondering the great mystery, I thought of Helen Burns, recalled her dying words—her faith—her doctrine of the equality of disembodied souls.I was still listening in thought to her well remembered tones—still picturing her pale and spiritual aspect, her wasted face and sublime gaze, as she lay on her placid deathbed, and whispered her longing to be restored to her divine Father’s bosom—when a feeble voice murmured from the couch behind: “Who is that?”
我知道里德夫人已经好几天没说话了，她现在正在恢复吗？我向她走过去。 I knew Mrs. Reed had not spoken for days: was she reviving?I went up to her.
“是我，里德舅妈。” “It is I, Aunt Reed.”
“‘我’是谁？”她回答说。“你是谁？”她吃惊而慌乱地看着我，不过还没失去控制。“你对我来说完全就是一个陌生人——贝茜在哪儿？” “Who—I?” was her answer.“Who are you?” looking at me with surprise and a sort of alarm, but still not wildly.“You are quite a stranger to me—where is Bessie?”
“她在门房呢，舅妈。” “She is at the lodge, aunt.”
“舅妈，”她重复着。“谁叫我舅妈？你不是吉普森家的人，不过我认识你——那张脸，那双眼睛还有前额，都很熟悉。你就像——咦，你就像简·爱！” “Aunt,” she repeated.“Who calls me aunt?You are not one of the Gibsons; and yet I know you—that face, and the eyes and forehead, are quiet familiar to me: you are like—why, you are like Jane Eyre!”
我什么也没说。我害怕说了我是谁以后会让她休克。 I said nothing: I was afraid of occasioning some shock by declaring my identity.
“不过，”她说，“恐怕我弄错了，我的想法骗了我。我希望见到简·爱，所以尽管不是她，我还是想象出了你跟她那些不存在的相似之处。再说，八年的时间她肯定变了很多。”我温柔地安抚她，说我就是她想象的和希望见到的人。发现她明白了我的意思，并且她的意识开始清醒以后，我解释了贝茜如何让她的丈夫去桑菲尔德把我带回来。 “Yet,” said she, “I am afraid it is a mistake: my thoughts deceive me.I wished to see Jane Eyre, and I fancy a likeness where none exists: besides, in eight years she must be so changed.”I now gently assured her that I was the person she supposed and desired me to be: and seeing that I was understood, and that her senses were quite collected, I explained how Bessie had sent her husband to fetch me from Thornfield.
“我病得很厉害，我知道，”她过了一会儿说道。“我几分钟之前想翻个身，结果发现手脚都动不了。在死之前我能放松下来也好。健康的时候我们不怎么去想的事，此刻却这么沉重地压在我心上。保姆在这儿吗？或者这间房子里只有你？” “I am very ill, I know,” she said ere long.“I was trying to turn myself a few minutes since, and find I cannot move a limb.It is as well I should ease my mind before I die: what we think little of in health, burdens us at such an hour as the present is to me.Is the nurse here? or is there no one in the room but you?”
我要她放心说只有我们两个人。 I assured her we were alone.
“唉，我曾经做过两件对不起你的事，现在我后悔了。一个是违背了我向我丈夫发的誓言，没有把你当作自己的孩子养大；另一个——”她停了下来。“不管怎样，这可能不太重要，或许，”她喃喃自语：“之后我可能会康复，在她面前把我自己弄得这么卑微太痛苦了。” “Well, I have twice done you a wrong which I regret now.One was in breaking the promise which I gave my husband to bring you up as my own child; the other—” she stopped.“After all, it is of no great importance, perhaps,” she murmured to herself: “and then I may get better; and to humble myself so to her is painful.”
她努力想改变一下姿势，不过失败了。她脸上的表情改变了，好像身体里感觉到了什么——可能是最后的剧痛的征兆。 She made an effort to alter her position, but failed: her face changed; she seemed to experience some inward sensation—the precursor, perhaps, of the last pang.
“哎，我必须把它处理了。来世就在眼前，我还是告诉她的好。——去拿我的梳妆盒，打开它，把你看到的那封信拿出来。” “Well, I must get it over.Eternity is before me: I had better tell her.—Go to my dressing-case, open it, and take out a letter you will see there.”
我听从了她的指示。“看那封信。”她说。 I obeyed her directions.“Read the letter,” she said.
信很短，这样写道：—— It was short, and thus conceived:—
“夫人，——您可以寄给我我侄女简·爱的地址吗，并且告诉我现在她怎么样了。我会尽快写信，希望她能来马德拉找我。上天保佑我的良苦用心让我得到我应得的，我没有结婚，没有子嗣，我希望能一辈子收养她，在我死的时候留给她一切我留下的东西。——我是，夫人，等等。 “Madam,—Will you have the goodness to send me the address of my niece, Jane Eyre, and to tell me how she is?It is my intention to write shortly and desire her to come to me at Madeira.Providence has blessed my endeavours to secure a competency; and as I am unmarried and childless, I wish to adopt her during my life, and bequeath her at my death whatever I may have to leave.—I am, Madam, &c., &c.,
“约翰·爱，于马德拉。” “JOHN EYRE, Madeira.”
上面写的日期是三年以前。 It was dated three years back.
“我为什么从来没有听说过？”我问。 “Why did I never hear of this?” I asked.
“因为我对你的讨厌根深蒂固并且深入骨髓，我一点儿都不想帮你得到富足的生活。我无法忘记你对我的行为，简——有一次你把怒火全部发在我身上，你宣布你在这世界上最憎恨的人是我的那种腔调，你肯定地说一想起我你就反胃时那种不像孩子的神情和声音，你还声称我对你既残酷又狠毒。我无法忘记那种感觉，当你开始发作并把你脑袋里的恶毒言语发泄到我身上。我感到了恐惧，就像是我曾经打过或者推搡过的动物用人类的眼睛盯着我，并且用人类的声音诅咒我。——给我拿点儿水！噢，快点儿！” “Because I disliked you too fixedly and thoroughly ever to lend a hand in lifting you to prosperity.I could not forget your conduct to me, Jane—the fury with which you once turned on me; the tone in which you declared you abhorred me the worst of anybody in the world; the unchildlike look and voice with which you affirmed that the very thought of me made you sick, and asserted that I had treated you with miserable cruelty.I could not forget my own sensations when you thus started up and poured out the venom of your mind: I felt fear as if an animal that I had struck or pushed had looked up at me with human eyes and cursed me in a man’s voice.—Bring me some water!Oh, make haste!”
“亲爱的里德夫人，”我递给她她需要的水，“别再想这所有事情了，让它们从你脑海里消逝吧。原谅我过激的语言。我那个时候是个孩子，那事到今天都八、九年了。” “Dear Mrs. Reed,” said I, as I offered her the draught she required, “think no more of all this, let it pass away from your mind.Forgive me for my passionate language: I was a child then; eight, nine years have passed since that day.”
我说的话她一点儿都没听进去，不过当她喝了喝水，吸了一口气，她又继续说了—— She heeded nothing of what I said; but when she had tasted the water and drawn breath, she went on thus—
“我告诉你我无法忘记，所以我开始报复。因为如果你被你叔叔领养了，并被安置在一个轻松舒适的环境里，我会忍受不了的。我给他写信，我说我很抱歉让他失望了，不过简·爱已经死了。她在洛伍德死于斑疹伤寒。现在做你想做的吧，写信来反驳我的断言——马上揭露我的谎言吧。我想，你生来就是折磨我的。我最后的时光，因为回忆这行为而痛苦。要不是你，我从来就不会干这种事。” “I tell you I could not forget it; and I took my revenge: for you to be adopted by your uncle, and placed in a state of ease and comfort, was what I could not endure.I wrote to him; I said I was sorry for his disappointment, but Jane Eyre was dead: she had died of typhus fever at Lowood.Now act as you please: write and contradict my assertion—expose my falsehood as soon as you like.You were born, I think, to be my torment: my last hour is racked by the recollection of a deed which, but for you, I should never have been tempted to commit.”
“我希望能说服您别再想它了，舅妈，希望您用仁慈和谅解来对待我。” “If you could but be persuaded to think no more of it, aunt, and to regard me with kindness and forgiveness”
“你的性子坏极了，”她说，“甚至到了今天我也无法理解。九年来无论受到怎样的对待你都能隐忍和克制，而到了第十年却在一瞬间爆发出全部怒火和暴力，我永远也无法理解。” “You have a very bad disposition,” said she, “and one to this day I feel it impossible to understand: how for nine years you could be patient and quiescent under any treatment, and in the tenth break out all fire and violence, I can never comprehend.”
“我的性子不像您想的那么坏。我容易激动，可是不会报复。我是个孩子的时候，很多次，我本来会非常乐意去爱您，如果您愿意让我去爱的话，而且我一直热切地希望现在跟您重归于好。吻我吧，舅妈。” “My disposition is not so bad as you think: I am passionate, but not vindictive.Many a time, as a little child, I should have been glad to love you if you would have let me; and I long earnestly to be reconciled to you now: kiss me, aunt.”
我把我的脸颊凑近她的嘴唇，她并不碰我。她说我倚在床上，冒犯了她，并且再一次要我给她水。当我扶她躺下——我刚才把她扶起来，让她靠在我的胳臂上喝水——我的手盖上了她冰冷湿黏的手。她虚弱的手指躲闪着我的触摸——呆滞的眼神逃避着我的注视。 I approached my cheek to her lips: she would not touch it.She said I oppressed her by leaning over the bed, and again demanded water.As I laid her down—for I raised her and supported her on my arm while she drank—I covered her ice-cold and clammy hand with mine: the feeble fingers shrank from my touch—the glazing eyes shunned my gaze.
“爱我，或者恨我，随你便，”我最后说，“我已经完全原谅您了。现在请求上帝的原谅吧，平静下来。” “Love me, then, or hate me, as you will,” I said at last, “you have my full and free forgiveness: ask now for God’s, and be at peace.”
可怜的、受苦的女人！现在要她努力改变她的思考习惯太晚了。活着，她一直恨我——死了，她也一定仍会恨我。 Poor, suffering woman! it was too late for her to make now the effort to change her habitual frame of mind: living, she had ever hated me—dying, she must hate me still.
护士此时进来了，贝茜也跟着进来了。我又逗留了半个小时，希望能看到一些示好的信号，不过她没有给出任何表示。她又迅速陷入了昏迷，她的意识也再也没能恢复，那天夜里的十二点钟她去世了。我没有在现场为她合上双眼，她的两个女儿也都不在。他们第二天早晨告诉我们一切都结束了。那个时候她已经入殓了。伊莉莎和我去看了她，乔治亚娜之前突然大哭起来，说她不敢去。萨拉·里德那曾经健壮、充满活力的身躯，就这样直直地躺在那里，僵硬而平静。她冰冷的眼皮遮盖着她冷酷的眼睛。她的前额和突出的五官特征仍然带着那无情的灵魂的印记。那具尸体对我来说是一个奇怪而庄严的东西。我忧郁而痛苦地注视着它：它没有激起任何柔软、甜蜜、同情或者充满希望，亦或是压抑的情绪。只有一种为她的悲哀——而不是我的损失——而感受到的刺心之痛——对这种死亡的恐惧，让我感到一种忧郁却又无泪的沮丧。 The nurse now entered, and Bessie followed.I yet lingered half an hour longer, hoping to see some sign of amity: but she gave none.She was fast relapsing into stupor; nor did her mind again rally: at twelve o’clock that night she died.I was not present to close her eyes, nor were either of her daughters.They came to tell us the next morning that all was over.She was by that time laid out.Eliza and I went to look at her: Georgiana, who had burst out into loud weeping, said she dared not go.There was stretched Sarah Reed’s once robust and active frame, rigid and still: her eye of flint was covered with its cold lid; her brow and strong traits wore yet the impress of her inexorable soul.A strange and solemn object was that corpse to me.I gazed on it with gloom and pain: nothing soft, nothing sweet, nothing pitying, or hopeful, or subduing did it inspire; only a grating anguish for HER woes—not MY loss—and a sombre tearless dismay at the fearfulness of death in such a form.
伊莉莎镇静地观察她的母亲。在几分钟的沉默之后她说—— Eliza surveyed her parent calmly.After a silence of some minutes she observed—
“以她的体质她应该可以活得更长，是烦恼缩短了她的生命。”接着一阵痉挛在一瞬间扭曲了她的嘴，之后她转身离开了房间，我也走了。我们两人都没有流一滴泪。 “With her constitution she should have lived to a good old age: her life was shortened by trouble.”And then a spasm constricted her mouth for an instant: as it passed away she turned and left the room, and so did I.Neither of us had dropt a tear.
第二十二章 CHAPTER XXII
罗切斯特先生只给了我一周的假，可是一个月过去了，我还没离开盖茨黑德。我希望在葬礼之后马上离开，但乔治亚娜恳求我留在这里，直到她能动身前往伦敦。她现在终于得到舅舅吉普森先生的邀请，可以去伦敦了。吉普森先生是来安排姐姐的葬礼，并处理一些家庭事务的。乔治亚娜说她害怕被留下来跟伊莉莎独处。说沮丧时得不到她的同情，惧怕时也得不到她的支持，准备行李时也得不到她的帮助。所以我尽力容忍她软弱的恸哭和自私的哀伤，尽量帮她赶做针线活，收拾她的衣物。在我干活的时候，她真的是无所事事。我暗自想道，“如果你跟我命中注定总在一起生活，表姐，我们会换个角色重新开始。我不会乖乖地安下心来服从你。我会给你布置你应该做的那份工作，并逼着你完成它，要么就让它搁着。我也会坚持让你把你那些拖长的腔调和半真半假的抱怨收起来，咽进肚子里不要说出来。只是因为我们彼此的联系碰巧十分短暂，而又发生在一个特别悲伤的时期，我才会愿意这么耐心顺从。 Mr. Rochester had given me but one week’s leave of absence: yet a month elapsed before I quitted Gateshead.I wished to leave immediately after the funeral, but Georgiana entreated me to stay till she could get off to London, whither she was now at last invited by her uncle, Mr. Gibson, who had come down to direct his sister’s interment and settle the family affairs.Georgiana said she dreaded being left alone with Eliza; from her she got neither sympathy in her dejection, support in her fears, nor aid in her preparations; so I bore with her feeble-minded wailings and selfish lamentations as well as I could, and did my best in sewing for her and packing her dresses.It is true, that while I worked, she would idle; and I thought to myself, “If you and I were destined to live always together, cousin, we would commence matters on a different footing.I should not settle tamely down into being the forbearing party; I should assign you your share of labour, and compel you to accomplish it, or else it should be left undone: I should insist, also, on your keeping some of those drawling, half-insincere complaints hushed in your own breast.It is only because our connection happens to be very transitory, and comes at a peculiarly mournful season, that I consent thus to render it so patient and compliant on my part.”
总算送走了乔治亚娜，不过现在又轮到伊莉莎请求我再呆一个星期。她说，她需要投入所有时间和精力来完成她的计划，她即将去一个未知的地方。她整天都呆在她的房间里，闩上房门，在里面装行李箱，清空抽屉，焚烧纸张，不跟任何人说话。她希望我照看宅子，接见来访的人，回复吊唁信函。 At last I saw Georgiana off; but now it was Eliza’s turn to request me to stay another week.Her plans required all her time and attention, she said; she was about to depart for some unknown bourne; and all day long she stayed in her own room, her door bolted within, filling trunks, emptying drawers, burning papers, and holding no communication with any one.She wished me to look after the house, to see callers, and answer notes of condolence.
一天早晨她告诉我没我的事了。“并且，”她补充说，“对于你宝贵的帮助以及谨慎的举止，我很感激！跟像你这样的人相处，与跟乔治亚娜相处不同。你履行生活的义务，不会给别人添麻烦。明天，”她继续说，“我就动身去欧洲大陆。我将在靠近里尔的一个宗教场所里居住——你也可以叫它修道院。在那儿我将得到宁静，远离侵扰。我会花一段时间考查罗马天主教教义，然后仔细研究他们那套体系的运作方式。如果我发现它像我猜想的那样，是一种最适宜的体系，能保证把世间一切事情都办地合理而井然有序，那我将皈依罗马教，可能还会做修女。” One morning she told me I was at liberty.“And,” she added, “I am obliged to you for your valuable services and discreet conduct!There is some difference between living with such an one as you and with Georgiana: you perform your own part in life and burden no one.Tomorrow,” she continued, “I set out for the Continent.I shall take up my abode in a religious house near Lisle—a nunnery you would call it; there I shall be quiet and unmolested.I shall devote myself for a time to the examination of the Roman Catholic dogmas, and to a careful study of the workings of their system: if I find it to be, as I half suspect it is, the one best calculated to ensure the doing of all things decently and in order, I shall embrace the tenets of Rome and probably take the veil.”
我既没有对她的决定表示惊讶，也没有试图劝说她放弃这个主意。“这个职业将非常适合你的，”我想，“希望能对你大有益处！” I neither expressed surprise at this resolution nor attempted to dissuade her from it.“The vocation will fit you to a hair,” I thought: “much good may it do you!”
我们分别的时候，她说：“再见，简·爱表妹。我祝你过得好，你是个有见地的人。” When we parted, she said: “Good-bye, cousin Jane Eyre; I wish you well: you have some sense.”
我回答说：“你也很有见识，伊莉莎表姐。不过我觉得，你所拥有的见识，再过一年，就将活生生地被关在一座法国修道院里了。然而，这并不干我的事。如果这适合你的话，我也就不在乎了。” I then returned: “You are not without sense, cousin Eliza; but what you have, I suppose, in another year will be walled up alive in a French convent.However, it is not my business, and so it suits you, I don’t much care.”
“你说得对，”她说。带着这些话，我们各自踏上了自己的路。由于我应该没有机会再次提到她或者她妹妹，我最好还是在这里说一句。乔治亚娜嫁给了一个上流社会富有但却老态龙钟的男人。伊莉莎真的当了修女，过完见习期后，如今在那个修道院当了院长，并把自己的财产捐献给了修道院。 “You are in the right,” said she; and with these words we each went our separate way.As I shall not have occasion to refer either to her or her sister again, I may as well mention here, that Georgiana made an advantageous match with a wealthy worn-out man of fashion, and that Eliza actually took the veil, and is at this day superior of the convent where she passed the period of her novitiate, and which she endowed with her fortune.
在一个或长或短的离别后回到家里人们会感觉怎样，我不知道。因为我从来没有体验过这种感觉。我只知道，一个孩子在长长的散步后回到盖茨黑德，因为看起来冰冷阴郁而被责骂是什么感觉；之后也了解了，从教堂回到洛伍德，期待着一顿饱饭和温暖的炉火，却两样都无法得到是什么感觉。这两次回归都是既不愉快也不舒心。没有一块磁石会将我吸回一个固定点，离得越近，吸引力就越强。然而，回到桑菲尔德的感觉却是有待尝试的。 How people feel when they are returning home from an absence, long or short, I did not know: I had never experienced the sensation.I had known what it was to come back to Gateshead when a child after a long walk, to be scolded for looking cold or gloomy; and later, what it was to come back from church to Lowood, to long for a plenteous meal and a good fire, and to be unable to get either.Neither of these returnings was very pleasant or desirable: no magnet drew me to a given point, increasing in its strength of attraction the nearer I came.The return to Thornfield was yet to be tried.
我的旅程似乎有些乏味——非常乏味。一天走五十英里，晚上在客栈中留宿一夜，第二天接着走五十英里。在前十二个小时里我想到了里德夫人最后的时光。我看到了她那被扭曲的、暗淡无光的脸庞，听到了她古怪变调的声音。我默默想着葬礼的那天，那个棺材，那个灵车，那队穿着黑色丧服的房客和仆人——亲人的数量很少——那张开大口的墓穴，沉默的教堂和肃穆的仪式。接着我又想到了伊莉莎和乔治亚娜，她们一个在交际场所被众人瞩目，另一个住在修道院的小房间中。我思索分析着她们南辕北辙的人格与个性。黄昏时抵达某个大镇，驱散了这些念头。夜晚让思绪转了方向。躺在旅店的床上，我抛开了回忆，开始期待未来。 My journey seemed tedious—very tedious: fifty miles one day, a night spent at an inn; fifty miles the next day.During the first twelve hours I thought of Mrs. Reed in her last moments; I saw her disfigured and discoloured face, and heard her strangely altered voice.I mused on the funeral day, the coffin, the hearse, the black train of tenants and servants—few was the number of relatives—the gaping vault, the silent church, the solemn service.Then I thought of Eliza and Georgiana; I beheld one the cynosure of a ball-room, the other the inmate of a convent cell; and I dwelt on and analysed their separate peculiarities of person and character.The evening arrival at the great town of—scattered these thoughts; night gave them quite another turn: laid down on my traveller’s bed, I left reminiscence for anticipation.
我将回到桑菲尔德，但是我还能在那儿呆多久呢？不会太久。这一点我很确定。我在离开期间，收到了费尔法克斯太太的来信，说府上的聚会结束了，罗切斯特先生三周前去了伦敦，不过估计两周后会回来。费尔法克斯太太猜测他去伦敦安排他的婚礼了，因为他曾提到买一辆新马车。她还是觉得他要跟英格拉姆小姐结婚的消息很奇怪，不过据大家所说，也从她亲眼所见，她已经不会再怀疑了，婚事不久就将举行。“如果你真的怀疑，那你就是疑心太重了，”我心里想，“我可不怀疑。” I was going back to Thornfield: but how long was I to stay there?Not long; of that I was sure.I had heard from Mrs. Fairfax in the interim of my absence: the party at the hall was dispersed; Mr. Rochester had left for London three weeks ago, but he was then expected to return in a fortnight.Mrs. Fairfax surmised that he was gone to make arrangements for his wedding, as he had talked of purchasing a new carriage: she said the idea of his marrying Miss Ingram still seemed strange to her; but from what everybody said, and from what she had herself seen, she could no longer doubt that the event would shortly take place.“You would be strangely incredulous if you did doubt it,” was my mental comment.“I don’t doubt it.”
问题接着来了，“我将去往何处？”我整夜都梦到英格拉姆小姐。在一个栩栩如生的晨梦里，我看到她对着我关上了桑菲尔德的大门，指给我另一条路。罗切斯特先生两臂合抱地在一边看——讽刺地笑着，似乎是在笑她，也在笑我。 The question followed, “Where was I to go?”I dreamt of Miss Ingram all the night: in a vivid morning dream I saw her closing the gates of Thornfield against me and pointing me out another road; and Mr. Rochester looked on with his arms folded—smiling sardonically, as it seemed, at both her and me.
我没有通知费尔法克斯太太我回来的具体日子，因为我不希望看到普通马车或是高级马车在米尔科特接我。我打算自己静静地走过去。在把行李箱留给马夫照看以后，我就从乔治客栈悄悄溜出来。在这个六月的傍晚，差不多六点的时候，我从那条老路走回桑菲尔德，这条路大部分横穿田野，很少有人通过。 I had not notified to Mrs. Fairfax the exact day of my return; for I did not wish either car or carriage to meet me at Millcote.I proposed to walk the distance quietly by myself; and very quietly, after leaving my box in the ostler’s care, did I slip away from the George Inn, about six o’clock of a June evening, and take the old road to Thornfield: a road which lay chiefly through fields, and was now little frequented.
这不是个明亮或者美好的夏日傍晚，虽然也很晴朗温和。一路上都是翻晒干草的人们在工作。天空虽然不是万里无云，却也预示着之后的好天气。那种蓝色——在可以看得见蓝色的地方——是温和安宁的，云层又高又薄。西边的天空同样温暖，并没有带着雨意的光芒使它冷却——看起来仿佛一团火焰，像一座祭坛在它大理石般的雾气屏障之后燃烧着，从云的缝隙中射出一道金红的光芒。 It was not a bright or splendid summer evening, though fair and soft: the haymakers were at work all along the road; and the sky, though far from cloudless, was such as promised well for the future: its blue—where blue was visible—was mild and settled, and its cloud strata high and thin.The west, too, was warm: no watery gleam chilled it—it seemed as if there was a fire lit, an altar burning behind its screen of marbled vapour, and out of apertures shone a golden redness.
随着路越来越近，我感觉到了快乐，如此快乐以至于我停下来了一次，问我自己这快乐意味着什么，并提醒理智，我并不是在回家，也不是去一个永久的安宁之所，或者是一个有好朋友们关注并等待着我的到来的地方。“费尔法克斯太太将微笑着，平静地欢迎你，这是肯定的，”我说，“小阿德拉将会拍着她的手掌，蹦蹦跳跳地来见你。不过你非常清楚，你在想他们之外的另一个人，而他并没在想你。” I felt glad as the road shortened before me: so glad that I stopped once to ask myself what that joy meant: and to remind reason that it was not to my home I was going, or to a permanent resting-place, or to a place where fond friends looked out for me and waited my arrival.“Mrs. Fairfax will smile you a calm welcome, to be sure,” said I; “and little Adele will clap her hands and jump to see you: but you know very well you are thinking of another than they, and that he is not thinking of you.”
可是有什么会像青春那样固执呢？有什么会像幼稚这样盲目呢？它们断言，我能有幸再次见到罗切斯特先生就足够快乐了，无论他是否会看着我。它们还说——“快点儿！快点儿！只要你可以，就赶快跟他在一起。最多几天或者几星期以后，你就将永远离开他了！”接着我扼制了那阵新生的痛苦——那是个畸形的东西，而我无法说服自己拥有和培育它——然后继续往前跑。 But what is so headstrong as youth?What so blind as inexperience?These affirmed that it was pleasure enough to have the privilege of again looking on Mr. Rochester, whether he looked on me or not; and they added—“Hasten! hasten! be with him while you may: but a few more days or weeks, at most, and you are parted from him for ever!”And then I strangled a new-born agony—a deformed thing which I could not persuade myself to own and rear—and ran on.
在桑菲尔德的草地上，人们也在翻晒干草。或者说，就在我到来的时刻，雇工们才刚刚放下手里的活儿，扛着耙子回家。再走过一两块田地，我就将穿过那条路，抵达大门。树篱上开满了那么多的玫瑰！不过我没时间去摘一朵，我想到屋子里去。我经过了一株高高的野蔷薇，它那长满叶子和鲜花的枝桠横过小路。我看到了石头铺就的窄小台阶。看到了——罗切斯特先生正坐在那儿，手里拿着一本书和一支笔。他在写着什么。 They are making hay, too, in Thornfield meadows: or rather, the labourers are just quitting their work, and returning home with their rakes on their shoulders, now, at the hour I arrive.I have but a field or two to traverse, and then I shall cross the road and reach the gates.How full the hedges are of roses!But I have no time to gather any; I want to be at the house.I passed a tall briar, shooting leafy and flowery branches across the path; I see the narrow stile with stone steps; and I see—Mr. Rochester sitting there, a book and a pencil in his hand; he is writing.
自然，他不是幽灵，可我的每根神经都在紧张，有一刻我没能控制住自己。这意味着什么？我没想到看到他的时候，我会如此颤抖，这样失声走调，身体失去力量。只要能动，我就要赶紧往回走。没必要把自己弄成一个大傻瓜。我知道有别的路可以进房子。不过即使我知道二十条别的路也没用了，他已经看到我了。 Well, he is not a ghost; yet every nerve I have is unstrung: for a moment I am beyond my own mastery.What does it mean?I did not think I should tremble in this way when I saw him, or lose my voice or the power of motion in his presence.I will go back as soon as I can stir: I need not make an absolute fool of myself.I know another way to the house.It does not signify if I knew twenty ways; for he has seen me.
“喂！”他喊道，收起了他的书和铅笔。“你回来了！请过来吧。” “Hillo!” he cries; and he puts up his book and his pencil.“There you are!Come on, if you please.”
我想我是过去了，尽管我不知道自己是怎么过去的。我几乎意识不到自己的动作，只关心怎样能显得平静。最重要的是，控制住我脸部的肌肉——我感觉到它在粗鲁地反抗我的意志，并且挣扎着想表达出我决心要隐藏的东西。不过我戴着面纱——它是放下来的。我可能可以利用它让自己的举止体面镇静。 I suppose I do come on; though in what fashion I know not; being scarcely cognisant of my movements, and solicitous only to appear calm; and, above all, to control the working muscles of my face—which I feel rebel insolently against my will, and struggle to express what I had resolved to conceal.But I have a veil—it is down: I may make shift yet to behave with decent composure.
“是简·爱吗？你是从米尔科特回来的吗？而且还是步行？是的——又是你的一个鬼主意。不让马车来接，不像常人在咔嗒咔嗒的马蹄声中走过大街小巷，而是在暮光之中溜进你的家，好像你是个梦幻或是个幽灵一样。过去的这个月你到底做什么去了？” “And this is Jane Eyre?Are you coming from Millcote, and on foot?Yes—just one of your tricks: not to send for a carriage, and come clattering over street and road like a common mortal, but to steal into the vicinage of your home along with twilight, just as if you were a dream or a shade.What the deuce have you done with yourself this last month?”
“我一直和我的舅妈在一起，先生，她已经去世了。” “I have been with my aunt, sir, who is dead.”
“真是简式的回答！善良的天使保佑我吧！她从另一个世界来——从已经去世的人的住处来，而且一个人在这天黑的时候跟我见面，对我说这些！如果我敢，我得碰碰你，看看你到底是真人还是幽灵，你这个鬼精灵！——不过我倒是情愿捕捉沼泽中蓝色的鬼火。渎职者！渎职者！”他停了一小会儿，又补充道。“离开我整整一个月，我敢肯定，你已经完全把我忘记了！” “A true Janian reply!Good angels be my guard!She comes from the other world—from the abode of people who are dead; and tells me so when she meets me alone here in the gloaming!If I dared, I’d touch you, to see if you are substance or shadow, you elf!—but I’d as soon offer to take hold of a blue ignis fatuus light in a marsh.Truant! truant!” he added, when he had paused an instant.“Absent from me a whole month, and forgetting me quite, I’ll be sworn!”
我知道再次见到主人我会很快乐，即便这快乐会被打破，即使他很快就不再是我的主人了，即使我对他来说什么也不是。然而在罗切斯特先生身上总是（至少我这样想）有那样一种在交谈时能让我感到幸福的巨大力量，仅仅是他分给像我这样的流浪者和迷途的鸟儿的一点儿残渣，对我来说也是一场盛宴。他最后的话是一种安慰，它们似乎意味着，我是否忘了他，对他来说是有些意味的。而且他把桑菲尔德称为我的家——但愿这真是我的家！ I knew there would be pleasure in meeting my master again, even though broken by the fear that he was so soon to cease to be my master, and by the knowledge that I was nothing to him: but there was ever in Mr. Rochester (so at least I thought) such a wealth of the power of communicating happiness, that to taste but of the crumbs he scattered to stray and stranger birds like me, was to feast genially.His last words were balm: they seemed to imply that it imported something to him whether I forgot him or not.And he had spoken of Thornfield as my home—would that it were my home!
他没有离开台阶，而我不太想请他让路。于是我马上问他是否去了伦敦。 He did not leave the stile, and I hardly liked to ask to go by.I inquired soon if he had not been to London.
“是的。我想你大概是通过千里眼发现的。” “Yes; I suppose you found that out by second-sight.”
“费尔法克斯太太写信告诉我的。” “Mrs. Fairfax told me in a letter.”
“她告诉你我去做什么了吗？” “And did she inform you what I went to do?”
“噢，是的，先生！每个人都知道您去做什么了。” “Oh, yes, sir!Everybody knew your errand.”
“你一定看到了那辆马车，简，告诉我你觉得它是否完全合适罗切斯特太太，她靠在那些紫色的靠垫上时是不是看起来像波狄西亚女王。我希望，简，我长得更好看些，能在外表上配得上她。告诉我，像你这样的仙女——你就不能给我一个咒符，或者一种魔幻的药，或诸如此类的东西，把我变成一个英俊的男人？ “You must see the carriage, Jane, and tell me if you don’t think it will suit Mrs. Rochester exactly; and whether she won’t look like Queen Boadicea, leaning back against those purple cushions.I wish, Jane, I were a trifle better adapted to match with her externally.Tell me now, fairy as you are—can’t you give me a charm, or a philter, or something of that sort, to make me a handsome man?”
“那将会超过魔法的力量，先生。”我在心里又补充说，“充满爱意的眼睛就是您需要的全部魅力，在这样的眼睛看来，您已经足够英俊了，或者说您的严厉有一种超越美丽的力量。” “It would be past the power of magic, sir;” and, in thought, I added, “A loving eye is all the charm needed: to such you are handsome enough; or rather your sternness has a power beyond beauty.”
罗切斯特先生有时候能用一种我无法理解的敏锐读懂我没说出的心思。就在此时，他没有理会我突然的回答，而是对我微笑了，那是他极少展露出的一种特别的微笑。他似乎觉得这种微笑对于一般的目的来说是大材小用。那真是一种情感的阳光——他现在把阳光洒在了我身上。 Mr. Rochester had sometimes read my unspoken thoughts with an acumen to me incomprehensible: in the present instance he took no notice of my abrupt vocal response; but he smiled at me with a certain smile he had of his own, and which he used but on rare occasions.He seemed to think it too good for common purposes: it was the real sunshine of feeling—he shed it over me now.
“过去，珍妮特，”他说，让出地方让我跨过台阶：“进屋去，让你那四处游荡疲倦不堪的小脚，在朋友的门槛里歇息吧。” “Pass, Janet,” said he, making room for me to cross the stile: “go up home, and stay your weary little wandering feet at a friend’s threshold.”
现在我要做的就是默默地听他的话。没有必要再多说了。我走过了台阶，没有说一句话，并打算能镇静地离开他。一种冲动迅速地攫住了我——一种力量逼我转过身去。我说了——或者说是我内心的某种力量替我说了，不由自主地—— All I had now to do was to obey him in silence: no need for me to colloquise further.I got over the stile without a word, and meant to leave him calmly.An impulse held me fast—a force turned me round.I said—or something in me said for me, and in spite of me—
“谢谢您，罗切斯特先生，谢谢您的关心。能再次回到您身边，我觉得特别高兴。您在哪里，哪里就是我的家——我唯一的家。 “Thank you, Mr. Rochester, for your great kindness.I am strangely glad to get back again to you: and wherever you are is my home—my only home.”
我如此快速地走开了，即使他想追也追不上。小阿德拉看见我的时候几乎乐疯了。费尔法克斯太太一如往常，用朴实的友好态度迎接我。利厄笑了，连索菲都欣喜地跟我说了声“晚上好”。这让人非常愉快。被你的同类爱着，感觉到你的存在能带给他们更多的快乐，没有什么比这更让人觉得幸福的了。 I walked on so fast that even he could hardly have overtaken me had he tried.Little Adele was half wild with delight when she saw me.Mrs. Fairfax received me with her usual plain friendliness.Leah smiled, and even Sophie bid me “bon soir” with glee.This was very pleasant; there is no happiness like that of being loved by your fellow-creatures, and feeling that your presence is an addition to their comfort.
那天夜里我断然闭上双眼，不愿去想未来。我停下来，屏蔽了那不断警告我离别在即，悲伤将至的声音。用完了茶点，费尔法克斯太太开始织毛衣，我在她旁边，坐在一把低座椅上，阿德拉，跪在地毯上，紧紧依偎着我。一种相互的爱意彷佛在平和的金色光晕中包围着我们，我默默地祈祷，我们今后不要分开得太远太快。不过，我们正这样坐着的时候，罗切斯特先生不宣而至，看着我们，似乎从这样一个和谐安宁的组合中感觉到了快乐——说他认为老太太应该舒心了，因为她的养女回来了，还说看到阿德拉“恨不得一口把她的英国小妈妈吞进肚子里去”——我半带奢望地祈祷他结婚以后也能让我们在一起，在他的保护之下，不完全被剥夺他带来的阳光。 I that evening shut my eyes resolutely against the future: I stopped my cars against the voice that kept warning me of near separation and coming grief.When tea was over and Mrs. Fairfax had taken her knitting, and I had assumed a low seat near her, and Adele, kneeling on the carpet, had nestled close up to me, and a sense of mutual affection seemed to surround us with a ring of golden peace, I uttered a silent prayer that we might not be parted far or soon;but when, as we thus sat, Mr. Rochester entered, unannounced, and looking at us, seemed to take pleasure in the spectacle of a group so amicable—when he said he supposed the old lady was all right now that she had got her adopted daughter back again, and added that he saw Adele was “prete e croquer sa petite maman Anglaise”—I half ventured to hope that he would, even after his marriage, keep us together somewhere under the shelter of his protection, and not quite exiled from the sunshine of his presence.
我回到桑菲尔德以后两周过去了，这段时间平静得让人困惑。主人的婚礼现在没有人提了，我也没有看到任何为如此大事做的准备。几乎每天我都问费尔法克斯太太她是否听说了什么决定。她的回答总是否定的。有一次她说她真的问了罗切斯特先生，什么时候把他的新娘带回家。不过他只是用一个玩笑，和一个古怪的表情回答了她，她不知道他的想法。 A fortnight of dubious calm succeeded my return to Thornfield Hall.Nothing was said of the master’s marriage, and I saw no preparation going on for such an event.Almost every day I asked Mrs. Fairfax if she had yet heard anything decided: her answer was always in the negative.Once she said she had actually put the question to Mr. Rochester as to when he was going to bring his bride home; but he had answered her only by a joke and one of his queer looks, and she could not tell what to make of him.
有一件事尤其让我惊讶，那就是他没有来来往往地奔波，也没有拜访英格拉姆庄园。当然，那是在二十英里以外，在这里与另一个郡的交界处。然而这距离对于热切的恋人来说算得了什么？对于像罗切斯特先生这样一个熟练而又不知疲倦的骑马人来说，只用骑一个上午就到了。我开始萌生我没有权利拥有的希望，也就是婚事破灭了，谣言是错的，或者一方或者双方都改变了主意。我曾经注视主人的脸，想看看它是否忧伤或者愤怒。不过我都不记得它以前曾经像现在这样没有没有愁云，心平气和。有时我和我的学生与他在一起，如果我没有精神，陷入不可避免的沮丧，他就会变得更快乐。他从来没有像现在这样频繁地召唤我前去，每当这时也从来没有对我这样好过——而且，唉！我也从来没有如此地爱过他。 One thing specially surprised me, and that was, there were no journeyings backward and forward, no visits to Ingram Park: to be sure it was twenty miles off, on the borders of another county; but what was that distance to an ardent lover?To so practised and indefatigable a horseman as Mr. Rochester, it would be but a morning’s ride.I began to cherish hopes I had no right to conceive: that the match was broken off; that rumour had been mistaken; that one or both parties had changed their minds.I used to look at my master’s face to see if it were sad or fierce; but I could not remember the time when it had been so uniformly clear of clouds or evil feelings.If, in the moments I and my pupil spent with him, I lacked spirits and sank into inevitable dejection, he became even gay.Never had he called me more frequently to his presence; never been kinder to me when there—and, alas! never had I loved him so well.
第二十三章 CHAPTER XXIII
仲夏灿烂的阳光照耀着英格兰，天空如此纯净，我们这环海陆地上难得一见的晴天，现在却天天阳光明媚。就像一组意大利的好天气，如同快乐的候鸟般，从南方飞来，歇息在阿尔比恩的峭壁上。干草全都收了进来，桑菲尔德周围的田地都收割完毕，一片翠绿。道路白晃晃地被阳光烤着，树木正长得郁郁葱葱。树篱和林子枝叶繁茂，色彩浓郁，与它们之间阳光普照的干净草地形成鲜明对比。 A splendid Midsummer shone over England: skies so pure, suns so radiant as were then seen in long succession, seldom favour even singly, our wave-girt land.It was as if a band of Italian days had come from the South, like a flock of glorious passenger birds, and lighted to rest them on the cliffs of Albion.The hay was all got in; the fields round Thornfield were green and shorn; the roads white and baked; the trees were in their dark prime; hedge and wood, full-leaved and deeply tinted, contrasted well with the sunny hue of the cleared meadows between.
施洗约翰节前夜，阿德拉因为在海村路上摘了一天的野草莓，累得太阳刚下山就上床睡觉了。看着她睡着后，我起身，向花园走去。 On Midsummer-eve, Adele, weary with gathering wild strawberries in Hay Lane half the day, had gone to bed with the sun.I watched her drop asleep, and when I left her, I sought the garden.
现在是二十四小时中最甜蜜的时刻——“白昼已燃尽它的烈火”，露珠清凉地滴落在喘息的平原和被烤焦的山顶上。太阳已独自落下——留下斑斓的云彩——散出庄严的紫色，在一个山巅的某处，燃烧起红宝石与火炉般的火焰，延伸得又高又远，愈加柔和，铺满了半边天。东方自有其魅力，晴朗深蓝，自有其羞怯的宝石——一颗初升的孤星，很快它就将以其月亮为荣了，可现在那月亮仍在地平线下。 It was now the sweetest hour of the twenty-four:—“Day its fervid fires had wasted,” and dew fell cool on panting plain and scorched summit.Where the sun had gone down in simple state—pure of the pomp of clouds—spread a solemn purple, burning with the light of red jewel and furnace flame at one point, on one hill-peak, and extending high and wide, soft and still softer, over half heaven.The east had its own charm or fine deep blue, and its own modest gem, a casino and solitary star: soon it would boast the moon; but she was yet beneath the horizon.
