我在人行道上走了一会儿，但是一种微妙、熟悉的气味——雪茄的气味——从哪扇窗户溜了出来。我看见图书室的窗户开了一手宽，我知道有人可以从那儿看到我，于是我就走开，到果园里去。整个庭院没有比这个角落更隐蔽，更像伊甸园了。树木茂密，繁花盛开。一侧有一堵很高的墙将它与院子隔开，另一侧，一条山毛榉林荫道将其与草坪屏风般挡住。尽头处是一道矮墙，作为其与孤独的田野的唯一界限。一条蜿蜒的步行线直通矮墙，小路月桂环绕，尽头是一棵巨大的七叶树，树下围着一圈座位。在此处漫步可以不被人看到。当此时露水如蜜般滴落，寂静笼罩一切，暮色聚集，我感觉仿佛可以永远徜徉在这样的僻静处。冉冉升起的明月将其光芒洒在果园深处的开阔地，我被吸引得穿过花丛果林，向其走去。却又停下了脚步——不是因为听到了什么，看到了什么，而是再次闻到了那令人警觉的芳香。 I walked a while on the pavement; but a subtle, well-known scent—that of a cigar—stole from some window; I saw the library casement open a handbreadth; I knew I might be watched thence; so I went apart into the orchard.No nook in the grounds more sheltered and more Eden-like; it was full of trees, it bloomed with flowers: a very high wall shut it out from the court, on one side; on the other, a beech avenue screened it from the lawn.At the bottom was a sunk fence; its sole separation from lonely fields: a winding walk, bordered with laurels and terminating in a giant horse chestnut, circled at the base by a seat, led down to the fence.Here one could wander unseen.While such honey-dew fell, such silence reigned, such gloaming gathered, I felt as if I could haunt such shade for ever; but in threading the flower and fruit parterres at the upper part of the enclosure, enticed there by the light the now rising moon cast on this more open quarter, my step is stayed—not by sound, not by sight, but once more by a warning fragrance.
野蔷薇、青蒿、茉莉、石竹、玫瑰，早已呈上它们的晚香，而这种新气味并非来自灌木或花丛，那是——我很清楚——是罗切斯特先生的雪茄。我环顾四周，仔细聆听。我看见果树挂满了即将成熟的果子。我听见一只夜莺在半英里外的林子里鸣唱。没看到移动的身影，没听到走近的脚步声，但那气味却越来越浓：我必须逃走了。我走向通往灌木丛的小门，却看到罗切斯特先生进来了。我躲进旁边的常春藤深处。他不会久呆的，他很快就会原路返回，我只要坐着不动，他就绝不会看见我。 Sweet-briar and southernwood, jasmine, pink, and rose have long been yielding their evening sacrifice of incense: this new scent is neither of shrub nor flower; it is—I know it well—it is Mr. Rochester’s cigar.I look round and I listen.I see trees laden with ripening fruit.I hear a nightingale warbling in a wood half a mile off; no moving form is visible, no coming step audible; but that perfume increases: I must flee.I make for the wicket leading to the shrubbery, and I see Mr. Rochester entering.I step aside into the ivy recess; he will not stay long: he will soon return whence he came, and if I sit still he will never see me.
然而不是——黄昏对他与对我一样令人愉悦，这古老的花园也同样迷人。他漫步向前，时而举起醋栗枝条，看看上面坠满的大如梅子的果实；时而弯腰凑近一簇花，或者闻闻它们的芳香，或者赏赏花瓣上的露珠。一只大蛾子从我身边嗡嗡地飞过，停在罗切斯特先生脚边的一株植物上。他看见了，就俯身观察它。 But no—eventide is as pleasant to him as to me, and this antique garden as attractive; and he strolls on, now lifting the gooseberry tree branches to look at the fruit, large as plums, with which they are laden; now taking a ripe cherry from the wall; now stooping towards a knot of flowers, either to inhale their fragrance or to admire the dew-beads on their petals.A great moth goes humming by me; it alights on a plant at Mr. Rochester’s foot: he sees it, and bends to examine it.
“现在，他背对着我，”我想着，“而且还忙着。或许，如果我轻轻地走，就可以溜走而不被他发现。” “Now, he has his back towards me,” thought I, “and he is occupied too; perhaps, if I walk softly, I can slip away unnoticed.”
于是我踏上路边的草皮，以免石子路的噼啪声暴露自己。他正站在花坛中间，离我要过的地方有一两码远，显然那飞蛾吸引了他。“我肯定能顺利过去，”我想。我穿过他的身影，这影子被还未中天的月亮拉得长长的，投在花园里。他头也不回，轻轻地说—— I trode on an edging of turf that the crackle of the pebbly gravel might not betray me: he was standing among the beds at a yard or two distant from where I had to pass; the moth apparently engaged him.“I shall get by very well,” I meditated.As I crossed his shadow, thrown long over the garden by the moon, not yet risen high, he said quietly, without turning—
“简，过来看看这个家伙。” “Jane, come and look at this fellow.”
我没弄出声响，他背后也没长眼睛——莫非他的影子有感觉？我起初吃了一惊，然后走近他。 I had made no noise: he had not eyes behind—could his shadow feel?I started at first, and then I approached him.
“看它的翅膀，”他说，“它让我想起一种西印度的昆虫。这么大这么艳丽的夜游动物，在英格兰可不常见。看！它飞了。” “Look at his wings,” said he, “he reminds me rather of a West Indian insect; one does not often see so large and gay a night-rover in England; there! he is flown.”
那飞蛾飞走了。我也正怯懦地退开，但罗切斯特先生跟上了我，走到小门口时，他说—— The moth roamed away.I was sheepishly retreating also; but Mr. Rochester followed me, and when we reached the wicket, he said—
“回来吧，如此可爱的夜晚，在屋里坐着多遗憾。在这日落与月升的时刻，肯定没人愿意去睡觉。” “Turn back: on so lovely a night it is a shame to sit in the house; and surely no one can wish to go to bed while sunset is thus at meeting with moonrise.”
那是我的一个缺点，即虽然我有时候回答问题伶牙俐齿，但有时却悲哀地不会编造借口，尤其是在关键时刻，不能随口说出一句貌似可信的托辞，来摆脱令人痛苦的尴尬。我不喜欢在这种时候与罗切斯特先生单独在一起，漫步在果园中。但我又找不出一个借口离开他。我慢腾腾地跟在他身后，忙着想办法脱身。他却看上去平静而庄重，我对自己的困惑感到惭愧了。邪恶——不论此时或将来——大概只存在于我自己心里。他的内心是无意而平静的。 It is one of my faults, that though my tongue is sometimes prompt enough at an answer, there are times when it sadly fails me in framing an excuse; and always the lapse occurs at some crisis, when a facile word or plausible pretext is specially wanted to get me out of painful embarrassment.I did not like to walk at this hour alone with Mr. Rochester in the shadowy orchard; but I could not find a reason to allege for leaving him.I followed with lagging step, and thoughts busily bent on discovering a means of extrication; but he himself looked so composed and so grave also, I became ashamed of feeling any confusion: the evil—if evil existent or prospective there was—seemed to lie with me only; his mind was unconscious and quiet.
“简，”我们踏上月桂夹道的小路，慢慢地往矮墙和那棵七叶树走去。他又说，“夏天的桑菲尔德很美，不是么？” “Jane,” he recommenced, as we entered the laurel walk, and slowly strayed down in the direction of the sunk fence and the horse chestnut, “Thornfield is a pleasant place in summer, is it not?”
“是的，先生。” “Yes, sir.”
“你肯定有些迷上这宅子了——你，对自然之美有独到的眼光，而且很容易产生依恋之情？” “You must have become in some degree attached to the house,—you, who have an eye for natural beauties, and a good deal of the organ of Adhesiveness?”
“我迷上它了，的确。” “I am attached to it, indeed.”
“而且尽管我不明白是怎么回事，我发现你对那个小傻瓜阿德拉，甚至单纯的费尔法克斯夫人，也很关心？” “And though I don’t comprehend how it is, I perceive you have acquired a degree of regard for that foolish little child Adele, too; and even for simple dame Fairfax?”
“是的，先生。虽然方式不同，但我对她们两人都有感情。” “Yes, sir; in different ways, I have an affection for both.”
“而且你离开她们还会难过？” “And would be sorry to part with them?”
“是的。” “Yes.”
“可惜！”他叹了口气，停了一会儿。“生活就是这样，”他不久又继续，“你刚到一个愉快的栖息之所安定下来，就会有个声音叫你起身离开，因为休息的期限已满。” “Pity!” he said, and sighed and paused.“It is always the way of events in this life,” he continued presently: “no sooner have you got settled in a pleasant resting-place, than a voice calls out to you to rise and move on, for the hour of repose is expired.”
“我必须离开吗，先生？”我问。“我必须离开桑菲尔德吗？” “Must I move on, sir?” I asked.“Must I leave Thornfield?”
“我想是的，简。很抱歉，珍妮特，但我想你确实得走了。” “I believe you must, Jane.I am sorry, Janet, but I believe indeed you must.”
这可是一重击，但我不会让它打垮我。 This was a blow: but I did not let it prostrate me.
“那么，先生，只要让我走的命令一下，我就马上做好准备。” “Well, sir, I shall be ready when the order to march comes.”
“就是现在——我必须今晚下命令。” “It is come now—I must give it tonight.”
“然后您就要结婚了，先生？” “Then you ARE going to be married, sir?”
“正——是——如——此——完——全——正——确。以你一贯的敏锐，你一语中的。” “Ex-act-ly—pre-cise-ly: with your usual acuteness, you have hit the nail straight on the head.”
“快了吗，先生？” “Soon, sir?”
“很快，我的——就是说，爱小姐，你还记得，简，我第一次，或者说谣言，清楚地告诉你，我打算把自己老单身汉的脖子套进神圣的绳索，踏进圣洁的婚姻殿堂——”将英格拉姆小姐拥揽入怀，总之（她可真够抱的，但那不是重点——只要有我那漂亮的布兰奇，什么绝妙的东西都不需要了）。喂，我在说话呢——听我说，简！你不是在回头找飞蛾吧，是吗？那只是只瓢虫，孩子，‘正飞回家去’。我想提醒你，正是你，以我敬重的判断力——以你那谨慎的远见，和适合你责任和下人地位的谦逊，第一个跟我说——如果我要娶英格拉姆小姐，你和小阿德拉最好立即离开。我忽略了这种建议所表达的对我的爱人人格的污蔑。真的，当你远离我，珍妮特，我将试图忘掉。我只会看重它的智慧，而其已被我奉为我的行动准则。阿德拉必须去上学。而你，简小姐，必须找一份新工作。” “Very soon, my—that is, Miss Eyre: and you’ll remember, Jane, the first time I, or Rumour, plainly intimated to you that it was my intention to put my old bachelor’s neck into the sacred noose, to enter into the holy estate of matrimony—to take Miss Ingram to my bosom, in short (she’s an extensive armful: but that’s not to the point—one can’t have too much of such a very excellent thing as my beautiful Blanche): well, as I was saying—listen to me, Jane!You’re not turning your head to look after more moths, are you?That was only a lady-clock, child, ‘flying away home.’I wish to remind you that it was you who first said to me, with that discretion I respect in you—with that foresight, prudence, and humility which befit your responsible and dependent position—that in case I married Miss Ingram, both you and little Adele had better trot forthwith.I pass over the sort of slur conveyed in this suggestion on the character of my beloved; indeed, when you are far away, Janet, I’ll try to forget it: I shall notice only its wisdom; which is such that I have made it my law of action.Adele must go to school; and you, Miss Eyre, must get a new situation.”
“是的，先生。我会马上登广告。同时，我想——”我正要说，“我想我可能得呆在这里，直到我找到另一个栖身之处。”但我停下来了，觉得冒险说一长句话不可行，因为我的声音已经不太受控制了。 “Yes, sir, I will advertise immediately: and meantime, I suppose—” I was going to say, “I suppose I may stay here, till I find another shelter to betake myself to:” but I stopped, feeling it would not do to risk a long sentence, for my voice was not quite under command.
“一个月左右，我希望就能成为新浪，”罗切斯特先生继续说，“在这期间，我会亲自为你找一份工作和住所。” “In about a month I hope to be a bridegroom,” continued Mr. Rochester; “and in the interim, I shall myself look out for employment and an asylum for you.”
“谢谢你，先生。很抱歉给你——” “Thank you, sir; I am sorry to give—”
“噢，不需要道歉！我认为当一个下人把自己的工作干得像你一样好，她可以要求雇主任何他很方便办到的帮助。事实上我已经通过我未来的岳母，听说了一个我觉得可能适合的职位。那就是去爱尔兰的康诺特，去教比特纳特屋狄奥尼修斯·奥·高尔夫人的五个女儿。你会喜欢上爱尔兰的，我想。他们都说爱尔兰人很热心。” “Oh, no need to apologise!I consider that when a dependent does her duty as well as you have done yours, she has a sort of claim upon her employer for any little assistance he can conveniently render her; indeed I have already, through my future mother-in-law, heard of a place that I think will suit: it is to undertake the education of the five daughters of Mrs. Dionysius O’Gall of Bitternutt Lodge, Connaught, Ireland.You’ll like Ireland, I think: they’re such warm-hearted people there, they say.”
“那里太远了，先生。” “It is a long way off, sir.”
“没关系——你这样理智的姑娘不会拒绝旅行和路远吧。” “No matter—a girl of your sense will not object to the voyage or the distance.”
“旅行没什么，但是路太远了。而且还隔着大海——” “Not the voyage, but the distance: and then the sea is a barrier—”
“和什么隔着大海，简？” “From what, Jane?”
“和英格兰，和桑菲尔德。和——” “From England and from Thornfield: and—”
“什么？” “Well?”
“和你，先生。” “From YOU, sir.”
这话我几乎是脱口而出，由于自由意志无法控制，我的泪水涌了出来。但我没有哭出声，也没有抽泣。想到奥·高尔夫人和比特纳特屋，我的心都凉了。而一想到我和此时与我并肩行走的主人中间的所有海水和浪花，仿佛命中注定一般，奔腾汹涌，心就更凉。但回想到更宽的大海——夹在我，和我自然而然不可避免地爱着的人中间的财富、地位和世俗，心就凉透了。 I said this almost involuntarily, and, with as little sanction of free will, my tears gushed out.I did not cry so as to be heard, however; I avoided sobbing.The thought of Mrs. O’Gall and Bitternutt Lodge struck cold to my heart; and colder the thought of all the brine and foam, destined, as it seemed, to rush between me and the master at whose side I now walked, and coldest the remembrance of the wider ocean—wealth, caste, custom intervened between me and what I naturally and inevitably loved.
“路太远了。”我又说了遍。 “It is a long way,” I again said.
“是很远，肯定是。而且当你到了爱尔兰康诺特的比特纳特屋，我肯定再也见不到你了，简。那是肯定的。我从未去过爱尔兰，不怎么喜欢那个国家。我们一直是好朋友，简。是吗？” “It is, to be sure; and when you get to Bitternutt Lodge, Connaught, Ireland, I shall never see you again, Jane: that’s morally certain.I never go over to Ireland, not having myself much of a fancy for the country.We have been good friends, Jane; have we not?”
“是的，先生。” “Yes, sir.”
“当朋友即将离别，他们会亲密地共度剩余的那点时间。来吧！当星星在那边的天空中熠熠闪耀，我们要静静地聊聊旅行和分别，聊上半个小时左右。这就是七叶树，这就是老树根上的凳子。来吧，我们今晚就静静地坐在这儿，虽说我们注定再也不能坐在一起了。”他让我坐下，自己也坐下了。 “And when friends are on the eve of separation, they like to spend the little time that remains to them close to each other.Come! we’ll talk over the voyage and the parting quietly half-an-hour or so, while the stars enter into their shining life up in heaven yonder: here is the chestnut tree: here is the bench at its old roots.Come, we will sit there in peace tonight, though we should never more be destined to sit there together.”He seated me and himself.
“到爱尔兰很远，珍妮特，我很抱歉让我的小朋友去做如此令人疲倦的旅行。但如果我没有更好的办法，又能怎么办呢？你认为你和我有什么相似之处吗，简？” “It is a long way to Ireland, Janet, and I am sorry to send my little friend on such weary travels: but if I can’t do better, how is it to be helped?Are you anything akin to me, do you think, Jane?”
此刻我不能冒险做任何回答。我内心平静。 I could risk no sort of answer by this time: my heart was still.
“因为，”他说，“我有时对你有一种奇怪的感情——尤其像现在这样，你离我很近的时候。就好像我左边肋骨下有一根筋，与你那小身躯同样部位的一根类似的筋，紧紧地缠绕在一起，难以解开。如果那汹涌的海峡，还有约两百里的陆地横档在我们中间，恐怕那根联系的绳索就会绷断。于是我就很紧张地以为，那时我的心会流血的。而你——你会忘记我。” “Because,” he said, “I sometimes have a queer feeling with regard to you—especially when you are near me, as now: it is as if I had a string somewhere under my left ribs, tightly and inextricably knotted to a similar string situated in the corresponding quarter of your little frame.And if that boisterous Channel, and two hundred miles or so of land come broad between us, I am afraid that cord of communion will be snapt; and then I’ve a nervous notion I should take to bleeding inwardly.As for you,—you’d forget me.”
“我永远不会，先生，你知道——”我无法继续。 “That I NEVER should, sir: you know—” Impossible to proceed.
“简，你听到林子里唱歌的夜莺了吗？”听！” “Jane, do you hear that nightingale singing in the wood?Listen!”
我一边听，一边剧烈地抽泣。我再也克制不住那一直强忍着的感情了，我不得不屈服了。我从头到脚都因为强烈的悲伤而战栗。当我能说话时，我只说出了一个冲动的愿望，即愿自己从未出生，或从未来过桑菲尔德。 In listening, I sobbed convulsively; for I could repress what I endured no longer; I was obliged to yield, and I was shaken from head to foot with acute distress.When I did speak, it was only to express an impetuous wish that I had never been born, or never come to Thornfield.
“因为离开它令你难过吗？” “Because you are sorry to leave it?”
激烈的情绪，被内心的悲痛和爱恋搅动着，正在要求主宰，为全面统治而斗争，要支配一切，战胜一切，要生存，要崛起，最终统治一切——是的，还要说话。 The vehemence of emotion, stirred by grief and love within me, was claiming mastery, and struggling for full sway, and asserting a right to predominate, to overcome, to live, rise, and reign at last: yes,—and to speak.
“我为离开桑菲尔德而难过，我爱桑菲尔德——我爱它，因为我在这里过得既充实又快乐——至少是暂时的。我没有被蔑视。没有被惊呆。我没有被埋没在地位低下的人当中，没有被排除在与坦诚、活力、高尚的人交往之外。我与自己尊重的人，令我愉快的人面对面地交谈，——与有创见的、有活力的、胸怀宽广的心灵交谈。我认识了你，罗切斯特先生。一想到我必须永远与你分开，我就感到恐怖，感到痛苦。我知道分别的必要，就像明白死亡的势必来临。” “I grieve to leave Thornfield: I love Thornfield:—I love it, because I have lived in it a full and delightful life,—momentarily at least.I have not been trampled on.I have not been petrified.I have not been buried with inferior minds, and excluded from every glimpse of communion with what is bright and energetic and high.I have talked, face to face, with what I reverence, with what I delight in,—with an original, a vigorous, an expanded mind.I have known you, Mr. Rochester; and it strikes me with terror and anguish to feel I absolutely must be torn from you for ever.I see the necessity of departure; and it is like looking on the necessity of death.”
“你怎么知道非分别不可？”他突然问道。 “Where do you see the necessity?” he asked suddenly.
“怎么？你，先生，已经把它摆在我面前了。 “Where?You, sir, have placed it before me.”
“以何种形式？” “In what shape?”
“以英格拉姆小姐的形式。一个高贵美丽的女人——你的新娘。” “In the shape of Miss Ingram; a noble and beautiful woman,—your bride.”
“我的新娘！什么新娘！我没有新娘！” “My bride!What bride?I have no bride!”
“但你会有的。” “But you will have.”
“是的——我会有的！——我会有的！”他咬牙切齿地说。 “Yes;—I will!—I will!”He set his teeth.
“那我就必须走——你自己说过的。” “Then I must go:—you have said it yourself.”
“不，你必须留下！我发誓——而且将信守誓言。” “No: you must stay!I swear it—and the oath shall be kept.”
“我告诉你我必须离开！”我反驳道，被什么东西激怒了。“你以为我会留下来，变得对你来说什么也不是？你以为我是个机器人？——一架毫无感情的机器？可以忍受嘴边的面包被抢走，杯子里的生命之水被泼掉？你以为我因为贫穷、卑微、朴实、矮小，就没有灵魂，没有感情吗？你错了！——我有与你一样的灵魂——与你一样的满腔激情！如果上帝赐给了我几分美貌，许多财富，我就会让你也难以离开我，就像现在我难以离开你一样。我现在不是通过世俗、传统跟你说话，甚至也不是凡人的肉体——是我的灵魂在跟你的灵魂对话，就像它们都穿过了坟墓，平等地站在上帝脚下——正如现在一样！” “I tell you I must go!”I retorted, roused to something like passion.“Do you think I can stay to become nothing to you?Do you think I am an automaton?—a machine without feelings?and can bear to have my morsel of bread snatched from my lips, and my drop of living water dashed from my cup?Do you think, because I am poor, obscure, plain, and little, I am soulless and heartless?You think wrong!—I have as much soul as you,—and full as much heart!And if God had gifted me with some beauty and much wealth, I should have made it as hard for you to leave me, as it is now for me to leave you.I am not talking to you now through the medium of custom, conventionalities, nor even of mortal flesh;—it is my spirit that addresses your spirit; just as if both had passed through the grave, and we stood at God’s feet, equal,—as we are!”
“正如现在一样！”罗切斯特先生重复道——“是这样，”他又补充道，将我揽入臂弯。把我搂进怀里，将他的嘴唇压在我的唇上：“是这样，简！” “As we are!” repeated Mr. Rochester—“so,” he added, enclosing me in his arms.Gathering me to his breast, pressing his lips on my lips: “so, Jane!”
“是的，是这样，先生，”我答道：“但又不是这样。因为你是个结了婚的人——或者说无异于一个结了婚的人，娶了个不如你的人——你与她没有交感——我相信你并不真心爱她。因为我看见过也听见过你嘲笑她。我会蔑视这种结合，所以我比你强——让我走！” “Yes, so, sir,” I rejoined: “and yet not so; for you are a married man—or as good as a married man, and wed to one inferior to you—to one with whom you have no sympathy—whom I do not believe you truly love; for I have seen and heard you sneer at her.I would scorn such a union: therefore I am better than you—let me go!”
“去哪里，简？去爱尔兰？” “Where, Jane?To Ireland?”
“是的——去爱尔兰。我说出了我的心声，现在可以去任何地方了。 “Yes—to Ireland.I have spoken my mind, and can go anywhere now.”
“简，静下来。不要这么挣扎，像只野蛮疯狂的鸟儿，拼命劈裂自己的翅膀。” “Jane, be still; don’t struggle so, like a wild frantic bird that is rending its own plumage in its desperation.”
“我不是鸟儿，也没有罗网来诱捕我。我是一个有着独立意志的自由人，此时这独立意志正要求我离开你。” “I am no bird; and no net ensnares me; I am a free human being with an independent will, which I now exert to leave you.”
又一次的努力使我获得自由，我直直地站在他面前。 Another effort set me at liberty, and I stood erect before him.
“那就让你的意志来决定你的命运，”他说：“我把我的手、我的心，还有我的全部财产都献给你。” “And your will shall decide your destiny,” he said: “I offer you my hand, my heart, and a share of all my possessions.”
“你在演闹剧，只会让我觉得好笑。” “You play a farce, which I merely laugh at.”
“我请你陪我度过一生——做我的另一半，做世界上最好的伴侣。” “I ask you to pass through life at my side—to be my second self, and best earthly companion.”
“你已经为你的命运做出了选择，你必须忍受。” “For that fate you have already made your choice, and must abide by it.”
“简，安静一会儿，你太激动了。我也会安静下来的。” “Jane, be still a few moments: you are over-excited: I will be still too.”
一阵风顺着月桂小路吹来，颤抖着吹过七叶树的树枝，飘走了——走了——到无尽的远方——消失了。夜莺的歌声是那一时刻唯一的声音，听着听着，我又哭了。罗切斯特先生静静地坐着，温柔而严肃地看着我。过了好久，他终于开口，说道—— A waft of wind came sweeping down the laurel-walk, and trembled through the boughs of the chestnut: it wandered away—away—to an indefinite distance—it died.The nightingale’s song was then the only voice of the hour: in listening to it, I again wept.Mr. Rochester sat quiet, looking at me gently and seriously.Some time passed before he spoke; he at last said—
“到我身边来，简，我们互相解释一下，互相理解吧。” “Come to my side, Jane, and let us explain and understand one another.”
“我再也不会回到你身边了：我既然已经被你抛开，就不能再回去。” “I will never again come to your side: I am torn away now, and cannot return.”
“但是，简，我把你当作妻子来召唤：你是我唯一想娶的人。” “But, Jane, I summon you as my wife: it is you only I intend to marry.”
我沉默了：我想他是在取笑我。 I was silent: I thought he mocked me.
“来吧，简——到这里来。” “Come, Jane—come hither.”
“你的新娘站在我们中间。” “Your bride stands between us.”
他起身，一步跨到我面前。 He rose, and with a stride reached me.
“我的新娘在这儿，”他说，又拉我入怀，“因为与我平等的人，相似的人在这儿。简，嫁给我好吗？ “My bride is here,” he said, again drawing me to him, “because my equal is here, and my likeness.Jane, will you marry me?”
我仍然没有回答，仍然挣扎着摆脱他的怀抱，因为我仍然不相信。 Still I did not answer, and still I writhed myself from his grasp: for I was still incredulous.
“你在怀疑我吗，简？” “Do you doubt me, Jane?”
“绝对怀疑。” “Entirely.”
“你不信任我？” “You have no faith in me?”
“一点也不。” “Not a whit.”
“在你眼里我是个骗子吗？”他激动地问。“有点怀疑，你会被说服的。我会爱上英格拉姆小姐什么？什么也没有：这你知道。她爱上我什么？什么也没有：我煞费苦心地去证明这点：我让流言传到她那儿，说我的财产不及别人认为的三分之一，之后我自己送上门去看个究竟。她和她母亲都冷若冰霜。我不愿意——也不可能——娶英格拉姆小姐。你——你这个陌生人，你这个近乎神秘的东西！——我爱你如同爱自已。你——贫穷而卑微，矮小又朴素——我请求你接受我做你丈夫。” “Am I a liar in your eyes?” he asked passionately.“Little sceptic, you SHALL be convinced.What love have I for Miss Ingram?None: and that you know.What love has she for me?None: as I have taken pains to prove: I caused a rumour to reach her that my fortune was not a third of what was supposed, and after that I presented myself to see the result; it was coldness both from her and her mother.I would not—I could not—marry Miss Ingram.You—you strange, you almost unearthly thing!—I love as my own flesh.You—poor and obscure, and small and plain as you are—I entreat to accept me as a husband.”
“什么，我！”我突然叫道，从他的认真——特别是他的鲁莽——开始相信他的真诚：“我？在这世上除了你没有一个朋友——如果你是我的朋友的话。而且除了你给我的钱，一个子儿也没有。” “What, me!”I ejaculated, beginning in his earnestness—and especially in his incivility—to credit his sincerity: “me who have not a friend in the world but you—if you are my friend: not a shilling but what you have given me?”
“你，简，我一定要你属于我——完全属于我。你会是我的吗？说你愿意，快。” “You, Jane, I must have you for my own—entirely my own.Will you be mine?Say yes, quickly.”
“罗切斯特先生，让我看看你的脸：转向月光。” “Mr. Rochester, let me look at your face: turn to the moonlight.”
“为什么？” “Why?”
“因为我想看看你的表情——转过去！” “Because I want to read your countenance—turn!”
“好啦！你会发现它还不如一张被抓得皱巴巴的纸清晰可辨。看吧：不过快点儿，我很难受。” “There! you will find it scarcely more legible than a crumpled, scratched page.Read on: only make haste, for I suffer.”
他满脸激动，面色通红，五官都在剧烈抽动，眼里闪着奇异的光。 His face was very much agitated and very much flushed, and there were strong workings in the features, and strange gleams in the eyes.
“噢，简，你在折磨我！”他叫道。“你用你那锐利的，而又忠诚大度的目光折磨我！” “Oh, Jane, you torture me!” he exclaimed.“With that searching and yet faithful and generous look, you torture me!”
“怎么会呢？如果你是真心的，你的请求是真的，那我对你唯一的感情肯定是感激和忠诚——不会是折磨。” “How can I do that?If you are true, and your offer real, my only feelings to you must be gratitude and devotion—they cannot torture.”
“感激！”他叫道，疯狂地继续说——“简，快答应我。说，爱德华——叫我的名字——爱德华——我愿意嫁给你。” “Gratitude!” he ejaculated; and added wildly—“Jane accept me quickly.Say, Edward—give me my name—Edward—I will marry you.”
“你是认真的？你真心爱我？你诚心希望我做你妻子？” “Are you in earnest?Do you truly love me?Do you sincerely wish me to be your wife?”
“是的。如果需要我发誓你才满意，我就发誓。” “I do; and if an oath is necessary to satisfy you, I swear it.”
“那好，先生，我愿意嫁给你。”“叫我爱德华——我的小夫人！” “Then, sir, I will marry you.”“To put Adele to bed: it is past her bedtime.”“Edward—my little wife!”
“亲爱的爱德华！” “Dear Edward!”
“到我这边来——现在整个儿到我身边来，”他说，又把脸贴在我脸上，用他低沉的声音，对着我的耳朵说，“让我幸福吧——我也会让你幸福的。” “Come to me—come to me entirely now,” said he; and added, in his deepest tone, speaking in my ear as his cheek was laid on mine, “Make my happiness—I will make yours.”
“上帝饶恕我！”很快他又添了一句。“别让人来干预我，让我得到她，我要拥有她。” “God pardon me!” he subjoined ere long; “and man meddle not with me: I have her, and will hold her.”
“没有人来干预，先生。我没有亲戚来干预。”“没有——那再好不过，”他说。如果我对他的爱少一点，我会觉得他那狂喜的腔调和表情几乎粗野。可是，坐在他身边，从离别的噩梦中被唤醒——被唤入婚姻的天堂——我一心只想着狂饮如此充足的幸福之泉。他一遍又一遍地说，“你开心吗，简？”我一遍又一遍地回答，“开心。”之后他喃喃道，“会赎罪的——会赎罪的。我难道不是发现她没有朋友，冷酷，无人安慰么？我难道不会保护，珍爱，安抚她么？难道我的心中没有爱情，没有坚定的决心么？在上帝的法庭里会赎罪的。我知道造物主批准我的行为。至于世间的评判——我不会理睬。至于别人的看法——我不在乎。” “There is no one to meddle, sir.I have no kindred to interfere.”“No—that is the best of it,” he said.And if I had loved him less I should have thought his accent and look of exultation savage; but, sitting by him, roused from the nightmare of parting—called to the paradise of union—I thought only of the bliss given me to drink in so abundant a flow.Again and again he said, “Are you happy, Jane?”And again and again I answered, “Yes.”After which he murmured, “It will atone—it will atone.Have I not found her friendless, and cold, and comfortless?Will I not guard, and cherish, and solace her?Is there not love in my heart, and constancy in my resolves?It will expiate at God’s tribunal.I know my Maker sanctions what I do.For the world’s judgment—I wash my hands thereof.For man’s opinion—I defy it.”
但是今晚发生了什么呢？月亮还未降落，我们已完全被笼罩在阴影中：我几乎看不清主人的脸，虽说我就在他身边。什么使七叶树苦恼了？它扭动着，呻吟着。风呼啸着穿过月桂小道，扑面而来。 But what had befallen the night?The moon was not yet set, and we were all in shadow: I could scarcely see my master’s face, near as I was.And what ailed the chestnut tree? it writhed and groaned; while wind roared in the laurel walk, and came sweeping over us.
“我们得进去了，”罗切斯特先生说：“变天了。不然我就与你坐到天明，简。” “We must go in,” said Mr. Rochester: “the weather changes.I could have sat with thee till morning, Jane.”
“我也愿意这样。”我想。或许我该将这话说出口。但是，一道鲜明的灰色闪电，从我正望着的云层中跃出，接着是一声噼啪的霹雳，近处一片轰隆隆的声音，我只想把自己花了的眼睛藏进罗切斯特先生的肩膀里。 “And so,” thought I, “could I with you.”I should have said so, perhaps, but a livid, vivid spark leapt out of a cloud at which I was looking, and there was a crack, a crash, and a close rattling peal; and I thought only of hiding my dazzled eyes against Mr. Rochester’s shoulder.
雨倾泻下来。他催我跑上小路，穿过院子，进入房子里。但我们还没跨过门槛，就已经湿透了。在大厅里，他摘下我的披肩，抖落我散开的头发上的水滴，这时费尔法克斯太太从她屋里走了出来。我开始没看到她，罗切斯特先生也没有。灯是亮着的。时钟敲响了十二点。 The rain rushed down.He hurried me up the walk, through the grounds, and into the house; but we were quite wet before we could pass the threshold.He was taking off my shawl in the hall, and shaking the water out of my loosened hair, when Mrs. Fairfax emerged from her room.I did not observe her at first, nor did Mr. Rochester.The lamp was lit.The clock was on the stroke of twelve.
“赶快脱掉你的湿衣服，”他说。“你走之前，晚安——晚安，亲爱的！” “Hasten to take off your wet things,” said he; “and before you go, good-night—good-night, my darling!”
他再三地吻我。我离开他的怀抱，一抬头，看到了那站着的寡妇，脸色苍白，严肃而吃惊。我只对她笑笑，跑上了楼。“下次再解释吧，”我想。当我到了自己房间，想到刚才她对所见的即使是暂时的误会，还是感到一阵剧痛，但是欢乐很快抹杀了所有其他情绪。风大声呼啸，雷在近处使劲炸响，电光凶猛频繁地闪耀，瀑布般的雨水持续了两个小时，而我既没有感到恐怖，也不害怕。罗切斯特先生在这期间到我门前来了三次，问我是否平安无事：那就是安慰，是面对一切的力量。 He kissed me repeatedly.When I looked up, on leaving his arms, there stood the widow, pale, grave, and amazed.I only smiled at her, and ran upstairs.“Explanation will do for another time,” thought I.Still, when I reached my chamber, I felt a pang at the idea she should even temporarily misconstrue what she had seen.But joy soon effaced every other feeling; and loud as the wind blew, near and deep as the thunder crashed, fierce and frequent as the lightning gleamed, cataract-like as the rain fell during a storm of two hours’ duration, I experienced no fear and little awe.Mr. Rochester came thrice to my door in the course of it, to ask if I was safe and tranquil: and that was comfort that was strength for anything.
早晨还没起床，小阿德拉就跑来告诉我，说夜里果园尽头那棵七叶树被雷电击中，劈成了两半。 Before I left my bed in the morning, little Adele came running in to tell me that the great horse-chestnut at the bottom of the orchard had been struck by lightning in the night, and half of it split away.
第二十四章 CHAPTER XXIV
我起身穿好衣服，想想发生过的一切，怀疑那是否是一场梦。我不能肯定那是真的，除非再见到罗切斯特先生，听他把那关于爱和承诺的话再说一遍。 As I rose and dressed, I thought over what had happened, and wondered if it were a dream.I could not be certain of the reality till I had seen Mr. Rochester again, and heard him renew his words of love and promise.
梳头时我看着镜子里自己的脸，觉得它不再平凡，容颜中含着希望，面色里透出生机。双眼仿佛看到了成果之泉，从闪耀的涟漪中借来光芒。我以前总是不愿看我的主人，因为我怕他不喜欢我的长相。但我相信我现在可以在他面前扬起头来，不再让我的容颜令他的爱意冷却。我从抽屉里拿出一件朴素却干净轻盈的夏衣穿上，好像从没有衣服如此地合身，因为没有哪件衣服是在如此喜悦的心情中穿上的。 While arranging my hair, I looked at my face in the glass, and felt it was no longer plain: there was hope in its aspect and life in its colour; and my eyes seemed as if they had beheld the fount of fruition, and borrowed beams from the lustrous ripple.I had often been unwilling to look at my master, because I feared he could not be pleased at my look; but I was sure I might lift my face to his now, and not cool his affection by its expression.I took a plain but clean and light summer dress from my drawer and put it on: it seemed no attire had ever so well become me, because none had I ever worn in so blissful a mood.
跑下大厅，我毫不意外地看到，昨夜的暴风雨之后，迎来了一个明媚的六月晨曦。通过开着的玻璃门，感觉到了清新芳香的微风。当我如此幸福，大自然必然也是高兴的。一个女乞丐和她的小男孩——面色苍白，衣衫褴褛——顺着小路走来。我跑下去，把钱包中所有的钱都给了他们——大概三、四先令。不管怎样，他们也该分享我的欢乐。白嘴鸦呱呱地叫，鸟儿叽叽喳喳地唱歌。但没有什么能跟我欣喜的心情一样愉快、悦耳。 I was not surprised, when I ran down into the hall, to see that a brilliant June morning had succeeded to the tempest of the night; and to feel, through the open glass door, the breathing of a fresh and fragrant breeze.Nature must be gladsome when I was so happy.A beggar-woman and her little boy—pale, ragged objects both—were coming up the walk, and I ran down and gave them all the money I happened to have in my purse—some three or four shillings: good or bad, they must partake of my jubilee.The rooks cawed, and blither birds sang; but nothing was so merry or so musical as my own rejoicing heart.
费尔法克斯太太面带悲伤地望向窗外，严肃地说——“爱小姐，来用早餐吗？”吓了我一跳。吃饭时她冷冷地沉默着，但我那时还不能向她解释。我必须等主人来给出解释，所以她也得等着。我尽量吃了点，然后急忙上楼了。碰到阿德拉从教室出来。 Mrs. Fairfax surprised me by looking out of the window with a sad countenance, and saying gravely—“Miss Eyre, will you come to breakfast?”During the meal she was quiet and cool: but I could not undeceive her then.I must wait for my master to give explanations; and so must she.I ate what I could, and then I hastened upstairs.I met Adele leaving the schoolroom.
“你要去哪儿？该上课了。” “Where are you going?It is time for lessons.”
“罗切斯特先生让我去育儿室。” “Mr. Rochester has sent me away to the nursery.”
“他在哪儿？” “Where is he?”
“在里面，”指着她刚出来的房间。我进去，他正站在那儿。 “In there,” pointing to the apartment she had left; and I went in, and there he stood.
“过来跟我说早安，”他说。我高兴地上前去。我现在得到的不仅仅是冷冷的话语，或握握手，而是拥抱，是亲吻。仿佛受他如此爱恋，如此爱抚，是自然而然、天经地义的。 “Come and bid me good-morning,” said he.I gladly advanced; and it was not merely a cold word now, or even a shake of the hand that I received, but an embrace and a kiss.It seemed natural: it seemed genial to be so well loved, so caressed by him.
“简，你看起来容光焕发，笑容满面，漂亮极了，”他说：“今早真的好漂亮。这是我那苍白的小精灵吗？这是我的小芥子吗？这个满面容光，深深的酒窝，红红的嘴唇，褐色的头发如缎般光滑，有着亮如秋水般褐色眸子的小女孩？（读者啊，我的眼睛是绿色的，但你必须原谅这个错误，因为我想对他来说，我的眼睛是刚染过色的。） “Jane, you look blooming, and smiling, and pretty,” said he: “truly pretty this morning.Is this my pale, little elf?Is this my mustard-seed?This little sunny-faced girl with the dimpled cheek and rosy lips; the satin-smooth hazel hair, and the radiant hazel eyes?”(I had green eyes, reader; but you must excuse the mistake: for him they were new-dyed, I suppose.)
“我是简·爱，先生。” “It is Jane Eyre, sir.”
“马上就是简·罗切斯特了，”他说，“只需四个星期，珍妮特，一天也不能多。你听到了吗？” “Soon to be Jane Rochester,” he added: “in four weeks, Janet; not a day more.Do you hear that?”
我听到了，但还不能完全理解：我被弄晕了。这宣告对我的感觉，远比快乐更加强烈——给人以重击，令人震惊。那感觉，我想，几乎就是恐惧。 I did, and I could not quite comprehend it: it made me giddy.The feeling, the announcement sent through me, was something stronger than was consistent with joy—something that smote and stunned.It was, I think almost fear.
“你刚才满面红光，现在又脸色苍白了，简，为什么？” “You blushed, and now you are white, Jane: what is that for?”
“因为你给了我一个新名字——简·罗切斯特，这听起来好陌生。” “Because you gave me a new name—Jane Rochester; and it seems so strange.”
“是的，罗切斯特夫人，”他说，“年轻的罗切斯特夫人——费尔法克斯·罗切斯特的小新娘。” “Yes, Mrs. Rochester,” said he; “young Mrs. Rochester—Fairfax Rochester’s girl-bride.”
“这绝不行，先生。听起来都不像。这世上的人不会拥有完美的幸福的。我又不是天生与我的同类有着不同的命运：想象这种好事的降临只是童话——是白日梦。” “It can never be, sir; it does not sound likely.Human beings never enjoy complete happiness in this world.I was not born for a different destiny to the rest of my species: to imagine such a lot befalling me is a fairy tale—a day-dream.”
“这梦想我能够，也愿意实现。我今天就开始。今天早上我已经写信给我伦敦的银行家，让他将替我保管的一些珠宝送来——是桑菲尔德府上太太们的传家宝。希望过一两天就能将它们倒入你的衣兜，如果我要娶的是一个贵族的女儿，她所能享受的一切特权，一切关注，我都要让你得到。 “Which I can and will realise.I shall begin today.This morning I wrote to my banker in London to send me certain jewels he has in his keeping,—heirlooms for the ladies of Thornfield.In a day or two I hope to pour them into your lap: for every privilege, every attention shall be yours that I would accord a peer’s daughter, if about to marry her.”
“噢，先生！——绝不要提什么珠宝！我不喜欢听那些。给简·爱珠宝，听起来既不自然又怪怪地，我宁愿不要它们。” “Oh, sir!—never rain jewels!I don’t like to hear them spoken of.Jewels for Jane Eyre sounds unnatural and strange: I would rather not have them.”
“我要亲自将钻石项链戴在你的脖子上，将饰环戴上你的额头——它们会非常相配，因为大自然至少在你额上打上了高贵的印记。简，我要给你纤细的手腕套上手镯，再给这仙女般的手指戴上戒指。” “I will myself put the diamond chain round your neck, and the circlet on your forehead,—which it will become: for nature, at least, has stamped her patent of nobility on this brow, Jane; and I will clasp the bracelets on these fine wrists, and load these fairylike fingers with rings.”
“不，不，先生！想想别的话题，谈谈别的事情，换一种语气吧。不要把我当个美人似的跟我说话，我只是你相貌平庸，贵格会教徒般的家庭教师。” “No, no, sir! think of other subjects, and speak of other things, and in another strain.Don’t address me as if I were a beauty; I am your plain, Quakerish governess.”
“你在我眼里就是美人，而且是正合我意的美人——娇弱而轻柔。” “You are a beauty in my eyes, and a beauty just after the desire of my heart,—delicate and aerial.”
“你是说我弱小，不起眼吧。你在做梦，先生——或者你在嘲笑我。看在上帝份上，不要讽刺我！” “Puny and insignificant, you mean.You are dreaming, sir,—or you are sneering.For God’s sake don’t be ironical!”
“我还要全世界都知道你是个美人。”他继续说。而此时我已对他这种语气感到不安，因为我觉得他要么是在欺骗自己，要么在试图骗我。“我要我的简穿上绸缎花边，头发上插上玫瑰。我还要给我最心爱的脑袋罩上无价的面纱。” “I will make the world acknowledge you a beauty, too,” he went on, while I really became uneasy at the strain he had adopted, because I felt he was either deluding himself or trying to delude me.“I will attire my Jane in satin and lace, and she shall have roses in her hair; and I will cover the head I love best with a priceless veil.”
“那时候你就不认识我了，先生，我就不再是你的简·爱了，而是一只穿着小丑服装的猴子——一只披着借来的羽毛的鸟。我看你穿上舞台服饰，就如我自己穿着贵妇的长袍一样。我不说你英俊，先生，尽管我深深爱着你。就是因为爱得如此深沉才不恭维你。你也不要奉承我。” “And then you won’t know me, sir; and I shall not be your Jane Eyre any longer, but an ape in a harlequin’s jacket—a jay in borrowed plumes.I would as soon see you, Mr. Rochester, tricked out in stage-trappings, as myself clad in a court-lady’s robe; and I don’t call you handsome, sir, though I love you most dearly: far too dearly to flatter you.Don’t flatter me.”
然而，他继续着他的话题，并没理会我的反对。“我今天就要带你坐着马车去米尔科特，你得为自己选几套衣裳。我告诉你了我们四周后就要结婚。婚礼要安静地举行，就在那边的教堂里。然后我就立即把你送到城里。在那儿稍作休息，我就把我的宝贝带到离阳光更近的地方去：到法国的葡萄园和意大利平原，让她看看古老传说和现代记录中的所有名胜。她还要学会通过和别人公正地比较，来珍重自己。” He pursued his theme, however, without noticing my deprecation.“This very day I shall take you in the carriage to Millcote, and you must choose some dresses for yourself.I told you we shall be married in four weeks.The wedding is to take place quietly, in the church down below yonder; and then I shall waft you away at once to town.After a brief stay there, I shall bear my treasure to regions nearer the sun: to French vineyards and Italian plains; and she shall see whatever is famous in old story and in modern record: she shall taste, too, of the life of cities; and she shall learn to value herself by just comparison with others.”
“我会去旅行？——和你一起，先生？” “Shall I travel?—and with you, sir?”
“你会逗留于巴黎、罗马、那不勒斯，住在佛罗伦萨、威尼斯，还有维也纳：所有我漫游过的地方，我都要你重走一遍，我脚踩过的地方，你纤细的双脚也要踏上去。十年来，我疯了似地跑遍了欧洲。那时只有厌恶、仇恨和愤怒与我为伴：如今我被治愈，被净化了，将与安慰我的天使一同重游故地。” “You shall sojourn at Paris, Rome, and Naples: at Florence, Venice, and Vienna: all the ground I have wandered over shall be re-trodden by you: wherever I stamped my hoof, your sylph’s foot shall step also.Ten years since, I flew through Europe half mad; with disgust, hate, and rage as my companions: now I shall revisit it healed and cleansed, with a very angel as my comforter.”
他说这些的时候我笑了。“我不是天使，”我称，“而且至死也不会成为天使：我只是我自己。”罗切斯特先生，你不能指望或强求我有什么神仙般的东西——你不可能得到，正如我从你身上也得不到一样：而且我也根本没有期望。” I laughed at him as he said this.“I am not an angel,” I asserted; “and I will not be one till I die: I will be myself.Mr. Rochester, you must neither expect nor exact anything celestial of me—for you will not get it, any more than I shall get it of you: which I do not at all anticipate.”
“那你指望我什么？” “What do you anticipate of me?”
“或许你暂时会和现在一样——但为期很短。然后你就变得冷酷，反复无常，变得严厉。那时我就得费尽心机让你开心。但等你习惯了我，也许又会喜欢上我——我说的是喜欢我，不是爱我。我想你的爱在六个月内，或者不到六个月，就会化为泡影。我从男人写的书中看到过，一个丈夫的热情最多能持续这么久。然而，毕竟作为一个朋友和伴侣，我希望对于亲爱的主人而言我绝不要变得太令人讨厌。” “For a little while you will perhaps be as you are now,—a very little while; and then you will turn cool; and then you will be capricious; and then you will be stern, and I shall have much ado to please you: but when you get well used to me, you will perhaps like me again,—LIKE me, I say, not LOVE me.I suppose your love will effervesce in six months, or less.I have observed in books written by men, that period assigned as the farthest to which a husband’s ardour extends.Yet, after all, as a friend and companion, I hope never to become quite distasteful to my dear master.”
“令人讨厌！又喜欢你！我想我会一直不断地喜欢你：我要让你承认，我不只是喜欢你，而是爱你——真诚、热烈、恒久不变。” “Distasteful! and like you again!I think I shall like you again, and yet again: and I will make you confess I do not only LIKE, but LOVE you—with truth, fervour, constancy.”
“但是你不会反复无常吧，先生？” “Yet are you not capricious, sir?”
“对那些仅靠脸蛋来取悦我的女人来说，当我发现她们既没有灵魂有没有真心，我就是真正的恶魔——一旦她们让我看到了她们的单调、轻浮，或许还有愚蠢、粗鄙和暴躁。但对于清澈的目光，流利的口才，烈火造就的灵魂，宁愿弯曲而不折断的个性——既柔软又稳重，既温顺又坚强——我会永远温柔、忠诚。” “To women who please me only by their faces, I am the very devil when I find out they have neither souls nor hearts—when they open to me a perspective of flatness, triviality, and perhaps imbecility, coarseness, and ill-temper:but to the clear eye and eloquent tongue, to the soul made of fire, and the character that bends but does not break—at once supple and stable, tractable and consistent—I am ever tender and true.”
“你遇到过这种人吗，先生？你爱上过这样的人吗？” “Had you ever experience of such a character, sir?Did you ever love such an one?”
“我现在正爱着呢。” “I love it now.”
“但在我之前：如果我，确实在各方面达到了你严苛的标准？” “But before me: if I, indeed, in any respect come up to your difficult standard?”
“我从未见像过你这样的人。简，你让令我开心，你征服了我——你很顺从，我喜欢你这种柔顺，我将你柔顺如丝的个性缠绕于我的手指，便有一种震颤从胳臂一直传到心里。我受到感染——被征服了。这种感染别我的言语更加甜蜜。我经受的这种征服比我赢得的任何胜利都更具魔力。你为什么笑，简？你那神秘的、令人费解的表情变化是什么意思？” “I never met your likeness.Jane, you please me, and you master me—you seem to submit, and I like the sense of pliancy you impart; and while I am twining the soft, silken skein round my finger, it sends a thrill up my arm to my heart.I am influenced—conquered; and the influence is sweeter than I can express; and the conquest I undergo has a witchery beyond any triumph I can win.Why do you smile, Jane?What does that inexplicable, that uncanny turn of countenance mean?”
“我在想，先生（你会原谅这个想法的，它自己冒出来的），我在想赫尔克里士和参孙，以及他们的女人——” “I was thinking, sir (you will excuse the idea; it was involuntary), I was thinking of Hercules and Samson with their charmers—”
“你这么想，你这个小顽皮——” “You were, you little elfish—”
“嘘，先生！你刚刚说话不太明智，就像那些绅士们的行为有失明智一样。但是，如果他们结了婚，他们无疑会以作为丈夫的一脸严肃，来弥补求婚时的那份柔情。恐怕你也会这样的。我在想一年之后，如果我向你提出什么你不太方便办到或是不太乐意办的请求，你会如何回答我呢。” “Hush, sir!You don’t talk very wisely just now; any more than those gentlemen acted very wisely.However, had they been married, they would no doubt by their severity as husbands have made up for their softness as suitors; and so will you, I fear.I wonder how you will answer me a year hence, should I ask a favour it does not suit your convenience or pleasure to grant.”
“现在就说一件吧，简——最小的事：我希望你能求我——” “Ask me something now, Jane,—the least thing: I desire to be entreated—”
“我确实要说，我已经想好了一个请求。” “Indeed I will, sir; I have my petition all ready.”
“说！“但如果你抬起头来用那种神情对我一笑，而我还不知道什么意思就一口答应，那就把我弄成傻子了。” “Speak!But if you look up and smile with that countenance, I shall swear concession before I know to what, and that will make a fool of me.”
“绝不会，先生。我只要求一件事：不要送珠宝来，也不要给我戴上玫瑰：你还不如给你那条简单朴素的手绢镶上一条金丝花边呢。” “Not at all, sir; I ask only this: don’t send for the jewels, and don’t crown me with roses: you might as well put a border of gold lace round that plain pocket handkerchief you have there.”
“我还不如‘给纯金镀金’，我知道。你的请求被满足了——目前。我会撤回发给银行代理人的命令。但你还没要什么呢，你只是请求我收回礼物。再试试看。” “I might as well ‘gild refined gold.’I know it: you request is granted then—for the time.I will remand the order I despatched to my banker.But you have not yet asked for anything; you have prayed a gift to be withdrawn: try again.”
“那么，先生，请好心满足下我的好奇心吧，有个问题我很好奇。” “Well then, sir, have the goodness to gratify my curiosity, which is much piqued on one point.”
他看起来很慌乱。“什么？什么？”他匆匆地说。“好奇心是个危险的请求，还好我没发誓答应所有请求——” He looked disturbed.“What? what?” he said hastily.“Curiosity is a dangerous petition: it is well I have not taken a vow to accord every request—”
“但是答应这件事没有危险，先生。” “But there can be no danger in complying with this, sir.”
“说吧，简。不过我希望你想要的是我一半的财产，而不是想打听什么，或许，一个秘密。” “Utter it, Jane: but I wish that instead of a mere inquiry into, perhaps, a secret, it was a wish for half my estate.”
“得啦，亚哈随鲁王！我要你的一半财产干什么？你以为我是犹太高利贷者，想买地产投资啊？那我宁可得到的是你全部的信任。如果你心里有我，就不会对我隐瞒什么吧？” “Now, King Ahasuerus!What do I want with half your estate?Do you think I am a Jew-usurer, seeking good investment in land?I would much rather have all your confidence.You will not exclude me from your confidence if you admit me to your heart?”
“欢迎你知道所有我值得保有的秘密，简。但是，看在上帝的份上，别想背上这没用的负担！不要渴望毒药——不要变成我手中彻底的夏娃！” “You are welcome to all my confidence that is worth having, Jane; but for God’s sake, don’t desire a useless burden!Don’t long for poison—don’t turn out a downright Eve on my hands!”
“为什么不呢，先生？你刚刚告诉我你多么喜欢被征服，被说服是多么愉快。你不觉得我最好利用你的表白，开始哄你、求你——必要的话甚至哭啼、生气——就为了尝试一下我的权力？” “Why not, sir?You have just been telling me how much you liked to be conquered, and how pleasant over-persuasion is to you.Don’t you think I had better take advantage of the confession, and begin and coax and entreat—even cry and be sulky if necessary—for the sake of a mere essay of my power?”
“我打赌你不敢做这种实验。步步紧逼、擅自行为，那么游戏就结束了。” “I dare you to any such experiment.Encroach, presume, and the game is up.”
“是吗，先生？你这么快就认输了。你现在看起来多么严厉啊！你的眉头都和我的手指一样粗了，你的额头，就像我看过的什么惊人的诗中写的，‘乌云密布的雷声阁楼。’你婚后就会这副样子吧，先生，我猜？” “Is it, sir?You soon give in.How stern you look now!Your eyebrows have become as thick as my finger, and your forehead resembles what, in some very astonishing poetry, I once saw styled, ‘a blue-piled thunderloft.’That will be your married look, sir, I suppose?”
“如果你婚后也是这副样子，我，作为一名基督徒，将立即打消与你这个小妖精或火蛇共度一生的念头。不过，小东西——你到底想问出什么来？” “If that will be YOUR married look, I, as a Christian, will soon give up the notion of consorting with a mere sprite or salamander.But what had you to ask, thing,—out with it?”
“瞧，你现在连礼貌都没有了。不过比起奉承来我更喜欢鲁莽。我宁愿做个小东西也当什么天使。这就是我要问的——你为什么费尽心机让我相信你要娶英格拉姆小姐？” “There, you are less than civil now; and I like rudeness a great deal better than flattery.I had rather be a THING than an angel.This is what I have to ask,—Why did you take such pains to make me believe you wished to marry Miss Ingram?”
“就这个？谢天谢地，没有更糟！”现在他舒展开了阴郁的眉头，低头对我微笑，轻抚我的头发，仿佛是避开了什么危险，高兴不已。“我想我还是坦白吧，”他继续道，“即使我可能会让你有点生气，简——你生气时那烈火般的情绪我已经见识过了。昨晚清冷的月光下，你奋起反抗命运，声称和我平等的时候，脸都红得发亮。珍妮特，顺便说一下，这可是你让我说的。” “Is that all?Thank God it is no worse!”And now he unknit his black brows; looked down, smiling at me, and stroked my hair, as if well pleased at seeing a danger averted.“I think I may confess,” he continued, “even although I should make you a little indignant, Jane—and I have seen what a fire-spirit you can be when you are indignant.You glowed in the cool moonlight last night, when you mutinied against fate, and claimed your rank as my equal.Janet, by-the-bye, it was you who made me the offer.”
“当然了。但请讲正题吧，先生——英格拉姆小姐？” “Of course I did.But to the point if you please, sir—Miss Ingram?”
“好吧，我假装追求英格拉姆小姐，因为我希望你疯狂地爱上我，正如我爱你一样。而我知道妒忌是帮我达到目的的最好帮手。” “Well, I feigned courtship of Miss Ingram, because I wished to render you as madly in love with me as I was with you; and I knew jealousy would be the best ally I could call in for the furtherance of that end.”
“好极了！你在你可渺小了——比我的小指尖大不了多少。那么做真是太可耻，太丢脸了。你没有想到过英格拉姆小姐的感受吗，先生？” “Excellent!Now you are small—not one whit bigger than the end of my little finger.It was a burning shame and a scandalous disgrace to act in that way.Did you think nothing of Miss Ingram’s feelings, sir?”
“她的感情只集中于一点——骄傲。需要压一压她的锐气。你妒忌了吗，简？” “Her feelings are concentrated in one—pride; and that needs humbling.Were you jealous, Jane?”
“别管了，罗切斯特先生，你现在没有兴趣知道这个。再认真回答我一次。你不认为英格拉姆小姐不会因你不诚实的玩弄而痛苦吗？她不会感到被遗弃、被抛弃吗？ “Never mind, Mr. Rochester: it is in no way interesting to you to know that.Answer me truly once more.Do you think Miss Ingram will not suffer from your dishonest coquetry?Won’t she feel forsaken and deserted?”
“不可能！——我告诉你，相反，是她抛弃了我。一想到我破产，她的热情立即就冷却了，或者说熄灭了。” “Impossible!—when I told you how she, on the contrary, deserted me: the idea of my insolvency cooled, or rather extinguished, her flame in a moment.”
“罗切斯特先生，你可真古怪，真有心计。恐怕你对某些事情的原则有悖常理。” “You have a curious, designing mind, Mr. Rochester.I am afraid your principles on some points are eccentric.”
“我的原则从未受过训练，简。可能会由于疏于管理而出点偏差。” “My principles were never trained, Jane: they may have grown a little awry for want of attention.”
“再问一遍，认真地，我可以享受你赐予我的巨大幸福，而不必担心会有别人承受我刚刚经历过的痛苦吗？” “Once again, seriously; may I enjoy the great good that has been vouchsafed to me, without fearing that any one else is suffering the bitter pain I myself felt a while ago?”
“你当然可以，我善良的小姑娘，除你之外，世上没有人对我怀有如此纯洁的爱了——我把这安慰人的药膏，简，把对你爱情的信赖，涂在我心坎。” “That you may, my good little girl: there is not another being in the world has the same pure love for me as yourself—for I lay that pleasant unction to my soul, Jane, a belief in your affection.”
我转过头，将嘴唇贴上那只搭在我肩上的手。我爱他如此之深——深到自己都不相信能说出口——深到言辞都无力表达。 I turned my lips to the hand that lay on my shoulder.I loved him very much—more than I could trust myself to say—more than words had power to express.
“再提点要求吧，”他马上说，“被人请求，然后答应请求，这对我来说真是愉快。” “Ask something more,” he said presently; “it is my delight to be entreated, and to yield.”
我又准备好了一个请求。“把你的打算告诉费尔法克斯太太，先生。她昨晚看见我和你在大厅里，很吃惊。在我再见她之前给他解释解释吧。被这么善良的人误解，让我很痛苦。” I was again ready with my request.“Communicate your intentions to Mrs. Fairfax, sir: she saw me with you last night in the hall, and she was shocked.Give her some explanation before I see her again.It pains me to be misjudged by so good a woman.”
“去你房间，戴上你的帽子。”他答道。“我要你今天上午和我去米尔科特。趁你去准备，我去跟老太太讲清楚。珍妮特，是不是她认为你为爱放弃一切，很不值得？” “Go to your room, and put on your bonnet,” he replied.“I mean you to accompany me to Millcote this morning; and while you prepare for the drive, I will enlighten the old lady’s understanding.Did she think, Janet, you had given the world for love, and considered it well lost?”
“我想她是认为我忘记了自己的地位，还有你的，先生。” “I believe she thought I had forgotten my station, and yours, sir.”
“地位！地位！——你的地位在我心里，在那些想冒犯你的人的头上，现在和将来都如此。——去吧。” “Station! station!—your station is in my heart, and on the necks of those who would insult you, now or hereafter.—Go.”
我很快穿好衣服，听见罗切斯特先生出了费尔法克斯太太房间，就赶紧下楼去那里。老太太正在读早晨的经文——那天的功课。圣经在她面前摊开，上面搁着她的眼镜。罗切斯特先生的宣告打断了她的活计，此刻似乎已被忘掉。她的眼睛盯着对面空荡荡的墙壁，流露出平静的心灵被不寻常的消息扰乱的惊异。看见我，她回过神来，努力想对我笑笑，说几句祝贺的话。可那笑容却不见了，话也没能说完。她戴上眼镜，合上圣经，把椅子从桌边退开。 I was soon dressed; and when I heard Mr. Rochester quit Mrs. Fairfax’s parlour, I hurried down to it.The old lady, had been reading her morning portion of Scripture—the Lesson for the day; her Bible lay open before her, and her spectacles were upon it.Her occupation, suspended by Mr. Rochester’s announcement, seemed now forgotten: her eyes, fixed on the blank wall opposite, expressed the surprise of a quiet mind stirred by unwonted tidings.Seeing me, she roused herself: she made a sort of effort to smile, and framed a few words of congratulation; but the smile expired, and the sentence was abandoned unfinished.She put up her spectacles, shut the Bible, and pushed her chair back from the table.
“我太震惊了，”她开始说，“我真不知道该跟你说什么好，爱小姐。我肯定没在做梦吧，是吗？我有时独自坐着想些从未发生过的事情，就会迷糊睡着。就像我不止一次在打盹的时候，我那死去十五年的丈夫，进来坐在我身边，我甚至听到他和以前一样叫我的名字，艾丽斯。现在，你能不能告诉我，罗切斯特先生是不是确实要你嫁给他？不要笑话我。但我确实觉得他五分钟前来这儿，说一个月后你就会成为他妻子。” “I feel so astonished,” she began, “I hardly know what to say to you, Miss Eyre.I have surely not been dreaming, have I?Sometimes I half fall asleep when I am sitting alone and fancy things that have never happened.It has seemed to me more than once when I have been in a doze, that my dear husband, who died fifteen years since, has come in and sat down beside me; and that I have even heard him call me by my name, Alice, as he used to do.Now, can you tell me whether it is actually true that Mr. Rochester has asked you to marry him?Don’t laugh at me.But I really thought he came in here five minutes ago, and said that in a month you would be his wife.”
“他对我说了同样的话”，我答道。 “He has said the same thing to me,” I replied.
“他真说了！你相信他吗？你答应他了吗？” “He has!Do you believe him?Have you accepted him?”
“答应了。” “Yes.”
她一脸困惑地看着我。“我真没想到。他是个骄傲的人：罗切斯特家的人都很骄傲。而且他的父亲，至少，很贪财。他，也总是被说很小气。他打算娶你吗？” She looked at me bewildered.“I could never have thought it.He is a proud man: all the Rochesters were proud: and his father, at least, liked money.He, too, has always been called careful.He means to marry you?”
“他是这么跟我说的。” “He tells me so.”
她把我整个审视一番：从她的目光可以看出，那双眼睛并没在我身上发现足够的魅力来揭开这个谜。 She surveyed my whole person: in her eyes I read that they had there found no charm powerful enough to solve the enigma.
“我不明白！”她又道。“但是既然你这么说了，无疑是真的了。结局会如何，我说不准。我真的不知道。这种事情上，地位和财富的平等通常才是可取的，而且你们年龄相差了二十岁。他几乎可以做你的父亲了。” “It passes me!” she continued; “but no doubt, it is true since you say so.How it will answer, I cannot tell: I really don’t know.Equality of position and fortune is often advisable in such cases; and there are twenty years of difference in your ages.He might almost be your father.”
“不，真的，费尔法克斯太太！”我有点恼了，“他一点也不像我父亲！无论谁见到我们在一起都不会有一丁点这种想法的。罗切斯特先生看起来很年轻，和那些二十五岁的男人一样年轻。” “No, indeed, Mrs. Fairfax!” exclaimed I, nettled; “he is nothing like my father!No one, who saw us together, would suppose it for an instant.Mr. Rochester looks as young, and is as young, as some men at five-and-twenty.”
“他真的是处于爱而要娶你吗？”她问。 “Is it really for love he is going to marry you?” she asked.
我被她的冷酷和怀疑刺痛，泪水从眼里涌起。 I was so hurt by her coldness and scepticism, that the tears rose to my eyes.
“对不起，我让你伤心了，”寡妇接着说，“但是你这么年轻，对男人这么不了解，我希望能让你警惕些。老话说‘发光的不一定都是金子’。这件事上，我的确担心会发生什么你我都预料不到的事。” “I am sorry to grieve you,” pursued the widow; “but you are so young, and so little acquainted with men, I wished to put you on your guard.It is an old saying that ‘all is not gold that glitters;’ and in this case I do fear there will be something found to be different to what either you or I expect.”
“为什么？——我是怪物吗？”我说：“难道罗切斯特先生不可能对我产生真爱吗？” “Why?—am I a monster?”I said: “is it impossible that Mr. Rochester should have a sincere affection for me?”
“不，你很好，而且近来还大有长进。而且罗切斯特先生，我敢说，也喜欢你。我注意了很长时间，你很受他的宠爱。有时候，为你着想，看到他明显很喜欢你，感到有些担心，想帮你提防些。但即使有什么出错的可能，我也不愿提及。我知道这种说法可能吓到你，或者冒犯你。而你如此谨慎，如此谦虚，如此敏感，我希望你能够保护自己。昨晚我找遍了整个宅子，哪儿都不着你，主人也不见了。然后十二点时，看到你和他进来，那时我的难受真是没法言说。” “No: you are very well; and much improved of late; and Mr. Rochester, I daresay, is fond of you.I have always noticed that you were a sort of pet of his.There are times when, for your sake, I have been a little uneasy at his marked preference, and have wished to put you on your guard: but I did not like to suggest even the possibility of wrong.I knew such an idea would shock, perhaps offend you; and you were so discreet, and so thoroughly modest and sensible, I hoped you might be trusted to protect yourself.Last night I cannot tell you what I suffered when I sought all over the house, and could find you nowhere, nor the master either; and then, at twelve o’clock, saw you come in with him.”
“好啦，现在不要紧了，”我不耐烦地打断她。“一切都好就足够了。” “Well, never mind that now,” I interrupted impatiently; “it is enough that all was right.”
“我希望到头来一切都好，”她说：“但相信我，你还是小心为好。试着和罗切斯特先生保持距离，别相信你自己，也别相信他。处在他这种地位的绅士们通常是不会娶家庭教师为妻的。“ “I hope all will be right in the end,” she said: “but believe me, you cannot be too careful.“To put Adele to bed: it is past her bedtime.”Gentlemen in his station are not accustomed to marry their governesses.”
我真的开始生气了。还好，阿德拉跑了进来。 I was growing truly irritated: happily, Adele ran in.
“让我去吧——让我也去米尔科特吧！”她叫道。“罗切斯特先生不让我去，可是马车里还有那么大地方呢。小姐，求求他让我去吧。” “Let me go,—let me go to Millcote too!” she cried.“Mr. Rochester won’t: though there is so much room in the new carriage.Beg him to let me go mademoiselle.”
“我会的，阿德拉。”我赶紧跟她走了，很高兴离开我那令人沮丧的告诫者。马车已经备好，被拉到正门口。我的主人在小路上，派洛特跟着他跑前跑后。 “That I will, Adele;” and I hastened away with her, glad to quit my gloomy monitress.The carriage was ready: they were bringing it round to the front, and my master was the pavement, Pilot following him backwards and forwards.
“阿德拉可以和我们一起去吗，先生？” “Adele may accompany us, may she not, sir?”
“我告诉她了不行。我不要这小家伙。——我只要你。” “I told her no.I’ll have no brats!—I’ll have only you.”
“请让她去吧，罗切斯特先生，这样更好些。” “Do let her go, Mr. Rochester, if you please: it would be better.”
“好什么好，她只会碍事。” “Not it: she will be a restraint.”
他真专横，神色语气都是。费尔法克斯太太的警告让我寒心，她的疑虑也让我沮丧。某些虚幻、不确定的东西困扰了我的希望。我对他的一半信心都丧失了。正要机械地服从他，不再抗议。但他在扶我上车时看了看我的脸。 He was quite peremptory, both in look and voice.The chill of Mrs. Fairfax’s warnings, and the damp of her doubts were upon me: something of unsubstantiality and uncertainty had beset my hopes.I half lost the sense of power over him.I was about mechanically to obey him, without further remonstrance; but as he helped me into the carriage, he looked at my face.
“怎么了？”他问。“阳光全没啦。你真想让那小家伙去？不让她去你就会生气？” “What is the matter?” he asked; “all the sunshine is gone.Do you really wish the bairn to go?Will it annoy you if she is left behind?”
“我非常想让她去，先生。” “I would far rather she went, sir.”
“那就去拿你的帽子吧，快点儿，像闪电一样！”他对阿德拉大叫。 “Then off for your bonnet, and back like a flash of lightning!”cried he to Adele.
她飞速地执行命令。 She obeyed him with what speed she might.
“毕竟，一早晨的打扰也没什么大碍，”他说，“反正我很快就要把你——你的思想，你的言谈，你的陪伴——全部要过来，占有一辈子。” “After all, a single morning’s interruption will not matter much,” said he, “when I mean shortly to claim you—your thoughts, conversation, and company—for life.”
阿德拉被抱上车后，就开始亲我，以表示对我替她说情的感激。但很快就被塞到他那边的角落里了。于是她就朝我这边偷看。身边坐着这位严厉的大人让她很不自在。看他那副烦躁的样子，她也不敢多说多看，更不敢问他什么。 Adele, when lifted in, commenced kissing me, by way of expressing her gratitude for my intercession: she was instantly stowed away into a corner on the other side of him.She then peeped round to where I sat; so stern a neighbour was too restrictive to him, in his present fractious mood, she dared whisper no observations, nor ask of him any information.
“让她坐我这边吧，”我央求道，“她可能会让你烦心，先生。我这边有很大地方。” “Let her come to me,” I entreated: “she will, perhaps, trouble you, sir: there is plenty of room on this side.”
他把她像哈巴狗一样递了过来。“我还是要送她去上学。”他说。不过此时是笑着的。 He handed her over as if she had been a lapdog.“I’ll send her to school yet,” he said, but now he was smiling.
阿德拉听到了，就问是不是她去上学“不带小姐？” Adele heard him, and asked if she was to go to school “sans mademoiselle?”
“是的，”他答道，“当然不带小姐。因为我要带小姐去月亮上，我要在白色的火山谷找一个山洞，小姐会和我住在那儿，和我一个人。” “Yes,” he replied, “absolutely sans mademoiselle; for I am to take mademoiselle to the moon, and there I shall seek a cave in one of the white valleys among the volcano-tops, and mademoiselle shall live with me there, and only me.”
“她会没有东西吃的，你会饿死她的。”阿德拉说。 “She will have nothing to eat: you will starve her,” observed Adele.
“我会早晚为她采取吗哪的，月亮上的平原和山坡上都长满了吗哪，阿德拉。” “I shall gather manna for her morning and night: the plains and hillsides in the moon are bleached with manna, Adele.”
“她还要取暖，她拿什么生火呢？” “She will want to warm herself: what will she do for a fire?”
“月亮上的山会喷火，当她冷了，我就把她抱到山顶，放在火山口旁边。” “Fire rises out of the lunar mountains: when she is cold, I’ll carry her up to a peak, and lay her down on the edge of a crater.”
“噢，那地方多糟——多不舒服啊！再说她的衣服，穿破了呢，她怎么弄到新衣服？” “Oh, qu’ elle y sera mal—peu comfortable!And her clothes, they will wear out: how can she get new ones?”
罗切斯特先生承认被难住了。“哼！”他道。“你会怎么办，阿德拉？敲敲你的脑筋，想个办法。用一片白色或粉色的云当作袍子，你认为呢？或者剪一块彩虹做围巾也够漂亮的。” Mr. Rochester professed to be puzzled.“Hem!” said he.“What would you do, Adele?Cudgel your brains for an expedient.How would a white or a pink cloud answer for a gown, do you think?And one could cut a pretty enough scarf out of a rainbow.”
“那她现在这样更好些，”阿德拉想了一会儿得出结论。“而且，只和你一个人住在月亮上，她厌烦的。如果我是小姐，我绝不会答应跟你走。” “She is far better as she is,” concluded Adele, after musing some time: “besides, she would get tired of living with only you in the moon.If I were mademoiselle, I would never consent to go with you.”
“她已经答应了，还发了誓呢。” “She has consented: she has pledged her word.”
“但你把她带不过去啊，到月亮上去又没有路，只有空气，而你和她都不会飞。” “But you can’t get her there; there is no road to the moon: it is all air; and neither you nor she can fly.”
“阿德拉，看那片田野。”我们这时已经出了桑菲尔德大门，正沿着平坦的大道向米尔科特驶去。雷雨过后，路上的尘土都被冲走了，路旁的矮的树篱，高的树木，都闪着绿光，透出雨后的清新。 “Adele, look at that field.”We were now outside Thorn field gates, and bowling lightly along the smooth road to Millcote, where the dust was well laid by the thunderstorm, and, where the low hedges and lofty timber trees on each side glistened green and rain refreshed.
“就那块田地，阿德拉，大概两周前的一个傍晚，我在那儿散步到很晚——就是你帮我在果园草地上收干草的那天。耙地累了，就坐在阶梯上休息。我拿出一个小本，一支铅笔，开始记下很久以前降临在我身上的不幸，希望幸福的日子能够来临。我写得很快，尽管日光正从树叶上消失。正在那时，有个东西从小路上走来，站在离我两码远的地方。我看看它。那是个头戴蛛丝面纱的小东西。我点头让它走近些，它很快站到了我膝边。我没有跟它说话，它也没跟我说话。但我读懂了它的眼神，它也读懂了我的。我们无声的交谈是这个意思—— “In that field, Adele, I was walking late one evening about a fortnight since—the evening of the day you helped me to make hay in the orchard meadows; and, as I was tired with raking swaths, I sat down to rest me on a stile;and there I took out a little book and a pencil, and began to write about a misfortune that befell me long ago, and a wish I had for happy days to come: I was writing away very fast, though daylight was fading from the leaf, when something came up the path and stopped two yards off me.I looked at it.It was a little thing with a veil of gossamer on its head.I beckoned it to come near me; it stood soon at my knee.I never spoke to it, and it never spoke to me, in words; but I read its eyes, and it read mine; and our speechless colloquy was to this effect—
“它是个仙女，从精灵仙境而来。它的使命就是令我幸福。我必须和它离开尘世，到一个偏僻的地方去——比如说月亮这种地方——它还朝干草山上升起的月牙儿点头，说我们可以住在雪花般的山洞或银色的山谷里。我说我愿意去，但提醒它，就像你说的，我没有用来飞的翅膀。 “It was a fairy, and come from Elf-land, it said; and its errand was to make me happy: I must go with it out of the common world to a lonely place—such as the moon, for instance—and it nodded its head towards her horn, rising over Hay-hill: it told me of the alabaster cave and silver vale where we might live.I said I should like to go; but reminded it, as you did me, that I had no wings to fly.
“‘噢，’仙女回答说，‘那没关系！给你一个护身符，可以排除万难。’她拿出一枚漂亮的金戒指。‘戴上，’她说，‘戴在我左手第四根指头上，我就属于你了，你也属于我了。我们要离开地球，去远方创造我们自己的天堂。’那戒指，阿德拉，就在我的裤兜里，化装成一枚金币。但我很快就要把它重新变成一枚戒指。” “‘Oh,’ returned the fairy, ‘that does not signify!Here is a talisman will remove all difficulties;’ and she held out a pretty gold ring.‘Put it,’ she said, ‘on the fourth finger of my left hand, and I am yours, and you are mine; and we shall leave earth, and make our own heaven yonder.’She nodded again at the moon.The ring, Adele, is in my breeches-pocket, under the disguise of a sovereign: but I mean soon to change it to a ring again.”
“但它和小姐有什么关系？我不在乎什么仙女，你说的是你要带小姐到月亮上去？” “But what has mademoiselle to do with it?I don’t care for the fairy: you said it was mademoiselle you would take to the moon?”
“小姐就是个仙女，”他神秘地低语道。于是我告诉她不要听他开玩笑。而她则表现出了地道的法国式怀疑。把罗切斯特先生称为“真正的说谎者”，并声明她根本不相信他的“仙女的故事”，而且“根本就没有仙女，就算有的话”，她断定她们也绝不会在他面前出现，绝也不会给他戒指，或者愿意跟他去月亮上住。 “Mademoiselle is a fairy,” he said, whispering mysteriously.Whereupon I told her not to mind his badinage; and she, on her part, evinced a fund of genuine French scepticism:denominating Mr. Rochester “un vrai menteur,” and assuring him that she made no account whatever of his “contes de fee,” and that “du reste, il n’y avait pas de fees, et quand meme il y en avait:” she was sure they would never appear to him, nor ever give him rings, or offer to live with him in the moon.
在米尔科特度过的时光真有点恼人。罗切斯特先生非要我去一家绸缎店，命令我挑半打衣料。我讨厌这差事，就求他再推迟些，不行——现在就得办。我再三地恳求，才把半打减为两块，但他执意要亲自挑选。我焦急地看他的目光徘徊于那些艳丽的商品：他挑中了一块极为鲜艳的的紫晶色丝绸，还有一块华丽的粉红色缎子。我又低声告诉他，还不如给我买件金袍子，一定银帽子呢。我绝不敢穿他挑中的料子。他如石头般顽固，好不容易才说服他换了一块素净的黑色缎子和一块珍珠灰的丝绸。“暂时能凑合，”他说，“但他还是要看我像鲜花一样闪亮。”我很高兴把他拉出绸缎店，又拽出珠宝店。他给我买的越多，我的脸越是发烧，感到恼火，觉得受辱。我们再次钻进马车，我靠在座位上，浑身发热，疲惫不堪。这才想起，在这一连串发生的好事坏事中，我竟完全忘记了——那封我的叔叔，约翰·爱，写给里德夫人的信，以及他想收养我，让我做他合法继承人的意愿。“那倒真是，一种宽慰，”我想，“如果我有一小点独立财产，我就不会让罗切斯特先生把我当作玩偶来打扮，或者跟第二个达娜厄似的，整天坐在那儿，任由金雨淋满全身。我一回家就要往马德拉写信，告诉约翰叔叔我要结婚了，而且嫁的人，如果有一天能给罗切斯特先生增加点财产，现在也好忍受一直由他养着。”这念头多少让我多少放松了些（这事那天没办成），我才敢再次迎合我那主人及情人的目光。虽然我总是回避他的面孔和目光，但他的眼睛总执拗地搜寻我的目光。他笑了，我觉得他的笑就像苏丹王，一时欢喜温柔，便向得到了黄金宝石赏赐的奴隶赐予一笑。他的手总是在搜寻我的手，我紧握一下，又用力推回去，那手都被我的激情握红了。 The hour spent at Millcote was a somewhat harassing one to me.Mr. Rochester obliged me to go to a certain silk warehouse: there I was ordered to choose half-a-dozen dresses.I hated the business, I begged leave to defer it: no—it should be gone through with now.By dint of entreaties expressed in energetic whispers, I reduced the half-dozen to two: these however, he vowed he would select himself.With anxiety I watched his eye rove over the gay stores: he fixed on a rich silk of the most brilliant amethyst dye, and a superb pink satin.I told him in a new series of whispers, that he might as well buy me a gold gown and a silver bonnet at once: I should certainly never venture to wear his choice.With infinite difficulty, for he was stubborn as a stone, I persuaded him to make an exchange in favour of a sober black satin and pearl-grey silk.“It might pass for the present,” he said; “but he would yet see me glittering like a parterre.”Glad was I to get him out of the silk warehouse, and then out of a jewellers shop: the more he bought me, the more my cheek burned with a sense of annoyance and degradation.As we re-entered the carriage, and I sat back feverish and fagged, I remembered what, in the hurry of events, dark and bright, I had wholly forgotten—the letter of my uncle, John Eyre, to Mrs. Reed: his intention to adopt me and make me his legatee.“It would, indeed, be a relief,” I thought, “if I had ever so small an independency; I never can bear being dressed like a doll by Mr. Rochester, or sitting like a second Danae with the golden shower falling daily round me.I will write to Madeira the moment I get home, and tell my uncle John I am going to be married, and to whom: if I had but a prospect of one day bringing Mr. Rochester an accession of fortune, I could better endure to be kept by him now.”And somewhat relieved by this idea (which I failed not to execute that day), I ventured once more to meet my master’s and lover’s eye, which most pertinaciously sought mine, though I averted both face and gaze.He smiled; and I thought his smile was such as a sultan might, in a blissful and fond moment, bestow on a slave his gold and gems had enriched: I crushed his hand, which was ever hunting mine, vigorously, and thrust it back to him red with the passionate pressure.
“你不必这副样子，”我说，“再这样，我就一直穿我洛伍德的旧衣裳。我就穿这件淡紫色的条纹布结婚，你可以那那块珍珠灰的丝绸做晨衣，那块黑缎子也可以做无数的背心。” “You need not look in that way,” I said; “if you do, I’ll wear nothing but my old Lowood frocks to the end of the chapter.I’ll be married in this lilac gingham: you may make a dressing-gown for yourself out of the pearl-grey silk, and an infinite series of waistcoats out of the black satin.”
他咯咯笑了，搓搓双手。“噢，看她说话就足够了！”他叫道。我可不愿拿这个英国小姑娘去换土耳其后宫的所有嫔妃，她们羚羊般的眼睛，女神的身材，所有的一切！” He chuckled; he rubbed his hands.“Oh, it is rich to see and hear her?” he exclaimed.“Is she original?Is she piquant?I would not exchange this one little English girl for the Grand Turk’s whole seraglio, gazelle-eyes, houri forms, and all!”
这东方的引喻又伤了我。“我可一点儿也替代不了你的嫔妃，”我说，“所以不要把我当作那种人。如果你迷恋那种人，先生，你就赶快去斯坦布尔的集市上去吧，把你手头看似在这儿不知怎么花的闲钱，全拿去买一帮奴隶吧。” The Eastern allusion bit me again.“I’ll not stand you an inch in the stead of a seraglio,” I said; “so don’t consider me an equivalent for one.If you have a fancy for anything in that line, away with you, sir, to the bazaars of Stamboul without delay, and lay out in extensive slave-purchases some of that spare cash you seem at a loss to spend satisfactorily here.”
“珍妮特，我为买下这么多人，这么多种类黑眼睛而讨价还价的时候，你要干什么呢？” “And what will you do, Janet, while I am bargaining for so many tons of flesh and such an assortment of black eyes?”
“我将收拾行囊，出门做个传教士，向那些被你奴役的人，包括你那些后宫妻妾，宣讲自由。我要闯进后院，激起叛乱。而你，先生，就算是位三尾的显贵，也会瞬间发现自己已落入我们手心，被戴上枷锁。除非你签发一个专制君主所授予的最自由的宪章，我才会同意给你自由。” “I’ll be preparing myself to go out as a missionary to preach liberty to them that are enslaved—your harem inmates amongst the rest.I’ll get admitted there, and I’ll stir up mutiny; and you, three-tailed bashaw as you are, sir, shall in a trice find yourself fettered amongst our hands: nor will I, for one, consent to cut your bonds till you have signed a charter, the most liberal that despot ever yet conferred.”
“我会任你处置的、求你开恩，简。” “I would consent to be at your mercy, Jane.”
“我不会开恩，罗切斯特先生，如果你用这种眼神祈求我的话。看你这副样子，我就肯定，你不论被迫签订了什么宪章，只要你一被释放，你最先做的就是违反它的条款。” “I would have no mercy, Mr. Rochester, if you supplicated for it with an eye like that.While you looked so, I should be certain that whatever charter you might grant under coercion, your first act, when released, would be to violate its conditions.”
“哎呀，简，你想要什么？我怀疑除了圣坛面前的婚礼，你还想强迫我再私下进行什么结婚仪式吧？我知道，你要给我定一些特殊的规矩——是些什么呢？” “Why, Jane, what would you have?I fear you will compel me to go through a private marriage ceremony, besides that performed at the altar.You will stipulate, I see, for peculiar terms—what will they be?”
“我只要一颗平静的心，先生。不被满满的义务所压扁。你还记得你怎么说塞莉娜·瓦伦的吗？——你给她钻石、开司米毛料？我不会做你的英国塞莉娜·瓦伦。我要继续做阿德拉的老师，自己挣食宿费，还有一年三十英镑薪水。我会用那些钱添置自己的衣裳，你什么也不要给我，除了——” “I only want an easy mind, sir; not crushed by crowded obligations.Do you remember what you said of Celine Varens?—of the diamonds, the cashmeres you gave her?I will not be your English Celine Varens.I shall continue to act as Adele’s governess; by that I shall earn my board and lodging, and thirty pounds a year besides.I’ll furnish my own wardrobe out of that money, and you shall give me nothing but—”
“嗯，除了什么？” “Well, but what?”
“你的尊重。如果我也回报以尊重，那就互不相欠了。” “Your regard; and if I give you mine in return, that debt will be quit.”
“唉，天生的冷酷无礼，纯正的秉性骄傲，你可是无人能及。”他说。我们正驶近桑菲尔德。“今天和我同进晚餐好吗？”我们重返大门时他问道。 “Well, for cool native impudence and pure innate pride, you haven’t your equal,” said he.We were now approaching Thornfield.“Will it please you to dine with me today?” he asked, as we re-entered the gates.
“不，谢谢，先生。” “No, thank you, sir.”
“为什么说‘不，谢谢’，可以问问吗？” “And what for, ‘no, thank you?’ if one may inquire.”
“我从未与你共进晚餐过，先生。而且我现在也没看到有这样做的理由，直到——” “I never have dined with you, sir: and I see no reason why I should now: till—”
“直到什么？你总爱说半句话。” “Till what?You delight in half-phrases.”
“直到我不得已。” “Till I can’t help it.”
“你是以为我吃饭的样子像个食人魔，或是食尸鬼，所以害怕陪我就餐吗？” “Do you suppose I eat like an ogre or a ghoul, that you dread being the companion of my repast?”
“我没有对此产生猜想，先生。但我想像往常一样再过一个月。” “I have formed no supposition on the subject, sir; but I want to go on as usual for another month.”
“你要立即放弃你家庭教师的差事。” “You will give up your governessing slavery at once.”
“真的，请原谅，先生，我不能。我要像往常一样。我会整天不见你，正如已经习惯的一样。你想见我的话，可以晚上派人叫我，我会来的。但其他时间不可以。” “Indeed, begging your pardon, sir, I shall not.I shall just go on with it as usual.I shall keep out of your way all day, as I have been accustomed to do: you may send for me in the evening, when you feel disposed to see me, and I’ll come then; but at no other time.”
“我想抽支烟，简，或者吸一撮鼻烟来安慰自己，按阿德拉的说法，以‘让我定定神的名义’。可惜我没带雪茄盒，鼻烟壶也没带。不过听着——悄悄话。现在你一时得逞，小暴君。不过很快就轮到我了。我一旦牢牢抓住了你，为了拥有你，保住你，我就要——打个比方——把你栓到链子上，就像这样”（摸摸他的表链）。“对，漂亮的小东西，我要把你戴在胸前，免得丢了我的宝贝。” “I want a smoke, Jane, or a pinch of snuff, to comfort me under all this, ‘pour me donner une contenance,’ as Adele would say; and unfortunately I have neither my cigar-case, nor my snuff-box.But listen—whisper.It is your time now, little tyrant, but it will be mine presently; and when once I have fairly seized you, to have and to hold, I’ll just—figuratively speaking—attach you to a chain like this” (touching his watch-guard).“Yes, bonny wee thing, I’ll wear you in my bosom, lest my jewel I should tyne.”
他一边扶我下车，一边说着这些。当他抱阿德拉下来时，我已经进屋，自己上楼了。 He said this as he helped me to alight from the carriage, and while he afterwards lifted out Adele, I entered the house, and made good my retreat upstairs.
傍晚时，他按时叫我去见他。我已经为他想了个活儿，因为我决定不要把所有时间都花在面对面的交谈上。我记得他的好嗓子，知道他喜欢唱歌——好歌手一般都这样。我自己不是歌唱家，以他那种挑剔的眼光，连个乐手都算不上。但对于精彩的表演，我却很乐意倾听。当暮色低垂，窗格上开始出现一面面闪着星光的蓝色旗子，我就起身打开琴盖，求他看在老天的份上，为我唱首歌。他说我是个任性的巫婆，还说宁可以后再唱。但我断言没有比此刻更合适的了。 He duly summoned me to his presence in the evening.I had prepared an occupation for him; for I was determined not to spend the whole time in a tete-e-tete conversation.I remembered his fine voice; I knew he liked to sing—good singers generally do.I was no vocalist myself, and, in his fastidious judgment, no musician, either; but I delighted in listening when the performance was good.No sooner had twilight, that hour of romance, began to lower her blue and starry banner over the lattice, than I rose, opened the piano, and entreated him, for the love of heaven, to give me a song.He said I was a capricious witch, and that he would rather sing another time; but I averred that no time was like the present.
“我喜欢他的嗓音吗？”他问。 “Did I like his voice?” he asked.
“非常喜欢。”我并不喜欢纵容他那敏感的虚荣心。但仅此一次，且作权宜之计，我甚至迎合并激发他的虚荣心。 “Very much.”I was not fond of pampering that susceptible vanity of his; but for once, and from motives of expediency, I would e’en soothe and stimulate it.
“那好，简，但你必须伴奏。” “Then, Jane, you must play the accompaniment.”
“很好，先生，我试试。” “Very well, sir, I will try.”
我的确试了，但马上就被赶下凳子，还被叫做“小笨蛋”。把我无礼地推到一边——正合我意——他占据了我的位置，开始自己伴奏。他可以边弹边唱。我赶快坐到窗边休息处。当我坐在那儿，望向窗外静静地树林，朦胧的草坪，圆润的音色唱响，和着优美的旋律—— I did try, but was presently swept off the stool and denominated “a little bungler.”Being pushed unceremoniously to one side—which was precisely what I wished—he usurped my place, and proceeded to accompany himself: for he could play as well as sing.I hied me to the window-recess.And while I sat there and looked out on the still trees and dim lawn, to a sweet air was sung in mellow tones the following strain:—
“最真挚的爱从燃烧的心窝涌出，生命的热浪在每一根血管中欢快地激荡。 “The truest love that ever heart Felt at its kindled core, Did through each vein, in quickened start, The tide of being pour.
她的到来是我每天的希望，他的离去让我神伤。她偶尔的脚步延迟也使我血管冰凉。 Her coming was my hope each day, Her parting was my pain; The chance that did her steps delay Was ice in every vein.
我梦想过那是莫名的幸福，我爱别人，别人爱我。我朝这目标向前冲去，急切而盲目。 I dreamed it would be nameless bliss, As I loved, loved to be; And to this object did I press As blind as eagerly.
可是在我们两个生命之间，横亘着无路的宽广空间，如海潮绿色的波涛般危险。 But wide as pathless was the space That lay our lives between, And dangerous as the foamy race Of ocean-surges green.
犹如强盗出没的小路，穿过荒野或森林。力量和正义，悲伤和愤怒，把我们的心灵隔开。 And haunted as a robber-path Through wilderness or wood; For Might and Right, and Woe and Wrath, Between our spirits stood.
我不畏艰险，我蔑视困难。我反抗凶兆，不论何种威胁、骚扰、警告，我都不屑一顾。 I dangers dared; I hindrance scorned; I omens did defy: Whatever menaced, harassed, warned, I passed impetuous by.
我的彩虹闪电般疾驰，我仿佛在梦中飞翔。阵雨和骄阳之子，在我眼前光荣崛起。 On sped my rainbow, fast as light; I flew as in a dream; For glorious rose upon my sight That child of Shower and Gleam.
那温柔庄严的欢欣，仍旧照耀着灰暗苦难的云朵。我已毫不在乎，任凭灾难密集冷酷地逼近。 Still bright on clouds of suffering dim Shines that soft, solemn joy; Nor care I now, how dense and grim Disasters gather nigh.
在这甜蜜的时刻我已无所顾忌，虽然我曾冲破的一切险阻，再次迅猛袭击，声称要无情地报复。 I care not in this moment sweet, Though all I have rushed o’er Should come on pinion, strong and fleet, Proclaiming vengeance sore:
尽管高傲的憎恨会把我击倒，公理不容我上前。残暴的强权怒火中烧，发誓与我不同戴天。 Though haughty Hate should strike me down, Right, bar approach to me, And grinding Might, with furious frown, Swear endless enmity.
我的爱人将她的小手和那崇高的信赖一并给我，发誓让神圣的婚姻将我们紧系在一起。 My love has placed her little hand With noble faith in mine, And vowed that wedlock’s sacred band Our nature shall entwine.
我的爱人用永恒的一吻，发誓与我同生——同死。我最终得到了我莫名的幸福。因为我爱她，她也爱我！” My love has sworn, with sealing kiss, With me to live—to die; I have at last my nameless bliss.As I love—loved am I!”
他起身向我走来，我看见他脸庞发亮，圆圆的鹰一般的眼睛闪着光，一颦一笑都充满了温柔与热情。我一时感到胆怯——但马上又振作起来了。我不要柔情蜜意的场面，也不要大胆露骨的表示。但此时却面临这两种危险。必须准备好防患的武器——我磨尖了舌头，他一走到面前，我就厉声问，“他现在要跟谁结婚？” He rose and came towards me, and I saw his face all kindled, and his full falcon-eye flashing, and tenderness and passion in every lineament.I quailed momentarily—then I rallied.Soft scene, daring demonstration, I would not have; and I stood in peril of both: a weapon of defence must be prepared—I whetted my tongue: as he reached me, I asked with asperity, “whom he was going to marry now?”
“亲爱的简竟然问这么奇怪的问题。” “That was a strange question to be put by his darling Jane.”
“真的！我认为这是个很自然很必要的问题：他提到他和他未来的妻子一同死去。这种异教徒的念头是什么意思？我可不愿和他一起死——他尽可放心。” “Indeed!I considered it a very natural and necessary one: he had talked of his future wife dying with him.What did he mean by such a pagan idea?I had no intention of dying with him—he might depend on that.”
“噢，他所向往，所祈祷的一切，就是你和他一起活！死对你这种人可不合适。” “Oh, all he longed, all he prayed for, was that I might live with him!Death was not for such as I.”
“确实是合适的。时候一到，我和他一样有死的权利。但我需要耐心等待，而不是急急忙忙自焚殉夫。” “Indeed it was: I had as good a right to die when my time came as he had: but I should bide that time, and not be hurried away in a suttee.”
“你能否原谅他自私的念头，给一个表示和解的宽恕的吻呢？” “Would I forgive him for the selfish idea, and prove my pardon by a reconciling kiss?”
“不，我宁愿免了。” “No: I would rather be excused.”
此时我听自己被称道“铁石心肠的小东西”，还说“别的女人听到男人吟唱这种赞美她的诗歌，肯定连骨头都融化了。” Here I heard myself apostrophised as a “hard little thing;” and it was added, “any other woman would have been melted to marrow at hearing such stanzas crooned in her praise.”
我告诉他我天生心肠硬——硬如顽石。他以后会经常发现如此。而且，我决心在接下来的四周内，给他看我性格中的各种粗糙面。趁他还来得及取消婚约，彻底了解下自己做的是笔什么生意。 I assured him I was naturally hard—very flinty, and that he would often find me so; and that, moreover, I was determined to show him divers rugged points in my character before the ensuing four weeks elapsed: he should know fully what sort of a bargain he had made, while there was yet time to rescind it.
“你能心平气和，讲点道理吗？” “Would I be quiet and talk rationally?”
“如果你喜欢，我会心平气和。至于讲道理，我认为自己现在就很讲道理。” “I would be quiet if he liked, and as to talking rationally, I flattered myself I was doing that now.”
他焦躁起来，又呸又啐的。“很好”，我想，“你尽管愤怒烦躁吧，但我肯定，这是对付你的最佳手段。我喜欢你胜于可以言说的地步。但我不会陷入多愁善感的流俗，我要用这巧辩的锋芒，让你悬崖勒马。并且，凭着这尖锐的武器，也可以保持对双方都确有好处的距离。” He fretted, pished, and pshawed.“Very good,” I thought; “you may fume and fidget as you please: but this is the best plan to pursue with you, I am certain.I like you more than I can say; but I’ll not sink into a bathos of sentiment: and with this needle of repartee I’ll keep you from the edge of the gulf too; and, moreover, maintain by its pungent aid that distance between you and myself most conducive to our real mutual advantage.”
我得寸进尺，让他很是恼火。等他愤怒地退到房间另一边时，我起身说一句“祝你晚安，先生”，以自然和惯有的礼貌方式，从边门走了。 From less to more, I worked him up to considerable irritation; then, after he had retired, in dudgeon, quite to the other end of the room, I got up, and saying, “I wish you good-night, sir,” in my natural and wonted respectful manner, I slipped out by the side-door and got away.
这种方法开了头，就在整个考验期坚持了下来，而且大获全胜。当然，他被弄得恼怒不堪，但总体而言，我发现他还是非常愉快的。而绵羊般的温顺，斑鸠似的多情，只会助长他的专横，而不像现在这样取悦他的判断，满足他的常识，甚至投合他的趣味。 The system thus entered on, I pursued during the whole season of probation; and with the best success.He was kept, to be sure, rather cross and crusty; but on the whole I could see he was excellently entertained, and that a lamb-like submission and turtledove sensibility, while fostering his despotism more, would have pleased his judgment, satisfied his common-sense, and even suited his taste less.
在别人面前，我与以往一样，恭敬文雅，其他任何举动都不必要。只有在晚上谈话时，我才冲撞他，折磨他。他仍然在七点钟准时派人叫我。尽管现在我出现在他面前，他不再满嘴“亲爱的”，“宝贝儿”之类的甜蜜字眼。给我的最好称呼就是“令人恼火的木偶”，“恶毒的精灵”，“妖精”，“傻瓜”等等。替代爱抚的，则是鬼脸。不再紧握我的手，而是捏一下胳膊。不再亲吻脸颊，而是狠揪一下耳朵。这倒很好，现在宁愿要这种粗鲁的喜爱，也不要更温存的柔情。我发现费尔法克斯太太也赞同，她对我的忧虑消失了，因此我也确定自己做得没错。同时，罗切斯特先生则断言我把他折磨得皮包骨了，威胁说等那马上到来的时刻来临，就要对我现在的行为进行可怕的报复。对他的恫吓，我暗自发笑。“我现在可以让你受到合乎情理的约束”，我想，“以后也无疑能够做到。如果一个办法失效了，就必须想出另一个办法。” In other people’s presence I was, as formerly, deferential and quiet; any other line of conduct being uncalled for: it was only in the evening conferences I thus thwarted and afflicted him.He continued to send for me punctually the moment the clock struck seven; though when I appeared before him now, he had no such honeyed terms as “love” and “darling” on his lips: the best words at my service were “provoking puppet,” “malicious elf,” “sprite,” “changeling,” &c.For caresses, too, I now got grimaces; for a pressure of the hand, a pinch on the arm; for a kiss on the cheek, a severe tweak of the ear.It was all right: at present I decidedly preferred these fierce favours to anything more tender.Mrs. Fairfax, I saw, approved me: her anxiety on my account vanished; therefore I was certain I did well.Meantime, Mr. Rochester affirmed I was wearing him to skin and bone, and threatened awful vengeance for my present conduct at some period fast coming.I laughed in my sleeve at his menaces.“I can keep you in reasonable check now,” I reflected; “and I don’t doubt to be able to do it hereafter: if one expedient loses its virtue, another must be devised.”
但毕竟我的任务也并不轻松。我时常宁愿讨他欢心，也不愿戏弄他。我未来的丈夫正在变成我的整个世界。不仅是整个世界，他几乎是我进入天堂的希望。他站在我和一切宗教观念之间，犹如日蚀把人与明亮的太阳隔开。那些日子里，我看不见上帝，因为我已经把它的造物当成了崇拜的偶像。 Yet after all my task was not an easy one; often I would rather have pleased than teased him.My future husband was becoming to me my whole world; and more than the world: almost my hope of heaven.He stood between me and every thought of religion, as an eclipse intervenes between man and the broad sun.I could not, in those days, see God for His creature: of whom I had made an idol.
第二十五章 CHAPTER XXV
一个月的求婚期很快过去了，最后的几个小时也屈指可数。最后一天——婚礼之日如期到来。一切准备工作皆已就绪。至少我已无事可干。我的箱子已经装好、锁上、捆住，沿着我那小卧室的墙一字排开。明日此时，它们就将远行，踏上去往伦敦的道路，而我也一样（悉听神意），——准确地说不是我，而是简·罗切斯特，一位我尚不认识的人。地址标签还没钉上，那四张小方块纸还躺在抽屉里。罗切斯特先生亲自在每张标签写上地址：“罗切斯特太太，旅馆，伦敦”。我无法说服自己贴上它们，或者让别人把它们贴上。罗切斯特太太！她不存在，她得到明天才降临呢，明天上午八点以后。我只有确定她活生生来到这世上，才能把所有那些财产给她。那边梳妆台对面的的壁橱里，据说她的衣服已经代替了我在洛伍德的黑呢裙和草帽的位置，这已经足够了。那套结婚礼服不属于我，那珍珠色的长袍，薄雾般的面纱，从被占用的旅行箱上垂下。我关上壁橱的门，藏住里面那奇怪的、鬼魂般的服装。这些衣服在这夜晚时分——九点钟——穿透屋里的阴影，发出幽灵般的微光。“我要把你自己留在这儿，白色的梦。”我说。“我太兴奋了。我听到风在呼呼地吹，我要出去感受一下。” The month of courtship had wasted: its very last hours were being numbered.There was no putting off the day that advanced—the bridal day; and all preparations for its arrival were complete.I, at least, had nothing more to do: there were my trunks, packed, locked, corded, ranged in a row along the wall of my little chamber; tomorrow, at this time, they would be far on their road to London: and so should I (D.V.),—or rather, not I, but one Jane Rochester, a person whom as yet I knew not.The cards of address alone remained to nail on: they lay, four little squares, in the drawer.Mr. Rochester had himself written the direction, “Mrs. Rochester,—Hotel, London,” on each: I could not persuade myself to affix them, or to have them affixed.Mrs. Rochester! She did not exist: she would not be born till tomorrow, some time after eight o’clock a.m.; and I would wait to be assured she had come into the world alive before I assigned to her all that property.It was enough that in yonder closet, opposite my dressing-table, garments said to be hers had already displaced my black stuff Lowood frock and straw bonnet: for not to me appertained that suit of wedding raiment; the pearl-coloured robe, the vapoury veil pendent from the usurped portmanteau.I shut the closet to conceal the strange, wraith-like apparel it contained; which, at this evening hour—nine o’clock—gave out certainly a most ghostly shimmer through the shadow of my apartment.“I will leave you by yourself, white dream,” I said.“I am feverish: I hear the wind blowing: I will go out of doors and feel it.”
不仅是匆忙的准备令我兴奋，不仅是对巨变的期待——新生活明天就要开始——令我兴奋。无疑，这两者都在我这不安、激动的情绪中起了作用，而这种情绪则促使我这么晚还跑到愈发漆黑的院子里去。但比起这些，还有第三个原因对我影响更大。 It was not only the hurry of preparation that made me feverish; not only the anticipation of the great change—the new life which was to commence tomorrow: both these circumstances had their share, doubtless, in producing that restless, excited mood which hurried me forth at this late hour into the darkening grounds: but a third cause influenced my mind more than they.
我心中有个奇怪而焦虑的想法。发生了一件我难以理解的事，除我之外没人知道或见到。那件事发生在前一天晚上。罗切斯特先生那晚不在家，现在还没回来。他去了三十里外的小田产，处理两三座农庄的事务——他必须在按计划离开英国之前，亲自处理那些事务。我此时还在等他归来，急于卸下心头的负担，并让他帮我解开这困惑着我的谜团。等他回来，读者，等我把我的秘密告诉他，你也就知道了。 I had at heart a strange and anxious thought.Something had happened which I could not comprehend; no one knew of or had seen the event but myself: it had taken place the preceding night.Mr. Rochester that night was absent from home; nor was he yet returned: business had called him to a small estate of two or three farms he possessed thirty miles off—business it was requisite he should settle in person, previous to his meditated departure from England.I waited now his return; eager to disburthen my mind, and to seek of him the solution of the enigma that perplexed me.Stay till he comes, reader; and, when I disclose my secret to him, you shall share the confidence.
