我朝果园走去，想在那儿找个避风的地方。南风刮了一整天，却未曾带来半点雨星。夜色渐深，风非但没有减弱，反而刮得更猛，吼得更凶。树木被吹得倒向一边，根本转不回来，树枝一个小时也不能晃回来一次；枝叶繁茂的树冠统统向北弯着；云朵被吹得从南向北飘，一朵快速地紧跟着一朵，接连不断。那个七月里的日子里，见不到一线蓝天。 I sought the orchard, driven to its shelter by the wind, which all day had blown strong and full from the south, without, however, bringing a speck of rain.Instead of subsiding as night drew on, it seemed to augment its rush and deepen its roar: the trees blew steadfastly one way, never writhing round, and scarcely tossing back their boughs once in an hour; so continuous was the strain bending their branchy heads northward—the clouds drifted from pole to pole, fast following, mass on mass: no glimpse of blue sky had been visible that July day.
我乘风奔跑，将我的烦恼传递给空中怒吼的无尽气流，倒也不失为一种狂喜。沿着月桂小路下行，迎面看到栗树的残骸。它黑漆漆地立在那儿，被撕裂成两半，树干从中间裂开，恐怖地张着大嘴。裂开的两半并未完全分开，坚实的树基和强壮的根部使它们的底部仍然连在一起。然而生命的完整已被毁掉——树液再也无法流动，两边的大树枝都已死去，下个冬天的暴风雪肯定会将它们中一个或全都压倒在地。不过，它们仍可称作是一棵树——一棵死树，完整的死树。 It was not without a certain wild pleasure I ran before the wind, delivering my trouble of mind to the measureless air-torrent thundering through space.Descending the laurel walk, I faced the wreck of the chestnut-tree; it stood up black and riven: the trunk, split down the centre, gasped ghastly.The cloven halves were not broken from each other, for the firm base and strong roots kept them unsundered below;though community of vitality was destroyed—the sap could flow no more: their great boughs on each side were dead, and next winter’s tempests would be sure to fell one or both to earth: as yet, however, they might be said to form one tree—a ruin, but an entire ruin.
“你们互相坚守，这样很好。”我说，仿佛这两半巨大的碎片是活着的，还能听到我说话。“我想，尽管你们看起来损伤成这样，被烧黑烤焦，但肯定有一点生命的感觉存在，从你们固守着的那忠诚正直的树根部升起。你们不会再有绿叶，再也看不见鸟儿在你们的树枝上筑巢、歌唱。欢乐与爱的时光已经消逝，但你们并不孤寂。你们相互为伴，一同腐朽。”当我抬头看它们时，月亮瞬间出现在裂缝中间的那片天空，她的圆盘血红血红的，被遮去了一半。她好像向我投来迷惑、忧郁的一瞥，又立即把自己埋藏在深厚的流云里。桑菲尔德四周的风减弱了片刻，但远处的树林和水面上，却响起了一阵狂野、悲痛的哀号声，听起来令人难过，于是我就又跑掉了。 “You did right to hold fast to each other,” I said: as if the monster-splinters were living things, and could hear me.“I think, scathed as you look, and charred and scorched, there must be a little sense of life in you yet, rising out of that adhesion at the faithful, honest roots: you will never have green leaves more—never more see birds making nests and singing idyls in your boughs;the time of pleasure and love is over with you: but you are not desolate: each of you has a comrade to sympathise with him in his decay.”As I looked up at them, the moon appeared momentarily in that part of the sky which filled their fissure; her disk was bloodred and half overcast; she seemed to throw on me one bewildered, dreary glance, and buried herself again instantly in the deep drift of cloud.The wind fell, for a second, round Thornfield; but far away over wood and water, poured a wild, melancholy wail: it was sad to listen to, and I ran off again.
我在果园里穿来穿去，捡起树根周围草地上密密麻麻散布着的苹果，然后把成熟了的和未成熟的分开。我把它们抱回家，放进储藏室。然后我又去了藏书室，确定一下炉火是不是烧着。虽然是夏天，但我知道在这样阴沉的夜晚，罗切斯特先生进屋时还是希望看到令人愉快的炉火。很好，火已经烧了一阵了，燃得正旺。我把他的扶手椅搬到壁炉边，把桌子推过去，放下窗帘，把蜡烛拿进来以备用。从未有过的不安，让我不干完这些就无法安坐，也无法在屋子里呆下去。此时屋子里的小钟和大厅里的老钟同时敲响了十点。 Here and there I strayed through the orchard, gathered up the apples with which the grass round the tree roots was thickly strewn; then I employed myself in dividing the ripe from the unripe; I carried them into the house and put them away in the store-room.Then I repaired to the library to ascertain whether the fire was lit, for, though summer, I knew on such a gloomy evening Mr. Rochester would like to see a cheerful hearth when he came in: yes, the fire had been kindled some time, and burnt well.I placed his arm-chair by the chimney-corner: I wheeled the table near it: I let down the curtain, and had the candles brought in ready for lighting.More restless than ever, when I had not completed these arrangements I could not sit still, nor even remain in the house: a little time-piece in the room and the old clock in the hall simultaneously struck ten.
“这么晚了！”我说。“我要跑到大门口去，现在时不时地有点月光，我还能看清路。他现在可能要回来了，去接他也许能减少点焦虑。” “How late it grows!” I said.“I will run down to the gates: it is moonlight at intervals; I can see a good way on the road.He may be coming now, and to meet him will save some minutes of suspense.”
风在遮蔽着大门的大树树顶怒吼，但我放眼看去，道路两旁却一片寂静，只有云影不时地在月亮探出头来时掠过。只见灰白的一条长道，没有一点动静。 The wind roared high in the great trees which embowered the gates; but the road as far as I could see, to the right hand and the left, was all still and solitary: save for the shadows of clouds crossing it at intervals as the moon looked out, it was but a long pale line, unvaried by one moving speck.
我看着看着，一滴孩子气的泪水就模糊了视线——一滴失望和焦急的泪水。我感到惭愧，把它擦掉了。我在徘徊。月亮把自己整个儿关进闺房，还拉上了厚厚的云帘。夜色更深了，大风带来了骤雨。 A puerile tear dimmed my eye while I looked—a tear of disappointment and impatience; ashamed of it, I wiped it away.I lingered; the moon shut herself wholly within her chamber, and drew close her curtain of dense cloud: the night grew dark; rain came driving fast on the gale.
“希望他能回来！希望他能回来！”我大叫着，怀揣着充满了忧郁症般的预感。我本以为他茶点之前就能到了，可现在天都黑了，什么事耽搁他了呢？出什么意外了吗？昨晚那事又涌上心头。我认为那是灾难的预兆。我怕自己的愿望太美好而无法实现。而且我最近享受了如此多的幸福，我估计我的运气已经到了顶点，现在该衰落了。 “I wish he would come! I wish he would come!”I exclaimed, seized with hypochondriac foreboding.I had expected his arrival before tea; now it was dark: what could keep him?Had an accident happened?The event of last night again recurred to me.I interpreted it as a warning of disaster.I feared my hopes were too bright to be realised; and I had enjoyed so much bliss lately that I imagined my fortune had passed its meridian, and must now decline.
“不，我不能回屋去。”我想，“他在外面承受狂风暴雨，我不能安坐于火边。与其自己揪心，不如动动腿脚，到前面去接他。” “Well, I cannot return to the house,” I thought; “I cannot sit by the fireside, while he is abroad in inclement weather: better tire my limbs than strain my heart; I will go forward and meet him.”
我出发了，快步走着，但没走多远。还没走四分之一英里，就听到马蹄的得得声。一位骑马者疾驰而来，旁边跑着一条狗。不详的预感烟消云散！是他，那是他，骑着梅斯罗，后面跟着派洛特。他看见我了，因为月亮已经在空中开辟了一块蓝色的空间，明亮如水。他摘下帽子，在头顶挥动。我跑过去接他。 I set out; I walked fast, but not far: ere I had measured a quarter of a mile, I heard the tramp of hoofs; a horseman came on, full gallop; a dog ran by his side.Away with evil presentiment!It was he: here he was, mounted on Mesrour, followed by Pilot.He saw me; for the moon had opened a blue field in the sky, and rode in it watery bright: he took his hat off, and waved it round his head.I now ran to meet him.
“嗨！”他大叫着，从马鞍上弯下腰，伸出手：“很明显，你离不开我啦。踩在我靴尖上，两只手都给我，上！” “There!” he exclaimed, as he stretched out his hand and bent from the saddle: “You can’t do without me, that is evident.Step on my boot-toe; give me both hands: mount!”
我照办了。欢乐使我更敏捷，我一跃坐到了他前面。我得到一个欢迎的热吻，连同他那得意的胜利姿态，我也尽量地吞了下去。他止住狂喜，问我，“怎么了，珍妮特，这时候了还来接我？出什么事了吗？” I obeyed: joy made me agile: I sprang up before him.A hearty kissing I got for a welcome, and some boastful triumph, which I swallowed as well as I could.He checked himself in his exultation to demand, “But is there anything the matter, Janet, that you come to meet me at such an hour?Is there anything wrong?”
“没有，但我以为你再也不回来了呢。我不能忍受在屋里等你，尤其是外面还风雨交加。” “No, but I thought you would never come.I could not bear to wait in the house for you, especially with this rain and wind.”
“风雨交加，确实！看，你浑身湿的，像条美人鱼，把我的斗篷裹上。我想你在发烧，珍妮特，你的脸和手都滚烫滚烫的。我再问一遍，出什么事了吗？” “Rain and wind, indeed!Yes, you are dripping like a mermaid; pull my cloak round you: but I think you are feverish, Jane: both your cheek and hand are burning hot.I ask again, is there anything the matter?”
“没有。我现在既不害怕也不难过。” “Nothing now; I am neither afraid nor unhappy.”
“那你刚才是又害怕又难过喽？” “Then you have been both?”
“有一点。不过我会慢慢跟你道来的，先生。我敢说你只会取笑我的痛苦。” “Rather: but I’ll tell you all about it by-and-bye, sir; and I daresay you will only laugh at me for my pains.”
“明天一过，我就会痛快地取笑你，不过那之前可不敢，我的胜利还没确定呢。这是你吗，这一个月来滑得像条泥鳅，刺儿多得像株野玫瑰的你吗？我的指头不管伸到哪儿都会被扎。可现在我怀里抱的仿佛是一只迷途的羔羊。你溜出羊圈来找你的牧羊人了，是吗，简？” “I’ll laugh at you heartily when tomorrow is past; till then I dare not: my prize is not certain.This is you, who have been as slippery as an eel this last month, and as thorny as a briar-rose?I could not lay a finger anywhere but I was pricked; and now I seem to have gathered up a stray lamb in my arms.You wandered out of the fold to seek your shepherd, did you, Jane?”
“我是需要你，但别得意了。到桑菲尔德了，让我下去。” “I wanted you: but don’t boast.Here we are at Thornfield: now let me get down.”
他把我放到小道上。约翰接过马，他跟我进了大厅，催我赶快换上干衣服，然后去藏书室找他。我上楼时又叫住了我，让我保证别弄得太久。我没收拾多久，五分钟后就回到了他身边。他在吃晚饭。 He landed me on the pavement.As John took his horse, and he followed me into the hall, he told me to make haste and put something dry on, and then return to him in the library; and he stopped me, as I made for the staircase, to extort a promise that I would not be long: nor was I long; in five minutes I rejoined him.I found him at supper.
“坐下来陪我，简。如系天意，在未来很长一段时间内，这将是你在桑菲尔德吃的倒数第二顿饭。” “Take a seat and bear me company, Jane: please God, it is the last meal but one you will eat at Thornfield Hall for a long time.”
我挨着他坐下来，但告诉他我不想吃。“是不是因为要出门旅行，简？是不是想到要去伦敦你就没胃口了？” I sat down near him, but told him I could not eat.“Is it because you have the prospect of a journey before you, Jane?Is it the thoughts of going to London that takes away your appetite?”
“我今晚看不清我的前途，先生，我几乎不知道自己脑子里在想些什么。生活中的一切看起来都不真实。” “I cannot see my prospects clearly tonight, sir; and I hardly know what thoughts I have in my head.Everything in life seems unreal.”
“除了我，我可是够实在了——触碰我。” “Except me: I am substantial enough—touch me.”
“你，先生，是最像幻象的，你只是个梦。” “You, sir, are the most phantom-like of all: you are a mere dream.”
他伸出手，笑了。“那是梦吗？”他说，将手靠近我的眼睛。他有一只粗壮、强健、有力的手，胳膊也又长又壮。 He held out his hand, laughing.“Is that a dream?” said he, placing it close to my eyes.He had a rounded, muscular, and vigorous hand, as well as a long, strong arm.
“是的。虽然触碰到了它，却还是个梦。”我把他的手从面前放下去，说道。“先生，你用完晚饭了吗？” “Yes; though I touch it, it is a dream,” said I, as I put it down from before my face.“Sir, have you finished supper?”
“是的，简。” “Yes, Jane.”
我打铃，让人把盘子端走。又剩我们两个人了，我拨了拨火，然后在主人脚边的矮凳上坐下。 I rang the bell and ordered away the tray.When we were again alone, I stirred the fire, and then took a low seat at my master’s knee.
“快午夜了。”我说。 “It is near midnight,” I said.
“是啊，但是记住，简，你答应过婚礼前夜陪我守夜的。” “Yes: but remember, Jane, you promised to wake with me the night before my wedding.”
“我记得。我会遵守承诺，至少再呆一两个小时，我还不想睡。” “I did; and I will keep my promise, for an hour or two at least: I have no wish to go to bed.”
“你一切都准备停当了？” “Are all your arrangements complete?”
“都好了，先生。” “All, sir.”
“我的也好了，”他回道，“我把所有事情都处理好了。我们明天就可以离开桑菲尔德了，从教堂回来半小时内就走。” “And on my part likewise,” he returned, “I have settled everything; and we shall leave Thornfield tomorrow, within half-an-hour after our return from church.”
“很好，先生。” “Very well, sir.”
“你说‘很好’时笑得多特别啊，简！你两颊上多亮啊！你眼睛闪得多古怪啊！你还好吗？” “With what an extraordinary smile you uttered that word—‘very well,’ Jane!What a bright spot of colour you have on each cheek! and how strangely your eyes glitter!Are you well?”
“我想我很好。” “I believe I am.”
“想！怎么回事？告诉我你感觉如何。” “Believe!What is the matter?Tell me what you feel.”
“我不能，先生。言辞无法形容我的感觉。我希望此刻永远不要结束，谁知道接下来的命运会怎样呢？” “I could not, sir: no words could tell you what I feel.I wish this present hour would never end: who knows with what fate the next may come charged?”
“你多疑了，简。你是太兴奋了，或是太疲惫了。” “This is hypochondria, Jane.You have been over-excited, or over fatigued.”
“你呢，先生，你觉得平静、开心吗？” “Do you, sir, feel calm and happy?”
“平静？——不，但很开心，打心眼里高兴。” “Calm?—no: but happy—to the heart’s core.”
我抬头细看他脸上的幸福之色，确实热情洋溢、红光满面。 I looked up at him to read the signs of bliss in his face: it was ardent and flushed.
“跟我说说你的心里话，简，”他说，“放下心头的负担吧，分给我一些。你怕什么？怕我不会是个好丈夫吗？” “Give me your confidence, Jane,” he said: “relieve your mind of any weight that oppresses it, by imparting it to me.What do you fear?—that I shall not prove a good husband?”
“我绝不会那么想。” “It is the idea farthest from my thoughts.”
“你是在担忧将要进入的新天地？将要开始的新生活吗？” “Are you apprehensive of the new sphere you are about to enter?—of the new life into which you are passing?”
“不是。” “No.”
“你难倒我了，简。你忧郁的眼神和忧伤的语气让我困惑不解，让我很痛苦。我想要个解释。” “You puzzle me, Jane: your look and tone of sorrowful audacity perplex and pain me.I want an explanation.”
“那么，先生，听着。昨晚你不是不在家吗？” “Then, sir, listen.You were from home last night?”
“是啊，我知道。你刚才提到我不在的时候发生什么事了——也许没什么大事，但是，总之让你不安了。说来我听听。或许费尔法克斯太太说了什么？或者你听到仆人们谈论什么了？——你敏感的自尊被伤害了？” “I was: I know that; and you hinted a while ago at something which had happened in my absence:—nothing, probably, of consequence; but, in short, it has disturbed you.Let me hear it.Mrs. Fairfax has said something, perhaps? or you have overheard the servants talk?—your sensitive self-respect has been wounded?”
“不是，先生。”钟敲响了十二点。我等着小钟结束它清脆的谐音，大钟停止那沙哑的振荡，然后才接着说： “No, sir.”It struck twelve—I waited till the time-piece had concluded its silver chime, and the clock its hoarse, vibritting stroke, and then I proceeded.
“我昨天一整天都很忙，忙个不停却很快乐。因为我没有，如你所想的那样，因为对新天地之类的害怕而烦恼。我想能有希望与你共同生活，是件很极好的事情，因为我爱你。不，先生，现在不要爱抚我——别打搅我说话。昨天我信任上苍，相信一切利于你我幸福的事情都进行得很好。天气很好，如果你还记得，风和日丽，使我不必为你旅途的安全和舒适担心。用完茶后，我在小路上走了一会儿，想着你，想象着你离我很近，几乎就在身边。我想着我眼前的生活——你的生活，先生——一种比我的更加广阔和活跃的生活，就像溪流交汇处的深海，远不同于溪流自己那浅窄的航道。我不明白道德家们为什么把这个世界称作凄凉的荒原。在我看来，它就像一朵盛开的玫瑰。就在日落时分，空气变凉，天空开始阴云密布。我走进屋，索菲让我上楼看我的结婚礼服，他们刚买回来。在礼服下面的盒子里，我看见了你的礼物——那块面纱。你如此地奢华，竟让人从伦敦给送了过来。我估计，既然我不要珠宝，你是决心要骗我接受另一件同样贵重的东西。打开它时我笑了，计划着怎么取笑你的贵族趣味，和你想把你的平民新娘藏在贵妇面纱下的努力。我在想如何把我为自己那出生卑微的脑袋准备的、一块不曾绣花的方巾带下来，然后问问你，那对于一个不能给丈夫带来财富、美貌及姻亲关系的女人，是不是不够好。我清楚地看到了你的表情，听到了你激烈的共和主义式的回答，还有你傲慢地否认你没有必要通过与钱包或贵族结亲，来增加自己的财富，或提升自己的地位。” “All day yesterday I was very busy, and very happy in my ceaseless bustle; for I am not, as you seem to think, troubled by any haunting fears about the new sphere, et cetera: I think it a glorious thing to have the hope of living with you, because I love you.No, sir, don’t caress me now—let me talk undisturbed.Yesterday I trusted well in Providence, and believed that events were working together for your good and mine: it was a fine day, if you recollect—the calmness of the air and sky forbade apprehensions respecting your safety or comfort on your journey.I walked a little while on the pavement after tea, thinking of you; and I beheld you in imagination so near me, I scarcely missed your actual presence.I thought of the life that lay before me—YOUR life, sir—an existence more expansive and stirring than my own: as much more so as the depths of the sea to which the brook runs are than the shallows of its own strait channel.I wondered why moralists call this world a dreary wilderness: for me it blossomed like a rose.Just at sunset, the air turned cold and the sky cloudy: I went in, Sophie called me upstairs to look at my wedding-dress, which they had just brought; and under it in the box I found your present—the veil which, in your princely extravagance, you sent for from London: resolved, I suppose, since I would not have jewels, to cheat me into accepting something as costly.I smiled as I unfolded it, and devised how I would tease you about your aristocratic tastes, and your efforts to masque your plebeian bride in the attributes of a peeress.I though how I would carry down to you the square of unembroidered blond I had myself prepared as a covering for my low-born head, and ask if that was not good enough for a woman who could bring her husband neither fortune, beauty, nor connections.I saw plainly how you would look; and heard your impetuous republican answers, and your haughty disavowal of any necessity on your part to augment your wealth, or elevate your standing, by marrying either a purse or a coronet.”
“你真是太了解我了，你这个小巫女！”罗切斯特先生插话道，“但除了刺绣，你从那块面纱里还发现什么了？你是发现了毒药还是匕首，让你现在如此悲哀？” “How well you read me, you witch!” interposed Mr. Rochester: “but what did you find in the veil besides its embroidery?Did you find poison, or a dagger, that you look so mournful now?”
“没，没有，先生。除了那织物的精美和奢华，除了费尔法克斯·罗切斯特的骄傲，我什么也没发现。而且那也没有吓到我，因为我已经见惯了那个魔鬼的样子。但是，先生，天黑的时候起风了。昨晚的风和今晚不同，不是狂野而猛烈，而是带着一种沉闷、幽怨的声音，更加可怕。当时我真希望你能在家。我走进这间屋子，空空的椅子和没有炉火的火炉让我感到一阵寒冷。我上床后很长一段时间都没能入睡——一种焦虑的兴奋让我很痛苦。狂风越吹越大，听起来好像是一阵被蒙住的哀鸣。起初我不知道这声音来自屋里还是屋外，但它再三响起，总是在风声停歇的时候，模模糊糊却阴郁忧愁。后来我终于明白那肯定是远处的哪只狗在叫嚣。它停下来的时候我非常高兴。睡着之时，我还一直梦到一个漆黑的、狂风大作的夜晚。我还一直希望能和你在一起，并且奇怪而又遗憾地感觉到有什么障碍把我们隔开了。刚刚睡着的时候，我都沿着一条弯弯曲曲的不认识的路在走。一片漆黑笼罩了我，雨抽打着我。我还抱着一个小孩：一个非常小的家伙，又小又弱，不能走路，在我冰冷的怀中发抖，可怜的恸哭声传入我耳中。我以为，先生，你就在前面远远的路上走着，我竭力赶上你，一次次努力地呼唤你的名字，求你停下——但我的行动受阻，声音也发不出来。而你，我觉得，却越走越远。” “No, no, sir; besides the delicacy and richness of the fabric, I found nothing save Fairfax Rochester’s pride; and that did not scare me, because I am used to the sight of the demon.But, sir, as it grew dark, the wind rose: it blew yesterday evening, not as it blows now—wild and high—but ‘with a sullen, moaning sound’ far more eerie.I wished you were at home.I came into this room, and the sight of the empty chair and fireless hearth chilled me.For some time after I went to bed, I could not sleep—a sense of anxious excitement distressed me.The gale still rising, seemed to my ear to muffle a mournful under-sound; whether in the house or abroad I could not at first tell, but it recurred, doubtful yet doleful at every lull; at last I made out it must be some dog howling at a distance.I was glad when it ceased.On sleeping, I continued in dreams the idea of a dark and gusty night.I continued also the wish to be with you, and experienced a strange, regretful consciousness of some barrier dividing us.During all my first sleep, I was following the windings of an unknown road; total obscurity environed me; rain pelted me; I was burdened with the charge of a little child: a very small creature, too young and feeble to walk, and which shivered in my cold arms, and wailed piteously in my ear.I thought, sir, that you were on the road a long way before me; and I strained every nerve to overtake you, and made effort on effort to utter your name and entreat you to stop—but my movements were fettered, and my voice still died away inarticulate; while you, I felt, withdrew farther and farther every moment.”
“现在我就在你身边，简，这些梦还压在你心上吗？神经质的小东西！忘掉空想的悲伤，只想真实的幸福吧！你说你爱我，珍妮特，是的——我不会忘记，你也不能否认。那些话还在你嘴唇上，不曾消失。我听得既清楚又温柔，或许它过于庄重，却如音乐般甜蜜——‘我想能有希望与你共同生活，是件极好的事情，爱德华，因为我爱你。’你爱我吗，简？——再说一遍。” “And these dreams weigh on your spirits now, Jane, when I am close to you?Little nervous subject! Forget visionary woe, and think only of real happiness!You say you love me, Janet: yes—I will not forget that; and you cannot deny it.THOSE words did not die inarticulate on your lips.I heard them clear and soft: a thought too solemn perhaps, but sweet as music—‘I think it is a glorious thing to have the hope of living with you, Edward, because I love you.’Do you love me, Jane?—repeat it.”
“爱，先生，我全心全意地爱你。” “I do, sir—I do, with my whole heart.”
“唉，”他沉默了几分钟后，说道，“奇怪，这句话刺痛了我的胸膛。为什么呢？我想是因为你说的时候如此真诚，有着虔诚的力量；还因为你此刻抬头看我的眼神里充满极度的信赖、诚实与忠诚。这太过了，就像在我身边的是个幽灵一样。顽皮点吧，简，你很明白该做出什么样的表情：摆一个你那野蛮、羞怯、挑衅的微笑吧，告诉我你恨我，取笑我、激怒我吧。干什么都行，就是不要感动我。我宁愿愤怒也不愿忧伤。” “Well,” he said, after some minutes’ silence, “it is strange; but that sentence has penetrated by breast painfully.Why? I think because you said it with such an earnest, religious energy, and because your upward gaze at me now is the very sublime of faith, truth, and devotion: it is too much as if some spirit were near me.Look wicked, Jane: as you know well how to look: coin one of your wild, shy, provoking smiles; tell me you hate me—tease me, vex me; do anything but move me: I would rather be incensed than saddened.”
“我讲完故事后，就会取笑你、激怒你，让你满意。但请听我说完。” “I will tease you and vex you to your heart’s content, when I have finished my tale: but hear me to the end.”
“我以为，简，你已经讲完了呢。我以为你忧伤的原因就是那个梦呢。” “I thought, Jane, you had told me all.I thought I had found the source of your melancholy in a dream.”
我摇摇头。“什么！还有别的？但我相信肯定没什么大不了的事。我先警告你我可不相信。继续吧。” I shook my head.“What! is there more?But I will not believe it to be anything important.I warn you of incredulity beforehand.Go on.”
他神色不安，举止显得急躁，令人诧异。但我还是继续了。 The disquietude of his air, the somewhat apprehensive impatience of his manner, surprised me: but I proceeded.
“我做了另一个梦，先生。梦到桑菲尔德变成一片凄凉的废墟，成了蝙蝠和猫头鹰的栖息地。宏伟的正墙只剩下一段贝壳似的断壁，高大而脆弱。我在月光下徘徊，穿过荒草丛生的围墙：这边绊倒一个大理石火炉，那边又撞上一块已掉落的飞檐碎片。我裹着块披肩，仍然抱着那个不认识的小孩。无论我胳膊有多累，也无法把它搁到什么地方——无论它的重量怎么拖累我行进，我都必须带着它。我听到远处道路上马儿飞驰的声音，我确定那就是你。你走了很多年，去了一个很远的国度。我急忙疯狂地冒险爬上那薄薄的墙壁，渴望从上面看你一眼。石块从我脚下滚落，我抓着的常春藤枝蔓也断开了，小孩吓得搂紧我的脖子，几乎勒死我。最后我爬到了顶上。我看见你在白色的路上像个小点儿，越来越小。风刮得太猛，我站都站不稳。我在狭窄的墙头坐下来，哄着膝盖上那个吓坏了的孩子。你在路上拐了个弯，我弯腰想看最后一眼。墙倒了，我一晃，孩子从我膝上滚下去，我失去平衡，也掉了下去，然后就醒了。” “I dreamt another dream, sir: that Thornfield Hall was a dreary ruin, the retreat of bats and owls.I thought that of all the stately front nothing remained but a shell-like wall, very high and very fragile-looking.I wandered, on a moonlight night, through the grass-grown enclosure within: here I stumbled over a marble hearth, and there over a fallen fragment of cornice.Wrapped up in a shawl, I still carried the unknown little child: I might not lay it down anywhere, however tired were my arms—however much its weight impeded my progress, I must retain it.I heard the gallop of a horse at a distance on the road; I was sure it was you; and you were departing for many years and for a distant country.I climbed the thin wall with frantic perilous haste, eager to catch one glimpse of you from the top: the stones rolled from under my feet, the ivy branches I grasped gave way, the child clung round my neck in terror, and almost strangled me; at last I gained the summit.I saw you like a speck on a white track, lessening every moment.The blast blew so strong I could not stand.I sat down on the narrow ledge; I hushed the scared infant in my lap: you turned an angle of the road: I bent forward to take a last look; the wall crumbled; I was shaken; the child rolled from my knee, I lost my balance, fell, and woke.”
“好啦，简，完了吧。” “Now, Jane, that is all.”
“那只是序言，先生，故事还在后面。醒来时，一道光线使我目眩，我想——噢，天亮了！可是我错了，那只是烛光而已。我想，是索菲进来了。梳妆台上有一支蜡烛，衣橱的门敞开着，我上床之前把结婚礼服和面纱挂在里面的。我听到那儿发出窸窸窣窣的声音。我问：‘索菲，你干什么呢？’没人回答。但有个人影从衣橱里冒出来，高举着蜡烛，打量着从旅行箱上的垂下来的礼服。‘索菲！索菲！’我又喊道，但还是没有回答。我起来，俯身向前，先是惊奇，然后是迷惑，接着我浑身的血液都冰凉了。罗切斯特先生，那不是索菲，不是利娅，不是费尔法克斯太太，也不是——不，我敢肯定，现在也仍肯定——甚至也不是那个古怪的女人，格雷斯·普尔。” “All the preface, sir; the tale is yet to come.On waking, a gleam dazzled my eyes; I thought—Oh, it is daylight!But I was mistaken; it was only candlelight.Sophie, I supposed, had come in.There was a light in the dressing-table, and the door of the closet, where, before going to bed, I had hung my wedding-dress and veil, stood open; I heard a rustling there.I asked, ‘Sophie, what are you doing?’No one answered; but a form emerged from the closet; it took the light, held it aloft, and surveyed the garments pendent from the portmanteau.‘Sophie! Sophie!’I again cried: and still it was silent.I had risen up in bed, I bent forward: first surprise, then bewilderment, came over me; and then my blood crept cold through my veins.Mr. Rochester, this was not Sophie, it was not Leah, it was not Mrs. Fairfax: it was not—no, I was sure of it, and am still—it was not even that strange woman, Grace Poole.”
“肯定是她们中的一个。”主人打断我。 “It must have been one of them,” interrupted my master.
“不，先生，我严肃地向你保证，正好相反。我面前站着的那个人我在桑菲尔德从没见过。那身高、那轮廓对我都很陌生。” “No, sir, I solemnly assure you to the contrary.The shape standing before me had never crossed my eyes within the precincts of Thornfield Hall before; the height, the contour were new to me.”
“描述一下，简。” “Describe it, Jane.”
“先生，那好像是个女人，又高又大，又厚又黑的头发在背后长长地垂着。我不知道她穿的是什么衣服，反正又白又直，说不上来是睡袍、床单，还是裹尸布。” “It seemed, sir, a woman, tall and large, with thick and dark hair hanging long down her back.I know not what dress she had on: it was white and straight; but whether gown, sheet, or shroud, I cannot tell.”
“你看到她的脸了吗？” “Did you see her face?”
“起初没有。但不久她就取下我的面纱，举起来盯着看了很久，然后随手戴到自己头上，转身去照镜子。那一刻，我清楚地看到了幽暗的长方镜子里反射出来的容貌和五官。” “Not at first.But presently she took my veil from its place; she held it up, gazed at it long, and then she threw it over her own head, and turned to the mirror.At that moment I saw the reflection of the visage and features quite distinctly in the dark oblong glass.”
“是什么样子的？” “And how were they?”
“可怕，恐怖——噢，先生，我从未见过那样一张脸！那是一张面无血色的脸——一张野蛮的脸。但愿我能忘掉那红色的滴溜溜转的眼睛，还有那吓人的黑漆漆肿胀的轮廓！” “Fearful and ghastly to me—oh, sir, I never saw a face like it!It was a discoloured face—it was a savage face.I wish I could forget the roll of the red eyes and the fearful blackened inflation of the lineaments!”
“鬼通常都是苍白的，简。” “Ghosts are usually pale, Jane.”
“先生，这个是紫色的。嘴唇肿胀乌黑，额头满是皱纹，黑色的眉毛离眼睛很远，竖在充血的眼睛上方。我能告诉你它让我想起什么了吗？” “This, sir, was purple: the lips were swelled and dark; the brow furrowed: the black eyebrows widely raised over the bloodshot eyes.Shall I tell you of what it reminded me?”
“说吧。” “You may.”
“邪恶的日耳曼妖怪——吸血鬼。” “Of the foul German spectre—the Vampyre.”
“啊！——它做什么了？” “Ah!—what did it do?”
“先生，它把我的面纱从它枯瘦的脑袋上拿下来，撕成两半，全扔到地上，用力踩踏。” “Sir, it removed my veil from its gaunt head, rent it in two parts, and flinging both on the floor, trampled on them.”
“然后呢？” “Afterwards?”
“它拉开窗帘往外看，或许是看到黎明快要到来了，于是它拿着蜡烛往门口退去。经过我床边时又停下来了，火一般的眼睛瞪着我——把蜡烛推到我面前，在我眼皮底下把它吹灭了。我感到她那可怕的脸庞在我面前闪着光，于是我就昏了过去。这是我人生中的第二次——仅仅是第二次——我被吓昏了。” “It drew aside the window-curtain and looked out; perhaps it saw dawn approaching, for, taking the candle, it retreated to the door.Just at my bedside, the figure stopped: the fiery eyes glared upon me—she thrust up her candle close to my face, and extinguished it under my eyes.I was aware her lurid visage flamed over mine, and I lost consciousness: for the second time in my life—only the second time—I became insensible from terror.”
“你醒来的时候和谁在一起？” “Who was with you when you revived?”
“没人，先生，只有大白天。我起床，把头和脸浸在水里，喝了一大口水。我感觉虽然虚弱但并没生病，并决定不把这个幻象告诉任何人，除了你。现在，先生，告诉我这个女人是谁，是干什么的？” “No one, sir, but the broad day.I rose, bathed my head and face in water, drank a long draught; felt that though enfeebled I was not ill, and determined that to none but you would I impart this vision.Now, sir, tell me who and what that woman was?”
“肯定是你大脑过度兴奋的产物。我得对你留心了，我的宝贝，你的神经可受不了粗暴的对待。” “The creature of an over-stimulated brain; that is certain.I must be careful of you, my treasure: nerves like yours were not made for rough handling.”
“先生，毫无疑问，我的神经没有问题。那东西是真的，那件事的的确确发生过。” “Sir, depend on it, my nerves were not in fault; the thing was real: the transaction actually took place.”
“那你之前的那些梦，也是真的吗？桑菲尔德是废墟吗？我和你被无法逾越的障碍隔断了吗？我离开你时一滴眼泪都没有——一个吻也没有——一句话也没有吗？” “And your previous dreams, were they real too?Is Thornfield Hall a ruin?Am I severed from you by insuperable obstacles?Am I leaving you without a tear—without a kiss—without a word?”
“还没有。” “Not yet.”
“我会这么做吗？嗨，将我们不可分离地联系在一起的日子已经开始啦。我们一旦结合，这种心理恐惧就再也不会出现了，我保证。” “Am I about to do it?Why, the day is already commenced which is to bind us indissolubly; and when we are once united, there shall be no recurrence of these mental terrors: I guarantee that.”
“心理恐惧，先生！我也希望我相信他们只是如此。连你都无法解释那个可怕的造访者之谜，我更是希望如此了。” “Mental terrors, sir!I wish I could believe them to be only such: I wish it more now than ever; since even you cannot explain to me the mystery of that awful visitant.”
“既然我都无法解释，简，那它肯定不是真的。” “And since I cannot do it, Jane, it must have been unreal.”
“但是，先生，当我今早起床对自己这么说时，我环顾屋子四周，希望在大白天从每个熟悉的令人愉快的物件上获得勇气和安慰，就在那儿——地毯上——我看到那使我的假设完全不成立的东西——那块从上到下被撕成两半的面纱！” “But, sir, when I said so to myself on rising this morning, and when I looked round the room to gather courage and comfort from the cheerful aspect of each familiar object in full daylight, there—on the carpet—I saw what gave the distinct lie to my hypothesis,—the veil, torn from top to bottom in two halves!”
我感到罗切斯特先生吃了一惊，打了个战栗。他赶紧伸出胳膊抱住我。“感谢上帝！”他叫道，“昨晚要是真有什么坏东西走近你，仅仅是弄坏了一块面纱。噢，想想会发生什么事啊！” I felt Mr. Rochester start and shudder; he hastily flung his arms round me.“Thank God!” he exclaimed, “that if anything malignant did come near you last night, it was only the veil that was harmed.Oh, to think what might have happened!”
他急促地喘着气，紧紧地抱住我，我几乎透不过气来。几分钟的静默之后，他又快乐地继续道： He drew his breath short, and strained me so close to him, I could scarcely pant.After some minutes’ silence, he continued, cheerily—
“听着，珍妮特，我把这一切解释给你听。这事一半是做梦，一半是真的。我不怀疑确实有个女人进了你的房间，那个女人就是——肯定是——格雷斯·普尔。你自己都把她叫做怪人，从你所知道的一切，你有理由这么叫她——她是怎么对待我的？又是怎么对待梅森的？在半睡半醒的状态下，你发现了她的闯入和其他行为。但你在发烧，几乎神志昏迷，你把她看成了与她本人不像的妖怪模样。那蓬乱的长发，肿胀的黑色脸庞，夸张的身材，都是幻想的产物，噩梦的结果。恶意地撕毁面纱倒是真的，正像她所为。我知道你会问我为什么要把这么个女人留在家里。等我们结婚一周年时我会告诉你，但不是现在。你满意了吗，简？接受我对这个谜的解答吗？” “Now, Janet, I’ll explain to you all about it.It was half dream, half reality.A woman did, I doubt not, enter your room: and that woman was—must have been—Grace Poole.You call her a strange being yourself: from all you know, you have reason so to call her—what did she do to me? what to Mason?In a state between sleeping and waking, you noticed her entrance and her actions; but feverish, almost delirious as you were, you ascribed to her a goblin appearance different from her own: the long dishevelled hair, the swelled black face, the exaggerated stature, were figments of imagination; results of nightmare: the spiteful tearing of the veil was real: and it is like her.I see you would ask why I keep such a woman in my house: when we have been married a year and a day, I will tell you; but not now.Are you satisfied, Jane?Do you accept my solution of the mystery?”
我想了想，这对我而言的确是唯一一个可能的答案，满意倒并没有。不过为了让他高兴，我努力装作如此——如释重负，于是我给他一个满意的微笑。此时早已过了一点，我打算离开他。 I reflected, and in truth it appeared to me the only possible one: satisfied I was not, but to please him I endeavoured to appear so—relieved, I certainly did feel; so I answered him with a contented smile.And now, as it was long past one, I prepared to leave him.
“索菲不是和阿代勒睡在育儿室吗？”我点蜡烛的时候他问道。 “Does not Sophie sleep with Adele in the nursery?” he asked, as I lit my candle.
“是的，先生。” “Yes, sir.”
“阿代勒的小床还容得下你。你今晚得和她同睡了，简。你刚讲的事肯定让你神经紧张，我不愿让你单独睡。答应我去育儿室吧。” “And there is room enough in Adele’s little bed for you.You must share it with her tonight, Jane: it is no wonder that the incident you have related should make you nervous, and I would rather you did not sleep alone: promise me to go to the nursery.”
“我很乐意去，先生。” “I shall be very glad to do so, sir.”
“从里面把门关好。上楼时叫醒索菲，就说要她明早按时叫你起床，因为你八点以前必须穿戴好并吃完早饭。现在，别再有忧郁的想法了，把那些阴暗的事情赶走，珍妮特。你没听到狂风已经变成沙沙细语，雨也不再敲打窗玻璃了吗？看这儿”（他撩起窗帘）——“真是个可爱的夜晚！” “And fasten the door securely on the inside.Wake Sophie when you go upstairs, under pretence of requesting her to rouse you in good time tomorrow; for you must be dressed and have finished breakfast before eight.And now, no more sombre thoughts: chase dull care away, Janet.Don’t you hear to what soft whispers the wind has fallen? and there is no more beating of rain against the windowpanes: look here” (he lifted up the curtain)—“it is a lovely night!”
的确如此。半边天空纯净得一尘不染。被风刮到西边的云朵，现在又排着长队被吹向东方，宛若一条银色的柱子。月光静静地洒下来。 It was.Half heaven was pure and stainless: the clouds, now trooping before the wind, which had shifted to the west, were filing off eastward in long, silvered columns.The moon shone peacefully.
“好啦，”罗切斯特先生探询地注视着我的眼睛说，“我的珍妮特现在感觉怎样啊？” “Well,” said Mr. Rochester, gazing inquiringly into my eyes, “how is my Janet now?”
“夜色宁静，先生，我也一样。” “The night is serene, sir; and so am I.”
“今晚你就不会梦到离别和悲伤，而是梦到欢乐的爱情和幸福的结合。” “And you will not dream of separation and sorrow tonight; but of happy love and blissful union.”
这个预言只实现了一半，我的确没有梦到悲伤，但也同样没有梦到欢乐。因为我根本没有睡着。小阿代勒在我怀里，我看着她熟睡的童颜——如此平静、如此安宁、如此天真——等待着即将到来的那天，我的全部生活都被唤起，躁动。太阳一升起我就起来了。记得我离开时阿代勒搂着我不放，记得我把她的小手从我脖子上松开时，亲了她，还带着一种奇怪的情绪对着她哭泣，然后离开她，因为怕我的啜泣声会打断她的熟睡。她就像我过去生活的标志。而他，我正要打扮去见的人，则像是使我既畏惧又向往的未知的将来。 This prediction was but half fulfilled: I did not indeed dream of sorrow, but as little did I dream of joy; for I never slept at all.With little Adele in my arms, I watched the slumber of childhood—so tranquil, so passionless, so innocent—and waited for the coming day: all my life was awake and astir in my frame: and as soon as the sun rose I rose too.I remember Adele clung to me as I left her: I remember I kissed her as I loosened her little hands from my neck; and I cried over her with strange emotion, and quitted her because I feared my sobs would break her still sound repose.She seemed the emblem of my past life; and he I was now to array myself to meet, the dread, but adored, type of my unknown future day.
第二十六章 CHAPTER XXVI
七点钟光景，索菲来帮我梳洗打扮。为了把我打扮好，她的确花了很长时间；我想可能是太长了，罗切斯特先生都等得有些不耐烦了，于是派人来催问我为什么还没有过来。她刚用一枚别针将面纱（其实不过是一块普通的金色方巾）固定在我的头发上，我便立刻从她手下溜走了。 Sophie came at seven to dress me: she was very long indeed in accomplishing her task; so long that Mr. Rochester, grown, I suppose, impatient of my delay, sent up to ask why I did not come.She was just fastening my veil (the plain square of blond after all) to my hair with a brooch; I hurried from under her hands as soon as I could.
“站住！”她用法文喊道，“照照镜子，你连看都还没看一眼呢。” “Stop!” she cried in French. “Look at yourself in the mirror: you have not taken one peep.”
于是我在门口转过身。我看到镜中出现的是一个穿着礼服，戴着面纱的身影，和平时的自己相去甚远，宛若陌生人一般。“简！”喊声传来，我便急急地向楼下跑去。罗切斯特先生在楼梯脚下等我。 So I turned at the door: I saw a robed and veiled figure, so unlike my usual self that it seemed almost the image of a stranger.“Jane!” called a voice, and I hastened down.I was received at the foot of the stairs by Mr. Rochester.
“真能磨蹭！”他说，“我的脑袋都急得冒火了，你耽搁得也太久了！” “Lingerer!” he said, “my brain is on fire with impatience, and you tarry so long!”
他把我领进餐厅，从上到下急切地打量着我，说我“清新如百合，不仅是他生命的骄傲，还是他眼里的渴望。”随后他告诉我，只给我十分钟的时间吃早饭，便按了铃。一个他刚刚雇来的男仆应声而至。 He took me into the dining-room, surveyed me keenly all over, pronounced me “fair as a lily, and not only the pride of his life, but the desire of his eyes,” and then telling me he would give me but ten minutes to eat some breakfast, he rang the bell.One of his lately hired servants, a footman, answered it.
“约翰把马车准备好了么？” “Is John getting the carriage ready?”
“好了，先生。” “Yes, sir.”
“行李送下去了吗？” “Is the luggage brought down?”
“他们正在往下搬，先生。” “They are bringing it down, sir.”
“你去教堂看一看伍德先生（牧师）和文书在不在，然后回来告诉我。” “Go you to the church: see if Mr. Wood (the clergyman) and the clerk are there: return and tell me.”
正如读者所知，教堂就在门外不远处，男仆一会儿便回来了。 The church, as the reader knows, was but just beyond the gates; the footman soon returned.
“伍德先生在法衣室，正在穿他的白法衣。” “Mr. Wood is in the vestry, sir, putting on his surplice.”
“马车呢？” “And the carriage?”
“正在套马。” “The horses are harnessing.”
“我们不用坐车去教堂，但是我们回来的时候，马车要备好，所有的箱子和行李都要装车捆好，车夫要在座位上候着。” “We shall not want it to go to church; but it must be ready the moment we return: all the boxes and luggage arranged and strapped on, and the coachman in his seat.”
“好的，先生。” “Yes, sir.”
“简，你准备好了吗？” “Jane, are you ready?”
我站起身。没有伴郎也没有伴娘，没有亲戚等着我们或为我们带路。谁都没有，只有罗切斯特先生和我。我们经过大厅时，费尔法克斯太太站在那儿。我本来乐意跟她说说话，但我的手被一只铁腕紧紧抓着，催我大步前进，我几乎都跟不上。看看罗切斯特先生的脸就知道，不论什么原因，一秒钟的耽搁他都不能忍受。我不知道别的新郎是否像他一样——这么专心致志、坚定不移，或还有谁能在这样坚毅的眉毛下，露出如此火热闪亮的眼睛。 I rose.There were no groomsmen, no bridesmaids, no relatives to wait for or marshal: none but Mr. Rochester and I.Mrs. Fairfax stood in the hall as we passed.I would fain have spoken to her, but my hand was held by a grasp of iron: I was hurried along by a stride I could hardly follow; and to look at Mr. Rochester’s face was to feel that not a second of delay would be tolerated for any purpose.I wonder what other bridegroom ever looked as he did—so bent up to a purpose, so grimly resolute: or who, under such steadfast brows, ever revealed such flaming and flashing eyes.
我不知道那天是晴还是阴。走下车道时，我既没看天也没看地，我的心与我的眼一起，二者仿佛都移到了罗切斯特先生的身体上。一起走着的时候，我想看看他那凶猛、暴躁的目光紧盯着不放的无形的东西是什么。我想感受他正在奋力抵抗的种种念头。 I know not whether the day was fair or foul; in descending the drive, I gazed neither on sky nor earth: my heart was with my eyes; and both seemed migrated into Mr. Rochester’s frame.I wanted to see the invisible thing on which, as we went along, he appeared to fasten a glance fierce and fell.I wanted to feel the thoughts whose force he seemed breasting and resisting.
走到教堂门口他停下来，发现我已经气喘吁吁了。“我爱得太残酷了吗？”他说，“耽搁一会儿吧，靠着我，简。” At the churchyard wicket he stopped: he discovered I was quite out of breath.“Am I cruel in my love?” he said.“Delay an instant: lean on me, Jane.”
至今我还能想起那副画面，古老的灰色教堂静静地矗立在面前，一只白嘴鸦在尖顶上盘旋，远处是清晨那泛红的天。我还记得绿草丛生的坟堆，也没忘记两个陌生人在低矮的坟丘中游荡，读着几块长满青苔的墓碑上刻着的碑文。我注意到他们，是因为他们一看见我们，就绕到了教堂后面。我肯定他们会从侧门进入教堂并观看我们的婚礼。罗切斯特先生并未注意到他们，他只是热切地看着我的脸，而这张脸肯定一时毫无血色，因为我感到额头上冒着冷汗，两颊和嘴唇一片冰凉。很快，我便恢复过来，和他一起缓缓走在通往门廊的小路上。 And now I can recall the picture of the grey old house of God rising calm before me, of a rook wheeling round the steeple, of a ruddy morning sky beyond.I remember something, too, of the green grave mounds; and I have not forgotten, either, two figures of strangers straying amongst the low hillocks and reading the mementoes graven on the few mossy head-stones.I noticed them, because, as they saw us, they passed round to the back of the church; and I doubted not they were going to enter by the side-aisle door and witness the ceremony.By Mr. Rochester they were not observed; he was earnestly looking at my face from which the blood had, I daresay, momentarily fled: for I felt my forehead dewy, and my cheeks and lips cold.When I rallied, which I soon did, he walked gently with me up the path to the porch.
我们走进安静朴实的教堂，牧师穿着白法衣站在低矮的祭台前等着，文书站在他身边。一切都很平静，只有两个身影在远处的角落里移动。我猜得没错，那两个陌生人在我们之前溜进了教堂，正站在罗切斯特家的地下墓室旁，背对着我们，隔着栏杆观察那年头已久、污迹斑斑的大理石坟墓。那儿跪着一位天使，守护着在内战中死于马斯顿荒原的戴默·德·罗切斯特，还有他的妻子伊丽莎白的遗骸。 We entered the quiet and humble temple; the priest waited in his white surplice at the lowly altar, the clerk beside him.All was still: two shadows only moved in a remote corner.My conjecture had been correct: the strangers had slipped in before us, and they now stood by the vault of the Rochesters, their backs towards us, viewing through the rails the old time-stained marble tomb, where a kneeling angel guarded the remains of Damer de Rochester, slain at Marston Moor in the time of the civil wars, and of Elizabeth, his wife.
我们在圣餐仪式的栏杆前站好。听到身后响起细微的脚步声，我便回头扫了一眼：陌生人中的一位——显然是为绅士——正向圣坛走来。仪式开始了。牧师解释了一番婚姻的目的，然后又向前一步，朝罗切斯特先生微微俯身，继续说： Our place was taken at the communion rails.Hearing a cautious step behind me, I glanced over my shoulder: one of the strangers—a gentleman, evidently—was advancing up the chancel.The service began.The explanation of the intent of matrimony was gone through; and then the clergyman came a step further forward, and, bending slightly towards Mr. Rochester, went on.
“我要求和命令你二人——就如可怕的末日审判之时，一切心灵的秘密都会暴露，你们也将如实回答——如果你们其中的一位知道有什么障碍，使你们不能结为合法夫妻，那么现在就坦白吧。因为你们要知道，那些众多未经上帝许可的婚姻，都不是神圣的结合，也都不是合法的婚姻。” “I require and charge you both (as ye will answer at the dreadful day of judgment, when the secrets of all hearts shall be disclosed), that if either of you know any impediment why ye may not lawfully be joined together in matrimony, ye do now confess it;for be ye well assured that so many as are coupled together otherwise than God’s Word doth allow, are not joined together by God, neither is their matrimony lawful.”
他按照惯例停了一下。这句话之后的停顿何曾被回答打破过呢？没有。或许，一百年内才有一次。牧师没有抬眼离开他的书，静默一会儿后，继续下去。他的手已经伸向罗切斯特先生，开口问道，“你愿意娶这个女人为妻吗？”此刻附近一个清晰的声音说道： He paused, as the custom is.When is the pause after that sentence ever broken by reply?Not, perhaps, once in a hundred years.And the clergyman, who had not lifted his eyes from his book, and had held his breath but for a moment, was proceeding: his hand was already stretched towards Mr. Rochester, as his lips unclosed to ask, “Wilt thou have this woman for thy wedded wife?”—when a distinct and near voice said—
“婚礼不能继续，我宣布存在障碍。” “The marriage cannot go on: I declare the existence of an impediment.”
牧师抬头看着说话人，一时无言，文书也一样。罗切斯特先生微微一颤，仿佛脚下发生了地震。站稳之后，头也不回，眼也不动地说：“继续。” The clergyman looked up at the speaker and stood mute; the clerk did the same; Mr. Rochester moved slightly, as if an earthquake had rolled under his feet: taking a firmer footing, and not turning his head or eyes, he said, “Proceed.”
他低沉的语调说出这句话后，全场一片死寂。不久，伍德先生说： Profound silence fell when he had uttered that word, with deep but low intonation.Presently Mr. Wood said—
“不调查一下刚才宣称的事，没证明它的真假之前，我无法继续。” “I cannot proceed without some investigation into what has been asserted, and evidence of its truth or falsehood.”
“请彻底停止仪式。”我们身后的声音补充道，“我能证明我的宣称，这桩婚姻存在不可逾越的障碍。” “The ceremony is quite broken off,” subjoined the voice behind us.“I am in a condition to prove my allegation: an insuperable impediment to this marriage exists.”
罗切斯特先生听了，却没有理睬。他顽强刚硬地站着，纹丝不动，只是握住了我的手。他握得好紧，手好烫！此刻他那苍白、刚毅、宽阔的前额多像刚开采的大理石啊！他的眼睛多么亮，依然很警觉，而其深处又是多么狂野！ Mr. Rochester heard, but heeded not: he stood stubborn and rigid, making no movement but to possess himself of my hand.What a hot and strong grasp he had! and how like quarried marble was his pale, firm, massive front at this moment!How his eye shone, still watchful, and yet wild beneath!
伍德先生似乎不知所错。“这障碍是什么性质的？”他问道，“也许可以克服——通过解释消除？” Mr. Wood seemed at a loss.“What is the nature of the impediment?” he asked.“Perhaps it may be got over—explained away?”
“不可能。”那人回答，“我说它不可逾越，是经过考虑的。” “Hardly,” was the answer.“I have called it insuperable, and I speak advisedly.”
说话人走上前，靠在栏杆上。他继续一字一句地说下去，清楚、平静、坚定，但并不大声： The speaker came forward and leaned on the rails.He continued, uttering each word distinctly, calmly, steadily, but not loudly—
“这个障碍只在于前一次婚姻的存在。罗切斯特先生有一位现在还健在的妻子。” “It simply consists in the existence of a previous marriage.Mr. Rochester has a wife now living.”
我的神经被这些低声说出的字眼震撼到了，对雷声也从未如此过；我感觉到了血液细微的暴动，对于严寒烈火也从未如此过。但我依然镇定，没有晕倒。我看着罗切斯特先生，让他也看着我。他的脸庞如岩石般苍白，眼睛璀璨光亮，又透着坚毅。他什么也没有否认，仿佛藐视一切。他没有说话，也没有微笑，似乎不认识我这个人，只是紧紧地搂着我的腰，让我死死地贴在他身边。 My nerves vibrated to those low-spoken words as they had never vibrated to thunder—my blood felt their subtle violence as it had never felt frost or fire; but I was collected, and in no danger of swooning.I looked at Mr. Rochester: I made him look at me.His whole face was colourless rock: his eye was both spark and flint.He disavowed nothing: he seemed as if he would defy all things.Without speaking, without smiling, without seeming to recognise in me a human being, he only twined my waist with his arm and riveted me to his side.
“你是谁？”他问那个闯入者。 “Who are you?” he asked of the intruder.
“我叫布里格斯，伦敦某街的律师。” “My name is Briggs, a solicitor of—Street, London.”
“你要塞给我一个妻子？” “And you would thrust on me a wife?”
“我只是提醒你尊夫人的存在，先生，如果你不承认，法律也会承认的。” “I would remind you of your lady’s existence, sir, which the law recognises, if you do not.”
“那就请跟我讲讲她——她的名字，她的出身，她的住所。” “Favour me with an account of her—with her name, her parentage, her place of abode.”
“当然。”布里格斯先生冷静地从口袋里掏出一张纸，以一种带着鼻音的官腔读出： “Certainly.”Mr. Briggs calmly took a paper from his pocket, and read out in a sort of official, nasal voice:—
“‘我断言并能证明，公元某年十月二十日（十五年前的一天），英国某郡桑菲尔德府，及某郡芬丁庄园的爱德华·费尔法克斯·罗切斯特，和我的姐姐，商人乔纳斯·梅森及其妻子，克里奥尔人安托瓦妮特的女儿，伯莎·安托瓦妮特·梅森，在牙买加西班牙城的某教堂结婚。婚姻登记可见于该教堂的登记薄，我现有一份复件。理查德·梅森签字。’” “‘I affirm and can prove that on the 20th of October A.D.—(a date of fifteen years back), Edward Fairfax Rochester, of Thornfield Hall, in the county of—, and of Ferndean Manor, in-shire, England, was married to my sister, Bertha Antoinetta Mason, daughter of Jonas Mason, merchant, and of Antoinetta his wife, a Creole, at—church, Spanish Town, Jamaica.The record of the marriage will be found in the register of that church—a copy of it is now in my possession.Signed, Richard Mason.’”
“那——如果是真的文件——也只能证明我结过婚，不能证明上面提及的作为我妻子的女人还活着。” “That—if a genuine document—may prove I have been married, but it does not prove that the woman mentioned therein as my wife is still living.”
“她三个月前还活着。”律师答道。 “She was living three months ago,” returned the lawyer.
“你如何知道？” “How do you know?”
“我有此事的证人。他的证词，先生，就连你也无法辩驳。” “I have a witness to the fact, whose testimony even you, sir, will scarcely controvert.”
“带他来——要不就去死吧。” “Produce him—or go to hell.”
“我就带他来——他就在此。梅森先生，劳驾请上前来。” “I will produce him first—he is on the spot.Mr. Mason, have the goodness to step forward.”
罗切斯特先生一听到这个名字就咬紧了牙关，身体抽搐似的一阵剧烈的颤抖。我挨着他，感觉到他的身体因愤怒或绝望而痉挛般地抽动着。第二位陌生人，刚才一直在后面徘徊，此时走上前来。一张苍白的脸从律师肩头露了出来——是的，那就是梅森本人。罗切斯特先生转身怒视着他。他的眼睛，如我常说的那样，本是黑色的，此刻却有一种黄褐色，不，血红色的光呈现在其阴郁之中。他的脸通红，橄榄色的脸颊，苍白的前额，由于心火上升并扩散而泛着光。他动了动，抬起强壮的胳臂——他本可以一拳把梅森打倒在地，无情地把他打得断气，但梅森缩身闪开了，无力地叫道，“我的上帝啊！”罗切斯特先生出一种冷冷的蔑视——他的盛怒退去，如同受到重挫而束手无策。他只问了句：“你有什么要说的？” Mr. Rochester, on hearing the name, set his teeth; he experienced, too, a sort of strong convulsive quiver; near to him as I was, I felt the spasmodic movement of fury or despair run through his frame.The second stranger, who had hitherto lingered in the background, now drew near; a pale face looked over the solicitor’s shoulder—yes, it was Mason himself.Mr. Rochester turned and glared at him.His eye, as I have often said, was a black eye: it had now a tawny, nay, a bloody light in its gloom;and his face flushed—olive cheek and hueless forehead received a glow as from spreading, ascending heart-fire: and he stirred, lifted his strong arm—he could have struck Mason, dashed him on the church-floor, shocked by ruthless blow the breath from his body—but Mason shrank away, and cried faintly, “Good God!”Contempt fell cool on Mr. Rochester—his passion died as if a blight had shrivelled it up: he only asked—“What have YOU to say?”
梅森惨白的嘴唇间冒出个模糊的回答。 An inaudible reply escaped Mason’s white lips.
“你说不清楚就见鬼去吧。我再问一遍，你有什么要说的？” “The devil is in it if you cannot answer distinctly.I again demand, what have you to say?”
“先生——先生，”牧师插话道，“不要忘了你现在在一个神圣的地方。”然后又和气地问梅森，“你是不是知道，先生，这位绅士的妻子还活着？” “Sir—sir,” interrupted the clergyman, “do not forget you are in a sacred place.”Then addressing Mason, he inquired gently, “Are you aware, sir, whether or not this gentleman’s wife is still living?”
“大胆点，”律师催促他，“说出来。” “Courage,” urged the lawyer,—“speak out.”
“她现在住在桑菲尔德府里。”梅森这回说得更清楚了，“去年四月我在那儿见过她。我是她的弟弟。” “She is now living at Thornfield Hall,” said Mason, in more articulate tones: “I saw her there last April.I am her brother.”
“在桑菲尔德府！”牧师喊道，“不可能！我是这一带的老住户了，先生，从来没听说过桑菲尔德府上有位罗切斯特太太。” “At Thornfield Hall!” ejaculated the clergyman.“Impossible!I am an old resident in this neighbourhood, sir, and I never heard of a Mrs. Rochester at Thornfield Hall.”
我看见罗切斯特先生的嘴角被一丝冷酷的笑容扭曲了，他喃喃地说： I saw a grim smile contort Mr. Rochester’s lips, and he muttered—
“不，上帝作证。我小心谨慎不让任何人听说这事，或知道她有这样的名分。”他陷入沉思，自己斟酌了十分钟，下定决心，宣布道： “No, by God!I took care that none should hear of it—or of her under that name.”He mused—for ten minutes he held counsel with himself: he formed his resolve, and announced it—
“够了！把一切都说出来吧，就像子弹射出枪膛。伍德，合上你的书，脱掉你的法衣。约翰·格林（对文书说），离开教堂吧。今天不会有婚礼了。”那人照办了。 “Enough! all shall bolt out at once, like the bullet from the barrel.Wood, close your book and take off your surplice; John Green (to the clerk), leave the church: there will be no wedding today.”The man obeyed.
罗切斯特先生大胆而不顾一切地继续说：“重婚是个肮脏的字眼！然而，我偏要做一个重婚者。可惜命运胜我一筹，或者是上天阻拦了我——或许是后者。此刻我和魔鬼差不多，而且，按我这位牧师说的，我无疑应该受到上帝最严厉的审判，甚至该受到不灭之火和不死之虫的折磨。先生们，我的计划泡汤了。这位律师和他当事人所说不假：我的确结过婚，并且嫁给我的女人还活着！伍德，你说你从未听说那边府上有位罗切斯特太太，但我敢说你肯定多次听过流言，说有一个神秘的疯子关在那儿，被看守着，监视着。有人悄悄告诉过你，说她是我的私生妹妹，有人说是被我遗弃的情妇。现在我告诉你，她是我的妻子，十五年前就嫁给我的——伯莎·梅森，也就是这位勇敢人物的姐姐。他这会儿正四肢发抖，面色苍白，向你展示男人有一颗多么勇敢的心。振作点，迪克！——别怕我！——揍你简直就跟打女人一样。伯莎·梅森是个疯子，而且她来自一个疯子家庭，三代人都是白痴和疯子！她母亲，那个克里奥尔人，不仅是个疯女人，还是个酒鬼！娶了她女儿之后我才知道这些，因为他们之前对家庭秘密守口如瓶。伯莎就像个孝顺的孩子，在这两方面上都继承了她母亲的特质。我有了个迷人的配偶——纯洁、聪明、谦恭，你们可以想象我有多幸福。我经历了多么有趣的场面！噢！我的经历多么神奇，你们要知道就好了！不过我不愿再解释。布里格斯、伍德、梅森，我邀请你们到我家去，见见普尔夫人的病人，我的妻子！你们会看到我被骗娶了个什么样的人，判断一下我是否有权违背婚约，去寻求至少有点人性的人的同情。这个女孩，”他看着我，接着说道，“对这令人恶心的秘密，不比你们知道的多，伍德。她以为一切都是公正合法的，做梦都没想到会落入骗婚的圈套，嫁给一个行骗的小人，而这个卑鄙的人早就有了一个邪恶的、疯狂的、禽兽般的配偶。你们全都来——跟我走！” Mr. Rochester continued, hardily and recklessly: “Bigamy is an ugly word!—I meant, however, to be a bigamist; but fate has outmanoeuvred me, or Providence has checked me,—perhaps the last. I am little better than a devil at this moment; and, as my pastor there would tell me, deserve no doubt the sternest judgments of God, even to the quenchless fire and deathless worm.Gentlemen, my plan is broken up:—what this lawyer and his client say is true: I have been married, and the woman to whom I was married lives!You say you never heard of a Mrs. Rochester at the house up yonder, Wood; but I daresay you have many a time inclined your ear to gossip about the mysterious lunatic kept there under watch and ward.Some have whispered to you that she is my bastard half-sister: some, my castoff mistress.I now inform you that she is my wife, whom I married fifteen years ago,—Bertha Mason by name; sister of this resolute personage, who is now, with his quivering limbs and white cheeks, showing you what a stout heart men may bear.Cheer up, Dick!—never fear me!—I’d almost as soon strike a woman as you.Bertha Mason is mad; and she came of a mad family; idiots and maniacs through three generations?Her mother, the Creole, was both a madwoman and a drunkard!—as I found out after I had wed the daughter: for they were silent on family secrets before.Bertha, like a dutiful child, copied her parent in both points.I had a charming partner—pure, wise, modest: you can fancy I was a happy man.I went through rich scenes!Oh! my experience has been heavenly, if you only knew it!But I owe you no further explanation.Briggs, Wood, Mason, I invite you all to come up to the house and visit Mrs. Poole’s patient, and MY WIFE!You shall see what sort of a being I was cheated into espousing, and judge whether or not I had a right to break the compact, and seek sympathy with something at least human.This girl,” he continued, looking at me, “knew no more than you, Wood, of the disgusting secret: she thought all was fair and legal and never dreamt she was going to be entrapped into a feigned union with a defrauded wretch, already bound to a bad, mad, and embruted partner!Come all of you—follow!”
他仍然紧紧地拉着我，离开了教堂。三位先生跟在后面。我们发现马车正停在大厅前的门口。 Still holding me fast, he left the church: the three gentlemen came after.At the front door of the hall we found the carriage.
“约翰，把车拉回车库，”罗切斯特先生冷静地说，“今天不需要了。” “Take it back to the coach-house, John,” said Mr. Rochester coolly; “it will not be wanted today.”
进门时，费尔法克斯夫人、阿代勒、索菲、利娅都出来迎接我们。 At our entrance, Mrs. Fairfax, Adele, Sophie, Leah, advanced to meet and greet us.
“都回去！”主人吼道，“收起你们的祝贺！谁需要啊？我可不要！——它晚了十五年！” “To the right-about—every soul!” cried the master; “away with your congratulations!Who wants them?Not I!—they are fifteen years too late!”
他径直走进去，上了楼梯，仍然握着我的手，还招手让先生们跟着他。他们跟了上来。我们上了二楼，穿过走廊，又继续走上三楼。罗切斯特先生用那把主人的钥匙打开了那扇低矮的黑门，带我们走进那间挂着帷幔，摆着张大床，还有雕花柜子的房间。 He passed on and ascended the stairs, still holding my hand, and still beckoning the gentlemen to follow him, which they did.We mounted the first staircase, passed up the gallery, proceeded to the third storey: the low, black door, opened by Mr. Rochester’s master-key, admitted us to the tapestried room, with its great bed and its pictorial cabinet.
“你知道这地方，梅森。”我们的向导说，“她就是在这里咬了你，刺伤了你。” “You know this place, Mason,” said our guide; “she bit and stabbed you here.”
他掀起墙上的帷幔，露出第二道门，他也把它打开了。屋子里没有窗户，高大坚固的壁炉栅栏围着一炉火，天花板上用链子吊着一盏灯。格雷斯·普尔弯向炉火，似乎在用炖锅做什么吃的。房间尽头的阴影深处，有个身影在来回晃动。凭第一眼，看不出那是个动物还是个人：它看起来似乎四肢着地爬来爬去，又抓又叫，像只奇怪的野兽；但它穿着人的衣服，一头黑白相间、乱如鬃毛般的头发遮住了它的头和脸。 He lifted the hangings from the wall, uncovering the second door: this, too, he opened.In a room without a window, there burnt a fire guarded by a high and strong fender, and a lamp suspended from the ceiling by a chain.Grace Poole bent over the fire, apparently cooking something in a saucepan.In the deep shade, at the farther end of the room, a figure ran backwards and forwards.What it was, whether beast or human being, one could not, at first sight, tell: it grovelled, seemingly, on all fours; it snatched and growled like some strange wild animal: but it was covered with clothing, and a quantity of dark, grizzled hair, wild as a mane, hid its head and face.
“早上好，普尔太太！”罗切斯特先生道，“你好吗？你照管的人今天如何？” “Good-morrow, Mrs. Poole!” said Mr. Rochester.“How are you? and how is your charge today?”
“我们还过得去，先生，谢谢你。”格雷斯答道，小心翼翼地端起沸腾的一锅食物放到铁架上，“有点暴躁，但不疯癫。” “We’re tolerable, sir, I thank you,” replied Grace, lifting the boiling mess carefully on to the hob: “rather snappish, but not ’rageous.”
一声凶猛的吼叫仿佛揭穿了她的正面报告。这穿着衣服的野兽直起身，用后腿站了起来。 A fierce cry seemed to give the lie to her favourable report: the clothed hyena rose up, and stood tall on its hind-feet.
“啊！先生，她看见你了！”格雷斯叫道，“你最好别呆在这儿。” “Ah! sir, she sees you!” exclaimed Grace: “you’d better not stay.”
“就一会儿，格雷斯，你必须允许我呆一会儿。” “Only a few moments, Grace: you must allow me a few moments.”
“那小心点儿，先生！——看在上帝的份上，千万小心！” “Take care then, sir!—for God’s sake, take care!”
那个疯子吼叫着，拨开脸上蓬乱的头发，凶狠地盯着她的造访者们。我完全认出了那张紫色的脸，那肿胀的五官。普尔太太走上前。 The maniac bellowed: she parted her shaggy locks from her visage, and gazed wildly at her visitors.I recognised well that purple face,—those bloated features.Mrs. Poole advanced.
“让开。”罗切斯特先生说着，把她推到一边，“我想她现在没拿着刀，我提防着呢。” “Keep out of the way,” said Mr. Rochester, thrusting her aside: “she has no knife now, I suppose, and I’m on my guard.”
“谁知道她拿着什么呢，先生。她太狡猾了，再怎么谨慎也无法预测她的诡计。” “One never knows what she has, sir: she is so cunning: it is not in mortal discretion to fathom her craft.”
“我们最好离开她。”梅森小声说道。 “We had better leave her,” whispered Mason.
“见鬼去吧！”这就是他姐夫的劝告。 “Go to the devil!” was his brother-in-law’s recommendation.
“小心！”格雷斯喊道。三位绅士同时往后退。罗切斯特先生把我拉到他身后。那疯子跳过来，凶狠地掐住他的脖子，又咬他的脸，和他扭打起来。她是个高大的女人，几乎和他的丈夫一般高，而且还很胖。扭打中她显示出了男人似的力量——尽管罗切斯特先生有着运动员般的体格，但还是不止一次地险些被她掐死。他本可以狠狠一拳把她放倒，可他不愿出手，只是和她摔打着。最后他控制住了她的胳膊，格雷斯·普尔递给他一条绳，他从后面捆住她，又用手边另一根绳子，将她绑到一把椅子上。这一切都伴随着她疯狂的叫喊声，以及痉挛般剧烈的撞击。然后罗切斯特转过身，看着旁观者，朝他们凄凉地苦笑。 “‘Ware!” cried Grace.The three gentlemen retreated simultaneously.Mr. Rochester flung me behind him: the lunatic sprang and grappled his throat viciously, and laid her teeth to his cheek: they struggled.She was a big woman, in stature almost equalling her husband, and corpulent besides: she showed virile force in the contest—more than once she almost throttled him, athletic as he was.He could have settled her with a well-planted blow; but he would not strike: he would only wrestle.At last he mastered her arms; Grace Poole gave him a cord, and he pinioned them behind her: with more rope, which was at hand, he bound her to a chair.The operation was performed amidst the fiercest yells and the most convulsive plunges.Mr. Rochester then turned to the spectators: he looked at them with a smile both acrid and desolate.
“那就是我妻子。”他说，“这就是我所知道的夫妻之间的拥抱——这就是在我闲暇时得到的安慰与亲热！而这才是我想要的！”（把他的手放在我肩上）“这个年轻女孩，站在地狱之门，却如此严肃、宁静，如此镇定地看着魔鬼乱舞。我需要她，就像吃完那油腻的炖肉之后，需要换换口味。伍德，布里格斯，你们瞧瞧这差别！将这清澈的双眼和那边通红的眼睛比比，这个脸蛋和那副面具，这个身段和那个体积都比比。然后再审判我吧，传播福音的牧师，维护法律的人，记住，你们如何审判我，也将如何被审判！现在你们都走吧。我得把我的宝贝关起来。” “That is MY WIFE,” said he.“Such is the sole conjugal embrace I am ever to know—such are the endearments which are to solace my leisure hours!And THIS is what I wished to have” (laying his hand on my shoulder): “this young girl, who stands so grave and quiet at the mouth of hell, looking collectedly at the gambols of a demon, I wanted her just as a change after that fierce ragout.Wood and Briggs, look at the difference!Compare these clear eyes with the red balls yonder—this face with that mask—this form with that bulk; then judge me, priest of the gospel and man of the law, and remember with what judgment ye judge ye shall be judged!Off with you now.I must shut up my prize.”
我们都退了出来。罗切斯特先生在我们后面呆了一会儿，叮嘱了格雷斯·普尔几句话。下楼时，律师跟我谈话。 We all withdrew.Mr. Rochester stayed a moment behind us, to give some further order to Grace Poole.The solicitor addressed me as he descended the stair.
“你，小姐，”他说，“是无辜的。你叔叔听了会很高兴的——要是梅森先生回到马德拉的时候他还活着的话。” “You, madam,” said he, “are cleared from all blame: your uncle will be glad to hear it—if, indeed, he should be still living—when Mr. Mason returns to Madeira.”
“我叔叔！他怎么了？你认识他吗？” “My uncle! What of him? Do you know him?”
“梅森先生认识。多年来，爱先生一直和他丰沙尔多的家保持书信联系。你叔叔收到你的来信，得知你打算嫁给罗切斯特先生的时候，梅森先生正好在返回牙买加的途中，停留在马德拉养身体，恰好和他在一起。因为他知道我的当事人认识一位叫罗切斯特的绅士，爱先生就提起了这个消息。你可以想象，梅森先生听说后多么吃惊、难过，于是就把实情说了出来。非常抱歉地告诉你，你叔叔现在卧病在床，而且考虑到疾病的性质——痨病——还有患病的程度，他很可能会一病不起。他那时没法亲自赶来英国，把你从这个陷阱中解救出来，但他恳求梅森先生立即采取措施，阻止这场欺诈的婚姻。还让他向我求助。我迅速处理这件事，令人欣慰的是我来得还不太晚，想必你也有同感吧。要不是我确定你还没赶到马德拉，你叔叔可能就已经去世的话，我就会建议你和梅森先生一起回去；但既然如此，我想你最好还是留在英国，等你收到他的信，或者听说了他的消息再说吧。还有别的事需要我们再呆下去吗？”他问梅森先生。 “Mr. Mason does.Mr. Eyre has been the Funchal correspondent of his house for some years.When your uncle received your letter intimating the contemplated union between yourself and Mr. Rochester, Mr. Mason, who was staying at Madeira to recruit his health, on his way back to Jamaica, happened to be with him.Mr. Eyre mentioned the intelligence; for he knew that my client here was acquainted with a gentleman of the name of Rochester.Mr. Mason, astonished and distressed as you may suppose, revealed the real state of matters.Your uncle, I am sorry to say, is now on a sick bed; from which, considering the nature of his disease—decline—and the stage it has reached, it is unlikely he will ever rise.He could not then hasten to England himself, to extricate you from the snare into which you had fallen, but he implored Mr. Mason to lose no time in taking steps to prevent the false marriage.He referred him to me for assistance.I used all despatch, and am thankful I was not too late: as you, doubtless, must be also.Were I not morally certain that your uncle will be dead ere you reach Madeira, I would advise you to accompany Mr. Mason back; but as it is, I think you had better remain in England till you can hear further, either from or of Mr. Eyre.Have we anything else to stay for?” he inquired of Mr. Mason.
“没，没了——我们走吧。”他焦急地答道。没等向罗切斯特先生告别，二人就出了大厅的门。牧师逗留了一会儿，跟他那傲慢的教区居民交谈了几句，也许是告诫，也许是责备，完成任务后也离开了。 “No, no—let us be gone,” was the anxious reply; and without waiting to take leave of Mr. Rochester, they made their exit at the hall door.The clergyman stayed to exchange a few sentences, either of admonition or reproof, with his haughty parishioner; this duty done, he too departed.
我站在自己房间半掩着的门边，听见他走了，才退回到房间里。家里清净了，我关上房门，插好门闩，以免有人闯入，然后开始——不是哭泣，也不是哀伤，我还很镇定，不至于这样，而是——机械地脱掉结婚礼服，换上我昨天穿的呢料裙，我曾以为那是最后一次穿它。然后我坐下来，感到虚弱而疲倦。我把双臂靠在桌子上，撑住脑袋。现在我可以思考了：刚才只是听、看、动——被人领着或拖着上上下下——目睹一件事推动着另一件事，一个秘密揭露着另一个秘密。但现在，我要思考。 I heard him go as I stood at the half-open door of my own room, to which I had now withdrawn.The house cleared, I shut myself in, fastened the bolt that none might intrude, and proceeded—not to weep, not to mourn, I was yet too calm for that, but—mechanically to take off the wedding dress, and replace it by the stuff gown I had worn yesterday, as I thought, for the last time.I then sat down: I felt weak and tired.I leaned my arms on a table, and my head dropped on them.And now I thought: till now I had only heard, seen, moved—followed up and down where I was led or dragged—watched event rush on event, disclosure open beyond disclosure: but NOW, I THOUGHT.
这是个足够宁静的早晨——除了疯子那短暂的一幕。教堂里那一幕也没有喧闹，没有怒气勃发，没有大声争吵，没有辩论，没有反抗或挑战，没有眼泪，没有啜泣：只说了几句话，只有心平气和的反对这场婚姻的宣告。罗切斯特先生也只提了几个严厉、简短的问题，接着是对方的回答、解释、举证。我的主人公开说出真相，然后我们看到了活生生的证据。闯入者走了，一切都结束了。 The morning had been a quiet morning enough—all except the brief scene with the lunatic: the transaction in the church had not been noisy; there was no explosion of passion, no loud altercation, no dispute, no defiance or challenge, no tears, no sobs: a few words had been spoken, a calmly pronounced objection to the marriage made;some stern, short questions put by Mr. Rochester; answers, explanations given, evidence adduced; an open admission of the truth had been uttered by my master; then the living proof had been seen; the intruders were gone, and all was over.
我和往常一样在自己房间里——只有我自己，没有什么明显的变化，没什么东西打击我、损伤我、残害我。但昨天的那个简·爱去哪儿了？——她的生活在哪儿？——她的期望又在哪儿？ I was in my own room as usual—just myself, without obvious change: nothing had smitten me, or scathed me, or maimed me.And yet where was the Jane Eyre of yesterday?—where was her life?—where were her prospects?
简·爱，一个曾经充满热情、满怀期望的女人——还差点做了新娘，又成了个冷漠孤独的女孩。她的生命惨白，前程一片荒芜。就如盛夏遭遇了圣诞的严寒；六月天卷起了十二月的暴风雪；成熟的苹果被冰凌上釉；盛开的玫瑰被积雪摧残；干草地和玉米田盖上了一层冰冻的寿衣。昨晚还鲜花盛开的小路，今天却被无人踩踏的白雪所覆盖。十二小时之前还枝繁叶茂、散发着芳香、犹如热带丛林一般的树林，此刻却蔓延着一片荒芜、野蛮的景象，白茫茫的一片，犹如挪威冬天的松树林。我所有的希望都破碎了——遭到厄运微妙的一击，正如一夜之间，灾难降临于埃及所有的长子。我看着我所珍视的希望，昨天还那么生机勃勃、容光焕发，今天却成为僵硬、冰冷、青灰色的、无法复活的尸体。我审视着我的爱情，这属于我主人的感情——他创造了它。它在我心中颤抖，犹如在冰冷的摇篮中受苦的婴儿。疾病与痛苦缠绕着它，它却不能寻求罗切斯特先生的怀抱——无法从他的胸膛得到温暖。噢，它再也不能求助于他了，因为忠诚已被扼杀，信任已被摧毁！罗切斯特先生对我来说已不再是往日的他，因为他不再是我想象中的那个他了。我并不愿怪罪于他，也不愿说他背叛了我，但他的思想已不再是纯洁无暇的真实。有他在场，我必须走，这一点我很清楚。什么时候，怎么走，去哪里，我还不清楚。但他自己，我毫不怀疑，肯定会急着把我从桑菲尔德赶走。似乎他不可能对我怀有真情，这只不过是一时的激情而已。而这激情受到阻碍，他将不会再想要我了。我现在甚至怕从他面前经过，我的出现肯定让他厌恶。噢，我的眼睛真是瞎了！我的行为真是软弱！ Jane Eyre, who had been an ardent, expectant woman—almost a bride, was a cold, solitary girl again: her life was pale; her prospects were desolate.A Christmas frost had come at midsummer; a white December storm had whirled over June; ice glazed the ripe apples, drifts crushed the blowing roses; on hayfield and cornfield lay a frozen shroud: lanes which last night blushed full of flowers, today were pathless with untrodden snow;and the woods, which twelve hours since waved leafy and flagrant as groves between the tropics, now spread, waste, wild, and white as pine-forests in wintry Norway.My hopes were all dead—struck with a subtle doom, such as, in one night, fell on all the first-born in the land of Egypt.I looked on my cherished wishes, yesterday so blooming and glowing; they lay stark, chill, livid corpses that could never revive.I looked at my love: that feeling which was my master’s—which he had created; it shivered in my heart, like a suffering child in a cold cradle; sickness and anguish had seized it; it could not seek Mr. Rochester’s arms—it could not derive warmth from his breast.Oh, never more could it turn to him; for faith was blighted—confidence destroyed!Mr. Rochester was not to me what he had been; for he was not what I had thought him.I would not ascribe vice to him; I would not say he had betrayed me; but the attribute of stainless truth was gone from his idea, and from his presence I must go: THAT I perceived well.When—how—whither, I could not yet discern; but he himself, I doubted not, would hurry me from Thornfield.Real affection, it seemed, he could not have for me; it had been only fitful passion: that was balked; he would want me no more.I should fear even to cross his path now: my view must be hateful to him.Oh, how blind had been my eyes!How weak my conduct!
我的眼睛被蒙起来，闭上了。黑暗的漩涡仿佛在我四周流动，思绪如同黑色混沌的涌流奔腾而来。自暴自弃、松懈、消极，我好像是把自己搁置在一条大河干涸的河床上；我听到一股洪流从远处的大山里倾泻而出，感觉到那急流就要逼近；想起身又缺乏意志，想逃跑又没有力量。我昏昏沉沉地躺着，渴望死去。只有一个念头还有点儿活力，在我心头跳动——我想到了上帝，这引起了我无声的祈祷。这些祷告在我昏暗的心中上下游荡，就像是某些应该低声说出却又无力表达的话语： My eyes were covered and closed: eddying darkness seemed to swim round me, and reflection came in as black and confused a flow.Self-abandoned, relaxed, and effortless, I seemed to have laid me down in the dried-up bed of a great river; I heard a flood loosened in remote mountains, and felt the torrent come: to rise I had no will, to flee I had no strength.I lay faint, longing to be dead.One idea only still throbbed life-like within me—a remembrance of God: it begot an unuttered prayer: these words went wandering up and down in my rayless mind, as something that should be whispered, but no energy was found to express them—
“不要远离我，因为灾难临近，没人帮我。” “Be not far from me, for trouble is near: there is none to help.”
灾难临近了，我并没有祈求上天将其避免——因为我没有合十双手，没有弯曲双膝，也没有蠕动双唇。它来了，翻滚着巨浪，倾泄于我。我意识到自己孤寂的生活，丢失的爱情，破灭的希望，遭到致命打击的信念：这所有的意识阴沉沉的，形成一团，在我头顶极力地推波助澜。那痛苦的时刻无法形容，真的是“大水灌入我的灵魂；我深陷泥潭；我无法立足；坠入深渊；洪水将我淹没。” It was near: and as I had lifted no petition to Heaven to avert it—as I had neither joined my hands, nor bent my knees, nor moved my lips—it came: in full heavy swing the torrent poured over me.The whole consciousness of my life lorn, my love lost, my hope quenched, my faith death-struck, swayed full and mighty above me in one sullen mass.That bitter hour cannot be described: in truth, “the waters came into my soul; I sank in deep mire: I felt no standing; I came into deep waters; the floods overflowed me.”
第二十七章 CHAPTER XXVII
下午不知什么时候，我抬起头，四处看了看，发现夕阳正在墙上镀着落日的余辉。我问自己：“我该怎么办？” Some time in the afternoon I raised my head, and looking round and seeing the western sun gilding the sign of its decline on the wall, I asked, “What am I to do?”
可我脑中回答——“立刻离开桑菲尔德”——如此迅速，如此可怕，我连忙堵住了耳朵。我说我现在还忍受不了这些。“不能做爱德华·罗切斯特的新娘只是我痛苦中的最小部分。”我称道，“从最华丽的梦中醒来，发现一切都是虚无缥缈的，这种恐惧我还能够承受、克服。可是要我果断、立即、彻底地离开他，却是我无法忍受的。我做不到。” But the answer my mind gave—“Leave Thornfield at once”—was so prompt, so dread, that I stopped my ears.I said I could not bear such words now.“That I am not Edward Rochester’s bride is the least part of my woe,” I alleged: “that I have wakened out of most glorious dreams, and found them all void and vain, is a horror I could bear and master; but that I must leave him decidedly, instantly, entirely, is intolerable. I cannot do it.”
但那时，心中有一个声音坚称我做得到，还预言我应该这么做。我的内心在挣扎着，我想变得软弱，或许可以避免眼前更多的痛苦。而良心却变为暴君，掐住激情的脖颈，嘲弄地说，她只不过把自己美丽的脚在泥沼中蘸了一下，还发誓要用他铁一般的臂膀将她抛下深不可测的痛苦的深渊。 But, then, a voice within me averred that I could do it and foretold that I should do it.I wrestled with my own resolution: I wanted to be weak that I might avoid the awful passage of further suffering I saw laid out for me; and Conscience, turned tyrant, held Passion by the throat, told her tauntingly, she had yet but dipped her dainty foot in the slough, and swore that with that arm of iron he would thrust her down to unsounded depths of agony.
“把我拉走吧，”我喊道，“让人帮帮我吧！” “Let me be torn away,” then I cried.“Let another help me!”
“不，你必须自己挣脱，没人会帮你。你必须自己挖出你的右眼，砍掉你的右手；你的心将会是牺牲品，而你要做祭司，将它刺穿。” “No; you shall tear yourself away, none shall help you: you shall yourself pluck out your right eye; yourself cut off your right hand: your heart shall be the victim, and you the priest to transfix it.”
我突然起身，害怕在孤独中被这么一位如此无情的法官纠缠，害怕一个如此可怕的声音充斥着这寂静。我站直后感到天旋地转。我发现自己是由于情绪激动、营养不足而有些病怏怏的。这一天我一顿饭都没吃，一口水也没喝，因为我连早饭都没吃。而且，我现在才想起来，我把自己关在这里这么久，却没人来过问，或请我下楼，甚至连小阿代勒也没来敲门，费尔法克斯太太也没来找我，心中一阵莫名的剧痛。“朋友总是忘记那些被命运抛弃的人。”我喃喃道，打开门闩往外走。我被一个东西绊了一下，由于仍然头晕眼花，四肢无力，没能立即缓过神来。 I rose up suddenly, terror-struck at the solitude which so ruthless a judge haunted,—at the silence which so awful a voice filled.My head swam as I stood erect.I perceived that I was sickening from excitement and inanition; neither meat nor drink had passed my lips that day, for I had taken no breakfast.And, with a strange pang, I now reflected that, long as I had been shut up here, no message had been sent to ask how I was, or to invite me to come down: not even little Adele had tapped at the door; not even Mrs. Fairfax had sought me.“Friends always forget those whom fortune forsakes,” I murmured, as I undrew the bolt and passed out.I stumbled over an obstacle: my head was still dizzy, my sight was dim, and my limbs were feeble. I could not soon recover myself.
我跌倒了，但没倒在地上——一只伸出的胳膊抓住了我。我抬眼望去——是罗切斯特先生，他坐在我房间门口对面的一把椅子上。 I fell, but not on to the ground: an outstretched arm caught me.I looked up—I was supported by Mr. Rochester, who sat in a chair across my chamber threshold.
“你终于出来了。”他说，“唔，我等了你好久了，而且一直在听，可一点动静都没有，也没有哭泣声。那死一般的沉寂再多持续五分钟，我就要像窃贼般破门而入了。那你是在躲我吗？你把自己关起来独自伤心！我宁愿你出来痛骂我一顿。你是个性情中人。我还想着会有什么样的场景呢。我准备迎接你的热泪滂沱，但只想让它们洒在我的胸膛；现在却是无知觉的地板接收了它们，要么就是你湿透了的手绢。但我错了：你根本没哭！我看到了苍白的脸庞和暗淡的眼神，但没有泪痕。那么，我想，你的心一直在流血吧？” “You come out at last,” he said.“Well, I have been waiting for you long, and listening: yet not one movement have I heard, nor one sob: five minutes more of that death-like hush, and I should have forced the lock like a burglar.So you shun me?—you shut yourself up and grieve alone!I would rather you had come and upbraided me with vehemence.You are passionate.I expected a scene of some kind.I was prepared for the hot rain of tears; only I wanted them to be shed on my breast: now a senseless floor has received them, or your drenched handkerchief.But I err: you have not wept at all!I see a white cheek and a faded eye, but no trace of tears.I suppose, then, your heart has been weeping blood?”
“啊，简！一句责骂也没有吗？没有尖酸、辛辣的言词辞？没有伤害感情或刺激情绪的话吗？你就这么静静地坐在我让你坐下的地方，用这种厌烦、消沉的表情看着我。” “Well, Jane! not a word of reproach?Nothing bitter—nothing poignant?Nothing to cut a feeling or sting a passion?You sit quietly where I have placed you, and regard me with a weary, passive look.”
“简，我从来没想要这样伤害你。如果一个人有一只亲如女儿的小母羊，让它吃他口中的面包，喝他杯中的清水，放它在他怀里，却因一时的错误，在屠宰场杀了它，那他面对这血淋淋的大错所感到的懊悔也不及我现在的深。你会原谅我吗？” “Jane, I never meant to wound you thus.If the man who had but one little ewe lamb that was dear to him as a daughter, that ate of his bread and drank of his cup, and lay in his bosom, had by some mistake slaughtered it at the shambles, he would not have rued his bloody blunder more than I now rue mine.Will you ever forgive me?”
读者啊，我在那一刻当场就原谅了他。他眼里充满深深的懊悔，语气里充满诚挚的遗憾，举止充满男子汉的气概。不仅如此，他的整个面容和态度都流露出不变的爱意——我完全原谅了他，但并没有用言语表达出来，只是藏在了我的心灵深处。 Reader, I forgave him at the moment and on the spot.There was such deep remorse in his eye, such true pity in his tone, such manly energy in his manner; and besides, there was such unchanged love in his whole look and mien—I forgave him all: yet not in words, not outwardly; only at my heart’s core.
“你认为我是个无赖吗，简？”过了一会儿，他又渴望地问道——我想他大概是在奇怪我一直都很沉默、温驯，看起来像是软弱的表现而不是意志力的体现。 “You know I am a scoundrel, Jane?” ere long he inquired wistfully—wondering, I suppose, at my continued silence and tameness, the result rather of weakness than of will.
“是的，先生。” “Yes, sir.”
“那就直白尖锐地告诉我——不要饶恕我。” “Then tell me so roundly and sharply—don’t spare me.”
“我不能，我很累，很不舒服。我想喝水。”他发出一声颤抖的叹息，把我搂入怀中，抱我下楼。开始我不知道他把我抱到了哪个房间，我模糊的视线里一切都是混沌的。不久我感觉到了炉火那令人振作的温暖，因为虽然是夏天，我在自己房里却早已冻得浑身冰凉。他把酒送到我嘴边，我喝了一口，清醒了些。然后又吃了些他递上的食物，很快就恢复了过来。我在藏书室，坐在他的椅子上，他就在身边。“如果我现在就能去死，没有剧痛，那该多好。”我想，“那我就不用费劲扯断与罗切斯特先生息息相关的心弦。看来，我必须离开他。可我不想离开她——我离不开他。” “I cannot: I am tired and sick.I want some water.”He heaved a sort of shuddering sigh, and taking me in his arms, carried me downstairs.At first I did not know to what room he had borne me; all was cloudy to my glazed sight: presently I felt the reviving warmth of a fire; for, summer as it was, I had become icy cold in my chamber.He put wine to my lips; I tasted it and revived; then I ate something he offered me, and was soon myself.I was in the library—sitting in his chair—he was quite near.“If I could go out of life now, without too sharp a pang, it would be well for me,” I thought; “then I should not have to make the effort of cracking my heart-strings in rending them from among Mr. Rochester’s.I must leave him, it appears.I do not want to leave him—I cannot leave him.”
“你现在怎么样，简？”“好多了，先生，很快就没事了。” “How are you now, Jane?”“Much better, sir; I shall be well soon.”
“再喝口酒，简。” “Taste the wine again, Jane.”
我听了他的话。然后他把杯子放到桌子上，站在我面前，专注地看着我。他突然转身，口齿不清地喊了句什么，充满了某种激情。他快步穿过房间又返回来，朝我弯下腰，像是要吻我，但我想到现在爱抚已经被禁止。我转过脸去，将他推开。 I obeyed him; then he put the glass on the table, stood before me, and looked at me attentively.Suddenly he turned away, with an inarticulate exclamation, full of passionate emotion of some kind; he walked fast through the room and came back; he stooped towards me as if to kiss me; but I remembered caresses were now forbidden.I turned my face away and put his aside.
“怎么！这什么意思？”他急忙喊道，“噢，我知道了！你不愿亲吻伯莎·梅森的丈夫？你以为我怀里已经有人，拥抱已被占据了吗？” “What!—How is this?” he exclaimed hastily.“Oh, I know! you won’t kiss the husband of Bertha Mason?You consider my arms filled and my embraces appropriated?”
“不论如何，那里没有我的地方，我也没有要求的权利了，先生。” “At any rate, there is neither room nor claim for me, sir.”
“为什么，简？不用你费力讲出来，我帮你回答吧——因为我已经有妻子了，你会这么回答。我猜得对吗？” “Why, Jane?I will spare you the trouble of much talking; I will answer for you—Because I have a wife already, you would reply.—I guess rightly?”
“是的。” “Yes.”
“你若这么想，那肯定是对我有偏见。你肯定把我当作一个心怀诡计的浪荡子——一个卑鄙、粗俗的流氓，一直假装怀有无私的爱，好把你拖进设计好的陷阱，剥夺你的名誉，掠夺你的自尊。你对此有何意见？我想你无话可说。首先你还很虚弱，呼吸都困难。其次，你还不习惯于指责我、谩骂我。而且，眼泪的闸门已经打开，要是你说得太多，泪水就会冲出来。你不愿劝诫、责骂，大闹一场，你在想如何装作说话，而那正是你认为无用的。我了解你——我也防备着。” “If you think so, you must have a strange opinion of me; you must regard me as a plotting profligate—a base and low rake who has been simulating disinterested love in order to draw you into a snare deliberately laid, and strip you of honour and rob you of self-respect.What do you say to that?I see you can say nothing in the first place, you are faint still, and have enough to do to draw your breath; in the second place, you cannot yet accustom yourself to accuse and revile me, and besides, the flood-gates of tears are opened, and they would rush out if you spoke much;and you have no desire to expostulate, to upbraid, to make a scene: you are thinking how TO ACT—TALKING you consider is of no use.I know you—I am on my guard.”
“先生，我不想跟你作对。”我说，我颤抖的声音警告我要长话短说。 “Sir, I do not wish to act against you,” I said; and my unsteady voice warned me to curtail my sentence.
“不按你的字义说，而按我的字义，你是在策划毁灭我。你已经说了我是个已婚男人——作为一个已婚男人你应该回避我，躲开我，刚才你就已经拒绝吻我。你打算把自己弄成一个完全陌的生人，只是作为阿代勒的家庭教师，住在这个屋檐下。假如我对你说一句友好的话，假如你对我再产生一点友好的感情，你就会说：‘那人差点让我做了他的情妇，我必须对他冷若冰霜，硬如岩石。’于是你就会真的变成那样。” “Not in your sense of the word, but in mine you are scheming to destroy me.You have as good as said that I am a married man—as a married man you will shun me, keep out of my way: just now you have refused to kiss me.You intend to make yourself a complete stranger to me: to live under this roof only as Adele’s governess; if ever I say a friendly word to you, if ever a friendly feeling inclines you again to me, you will say,—‘That man had nearly made me his mistress: I must be ice and rock to him;’ and ice and rock you will accordingly become.”
我清了清嗓子，使声音稳定下来，答道：“我的处境全变了，先生，我也必须改变——这一点毫无疑问。为了避免感情波动，避免与回忆和联想的持续斗争，只有一条出路——阿代勒得请一位新的家庭教师，先生。” I cleared and steadied my voice to reply: “All is changed about me, sir; I must change too—there is no doubt of that; and to avoid fluctuations of feeling, and continual combats with recollections and associations, there is only one way—Adele must have a new governess, sir.”
“噢，阿代勒会去上学，我已经决定了。我也不愿用桑菲尔德府丑恶的联想和回忆来折磨你。这个该诅咒的地方，这个亚干的帐篷，这个傲慢的坟墓，向着开阔的天空露出活死人的恐怖样子；这狭窄的石头地狱，有一个真正的魔鬼，比我们想象中的诸多魔鬼还要可恶。简，你不能再住在这儿了，我也不能。我把你带到桑菲尔德来就是个错误，我明知这里闹鬼还这么做。我见你之前就让他们瞒着你，不让你知道这里所有的诅咒。就因为我怕如果家庭教师知道她和一个什么样的人住在同一所房子里，阿代勒就永远不会有老师了。此外，我的计划不允许我将那疯子挪到别处——虽然我还有座芬丁庄园，那里比这里更加幽静、隐蔽。我本可以把她更安全地安置在那里，但考虑到那里位于森林中央，环境不卫生，我的良心才打消了这样的安排。或许那儿潮湿的墙壁很快就会帮我摆脱她这个包袱，但每个坏人都有自己的恶行，而我的并不是企图间接谋杀，即使那是我最恨的人。 “Oh, Adele will go to school—I have settled that already; nor do I mean to torment you with the hideous associations and recollections of Thornfield Hall—this accursed place—this tent of Achan—this insolent vault, offering the ghastliness of living death to the light of the open sky—this narrow stone hell, with its one real fiend, worse than a legion of such as we imagine.Jane, you shall not stay here, nor will I.I was wrong ever to bring you to Thornfield Hall, knowing as I did how it was haunted.I charged them to conceal from you, before I ever saw you, all knowledge of the curse of the place; merely because I feared Adele never would have a governess to stay if she knew with what inmate she was housed, and my plans would not permit me to remove the maniac elsewhere—though I possess an old house, Ferndean Manor, even more retired and hidden than this, where I could have lodged her safely enough, had not a scruple about the unhealthiness of the situation, in the heart of a wood, made my conscience recoil from the arrangement.Probably those damp walls would soon have eased me of her charge: but to each villain his own vice; and mine is not a tendency to indirect assassination, even of what I most hate.
“然而，对你隐瞒这疯女人在这里的住处，就像用斗篷盖上个孩子，把它放到见血封喉的树下。那个魔鬼的四周全都下了毒，而且一向如此。但我要关闭桑菲尔德，我要钉死前门，用木板盖上底层窗户，我要给普尔太太两百镑的年薪，让她在这儿和我妻子——你对那可怕的巫婆的称呼——住在一起。格雷斯为了钱可以做很多事，她可以让她儿子，格里姆斯比收容所的管家，来陪她，让他在我妻子发狂的时候帮她一把。她发病的时候就会受到妖精的驱使，晚上放火烧床上睡觉的人、拿刀刺人、把人身上的肉从骨头上咬下来等等——” “Concealing the mad-woman’s neighbourhood from you, however, was something like covering a child with a cloak and laying it down near a upas-tree: that demon’s vicinage is poisoned, and always was.But I’ll shut up Thornfield Hall: I’ll nail up the front door and board the lower windows: I’ll give Mrs. Poole two hundred a year to live here with MY WIFE, as you term that fearful hag:Grace will do much for money, and she shall have her son, the keeper at Grimsby Retreat, to bear her company and be at hand to give her aid in the paroxysms, when MY WIFE is prompted by her familiar to burn people in their beds at night, to stab them, to bite their flesh from their bones, and so on—”
“先生，”我打断了他，“你对那位不幸的夫人太无情了。你说起她就带着憎恨，怀着报复性的厌恶心理。这很残忍——她发疯也是不得已。” “Sir,” I interrupted him, “you are inexorable for that unfortunate lady: you speak of her with hate—with vindictive antipathy.It is cruel—she cannot help being mad.”
“简，我的小宝贝（我要这么叫你，因为你就是），你不知道你自己在说什么，你又错怪我了。不是因为她疯了我才恨她。如果你疯了，你认为我会恨你吗？” “Jane, my little darling (so I will call you, for so you are), you don’t know what you are talking about; you misjudge me again: it is not because she is mad I hate her.If you were mad, do you think I should hate you?”
“我想会的，先生。” “I do indeed, sir.”
“那你就错了，你根本不了解我，根本不了解我怀着何种的爱。你身上的每一寸肌肤都如同我自己的一样珍贵，痛苦疾病之时也同样珍贵。你的心是我的宝贝，即使碎了也仍然是。如果你胡言乱语，我的胳膊会搂着你，而不用什么紧身马甲。即使你发怒时胡乱抓打，对我也有吸引力。如果你像那女人今天早上那样对我猛烈攻击，我会拥抱你，至少爱意与限制一样多。我不会像对她那样厌恶地躲开你。你安静的时候，不会有什么看守、护士，只会有我。我会用不知疲倦的柔情包裹你，尽管你不会回报我以微笑；我会永不厌烦地凝视着你的眼睛，尽管它们已不再认识我。——但我为什么要顺着这个念头想呢？我刚才在说要你离开桑菲尔德的事。你知道，一切快速出发的准备都已经做好了，明天你就走吧。我只请求你在这房子里再忍受一夜，简。然后就和这里的痛苦和恐怖永远再见。我自有去处，那是个安全的避难所，可以避开可憎的回忆，避开不受欢迎的侵扰——甚至可以避开谎言和诽谤。” “Then you are mistaken, and you know nothing about me, and nothing about the sort of love of which I am capable.Every atom of your flesh is as dear to me as my own: in pain and sickness it would still be dear.Your mind is my treasure, and if it were broken, it would be my treasure still: if you raved, my arms should confine you, and not a strait waistcoat—your grasp, even in fury, would have a charm for me: if you flew at me as wildly as that woman did this morning, I should receive you in an embrace, at least as fond as it would be restrictive.I should not shrink from you with disgust as I did from her: in your quiet moments you should have no watcher and no nurse but me; and I could hang over you with untiring tenderness, though you gave me no smile in return; and never weary of gazing into your eyes, though they had no longer a ray of recognition for me.—But why do I follow that train of ideas?I was talking of removing you from Thornfield.All, you know, is prepared for prompt departure: tomorrow you shall go.I only ask you to endure one more night under this roof, Jane; and then, farewell to its miseries and terrors for ever!I have a place to repair to, which will be a secure sanctuary from hateful reminiscences, from unwelcome intrusion—even from falsehood and slander.”
“那带上阿代勒吧，先生，”我插话道，“她可以和你作伴。” “And take Adele with you, sir,” I interrupted; “she will be a companion for you.”
“你是什么意思，简？我告诉你了我要送阿代勒去上学，而且我为什么要个孩子作伴，还不是我自己的孩子——一个法国舞女的私生子？你为什么拿她来强求我！我说，你为什么要指定阿代勒来给我作伴？” “What do you mean, Jane?I told you I would send Adele to school; and what do I want with a child for a companion, and not my own child,—a French dancer’s bastard?Why do you importune me about her!I say, why do you assign Adele to me for a companion?”
“你说到了隐居，先生。隐居和孤独都很乏味，对你而言太乏味了。” “You spoke of a retirement, sir; and retirement and solitude are dull: too dull for you.”
“孤独！孤独！”他恼怒地重复着，“看来我必须得解释一下了。我不知道你脸上露出的难解的表情是什么。你要分担我的孤独。明白吗？” “Solitude! solitude!” he reiterated with irritation.“I see I must come to an explanation.I don’t know what sphynx-like expression is forming in your countenance.You are to share my solitude.Do you understand?”
我摇摇头，他变得激动起来，我甚至连冒险表示一下无声的否定，都需要相当的勇气。他在屋子里快步走着，然后停了下来，就像突然在某一点生了根。他使劲看了我很久，我转过脸，盯着炉火，尽量表现出并保持着一种平静、镇定的样子。 I shook my head: it required a degree of courage, excited as he was becoming, even to risk that mute sign of dissent.He had been walking fast about the room, and he stopped, as if suddenly rooted to one spot.He looked at me long and hard: I turned my eyes from him, fixed them on the fire, and tried to assume and maintain a quiet, collected aspect.
“至于简的性格障碍，”他终于说道，语气比我从他的神态中料想的冷静得多，“这丝线到目前为止还算绕得顺利，但我早知道它会打结、混乱。这就是了：现在是焦躁、愤怒和无尽的烦恼！天哪！我真想使出参孙的一分力量，扯开这纠缠的乱麻！” “Now for the hitch in Jane’s character,” he said at last, speaking more calmly than from his look I had expected him to speak.“The reel of silk has run smoothly enough so far; but I always knew there would come a knot and a puzzle: here it is.Now for vexation, and exasperation, and endless trouble!By God! I long to exert a fraction of Samson’s strength, and break the entanglement like tow!”
他又开始走动，但很快又停下了，这次正好停在我面前。 He recommenced his walk, but soon again stopped, and this time just before me.
