“简！听听原由好吗？”他弯腰将嘴凑近我耳朵说，“因为，如果你不肯，我就要使用暴力了。”他声音嘶哑，神态就像一个将要冲破难以忍受的束缚之人，不顾一切地发泼撒野。我知道再多一刻，再多一分暴怒的冲动，我就会拿他毫无办法。此刻，刚刚过去的瞬间，是我所有能控制、约束他的时候——任何一个厌恶、逃避、害怕的举动都会注定我的命运，还有他的命运。然而我并不害怕，一点也不。我感到内心有一股力量，一种气势在支撑着我。紧急关头虽然危险，却也并非没有迷人之处，或许就如印第安人在他的独木舟中感受激流滑行。我握住他攥紧的拳头，掰开他扭曲的手指，安慰他说： “Jane! will you hear reason?” (he stooped and approached his lips to my ear); “because, if you won’t, I’ll try violence.”His voice was hoarse; his look that of a man who is just about to burst an insufferable bond and plunge headlong into wild license.I saw that in another moment, and with one impetus of frenzy more, I should be able to do nothing with him.The present—the passing second of time—was all I had in which to control and restrain him—a movement of repulsion, flight, fear would have sealed my doom,—and his.But I was not afraid: not in the least.I felt an inward power; a sense of influence, which supported me.The crisis was perilous; but not without its charm: such as the Indian, perhaps, feels when he slips over the rapid in his canoe.I took hold of his clenched hand, loosened the contorted fingers, and said to him, soothingly—
“坐下吧。我愿意和你谈，你想谈多久就多久。你想说什么，我都会听你说，不管有理没理。” “Sit down; I’ll talk to you as long as you like, and hear all you have to say, whether reasonable or unreasonable.”
他坐下来，但没能立即开口。我已经强忍着泪水有些时候了，我痛苦地克制着它们，因为我知道他不愿看我哭。然而此刻，我认为可以让它们尽情地流下来，想流多久就流多久。如果泪水惹恼他，那更好。于是我便不再克制，尽情地哭了起来。 He sat down: but he did not get leave to speak directly.I had been struggling with tears for some time: I had taken great pains to repress them, because I knew he would not like to see me weep.Now, however, I considered it well to let them flow as freely and as long as they liked.If the flood annoyed him, so much the better.So I gave way and cried heartily.
很快我就听到他真诚地恳求我镇定下来。我说他都那么愤怒，我无法镇定。 Soon I heard him earnestly entreating me to be composed.I said I could not while he was in such a passion.
“但我没有生气，简，我只是太爱你了。刚才你那苍白的小脸蛋冷酷如铁，那么坚决、冰冷，我忍受不了。现在安静下来吧，擦擦眼睛。” “But I am not angry, Jane: I only love you too well; and you had steeled your little pale face with such a resolute, frozen look, I could not endure it.Hush, now, and wipe your eyes.”
他柔和的声音表明他已经被征服了，于是我也就镇定了下来。现在他试图把头靠在我肩上，但我不许。然后他又想把我拉过去，我还是不许。 His softened voice announced that he was subdued; so I, in my turn, became calm.Now he made an effort to rest his head on my shoulder, but I would not permit it.Then he would draw me to him: no.
“简！简！”他叫着，语气里透着如此的悲痛，使我的每根神经都震颤起来，“这么说你不爱我了吗？你看重的只是我的地位和我妻子的头衔？现在你觉得我没有资格做你丈夫了，所以我一碰你，你就往后缩，好像我是什么癞蛤蟆或猿猴似的。” “Jane! Jane!” he said, in such an accent of bitter sadness it thrilled along every nerve I had; “you don’t love me, then?It was only my station, and the rank of my wife, that you valued?Now that you think me disqualified to become your husband, you recoil from my touch as if I were some toad or ape.”
这些话刺伤了我，但我能做什么，或者能说什么呢？也许我应该什么也不做，什么也不说。可是被伤害他感情的罪恶感如此折磨着，我无法克制想在自己造成的创伤处涂上药膏的渴望。 These words cut me: yet what could I do or I say?I ought probably to have done or said nothing; but I was so tortured by a sense of remorse at thus hurting his feelings, I could not control the wish to drop balm where I had wounded.
“我确实爱你，”我说，“超出任何时候。但我不能表达或放纵这种感情，这是我最后一次表白了。” “I DO love you,” I said, “more than ever: but I must not show or indulge the feeling: and this is the last time I must express it.”
“最后一次，简！什么！你以为跟我一起生活，天天见面，而且，假如你依然爱我，却还能保持冷淡和距离吗？” “The last time, Jane!What! do you think you can live with me, and see me daily, and yet, if you still love me, be always cold and distant?”
“不，先生，我肯定不能。所以我想只有一条出路，但如果我说出来，你会暴怒的。” “No, sir; that I am certain I could not; and therefore I see there is but one way: but you will be furious if I mention it.”
“噢，说吧！如果我大发雷霆，你还有哭的本事呢。” “Oh, mention it!If I storm, you have the art of weeping.”
“罗切斯特先生，我必须离开你。” “Mr. Rochester, I must leave you.”
“多久，简？几分钟吧。梳梳你的头发——有点乱了；洗洗脸——看上去烧得通红？” “For how long, Jane?For a few minutes, while you smooth your hair—which is somewhat dishevelled; and bathe your face—which looks feverish?”
“我必须离开阿代勒和桑菲尔德。我必须永远离开你。我必须在陌生的面孔和环境中开始新的生活。” “I must leave Adele and Thornfield.I must part with you for my whole life: I must begin a new existence among strange faces and strange scenes.”
“当然，我说过了你应该如此。我不听你那离开我的疯话。你的意思是你必须成为我的一部分。至于新生活，那很好。你还是要成为我的妻子，我还没结婚。你将成为罗切斯特太太——事实上和名义上都是。只要你我还活着，我就只与你相守。你要去法国南部的一个地方，我在地中海海岸的一幢白色别墅。你在那儿将过上幸福的、受保护的、最纯洁的生活。别担心我要引诱你犯错——做我的情妇。你为什么摇头？简，你得讲理，要不我真的又要发疯了。” “Of course: I told you you should.I pass over the madness about parting from me.You mean you must become a part of me.As to the new existence, it is all right: you shall yet be my wife: I am not married.You shall be Mrs. Rochester—both virtually and nominally.I shall keep only to you so long as you and I live.You shall go to a place I have in the south of France: a whitewashed villa on the shores of the Mediterranean.There you shall live a happy, and guarded, and most innocent life.Never fear that I wish to lure you into error—to make you my mistress.Why did you shake your head?Jane, you must be reasonable, or in truth I shall again become frantic.”
他的声音和手都在颤抖，大鼻孔张得更大了，眼睛发光，但我还是敢说话。 His voice and hand quivered: his large nostrils dilated; his eye blazed: still I dared to speak.
“先生，你妻子还活着，这是你今天早上亲自承认的事实。如果我如你所愿与你共同生活，我就成了你的情妇。其他说法都是诡辩，是谎言。” “Sir, your wife is living: that is a fact acknowledged this morning by yourself.If I lived with you as you desire, I should then be your mistress: to say otherwise is sophistical—is false.”
“简，我不是个好脾气的人，你忘了这一点。我没有耐性，我不够冷静，不是公正无私。可怜可怜我，可怜可怜你自己，把你的手指放在我的脉搏上，感受它的跳动，而且——当心！” “Jane, I am not a gentle-tempered man—you forget that: I am not long-enduring; I am not cool and dispassionate.Out of pity to me and yourself, put your finger on my pulse, feel how it throbs, and—beware!”
他把手腕露出来，伸向我。他的脸和唇都已失去血色，变得青灰。我痛苦万分。用他如此痛恨的拒绝刺激他，使他如此极度的焦虑，是残忍的，而让步却又是不可能的。我做出了人类被逼到绝境时的本能反应——向高于人类的神明求助。一句“上帝帮帮我！”不由自主地脱口而出。 He bared his wrist, and offered it to me: the blood was forsaking his cheek and lips, they were growing livid; I was distressed on all hands.To agitate him thus deeply, by a resistance he so abhorred, was cruel: to yield was out of the question.I did what human beings do instinctively when they are driven to utter extremity—looked for aid to one higher than man: the words “God help me!” burst involuntarily from my lips.
“我真傻！”罗切斯特先生突然喊道，“我一直跟她说我没结婚，却不解释为什么。我忘了她对那个女人的个性，对那该死的婚姻的背景还一无所知。噢，我肯定简会同意我的看法，等她知道了我所知道的一切！把你的手放到我手心，珍妮特，好让我摸到你，看到你，证明你在我身边。我用几句话就能跟你说清楚事实的真相。你能听我讲吗？” “I am a fool!” cried Mr. Rochester suddenly.“I keep telling her I am not married, and do not explain to her why.I forget she knows nothing of the character of that woman, or of the circumstances attending my infernal union with her.Oh, I am certain Jane will agree with me in opinion, when she knows all that I know!Just put your hand in mine, Janet—that I may have the evidence of touch as well as sight, to prove you are near me—and I will in a few words show you the real state of the case.Can you listen to me?"
“可以，先生。你愿意讲几个小时都可以。” “Yes, sir; for hours if you will.”
“我只要几分钟。简，你有没有听说过，或者你是否知道，我不是这家里的长子，我曾经还有个哥哥？” “I ask only minutes.Jane, did you ever hear or know at I was not the eldest son of my house: that I had once a brother older than I?”
“我记得费尔法克斯太太告诉过我一次。” “I remember Mrs. Fairfax told me so once.”
“是不是还听说我父亲是个贪得无厌的人？” “And did you ever hear that my father was an avaricious, grasping man?”
“我知道一点。” “I have understood something to that effect.”
“唉，简，由于贪心，他决心保持财产的完整，不愿将其分割，给我一大份。他决定将全部家产都给我的哥哥，罗兰。但他也不忍心让自己的一个儿子成为穷人。所以我必须有个富足的婚姻。他不久就给我找了个对象。梅森先生，一个西印度的种植园主兼商人，是他的老熟人。他肯定这人的家境确实殷实，就做了调查。他发现梅森先生有一儿一女，还从梅森先生那儿得知他能够也愿意给女儿一笔三万英镑的财产。我一离开大学就被送到牙买加，娶一个已经为我定好的新娘。我父亲对她的钱什么也没说，却告诉我梅森小姐是西班牙城有名的美女，这倒是不假。我发现她很漂亮，有着布兰奇·英格拉姆的风范：身材高挑、皮肤黝黑、庄严高贵。她家人想促成这门亲，因为我门第很好；她也这么希望。他们让我在舞会上见她，她打扮得相当华丽。我几乎没有单独见过她，也很少与她单独交谈。她恭维我，为讨好我而极力展示她的美丽与才华。她那个圈子的男人似乎都仰慕她，也嫉妒我。我眼花缭乱，欢欣鼓舞，我的感官受到了刺激。那时候无知、不成熟、没有经验，我以为我爱上了她。社交场合愚蠢的角逐，年轻人的好色、轻率与盲目，让人糊里糊涂，什么傻事都干得出来。她的亲戚鼓励我，我的对手激怒我，她也引诱我，我几乎还不知道自己身在何处，一桩婚姻就达成了。噢，我一想到这事就毫无自尊可言！我被内心中自我鄙视的痛苦所掌控。我从未爱过她，从未敬重过她，我甚至不了解她。我都不确定她本性中是否存在什么美德。在她的心灵或举止中我找不到一点谦逊、仁慈、坦率或文雅，而且，我还娶了她——我真是个庸俗、卑下、瞎了眼的傻瓜！要是少些罪孽，我或许早就——不过还是让我记住我是在和谁说话吧。” “Well, Jane, being so, it was his resolution to keep the property together; he could not bear the idea of dividing his estate and leaving me a fair portion: all, he resolved, should go to my brother, Rowland.Yet as little could he endure that a son of his should be a poor man.I must be provided for by a wealthy marriage.He sought me a partner betimes.Mr. Mason, a West India planter and merchant, was his old acquaintance.He was certain his possessions were real and vast: he made inquiries.Mr. Mason, he found, had a son and daughter; and he learned from him that he could and would give the latter a fortune of thirty thousand pounds: that sufficed.When I left college, I was sent out to Jamaica, to espouse a bride already courted for me.My father said nothing about her money; but he told me Miss Mason was the boast of Spanish Town for her beauty: and this was no lie.I found her a fine woman, in the style of Blanche Ingram: tall, dark, and majestic.Her family wished to secure me because I was of a good race; and so did she.They showed her to me in parties, splendidly dressed.I seldom saw her alone, and had very little private conversation with her.She flattered me, and lavishly displayed for my pleasure her charms and accomplishments.All the men in her circle seemed to admire her and envy me.I was dazzled, stimulated: my senses were excited; and being ignorant, raw, and inexperienced, I thought I loved her.There is no folly so besotted that the idiotic rivalries of society, the prurience, the rashness, the blindness of youth, will not hurry a man to its commission.Her relatives encouraged me; competitors piqued me; she allured me: a marriage was achieved almost before I knew where I was.Oh, I have no respect for myself when I think of that act!—an agony of inward contempt masters me.I never loved, I never esteemed, I did not even know her.I was not sure of the existence of one virtue in her nature: I had marked neither modesty, nor benevolence, nor candour, nor refinement in her mind or manners—and, I married her:—gross, grovelling, mole-eyed blockhead that I was!With less sin I might have—But let me remember to whom I am speaking.”
“我从没见过我那新娘的母亲，我以为她死了。蜜月结束后，我发现自己错了。她只是疯了，被关在疯人院里。她还有个小弟弟——一个彻底的哑巴白痴。年长的那个，你已经见过了（虽然我憎恶他全家，对他我却恨不起来。因为他那软弱的心里还有几分爱心，对他可怜的姐姐一直都很关心，对我也曾如狗一般地依恋），大概总有一天也会变成那样。我父亲和哥哥罗兰对这一切心知肚明，但他们只想着那三万英镑，还共同谋划对付我。” “My bride’s mother I had never seen: I understood she was dead.The honeymoon over, I learned my mistake; she was only mad, and shut up in a lunatic asylum.There was a younger brother, too—a complete dumb idiot.The elder one, whom you have seen (and whom I cannot hate, whilst I abhor all his kindred, because he has some grains of affection in his feeble mind, shown in the continued interest he takes in his wretched sister, and also in a dog-like attachment he once bore me), will probably be in the same state one day.My father and my brother Rowland knew all this; but they thought only of the thirty thousand pounds, and joined in the plot against me.”
“这是些肮脏的发现。但除了隐瞒真相的欺骗行为，我不能把这些怪罪于我的妻子，即使我发现她与我个性完全相反，她的趣味令我不快，她的心灵平庸、低下而狭隘，根本无法再被延展，使其变得更加开阔。我发现我不能安稳地跟她度过一个夜晚，甚至一是个小时。我俩之间根本不能展开和气地交谈，因为不论我谈起什么话题，她马上就把它转移到粗俗、陈腐、歪曲、愚蠢的方向。我发觉我永远不会拥有一个平静、稳定的家庭，因为没有哪个仆人能够忍受她总是蛮横无理地大发脾气，或者她荒谬、矛盾、苛刻的命令带给人的折磨——即使那样，我仍克制自己：我避免责备，减少抱怨，努力暗自吞下自己的懊悔和厌恶，压制住深深的反感。 “These were vile discoveries; but except for the treachery of concealment, I should have made them no subject of reproach to my wife, even when I found her nature wholly alien to mine, her tastes obnoxious to me, her cast of mind common, low, narrow, and singularly incapable of being led to anything higher, expanded to anything larger—when I found that I could not pass a single evening, nor even a single hour of the day with her in comfort;that kindly conversation could not be sustained between us, because whatever topic I started, immediately received from her a turn at once coarse and trite, perverse and imbecile—when I perceived that I should never have a quiet or settled household, because no servant would bear the continued outbreaks of her violent and unreasonable temper, or the vexations of her absurd, contradictory, exacting orders—even then I restrained myself: I eschewed upbraiding, I curtailed remonstrance; I tried to devour my repentance and disgust in secret; I repressed the deep antipathy I felt.
“简，我不拿令人厌恶的细节来烦你了,几句有力的话就能表达我要说的。我与楼上那女人一起生活了四年，四年中她真是折磨了我。她的个性以惊人的速度迅速成熟、发展，她的恶习更快更猛烈地涌现，如此严重，只有残酷手段才能制止，但我却不愿用残酷的手段。她的智力多像个侏儒，而她的恶习又像个巨人！那些恶习使我承担了多可怕的诅咒！伯莎·梅森，真是一个臭名昭著的母亲的女儿，拽着我经历了一切丑恶堕落的苦难，一个娶了放纵下流的妻子的男人必定会如此。 “Jane, I will not trouble you with abominable details: some strong words shall express what I have to say.I lived with that woman upstairs four years, and before that time she had tried me indeed: her character ripened and developed with frightful rapidity; her vices sprang up fast and rank: they were so strong, only cruelty could check them, and I would not use cruelty.What a pigmy intellect she had, and what giant propensities!How fearful were the curses those propensities entailed on me!Bertha Mason, the true daughter of an infamous mother, dragged me through all the hideous and degrading agonies which must attend a man bound to a wife at once intemperate and unchaste.
“在这期间我哥哥死了，四年之后我父亲也死了。我现在足够有钱了，却又穷得可怕。一种我所见过的最粗野、最肮脏、最腐化的性情与我紧紧地连在一起，而且在法律和社会上都被称作是我的一部分。而我无法通过法律程序来摆脱它。因为医生现在发现我的妻子疯了——她的荒淫行为让使她疯狂的芽苗过早地成熟。简，你不喜欢我的讲述。你看起来像是病了，剩下的我改天再讲好吗？” “My brother in the interval was dead, and at the end of the four years my father died too.I was rich enough now—yet poor to hideous indigence: a nature the most gross, impure, depraved I ever saw, was associated with mine, and called by the law and by society a part of me.And I could not rid myself of it by any legal proceedings: for the doctors now discovered that MY WIFE was mad—her excesses had prematurely developed the germs of insanity.Jane, you don’t like my narrative; you look almost sick—shall I defer the rest to another day?”
“不，先生，现在讲完吧。我同情你，我诚挚地同情你。” “No, sir, finish it now; I pity you—I do earnestly pity you.”
“同情，简，出自某些人之口则是个令人讨厌的、侮辱人的字眼，完全有理由将其当着说话人的面掷回去；但那是一种源于冷酷、自私之心的同情，是听到苦难后所生出的一种混合的、自我本位的痛苦，夹杂着对不幸者的无知的蔑视。但你的同情却不同，简。此时你满脸露出的，那几乎要从你的眼睛里溢出来的，让你的心在起伏的，使你的手在我手中颤抖的同情，都不是这种同情。你的同情，亲爱的，是爱情那受苦的母亲，它的痛苦是神圣的爱情降生时的剧痛。我接受它，简。让这女儿自由地到来吧——我的双臂等着接受她呢。” “Pity, Jane, from some people is a noxious and insulting sort of tribute, which one is justified in hurling back in the teeth of those who offer it; but that is a sort of pity native to callous, selfish hearts; it is a hybrid, egotistical pain at hearing of woes, crossed with ignorant contempt for those who have endured them.But that is not your pity, Jane; it is not the feeling of which your whole face is full at this moment—with which your eyes are now almost overflowing—with which your heart is heaving—with which your hand is trembling in mine.Your pity, my darling, is the suffering mother of love: its anguish is the very natal pang of the divine passion.I accept it, Jane; let the daughter have free advent—my arms wait to receive her.”
“好了，先生，继续吧。你发现她疯了时你是怎么办的？” “Now, sir, proceed; what did you do when you found she was mad?”
“简，我接近了绝望的边缘，仅存的一点自尊把我与那深渊隔开。在世人眼里，无疑我已毫无脸面。但我决心在自己眼里保持清白——一直都拒绝被她的罪恶所玷污，挣脱与她那精神缺陷的联系。但是社会还是把我的名字、我的人同她联系在一起，我还得天天看到她，听到她，我呼吸的空气与她的气息混合（呸！）。此外，我还记得我曾是她的丈夫——那个记忆，当时和现在都是令我难以表达的憎恶。而且，我知道只要她活着，我就不可能成为另一个好妻子的丈夫。可她尽管大我五岁（她家人和她父亲甚至连她的准确年龄都瞒着我），却很有可能跟我活得一样长。她虽然精神衰弱，身体却很健壮。就这样，我二十六岁时，就已经绝望了。 “Jane, I approached the verge of despair; a remnant of self-respect was all that intervened between me and the gulf.In the eyes of the world, I was doubtless covered with grimy dishonour; but I resolved to be clean in my own sight—and to the last I repudiated the contamination of her crimes, and wrenched myself from connection with her mental defects.Still, society associated my name and person with hers; I yet saw her and heard her daily: something of her breath (faugh!) mixed with the air I breathed; and besides, I remembered I had once been her husband—that recollection was then, and is now, inexpressibly odious to me;moreover, I knew that while she lived I could never be the husband of another and better wife; and, though five years my senior (her family and her father had lied to me even in the particular of her age), she was likely to live as long as I, being as robust in frame as she was infirm in mind.Thus, at the age of twenty-six, I was hopeless.
“一天夜里我被她的喊叫声吵醒了，（因为医生宣布她疯了，当然，她就被关了起来），那是一个炽热的西印第安之夜，那种天气常常在飓风到来之前出现。我无法入睡，就起床打开了窗户。空气就像硫磺烟，哪儿都找不到令人神清气爽的东西。蚊子嗡嗡地飞进来，在屋子里沉闷地飞舞。我可以听到从大海那儿发出的低沉的轰轰声，就像是在地震；乌云在海上翻滚，月亮沉没在波涛之中，又大又红，像一颗滚烫的炮弹，她向正酝酿着暴风雨的世界抛出她最后的血色一瞥。我的身体受到了这种氛围和景象的影响，耳朵里还充斥着那疯子仍然尖声喊出的诅咒。她还时不时提到我的名字，用一种对恶魔般仇恨的腔调，和那样肮脏的语言！——所谓的娼妓也没有哪个会使用比她更下流的字眼。虽然隔着两个房间，但一字一句我都能听清楚——西印度的房屋那薄薄的墙壁几乎一点也挡不住她狼一般的吼叫。 “One night I had been awakened by her yells—(since the medical men had pronounced her mad, she had, of course, been shut up)—it was a fiery West Indian night; one of the description that frequently precede the hurricanes of those climates.Being unable to sleep in bed, I got up and opened the window.The air was like sulphur-steams—I could find no refreshment anywhere.Mosquitoes came buzzing in and hummed sullenly round the room; the sea, which I could hear from thence, rumbled dull like an earthquake—black clouds were casting up over it; the moon was setting in the waves, broad and red, like a hot cannon-ball—she threw her last bloody glance over a world quivering with the ferment of tempest.I was physically influenced by the atmosphere and scene, and my ears were filled with the curses the maniac still shrieked out;wherein she momentarily mingled my name with such a tone of demon-hate, with such language!—no professed harlot ever had a fouler vocabulary than she: though two rooms off, I heard every word—the thin partitions of the West India house opposing but slight obstruction to her wolfish cries.
“‘这种生活，’我终于说道，‘就是地狱。这种空气、这些声音就像来自无底的深渊。如果可以，我有权把自己从那里解脱出来。这种人间的痛苦与拖累我灵魂的肉体将一同离开。我不害怕狂热者被永世焚烧，未来的情形不会比现在更坏——让我解脱吧，回到上帝那儿去！’” “‘This life,’ said I at last, ‘is hell: this is the air—those are the sounds of the bottomless pit!I have a right to deliver myself from it if I can.The sufferings of this mortal state will leave me with the heavy flesh that now cumbers my soul.Of the fanatic’s burning eternity I have no fear: there is not a future state worse than this present one—let me break away, and go home to God!’”
“说这话时我跪倒在一只大箱子面前，把锁打开，那里面放着两把上了膛的手枪。我想开枪打死自己。这个意图仅存了片刻，因为我并没发疯。那剧烈而纯粹的绝望产生的危机，和由此引起的自杀的愿望和设想，转瞬即逝。 “I said this whilst I knelt down at, and unlocked a trunk which contained a brace of loaded pistols: I mean to shoot myself.I only entertained the intention for a moment; for, not being insane, the crisis of exquisite and unalloyed despair, which had originated the wish and design of self-destruction, was past in a second.
“从欧洲刮来的一阵风，越过海洋，冲进开着的窗户。暴风雨爆发了，大雨倾盆，雷电交加，空气也变得纯净了。于是我就做出了一个决定，并下定了决心。当我在那湿漉漉的花园里，散步于淌着雨滴的桔子树下，身处于湿透了的石榴树、菠萝丛中，热带那灿烂的黎明在我四周亮了起来。我如此推理，简，现在听好，因为那一刻是真正的智慧安慰了我，给我指明了一条正确的道路。 “A wind fresh from Europe blew over the ocean and rushed through the open casement: the storm broke, streamed, thundered, blazed, and the air grew pure.I then framed and fixed a resolution.While I walked under the dripping orange-trees of my wet garden, and amongst its drenched pomegranates and pine-apples, and while the refulgent dawn of the tropics kindled round me—I reasoned thus, Jane—and now listen; for it was true Wisdom that consoled me in that hour, and showed me the right path to follow.
“欧洲吹来的甜甜的风依然在清新的树叶间低语，大西洋在光荣的自由中咆哮。我那长久以来干涸枯萎的心，随着那旋律膨胀起来，充满了鲜活的血液——我的生命向往新生——我的灵魂渴望甘露。我看见希望复活了，感到了重生的可能。在花园尽头的拱形花架下，我凝视着大海——比天空还要蓝。旧世界就在那边，光明的前景如此展开来—— “The sweet wind from Europe was still whispering in the refreshed leaves, and the Atlantic was thundering in glorious liberty; my heart, dried up and scorched for a long time, swelled to the tone, and filled with living blood—my being longed for renewal—my soul thirsted for a pure draught.I saw hope revive—and felt regeneration possible.From a flowery arch at the bottom of my garden I gazed over the sea—bluer than the sky: the old world was beyond; clear prospects opened thus:—
“‘去吧，’希望说，‘重新在欧洲生活。那里无人知道你被玷污的名字，也无人知晓你背负的肮脏的重担。你可以把那个疯子带回英国，关在桑菲尔德，给她应有的照料和防范。然后就去你想去的地方，结识你喜欢的人。那个女人，她如此长期地虐待你，玷污你的名声，践踏你的荣誉，摧残你的青春，她不是你妻子，你也不是她丈夫。按她的状况给予她应有的照料，你就做到了上帝和人性要求你的一切。让她的身份、她与你的关系，埋藏在忘却之中吧。你不能把此事告诉任何人。把她安置在安全舒适的地方，用秘密来掩盖她的堕落，然后离开她。’ “‘Go,’ said Hope, ‘and live again in Europe: there it is not known what a sullied name you bear, nor what a filthy burden is bound to you.You may take the maniac with you to England; confine her with due attendance and precautions at Thornfield: then travel yourself to what clime you will, and form what new tie you like.That woman, who has so abused your long-suffering, so sullied your name, so outraged your honour, so blighted your youth, is not your wife, nor are you her husband.See that she is cared for as her condition demands, and you have done all that God and humanity require of you.Let her identity, her connection with yourself, be buried in oblivion: you are bound to impart them to no living being.Place her in safety and comfort: shelter her degradation with secrecy, and leave her.’
“我严格依照这一建议行动。我父亲和哥哥没把我的婚姻告诉他们的熟人。因为，我在给他们的第一封信中说到我的婚姻——当时我已经开始对其后果感到极度厌恶感，而且从她的家庭成员的性格和体质上，看到了自己那可怕的未来——我就提出了一个迫切的请求，要他们保守秘密。很快，我父亲为我挑选的妻子那伤风败俗的行为，就已经严重到令他耻于承认她这个儿媳了。对这一婚姻，他远不愿声张，而且还和我一样急于隐瞒。 “I acted precisely on this suggestion.My father and brother had not made my marriage known to their acquaintance; because, in the very first letter I wrote to apprise them of the union—having already begun to experience extreme disgust of its consequences, and, from the family character and constitution, seeing a hideous future opening to me—I added an urgent charge to keep it secret: and very soon the infamous conduct of the wife my father had selected for me was such as to make him blush to own her as his daughter-in-law.Far from desiring to publish the connection, he became as anxious to conceal it as myself.
“然后我把她带到英国。与这么一个怪物同船，真是趟可怕的旅途。令人欣慰的是，最后我终于把她弄到了桑菲尔德，看着她安全地住进三楼的房间。十年来她把那间密室变成了野兽窝——妖精洞。为找个伺候她的人，我可费了不少功夫。必须找一个忠实可靠的人，因为她的胡言乱语必定会泄露我的秘密；而且，她有时也会神志清醒几天，有时几周，这期间她就整日辱骂我。最后我从格里姆斯疯人院雇到了格雷斯·普尔。她和那个外科大夫卡特（梅森被刺伤又被咬伤的那晚，就是他包扎的伤口），只有他们二人知道我的秘密。费尔法克斯太太可能也猜到些什么，但事实究竟如何她也无从知晓。总的来说格雷斯是个好看守。但由于她自身无可救药的缺点，而且跟她那恼人的工作有关，她的警觉不止一次松懈和丧失。那疯子又狡猾又恶毒，她每次都成功利用了看守的一时疏忽。有一次，她用藏匿的一把刀刺伤了她弟弟，她还两次弄到了密室门的钥匙，夜里溜了出来。第一次，她试图把我烧死在床上；第二次，她又像鬼一样地去找你。感谢上帝保佑你，她只拿了你的结婚礼服出气，那也许让她隐约想起了她自己做新娘的日子。但我真不敢想还可能会发生什么。我一想到今早扑向我脖子的那东西，想到它又黑又红的脸俯在我的小鸽子的窝巢上，我的血都凝固了。 “To England, then, I conveyed her; a fearful voyage I had with such a monster in the vessel.Glad was I when I at last got her to Thornfield, and saw her safely lodged in that third-storey room, of whose secret inner cabinet she has now for ten years made a wild beast’s den—a goblin’s cell.I had some trouble in finding an attendant for her, as it was necessary to select one on whose fidelity dependence could be placed; for her ravings would inevitably betray my secret: besides, she had lucid intervals of days—sometimes weeks—which she filled up with abuse of me.At last I hired Grace Poole from the Grimbsy Retreat.She and the surgeon, Carter (who dressed Mason’s wounds that night he was stabbed and worried), are the only two I have ever admitted to my confidence.Mrs. Fairfax may indeed have suspected something, but she could have gained no precise knowledge as to facts.Grace has, on the whole, proved a good keeper; though, owing partly to a fault of her own, of which it appears nothing can cure her, and which is incident to her harassing profession, her vigilance has been more than once lulled and baffled.The lunatic is both cunning and malignant; she has never failed to take advantage of her guardian’s temporary lapses; once to secrete the knife with which she stabbed her brother, and twice to possess herself of the key of her cell, and issue there from in the night-time.On the first of these occasions, she perpetrated the attempt to burn me in my bed; on the second, she paid that ghastly visit to you.I thank Providence, who watched over you, that she then spent her fury on your wedding apparel, which perhaps brought back vague reminiscences of her own bridal days: but on what might have happened, I cannot endure to reflect.When I think of the thing which flew at my throat this morning, hanging its black and scarlet visage over the nest of my dove, my blood curdles.
“那么，先生，”趁他停下来，我问，“你把她安置在这儿之后，又干了什么呢？你去了哪里？” “And what, sir,” I asked, while he paused, “did you do when you had settled her here?Where did you go?”
“我干了什么，简？我把自己变成了一团鬼火。我去了哪里？我像三月的鬼魂一般四处游荡。我到了欧洲大陆，又绕来绕去地走遍了那里的所有地方。我一直怀着一个愿望，就是去寻找一个我可以爱的，善良聪明的女人，与我留在桑菲尔德的那个泼妇完全相反的人——” “What did I do, Jane?I transformed myself into a will-o’-the-wisp.Where did I go?I pursued wanderings as wild as those of the Marchspirit.I sought the Continent, and went devious through all its lands.My fixed desire was to seek and find a good and intelligent woman, whom I could love: a contrast to the fury I left at Thornfield—”
“但是你不能结婚，先生。” “But you could not marry, sir.”
“我已决定而且确信我能够并应当结婚。虽然我欺骗了你，但欺骗不是我的本意。我本打算坦白地告诉你我的故事，公开地向你求婚。我认为我应该自由地去爱与被爱，这绝对是符合情理的。我从没怀疑过能找到某个女人，愿意并能理解我的处境，能接受我，尽管我仍背负着诅咒。” “I had determined and was convinced that I could and ought.It was not my original intention to deceive, as I have deceived you.I meant to tell my tale plainly, and make my proposals openly: and it appeared to me so absolutely rational that I should be considered free to love and be loved, I never doubted some woman might be found willing and able to understand my case and accept me, in spite of the curse with which I was burdened.”
“是么，先生？”“当你好奇的时候，简，你总是让我发笑。你睁着眼睛，活像一只迫切的小鸟，还常常坐立不安，仿佛口头回答对你来说还不够快，你还想读懂人家内心的东西。但在我继续下去之前，先告诉我你那句‘是么，先生？’是什么意思。那是你的口头禅，多少次都害我没完没了地说下去。我真不太明白是为什么。” “Well, sir?”“When you are inquisitive, Jane, you always make me smile.You open your eyes like an eager bird, and make every now and then a restless movement, as if answers in speech did not flow fast enough for you, and you wanted to read the tablet of one’s heart.But before I go on, tell me what you mean by your ‘Well, sir?’It is a small phrase very frequent with you; and which many a time has drawn me on and on through interminable talk: I don’t very well know why.”
“我的意思是——后来呢？你接下来怎么办了？这事后来怎样？” “I mean,—What next?How did you proceed?What came of such an event?”
“正是如此！现在你想知道什么？” “Precisely! and what do you wish to know now?”
“你有没有找到你喜欢的人，你有没有要她嫁给你，她又是怎么说的。” “Whether you found any one you liked: whether you asked her to marry you; and what she said.”
“我能告诉你我有没有找到一个我喜欢的人，我有没有要她嫁给我；但她怎么说的却还有待于记录在命运之册上。我漂泊了十年，时而在这个国家的首都，时而在那个国家的首都：有时候在圣彼得堡，更多的时候是在巴黎，间或在罗马、那不勒斯和佛罗伦萨。反正我有的是钱，还有家族的名望作通行证，我可以随意选择我的社交圈子，没有哪个圈子的大门会向我关闭。我在英国淑女、法国女伯爵、意大利太太、德国伯爵夫人中寻找我理想中的女人。可我找不到。有时，在飞逝的一瞬间，我以为我捕捉到了一瞥，听到了一声，看到了一个身影，宣布我的梦想的实现了，但我很快就发现事实并非如此。你不要以为我是在追求灵魂或肉体的绝对完美。我只向往适合我的——和那个克里奥尔人相反的人，可我的向往是徒劳的。在她们中间我找不到一个，找不到一个我愿意求婚的对象，即使我自由自在，但我一直警惕着不和谐的婚姻有多么危险、可怕、令人厌恶。失望使我不顾一切。我试着放荡，但绝不淫荡。我过去就痛恨淫荡，现在依旧痛恨。那正是我印第安妻子的特点，我对这一点和我那妻子都厌恶至极，所以就连寻欢作乐我也有所克制。任何近似于淫荡的享乐似乎都会使我接近于她和她的恶行，我都尽力避开。 “I can tell you whether I found any one I liked, and whether I asked her to marry me: but what she said is yet to be recorded in the book of Fate.For ten long years I roved about, living first in one capital, then another: sometimes in St. Petersburg; oftener in Paris; occasionally in Rome, Naples, and Florence.Provided with plenty of money and the passport of an old name, I could choose my own society: no circles were closed against me.I sought my ideal of a woman amongst English ladies, French countesses, Italian signoras, and German grafinnen.I could not find her.Sometimes, for a fleeting moment, I thought I caught a glance, heard a tone, beheld a form, which announced the realisation of my dream: but I was presently undeserved.You are not to suppose that I desired perfection, either of mind or person.I longed only for what suited me—for the antipodes of the Creole: and I longed vainly.Amongst them all I found not one whom, had I been ever so free, I—warned as I was of the risks, the horrors, the loathings of incongruous unions—would have asked to marry me.Disappointment made me reckless.I tried dissipation—never debauchery: that I hated, and hate.That was my Indian Messalina’s attribute: rooted disgust at it and her restrained me much, even in pleasure.Any enjoyment that bordered on riot seemed to approach me to her and her vices, and I eschewed it.
“但我不能孤单地生活，于是我尝试去找情妇作伴。我选中的第一个就是塞莉纳·瓦伦——又是让人想起来就唾弃自己的一步。你已经知道她是个什么人，我和她的私通关系又是如何终止的。她之后，又有两个继任者：一个意大利人嘉辛塔，一个德国人克拉拉，两人都被认为漂亮非凡。可几周之后，她们的美貌对我来说还算什么？嘉辛塔既不讲理又暴力，才三个月我就厌倦了她。克拉拉诚实文静，但很迟钝，没有头脑，难以打动：一点也不合我的口味。我很乐意给她足够的钱，给她安排个好出路，然后就很体面地摆脱了她。但是，简，我从你脸上看出你现在对我的印象很不好。你认为我是个冷酷的、没有操守的流氓，是吗？” “Yet I could not live alone; so I tried the companionship of mistresses.The first I chose was Celine Varens—another of those steps which make a man spurn himself when he recalls them.You already know what she was, and how my liaison with her terminated.She had two successors: an Italian, Giacinta, and a German, Clara; both considered singularly handsome.What was their beauty to me in a few weeks?Giacinta was unprincipled and violent: I tired of her in three months.Clara was honest and quiet; but heavy, mindless, and unimpressible: not one whit to my taste.I was glad to give her a sufficient sum to set her up in a good line of business, and so get decently rid of her.But, Jane, I see by your face you are not forming a very favourable opinion of me just now.You think me an unfeeling, loose-principled rake: don’t you?”
“我确实不如有时候那么喜欢你了，先生。难道你认为那种生活方式一点都没错吗？一会儿和这个情妇，一会儿和那个情妇？你说起来就像理所当然似的。” “I don’t like you so well as I have done sometimes, indeed, sir.Did it not seem to you in the least wrong to live in that way, first with one mistress and then another?You talk of it as a mere matter of course.”
“过去是那样的。我也不喜欢那种生活。那是一种卑下的生活，我再也不愿回到那种生活。雇佣一个情妇仅次于买一个奴隶：两者在本性和地位上都总是很低下，和比自己低下的人亲密地生活是有失身份的。我现在讨厌想起和塞纳莉、嘉辛塔、克拉拉共同生活的时光。” “It was with me; and I did not like it.It was a grovelling fashion of existence: I should never like to return to it.Hiring a mistress is the next worse thing to buying a slave: both are often by nature, and always by position, inferior: and to live familiarly with inferiors is degrading.I now hate the recollection of the time I passed with Celine, Giacinta, and Clara.”
我觉得这些都是真话，并从中得出论断，即如果我忘记自己以及被灌输的所有教诲，——以任何借口，任何理由，通过任何诱惑，成为那些可怜女孩们的继任者，总有一天他会以同样的感觉看待我，就如现在正玷污着他回忆的感觉一样。这一论断我并没有说出口，能感觉到就足够了。我将它深深刻在心里，遇到考验时或许会对我有帮助。 I felt the truth of these words; and I drew from them the certain inference, that if I were so far to forget myself and all the teaching that had ever been instilled into me,as—under any pretext—with any justification—through any temptation—to become the successor of these poor girls, he would one day regard me with the same feeling which now in his mind desecrated their memory.I did not give utterance to this conviction: it was enough to feel it.I impressed it on my heart, that it might remain there to serve me as aid in the time of trial.
“哎，简，你为什么不说‘是么，先生？’了？我还没说完呢。你看起来好严肃。你还是不喜欢我，我知道。但让我回归正题吧。去年一月，我摆脱了所有情妇，心情酸涩苦痛。我一无是处、漂泊而孤寂地生活，其结果是我满心失望，讨厌所有的男人，更加厌恶所有的女人（因为我开始认为聪明、可信、忠诚的女人只是个梦）。由于生意需要，我回到了英国。 “Now, Jane, why don’t you say ‘Well, sir?’I have not done.You are looking grave.You disapprove of me still, I see.But let me come to the point.Last January, rid of all mistresses—in a harsh, bitter frame of mind, the result of a useless, roving, lonely life—corroded with disappointment, sourly disposed against all men, and especially against all womankind (for I began to regard the notion of an intellectual, faithful, loving woman as a mere dream), recalled by business, I came back to England.
“在一个严寒的冬日下午，我骑马望见了桑菲尔德府。可恨的地方！我不指望在那儿有安宁与欢乐。在海村道的阶梯上，我看见一个安静的小人儿独自坐着。我漫不经心地从它身旁经过，就像经过它对面那棵截了树梢的柳树一样。它对我将意味着什么，我毫无预感；内心也毫无预兆说我生命的主宰，我善恶的守护神，正穿着粗陋的衣服在那儿等着。甚至当梅斯罗出了事，她严肃地过来要给我帮忙时，我都不认识它。孩子般纤细的人儿！就像一只红雀跳到我脚边，建议用它那娇小的翅膀来背我。我很粗暴，但那东西就是不走。它以奇怪的毅力站在我旁边，神态和说话都一副权威的样子。我必须得到帮助，而且得是由那双手来提供，于是我得到了帮助。 “On a frosty winter afternoon, I rode in sight of Thornfield Hall.Abhorred spot!I expected no peace—no pleasure there.On a stile in Hay Lane I saw a quiet little figure sitting by itself.I passed it as negligently as I did the pollard willow opposite to it: I had no presentiment of what it would be to me; no inward warning that the arbitress of my life—my genius for good or evil—waited there in humble guise.I did not know it, even when, on the occasion of Mesrour’s accident, it came up and gravely offered me help.Childish and slender creature!It seemed as if a linnet had hopped to my foot and proposed to bear me on its tiny wing.I was surly; but the thing would not go: it stood by me with strange perseverance, and looked and spoke with a sort of authority.I must be aided, and by that hand: and aided I was.
“当我一压上那娇弱的肩膀，一种新的东西——清新的活力与感觉——顿时潜入了我的身体。好在我得知这个小精灵一定会回到我身边——它属于我山下的那所房子——不然我就不会让它从我手中溜走，看它消失在昏暗的树篱背后而不无一丝遗憾。我听说你那晚回家了，简，尽管你可能不知道我在想你，在守候你。第二天，你在过道里陪阿代勒玩的时候，我暗自观察了你，有半小时。我记得那天下雪，你没法出门。我呆在自己房间，半掩着门，既能听到也能看到。阿代勒表面上占据了一会儿你的注意力，但我想你的思绪在别处。但你对她真有耐心，我的小简，你跟她说话，陪她玩了好长时间。最后，当她离开你后，你立刻陷入了沉思，自己在走廊里缓缓踱步。不时经过窗户，你就瞥一眼外面纷纷扬扬的大雪，听听呜咽的风声，然后又轻轻踱起步伐，继续幻想。我想那些白日的幻想还不阴暗：你眼里有时会掠过欢乐的光彩，容貌中透着一种温柔的激动，表达的心绪并非痛苦、恼怒或忧郁；你的眼神流露出年轻人甜蜜的思索，那思索之神展开希望那甘愿的翅膀，飞向理想的天国。费尔法克斯太太和一个仆人在大厅的说话声惊醒了你，你多么古怪地对自己一笑，也是在笑自己，珍妮特！你的笑里必定有些含义，非常机灵，像是在笑自己走了神。仿佛是在说：‘我的幻想固然美好，但我必须记住那绝对是虚构的。我脑中有一片玫瑰色的天空，一座绿草遍地、鲜花绽放的伊甸园。但我清楚地知道身外，脚下的路崎岖不平，四周黑暗的风暴正压过来。’你跑到楼下，让费尔法克斯太太给你吩咐些事做，我估计是清算一周的家庭账目之类的。我很恼火你脱离了我的视线。 “When once I had pressed the frail shoulder, something new—a fresh sap and sense—stole into my frame.It was well I had learnt that this elf must return to me—that it belonged to my house down below—or I could not have felt it pass away from under my hand, and seen it vanish behind the dim hedge, without singular regret.I heard you come home that night, Jane, though probably you were not aware that I thought of you or watched for you.The next day I observed you—myself unseen—for half-an-hour, while you played with Adele in the gallery.It was a snowy day, I recollect, and you could not go out of doors.I was in my room; the door was ajar: I could both listen and watch.Adele claimed your outward attention for a while; yet I fancied your thoughts were elsewhere: but you were very patient with her, my little Jane; you talked to her and amused her a long time.When at last she left you, you lapsed at once into deep reverie: you betook yourself slowly to pace the gallery.Now and then, in passing a casement, you glanced out at the thick-falling snow; you listened to the sobbing wind, and again you paced gently on and dreamed.I think those day visions were not dark: there was a pleasurable illumination in your eye occasionally, a soft excitement in your aspect, which told of no bitter, bilious, hypochondriac brooding: your look revealed rather the sweet musings of youth when its spirit follows on willing wings the flight of Hope up and on to an ideal heaven.The voice of Mrs. Fairfax, speaking to a servant in the hall, wakened you: and how curiously you smiled to and at yourself, Janet!There was much sense in your smile: it was very shrewd, and seemed to make light of your own abstraction.It seemed to say—‘My fine visions are all very well, but I must not forget they are absolutely unreal.I have a rosy sky and a green flowery Eden in my brain; but without, I am perfectly aware, lies at my feet a rough tract to travel, and around me gather black tempests to encounter.’You ran downstairs and demanded of Mrs. Fairfax some occupation: the weekly house accounts to make up, or something of that sort, I think it was.I was vexed with you for getting out of my sight.
“我焦急地等待夜晚的降临，那时候我就可以召唤你来见我。我想，对我来说，你有一种与众不同的、全新的性格。我想更深入地探寻，更好地了解它。你走了进来，神态羞怯却有主见。你打扮古雅，和现在很像。我让你说话，很快就发现你身上充满了奇怪的反差。你的装扮和举止完全被规矩束缚，神情常常很羞涩，总之是天性文雅的人。但是绝对不习惯与人交往，生怕自己失礼或出错而惹人注意。然而说话的时候，你就抬起一双锐利、勇敢、发光的眼睛，直视对方的脸，你的每一瞥都富有洞察力，富有威力。当被一个个封闭式问题紧逼时，你都能找到现成圆满的答案。很快你似乎就习惯了我，我相信你感到了你和你那冷酷暴躁的主人之间有共鸣，简。因为我惊奇地发现很快某种怡人的舒适就令你的举止镇定下来。如果我咆哮，你也不会对我的坏脾气表现出惊讶、害怕、厌烦或不快。你看着我，时而朝我笑笑，那笑容很单纯，却聪慧、优雅，我无法形容。我立即对我的所见又满意又激动。我喜欢我看到的东西，还希望看到更多。但是，很长一段时间，我疏远你，极少找你作伴。我是个精神享乐主义者，希望延长这种新奇又令人兴奋的交友乐趣。此外，有一阵子我还被萦绕心头的担忧所烦恼，害怕如果我肆意把玩这朵鲜花，会让它枯萎凋谢，失去它新鲜的迷人的魅力。那时我还不知道它并非转瞬即逝的花儿，而像一朵光芒四射、永不凋谢的宝石花。而且，我想看看如果我躲着你，你会不会找我——但你没有，你在教室呆得跟你的书桌和画架一样坚定。如果我偶尔遇见你，你就匆匆走过，只是出于认识和尊敬而稍作表示。那些天你惯有的表情，简，是一种沉思的样子。那不是沮丧，因为你并不苍白；但也不是轻快，因为你没什么希望，也没什么实质的快乐。我不知道你对我是怎么想的，或者是否想到过我。我决心弄清这一点。 “Impatiently I waited for evening, when I might summon you to my presence.An unusual—to me—a perfectly new character I suspected was yours: I desired to search it deeper and know it better.You entered the room with a look and air at once shy and independent: you were quaintly dressed—much as you are now.I made you talk: ere long I found you full of strange contrasts.Your garb and manner were restricted by rule; your air was often diffident, and altogether that of one refined by nature, but absolutely unused to society, and a good deal afraid of making herself disadvantageously conspicuous by some solecism or blunder;yet when addressed, you lifted a keen, a daring, and a glowing eye to your interlocutor’s face: there was penetration and power in each glance you gave; when plied by close questions, you found ready and round answers.Very soon you seemed to get used to me: I believe you felt the existence of sympathy between you and your grim and cross master, Jane;for it was astonishing to see how quickly a certain pleasant ease tranquillised your manner: snarl as I would, you showed no surprise, fear, annoyance, or displeasure at my moroseness; you watched me, and now and then smiled at me with a simple yet sagacious grace I cannot describe.I was at once content and stimulated with what I saw: I liked what I had seen, and wished to see more.Yet, for a long time, I treated you distantly, and sought your company rarely.I was an intellectual epicure, and wished to prolong the gratification of making this novel and piquant acquaintance: besides, I was for a while troubled with a haunting fear that if I handled the flower freely its bloom would fade—the sweet charm of freshness would leave it.I did not then know that it was no transitory blossom, but rather the radiant resemblance of one, cut in an indestructible gem.Moreover, I wished to see whether you would seek me if I shunned you—but you did not; you kept in the schoolroom as still as your own desk and easel; if by chance I met you, you passed me as soon, and with as little token of recognition, as was consistent with respect.Your habitual expression in those days, Jane, was a thoughtful look; not despondent, for you were not sickly; but not buoyant, for you had little hope, and no actual pleasure.I wondered what you thought of me, or if you ever thought of me, and resolved to find this out.
“我又开始注意你。跟你说话时，你的眼神透着些喜悦，举止间有种亲切。我发现你内心喜欢与人交往，是那安静的教室，单调的生活使你变得忧郁。我允许自己享受待你和善而感到的喜悦。善意很快就激发了情感：你的表情变得柔和，语气温柔，我喜欢你用那感激、快乐口吻呼出我的名字。那时候，简，我常常享受和你偶遇的乐趣。你的举止中有种好奇的犹豫：你看我时有点迟疑，那是一种挥之不去的疑虑。你不知道我反复无常想干什么——是扮演主人的角色，变得严厉；还是作为朋友，和蔼仁慈。我这时候太喜欢你了，常常会萌生出第一个念头。而且，当我诚恳地伸出手，你那稚嫩、渴望的脸上便升起红润、闪亮、欢喜的光彩，我费尽全力克制自己，才没有当时当地就把你拉入我怀里。” “I resumed my notice of you.There was something glad in your glance, and genial in your manner, when you conversed: I saw you had a social heart; it was the silent schoolroom—it was the tedium of your life—that made you mournful.I permitted myself the delight of being kind to you; kindness stirred emotion soon: your face became soft in expression, your tones gentle; I liked my name pronounced by your lips in a grateful happy accent.I used to enjoy a chance meeting with you, Jane, at this time: there was a curious hesitation in your manner: you glanced at me with a slight trouble—a hovering doubt: you did not know what my caprice might be—whether I was going to play the master and be stern, or the friend and be benignant.I was now too fond of you often to simulate the first whim; and, when I stretched my hand out cordially, such bloom and light and bliss rose to your young, wistful features, I had much ado often to avoid straining you then and there to my heart.”
“别再说那些日子了，先生。”我打断他，偷偷擦掉眼里的泪水。他的话对我来说是种折磨，因为我知道我必须怎么做，而且马上就做；而所有这些回忆，这些他的真情表露，就只会让我的任务变得更加艰难。 “Don’t talk any more of those days, sir,” I interrupted, furtively dashing away some tears from my eyes; his language was torture to me; for I knew what I must do—and do soon—and all these reminiscences, and these revelations of his feelings only made my work more difficult.
“不，简，”他答道，“既然眼前的一切如此稳妥，未来如此光明，又何必要沉湎于过去呢？” “No, Jane,” he returned: “what necessity is there to dwell on the Past, when the Present is so much surer—the Future so much brighter?”
听到他迷糊的断言，我不禁一颤。 I shuddered to hear the infatuated assertion.
“现在你明白是怎么回事了吧——明白吗？”他继续道，“我的青春和成人时代一半在无以言表的痛苦中度过，一半在令人压抑的孤独中度过。我第一次找到了可以让我真心去爱的人——我找到了你。你是我的同情者，我的另一半，我善良的天使。我强烈地依恋你、离不开你。我认为你心地善良、天资聪颖又可爱。我心中酝酿着一种炽热、庄严的激情，它倾向你，将你拉入我生命的中心和源泉，让我围绕着你，燃起纯洁、猛烈的火焰，将你我熔为一体。 “You see now how the case stands—do you not?” he continued.“After a youth and manhood passed half in unutterable misery and half in dreary solitude, I have for the first time found what I can truly love—I have found you.You are my sympathy—my better self—my good angel.I am bound to you with a strong attachment.I think you good, gifted, lovely: a fervent, a solemn passion is conceived in my heart; it leans to you, draws you to my centre and spring of life, wraps my existence about you, and, kindling in pure, powerful flame, fuses you and me in one.
“正因为我感觉到并明白了这一点，我才决心娶你。跟我说我有妻子，只是空洞的嘲弄，你现在知道了，我只是个可怕的恶魔。我试图欺骗你，我错了。但我怕你倔强的性格，我怕那早就被灌输的偏见。在冒险泄密之前，我想稳稳地得到你。这是怯懦。我起先就应该求助于你的高尚和大度，正如现在这样，向你坦白我痛苦的生活，向你描述我对更高尚、更有价值的生活是多么如饥似渴，向你展示，并非决心（那个词太无力了），而是我那无法抵挡的忠贞不渝的爱意，同样也得到了忠贞不渝的爱的回报。那时我本该求你接受我忠诚的誓言，并让你对我也发誓。简——现在就向我发誓吧。” “It was because I felt and knew this, that I resolved to marry you.To tell me that I had already a wife is empty mockery: you know now that I had but a hideous demon.I was wrong to attempt to deceive you; but I feared a stubbornness that exists in your character.I feared early instilled prejudice: I wanted to have you safe before hazarding confidences.This was cowardly: I should have appealed to your nobleness and magnanimity at first, as I do now—opened to you plainly my life of agony—described to you my hunger and thirst after a higher and worthier existence—shown to you, not my RESOLUTION (that word is weak), but my resistless BENT to love faithfully and well, where I am faithfully and well loved in return.Then I should have asked you to accept my pledge of fidelity and to give me yours.Jane—give it me now.”
沉默。 A pause.
“你为什么不说话，简？” “Why are you silent, Jane?”
我正在经历一场严峻的考验，一只炽热的铁手攫住了我的命脉。可怕的时刻：充满了挣扎、黑暗与燃烧！世上没人能有希望得到比我得到的爱还要深的爱了，而我也完全崇拜如此深爱着我的他。可我却必须放弃爱情和偶像。一个悲伤的词囊括了我无法忍受的责任——“走！” I was experiencing an ordeal: a hand of fiery iron grasped my vitals.Terrible moment: full of struggle, blackness, burning!Not a human being that ever lived could wish to be loved better than I was loved; and him who thus loved me I absolutely worshipped: and I must renounce love and idol.One drear word comprised my intolerable duty—“Depart!”
“简，你知道我想要你什么吗？只要一句承诺——‘我会成为你的，罗切斯特先生。’” “Jane, you understand what I want of you?Just this promise—‘I will be yours, Mr. Rochester.’”
“罗切斯特先生，我不会成为你的。” “Mr. Rochester, I will NOT be yours.”
另一段长长的静默。 Another long silence.
“简！”他重新开口，那温柔让我难过得心碎，而且还用不祥的恐怖使我变得石头般冰冷，因为这平静的声音是雄狮起身时的喘息——“简，你的意思是要我们各奔天涯？” “Jane!” recommenced he, with a gentleness that broke me down with grief, and turned me stone-cold with ominous terror—for this still voice was the pant of a lion rising—“Jane, do you mean to go one way in the world, and to let me go another?”
“是的。” “I do.”
“简”他弯腰搂住我说道，“现在还是这意思吗？” “Jane” (bending towards and embracing me), “do you mean it now?”
“是的。” “I do.”
“现在呢？”他轻轻地吻我的额头和脸颊。 “And now?” softly kissing my forehead and cheek.
“是的。”我迅速地完全挣脱他的怀抱。 “I do,” extricating myself from restraint rapidly and completely.
“噢，简，这太痛苦了！这——这太邪恶了。爱我就不是邪恶了。” “Oh, Jane, this is bitter!This—this is wicked.It would not be wicked to love me.”
“听你的才是邪恶。” “It would to obey you.”
狂乱的神色令他眉毛竖了起来，掠过他的脸庞。他直起身，但仍克制住自己。我把手撑在椅背上支持自己。我颤抖着，我在害怕，但我的心意已决。 A wild look raised his brows—crossed his features: he rose; but he forebore yet.I laid my hand on the back of a chair for support: I shook, I feared—but I resolved.
“再等一下，简。看一眼你走后我可怕的生活。所有的幸福都会随你而去。还剩下什么呢？作为妻子，我只有楼上那个疯子，你还不如让我去找那边墓地里的死尸去呢。我该怎么办，简？去哪儿寻找伴侣和希望？” “One instant, Jane.Give one glance to my horrible life when you are gone.All happiness will be torn away with you.What then is left?For a wife I have but the maniac upstairs: as well might you refer me to some corpse in yonder churchyard.What shall I do, Jane?Where turn for a companion and for some hope?”
“像我这样：相信上帝和你自己。相信天堂。希望在那里重逢。” “Do as I do: trust in God and yourself.Believe in heaven.Hope to meet again there.”
“这么说你不愿让步？” “Then you will not yield?”
“是的。” “No.”
“这么说你宣判我悲惨地活着，死后还要受诅咒？”他提高了嗓门。 “Then you condemn me to live wretched and to die accursed?”His voice rose.
“我建议你清白地活着，希望你平静地死去。” “I advise you to live sinless, and I wish you to die tranquil.”
“这么说你要夺走我的爱情与纯洁？你要把我推回贪求激情、以恶习为业的老路？” “Then you snatch love and innocence from me?You fling me back on lust for a passion—vice for an occupation?”
“罗切斯特先生，我不会把这种命运强加于你，就像我不会伸手抓住它当作自己的命运一样。我们生来就要奋斗与忍受——你和我一样。就这么做吧。你会在我忘记你之前忘记我的。” “Mr. Rochester, I no more assign this fate to you than I grasp at it for myself.We were born to strive and endure—you as well as I: do so.You will forget me before I forget you.”
“你这么说就把我变成了骗子。你玷污了我的名誉。我说我不会改变，你却当我面说我很快就会变。你的行为证明了你的判断多么歪曲，你的思想多么反常！难道把一个朋友推向绝望比仅仅违背一条人类的法律更好？而这种违背不会伤害任何人，因为你无亲无故，不需要担心与我生活会冒犯他们。” “You make me a liar by such language: you sully my honour.I declared I could not change: you tell me to my face I shall change soon.And what a distortion in your judgment, what a perversity in your ideas, is proved by your conduct!Is it better to drive a fellow-creature to despair than to transgress a mere human law, no man being injured by the breach?for you have neither relatives nor acquaintances whom you need fear to offend by living with me?”
这倒是真的。他说话的时候，我的良心和理智都背叛我，指责我拒绝他是一种罪过。它们的声音和感情的一样洪亮，而后者正在疯狂地大叫。“噢，答应他！”它叫道，“想想他的痛苦，想想他的危险，看看他被独自撇下的处境，想想他轻率的个性，考虑考虑他绝望之后的不顾一切——抚慰他，挽救他，爱他吧，告诉他你爱他并会成为他的。这世上有谁在乎你呢？或谁会因你的行为而受伤呢？” This was true: and while he spoke my very conscience and reason turned traitors against me, and charged me with crime in resisting him.They spoke almost as loud as Feeling: and that clamoured wildly. “Oh, comply!” it said. “Think of his misery; think of his danger—look at his state when left alone; remember his headlong nature; consider the recklessness following on despair—soothe him; save him; love him; tell him you love him and will be his.Who in the world cares for YOU? or who will be injured by what you do?”
回答却依然倔强——“我在乎自己。越是孤单、没有朋友、越是没有依靠，我就越要尊重自己。我会遵守上帝制定的、人类认可的法律。我会坚持神志清醒时而不是像现在这样发疯时所接受的原则。法律和原则不是用在没有诱惑之时，而是用在现在这种时刻——当肉体和灵魂都奋起反抗它们的严厉苛刻的时候。他们再严厉，也不可违反。如果我因个人之便而打破它们，那它们的价值何在？它们是有价值的——我一直相信如此。如果我现在不相信，是因为我疯了——疯得厉害。血管中流动着火焰，心跳快得我难以计数。此刻我只能坚持预期的设想和以往的决心，站稳脚跟。” Still indomitable was the reply—“I care for myself.The more solitary, the more friendless, the more unsustained I am, the more I will respect myself.I will keep the law given by God; sanctioned by man.I will hold to the principles received by me when I was sane, and not mad—as I am now.Laws and principles are not for the times when there is no temptation: they are for such moments as this, when body and soul rise in mutiny against their rigour; stringent are they; inviolate they shall be.If at my individual convenience I might break them, what would be their worth?They have a worth—so I have always believed; and if I cannot believe it now, it is because I am insane—quite insane: with my veins running fire, and my heart beating faster than I can count its throbs.Preconceived opinions, foregone determinations, are all I have at this hour to stand by: there I plant my foot.”
我做到了。罗切斯特看了看我的神情，知道我下定了决心。他愤怒到了极点，他得发泄一下，不管结果会如何。他穿过房间，抓住我的胳膊，搂住我的腰。他似乎要用那燃烧的目光吞噬我。那一刻我的身体失去了力量，犹如麦茬遇上了火炉的热风与烈火——但精神上，我仍然拥有我的灵魂，使我最终肯定平安无事。幸好我的灵魂还有位解读者——常常无意识，但仍很忠实的解读者——我的眼睛。我抬眼与他对视，看着他凶狠的面容，我不由一声长叹。他握得我好痛，我由于过分用力而几乎筋疲力尽。 I did.Mr. Rochester, reading my countenance, saw I had done so.His fury was wrought to the highest: he must yield to it for a moment, whatever followed; he crossed the floor and seized my arm and grasped my waist.He seemed to devour me with his flaming glance: physically, I felt, at the moment, powerless as stubble exposed to the draught and glow of a furnace: mentally, I still possessed my soul, and with it the certainty of ultimate safety.The soul, fortunately, has an interpreter—often an unconscious, but still a truthful interpreter—in the eye.My eye rose to his; and while I looked in his fierce face I gave an involuntary sigh; his gripe was painful, and my over-taxed strength almost exhausted.
“从来没有，”他咬牙切齿地说，“从来没有什么东西如此孱弱却又不可征服。她在我手里不过像根芦苇！”他用握着我的手使劲地摇我，说道，“我手指一动就能把她折断。可如果我折断它，撕毁它，揉碎它，又有什么好处呢？想想那双眼睛，想想其中流露出的坚决、任性和自由。它正藐视我，不仅带着勇气，还有那坚定的胜利。不论我怎么折腾这笼子，就是抓不着它——这野蛮、美丽的家伙！如果我撕破、捣毁这小监狱，我的暴行也只能让我的俘虏更自由。我或许是这房子的征服者，但在我成为这泥屋的主人之前，里面的居民早已逃向了天空。我要的就是你这种精神——有着意志和活力，美德和纯洁——而不光是你脆弱的躯体。出于自愿，你会轻轻飞来，依偎在我胸前；而违背你的意愿抓着你，你就会如一阵香气一样逃离我的手掌——我还没来得及吸上一口你的芬芳，你就消失殆尽。噢，来吧，简，来吧！” “Never,” said he, as he ground his teeth, “never was anything at once so frail and so indomitable.A mere reed she feels in my hand!”(And he shook me with the force of his hold.)“I could bend her with my finger and thumb: and what good would it do if I bent, if I uptore, if I crushed her?Consider that eye: consider the resolute, wild, free thing looking out of it, defying me, with more than courage—with a stern triumph.Whatever I do with its cage, I cannot get at it—the savage, beautiful creature!If I tear, if I rend the slight prison, my outrage will only let the captive loose.Conqueror I might be of the house; but the inmate would escape to heaven before I could call myself possessor of its clay dwelling place.And it is you, spirit—with will and energy, and virtue and purity—that I want: not alone your brittle frame.Of yourself you could come with soft flight and nestle against my heart, if you would: seized against your will, you will elude the grasp like an essence—you will vanish ere I inhale your fragrance.Oh! come, Jane, come!”
他边说边松开手，只是看着我。那目光比疯狂的束缚更令人难以抗拒。然而，现在只有傻瓜才会屈服。我挑战并打败了他的愤怒，还必须要逃离他的悲痛。我向门口退去。 As he said this, he released me from his clutch, and only looked at me.The look was far worse to resist than the frantic strain: only an idiot, however, would have succumbed now.I had dared and baffled his fury; I must elude his sorrow: I retired to the door.
“你要走吗，简？” “You are going, Jane?”
“我要走，先生。” “I am going, sir.”
“你要离开我吗？” “You are leaving me?”
“是的。” “Yes.”
“你不会来了吗？不来做我的安抚者，救赎者了吗？我深深的爱，强烈的痛，疯狂的祈求对你都不算什么吗？” “You will not come?You will not be my comforter, my rescuer?My deep love, my wild woe, my frantic prayer, are all nothing to you?”
他的声音中有着多么无以言表的哀伤！再次坚定地重复一遍该有多难。“我要走了。” What unutterable pathos was in his voice!How hard it was to reiterate firmly, “I am going.”
“简！” “Jane!”
“罗切斯特先生！” “Mr. Rochester!”
“那么，走吧——我同意了。但记住，你把我留在这儿受煎熬。上楼回你房间吧，想想我所有的话，简，看一眼我的苦难——想想我吧。” “Withdraw, then,—I consent; but remember, you leave me here in anguish.Go up to your own room; think over all I have said, and, Jane, cast a glance on my sufferings—think of me.”
他转过身，扑倒在沙发上。“噢，简！我的希望——我的爱——我的生命！”他痛苦地喊道。接着是一阵低沉强烈的呜咽。 He turned away; he threw himself on his face on the sofa.“Oh, Jane! my hope—my love—my life!” broke in anguish from his lips.Then came a deep, strong sob.
我已经走到门口，可是，读者啊，我又走了回去，就跟我刚离开时一样坚决地走了回去。我跪倒在他身边，把他的脸从靠垫上转过来，亲吻他的面颊，用手捋顺他的头发。 I had already gained the door; but, reader, I walked back—walked back as determinedly as I had retreated.I knelt down by him; I turned his face from the cushion to me; I kissed his cheek; I smoothed his hair with my hand.
“上帝保佑你，我亲爱的主人！”我说，“上帝保佑你免受伤害、远离过失，指引你，安慰你，来报答你过去对我的好意。” “God bless you, my dear master!” I said.“God keep you from harm and wrong—direct you, solace you—reward you well for your past kindness to me.”
“小简的爱本该是我最好的回报，”他答道，“没有它，我的心都碎了。但简会给我她的爱，是的，高尚、慷慨地给我。” “Little Jane’s love would have been my best reward,” he answered; “without it, my heart is broken.But Jane will give me her love: yes—nobly, generously.”
热血涌上他的脸，他眼里的热情闪着光，他跳起来站直，张开双臂，但我躲开了他的拥抱，立刻退出了房间。 Up the blood rushed to his face; forth flashed the fire from his eyes; erect he sprang; he held his arms out; but I evaded the embrace, and at once quitted the room.
“别了！”离开他时我的心在哭喊。绝望中又补充道：“永别了！” “Farewell!” was the cry of my heart as I left him.Despair added, “Farewell for ever!”
那晚我根本没想要睡，但一上床却沉沉地睡去了。梦中我又回到了孩提时代，梦到我躺在盖茨黑德的红房子里，夜晚漆黑，我心里充满奇怪的恐惧感。很久以前把我吓晕的那道光，又回到了这个梦里，仿佛滑动着爬上墙，颤颤巍巍地停在昏暗的天花板中心。我抬起头看：屋顶变成了云层，又高又朦胧，那光就像月亮破雾而出时的光芒。我看着她来临，怀着最奇特的期待，仿佛她的圆盘上将写下注定我命运的话。她冲出来了，从未见过月亮这样从云里冲出来：一只手先伸进黑色的云层，把它们拨走；接着，不是月亮，而是一个白色的人影在碧空中闪耀，灿烂的额头俯向大地。它把我看了又看。它跟我的心灵说起话来，声音远不可测，却又如此贴近，它在我心中低语： That night I never thought to sleep; but a slumber fell on me as soon as I lay down in bed.I was transported in thought to the scenes of childhood: I dreamt I lay in the red-room at Gateshead; that the night was dark, and my mind impressed with strange fears.The light that long ago had struck me into syncope, recalled in this vision, seemed glidingly to mount the wall, and tremblingly to pause in the centre of the obscured ceiling.I lifted up my head to look: the roof resolved to clouds, high and dim; the gleam was such as the moon imparts to vapours she is about to sever.I watched her come—watched with the strangest anticipation; as though some word of doom were to be written on her disk.She broke forth as never moon yet burst from cloud: a hand first penetrated the sable folds and waved them away; then, not a moon, but a white human form shone in the azure, inclining a glorious brow earthward.It gazed and gazed on me.It spoke to my spirit: immeasurably distant was the tone, yet so near, it whispered in my heart—
“我的女儿，逃离诱惑吧。” “My daughter, flee temptation.”
“母亲，我会的。” “Mother, I will.”
我从恍惚的梦中醒来，如此答道。依然是深夜，但七月的夜晚十分短暂。午夜一过，黎明就会来到。“开始完成我该做的事，越早越好。”我想。我起床，衣服是穿好的，因为除了鞋子我什么都没脱。我知道在抽屉的什么地方可以找到几件衣物，一个小盒，一只戒指。找这些东西时，我看到了一串珍珠项链，那是几天前罗切斯特先生硬塞给我的。我把它留下了，它不属于我，它属于那个已消失在空气中的幻想中的新娘。我把其他东西捆成一包；把我的钱包，内有二十先令（我全部的家当），放进衣兜里。我系好草帽，别上披肩，拿上包裹和暂时还不想穿的便鞋，溜出了房间。 So I answered after I had waked from the trance-like dream.It was yet night, but July nights are short: soon after midnight, dawn comes.“It cannot be too early to commence the task I have to fulfil,” thought I.I rose: I was dressed; for I had taken off nothing but my shoes.I knew where to find in my drawers some linen, a locket, a ring.In seeking these articles, I encountered the beads of a pearl necklace Mr. Rochester had forced me to accept a few days ago.I left that; it was not mine: it was the visionary bride’s who had melted in air.The other articles I made up in a parcel; my purse, containing twenty shillings (it was all I had), I put in my pocket: I tied on my straw bonnet, pinned my shawl, took the parcel and my slippers, which I would not put on yet, and stole from my room.
“再见，好心的费尔法克斯太太！”溜过她门口时我低声说道。“再见，亲爱的阿代勒！”我朝育儿室看了一眼说道。不允许我有进去拥抱她的想法了。我得骗过那只警惕的耳朵，也许此刻它正在听着。 “Farewell, kind Mrs. Fairfax!” I whispered, as I glided past her door.“Farewell, my darling Adele!” I said, as I glanced towards the nursery.No thought could be admitted of entering to embrace her.I had to deceive a fine ear: for aught I knew it might now be listening.
我本该一步不停地走过罗切斯特先生的房间，但我的心一到那门口就霎时停止了跳动，双脚也被迫停了下来。里面的人没睡，他不安地从屋子这头走到那头，我还听到了一声接一声的叹息。如果我愿意，这里就是我的天堂——暂时的天堂，只需走进去说—— I would have got past Mr. Rochester’s chamber without a pause; but my heart momentarily stopping its beat at that threshold, my foot was forced to stop also.No sleep was there: the inmate was walking restlessly from wall to wall; and again and again he sighed while I listened.There was a heaven—a temporary heaven—in this room for me, if I chose: I had but to go in and to say—
“罗切斯特先生，我会爱你，与你生死相依”，狂喜的源泉就会涌到我唇边。我想到了这情景。 “Mr. Rochester, I will love you and live with you through life till death,” and a fount of rapture would spring to my lips.I thought of this.
那善良的主人此刻无法入睡，正在焦急地盼望白天的到来。他一早就会派人叫我，而我已经走了。他会找我，却是枉然。他会觉得自己被抛弃，爱情遭到拒绝，他会痛苦，也许会绝望。这情景我也想到了。我的手向门锁伸去，但又缩了回来，继续悄悄往前走。 That kind master, who could not sleep now, was waiting with impatience for day.He would send for me in the morning; I should be gone.He would have me sought for: vainly.He would feel himself forsaken; his love rejected: he would suffer; perhaps grow desperate.I thought of this too.My hand moved towards the lock: I caught it back, and glided on.
我悲伤地走下拐来拐去的楼梯，我知道我该怎么做，便机械地去做了。我在厨房找到了侧门的钥匙，还找到了一小瓶油和一根羽毛，给钥匙和锁涂上了油。我拿了些水，拿了些面包，因为也许我得走很远。最近身体非常虚弱，绝不能倒下。我悄无声息地做完这一切。打开门，走出去，又轻轻地关上。昏暗的黎明照进了院子里。大门关着，上了锁，但有扇边门只插了门闩。我从那儿走了出去，把它也关上了。现在我已经走出了桑菲尔德。 Drearily I wound my way downstairs: I knew what I had to do, and I did it mechanically.I sought the key of the side-door in the kitchen; I sought, too, a phial of oil and a feather; I oiled the key and the lock.I got some water, I got some bread: for perhaps I should have to walk far; and my strength, sorely shaken of late, must not break down.All this I did without one sound.I opened the door, passed out, shut it softly.Dim dawn glimmered in the yard.The great gates were closed and locked; but a wicket in one of them was only latched.Through that I departed: it, too, I shut; and now I was out of Thornfield.
田野那边一英里之外，有一条路伸向与米尔科特相反的方向。我从没走过那条路，但经常注意到它，不知道它通向哪里。我朝它走去。现在容不得多想什么，也不能回头看一眼，甚至也不能向前看。对过去或是未来的一点念头都不能有。过去的一页极其甜美，又无比悲哀，只读一行就足以打消我的勇气，击垮我的精神。未来的一页是一片可怕的空白，就像洪水过后的世界。 A mile off, beyond the fields, lay a road which stretched in the contrary direction to Millcote; a road I had never travelled, but often noticed, and wondered where it led: thither I bent my steps.No reflection was to be allowed now: not one glance was to be cast back; not even one forward.Not one thought was to be given either to the past or the future.The first was a page so heavenly sweet—so deadly sad—that to read one line of it would dissolve my courage and break down my energy.The last was an awful blank: something like the world when the deluge was gone by.
我沿着田野、树篱和小径一直走，直到太阳升起。我相信这是个可爱的夏日清晨，我知道离开房子时穿上的鞋一会儿就被露水打湿了。但我没看到那升起的太阳，微笑的天空，也没看到那正在苏醒的大自然。就像一个被送往断头台的人，路过赏心悦目的景色，不会去想路边笑意盈盈的花朵，只会想到砧板和斧头的利刃，想到骨肉分离，想到尽头张着大口的墓穴。而我想的却是凄惶的逃离，无家可归的流浪——噢！还痛苦地想到我撇下的那一切。我情不自禁地想。我现在就想到了他——他在自己的房间，看着日出，希望我快去，告诉他我愿与他相守，成为他的人。我渴望如此，渴望回去。现在还不算太迟，那样我就可以免去他失去心上人的剧痛。我肯定我的出逃还没被发现。我可以回去做他的抚慰者、他的骄傲，救他脱离悲伤，或许是脱离毁灭。噢，我怕他自暴自弃，比我对自己的自暴自弃还要担心更多。这担心怎样地刺痛着我啊！它就是插在我胸口的带倒钩的箭头，我试着拔出来，却锥心地痛；而回忆将它扎得更深，使我愈发虚弱。鸟儿开始在灌木丛和矮树林中歌唱。鸟儿忠诚于他们的配偶，是爱情的象征。我算什么？在我内心的痛苦中，在恪守原则的疯狂努力中，我痛恨自己。我从自我认可中得不到安慰，甚至从自尊中也得不到。我损害了——伤害了——抛弃了我的主人。我在自己眼中都是可憎的。但我仍不能转身，甚至不能后退一步。一定是上帝在牵引着我。至于我的意志与良心，强烈的悲伤已经扼杀了一个，又使另一个窒息。我孤零零地向前走，放声哭泣，疯了一般地越走越快。源自内心的虚弱蔓延到四肢，攥住了我，我跌倒在地。我在地上躺了几分钟，脸贴在湿漉漉的草地上。我有种恐惧或是希望：我应该死在这里。但我很快就抬起头，手脚并用向前爬，然后又站了起来，一如既往急切而又坚定地走向大路。 I skirted fields, and hedges, and lanes till after sunrise.I believe it was a lovely summer morning: I know my shoes, which I had put on when I left the house, were soon wet with dew.But I looked neither to rising sun, nor smiling sky, nor wakening nature.He who is taken out to pass through a fair scene to the scaffold, thinks not of the flowers that smile on his road, but of the block and axe-edge; of the disseverment of bone and vein; of the grave gaping at the end: and I thought of drear flight and homeless wandering—and oh! with agony I thought of what I left.I could not help it.I thought of him now—in his room—watching the sunrise; hoping I should soon come to say I would stay with him and be his.I longed to be his; I panted to return: it was not too late; I could yet spare him the bitter pang of bereavement.As yet my flight, I was sure, was undiscovered.I could go back and be his comforter—his pride; his redeemer from misery, perhaps from ruin.Oh, that fear of his self-abandonment—far worse than my abandonment—how it goaded me!It was a barbed arrow-head in my breast; it tore me when I tried to extract it; it sickened me when remembrance thrust it farther in.Birds began singing in brake and copse: birds were faithful to their mates; birds were emblems of love.What was I?In the midst of my pain of heart and frantic effort of principle, I abhorred myself.I had no solace from self approbation: none even from self-respect.I had injured—wounded—left my master.I was hateful in my own eyes.Still I could not turn, nor retrace one step.God must have led me on.As to my own will or conscience, impassioned grief had trampled one and stifled the other.I was weeping wildly as I walked along my solitary way: fast, fast I went like one delirious.A weakness, beginning inwardly, extending to the limbs, seized me, and I fell: I lay on the ground some minutes, pressing my face to the wet turf.I had some fear—or hope—that here I should die: but I was soon up; crawling forwards on my hands and knees, and then again raised to my feet—as eager and as determined as ever to reach the road.
到了大路边，我不得不坐在树篱下休息一下。正坐着，我听到一阵车轮声，看见一辆马车驶了过来。我站起来，举起手，车停了下来。我问车到哪里去，车夫说了个很远的地名，我肯定罗切斯特先生在那里没有亲友。我问他多少钱能把我带去，他说三十先令。我说我只有二十先令，好吧，他说将就吧。他让我坐到里面，反正车也空着。我进去，关上门，车轱辘轱辘地上路了。 When I got there, I was forced to sit to rest me under the hedge; and while I sat, I heard wheels, and saw a coach come on.I stood up and lifted my hand; it stopped.I asked where it was going: the driver named a place a long way off, and where I was sure Mr. Rochester had no connections.I asked for what sum he would take me there; he said thirty shillings; I answered I had but twenty; well, he would try to make it do.He further gave me leave to get into the inside, as the vehicle was empty: I entered, was shut in, and it rolled on its way.
好心的读者啊，但愿你永远不会感受到我那时的感受！但愿你的眼睛永远不会像我这样泪雨滂沱，流了那么多滚烫而揪心的泪水。愿你永远不会像我当时那样，如此绝望、如此痛苦地向上帝祷告。因为你永远不会像我这样，害怕给自己全心全意爱着的人带来不幸。 Gentle reader, may you never feel what I then felt!May your eyes never shed such stormy, scalding, heart-wrung tears as poured from mine.May you never appeal to Heaven in prayers so hopeless and so agonised as in that hour left my lips; for never may you, like me, dread to be the instrument of evil to what you wholly love.
第二十八章 CHAPTER XXVIII
两天过去了。那是一个夏日的傍晚，车夫让我在一个叫惠特克劳斯的地方下了车。就我给的那点钱，他不愿再拉我了。而我在这世上，已经连一个先令都没有了。现在马车已经走出一英里远，只剩下我一个人了。这时我才发现，我忘了从马车口袋里取出我的包裹。我把它放在里面本是为了安全，它却留在那儿了，肯定是留在那儿了。现在我真是身无分文了。 Two days are passed.It is a summer evening; the coachman has set me down at a place called Whitcross; he could take me no farther for the sum I had given, and I was not possessed of another shilling in the world.The coach is a mile off by this time; I am alone.At this moment I discover that I forgot to take my parcel out of the pocket of the coach, where I had placed it for safety; there it remains, there it must remain; and now, I am absolutely destitute.
惠特克劳斯不是城镇，甚至也不是村庄。它只不过是根石柱，立在十字路口，刷成了白色。我估计在夜里从远处看更为明显。柱子顶上伸出四根路牌。根据上面刻的字，离这里最近的镇子有十英里路，最远的有二十多英里。从这些有名的城镇名字来看，我知道自己来到了哪个郡，是个中北部的郡。荒野幽暗，山脉绵延，这些我都看到了。我身后及左右都是大片的荒原，脚下的深谷在远处绵延为一片起伏的山峦。这里肯定人烟稀少，路上都没见到行人。道路通向东南西北，又白、又宽、又孤独。它们全都穿过荒原，路边还长着欧石南，茂密而又杂乱 。但还是可能会有行人偶尔经过，我现在不想被人看见。陌生人会好奇我在干什么，徘徊在路牌下，显然漫无目的，迷路了一般。也许会有人盘问我，我的回答却只能令人难以置信，引起猜疑。此刻我与人类社会毫无半点联系——没有任何魔力或希望召唤我回到我的同胞那儿去，也没人见到我就会大发善心或表示好意。我举目无亲，只有大自然这一万物之母。我要寻觅她的怀抱，祈求安宁。 Whitcross is no town, nor even a hamlet; it is but a stone pillar set up where four roads meet: whitewashed, I suppose, to be more obvious at a distance and in darkness.Four arms spring from its summit: the nearest town to which these point is, according to the inscription, distant ten miles; the farthest, above twenty.From the well-known names of these towns I learn in what county I have lighted; a north-midland shire, dusk with moorland, ridged with mountain: this I see.There are great moors behind and on each hand of me; there are waves of mountains far beyond that deep valley at my feet.The population here must be thin, and I see no passengers on these roads: they stretch out east, west, north, and south—white, broad, lonely; they are all cut in the moor, and the heather grows deep and wild to their very verge.Yet a chance traveller might pass by; and I wish no eye to see me now: strangers would wonder what I am doing, lingering here at the sign-post, evidently objectless and lost.I might be questioned: I could give no answer but what would sound incredible and excite suspicion.Not a tie holds me to human society at this moment—not a charm or hope calls me where my fellow-creatures are—none that saw me would have a kind thought or a good wish for me.I have no relative but the universal mother, Nature: I will seek her breast and ask repose.
我径直走进石南丛中，看见褐色的荒原中有条深沟，便沿着它往前走，在及膝的深草中艰难地跋涉。沿着沟转弯，在一个隐蔽的角落发现了一块长满青苔的花岗岩峭壁，于是我就坐在了下面。四周是深深的荒草，峭壁保护着我的脑袋，峭壁上面是天空。 I struck straight into the heath; I held on to a hollow I saw deeply furrowing the brown moorside; I waded knee-deep in its dark growth; I turned with its turnings, and finding a moss-blackened granite crag in a hidden angle, I sat down under it.High banks of moor were about me; the crag protected my head: the sky was over that.
即使是在这里，我的心也久久才得以平静。我隐隐约约地害怕野兽就在附近，或者什么冒险家或偷猎者会发现我。要是一阵风吹过荒地，我就赶紧抬头，生怕冲出来一头公牛；要是有只千鸟吹哨，我就以为是个人。不过，我发现自己的恐惧毫无根据，而且黄昏时候夜色渐深，万籁俱寂，这使我平静了下来，这才放下心来。之前我一直没有思考，只是倾听、观察、害怕，现在才恢复了思考的能力。 Some time passed before I felt tranquil even here: I had a vague dread that wild cattle might be near, or that some sportsman or poacher might discover me.If a gust of wind swept the waste, I looked up, fearing it was the rush of a bull; if a plover whistled, I imagined it a man.Finding my apprehensions unfounded, however, and calmed by the deep silence that reigned as evening declined at nightfall, I took confidence.As yet I had not thought; I had only listened, watched, dreaded; now I regained the faculty of reflection.
我要干什么？去哪儿？噢，真是难以忍受的问题。我什么也干不了，也无处可去！我那疲倦、颤抖的双腿，还需要走很远的路，才能到达有人烟的地方。我还必须恳求人家大发慈悲，才能得到一个寄宿的地方。得先强求人家，得到勉强的同情，肯定还要遭到拒绝，才能让人家听我的故事，或满足我的需要！ What was I to do?Where to go?Oh, intolerable questions, when I could do nothing and go nowhere!—when a long way must yet be measured by my weary, trembling limbs before I could reach human habitation—when cold charity must be entreated before I could get a lodging: reluctant sympathy importuned, almost certain repulse incurred, before my tale could be listened to, or one of my wants relieved!
我摸摸石南，很干燥，还带着夏日白昼的余热。我看看天，很纯净。一颗亲切的星星就在峡谷山脊的上空闪烁。露水落下来，带着慈爱的温柔。没有微风的低语。大自然似乎对我亲切又善良。我想她很爱我，尽管我无家可归。而从人类中只能指望得到怀疑、拒绝、侮辱的我，以孩子般的深情紧紧依恋着她。今晚，至少我是她的客人。因为我是她的孩子，所以我不用花钱，不用付出代价，我的母亲就会接纳我。我还有一口面包，是我中午路过一个小镇时花一便士买的面包卷，那是我最后的一便士。我看见越桔遍布四处，闪着成熟的光泽，就像石南丛中的黑色珠子。我摘了一把，就着面包一起吃了。我之前强烈的饥饿感，虽未满足，倒也被这隐士的粮食缓和了一些。吃完后我做了晚祷，然后找了个睡觉的地方。 I touched the heath, it was dry, and yet warm with the beat of the summer day.I looked at the sky; it was pure: a kindly star twinkled just above the chasm ridge.The dew fell, but with propitious softness; no breeze whispered.Nature seemed to me benign and good; I thought she loved me, outcast as I was; and I, who from man could anticipate only mistrust, rejection, insult, clung to her with filial fondness.Tonight, at least, I would be her guest, as I was her child: my mother would lodge me without money and without price.I had one morsel of bread yet: the remnant of a roll I had bought in a town we passed through at noon with a stray penny—my last coin.I saw ripe bilberries gleaming here and there, like jet beads in the heath: I gathered a handful and ate them with the bread.My hunger, sharp before, was, if not satisfied, appeased by this hermit’s meal.I said my evening prayers at its conclusion, and then chose my couch.
峭壁旁边的石南非常深，我躺下时脚都被盖住了。两边都是高高竖起的石南，只留下一条窄窄的空间受到夜风侵袭。我把披肩折成双折，盖在身上当被子；一个长满青苔的矮土墩就是我的枕头。这样夜宿，至少在夜晚刚开始的时候，还不冷。 Beside the crag the heath was very deep: when I lay down my feet were buried in it; rising high on each side, it left only a narrow space for the night-air to invade.I folded my shawl double, and spread it over me for a coverlet; a low, mossy swell was my pillow.Thus lodged, I was not, at least—at the commencement of the night, cold.
我本可以休息得十分舒适，只是被一颗悲伤的心给破坏了。它哀诉着它张开的伤口、流血的心扉、撕裂的心弦。它因罗切斯特先生和他的厄运而颤抖，带着痛苦的怜悯为他惋惜，怀着不息的渴望召唤着他。就像只双翼折断的小鸟般无能为力，却还依然哆嗦着那残破的翅膀，徒劳地寻找着他。 My rest might have been blissful enough, only a sad heart broke it.It plained of its gaping wounds, its inward bleeding, its riven chords.It trembled for Mr. Rochester and his doom; it bemoaned him with bitter pity; it demanded him with ceaseless longing; and, impotent as a bird with both wings broken, it still quivered its shattered pinions in vain attempts to seek him.
我被这种思绪折磨得疲惫不堪，于是起身跪着。夜晚已经来临，繁星升起，一个安宁、平静的夜晚，平静到无须恐惧。我们知道上帝无处不在，但肯定只有当他的作品最恢弘地展现在眼前时，我们才最能感受到他的存在。在那万里无云的夜空中，他的世界默默地沿着各自的轨道滚动，我们才能将他的无穷无尽、无所不能、无所不在，看得最清楚。我跪起来为罗切斯特先生祈祷。我抬起头，泪眼朦胧地看着那浩瀚的银河。想到它是什么——无数的星系犹如一道柔光掠过太空——我感到了上帝的力量和他的伟大。我肯定他的威力能拯救他的创造物，坚信地球以及它真爱的所有灵魂都不会毁灭。我将祈祷变为感恩：生命的源泉同样也是灵魂的救助者。罗切斯特先生是安全的。他属于上帝，他会得到上帝的保护。我再次依偎在小山的怀抱中，不久就忘却悲伤睡去了。 Worn out with this torture of thought, I rose to my knees.Night was come, and her planets were risen: a safe, still night: too serene for the companionship of fear.We know that God is everywhere; but certainly we feel His presence most when His works are on the grandest scale spread before us; and it is in the unclouded night-sky, where His worlds wheel their silent course, that we read clearest His infinitude, His omnipotence, His omnipresence.I had risen to my knees to pray for Mr. Rochester.Looking up, I, with tear-dimmed eyes, saw the mighty Milky-way.Remembering what it was—what countless systems there swept space like a soft trace of light—I felt the might and strength of God.Sure was I of His efficiency to save what He had made: convinced I grew that neither earth should perish, nor one of the souls it treasured.I turned my prayer to thanksgiving: the Source of Life was also the Saviour of spirits.Mr. Rochester was safe; he was God’s, and by God would he be guarded.I again nestled to the breast of the hill; and ere long in sleep forgot sorrow.
但是第二天，苍白而赤裸的需求来了。小鸟早已离巢，蜜蜂也早就趁着露水未干之时在一天最美好的晨光中去采石南的花蜜。当清晨长长的暗影已经缩短，阳光充满大地和天空的时候，我才起身，看了看周围。 But next day, Want came to me pale and bare.Long after the little birds had left their nests; long after bees had come in the sweet prime of day to gather the heath honey before the dew was dried—when the long morning shadows were curtailed, and the sun filled earth and sky—I got up, and I looked round me.
多么宁静、炎热、完美的一天！好一个漫无边际的沙漠般的荒原！到处都是阳光。我这希望住在里面，以此为生。我看见一条蜥蜴爬过峭壁，一只蜜蜂在甜蜜的越桔中忙碌。此刻我多想变成一只蜜蜂或一条蜥蜴，那我就可以在此找到合适的食物和永久的住处。但我是个人，有着人类的需求。我不能在无法满足这些需求的地方徘徊下去了。我起身，回头看看我留在身后的床。对未来无望，我只希望昨晚造物主大发慈悲，趁我睡着之时，取走了我的灵魂；希望我这疲惫的身躯能以死来免除与命运的进一步冲突，此刻就无声地腐朽，与这荒原的泥土和谐地融为一体。然而，生命仍属于我，连同它的需求、痛苦和责任。重担必须背负，需求必须满足，痛苦必须忍受，责任必须履行。我出发了。 What a still, hot, perfect day!What a golden desert this spreading moor!Everywhere sunshine.I wished I could live in it and on it.I saw a lizard run over the crag; I saw a bee busy among the sweet bilberries.I would fain at the moment have become bee or lizard, that I might have found fitting nutriment, permanent shelter here.But I was a human being, and had a human being’s wants: I must not linger where there was nothing to supply them.I rose; I looked back at the bed I had left.Hopeless of the future, I wished but this—that my Maker had that night thought good to require my soul of me while I slept; and that this weary frame, absolved by death from further conflict with fate, had now but to decay quietly, and mingle in peace with the soil of this wilderness.Life, however, was yet in my possession, with all its requirements, and pains, and responsibilities.The burden must be carried; the want provided for; the suffering endured; the responsibility fulfilled. I set out.
重返惠特克劳斯，我沿着一条背着阳光的路走，这时已是艳阳高照了。我已无心再依照别的条件来做选择。我走了很长时间，觉得自己几近崩溃，可以心安理得地向那快要把我击垮的疲劳屈服，可以放松一下这被迫的行动，于是便在附近看到的一块石头上坐下来，不可抗拒地顺从了那堵塞着内心和四肢的麻木。这时候，我听到一阵钟声，教堂的钟声。 Whitcross regained, I followed a road which led from the sun, now fervent and high.By no other circumstance had I will to decide my choice.I walked a long time, and when I thought I had nearly done enough, and might conscientiously yield to the fatigue that almost overpowered me—might relax this forced action, and, sitting down on a stone I saw near, submit resistlessly to the apathy that clogged heart and limb—I heard a bell chime—a church bell.
我转向声音传来的方向，在富有浪漫色彩的小山之间——一小时前我已不再注意它们的变化与景致，我看到一个村庄和一个尖顶。我右手边的山谷里全是牧场、稻田和树林，一条闪亮的小溪曲曲折折地穿过绿油油的田野、正在成熟的庄稼、郁郁葱葱的树林和清新向阳的草地。前面一阵车轮的辘辘声唤醒了我的注意力，只见一辆满载的马车正费劲地爬上山，不远处有两头牛和一个赶牛的人。人类的生活和劳作近在眼前。我必须挣扎下去，和其他人一样努力生活，含辛茹苦。 I turned in the direction of the sound, and there, amongst the romantic hills, whose changes and aspect I had ceased to note an hour ago, I saw a hamlet and a spire.All the valley at my right hand was full of pasture-fields, and cornfields, and wood; and a glittering stream ran zigzag through the varied shades of green, the mellowing grain, the sombre woodland, the clear and sunny lea.Recalled by the rumbling of wheels to the road before me, I saw a heavily-laden waggon labouring up the hill, and not far beyond were two cows and their drover.Human life and human labour were near.I must struggle on: strive to live and bend to toil like the rest.
下午两点左右，我进了那个村庄。 About two o’clock p.m.I entered the village.
一条街的尽头有家小商店，橱窗里摆着些面包。我渴望吃一块面包。吃一点点心或许能恢复点力气，不然的话，就很难继续走下去了。一回到我的同胞中，我就又希望拥有力量和精神了。我觉得在小村庄的砌道上饿晕过去会很丢人。我身上难道就没有任何东西能换一块面包卷吗？我想了想。我脖子上还系着一块小小的丝绸围巾，手上还有手套。我真不知道男人女人们穷到极致是如何度日的。我不知道这两样东西能否被接受，很可能不行，但我必须试试。 At the bottom of its one street there was a little shop with some cakes of bread in the window.I coveted a cake of bread.With that refreshment I could perhaps regain a degree of energy: without it, it would be difficult to proceed.The wish to have some strength and some vigour returned to me as soon as I was amongst my fellow-beings.I felt it would be degrading to faint with hunger on the causeway of a hamlet.Had I nothing about me I could offer in exchange for one of these rolls?I considered.I had a small silk handkerchief tied round my throat; I had my gloves.I could hardly tell how men and women in extremities of destitution proceeded.I did not know whether either of these articles would be accepted: probably they would not; but I must try.
我走进小店，里面有个女人。看到个穿着体面的人，估计是位小姐，她就礼貌地迎了上来。她怎么招待我呢？我感到一阵羞耻，说不出准备好的请求。我不敢给她那半旧的手套，皱巴巴的围巾，而且觉得那样会很荒唐。我只请求她允许我坐一会儿，因为我累了。她很失望没盼到顾客，冷冷地答应了我的请求。她指了张座位，我一屁股坐了下去。我冲动地想哭，但明白如此表现是多么不合时宜，于是便克制住了。一会儿我问她：“这村里有没有裁缝或做针线活儿的女人？” I entered the shop: a woman was there.Seeing a respectably dressed person, a lady as she supposed, she came forward with civility.How could she serve me?I was seized with shame: my tongue would not utter the request I had prepared.I dared not offer her the half-worn gloves, the creased handkerchief: besides, I felt it would be absurd.I only begged permission to sit down a moment, as I was tired.Disappointed in the expectation of a customer, she coolly acceded to my request.She pointed to a seat; I sank into it.I felt sorely urged to weep; but conscious how unseasonable such a manifestation would be, I restrained it.Soon I asked her “if there were any dressmaker or plain-workwoman in the village?”
“有，两三个吧。干活儿的人比活儿还多。” “Yes; two or three. Quite as many as there was employment for.”
我想了想。我现在被逼上绝路了。我必须直面生计问题。我所处之处，没有食物，没有朋友，一分钱也没有。我得做点什么。做什么呢？我必须去什么地方求职。去哪里呢？ I reflected.I was driven to the point now.I was brought face to face with Necessity.I stood in the position of one without a resource, without a friend, without a coin.I must do something. What?I must apply somewhere. Where?
“你知道这附近有什么地方要雇人吗？” “Did she know of any place in the neighbourhood where a servant was wanted?”
“不知道，我说不好。” “Nay; she couldn’t say.”
“这地方主要的行当是什么？大多数人都在干什么？” “What was the chief trade in this place?What did most of the people do?”
“有些是农场工人，还有好多人在奥利弗先生的针厂干活，还有的在铸造厂。” “Some were farm labourers; a good deal worked at Mr. Oliver’s needle-factory, and at the foundry.”
“奥利弗先生雇女人吗？” “Did Mr. Oliver employ women?”
“不雇，那是男人的活计。” “Nay; it was men’s work.”
“那女人们都做什么？” “And what do the women do?”
“我不知道。”她答道，“有人干这，有人干那。穷人总得想法活下去啊。” “I knawn’t,” was the answer.“Some does one thing, and some another.Poor folk mun get on as they can.”
她好像对我的问题不耐烦了。确实，我有什么权利强求她呢？有一两个邻居进来了，显然我的椅子有人要坐。我便告辞了。 She seemed to be tired of my questions: and, indeed, what claim had I to importune her?A neighbour or two came in; my chair was evidently wanted. I took leave.
我走上街头，边走边看左右两边所有的房子，却找不到走进去的借口或动机。我在村子里晃来晃去，往前走一小段距离又折回来，足足有一个多小时。我现在筋疲力尽，饥肠辘辘，便转进一条小巷，坐在树篱下面。但不一会儿我又站起身来，又接着找，找点儿吃的，或者找个人打听打听。小巷的尽头有座漂亮的小房子，前面有座花园，整洁精巧，繁花盛开。我在那儿停了下来。我有什么理由走近那扇白色的门，叩响那闪闪发光的门环呢？那屋子里住的人有什么兴致来招呼我呢？但我还是走过去，叩了门环。一个相貌文雅，衣着整洁的年轻女子打开了门。从我绝望的心中和昏昏沉沉的身体里发出一种可怜巴巴、支支吾吾的声音，我问道这儿需不需要仆人？ I passed up the street, looking as I went at all the houses to the right hand and to the left; but I could discover no pretext, nor see an inducement to enter any.I rambled round the hamlet, going sometimes to a little distance and returning again, for an hour or more.Much exhausted, and suffering greatly now for want of food, I turned aside into a lane and sat down under the hedge.Ere many minutes had elapsed, I was again on my feet, however, and again searching something—a resource, or at least an informant.A pretty little house stood at the top of the lane, with a garden before it, exquisitely neat and brilliantly blooming.I stopped at it.What business had I to approach the white door or touch the glittering knocker?In what way could it possibly be the interest of the inhabitants of that dwelling to serve me?Yet I drew near and knocked.A mild-looking, cleanly-attired young woman opened the door.In such a voice as might be expected from a hopeless heart and fainting frame—a voice wretchedly low and faltering—I asked if a servant was wanted here?
“不，”她说，“我们不用仆人。” “No,” said she; “we do not keep a servant.”
“能不能告诉我哪里可以找到一份工作？什么工作都可以。”我继续说，“我是个陌生人，在这儿谁也不认识。我想找份工作，干什么都可以。” “Can you tell me where I could get employment of any kind?” I continued.“I am a stranger, without acquaintance in this place.I want some work: no matter what.”
但她没必要为我着想，或帮我找个工作。而且，从她眼神里，我这个人，我的境遇和我的故事肯定值得怀疑。她摇摇头，说：“对不起，我不能给你提供消息。”白色的门轻巧有礼貌地关上了，但把我关在了外面。如果她能把门再多开一会儿，我想我肯定能讨到一块面包，因为我现在已经顾不得颜面了。 But it was not her business to think for me, or to seek a place for me: besides, in her eyes, how doubtful must have appeared my character, position, tale.She shook her head, she “was sorry she could give me no information,” and the white door closed, quite gently and civilly: but it shut me out.If she had held it open a little longer, I believe I should have begged a piece of bread; for I was now brought low.
我无法忍受再回到那吝啬的村子，而且，从那里也别指望能得到帮助。我宁愿走岔道到不远处的林子里去，那浓密的绿荫倒像能提供个诱人的栖息之处。但我如此病弱，饥饿难耐，本能使我徘徊在可能有食物的地方。当饥饿如秃鹰般用其尖嘴利爪抓住我不放之时，孤独亦非孤独，休息亦非休息。 I could not bear to return to the sordid village, where, besides, no prospect of aid was visible.I should have longed rather to deviate to a wood I saw not far off, which appeared in its thick shade to offer inviting shelter; but I was so sick, so weak, so gnawed with nature’s cravings, instinct kept me roaming round abodes where there was a chance of food.Solitude would be no solitude—rest no rest—while the vulture, hunger, thus sank beak and talons in my side.
我走近房子，又走开，然后又走回去，又再次走开。总是因为想到无权提出请求而离开，无权指望别人对我孤寂的命运感兴趣。同时，当我像条迷路的饿狗般四处游荡时，下午也快过去了。穿过一片田地时，我看到了前面教堂的尖顶，我赶紧向它走去。离教堂墓地不远的一座花园中间，矗立着一座漂亮的小房子，那肯定是牧师的住宅。我想起来陌生人来到个无亲无故的地方，需要工作时，有时会去找牧师介绍或帮忙。帮助愿意自助的人——至少是提供咨询——是牧师的职责。我好像是有权到这里来寻求建议。我重新鼓起勇气，集中最后一点微弱的力气，向前走去。我到那房子跟前，敲了敲厨房的门。一位老妇人开了门，我问这是否是牧师的家。 I drew near houses; I left them, and came back again, and again I wandered away: always repelled by the consciousness of having no claim to ask—no right to expect interest in my isolated lot.Meantime, the afternoon advanced, while I thus wandered about like a lost and starving dog.In crossing a field, I saw the church spire before me: I hastened towards it.Near the churchyard, and in the middle of a garden, stood a well-built though small house, which I had no doubt was the parsonage.I remembered that strangers who arrive at a place where they have no friends, and who want employment, sometimes apply to the clergyman for introduction and aid.It is the clergyman’s function to help—at least with advice—those who wished to help themselves.I seemed to have something like a right to seek counsel here.Renewing then my courage, and gathering my feeble remains of strength, I pushed on.I reached the house, and knocked at the kitchen-door.An old woman opened: I asked was this the parsonage?
“是的。” “Yes.”
“牧师在家吗？” “Was the clergyman in?”
“不在。” “No.”
