“他会很快回来吗？” “Would he be in soon?”
“不会，他出门了。” “No, he was gone from home.”
“出远门了吗？” “To a distance?”
“不是太远，三英里路吧。他父亲突然去世，他被叫走了。他现在在沼泽居呢，很可能要在那儿再呆两星期。” “Not so far—happen three mile.He had been called away by the sudden death of his father: he was at Marsh End now, and would very likely stay there a fortnight longer.”
“女主人在家吗？” “Was there any lady of the house?”
“不，没有女主人。就我一个管家。”读者啊，我不忍向她寻求救济，我还不能乞讨，我又慢慢地走开了。 “Nay, there was naught but her, and she was housekeeper;” and of her, reader, I could not bear to ask the relief for want of which I was sinking; I could not yet beg; and again I crawled away.
我又摘下我的围巾，我又想到那个小商店里的面包。噢，只要一块面包皮！哪怕只要一口吃的，就会减轻饥饿对我的折磨！我又本能地朝村里走，又找到那家店，走了进去。尽管除了我想请求的那个女人，还有别的人，我还是说了：“我能用这围巾换一个面包卷吗？” Once more I took off my handkerchief—once more I thought of the cakes of bread in the little shop.Oh, for but a crust! for but one mouthful to allay the pang of famine!Instinctively I turned my face again to the village; I found the shop again, and I went in; and though others were there besides the woman I ventured the request—“Would she give me a roll for this handkerchief?”
她显然满腹狐疑地看着我：“不，我从不这样卖东西。” She looked at me with evident suspicion: “Nay, she never sold stuff i’ that way.”
我几近绝望地说只要半块，她还是拒绝了。“我怎么知道你这围巾是从哪儿来的？”她说。 Almost desperate, I asked for half a cake; she again refused.“How could she tell where I had got the handkerchief?” she said.
“你肯收下我的手套吗？” “Would she take my gloves?”
“不要！我要它们做什么？” “No! what could she do with them?”
读者啊，详述这些细节可不是件愉快的事。有人说回味痛苦的往事是一种享受，但直到今天，我都不忍回忆我提到的那些日子。道德的堕落混合着肉体的折磨，构成了一种太过痛苦的回忆，不堪回首。我不怪那些拒绝我的人。我觉得这是意料之中的，无可奈何的事。普通的乞丐尚且常常令人生疑，一个打扮体面的乞丐则定是如此。诚然，我所乞求的只是一份工作，可人家凭什么给我提供工作？那些第一次见我，对我的个性一无所知的人，当然不会理我。至于那个不愿用面包换我围巾的女人，如果她觉得这事凶险，或者无利可图，那她就没做错。我还是长话短说吧。我讨厌这这话题。 Reader, it is not pleasant to dwell on these details.Some say there is enjoyment in looking back to painful experience past; but at this day I can scarcely bear to review the times to which I allude: the moral degradation, blent with the physical suffering, form too distressing a recollection ever to be willingly dwelt on.I blamed none of those who repulsed me.I felt it was what was to be expected, and what could not be helped: an ordinary beggar is frequently an object of suspicion; a well-dressed beggar inevitably so.To be sure, what I begged was employment; but whose business was it to provide me with employment?Not, certainly, that of persons who saw me then for the first time, and who knew nothing about my character.And as to the woman who would not take my handkerchief in exchange for her bread, why, she was right, if the offer appeared to her sinister or the exchange unprofitable.Let me condense now.I am sick of the subject.
天快黑的时候我经过一家农舍，农夫坐在敞开的门口，正吃着他的晚餐——面包和奶酪。我停下来说： A little before dark I passed a farm-house, at the open door of which the farmer was sitting, eating his supper of bread and cheese.I stopped and said—
“你能给我一片面包吗？我很饿。”他惊讶地看了我一眼，但没有回答，从他的面包上切下厚厚一片递给了我。我想他可能不认为我是乞丐，而不过是位奇怪的小姐，喜欢上了他的黑面包。一走出他的视线，我就坐下吃了起来。 “Will you give me a piece of bread? for I am very hungry.”He cast on me a glance of surprise; but without answering, he cut a thick slice from his loaf, and gave it to me.I imagine he did not think I was a beggar, but only an eccentric sort of lady, who had taken a fancy to his brown loaf.As soon as I was out of sight of his house, I sat down and ate it.
我不指望在哪个房子里找到住处，于是就去了那个前面提到过的那片林子。但我这一夜过得很惨，睡得不踏实。地面潮湿，空气寒冷，而且不止一次有人路过，我只好一次又一次地换地方，没有什么安全感，不得安宁。天快亮时下起了雨，接下来一整天都在下。读者啊，不要再让我详述那天的事了。我和先前一样去找工作，和先前一样被拒绝，和先前一样挨饿，只有一次吃了点食物。在一座村舍前，我看见一个小女孩正要把一点冷粥倒进猪食槽里。“你能把这个给我吗？”我问。 I could not hope to get a lodging under a roof, and sought it in the wood I have before alluded to.But my night was wretched, my rest broken: the ground was damp, the air cold: besides, intruders passed near me more than once, and I had again and again to change my quarters; no sense of safety or tranquillity befriended me.Towards morning it rained; the whole of the following day was wet.Do not ask me, reader, to give a minute account of that day; as before, I sought work; as before, I was repulsed; as before, I starved; but once did food pass my lips.At the door of a cottage I saw a little girl about to throw a mess of cold porridge into a pig trough.“Will you give me that?” I asked.
她瞪着我。“妈妈！”她叫道，“有个女的要我把粥给她。” She stared at me.“Mother!” she exclaimed, “there is a woman wants me to give her these porridge.”
“好啊，孩子，”里面一个声音答道，“她要是个叫花子就给她吧。反正猪也不吃。” “Well lass,” replied a voice within, “give it her if she’s a beggar.T pig doesn’t want it.”
女孩把结成硬块的粥倒进我手里，我立刻狼吞虎咽地吃了起来。 The girl emptied the stiffened mould into my hand, and I devoured it ravenously.
暮色渐深，我在一条偏僻的马道上停下来，那条路我已经走了一个多小时了。 As the wet twilight deepened, I stopped in a solitary bridle-path, which I had been pursuing an hour or more.
“我实在没力气了。”我自言自语道，“我觉得不能再走了。今晚又当个流浪者？雨这么大，我还得把头枕在那么冰冷潮湿的地上？恐怕我别无选择。谁会收留我呢？但那就糟透了，而且我还感到如此饥饿、虚弱、寒冷，如此孤寂，还有彻底的绝望。不过，我很可能天亮之前就会死掉。我问什么不甘于去死呢？我为什么挣扎着保留这没有价值的生命？因为我知道，或我相信，罗切斯特先生还活着。而且，死于饥寒交迫，我的天性也无法被动地顺从。噢，上帝！再支撑我一会儿吧！帮助我！——指引我吧！” “My strength is quite failing me,” I said in a soliloquy.“I feel I cannot go much farther.Shall I be an outcast again this night?While the rain descends so, must I lay my head on the cold, drenched ground?I fear I cannot do otherwise: for who will receive me?But it will be very dreadful, with this feeling of hunger, faintness, chill, and this sense of desolation—this total prostration of hope.In all likelihood, though, I should die before morning.And why cannot I reconcile myself to the prospect of death?Why do I struggle to retain a valueless life?Because I know, or believe, Mr. Rochester is living: and then, to die of want and cold is a fate to which nature cannot submit passively.Oh, Providence! sustain me a little longer!Aid!—direct me!”
我暗淡无光的眼睛扫过朦胧昏暗的风景。我看见自己已经远离那个村庄，完全看不见它了。村子周围的田地也消失了。岔路和小道又一次把我带到荒原边上。眼前只有几块地横在我和那昏暗的小山之间，那几块地几乎和石南一样未加开垦，一样荒芜、不生一毛。 My glazed eye wandered over the dim and misty landscape.I saw I had strayed far from the village: it was quite out of sight.The very cultivation surrounding it had disappeared.I had, by crossways and by-paths, once more drawn near the tract of moorland; and now, only a few fields, almost as wild and unproductive as the heath from which they were scarcely reclaimed, lay between me and the dusky hill.
“唉，我倒宁愿死在那里，而不是死在街头，死在人来人往的路上。”我想，“宁愿乌鸦和渡鸦——如果这地方有渡鸦的话——来啄取我骨头上的肉，也比关进贫济院的棺材里，腐朽在乞丐墓里好得多。” “Well, I would rather die yonder than in a street or on a frequented road,” I reflected.“And far better that crows and ravens—if any ravens there be in these regions—should pick my flesh from my bones, than that they should be prisoned in a workhouse coffin and moulder in a pauper’s grave.”
于是我转身朝小山走去。我到了那里。我只想找到个可以躺下的洞，哪怕不安全，至少够隐蔽。但这片荒地的表面看起来全都是平的。除了颜色之外都毫无变化。绿的是长满灯芯草和苔藓的沼泽，黑的是干燥的、只长石南的土地。夜色渐深，我仍然看得出这些变化，尽管只是明暗是转变。色彩已经随日光褪去了。 To the hill, then, I turned.I reached it.It remained now only to find a hollow where I could lie down, and feel at least hidden, if not secure.But all the surface of the waste looked level.It showed no variation but of tint: green, where rush and moss overgrew the marshes; black, where the dry soil bore only heath.Dark as it was getting, I could still see these changes, though but as mere alternations of light and shade; for colour had faded with the daylight.
我的目光依然在这阴沉沉的小山上游走，直到荒原尽头，消失在荒芜的景色之中。远远的沼泽和山脊之间一处模糊的地方，一道亮光突然闪现。“那是鬼火。”我最先这么想，以为它很快就会消失。然而，它却稳稳地烧着，既没后退也没前进。“那么，它是刚点燃的篝火吗？”我心生疑虑。我注视着它，想看它会不会散开，但没有，它既没变小也没变大。“那可能是屋子里的烛光，”我又猜测，“但如果是的话，我也到不了了。那里太远了，而且即使离我只有一码远又有何用呢？我只能敲开门，又会被人当面拒之门外。” My eye still roved over the sullen swell and along the moor-edge, vanishing amidst the wildest scenery, when at one dim point, far in among the marshes and the ridges, a light sprang up.“That is an ignis fatuus,” was my first thought; and I expected it would soon vanish.It burnt on, however, quite steadily, neither receding nor advancing.“Is it, then, a bonfire just kindled?” I questioned.I watched to see whether it would spread: but no; as it did not diminish, so it did not enlarge.“It may be a candle in a house,” I then conjectured; “but if so, I can never reach it.It is much too far away: and were it within a yard of me, what would it avail?I should but knock at the door to have it shut in my face.”
我无力地坐在地上，把脸朝向地面藏了起来。我一动不动地躺了一会儿，夜风掠过小山，吹过我身上，呻吟着消失在远方。雨下得很急，将我浑身浇湿。我若这样僵硬地化为冰霜，对待死神友好而麻木，这雨仍会敲打我，而我将毫无感觉。但我那活着的肉体被冰冷的雨水一淋，还是瑟瑟发抖。我很快就站起来了。 And I sank down where I stood, and hid my face against the ground.I lay still a while: the night-wind swept over the hill and over me, and died moaning in the distance; the rain fell fast, wetting me afresh to the skin.Could I but have stiffened to the still frost—the friendly numbness of death—it might have pelted on; I should not have felt it; but my yet living flesh shuddered at its chilling influence.I rose ere long.
那束光还在那儿，在雨中昏暗却坚定地闪烁着。我试图再走，拖着疲惫的双腿慢慢移向它。它引领我斜着爬过山坡，穿过一大片沼泽。那地方冬天会无法通行，即使现在这盛夏季节也泥泞得让人走一步滑一步，泥浆四溅。我摔倒了两次，但每次都站起来重整旗鼓。这道光是我最后的一丝希望，我必须到达那里。 The light was yet there, shining dim but constant through the rain.I tried to walk again: I dragged my exhausted limbs slowly towards it.It led me aslant over the hill, through a wide bog, which would have been impassable in winter, and was splashy and shaking even now, in the height of summer.Here I fell twice; but as often I rose and rallied my faculties.This light was my forlorn hope: I must gain it.
穿过沼泽，我看见荒原上有一道白色的印迹。走近一看，原来是条小路或小径，笔直地通向亮光处。那光从一座小土丘上射来，且位于一片树林之中——显然是杉树，昏暗中它们的形状和叶子还依稀可辨。我走近时，我的星星消失了。我们之间被什么障碍挡住了。我伸出手在面前的一片漆黑中摸索。我觉出是一道粗糙的矮石墙，墙上好像有道栅栏，里面是一道高高的刺篱。我摸索着前进。一个白色物体又在我面前一闪：那是个门——一个旋转栅门。我一碰，它就在铰链上转起来。两边竖着黑色的矮冬青，或是紫杉。 Having crossed the marsh, I saw a trace of white over the moor.I approached it; it was a road or a track: it led straight up to the light, which now beamed from a sort of knoll, amidst a clump of trees—firs, apparently, from what I could distinguish of the character of their forms and foliage through the gloom.My star vanished as I drew near: some obstacle had intervened between me and it.I put out my hand to feel the dark mass before me: I discriminated the rough stones of a low wall—above it, something like palisades, and within, a high and prickly hedge.I groped on.Again a whitish object gleamed before me: it was a gate—a wicket; it moved on its hinges as I touched it.On each side stood a sable bush-holly or yew.
我进了门，穿过矮树丛，看到一座房子的轮廓——黑漆漆的、低矮却相当长。但引路的亮光却不见了。一切都是模糊的。屋里的人去睡觉了吗？肯定是这样。我拐个弯去找门,那友好的光又从一扇很小的格子窗的菱形窗格玻璃中射了出来。这窗离地不到一尺，被常春藤或别的什么爬墙植物一遮，显得更小了。这些植物的叶子聚集在一起，把开着窗户的这面墙厚厚地盖了一层。窗口处的缝隙又窄又小，连窗帘或百叶窗都不需要了。我弯腰拨开覆盖在上面的叶子，里面的一切都尽收眼底。我清楚地看到擦得干干净净的铺沙地板，一个胡桃木的梳妆台，白鑞制的盘子摆成一排，反射着熊熊燃烧的泥炭火的红光。我还看见一只钟、一张白色的松木桌和几把椅子。那当作我的指路明灯的蜡烛，在桌子上燃烧着。借着烛光，一个老妇人正在织袜子。她长相有点粗糙，但却和周围的一切一样非常干净。 Entering the gate and passing the shrubs, the silhouette of a house rose to view, black, low, and rather long; but the guiding light shone nowhere.All was obscurity.Were the inmates retired to rest?I feared it must be so.In seeking the door, I turned an angle: there shot out the friendly gleam again, from the lozenged panes of a very small latticed window, within a foot of the ground, made still smaller by the growth of ivy or some other creeping plant, whose leaves clustered thick over the portion of the house wall in which it was set.The aperture was so screened and narrow, that curtain or shutter had been deemed unnecessary; and when I stooped down and put aside the spray of foliage shooting over it, I could see all within.I could see clearly a room with a sanded floor, clean scoured; a dresser of walnut, with pewter plates ranged in rows, reflecting the redness and radiance of a glowing peat-fire.I could see a clock, a white deal table, some chairs.The candle, whose ray had been my beacon, burnt on the table; and by its light an elderly woman, somewhat rough-looking, but scrupulously clean, like all about her, was knitting a stocking.
我只是粗略地打量着这些东西，没有什么非凡之处。火炉边的那一群更令人感兴趣。他们静静地坐在弥漫着玫瑰色的平静和暖意之中。两位优雅的女士，浑身透着小姐气质。一位坐在低矮的摇椅里，另一位坐在一个更矮的凳子上。两人都穿着黑纱和邦巴辛毛葛的重孝丧父，深色的服装更加映衬出她们白皙的脖颈和脸庞。一条又大又老的短毛大猎犬将它那硕大的头颅靠在一位姑娘的膝上，而另一位姑娘的膝头则卧着一只黑猫。 I noticed these objects cursorily only—in them there was nothing extraordinary.A group of more interest appeared near the hearth, sitting still amidst the rosy peace and warmth suffusing it.Two young, graceful women—ladies in every point—sat, one in a low rocking-chair, the other on a lower stool; both wore deep mourning of crape and bombazeen, which sombre garb singularly set off very fair necks and faces: a large old pointer dog rested its massive head on the knee of one girl—in the lap of the other was cushioned a black cat.
这简陋的厨房里竟有这样两位姑娘，真是奇怪！她们是谁？她们不可能是桌子边那个老妇人的女儿，因为她看起来像个乡巴佬，而她们却优雅而有教养。我从没在什么地方见过她们这样的脸，可是我盯着她们，却觉得五官长相都很熟悉。我不能说她们漂亮——对这个词来说她们太苍白太严肃。两人都在低头看书，沉思的面容几近严厉。两人之间摆着置物架，上面点着蜡烛，还有两大卷书。她们不时翻翻这两卷书，好像在和手中的小书作对比，就像人们做翻译时查阅词典一样。这情景如此安静，仿佛所有的人都是影子，而生火的房间就是一幅画。如此寂静，我都能听到壁炉里煤渣落下的声音，昏暗的角落里钟表的滴答声，甚至觉得能听见老妇人织针的咔哒声。所以，当一个声音打破这奇怪的静默时，我听得十分清楚。 A strange place was this humble kitchen for such occupants!Who were they?They could not be the daughters of the elderly person at the table; for she looked like a rustic, and they were all delicacy and cultivation.I had nowhere seen such faces as theirs: and yet, as I gazed on them, I seemed intimate with every lineament.I cannot call them handsome—they were too pale and grave for the word: as they each bent over a book, they looked thoughtful almost to severity.A stand between them supported a second candle and two great volumes, to which they frequently referred, comparing them, seemingly, with the smaller books they held in their hands, like people consulting a dictionary to aid them in the task of translation.This scene was as silent as if all the figures had been shadows and the firelit apartment a picture: so hushed was it, I could hear the cinders fall from the grate, the clock tick in its obscure corner; and I even fancied I could distinguish the click-click of the woman’s knitting-needles.When, therefore, a voice broke the strange stillness at last, it was audible enough to me.
“听着，黛安娜，”其中一位专心致志的学生说，“弗朗兹和老丹尼尔一起过夜，弗朗兹正在讲一个把他吓醒的梦——听着！”她低声读了些什么，我一个字也听不懂。那是种陌生的语言，既非法语亦非拉丁语。是不是希腊语或德语我也说不上来。 “Listen, Diana,” said one of the absorbed students; “Franz and old Daniel are together in the night-time, and Franz is telling a dream from which he has awakened in terror—listen!”And in a low voice she read something, of which not one word was intelligible to me; for it was in an unknown tongue—neither French nor Latin.Whether it were Greek or German I could not tell.
“很有力，”她念完后说，“我很喜欢。”另一位姑娘抬头听她的妹妹念完，一边盯着炉火，一边重复刚才念过的那一行。后来我懂了这门语言，知道了这本书，所以在这里引用一行，尽管我第一次听的时候，对我来说，就像敲击铜器一样毫无意义—— “That is strong,” she said, when she had finished: “I relish it.”The other girl, who had lifted her head to listen to her sister, repeated, while she gazed at the fire, a line of what had been read.At a later day, I knew the language and the book; therefore, I will here quote the line: though, when I first heard it, it was only like a stroke on sounding brass to me—conveying no meaning:—
“‘这时有个人走了出来，相貌犹如夜晚的星星。’好！好！”她叫着，幽深的眼睛闪闪发亮，“你面前正好有位朦胧而伟大的天使长！这一行值得一百页的夸赞。‘我用愤怒的天秤权衡我的思想，用愤怒的砝码权衡我的行为。’我喜欢这句！” “‘Da trat hervor Einer, anzusehen wie die Sternen Nacht.’Good! good!” she exclaimed, while her dark and deep eye sparkled.“There you have a dim and mighty archangel fitly set before you!The line is worth a hundred pages of fustian.‘Ich wage die Gedanken in der Schale meines Zornes und die Werke mit dem Gewichte meines Grimms.’I like it!”
两人又沉默了。 Both were again silent.
“有哪个国家的人这么说话的呀？”老妇人从她的织物上抬起头问道。 “Is there ony country where they talk i’ that way?” asked the old woman, looking up from her knitting.
“有，汉娜，一个比英国大得多的国家，那儿的人就这么说话。” “Yes, Hannah—a far larger country than England, where they talk in no other way.”
“噢，说实话，我可不知道他们彼此怎么能明白。如果你们谁到那儿去，我猜，肯定能听懂他们的话吧？” “Well, for sure case, I knawn’t how they can understand t’ one t’other: and if either o’ ye went there, ye could tell what they said, I guess?”
“我们可能只懂一些，不是全懂，因为我们可不像你想的那么聪明，汉娜。我们不会讲德语，没有词典的话读也不会读。” “We could probably tell something of what they said, but not all—for we are not as clever as you think us, Hannah.We don’t speak German, and we cannot read it without a dictionary to help us.”
“那这对你们有什么好处？” “And what good does it do you?”
“我们想有一天能教德语，或按他们说的，至少教些基础。那我们就能比现在多挣些钱。” “We mean to teach it some time—or at least the elements, as they say; and then we shall get more money than we do now.”
“很可能。不过别学了吧，你们今晚学得够多啦。” “Varry like: but give ower studying; ye’ve done enough for tonight.”
“我想也是，至少我累了。玛丽，你呢？” “I think we have: at least I’m tired.Mary, are you?”
“非常累。这么辛苦地学一门语言，没有老师，只靠词典，确实很费劲。” “Mortally: after all, it’s tough work fagging away at a language with no master but a lexicon.”
“的确是，的确，尤其是德语这种晦涩却极好的语言。不知圣约翰什么时候回家。” “It is, especially such a language as this crabbed but glorious Deutsch.I wonder when St. John will come home.”
“他肯定快回来了，都十点了。”看看了从腰带里掏出的的小金表，“雨真大，汉娜，你到客厅去看看火好吗？” “Surely he will not be long now: it is just ten (looking at a little gold watch she drew from her girdle).It rains fast, Hannah: will you have the goodness to look at the fire in the parlour?”
那妇人起身，开了一扇门，通过这扇门隐约可见一条通道。很快我听到她在里屋拨火的声音，不一会儿她就又回来了。 The woman rose: she opened a door, through which I dimly saw a passage: soon I heard her stir a fire in an inner room; she presently came back.
“啊，孩子们！”她说，“现在进那边屋子真难受，椅子撤到角落里，屋里空荡荡的，真冷清。” “Ah, childer!” said she, “it fair troubles me to go into yond’ room now: it looks so lonesome wi’ the chair empty and set back in a corner.”
她用围裙擦擦眼睛，两位姑娘先前严肃，此刻则悲伤起来。 She wiped her eyes with her apron: the two girls, grave before, looked sad now.
“可他去的是个更好的地方，”汉娜继续道，“我们不该盼他再回来。再说，没人比他死得更平静了。” “But he is in a better place,” continued Hannah: “we shouldn’t wish him here again.And then, nobody need to have a quieter death nor he had.”
“你说他从未提起我们？”一位小姐问。 “You say he never mentioned us?” inquired one of the ladies.
“他没时间，孩子。他一下子就去了，你们的父亲。他跟前一天一样有点不舒服，但不严重。圣约翰先生问他要不要派人叫你们来，你们的父亲还笑他呢。第二天他的头又开始有点发昏——就是两周前——他就去睡觉，再也没醒过来。等你们的哥哥进屋时，发现他几乎都僵硬了。啊，孩子们！他是这世上最后一个老派人了——因为跟那些过世了的人比，你们和圣约翰先生跟他们都不是一类人。你们的母亲也和你们一样，读了很多书。你和她长得很像，玛丽。黛安娜更像你们的父亲。” “He hadn’t time, bairn: he was gone in a minute, was your father.He had been a bit ailing like the day before, but naught to signify; and when Mr. St. John asked if he would like either o’ ye to be sent for, he fair laughed at him.He began again with a bit of a heaviness in his head the next day—that is, a fortnight sin’—and he went to sleep and niver wakened: he wor a’most stark when your brother went into t’ chamber and fand him.Ah, childer! that’s t’ last o’ t’ old stock—for ye and Mr. St. John is like of different soart to them ’at’s gone; for all your mother wor mich i’ your way, and a’most as book-learned.She wor the pictur’ o’ ye, Mary: Diana is more like your father.”
我觉得她们长得很像，不知道这老仆人（现在能肯定她的身份了）从哪儿看出的区别。两人都肤色姣好，身材苗条，相貌出众，充满智慧的样子。的确，一位比另一位的头发颜色深些，发型也不同。玛丽的浅褐色头发从中分开，梳成光滑的辫子；黛安娜的深色卷发厚厚地盖住了脖子。时钟敲响了十点。 I thought them so similar I could not tell where the old servant (for such I now concluded her to be) saw the difference.Both were fair complexioned and slenderly made; both possessed faces full of distinction and intelligence.One, to be sure, had hair a shade darker than the other, and there was a difference in their style of wearing it; Mary’s pale brown locks were parted and braided smooth: Diana’s duskier tresses covered her neck with thick curls.The clock struck ten.
“你们想吃晚饭了吧，我肯定。”汉娜说，“圣约翰先生回来也会一样。” “Ye’ll want your supper, I am sure,” observed Hannah; “and so will Mr. St. John when he comes in.”
于是她去准备晚饭了。小姐们起身，似乎打算去客厅。直到此时，我都一直在专心地观察她们，她们的相貌和谈话激起了我强烈的兴趣，我几乎忘了自己悲惨的处境。现在我又想起来了。相比之下，我好像比之前更孤单、更绝望了。想要打动这屋子里的人，让她们为我着想，使她们相信我的需求和不幸，说服她们给我一个栖身之所，使我免于流浪，这显得多么不可能啊！我在门外摸索着，迟疑地敲了门，感到最后那个念头真是妄想。汉娜开了门。 And she proceeded to prepare the meal.The ladies rose; they seemed about to withdraw to the parlour.Till this moment, I had been so intent on watching them, their appearance and conversation had excited in me so keen an interest, I had half-forgotten my own wretched position: now it recurred to me.More desolate, more desperate than ever, it seemed from contrast.And how impossible did it appear to touch the inmates of this house with concern on my behalf; to make them believe in the truth of my wants and woes—to induce them to vouchsafe a rest for my wanderings!As I groped out the door, and knocked at it hesitatingly, I felt that last idea to be a mere chimera.Hannah opened.
“你要做什么？”她问，声音中带着惊讶，借着手中的烛光打量着我。 “What do you want?” she inquired, in a voice of surprise, as she surveyed me by the light of the candle she held.
“我可以和你家女主人说话吗？” “May I speak to your mistresses?” I said.
“你最好告诉我你要跟她们说什么。你从哪儿来？” “You had better tell me what you have to say to them. Where do you come from?”
“我是个陌生人。” “I am a stranger.”
“你这时候到这儿来有什么事？” “What is your business here at this hour?”
“我想在外间或什么地方借宿一晚，还想要点面包吃。” “I want a night’s shelter in an out-house or anywhere, and a morsel of bread to eat.”
我担心的那种怀疑出现在汉娜脸上。“我可以给你一块面包，”她停了一下说，“但我们不收留流浪者过夜。这不可能。” Distrust, the very feeling I dreaded, appeared in Hannah’s face.“I’ll give you a piece of bread,” she said, after a pause; “but we can’t take in a vagrant to lodge. It isn’t likely.”
“请让我跟你家女主人谈谈吧。” “Do let me speak to your mistresses.”
“不行，我不让。她们能为你做什么呀？这时候你不该到处乱逛，这可不成体统。” “No, not I. What can they do for you?You should not be roving about now; it looks very ill.”
“可是如果你赶我走，我还能去哪儿呢？我能怎么办呢？” “But where shall I go if you drive me away? What shall I do?”
“噢，我保证你知道上哪儿去，知道怎么办。只要别去干坏事，就可以了。给你一便士。现在走吧——” “Oh, I’ll warrant you know where to go and what to do.Mind you don’t do wrong, that’s all.Here is a penny; now go—”
“一便士又不能吃，我没力气再往前走了。不要关门——噢，不要，看在上帝份上！” “A penny cannot feed me, and I have no strength to go farther.Don’t shut the door:—oh, don’t, for God’s sake!”
“必须关，雨下进来了——” “I must; the rain is driving in—”
“告诉年轻的小姐们一声。让我见见她们——” “Tell the young ladies. Let me see them—”
“真的，我不能。你本不该如此，要不你也不会这么闹了。走开。” “Indeed, I will not.You are not what you ought to be, or you wouldn’t make such a noise. Move off.”
“可我要是被赶走，我肯定会死的。” “But I must die if I am turned away.”
“你才不会。我看你是没安好心，这么晚了还到人家房子周围转来转去。要是你有什么同伙——强盗或之类的——在这附近，你可以告诉他们这屋里不仅我们几个，还有位先生，还有狗，还有枪。”然后这忠诚而顽固的仆人砰地关上门，并从里面闩上。 “Not you. I’m fear’d you have some ill plans agate, that bring you about folk’s houses at this time o’ night.If you’ve any followers—housebreakers or such like—anywhere near, you may tell them we are not by ourselves in the house; we have a gentleman, and dogs, and guns.”Here the honest but inflexible servant clapped the door to and bolted it within.
这是极致了。一阵异常难受的剧痛——真正绝望的剧痛——撕扯拖拽着我的心。我确实精疲力尽了，一步也挪不动了。我瘫在湿淋淋的门阶上，我呻吟着，绞着手，我痛苦地哭泣着。噢，死神！噢，在这最后的时刻、在这种惨状下来临吧！唉，这孤独——这来自同类的驱逐！不仅是希望之锚，就连坚毅这一立足点都不见了——至少片刻之间如此。但我很快竭力恢复了后一点。 This was the climax.A pang of exquisite suffering—a throe of true despair—rent and heaved my heart.Worn out, indeed, I was; not another step could I stir.I sank on the wet doorstep: I groaned—I wrung my hands—I wept in utter anguish.Oh, this spectre of death! Oh, this last hour, approaching in such horror!Alas, this isolation—this banishment from my kind!Not only the anchor of hope, but the footing of fortitude was gone—at least for a moment; but the last I soon endeavoured to regain.
“我只能死了，”我说，“我相信上帝。让我静静等待他的意志吧。” “I can but die,” I said, “and I believe in God.Let me try to wait His will in silence.”
这些话我不仅仅是想想，还说了出来。我把自己所有的悲伤憋在心里，努力强迫它留在心底，安安静静，一动不动。 These words I not only thought, but uttered; and thrusting back all my misery into my heart, I made an effort to compel it to remain there—dumb and still.
“人人都有一死，”身边很近的地方有个声音说道，“但并非所有人都注定遭受拖延早逝的命运，你若因为贫困死在这里就是如此。” “All men must die,” said a voice quite close at hand; “but all are not condemned to meet a lingering and premature doom, such as yours would be if you perished here of want.”
“谁，什么东西在说话？”我被这意想不到的声音吓到了，而且现在根本不指望能得到任何帮助了。一个影子在身边——是个什么东西，在这漆黑的夜里，我那衰弱的视力使我无法辨认。新来的人重重地敲着门。 “Who or what speaks?”I asked, terrified at the unexpected sound, and incapable now of deriving from any occurrence a hope of aid.A form was near—what form, the pitch-dark night and my enfeebled vision prevented me from distinguishing.With a loud long knock, the new-comer appealed to the door.
“是你吗，圣约翰先生？”汉娜喊道。 “Is it you, Mr. St. John?” cried Hannah.
“是——是的，快开门。” “Yes—yes; open quickly.”
“唔，你肯定又湿又冷吧，这疯狂的夜晚！进来吧。你妹妹们都为你担心呢，我想这附近有坏人。有个乞讨的女人——我想她还没走！——躺在那儿呢。起来！不嫌羞！哎，走开！” “Well, how wet and cold you must be, such a wild night as it is!Come in—your sisters are quite uneasy about you, and I believe there are bad folks about.There has been a beggar-woman—I declare she is not gone yet!—laid down there.Get up! for shame! Move off, I say!”
“嘘，汉娜！我有话跟这女人说。你把她关在外面已经尽职了，现在让我放她进来，尽我的责任。我刚才就在旁边，听了你俩的话。我想这情况特殊,至少我得问清楚。小姐，起来吧，在我前面进屋去。” “Hush, Hannah! I have a word to say to the woman.You have done your duty in excluding, now let me do mine in admitting her.I was near, and listened to both you and her.I think this is a peculiar case—I must at least examine into it.Young woman, rise, and pass before me into the house.”
我艰难地照办了。很快我就站在了干净明亮的厨房里，在火炉边瑟瑟发抖，病怏怏的，知道自己是一副很吓人、疯疯癫癫、饱经风霜的样子。两位小姐和她们的哥哥圣约翰，还有那个老仆人，都在盯着我。 With difficulty I obeyed him.Presently I stood within that clean, bright kitchen—on the very hearth—trembling, sickening; conscious of an aspect in the last degree ghastly, wild, and weather-beaten.The two ladies, their brother, Mr. St. John, the old servant, were all gazing at me.
“圣约翰，这是谁？”我听到有人问道。 “St. John, who is it?” I heard one ask.
“不知道，我在门口发现她的。”有人答道。 “I cannot tell: I found her at the door,” was the reply.
“她看起来好苍白。”汉娜说。 “She does look white,” said Hannah.
“面如死灰。”有人应道。“她会倒下的，让她坐下。” “As white as clay or death,” was responded.“She will fall: let her sit.”
我的确头晕，倒了下去，但一把椅子接住了我。我神智还算清醒，尽管此刻说不出话来。 And indeed my head swam: I dropped, but a chair received me.I still possessed my senses, though just now I could not speak.
“或许喝点水能让她恢复过来。汉娜，拿点水来。但她疲惫不堪。那么瘦，一点血色都没有！” “Perhaps a little water would restore her. Hannah, fetch some.But she is worn to nothing.How very thin, and how very bloodless!”
“真是个幽灵！” “A mere spectre!”
“她是病了，还是只是饿得？” “Is she ill, or only famished?”
“是饿得，我想。汉娜，那是牛奶吗？拿给我，再拿些面包。” “Famished, I think. Hannah, is that milk?Give it me, and a piece of bread.”
黛安娜（我从她弯腰时垂在我和炉火之间的卷发认出她来）掰下一点面包，蘸上牛奶放进我嘴里。她的脸离离我很近，我看到她脸上带着怜悯，从她急促的呼吸中感到了同情。她简单的话语也同样给人安慰：“试着吃点儿。” Diana (I knew her by the long curls which I saw drooping between me and the fire as she bent over me) broke some bread, dipped it in milk, and put it to my lips.Her face was near mine: I saw there was pity in it, and I felt sympathy in her hurried breathing.In her simple words, too, the same balm-like emotion spoke: “Try to eat.”
“对，试试。”玛丽温柔地重复道，她摘下我湿透了的帽子，抬起我的头。我尝了尝他们给我的东西：开始很柔弱，很快就急切起来。 “Yes—try,” repeated Mary gently; and Mary’s hand removed my sodden bonnet and lifted my head.I tasted what they offered me: feebly at first, eagerly soon.
“先别吃太多——让她慢点，”哥哥说，“她吃的够多了。”他拿走了牛奶杯和盛面包的盘子。 “Not too much at first—restrain her,” said the brother; “she has had enough.”And he withdrew the cup of milk and the plate of bread.
“再给她一点，圣约翰。看看她眼里的渴望。” “A little more, St. John—look at the avidity in her eyes.”
“现在先别给了，妹妹。要是她现在能说话，试着问问她的名字。” “No more at present, sister.Try if she can speak now—ask her her name.”
我觉得能说话了，就回答到：“我叫简·埃利奥特。”担心被人发现，我早就决定了用化名。 I felt I could speak, and I answered—“My name is Jane Elliott.”Anxious as ever to avoid discovery, I had before resolved to assume an ALIAS.
“你住在哪里？你的家人在哪里？” “And where do you live?Where are your friends?”
我没有说话。 I was silent.
“我们可以派人去找你认识的人吗？”我摇摇头。“你能不能说说你的事？” “Can we send for any one you know?”I shook my head.“What account can you give of yourself?”
不知为何，一跨过这房子的门槛，与主人面对面，我便不再感到无家可归、漂泊不定、被偌大的世界所遗弃。我敢于抛开乞丐身份，恢复了自己本来的举止和个性。我开始再度认识自己。当圣约翰先生让我讲我的事时——目前我太虚弱，讲不出来——稍稍停了一会儿后我说： Somehow, now that I had once crossed the threshold of this house, and once was brought face to face with its owners, I felt no longer outcast, vagrant, and disowned by the wide world.I dared to put off the mendicant—to resume my natural manner and character.I began once more to know myself; and when Mr. St. John demanded an account—which at present I was far too weak to render—I said after a brief pause—
“先生，今晚我没法细说。” “Sir, I can give you no details tonight.”
“那么，”他说，“你希望我为你做什么呢？” “But what, then,” said he, “do you expect me to do for you?”
“什么都不用。”我回答。我的力气只够做简短的回答。黛安娜接过话： “Nothing,” I replied.My strength sufficed for but short answers.Diana took the word—
“你的意思是，”她问，“我们已经给了你想要的帮助？我们可以让你离开到荒原雨夜里去吗？” “Do you mean,” she asked, “that we have now given you what aid you require? and that we may dismiss you to the moor and the rainy night?”
我看着她。我想，她容貌出众，本性善良又充满力量。我突然有了勇气。对她同情的目光回以微笑，我说：“我相信你们。如果我是只无家可归的流浪狗，我知道你们也不会把我从你们的火炉边赶走。事实上，我真的不担心。随你们拿我怎么办，或为我做什么都行。但请原谅我不能多说，我气短，一说话就痉挛。”三人都注视着我，都没有说话。 I looked at her.She had, I thought, a remarkable countenance, instinct both with power and goodness.I took sudden courage.Answering her compassionate gate with a smile, I said—“I will trust you.If I were a masterless and stray dog, I know that you would not turn me from your hearth tonight: as it is, I really have no fear.Do with me and for me as you like; but excuse me from much discourse—my breath is short—I feel a spasm when I speak.”All three surveyed me, and all three were silent.
“汉娜，”圣约翰先生最后说，“先让她坐在那儿，不要问她问题。十分钟后再把剩下的那些牛奶和面包给她吃。玛丽和黛安娜，咱们到客厅里去商量一下。” “Hannah,” said Mr. St. John, at last, “let her sit there at present, and ask her no questions; in ten minutes more, give her the remainder of that milk and bread.Mary and Diana, let us go into the parlour and talk the matter over.”
他们走了。很快一位小姐又回来了——我不知道是哪位。我坐在暖洋洋的炉火旁，一种愉悦的恍惚悄然流遍全身。她小声吩咐了汉娜几句。不久，在仆人的帮助下，我费力爬上一道楼梯。我那湿漉漉的衣服被脱掉，我很快就倒在一张温暖干燥的床上。感谢上帝——浑身无以言说的疲惫中充斥着感激的喜悦——我便睡着了。 They withdrew.Very soon one of the ladies returned—I could not tell which.A kind of pleasant stupor was stealing over me as I sat by the genial fire.In an undertone she gave some directions to Hannah.Ere long, with the servant’s aid, I contrived to mount a staircase; my dripping clothes were removed; soon a warm, dry bed received me.I thanked God—experienced amidst unutterable exhaustion a glow of grateful joy—and slept.
第二十九章 CHAPTER XXIX
接下来的三天三夜的记忆在我脑中非常模糊。我能记得起间或产生的一些感觉，但几乎没有形成什么想法，也没有做出任何行动。我知道自己在一个小房间里，一张狭窄的床上。我好像在这床上生了根，躺在上面像石头般一动不动，要把我从床上拉开，几乎就像要了我的命。我没有注意时间的流逝，没注意从早上到中午，从中午到晚上的变化。我注意到有人进进出出，甚至能分得清他们是谁。有人在我跟前说话我能听懂，但无法回答。就连张张嘴、挪动一下四肢都不可能。汉娜，那个仆人，来得最勤。她的到来让我不安。我感觉她希望我走，她不了解我和我的处境，对我有偏见。黛安娜和玛丽一天来一两次。她们会在我床边小声说这类的话： The recollection of about three days and nights succeeding this is very dim in my mind.I can recall some sensations felt in that interval; but few thoughts framed, and no actions performed.I knew I was in a small room and in a narrow bed.To that bed I seemed to have grown; I lay on it motionless as a stone; and to have torn me from it would have been almost to kill me.I took no note of the lapse of time—of the change from morning to noon, from noon to evening.I observed when any one entered or left the apartment: I could even tell who they were; I could understand what was said when the speaker stood near to me; but I could not answer; to open my lips or move my limbs was equally impossible.Hannah, the servant, was my most frequent visitor.Her coming disturbed me.I had a feeling that she wished me away: that she did not understand me or my circumstances; that she was prejudiced against me.Diana and Mary appeared in the chamber once or twice a day.They would whisper sentences of this sort at my bedside—
“还好我们把她留下来了。” “It is very well we took her in.”
“是啊，她要是整晚被关在外面，早上肯定就会发现她死在门口了。我不知道她经受了些什么？” “Yes; she would certainly have been found dead at the door in the morning had she been left out all night.I wonder what she has gone through?”
“人地生疏的困苦吧，我想——可怜、憔悴、苍白的流浪者！” “Strange hardships, I imagine—poor, emaciated, pallid wanderer?”
“我想，从她的谈吐来看，她不是个没受过教育的人，她的口音相当纯正。脱下来的衣服虽然湿漉漉又溅满泥水，却也是上等的、没怎么穿过的衣服。” “She is not an uneducated person, I should think, by her manner of speaking; her accent was quite pure; and the clothes she took off, though splashed and wet, were little worn and fine.”
“她的脸很特别，虽然又瘦又憔悴，但我倒很喜欢。等她身体好了，有了生气，模样肯定会很可爱。” “She has a peculiar face; fleshless and haggard as it is, I rather like it; and when in good health and animated, I can fancy her physiognomy would be agreeable.”
在她们的谈话中我从没听到关于后悔自己好客的字眼，或者是对我有怀疑或感到厌恶。我得到了安慰。 Never once in their dialogues did I hear a syllable of regret at the hospitality they had extended to me, or of suspicion of, or aversion to, myself.I was comforted.
圣约翰先生只来过一次，他看着我，说我昏睡的状态是长时间过度疲劳的反应。他说不必去请医生，并肯定只要顺其自然就会好起来。他说我全身的神经有些过度紧张，整个机体都得昏睡一段时间。我并没有生病。他想我的身体只要一开始恢复，就会好得越来越快。这些意见，他只用平静、低沉的只言片语就表达清楚了。停了片刻，他又以一副不习惯高谈阔论的人的腔调说了句：“她的相貌非常与众不同，没有一点粗俗堕落的样子。” Mr. St. John came but once: he looked at me, and said my state of lethargy was the result of reaction from excessive and protracted fatigue.He pronounced it needless to send for a doctor: nature, he was sure, would manage best, left to herself.He said every nerve had been overstrained in some way, and the whole system must sleep torpid a while.There was no disease.He imagined my recovery would be rapid enough when once commenced.These opinions he delivered in a few words, in a quiet, low voice; and added, after a pause, in the tone of a man little accustomed to expansive comment, “Rather an unusual physiognomy; certainly, not indicative of vulgarity or degradation.”
“一点也没有。”黛安娜回答道，“说实话，圣约翰，我倒是很喜欢这可怜的小人儿呢。我希望我们能长久地帮助她。” “Far otherwise,” responded Diana.“To speak truth, St. John, my heart rather warms to the poor little soul.I wish we may be able to benefit her permanently.”
“那恐怕不可能。”他答道，“你会发现她是位小姐，和家人闹了点误会，大概就轻率地出走了。如果她不太固执的话，我们也许能让她回到他们那儿去。不过我看她脸部线条有力，这让我怀疑她是否能会顺从。”他站在那儿打量了我几分钟，又说：“她看起来很聪明，但一点也不漂亮。” “That is hardly likely,” was the reply.“You will find she is some young lady who has had a misunderstanding with her friends, and has probably injudiciously left them.We may, perhaps, succeed in restoring her to them, if she is not obstinate: but I trace lines of force in her face which make me sceptical of her tractability.”He stood considering me some minutes; then added, “She looks sensible, but not at all handsome.”
“她病得这么重，圣约翰。” “She is so ill, St. John.”
“不是病不病的问题，她可能一直长得都很一般。五官缺乏优雅和美丽的协调。” “Ill or well, she would always be plain.The grace and harmony of beauty are quite wanting in those features.”
第三天我好了些，第四天我可以说话、挪动一下、从床上坐起来、转个身。汉娜给我端来些稀粥和烤面包。我想大约是午饭时间了。我吃得有滋有味。食物真好，不再有前几天发烧时的那种怪味儿。她走后，我感到相对有了些力气和精神。不久，觉得休息够了，我就想活动一下。我想起床，但是穿什么呢？我只有那身潮湿的、满是泥巴的衣裳。我穿着它在地上睡觉，又跌倒在沼泽里。我觉得穿这身去见我的恩人太丢人了。但我免去了这种耻辱。 On the third day I was better; on the fourth, I could speak, move, rise in bed, and turn.Hannah had brought me some gruel and dry toast, about, as I supposed, the dinner-hour.I had eaten with relish: the food was good—void of the feverish flavour which had hitherto poisoned what I had swallowed.When she left me, I felt comparatively strong and revived: ere long satiety of repose and desire for action stirred me.I wished to rise; but what could I put on?Only my damp and bemired apparel; in which I had slept on the ground and fallen in the marsh.I felt ashamed to appear before my benefactors so clad.I was spared the humiliation.
床边的椅子上放着我所有的东西，清洁又干爽。我的黑丝连衣裙就挂在墙上。泥沼的痕迹已被洗净，潮湿的褶皱也被熨平，看起来相当得体。我的鞋和袜子也都干干净净，能够见人了。屋子里有洗漱用品，还有梳子和刷子可以梳理头发。经过一番令人疲倦的程序，其间我每五分钟就休息一下，我总算穿戴完毕。我的衣服穿在身上松松垮垮的，因为我瘦了很多，不过我用一条披肩就掩藏了这一缺点。我恢复了干净体面的样子，没有一点我痛恨的、看似降低我身份的污点或凌乱的痕迹。我扶着楼梯扶手慢慢走下石制楼梯，踏上一条狭窄低矮的过道，很快就找到了厨房。 On a chair by the bedside were all my own things, clean and dry.My black silk frock hung against the wall.The traces of the bog were removed from it; the creases left by the wet smoothed out: it was quite decent.My very shoes and stockings were purified and rendered presentable.There were the means of washing in the room, and a comb and brush to smooth my hair.After a weary process, and resting every five minutes, I succeeded in dressing myself.My clothes hung loose on me; for I was much wasted, but I covered deficiencies with a shawl, and once more, clean and respectable looking—no speck of the dirt, no trace of the disorder I so hated, and which seemed so to degrade me, left—I crept down a stone staircase with the aid of the banisters, to a narrow low passage, and found my way presently to the kitchen.
厨房里充满了新鲜面包的香味和熊熊炉火的暖意。汉娜在烤面包。众所周知，未经教育松土或施肥的心田，最难根除偏见。那些偏见就像石缝里的野草般顽固地长在那里。的确，一开始汉娜冷酷而严厉，后来她开始变得温和了一些。当看到我穿戴整洁体面地进来，她甚至微笑起来。 It was full of the fragrance of new bread and the warmth of a generous fire.Hannah was baking.Prejudices, it is well known, are most difficult to eradicate from the heart whose soil has never been loosened or fertilised by education: they grow there, firm as weeds among stones.Hannah had been cold and stiff, indeed, at the first: latterly she had begun to relent a little; and when she saw me come in tidy and well-dressed, she even smiled.
“什么，你下床了！”她说，“这么说，你好些了。要是愿意的话，你就坐炉边我的椅子吧。” “What, you have got up!” she said.“You are better, then.You may sit you down in my chair on the hearthstone, if you will.”
她指向那把摇椅，我坐了下去。她忙来忙去，时而用眼角的余光打量我。从烤箱里取面包时，她转向我，直率地问： She pointed to the rocking-chair: I took it.She bustled about, examining me every now and then with the corner of her eye.Turning to me, as she took some loaves from the oven, she asked bluntly—
“你来这儿之前也讨过饭吗？” “Did you ever go a-begging afore you came here?”
我一时气愤，但想到生气也没用，而且我在她面前确实曾像个叫花子。于是我心平气和，但仍不失坚定地回答： I was indignant for a moment; but remembering that anger was out of the question, and that I had indeed appeared as a beggar to her, I answered quietly, but still not without a certain marked firmness—
“你把我当成乞丐是误解了。我和你、你家小姐一样，不是乞丐。” “You are mistaken in supposing me a beggar.I am no beggar; any more than yourself or your young ladies.”
停了一会儿她说：“我不明白。你好像没有家，没有铜子儿，我猜？” After a pause she said, “I dunnut understand that: you’ve like no house, nor no brass, I guess?”
“没有家或没有铜子儿（我想你的意思是钱吧），并不表明就是你说的乞丐。” “The want of house or brass (by which I suppose you mean money) does not make a beggar in your sense of the word.”
“你读过书吗？”她立刻问道。 “Are you book-learned?” she inquired presently.
“读过，读过很多。” “Yes, very.”
“但你从没上过寄宿学校？” “But you’ve never been to a boarding-school?”
“我在寄宿学校呆了八年。” “I was at a boarding-school eight years.”
她张大了眼睛说道：“那么，你怎么不能养活你自己？” She opened her eyes wide.“Whatever cannot ye keep yourself for, then?”
“我一直在养活自己，而且我相信以后还能养活自己。你拿这些醋栗做什么呀？”看她拿出一篮醋栗，我问道。 “I have kept myself; and, I trust, shall keep myself again.What are you going to do with these gooseberries?”I inquired, as she brought out a basket of the fruit.
“做馅饼。” “Mak’ ’em into pies.”
“给我，我来摘吧。” “Give them to me and I’ll pick them.”
“不，我什么也不要你做。” “Nay; I dunnut want ye to do nought.”
“但我必须做点什么呀。让我来吧。” “But I must do something. Let me have them.”
她同意了，甚至还拿来一条干净的毛巾垫在我衣服上，说：“免得把衣服弄脏了。” She consented; and she even brought me a clean towel to spread over my dress, “lest,” as she said, “I should mucky it.”
“看你那手，你没干过佣人的活。”她评论道，“你是个裁缝吗？” “Ye’ve not been used to sarvant’s wark, I see by your hands,” she remarked.“Happen ye’ve been a dressmaker?”
“不，你错了。现在，别管我以前是做什么的，别再为我费神了。请先告诉我这房子叫什么名字。” “No, you are wrong.And now, never mind what I have been: don’t trouble your head further about me; but tell me the name of the house where we are.”
“有人叫它沼泽居，也有人叫沼泽屋。” “Some calls it Marsh End, and some calls it Moor House.”
“住在这儿的那位先生叫圣约翰先生？” “And the gentleman who lives here is called Mr. St. John?”
“不，他不住这儿，他只是呆一阵儿。他自己的家在莫顿教区。” “Nay; he doesn’t live here: he is only staying a while.When he is at home, he is in his own parish at Morton.”
“几英里外的那个村子吗？” “That village a few miles off?"
“是啊。” “Aye.”
“他是干什么的呢？” “And what is he?”
“是个牧师。” “He is a parson.”
我想起当时我要见牧师时，牧师住宅里那个老管家的回答。“那么，这里是他父亲的住处？” I remembered the answer of the old housekeeper at the parsonage, when I had asked to see the clergyman.“This, then, was his father’s residence?”
“是啊，老里弗斯住在这儿，在他之前，他父亲、祖父、曾祖父都住在这里。” “Aye; old Mr. Rivers lived here, and his father, and grandfather, and gurt (great) grandfather afore him.”
“那么说，那位先生的名字叫圣约翰·里弗斯？” “The name, then, of that gentleman, is Mr. St. John Rivers?”
“是啊，圣约翰像是他受洗时起的名字。” “Aye; St. John is like his kirstened name.”
“他的妹妹们叫黛安娜·里弗斯和玛丽·里弗斯吗？” “And his sisters are called Diana and Mary Rivers?”
“是的。” “Yes.”
“他们的父亲去世了？” “Their father is dead?”
“三个礼拜之前中风死的。” “Dead three weeks sin’ of a stroke.”
“他们没有母亲？” “They have no mother?”
“女主人死了好些年了。” “The mistress has been dead this mony a year.”
“你在这家住了很长时间了吗？” “Have you lived with the family long?”
“我三十年前就住这儿了。他们三个都是我带大的。” “I’ve lived here thirty year.I nursed them all three.”
“那证明你肯定是个忠实可靠的仆人。我要为你这么说，尽管你不礼貌地称我为乞丐。” “That proves you must have been an honest and faithful servant.I will say so much for you, though you have had the incivility to call me a beggar.”
她再次吃惊地盯着我。“我想，”她说，“我可能是弄错了。但这地方骗子很多，你得原谅我。” She again regarded me with a surprised stare.“I believe,” she said, “I was quite mista’en in my thoughts of you: but there is so mony cheats goes about, you mun forgie me.”
“而且，”我有点严厉地继续说，“你想把我从门前赶走，在那样的夜晚，就算是一条狗你也不该关在门外。” “And though,” I continued, rather severely, “you wished to turn me from the door, on a night when you should not have shut out a dog.”
“好吧，那是狠心，但又能怎么办？我为孩子们想的比自己还要多。可怜的孩子们！除我之外没人照顾她们。我得提高警惕啊。” “Well, it was hard: but what can a body do?I thought more o’ th’ childer nor of mysel: poor things!They’ve like nobody to tak’ care on ’em but me.I’m like to look sharpish.”
我严肃地沉默了几分钟。 I maintained a grave silence for some minutes.
“你不要把我想得太坏了。”她又说。 “You munnut think too hardly of me,” she again remarked.
“但我就是把你想得很坏。”我说，“我来告诉你为什么——并不是你不留我住宿，或把我当成个骗子，而是你刚刚仅仅因为我没有‘铜子儿’，没有家，就侮辱我。世上有些最好的人也曾像我一样穷困，而你如果是基督徒的话，就不该把贫穷看成是一种罪过。” “But I do think hardly of you,” I said; “and I’ll tell you why—not so much because you refused to give me shelter, or regarded me as an impostor, as because you just now made it a species of reproach that I had no ‘brass’ and no house.Some of the best people that ever lived have been as destitute as I am; and if you are a Christian, you ought not to consider poverty a crime.”
“我再也不会了。”她说，“圣约翰先生也对我这么说，我知道我错了，但我现在对你的看法可大不相同了。你看起来完全是个体面的小人儿。” “No more I ought,” said she: “Mr. St. John tells me so too; and I see I wor wrang—but I’ve clear a different notion on you now to what I had.You look a raight down dacent little crater.”
“这就可以啦——我现在原谅你了。握握手吧。” “That will do—I forgive you now. Shake hands.”
她把她那沾满面粉、布满老茧的手放进我手里，我用一个诚挚的微笑照亮了她粗糙的面孔。从那一刻起，我们就成了朋友。 She put her floury and horny hand into mine; another and heartier smile illumined her rough face, and from that moment we were friends.
汉娜显然很爱说话。我摘醋栗、她和面做馅饼时，她就给我叙述关于她那男主人、女主人，还有被她称为“孩子们”的年轻人的各种细节。 Hannah was evidently fond of talking.While I picked the fruit, and she made the paste for the pies, she proceeded to give me sundry details about her deceased master and mistress, and “the childer,” as she called the young people.
他说老里弗斯是个极朴素的人，但是位绅士，出身于一个十分古老的家庭。沼泽居一建起来就属于里弗斯家了。她声称那房子“大约有两百年了。虽说是个小小的粗陋的地方，跟莫顿谷里奥利弗先生的大宅没法比。但我还记得比尔·奥利弗的父亲是个走乡串户的针匠师傅，而里弗斯家从亨利时代就是贵族，任何人去看看莫顿教堂法衣室里的登记薄就知道了。”尽管如此，她也承认，“老主人跟其他人一样，没什么大不同的地方：发疯似地爱打猎、种种庄稼等等。”女主人却不一样。她爱读书，学识渊博，“孩子们”都像她。这一带没人跟他们一样，甚至以前也没有。他们三个都喜欢读书，几乎从刚会说话时就喜欢上了，而且一直“有自己的个性”。圣约翰先生长大后，上了大学，做了牧师。女孩子们等离开学校后就会去找工作，当家庭教师。她们告诉过她，她们的父亲几年前由于信托人破产，赔了一大笔钱。现在他没钱给她们了，她们必须养活自己。她们很久没在家住了，这回是因为父亲去世才回来住几个星期，不过她们确实很喜欢沼泽居和莫顿，还有周围这些荒原和小山。她们去过伦敦，还到过很多大城市，但她们总说没什么地方能比得上家里。而且她们姐妹相处得很好——从不争吵或“争论”。她不知道哪里还有像这家人这么团结和睦的。 Old Mr. Rivers, she said, was a plain man enough, but a gentleman, and of as ancient a family as could be found.Marsh End had belonged to the Rivers ever since it was a house: and it was, she affirmed, “aboon two hundred year old—for all it looked but a small, humble place, naught to compare wi’ Mr. Oliver’s grand hall down i’ Morton Vale.But she could remember Bill Oliver’s father a journeyman needle maker; and th’ Rivers wor gentry i’ th’ owd days o’ th’ Henrys, as onybody might see by looking into th’ registers i’ Morton Church vestry.”Still, she allowed, “the owd maister was like other folk—naught mich out o’ t’ common way: stark mad o’ shooting, and farming, and sich like.”The mistress was different.She was a great reader, and studied a deal; and the “bairns” had taken after her.There was nothing like them in these parts, nor ever had been; they had liked learning, all three, almost from the time they could speak; and they had always been “of a mak’ of their own.”Mr. St. John, when he grew up, would go to college and be a parson; and the girls, as soon as they left school, would seek places as governesses: for they had told her their father had some years ago lost a great deal of money by a man he had trusted turning bankrupt;and as he was now not rich enough to give them fortunes, they must provide for themselves.They had lived very little at home for a long while, and were only come now to stay a few weeks on account of their father’s death; but they did so like Marsh End and Morton, and all these moors and hills about.They had been in London, and many other grand towns; but they always said there was no place like home; and then they were so agreeable with each other—never fell out nor “threaped.”She did not know where there was such a family for being united.
摘完醋栗，我问两位小姐和她们的哥哥现在去哪儿了。 Having finished my task of gooseberry picking, I asked where the two ladies and their brother were now.
“去莫顿散步了，不过半小时内就会回来喝茶。” “Gone over to Morton for a walk; but they would be back in half-an hour to tea.”
他们的确是按汉娜说的时间回来的，从厨房的门走进屋。圣约翰先生见到我只鞠了个躬就穿过厨房走了。两位小姐停下来，玛丽言语简洁、和气平静地表示，看到我身体恢复能下楼了，她很高兴。黛安娜握着我的手，对我摇摇头。 They returned within the time Hannah had allotted them: they entered by the kitchen door.Mr. St. John, when he saw me, merely bowed and passed through; the two ladies stopped: Mary, in a few words, kindly and calmly expressed the pleasure she felt in seeing me well enough to be able to come down; Diana took my hand: she shook her head at me.
“你该等我同意后再下楼的。”她说，“你看起来还是很苍白——还这么瘦！可怜的孩子！——可怜的姑娘！” “You should have waited for my leave to descend,” she said.“You still look very pale—and so thin!Poor child!—poor girl!”
黛安娜的声音，在我听来，像鸽子的咕咕声。她的双眼令我愿意与之相对。她的整个脸庞看上去都充满着魅力。玛丽的面容同样聪慧，五官同样漂亮，但表情却更为含蓄，举止虽然温柔，却更有距离感。黛安娜的神情和言谈都带有某种权威感，显然她很有主见。我天性乐于顺从她这种人的权威，并在自己良心和自尊的允许下，屈服于活跃的意志。 Diana had a voice toned, to my ear, like the cooing of a dove.She possessed eyes whose gaze I delighted to encounter.Her whole face seemed to me fill of charm.Mary’s countenance was equally intelligent—her features equally pretty; but her expression was more reserved, and her manners, though gentle, more distant.Diana looked and spoke with a certain authority: she had a will, evidently.It was my nature to feel pleasure in yielding to an authority supported like hers, and to bend, where my conscience and self-respect permitted, to an active will.
“你呆在这里干什么？”她继续说，“这不是你该呆的地方。玛丽和我有时会坐在厨房，因为我们在家比较随意，甚至有些放肆。但你是客人，应该到客厅里去。” “And what business have you here?” she continued.“It is not your place.Mary and I sit in the kitchen sometimes, because at home we like to be free, even to license—but you are a visitor, and must go into the parlour.”
“我在这儿很好。” “I am very well here.”
“一点也不好，汉娜跑来跑去，会把你弄得一身面粉。” “Not at all, with Hannah bustling about and covering you with flour.”
“再说，这炉火对你来说太热了。”玛丽插嘴道。 “Besides, the fire is too hot for you,” interposed Mary.
“就是啊。”她姐姐说，“来吧，听话。”她仍握着我的手，拉我起来，领我到了里屋。 “To be sure,” added her sister.“Come, you must be obedient.”And still holding my hand she made me rise, and led me into the inner room.
“坐那儿，”她把我推到沙发上，“我们先脱掉衣服，喝点茶。我们在这个小小的荒原之家还能享受另一种特权——要是愿意的话，趁汉娜忙着烤啊、煮啊、洗啊、烫啊的时候，我们就会自己动手做饭。” “Sit there,” she said, placing me on the sofa, “while we take our things off and get the tea ready; it is another privilege we exercise in our little moorland home—to prepare our own meals when we are so inclined, or when Hannah is baking, brewing, washing, or ironing.”
她关上门，留下我和圣约翰先生单独在一起。他坐在我对面，手里拿着一本书或是份报纸。我先仔细观察了客厅，然后又看了看客厅的主人。 She closed the door, leaving me solus with Mr. St. John, who sat opposite, a book or newspaper in his hand.I examined first, the parlour, and then its occupant.
客厅不大，陈设简陋，然而却很舒适，因为它干净整洁。老式的椅子非常明亮，胡桃木的桌子如镜子般光滑。几幅古怪又古老的男女肖像画装饰着褪了色的墙壁。带玻璃门的橱柜里摆着一些书和一套古瓷器。屋子里没有多余的装饰，除了侧桌上立着的一对针线盒和一只红木女式书台，也没有一件现代家具。一切东西，包括地毯和窗帘，乍看上去都很陈旧，却保养得很好。 The parlour was rather a small room, very plainly furnished, yet comfortable, because clean and neat.The old-fashioned chairs were very bright, and the walnut-wood table was like a looking-glass.A few strange, antique portraits of the men and women of other days decorated the stained walls; a cupboard with glass doors contained some books and an ancient set of china.There was no superfluous ornament in the room—not one modern piece of furniture, save a brace of workboxes and a lady’s desk in rosewood, which stood on a side-table: everything—including the carpet and curtains—looked at once well worn and well saved.
圣约翰先生就像墙上那些落满灰尘的画像一样，定定地坐着，眼睛盯着正在读的东西，嘴唇紧闭——他这样容易让人仔细观察。让他作为雕像，倒比作为一个人容易得多。他很年轻，大约二十八到三十岁之间，身材修长。眼睛镶在脸上，轮廓纯净，一张希腊式的脸，笔直的、古典式的鼻子，雅典式的嘴和下巴。的确，很少有英国人的脸像他这样古典的。怪不得他对我那不规则的轮廓那么吃惊，是他自己的太协调了。他的眼睛又大又蓝，长着褐色的睫毛。高高的额头，白得如同象牙一样，几缕金发随意地搭在上面。 Mr. St. John—sitting as still as one of the dusty pictures on the walls, keeping his eyes fixed on the page he perused, and his lips mutely sealed—was easy enough to examine.Had he been a statue instead of a man, he could not have been easier.He was young—perhaps from twenty-eight to thirty—tall, slender; his face riveted the eye; it was like a Greek face, very pure in outline: quite a straight, classic nose; quite an Athenian mouth and chin.It is seldom, indeed, an English face comes so near the antique models as did his.He might well be a little shocked at the irregularity of my lineaments, his own being so harmonious.His eyes were large and blue, with brown lashes; his high forehead, colourless as ivory, was partially streaked over by careless locks of fair hair.
这是个文雅的轮廓，不是么，读者？然而被描述的他却没有让人感到温和、柔顺、敏感，甚至平静。他现在静静地坐着，可他那鼻孔、嘴巴、眉毛，在我看来，都显露出某种不安，或者严厉，或者热切。直到他妹妹们回来，他都不曾跟我说过一句话，甚至都没看过我一眼。黛安娜进进出出地准备茶点，并给我带来一块在炉顶上烤的小饼。 This is a gentle delineation, is it not, reader?Yet he whom it describes scarcely impressed one with the idea of a gentle, a yielding, an impressible, or even of a placid nature.Quiescent as he now sat, there was something about his nostril, his mouth, his brow, which, to my perceptions, indicated elements within either restless, or hard, or eager.He did not speak to me one word, nor even direct to me one glance, till his sisters returned.Diana, as she passed in and out, in the course of preparing tea, brought me a little cake, baked on the top of the oven.
“快吃吧，”她说，“你肯定饿了。汉娜说你早饭后就只喝了点粥。” “Eat that now,” she said: “you must be hungry.Hannah says you have had nothing but some gruel since breakfast.”
我没有拒绝，因为我的食欲已被激起，而且很旺盛。里弗斯先生这时合上他的书，来到桌子旁边坐了下来，用他那双像画一样的蓝眼睛盯着我。他的注视中透出一种不拘礼节的直率，一种搜寻的、果断的坚定不移。这说明这之前他是故意不看陌生人，而并非羞怯。 I did not refuse it, for my appetite was awakened and keen.Mr. Rivers now closed his book, approached the table, and, as he took a seat, fixed his blue pictorial-looking eyes full on me.There was an unceremonious directness, a searching, decided steadfastness in his gaze now, which told that intention, and not diffidence, had hitherto kept it averted from the stranger.
“你很饿。”他说。 “You are very hungry,” he said.
“是的，先生。”我就是这样，一直如此，出于本能，简洁地回答问题，直白明了。 “I am, sir.”It is my way—it always was my way, by instinct—ever to meet the brief with brevity, the direct with plainness.
“发低烧时让你禁食三天是有好处的，一开始就满足你的食欲会有危险。现在你可以吃了，不过也得有节制。” “It is well for you that a low fever has forced you to abstain for the last three days: there would have been danger in yielding to the cravings of your appetite at first. Now you may eat, though still not immoderately.”
“我相信我不会吃你们太久的，先生。”我笨拙而不加润饰地回答道。 “I trust I shall not eat long at your expense, sir,” was my very clumsily-contrived, unpolished answer.
“对，”他冷冷地回答说，“等你告诉我们你家人的住址，我们就写信给他们，你就可以回家了。” “No,” he said coolly: “when you have indicated to us the residence of your friends, we can write to them, and you may be restored to home.”
“那个，我得坦白说，根本办不到。我根本无亲无故。” “That, I must plainly tell you, is out of my power to do; being absolutely without home and friends.”
三个人都看着我，但没有不信任。我觉得他们的眼中没有怀疑，更多的只是好奇。尤其是两位小姐。圣约翰的目光虽然表面上看起来很清澈，实际上却难以揣测。他似乎用他的眼睛来探寻别人的心思，而不是表达自己的心思。那目光既敏锐又含蓄，很大程度上会令人尴尬而非得到鼓励。 The three looked at me, but not distrustfully; I felt there was no suspicion in their glances: there was more of curiosity.I speak particularly of the young ladies.St. John’s eyes, though clear enough in a literal sense, in a figurative one were difficult to fathom.He seemed to use them rather as instruments to search other people’s thoughts, than as agents to reveal his own: the which combination of keenness and reserve was considerably more calculated to embarrass than to encourage.
“你的意思是，”他问，“你任何亲朋都没有，孤身一人？” “Do you mean to say,” he asked, “that you are completely isolated from every connection?”
“是的。我与任何人都毫无关联，无权进入英国任何一个家庭。” “I do. Not a tie links me to any living thing: not a claim do I possess to admittance under any roof in England.”
“以你的年龄，这种情况太少见了！” “A most singular position at your age!”
这时我看见他的眼神转向我交叠在桌子上的双手。我不知道他在搜寻什么。他自己马上就给出了解释。 Here I saw his glance directed to my hands, which were folded on the table before me.I wondered what he sought there: his words soon explained the quest.
“你没结过婚吗？你是个老姑娘？” “You have never been married?You are a spinster?”
黛安娜笑了。“嗨，她最多才十七八岁哪，圣约翰。”她说。 Diana laughed.“Why, she can’t be above seventeen or eighteen years old, St. John,” said she.
“我快十九了，但我没结婚。没有。” “I am near nineteen: but I am not married. No.”
我感到脸上升起一股灼热，一提及婚姻，我那痛苦不安的回忆就会被唤醒。他们都看出了我的窘迫和不安的情绪。黛安娜和玛丽为使我安心，将目光移开我通红的脸。但那位更冷酷、更严厉的哥哥则继续盯着我，直到他激起的烦恼令我不但脸红而且流出了眼泪。 I felt a burning glow mount to my face; for bitter and agitating recollections were awakened by the allusion to marriage.They all saw the embarrassment and the emotion.Diana and Mary relieved me by turning their eyes elsewhere than to my crimsoned visage; but the colder and sterner brother continued to gaze, till the trouble he had excited forced out tears as well as colour.
“这之前你住哪儿？”他现在问道。 “Where did you last reside?” he now asked.
“你太爱打听了，圣约翰。”玛丽低声咕哝道。可他靠在桌上，再次用他那坚定、带有穿透力的眼神看着我，要我回答。 “You are too inquisitive, St. John,” murmured Mary in a low voice; but he leaned over the table and required an answer by a second firm and piercing look.
“我住在什么地方，和谁同住，都是我的秘密。”我简明地回答。 “The name of the place where, and of the person with whom I lived, is my secret,” I replied concisely.
“那个，如果你愿意，依我看，你有权保密，不论是对圣约翰还是其他任何打探者。”黛安娜说道。 “Which, if you like, you have, in my opinion, a right to keep, both from St. John and every other questioner,” remarked Diana.
“可是如果我对你或你的往事一无所知，我就无法帮你。”他说，“而你需要帮助，不是吗？” “Yet if I know nothing about you or your history, I cannot help you,” he said.“And you need help, do you not?”
“迄今为止，我需要帮助，也一直在寻求帮助，先生，只希望哪位真正的慈善家能给我一份我能做的工作，让我能以此糊口，哪怕只能满足最基本的生活需求。” “I need it, and I seek it so far, sir, that some true philanthropist will put me in the way of getting work which I can do, and the remuneration for which will keep me, if but in the barest necessaries of life.”
“我不知道我是不是个真正的慈善家，但我愿意竭诚帮助你实现如此诚实的目的。那么，首先，告诉我你习惯做什么，能够做什么。” “I know not whether I am a true philanthropist; yet I am willing to aid you to the utmost of my power in a purpose so honest.First, then, tell me what you have been accustomed to do, and what you CAN do.”
这时我已喝下我的茶。茶水令我精神大振，就像巨人喝下烈酒一般，给我衰弱的神经注入新的气色，使我能够稳稳地对付这位富有洞察力的年轻法官。 I had now swallowed my tea.I was mightily refreshed by the beverage; as much so as a giant with wine: it gave new tone to my unstrung nerves, and enabled me to address this penetrating young judge steadily.
“里弗斯先生，”我转向他，像他看我一样看着他，坦率而毫无掩饰地说，“你和你的妹妹们已经给了我很大的帮助，那是人所能给予其同类的最大帮助。你们高尚的好客之情把我从死亡中救了出来。这种恩惠使你们拥有无限的权利要求我的感激，并且在一定程度上有了解我秘密的权利。我会在不损害自己内心平静，不损害自己和他人的精神与肉体安全的前提下，尽量把你们救了的这个流浪者的来历告诉你们。 “Mr. Rivers,” I said, turning to him, and looking at him, as he looked at me, openly and without diffidence, “you and your sisters have done me a great service—the greatest man can do his fellow being; you have rescued me, by your noble hospitality, from death.This benefit conferred gives you an unlimited claim on my gratitude, and a claim, to a certain extent, on my confidence.I will tell you as much of the history of the wanderer you have harboured, as I can tell without compromising my own peace of mind—my own security, moral and physical, and that of others.
“我是个孤儿，是个牧师的女儿。在我记事之前，父母就去世了。我是依赖别人长大的，并在一所慈善学校接受教育。我甚至可以告诉你们那学校的名字。我在那儿当了六年学生，当了两年老师——某郡的洛伍德孤儿院。里弗斯先生，你也许听说过吧？罗伯特·布罗克赫斯特牧师是那学校的司库。” “I am an orphan, the daughter of a clergyman.My parents died before I could know them.I was brought up a dependant; educated in a charitable institution.I will even tell you the name of the establishment, where I passed six years as a pupil, and two as a teacher—Lowood Orphan Asylum,—shire: you will have heard of it, Mr. Rivers?—the Rev. Robert Brocklehurst is the treasurer."
“我听说过布罗克赫斯特先生，也见过那所学校。” “I have heard of Mr. Brocklehurst, and I have seen the school.”
“大约一年前，我离开了洛伍德，做了一名家庭教师。我有了个好的处境，过得很快乐。四天前我被迫离开那地方，来到了这里。我离开的原因不能也不该解释，即使解释也没用，只会招来危险，而且听起来难以置信。我没有任何过失，我和你们三位中的任何一位一样毫无罪过。我很痛苦，而且肯定还得痛苦很久。因为把我从我视为天堂的地方赶出来的灾祸既离奇又可怕。我计划出走时只考虑到了两点——迅速、秘密。为保证这些，我留下了我所有的东西，只带了一个小包。而这小包，因为我的匆忙及心神不宁，我忘了把它从带我来惠特克劳斯的马车上拿下来。于是我来到这里时，身无分文。我在户外睡了两夜，又四处流浪了两天，没有踏进过一家门槛。但这段时间里我确实只有两次尝到了食物。就在我因为饥饿、疲惫和绝望而只剩最后一口气时，是你，里弗斯先生，没让我在你家门前饿死，还把我收留了下来。那之后我知道你两个妹妹为我所做的一切。虽然在我昏睡期间，但我并非毫无知觉。她们自然、真诚、亲切的怜悯，与你合乎福音的慈善一样，对我来说恩重如山。” “I left Lowood nearly a year since to become a private governess.I obtained a good situation, and was happy.This place I was obliged to leave four days before I came here.The reason of my departure I cannot and ought not to explain: it would be useless, dangerous, and would sound incredible.No blame attached to me: I am as free from culpability as any one of you three.Miserable I am, and must be for a time; for the catastrophe which drove me from a house I had found a paradise was of a strange and direful nature.I observed but two points in planning my departure—speed, secrecy: to secure these, I had to leave behind me everything I possessed except a small parcel; which, in my hurry and trouble of mind, I forgot to take out of the coach that brought me to Whitcross.To this neighbourhood, then, I came, quite destitute.I slept two nights in the open air, and wandered about two days without crossing a threshold: but twice in that space of time did I taste food; and it was when brought by hunger, exhaustion, and despair almost to the last gasp, that you, Mr. Rivers, forbade me to perish of want at your door, and took me under the shelter of your roof.I know all your sisters have done for me since—for I have not been insensible during my seeming torpor—and I owe to their spontaneous, genuine, genial compassion as large a debt as to your evangelical charity.”
“现在别让她再说话了，圣约翰，”我停下来时黛安娜说道，“她显然还不宜激动。先去沙发那儿坐下，埃利奥特小姐。” “Don’t make her talk any more now, St. John,” said Diana, as I paused; “she is evidently not yet fit for excitement.Come to the sofa and sit down now, Miss Elliott.”
听到这个化名我不觉吃了一惊：我已经忘了我的新名字。什么也逃不过里弗斯先生的眼睛，他立刻注意到了。 I gave an involuntary half start at hearing the alias: I had forgotten my new name.Mr. Rivers, whom nothing seemed to escape, noticed it at once.
“你说过你的名字叫简·埃利奥特吧？”他说。 “You said your name was Jane Elliott?” he observed.
“我是这么说的。我是觉得现在用这个名字方便些，但这不是我的真名，所以听到时感到有点陌生。” “I did say so; and it is the name by which I think it expedient to be called at present, but it is not my real name, and when I hear it, it sounds strange to me.”
“你不愿说出你的真名吗？” “Your real name you will not give?”
“是的，我怕被人发现，所以一切可能导致被人发现的披露，我都会避免。” “No: I fear discovery above all things; and whatever disclosure would lead to it, I avoid.”
“我肯定你是对的。”黛安娜说，“哥哥，现在真的该让她休息一下了。” “You are quite right, I am sure,” said Diana.“Now do, brother, let her be at peace a while.”
但圣约翰先生沉默一会儿，又像以前一样，冷静敏锐地重新开口说道： But when St. John had mused a few moments he recommenced as imperturbably and with as much acumen as ever.
“你不愿长期依靠我们的好客。我知道，你希望尽快摆脱我妹妹们的怜悯，而且，尤其是，我的慈善（我很明白你用词的区别，但我并不生气——这是对的）。你想独立于我们，是吗？” “You would not like to be long dependent on our hospitality—you would wish, I see, to dispense as soon as may be with my sisters’ compassion, and, above all, with my CHARITY (I am quite sensible of the distinction drawn, nor do I resent it—it is just): you desire to be independent of us?”
“是的，我已经说过了。告诉我如何工作，或如何找工作。我现在仅此一个请求，然后我就走，哪怕是去最简陋的小茅屋。但在那之前，请允许我继续呆在这儿，我害怕再次尝试无家可归、贫苦交加的恐惧。” “I do: I have already said so.Show me how to work, or how to seek work: that is all I now ask; then let me go, if it be but to the meanest cottage; but till then, allow me to stay here: I dread another essay of the horrors of homeless destitution.”
“你的确应该呆在这儿。”黛安娜把她白皙的手放在我头上说道。“你应当呆在这儿。”玛丽用她那不露声色的语气重复道，仿佛她天生就这样说话。 “Indeed you SHALL stay here,” said Diana, putting her white hand on my head.“You SHALL,” repeated Mary, in the tone of undemonstrative sincerity which seemed natural to her.
“你看，我的妹妹们很高兴收留你，”圣约翰先生说，“就像她们愿意留下并珍爱一只被寒风刮进窗户，快要冻僵的小鸟。我则更倾向于让你自食其力，也会努力这么做。但你要知道，我的能力有限。我只是在乡下的穷教区任职，我的帮助一定微不足道。如果你不屑于做这些日常琐事，就去找个比我提供的更有效的援助者吧。” “My sisters, you see, have a pleasure in keeping you,” said Mr. St. John, “as they would have a pleasure in keeping and cherishing a half-frozen bird, some wintry wind might have driven through their casement.I feel more inclination to put you in the way of keeping yourself, and shall endeavour to do so; but observe, my sphere is narrow.I am but the incumbent of a poor country parish: my aid must be of the humblest sort.And if you are inclined to despise the day of small things, seek some more efficient succour than such as I can offer.”
“她已经说了她愿意做任何她能做的正当的事，”黛安娜替我回答道，“而且你也知道，圣约翰，她也找不到别人帮忙，她也只能忍受你这种顽固的人了。” “She has already said that she is willing to do anything honest she can do,” answered Diana for me; “and you know, St. John, she has no choice of helpers: she is forced to put up with such crusty people as you.”
“我愿意做裁缝，做普通女工。要是做不了更好的活，我也愿意做个仆人，做保姆。”我答道。 “I will be a dressmaker; I will be a plain-workwoman; I will be a servant, a nurse-girl, if I can be no better,” I answered.
“好吧。”圣约翰十分冷淡地说，“如果你的想法确实如此，我答应帮助你，按我自己的时间和方式。” “Right,” said Mr. St. John, quite coolly.“If such is your spirit, I promise to aid you, in my own time and way.”
然后他又接着开始看喝茶之前看的那本书。我很快退了出去，以我目前的体力，我已说得够多，坐得够久了。 He now resumed the book with which he had been occupied before tea.I soon withdrew, for I had talked as much, and sat up as long, as my present strength would permit.
第三十章 CHAPTER XXX
我越是了解沼泽屋的人，就越是喜欢他们。没过几天，我的身体就康复了，可以坐一整天，有时还可以出去走走。我可以参与黛安娜和玛丽的所有活动；只要她们愿意，我还可以一直与她们畅聊；无论何时何地，只要她们允许，我都会去帮忙。在与她们的交往中有一种令人振奋的乐趣，我还是第一次尝到——那来自于我们趣味、情感和原则的完美融合的乐趣。 The more I knew of the inmates of Moor House, the better I liked them.In a few days I had so far recovered my health that I could sit up all day, and walk out sometimes.I could join with Diana and Mary in all their occupations; converse with them as much as they wished, and aid them when and where they would allow me.There was a reviving pleasure in this intercourse, of a kind now tasted by me for the first time—the pleasure arising from perfect congeniality of tastes, sentiments, and principles.
她们喜欢读的书，我也爱读，她们欣赏的东西也令我快乐，她们赞成的事情亦是我尊重的。她们热爱自己僻静的家。同样，我也从这座灰色的、小巧而又古老的建筑中发现了一种强烈而持久的魅力。它有着低矮的屋顶，格子状窗户，破败的墙壁，还有两边长着古杉的大道——那些树被山风吹得统统倒向了一边；花园里，紫杉和冬青郁郁葱葱，也只有那些生命力最顽强的花种才会开放。她们眷恋居所周遭的紫色荒原，眷恋从大门口延伸下去的卵石马道所通向的空谷。马道在蕨类丛生的山坡上蜿蜒，然后穿过石南荒野边缘的几块最荒凉的小牧场。这里饲养着一群灰色的沼地羊和它们面如苔藓的小羊羔。我要说，她们对这儿的景色怀有无比深切的依恋。我理解她们的这种感情，并与她们分享这份感情的强烈与真挚。我看到了这地方的魅力。我感觉到它孤寂的神圣，我的眼睛饱览了它连绵起伏的轮廓。苔藓、石南、野花遍布的草地、鲜艳夺目的欧洲蕨，还有那柔和的花岗岩峭壁，都给它的山脊与山谷着上了色彩。这些细节对我和对她们来说都一样，都是无数的纯洁、甜蜜的欢乐之源。猛烈的大风或柔和的微风，凄风苦雨的天气或宁静祥和的日子，日出时分或日落时刻，月色明亮或乌云密布的夜晚，都令我和她们一样对这一地区着迷，身心都深深为之陶醉。 I liked to read what they liked to read: what they enjoyed, delighted me; what they approved, I reverenced.They loved their sequestered home.I, too, in the grey, small, antique structure, with its low roof, its latticed casements, its mouldering walls, its avenue of aged firs—all grown aslant under the stress of mountain winds; its garden, dark with yew and holly—and where no flowers but of the hardiest species would bloom—found a charm both potent and permanent.They clung to the purple moors behind and around their dwelling—to the hollow vale into which the pebbly bridle-path leading from their gate descended, and which wound between fern banks first, and then amongst a few of the wildest little pasture fields that ever bordered a wilderness of heath,or gave sustenance to a flock of grey moorland sheep, with their little mossy-faced lambs:—they clung to this scene, I say, with a perfect enthusiasm of attachment.I could comprehend the feeling, and share both its strength and truth.I saw the fascination of the locality.I felt the consecration of its loneliness: my eye feasted on the outline of swell and sweep—on the wild colouring communicated to ridge and dell by moss, by heath-bell, by flower-sprinkled turf, by brilliant bracken, and mellow granite crag.These details were just to me what they were to them—so many pure and sweet sources of pleasure.The strong blast and the soft breeze; the rough and the halcyon day; the hours of sunrise and sunset; the moonlight and the clouded night, developed for me, in these regions, the same attraction as for them—wound round my faculties the same spell that entranced theirs.
在室内我们同样相处融洽。她们比我更有造诣，书也读得比我多，不过求知心切的我追随着她们已踏过的知识之路。我贪婪地阅读她们借给我的书，晚上与她们讨论我白天的收获，这真是莫大的满足。我们想法一致，观点相合。总之，大家志趣相投。 Indoors we agreed equally well.They were both more accomplished and better read than I was; but with eagerness I followed in the path of knowledge they had trodden before me.I devoured the books they lent me: then it was full satisfaction to discuss with them in the evening what I had perused during the day.Thought fitted thought; opinion met opinion: we coincided, in short, perfectly.
如果说我们三个人中有一个更出色，更像带头人的话，那就是黛安娜了。她的体态远胜于我：她容貌姣好，富有活力。她充沛的精力中流动着丰富的生命力，使我为之惊异又难以理解。晚上刚开始的时候，我还能谈一会儿，但起初的这阵活跃和流利过后，我就只乐意坐在黛安娜脚边的小凳子上，把头枕在她膝盖上，听她和玛丽轮流就一些我略知一二的话题进行充分的讨论。黛安娜提出要教我德语。我愿意跟她学。我看出她乐意也很适合做个教师，而我同样乐意也适合做个学生。我们的天性如此吻合，因此彼此间就产生了最强烈的感情。她们发现我会画画，便立即把她们的画笔和颜料都给我用。我这项略胜过她们的技能，既使她们惊奇，也令她们着迷。玛丽坐着看我画画，一坐就是一小时。然后她就跟我学，俨然一个温顺、聪明又勤奋的学生。就这样，我们忙这忙那，互相解闷，几天就像几个小时，几个星期的日子就像几天一样过去了。 If in our trio there was a superior and a leader, it was Diana.Physically, she far excelled me: she was handsome; she was vigorous.In her animal spirits there was an affluence of life and certainty of flow, such as excited my wonder, while it baffled my comprehension.I could talk a while when the evening commenced, but the first gush of vivacity and fluency gone, I was fain to sit on a stool at Diana’s feet, to rest my head on her knee, and listen alternately to her and Mary, while they sounded thoroughly the topic on which I had but touched.Diana offered to teach me German.I liked to learn of her: I saw the part of instructress pleased and suited her; that of scholar pleased and suited me no less.Our natures dovetailed: mutual affection—of the strongest kind—was the result.They discovered I could draw: their pencils and colour-boxes were immediately at my service.My skill, greater in this one point than theirs, surprised and charmed them.Mary would sit and watch me by the hour together: then she would take lessons; and a docile, intelligent, assiduous pupil she made.Thus occupied, and mutually entertained, days passed like hours, and weeks like days.
至于圣约翰先生，我跟他的两个妹妹之间自然而迅速地生出的这种亲密的关系，并没有延伸至他。我们之间现在还保持着距离的一个原因就是:他平时较少在家,他大部分的时间都用来探访他的教区里那些居所分散的病人和穷人了。 As to Mr. St John, the intimacy which had arisen so naturally and rapidly between me and his sisters did not extend to him.One reason of the distance yet observed between us was, that he was comparatively seldom at home: a large proportion of his time appeared devoted to visiting the sick and poor among the scattered population of his parish.
无论什么天气都不能阻止他的神职之旅。无论晴天或雨天，他都会在结束早晨的学习之后，戴上帽子，身后跟着他父亲的老猎犬卡洛，出门执行他的友爱或职责的使命——我不知道他对此是怎么看待的。有时，当天气很糟的时候，他的妹妹们会劝他别出去。这时，他会面带独特微笑，庄严多过愉悦，说道： No weather seemed to hinder him in these pastoral excursions: rain or fair, he would, when his hours of morning study were over, take his hat, and, followed by his father’s old pointer, Carlo, go out on his mission of love or duty—I scarcely know in which light he regarded it.Sometimes, when the day was very unfavourable, his sisters would expostulate.He would then say, with a peculiar smile, more solemn than cheerful—
“如果一阵风或几滴雨就可以使我放弃这么简单的工作，那么这种懈怠对于我给自己规划的将来有什么作用呢？” “And if I let a gust of wind or a sprinkling of rain turn me aside from these easy tasks, what preparation would such sloth be for the future I propose to myself?”
黛安娜和玛丽对这个问题一般会叹一口气，继而陷入沉思，显然很伤心。 Diana and Mary’s general answer to this question was a sigh, and some minutes of apparently mournful meditation.
但是除了他频繁外出之外，还有其他因素影响我们之间友情的培养：他似乎是个沉默寡言、心不在焉，甚至爱冥思苦想的人。他热衷于自己的牧师工作，生活和习惯无可挑剔。可他看上去好像并没有享受到一个虔诚的基督教徒和脚踏实地的慈善家所应得的回报——精神的宁静和心灵的满足。晚上，他时常会坐在窗边的桌子旁，面前有些纸张。他会停止读写，一只手撑起下巴，任凭思绪飞往到什么地方。然而从他频繁闪动和睁大的眼睛中，可以看出他的不安与激动。 But besides his frequent absences, there was another barrier to friendship with him: he seemed of a reserved, an abstracted, and even of a brooding nature.Zealous in his ministerial labours, blameless in his life and habits, he yet did not appear to enjoy that mental serenity, that inward content, which should be the reward of every sincere Christian and practical philanthropist.Often, of an evening, when he sat at the window, his desk and papers before him, he would cease reading or writing, rest his chin on his hand, and deliver himself up to I know not what course of thought; but that it was perturbed and exciting might be seen in the frequent flash and changeful dilation of his eye.
而且，我觉得自然对于他来说并不像对于他妹妹们那样，是快乐的宝藏。我听过一次，也仅仅是那一次，他表达了对那崎岖的山脉怀有强烈的感情，对他称作“家”的这个地方的黑色的屋顶和古旧的墙壁，怀着与生俱来的爱恋。只是他在表达这种感情时的语调和用词显露出的忧郁多于愉悦。他从来没有为了去感受荒原舒心的宁静而漫步其中，也从来不去寻找或深思荒原给人带来的千百种平静的乐趣。 I think, moreover, that Nature was not to him that treasury of delight it was to his sisters.He expressed once, and but once in my hearing, a strong sense of the rugged charm of the hills, and an inborn affection for the dark roof and hoary walls he called his home; but there was more of gloom than pleasure in the tone and words in which the sentiment was manifested;and never did he seem to roam the moors for the sake of their soothing silence—never seek out or dwell upon the thousand peaceful delights they could yield.
因为他的沉默寡言，我过了一阵子才有机会探究他的思想。在莫顿他自己的教堂中，我听了他的布道后，才对他的才能有了些初步的了解。我希望可以描述出那次布道，可那却非我的能力所及。我甚至无法如实表达出那次布道对我的影响。 Incommunicative as he was, some time elapsed before I had an opportunity of gauging his mind.I first got an idea of its calibre when I heard him preach in his own church at Morton.I wish I could describe that sermon: but it is past my power.I cannot even render faithfully the effect it produced on me.
开头很平静，的确，就其语言和音调来说，自始至终都很平静。然后，一股真挚而严加控制的热情，很快注入到清晰的语调中，激发出有力的言语。然后言语愈发刚劲有力——精炼、扼要而有分寸。布道者的力量使人心灵为之震颤，头脑为之惊异，但两者都没有变得温和。他的布道自始至终有一种奇怪的悲痛，缺乏安慰人心的温柔。他不断严厉地提到加尔文教义——上帝的挑选、命中注定和永世受罚。每次他提到这些时，听起来都像是在宣布末日的来临。他布道完毕后，他的话非但没让我感到更好、更平静，或是更受启发，相反，我感受到了一种难以言状的悲伤。因为在我看来——我不知道别人是否有相同的感受——他的雄辩来自于充满失望、思绪混乱的内心深处，那里躁动着永不满足的渴望，还有不安的抱负。尽管圣约翰·里弗斯生活纯粹、心地善良、充满热情，但我确信他还是没有找到上帝那不被世人理解的安宁。我认为，他和我都没有找到。我因为自己破碎的偶像和失去的乐园而悔恨，这隐藏的悔恨拷问着我。尽管我最近总是避免提起，但它仍然无情地占据着我，压迫着我。 It began calm—and indeed, as far as delivery and pitch of voice went, it was calm to the end: an earnestly felt, yet strictly restrained zeal breathed soon in the distinct accents, and prompted the nervous language.This grew to force—compressed, condensed, controlled.The heart was thrilled, the mind astonished, by the power of the preacher: neither were softened.Throughout there was a strange bitterness; an absence of consolatory gentleness; stern allusions to Calvinistic doctrines—election, predestination, reprobation—were frequent; and each reference to these points sounded like a sentence pronounced for doom.When he had done, instead of feeling better, calmer, more enlightened by his discourse, I experienced an inexpressible sadness; for it seemed to me—I know not whether equally so to others—that the eloquence to which I had been listening had sprung from a depth where lay turbid dregs of disappointment—where moved troubling impulses of insatiate yearnings and disquieting aspirations.I was sure St. John Rivers—pure-lived, conscientious, zealous as he was—had not yet found that peace of God which passeth all understanding: he had no more found it, I thought, than had I with my concealed and racking regrets for my broken idol and lost elysium—regrets to which I have latterly avoided referring, but which possessed me and tyrannised over me ruthlessly.
与此同时，一个月过去了。黛安娜和玛丽不久就要离开沼泽屋，回到等待她们的、截然不同的生活环境当中。那是英国南部的一个时髦的大城市，她们要去那里当家庭教师。她们各自在不同的家庭谋职，被那些富有而又傲慢的家庭成员视为卑微的侍从。这些人不了解也没有去发现她们内在的美德，只是欣赏她们后天学到的技艺，就像赏识他们家厨师的手艺和侍女的爱好一样。圣约翰先生还没有跟我说过他之前曾许诺的要给我找工作的事，但我迫切地需要一份工作。一天早晨，有那么几分钟，客厅里只有我们俩，我鼓起勇气走向窗子的凹陷处。那里放着他的书桌椅，俨然一间神圣的小书房。虽然不知道怎样组织语言来提出问题，可我还是打算开口说点什么。因为无论何时，要打破包裹着他沉默寡言的天性的外壳都是不容易的。这时他省了我的麻烦，先开口了。 Meantime a month was gone.Diana and Mary were soon to leave Moor House, and return to the far different life and scene which awaited them, as governesses in a large, fashionable, south-of-England city,where each held a situation in families by whose wealthy and haughty members they were regarded only as humble dependants, and who neither knew nor sought out their innate excellences, and appreciated only their acquired accomplishments as they appreciated the skill of their cook or the taste of their waiting-woman.Mr. St. John had said nothing to me yet about the employment he had promised to obtain for me; yet it became urgent that I should have a vocation of some kind.One morning, being left alone with him a few minutes in the parlour, I ventured to approach the window-recess—which his table, chair, and desk consecrated as a kind of study—and I was going to speak, though not very well knowing in what words to frame my inquiry—for it is at all times difficult to break the ice of reserve glassing over such natures as his—when he saved me the trouble by being the first to commence a dialogue.
当我走近时，他抬起头，说道：“你有事要问我？” Looking up as I drew near—“You have a question to ask of me?” he said.
“是的。我想知道你是否听说过什么适合我做的工作。” “Yes; I wish to know whether you have heard of any service I can offer myself to undertake?”
“三个礼拜前我找到了或者说为你设计了一份工作，但你在这里似乎既有用也很愉快，因为我的妹妹们很明显地离不开你，有你的陪伴她们格外高兴。我认为打扰你们融洽的相处很不合适，还是等她们快要离开沼泽居，而必须向你提起时再说吧。” “I found or devised something for you three weeks ago; but as you seemed both useful and happy here—as my sisters had evidently become attached to you, and your society gave them unusual pleasure—I deemed it inexpedient to break in on your mutual comfort till their approaching departure from Marsh End should render yours necessary.”
“那她们三天后就要走了吗？”我说。 “And they will go in three days now?” I said.
“是的。她们走后，我会回到莫顿的牧师公馆。汉娜会陪我去，这所老房子就关闭了。” “Yes; and when they go, I shall return to the parsonage at Morton: Hannah will accompany me; and this old house will be shut up.”
我等了一会儿，期待他会继续开始时提到的话题，但他似乎进入了另一段思绪。从他的表情可以看出他已经忘了我和我的事。我不得不把他的思绪重新拉回到这个与我的需要密切相关，并且我急于想知道答案的话题上来。 I waited a few moments, expecting he would go on with the subject first broached: but he seemed to have entered another train of reflection: his look denoted abstraction from me and my business.I was obliged to recall him to a theme which was of necessity one of close and anxious interest to me.
“你找的是什么样的工作，里弗斯先生？我希望耽搁了这么久，这份工作不会难以得到吧。” “What is the employment you had in view, Mr. Rivers?I hope this delay will not have increased the difficulty of securing it.”
“噢，不会。因为这工作只取决于我是否把它提供给你，你是否接受。” “Oh, no; since it is in employment which depends only on me to give, and you to accept.”
他又停下了，似乎不愿再继续说下去。我开始不耐烦了，烦躁不安地动了一两下，并用急切而严厉的眼神盯着他的脸。这如同话语一样有效地传达我的感受，而且省掉了说话可能带来的麻烦。 He again paused: there seemed a reluctance to continue.I grew impatient: a restless movement or two, and an eager and exacting glance fastened on his face, conveyed the feeling to him as effectually as words could have done, and with less trouble.
“不必着急听我说。”他说，“实话告诉你吧，我也没什么合适的或是挣钱的工作可以提供给你。在我解释之前，请你回想一下我之前对你的提醒。我明确地说如果我帮你的话，肯定就如瞎子帮助跛子一样。我很穷。因为我发现，在偿还完父亲的债务后，剩下的遗产就只有这座破败的庄园、后面那排枯萎的冷杉，还有前面那片长着紫杉和冬青灌木的荒原。我出身卑微，虽然“里弗斯”是个古老的姓氏，但是家族里唯有的三个后裔，两个人在陌生人中间挣钱糊口，剩下那一个认为自己是个远离故土的异客——生是如此，死将亦如此。是的，他认为，并且必然认为命运给了他荣耀，他期盼有一天，摆脱俗世枷锁的十字架会放在他的肩膀上，期盼教会斗士的首领——他自己也是其中最卑微的一员——发号施令：‘起来，跟着我！’” “You need be in no hurry to hear,” he said: “let me frankly tell you, I have nothing eligible or profitable to suggest.Before I explain, recall, if you please, my notice, clearly given, that if I helped you, it must be as the blind man would help the lame.I am poor; for I find that, when I have paid my father’s debts, all the patrimony remaining to me will be this crumbling grange, the row of scathed firs behind, and the patch of moorish soil, with the yewtrees and holly-bushes in front.I am obscure: Rivers is an old name; but of the three sole descendants of the race, two earn the dependant’s crust among strangers, and the third considers himself an alien from his native country—not only for life, but in death.Yes, and deems, and is bound to deem, himself honoured by the lot, and aspires but after the day when the cross of separation from fleshly ties shall be laid on his shoulders, and when the Head of that church-militant of whose humblest members he is one, shall give the word, ‘Rise, follow Me!’”
圣约翰就像在布道一样说着这番话，声音平静、低沉，面容镇静，目光炯炯。他继续说道： St. John said these words as he pronounced his sermons, with a quiet, deep voice; with an unflushed cheek, and a coruscating radiance of glance.He resumed—
“既然我自己就是个贫穷的无名小卒，我能提供给你的也只能是贫穷而卑微的活计了。你甚至会认为做这工作有失身份——因为我现在了解了你的气质属于世人所说的高雅，你的品位趋于理想化，你的社交圈子里至少都是文化人，——但是我认为没有哪种对人类有益的工作是不光彩的。我相信，基督徒被派去耕种的土地如果越贫瘠、越无人开垦，他辛苦劳作所得的回报就越少，而他的荣誉就越高。在这种情形下，他肩负的是先驱者的使命；传播《福音书》的第一批先驱者就是使徒们——他们的首领就是耶稣，耶稣就是救世主。 “And since I am myself poor and obscure, I can offer you but a service of poverty and obscurity.YOU may even think it degrading—for I see now your habits have been what the world calls refined: your tastes lean to the ideal, and your society has at least been amongst the educated; but I consider that no service degrades which can better our race.I hold that the more arid and unreclaimed the soil where the Christian labourer’s task of tillage is appointed him—the scantier the meed his toil brings—the higher the honour.His, under such circumstances, is the destiny of the pioneer; and the first pioneers of the Gospel were the Apostles—their captain was Jesus, the Redeemer, Himself.”
“嗯？”他又一次停下的时候我说，“继续说吧。” “Well?” I said, as he again paused—“proceed.”
他在继续讲话前看了看我。确实，他似乎在从容地解读我的面孔，好像我的五官和面部的线条是一页纸上的文字。细细观察一番所得到的结论，他在之后的谈话中表露了一部分。 He looked at me before he proceeded: indeed, he seemed leisurely to read my face, as if its features and lines were characters on a page.The conclusions drawn from this scrutiny he partially expressed in his succeeding observations.
“我相信你会接受我提供的职位，”他说，“并且会干些时日，尽管不是永久地干下去，就像我不可能永久地在这个静谧隐蔽、狭小且越来越小的地方做一名英国乡村牧师。因为在你的天性里，有一种抗拒安逸的因子，这东西我也有，只是类型不同。” “I believe you will accept the post I offer you,” said he, “and hold it for a while: not permanently, though: any more than I could permanently keep the narrow and narrowing—the tranquil, hidden office of English country incumbent; for in your nature is an alloy as detrimental to repose as that in mine, though of a different kind.”
“请务必解释一下。”在他又一次停下时我催促道。 “Do explain,” I urged, when he halted once more.
