“他肯定是个坏人。”里弗斯先生说道。 “He must have been a bad man,” observed Mr. Rivers.
“你不了解他，别去评价他。”我有些激动地说。 “You don’t know him—don’t pronounce an opinion upon him,” I said, with warmth.
“很好。”他平静地答道，“我的脑子里也确实没在想他，我还得讲完我的故事。既然你不愿过问那个女教师的名字，我只能自己告诉你了。等等！我把它写在这儿，把重要的事情用白纸黑字写下来往往更能让人安心。” “Very well,” he answered quietly: “and indeed my head is otherwise occupied than with him: I have my tale to finish.Since you won’t ask the governess’s name, I must tell it of my own accord.Stay! I have it here—it is always more satisfactory to see important points written down, fairly committed to black and white.”
他又一次不慌不忙地拿出了那个皮夹子，打开它，翻了一遍，从一个夹层中抽出一张破旧的纸条，像是匆忙中撕下来的。我从纸的质地，还有上面深蓝、湖蓝和朱红色的污迹认出来，那是从遮盖画像的那张纸上撕下来的纸条。他站起身，把纸条拿到我眼前。我看到上面自己的笔迹，用墨汁写的字“简·爱”——无疑是我在走神的时候写下的。 And the pocket-book was again deliberately produced, opened, sought through; from one of its compartments was extracted a shabby slip of paper, hastily torn off: I recognised in its texture and its stains of ultra-marine, and lake, and vermillion, the ravished margin of the portrait-cover.He got up, held it close to my eyes: and I read, traced in Indian ink, in my own handwriting, the words “JANE EYRE”—the work doubtless of some moment of abstraction.
“布里格斯写给我的信是关于‘简·爱’的，”他说，“寻人启事上也是在找一个叫‘简·爱’的人，然而我认识一个叫‘简·埃利奥特’的人。我承认我也曾怀疑过，但是就在昨天下午，疑惑终于被证实了。你承认这个真名，丢掉别名吗？” “Briggs wrote to me of a Jane Eyre:” he said, “the advertisements demanded a Jane Eyre: I knew a Jane Elliott.—I confess I had my suspicions, but it was only yesterday afternoon they were at once resolved into certainty.You own the name and renounce the alias?”
“好吧，好吧，但是布里格斯先生在哪里呢？他可能比你知道更多关于罗切斯特先生的消息。” “Yes—yes; but where is Mr. Briggs?He perhaps knows more of Mr. Rochester than you do.”
“布里格斯在伦敦。我怀疑他压根就不知道关于罗切斯特先生的事情，他关注的并不是罗切斯特先生。而你却拣了芝麻丢了西瓜：你不问问为什么布里格斯先生要找你，他找你为了什么事。” “Briggs is in London.I should doubt his knowing anything at all about Mr. Rochester; it is not in Mr. Rochester he is interested.Meantime, you forget essential points in pursuing trifles: you do not inquire why Mr. Briggs sought after you—what he wanted with you.”
“好吧，那他想做什么？” “Well, what did he want?”
“就是为了告诉你，你的叔叔——住在马德拉的爱先生去世了，他把所有的财产都留给了你，你现在有钱了。仅仅这些，没别的了。” “Merely to tell you that your uncle, Mr. Eyre of Madeira, is dead; that he has left you all his property, and that you are now rich—merely that—nothing more.”
“我！——有钱了？” “I!—rich?”
“是啊，就是你，有钱了——十足的女继承人。” “Yes, you, rich—quite an heiress.”
接着是一阵沉默。 Silence succeeded.
“当然你必须证实自己的身份。”圣约翰接着马上说道，“这步骤一点也不难，然后你就能立即得到财产所有权了。你的财产现在归属于英国国债名下，布里格斯持有遗嘱和必要的文件。” “You must prove your identity of course,” resumed St. John presently: “a step which will offer no difficulties; you can then enter on immediate possession.Your fortune is vested in the English funds; Briggs has the will and the necessary documents.”
这里又翻出了一张新牌！读者们，这是件好事——转眼间从贫穷到富有——非常好的事情，但也不是一件能让人立刻明白，从而乐在其中的事。而且生活中还会有其他的机会比此事更能让人为之激动、为之欣喜。这件事实实在在，发生在现世，没有任何理想的成分；与之相关的一切也都实实在在，清清楚楚，它的表现形式也是如此。 Here was a new card turned up!It is a fine thing, reader, to be lifted in a moment from indigence to wealth—a very fine thing; but not a matter one can comprehend, or consequently enjoy, all at once.And then there are other chances in life far more thrilling and rapture-giving: THIS is solid, an affair of the actual world, nothing ideal about it: all its associations are solid and sober, and its manifestations are the same.
当一个人听到自己得到了一大笔财产，他不会又蹦又跳，高喊“万岁！”，他会开始考虑自己的责任和应做的事业。在称心如意之余便会生出种种心事，于是我们克制自己，庄重地皱着眉头，为我们的幸福而思索。 One does not jump, and spring, and shout hurrah! at hearing one has got a fortune; one begins to consider responsibilities, and to ponder business; on a base of steady satisfaction rise certain grave cares, and we contain ourselves, and blood over our bliss with a solemn brow.
况且，“遗产”、“遗赠”这两个词总是伴随着“死亡”、“葬礼”这些词。我听说过的那位叔叔去世了——我唯一的亲人。自从我知道我还有个叔叔，我就一直希望将来某天能见他一面，可是现在，我再也别想了。而且，这笔钱只留给了我，不是给我和一个欢乐的大家庭，而仅仅是身单影只的我。这无疑是一大恩赐，自我独立将会是非常棒的事。是的，我感觉到了这点，这种想法充斥着我的心。 Besides, the words Legacy, Bequest, go side by side with the words, Death, Funeral.My uncle I had heard was dead—my only relative; ever since being made aware of his existence, I had cherished the hope of one day seeing him: now, I never should.And then this money came only to me: not to me and a rejoicing family, but to my isolated self.It was a grand boon doubtless; and independence would be glorious—yes, I felt that—that thought swelled my heart.
“你终于舒展了眉头。”里弗斯先生说，“我还以为美杜莎女神在看着你，要把你变成一块石头呢。也许现在你要问问你身价多少了？” “You unbend your forehead at last,” said Mr. Rivers.“I thought Medusa had looked at you, and that you were turning to stone.Perhaps now you will ask how much you are worth?”
“我身价多少？” “How much am I worth?”
“喔，一点也不多！当然也不足挂齿了——我想他们说的是两万英镑吧——但那又怎样呢？” “Oh, a trifle!Nothing of course to speak of—twenty thousand pounds, I think they say—but what is that?”
“两万英镑？” “Twenty thousand pounds?”
这真是又让人大吃一惊，我之前一直估计有四五千。这个消息着实让我惊讶了好一会儿。我从来没听圣约翰先生大笑过，这会儿他也笑了起来。 Here was a new stunner—I had been calculating on four or five thousand.This news actually took my breath for a moment: Mr. St. John, whom I had never heard laugh before, laughed now.
“唔，”他说，“即使你犯下了谋杀罪，而我告诉你你的罪行被发现了，你也决不会表现得比现在更吃惊。” “Well,” said he, “if you had committed a murder, and I had told you your crime was discovered, you could scarcely look more aghast.”
“这是很大的一笔钱——难道你不觉得是弄错了吗？” “It is a large sum—don’t you think there is a mistake?”
“一点错也没有。” “No mistake at all.”
“也许你把数字念错了，可能只是两千英镑！” “Perhaps you have read the figures wrong—it may be two thousand!”
“那是用字母写的，不是用数字——两万英镑。” “It is written in letters, not figures,—twenty thousand.”
我再一次觉得自己就像是一个平常胃口的人，却坐下来独自享用一桌为一百人准备的宴席。里弗斯先生起身披上了斗篷。 I again felt rather like an individual of but average gastronomical powers sitting down to feast alone at a table spread with provisions for a hundred.Mr. Rivers rose now and put his cloak on.
“要不是今晚暴风雪肆虐，”他说，“我就派汉娜到山谷来跟你作伴了，你一个人看起来非常可怜。可是汉娜啊，可怜的女人！不能像我一样在积雪中大步地行走，她的腿没有那么长，所以我不得不留下你与忧伤独处了。晚安。” “If it were not such a very wild night,” he said, “I would send Hannah down to keep you company: you look too desperately miserable to be left alone.But Hannah, poor woman!could not stride the drifts so well as I: her legs are not quite so long: so I must e’en leave you to your sorrows. Good-night.”
他正在拨门闩时，我突然产生了一个念头。“等一下！”我叫道。 He was lifting the latch: a sudden thought occurred to me.“Stop one minute!” I cried.
“怎么了？” “Well?”
“我不明白的是为什么布里格斯先生给你写信问我的事，或者说，他怎么认识了你，怎么想得到住在远离尘嚣之地的你有能力帮他找到我呢？ “It puzzles me to know why Mr. Briggs wrote to you about me; or how he knew you, or could fancy that you, living in such an out-of-the way place, had the power to aid in my discovery.”
“噢！我是个牧师，”他说，“人们常常把一些怪事诉诸牧师。”门闩再次响了起来。 “Oh! I am a clergyman,” he said; “and the clergy are often appealed to about odd matters.”Again the latch rattled.
“不行，这种说法我不满意！”我喊道。的确，这种匆忙而又没作解释的回答不但没有打消我的好奇心，反而更加刺激了它。 “No; that does not satisfy me!”I exclaimed: and indeed there was something in the hasty and unexplanatory reply which, instead of allaying, piqued my curiosity more than ever.
“这是件非常奇怪的事情，”我补充道，“我必须对它多加了解。” “It is a very strange piece of business,” I added; “I must know more about it.”
“下次吧。” “Another time.”
“不行，今晚！就在今晚！”他从门边转过身来，我站到他和门之间。他看起来很是尴尬。 “No; tonight!—tonight!” and as he turned from the door, I placed myself between it and him.He looked rather embarrassed.
“在你全部告诉我之前绝对不能走。”我说。 “You certainly shall not go till you have told me all,” I said.
“我现在还是不想说。” “I would rather not just now.”
“你得说！你必须说！” “You shall!—you must!”
“我宁愿让黛安娜或玛丽告诉你。” “I would rather Diana or Mary informed you.”
他的这些回绝当然使我的心情急切到了极点。它必须被满足，一刻也不能耽误，我这么告诉他。 Of course these objections wrought my eagerness to a climax: gratified it must be, and that without delay; and I told him so.
“但是我告诉过你，我是个铁石心肠的男人，”他说，“很难被说服。” “But I apprised you that I was a hard man,” said he, “difficult to persuade.”
“我也是个铁石心肠的女人，不可能被拖延。” “And I am a hard woman,—impossible to put off.”
“那么，”他接着说，“我很冷酷，什么热情都感化不了。” “And then,” he pursued, “I am cold: no fervour infects me.”
“那么我有如火的热情，火能把冰融化。火焰已经把你斗篷上的雪全部融化了，并且雪水流到了我的地板上，把它弄得像是被踩踏过的路面。里弗斯先生，你希望我原谅你把我厨房沙地弄脏的重大罪过和恶劣行径，那就把我想知道的都告诉我吧。” “Whereas I am hot, and fire dissolves ice.The blaze there has thawed all the snow from your cloak; by the same token, it has streamed on to my floor, and made it like a trampled street.As you hope ever to be forgiven, Mr. Rivers, the high crime and misdemeanour of spoiling a sanded kitchen, tell me what I wish to know.”
“那么，好吧，”他说，“我让步了。即使不是因为你的急切心情，也是因为你滴水穿石般的坚持和毅力。再者说，你终有一天要知道的，早点晚点都一样。你的名字叫‘简·爱’？” “Well, then,” he said, “I yield; if not to your earnestness, to your perseverance: as stone is worn by continual dropping.Besides, you must know some day,—as well now as later.Your name is Jane Eyre?”
“当然了，之前已经确认过了。” “Of course: that was all settled before.”
“你也许还不知道，我跟你同名吧？我受洗礼时的名字是圣约翰·爱·里弗斯。” “You are not, perhaps, aware that I am your namesake?—that I was christened St. John Eyre Rivers?”
“不知道，真的！我现在想起来了，我从你在不同时间借给我的书上，都看到你的名字缩写中有个字母E，但是我从没问过它代表什么名字。但是那又说明什么？当然——” “No, indeed!I remember now seeing the letter E. comprised in your initials written in books you have at different times lent me; but I never asked for what name it stood.But what then? Surely—”
我打住了，我不能相信自己会产生这种想法，更别说把它表达出来了。这想法闯进了我的脑海，变得具体，然后在一瞬间突显出一种坚固、可靠的可能性。种种情形交织在一起，各就各位，有序地编织在一起。至今一直杂乱地集结在一起的链条被拉直了，每个环节都完美无缺，完整地连结在一起。不等圣约翰再次开口，我凭直觉就知道了这是怎么回事。但是我不能要求读者也有同样的直觉，所以我必须重复一下他的解释。 I stopped: I could not trust myself to entertain, much less to express, the thought that rushed upon me—that embodied itself,—that, in a second, stood out a strong, solid probability.Circumstances knit themselves, fitted themselves, shot into order: the chain that had been lying hitherto a formless lump of links was drawn out straight,—every ring was perfect, the connection complete.I knew, by instinct, how the matter stood, before St. John had said another word; but I cannot expect the reader to have the same intuitive perception, so I must repeat his explanation.
“我母亲的姓氏是‘爱’，她有两个兄弟：一个是位牧师，与盖茨黑德的简·里德小姐结为夫妻；另一个是已故的约翰·爱先生，生前是马德拉群岛的首府丰沙尔的一个商人。作为爱先生的律师，布里格斯先生去年八月写信给我们通知我们舅舅的死讯，还说他已经把财产都留给了他做牧师的哥哥的孤女。就因为他曾和我父亲有过一次从来不曾得到和解的争吵，所以他忽略了我们。打那儿之后又过了几周，他又写信通知我们女继承人出走了，问我们可有关于她的消息。一个无意中写在纸条上的名字使我找到了她。剩下的故事你都知道了。”他又要走了，但是我用后背抵住了门。 “My mother’s name was Eyre; she had two brothers; one a clergyman, who married Miss Jane Reed, of Gateshead; the other, John Eyre, Esq., merchant, late of Funchal, Madeira.Mr. Briggs, being Mr. Eyre’s solicitor, wrote to us last August to inform us of our uncle’s death, and to say that he had left his property to his brother the clergyman’s orphan daughter, overlooking us, in consequence of a quarrel, never forgiven, between him and my father.He wrote again a few weeks since, to intimate that the heiress was lost, and asking if we knew anything of her.A name casually written on a slip of paper has enabled me to find her out.You know the rest.”Again he was going, but I set my back against the door.
“请让我说几句，”我说，“让我有工夫喘口气，想一想。”我打住了。他站在我面前，手拿帽子，看起来泰然自若。我继续道： “Do let me speak,” I said; “let me have one moment to draw breath and reflect.”I paused—he stood before me, hat in hand, looking composed enough.I resumed—
“你的母亲是我父亲的姊妹？” “Your mother was my father’s sister?”
“是的。” “Yes.”
“也就是说，是我的姑妈？” “My aunt, consequently?”
他点点头。 He bowed.
“我的约翰叔叔就是你的约翰舅舅？你、黛安娜和玛丽是他姊妹的孩子，而我是他兄弟的孩子？” “My uncle John was your uncle John?You, Diana, and Mary are his sister’s children, as I am his brother’s child?”
“不可否认。” “Undeniably.”
“那么，你们仨就是我的表哥表姐了，我们彼此各有一半的血统是相同的？” “You three, then, are my cousins; half our blood on each side flows from the same source?”
“我们是表兄妹，是的。” “We are cousins; yes.”
我仔细观察他。看来我找到了一个哥哥，一个值得我骄傲的哥哥，一个我可以去爱的哥哥；还有两个姐姐，她们的品质没得说，当我仅仅以陌生人的身份认识她们时，我内心真挚的情感和爱慕便被激发了出来。我曾跪在湿漉漉的地上，透过荒原小屋厨房那低矮的格子窗向里看，我怀着掺杂着兴趣和绝望的痛苦心情，凝视着里面的两个姑娘，她们竟然就是我的近亲。而这位年轻、庄重的绅士，曾在他的门口发现了奄奄一息的我，他就是我的血肉之亲。对于我这么一个可怜的人来说，这是多么伟大的一个发现啊！这才是财富！心灵的财富！一座纯粹、温暖的感情宝藏。这是上天的恩赐，光辉灿烂、活灵活现、激动人心。它不像笨重的黄金礼物，尽管贵重而又受欢迎，但是它的分量也发人深省。突来的喜悦使我拍起手来，我的脉搏也有力地跳动了起来，血液也为之振奋。 I surveyed him.It seemed I had found a brother: one I could be proud of,—one I could love; and two sisters, whose qualities were such, that, when I knew them but as mere strangers, they had inspired me with genuine affection and admiration.The two girls, on whom, kneeling down on the wet ground, and looking through the low, latticed window of Moor House kitchen, I had gazed with so bitter a mixture of interest and despair, were my near kinswomen; and the young and stately gentleman who had found me almost dying at his threshold was my blood relation.Glorious discovery to a lonely wretch!This was wealth indeed!—wealth to the heart!—a mine of pure, genial affections.This was a blessing, bright, vivid, and exhilarating;—not like the ponderous gift of gold: rich and welcome enough in its way, but sobering from its weight.I now clapped my hands in sudden joy—my pulse bounded, my veins thrilled.
“哦，我真高兴！我真高兴啊！”我喊道。 “Oh, I am glad!—I am glad!”I exclaimed.
圣约翰微笑着。“我不是说过你是拣了芝麻丢了西瓜嘛？”他说道，“我告诉你你得到了一笔财产的时候，你却表情严肃，而现在你却为了不重要的小事而兴奋。” St. John smiled.“Did I not say you neglected essential points to pursue trifles?” he asked.“You were serious when I told you you had got a fortune; and now, for a matter of no moment, you are excited.”
“你这是什么意思？这对你来说也许是无足轻重的，你有两个妹妹，不在乎多一个表妹。可我之前什么亲人也没有，而现在却有三位亲人——或者两个，如果你不愿意被包括在内的话——一下子出现在我的世界里。我再说一遍，我真高兴！” “What can you mean?It may be of no moment to you; you have sisters and don’t care for a cousin; but I had nobody; and now three relations,—or two, if you don’t choose to be counted,—are born into my world full-grown.I say again, I am glad!”
我快速地地穿过房间，又停了下来，头脑中涌出无数的想法，速度之快令我来不及接受、理解和梳理，弄得我几乎透不过气来。这些想法就是关于可能实现的，能够实现的，将要实现的，应该实现的，不久就要做的。我看着空白的墙壁，它就像是布满星星的天空，每一颗冉冉升起的星星都照亮了我的一个目标或者一份欢乐。那些曾救过我生命的人，直到此刻我还未曾表白地爱着他们，我现在可以报答他们了。他们戴着枷锁，我可以给他们自由；他们彼此离散，我可以使他们重新团聚。我所拥有的独立和财富，同时也是他们的。我们不是四个人吗？两万英镑平均分成四份就是每人五千英镑,很公平——这些不但足够，并且还有余——实现了公平，确保了彼此的幸福。现在这笔钱对我来说不是负担了，它已经不仅仅是金钱的遗赠，而是一份生命、希望和欢乐的遗产了。 I walked fast through the room: I stopped, half suffocated with the thoughts that rose faster than I could receive, comprehend, settle them:—thoughts of what might, could, would, and should be, and that ere long.I looked at the blank wall: it seemed a sky thick with ascending stars,—every one lit me to a purpose or delight.Those who had saved my life, whom, till this hour, I had loved barrenly, I could now benefit.They were under a yoke,—I could free them: they were scattered,—I could reunite them: the independence, the affluence which was mine, might be theirs too.Were we not four?Twenty thousand pounds shared equally would be five thousand each, justice—enough and to spare: justice would be done,—mutual happiness secured.Now the wealth did not weigh on me: now it was not a mere bequest of coin,—it was a legacy of life, hope, enjoyment.
当这些想法如风暴般席卷我的心灵时，我不知道自己当时是什么样子。但是我很快就发现里弗斯先生在我身后放了一把椅子，温柔地试着让我坐下来。他还建议我要镇静。我对这种暗示我手足无措、精神涣散的做法不屑一顾，挣开了他的手，我又开始来回走了起来。 How I looked while these ideas were taking my spirit by storm, I cannot tell; but I perceived soon that Mr. Rivers had placed a chair behind me, and was gently attempting to make me sit down on it.He also advised me to be composed; I scorned the insinuation of helplessness and distraction, shook off his hand, and began to walk about again.
“明天给黛安娜和玛丽写信，”我说，“让她们直接回家来。黛安娜说过如果有一千英镑她们就觉得富有了，所以有五千英镑的话，她们会过得很好。” “Write to Diana and Mary tomorrow,” I said, “and tell them to come home directly.Diana said they would both consider themselves rich with a thousand pounds, so with five thousand they will do very well.”
“告诉我去哪儿能给你取杯水来。”圣约翰说，“你真得努力让自己的感情平静下来。” “Tell me where I can get you a glass of water,” said St. John; “you must really make an effort to tranquillise your feelings.”
“胡说！这笔遗赠会对你产生什么影响呢？能把你留在英国，诱使你娶奥利弗小姐为妻，然后像普通人一样安居下来吗？” “Nonsense! and what sort of an effect will the bequest have on you?Will it keep you in England, induce you to marry Miss Oliver, and settle down like an ordinary mortal?”
“你精神错乱，头脑糊涂了。我告诉你这个消息太唐突了，这给你带来的兴奋是你无法承受的。” “You wander: your head becomes confused.I have been too abrupt in communicating the news; it has excited you beyond your strength.”
“里弗斯先生！你让我完全没有耐心了。我足够理智，是你误解了，或者更确切地说是佯装误解。” “Mr. Rivers! you quite put me out of patience: I am rational enough; it is you who misunderstand, or rather who affect to misunderstand.”
“也许，如果你解释得再详细一点，我应该能更好地理解。” “Perhaps, if you explained yourself a little more fully, I should comprehend better.”
“解释！还有什么好解释的？你不会不明白，两万英镑，也就是现在所讨论的这笔钱，平均分给我们叔叔（舅舅）的一个侄女、一个外甥和两个外甥女，每人是会得到五千英镑吧？我要求的就是，你给你妹妹们写信，告诉她们她们所得到的财产。” “Explain! What is there to explain?You cannot fail to see that twenty thousand pounds, the sum in question, divided equally between the nephew and three nieces of our uncle, will give five thousand to each?What I want is, that you should write to your sisters and tell them of the fortune that has accrued to them.”
“你指的是你所得到的吧。” “To you, you mean.”
“我已经告诉你我对此事的观点了，我也产生不了别的想法了。我不是一个野蛮自私、盲目不公和极其忘恩负义的人。而且，我下定决心要有一个家，有亲人。我喜欢荒原小屋，并且会住在那里；我喜欢黛安娜和玛丽，并且会一辈子都与她们相依偎。五千英镑就可以让我高兴、给我带来好处了，拥有两万英镑会是一种折磨，让我感到压抑。而且，这些钱不应该都给我，虽然在法律上可能是公正的。所以，我把对我来说绝对是多余的部分转交给你们。不要再反对，也不要再讨论了。让我们彼此达成一致意见，赶紧把它定下来吧。” “I have intimated my view of the case: I am incapable of taking any other.I am not brutally selfish, blindly unjust, or fiendishly ungrateful.Besides, I am resolved I will have a home and connections.I like Moor House, and I will live at Moor House; I like Diana and Mary, and I will attach myself for life to Diana and Mary.It would please and benefit me to have five thousand pounds; it would torment and oppress me to have twenty thousand; which, moreover, could never be mine in justice, though it might in law.I abandon to you, then, what is absolutely superfluous to me.Let there be no opposition, and no discussion about it; let us agree amongst each other, and decide the point at once.”
“你这是一时冲动，才会做出这样的决定，你必须多花些时日来考虑这个问题，然后你的话才能算数。” “This is acting on first impulses; you must take days to consider such a matter, ere your word can be regarded as valid.”
“哦！如果你怀疑的只是我的诚意的话，那好说，你看这件事公平不公平？” “Oh! if all you doubt is my sincerity, I am easy: you see the justice of the case?”
“我确实看到了某种公平，但这是与惯例相违背的。再说，你有权得到所有的财产。这是我的舅舅通过努力挣来的，他愿意留给谁是他的自由，而他留给了你。归根到底，公正允许你拥有它，你可以心安理得地认为它完全属于你。” “I DO see a certain justice; but it is contrary to all custom.Besides, the entire fortune is your right: my uncle gained it by his own efforts; he was free to leave it to whom he would: he left it to you.After all, justice permits you to keep it: you may, with a clear conscience, consider it absolutely your own.”
“对我而言，”我说，“这件事既十分关乎良心，也十分关乎情感。我必须迁就我的情感，我很少有机会这么做。即使你同我争论、反对、烦扰我一年，我也不会放弃这美妙的喜悦。我已经看到了它一眼——那就是多少报答你们的恩德，为自己赢得终身的朋友。” “With me,” said I, “it is fully as much a matter of feeling as of conscience: I must indulge my feelings; I so seldom have had an opportunity of doing so.Were you to argue, object, and annoy me for a year, I could not forego the delicious pleasure of which I have caught a glimpse—that of repaying, in part, a mighty obligation, and winning to myself lifelong friends.”
“你现在这么想，”圣约翰再次接过话，“是因为你不知道拥有财富，以及之后享受财富是什么滋味。你还想象不到两万英镑会使你变得多么举足轻重，会让你在社会上得到怎样的地位，会为你开辟怎样的前景。你还不——” “You think so now,” rejoined St. John, “because you do not know what it is to possess, nor consequently to enjoy wealth: you cannot form a notion of the importance twenty thousand pounds would give you; of the place it would enable you to take in society; of the prospects it would open to you: you cannot—”
“然而你，”我插话道，“根本无法想象我对兄弟姐妹之情的渴望。我从来都没有家，从来都没有兄弟或姐妹，现在我必须而且必然会拥有他们。你不是不情愿承认并接受我这个妹妹吧，是么？” “And you,” I interrupted, “cannot at all imagine the craving I have for fraternal and sisterly love.I never had a home, I never had brothers or sisters; I must and will have them now: you are not reluctant to admit me and own me, are you?”
“简，我会做你的哥哥，我的妹妹们会成为你的姐姐，不需要你牺牲自己的正当权利作为条件。” “Jane, I will be your brother—my sisters will be your sisters—without stipulating for this sacrifice of your just rights.”
“哥哥？是啊，距离我一千里格之外！姐姐们？是的，在陌生人中当奴隶！我，家财万贯,塞满了既不是自己挣的、也不应该得到的钱！而你们，身无分文！多么好的平等与友爱！多么紧密的团聚！多么亲切的依恋！” “Brother? Yes; at the distance of a thousand leagues!Sisters? Yes; slaving amongst strangers!I, wealthy—gorged with gold I never earned and do not merit!You, penniless!Famous equality and fraternisation!Close union!Intimate attachment!”
“可是，简，你对亲属关系和家庭幸福的渴望可以通过其他方式来实现，而不是你所想的这种方式，你可以结婚啊。” “But, Jane, your aspirations after family ties and domestic happiness may be realised otherwise than by the means you contemplate: you may marry.”
“又再胡说！结婚！我可不想结婚，也永远不会结婚。” “Nonsense, again!Marry! I don’t want to marry, and never shall marry.”
“这么说就太过了，如此鲁莽的断言正好证明了你兴奋过度。” “That is saying too much: such hazardous affirmations are a proof of the excitement under which you labour.”
“这么说不过分。我知道自己的感受，单单是结婚这个念头我都不愿去想。没有人会因爱而娶我，我也不愿意被人仅仅看作是金钱上的投机。我不想要一个陌生人，与我没有共同语言，格格不入，相差甚远；我想要亲人，那些让我对其怀有十足的同胞之情的人。再说一遍你会做我的哥哥。你之前说出这话时我很满足，很高兴。再说一遍吧，如果你能，再诚心地说一遍吧。” “It is not saying too much: I know what I feel, and how averse are my inclinations to the bare thought of marriage.No one would take me for love; and I will not be regarded in the light of a mere money speculation.And I do not want a stranger—unsympathising, alien, different from me; I want my kindred: those with whom I have full fellow-feeling.Say again you will be my brother: when you uttered the words I was satisfied, happy; repeat them, if you can, repeat them sincerely.”
“我认为我能。我知道我一直爱着我自己的妹妹们，我也知道我对她们的感情是建立在什么基础之上的——对她们价值的尊重，对她们才能的赞赏。你也有自己的原则和思想。你的品味和习惯与黛安娜和玛丽的相似，你的出现总是令我感到愉快，我早已在和你的谈话中找到了有益的慰藉。我觉得我可以轻易并且自然地在我心中为你留出位置，作为我的第三个，也是最小的妹妹。” “I think I can.I know I have always loved my own sisters; and I know on what my affection for them is grounded,—respect for their worth and admiration of their talents.You too have principle and mind: your tastes and habits resemble Diana’s and Mary’s; your presence is always agreeable to me; in your conversation I have already for some time found a salutary solace.I feel I can easily and naturally make room in my heart for you, as my third and youngest sister.”
“谢谢你，这话今晚让我满足了。现在你最好走吧，因为要是你呆得再久一会儿，说不定又会因为某些不信任的疑虑而惹恼我。” “Thank you: that contents me for tonight.Now you had better go; for if you stay longer, you will perhaps irritate me afresh by some mistrustful scruple.”
“那么学校呢，爱小姐？我想，如今得把它关了吧？” “And the school, Miss Eyre?It must now be shut up, I suppose?”
“不。我会继续当老师，直到你找到接替我的人选。” “No. I will retain my post of mistress till you get a substitute.”
他微笑着同意了。我们握了握手，他告辞了。 He smiled approbation: we shook hands, and he took leave.
我也不必再详细地描述后来为了如我所愿地解决遗产问题，我所经历的争斗和辩论。 I need not narrate in detail the further struggles I had, and arguments I used, to get matters regarding the legacy settled as I wished.
我的任务虽然十分艰难，但因为我决心已定，我的表哥表姐们最后也看到了我要把财产平均分配的心意不可改变，他们内心也感受到了我这种打算的公平性；此外，他们一定也意识到了如果处在我的位置上，他们也会做我想要做的事——最终他们妥协了，同意将此事交付公断。我们选择了奥利弗先生和一位能干的律师作为仲裁人，两位的意见都与我的一致，我达到了自己的目的。财产转让的文书已经起草出来了，圣约翰、黛安娜、玛丽和我，每人都拥有了一份财产。 My task was a very hard one; but, as I was absolutely resolved—as my cousins saw at length that my mind was really and immutably fixed on making a just division of the property—as they must in their own hearts have felt the equity of the intention;and must, besides, have been innately conscious that in my place they would have done precisely what I wished to do—they yielded at length so far as to consent to put the affair to arbitration.The judges chosen were Mr. Oliver and an able lawyer: both coincided in my opinion: I carried my point.The instruments of transfer were drawn out: St. John, Diana, Mary, and I, each became possessed of a competency.
第三十四章 CHAPTER XXXIV
一切都办妥的时候已经快到圣诞节了，全国上下休假的日子就要到来了。我已经把莫顿学校关了，并且特别注意不让学生从我这里空手而别。好的财运不但使人心情畅快，而且出手也大方了。把我们得到很多的东西分一些给他人，就是为自己沸腾的情感提供一个宣泄的机会。我早已感觉到许多乡村学生喜欢我，我很高兴，而我们分别的时刻证明了我的感觉是对的。她们对我的感情表现得朴实而强烈。令我深感满意的是，我发现在他们那质朴无邪的心中真有我的一席之地。于是我许诺每个星期都会去看望她们，并且会在学校里给她们上一小时课。 It was near Christmas by the time all was settled: the season of general holiday approached.I now closed Morton school, taking care that the parting should not be barren on my side.Good fortune opens the hand as well as the heart wonderfully; and to give somewhat when we have largely received, is but to afford a vent to the unusual ebullition of the sensations.I had long felt with pleasure that many of my rustic scholars liked me, and when we parted, that consciousness was confirmed: they manifested their affection plainly and strongly.Deep was my gratification to find I had really a place in their unsophisticated hearts: I promised them that never a week should pass in future that I did not visit them, and give them an hour’s teaching in their school.
里弗斯先生走过来，看到班级里的六十个女孩子从我面前鱼贯而出。我锁上了教室的门，站在那儿，手里拿着钥匙，正在和六七个最优秀的学生说几句特别的临别之言。这几个女孩子举止得体、值得敬重、谦逊有礼、博学广识，是英国农民阶层中的佼佼者。这已经算是了不起了，因为毕竟英国的农民阶层是欧洲所有的农民中最有教养、最讲礼节、最懂自尊的。从那之后，我见过法国与德国的农妇，在我看来，她们中最好的与我们莫顿的女孩们相比，也显得无知、粗俗和愚笨。 Mr. Rivers came up as, having seen the classes, now numbering sixty girls, file out before me, and locked the door, I stood with the key in my hand, exchanging a few words of special farewell with some half-dozen of my best scholars: as decent, respectable, modest, and well-informed young women as could be found in the ranks of the British peasantry.And that is saying a great deal; for after all, the British peasantry are the best taught, best mannered, most self-respecting of any in Europe: since those days I have seen paysannes and Bauerinnen; and the best of them seemed to me ignorant, coarse, and besotted, compared with my Morton girls.
“你觉得自己这段时间的努力得到回报了吗？”学生们走后，里弗斯先生问道，“意识到自己在青春时代做了些真正的好事难道不令人感到愉快吗？” “Do you consider you have got your reward for a season of exertion?” asked Mr. Rivers, when they were gone.“Does not the consciousness of having done some real good in your day and generation give pleasure?”
“当然了。” “Doubtless.”
“而且你仅仅辛苦了几个月！如果把一生都奉献给民族复兴的事业，生命不是更有意义吗？” “And you have only toiled a few months!Would not a life devoted to the task of regenerating your race be well spent?”
“是的，”我说，“但是我不能一直这样做下去。我愿意培养他人的才能，也渴望发挥自己的才能。而现在我必须发挥自己的才能，别想让我的身心再回到学校上了，我已经摆脱它了，我想好好度个假。” “Yes,” I said; “but I could not go on for ever so: I want to enjoy my own faculties as well as to cultivate those of other people.I must enjoy them now; don’t recall either my mind or body to the school; I am out of it and disposed for full holiday.”
他神情严肃地说道：“现在是怎么了？你突然表现得这么急切，是怎么回事？你打算干什么？” He looked grave.“What now?What sudden eagerness is this you evince?What are you going to do?”
“我要行动起来，尽我所能地行动起来。首先我得请求你给汉娜自由，另找别人服侍你。” “To be active: as active as I can.And first I must beg you to set Hannah at liberty, and get somebody else to wait on you.”
“你需要她吗？” “Do you want her?”
“是的，我需要她陪我回到荒原小屋。黛安娜和玛丽一星期后就会回来，我想在她们回来之前把一切都收拾好。” “Yes, to go with me to Moor House.Diana and Mary will be at home in a week, and I want to have everything in order against their arrival.”
“我明白了。我之前还以为你要跑去哪里长途旅行呢。这样也好，汉娜会跟你一起去。” “I understand.I thought you were for flying off on some excursion.It is better so: Hannah shall go with you.”
“告诉她明天之前准备好。这是教室的钥匙，我明早再把我住所的钥匙给你。” “Tell her to be ready by tomorrow then; and here is the schoolroom key: I will give you the key of my cottage in the morning.”
他接过钥匙。“你兴高采烈地辞去了工作。”他说，“我不太明白你这种轻松愉快的心情，因为我不知道你辞掉这份工作后，又会为自己找什么样的工作。现在你生活的目标、意向和抱负是什么？” He took it.“You give it up very gleefully,” said he; “I don’t quite understand your light-heartedness, because I cannot tell what employment you propose to yourself as a substitute for the one you are relinquishing.What aim, what purpose, what ambition in life have you now?”
“我的首要目标就是‘清扫’（你理解这个词的全部含义吗？）——把荒原小屋从房间到地下室全部清扫干净；其次就是用黄蜡、油和数不清的抹布把房子擦得锃亮；再次，就是以数学的精确度把所有的桌椅、床和地毯摆放妥当；然后我要差不多用尽你的煤和泥炭，给每间屋子都烧好火；最后呢，在你的妹妹们预计要回来之前的那两天，我和汉娜要忙活着拌鸡蛋、拣葡萄干、磨香料、做圣诞饼、剁做肉馅饼用的食材，还要郑重其事地完成其他烹饪仪式。对你这种门外汉，语言是不能充分说清楚我们要做的活儿的。总的来说，我的目的就是在下周四黛安娜和玛丽回来之前，把所有的东西都准备就绪，万无一失；我的雄心就是在她们到来时给她们一个最理想的欢迎。” “My first aim will be to CLEAN DOWN (do you comprehend the full force of the expression?)—to CLEAN DOWN Moor House from chamber to cellar; my next to rub it up with bees-wax, oil, and an indefinite number of cloths, till it glitters again; my third, to arrange every chair, table, bed, carpet, with mathematical precision;afterwards I shall go near to ruin you in coals and peat to keep up good fires in every room;and lastly, the two days preceding that on which your sisters are expected will be devoted by Hannah and me to such a beating of eggs, sorting of currants, grating of spices, compounding of Christmas cakes, chopping up of materials for mince-pies, and solemnising of other culinary rites, as words can convey but an inadequate notion of to the uninitiated like you.My purpose, in short, is to have all things in an absolutely perfect state of readiness for Diana and Mary before next Thursday; and my ambition is to give them a beau-ideal of a welcome when they come.”
圣约翰微微一笑，他还是不太满意。 St. John smiled slightly: still he was dissatisfied.
“对于目前来说这些都非常好。”他说，“但说真的，我相信你在最初的兴奋过去之后，眼光会看得更远，而不是局限于家人的亲情和家庭的欢乐之中。” “It is all very well for the present,” said he; “but seriously, I trust that when the first flush of vivacity is over, you will look a little higher than domestic endearments and household joys.”
“这是世界上最好的东西！”我打断他。 “The best things the world has!” I interrupted.
“不，简，不是的。这个世界不是享乐的场所，不要试图把它变成这样；它也不是歇息的场所，不要懒惰懈怠。” “No, Jane, no: this world is not the scene of fruition; do not attempt to make it so: nor of rest; do not turn slothful.”
“正相反，我打算忙碌一番。” “I mean, on the contrary, to be busy.”
“简，我原谅你眼下这么做。我给你两个月的时间让你充分享受现在的新身份，痛快地沉浸在刚找到亲人的喜悦中；但在那之后，我希望你不要再把眼光局限于荒原小屋、莫顿、姐妹圈子和文明富足带来的自私安逸和感官享受。我希望那时你的活力能再次让你忙活起来。” “Jane, I excuse you for the present: two months’ grace I allow you for the full enjoyment of your new position, and for pleasing yourself with this late-found charm of relationship; but THEN, I hope you will begin to look beyond Moor House and Morton, and sisterly society, and the selfish calm and sensual comfort of civilised affluence.I hope your energies will then once more trouble you with their strength.”
我吃惊地看着他。“圣约翰，”我说，“我觉得你这么说简直是不怀好意。我想要像个女王那样心满意足，而你却想方设法令我心神不宁！你有什么目的？” I looked at him with surprise.“St. John,” I said, “I think you are almost wicked to talk so.I am disposed to be as content as a queen, and you try to stir me up to restlessness!To what end?”
“目的就是使上帝赋予你的才能能够发挥作用，这一点他总有一天会严加盘问的。简，我会焦虑地密切注视你——我提醒你。要尽力抑制你对庸俗的家庭欢乐抱有的过分热情。不要牢牢抓住亲情的纽带不放手，把你的恒心和热情投入到恰当的事业中，不要把它们浪费在平凡而转瞬即逝的事物上。你听到了吗，简？” “To the end of turning to profit the talents which God has committed to your keeping; and of which He will surely one day demand a strict account.Jane, I shall watch you closely and anxiously—I warn you of that.And try to restrain the disproportionate fervour with which you throw yourself into commonplace home pleasures.Don’t cling so tenaciously to ties of the flesh; save your constancy and ardour for an adequate cause; forbear to waste them on trite transient objects.Do you hear, Jane?”
“听到了，你好像在说希腊语一样。我觉得我有充分的理由来感受快乐，我一定要快乐。再见！” “Yes; just as if you were speaking Greek.I feel I have adequate cause to be happy, and I WILL be happy. Goodbye!”
我在荒原小屋忙得不亦乐乎，汉娜也是如此。她看到我在乱七八糟的房子里忙忙得乐不可支——我是怎样刷洗、除尘、清理，还有烹调，她简直为我着了迷。然而事实上，在一两天最混乱的日子过后，我们逐渐从自己制造的狼藉中理出了头绪，这令人感到高兴。我之前去了一趟S城，购买了一些新家具。我的表哥表姐们全权委托我，让我随自己的意愿对房子进行改动，还拿出了一笔钱专为此用。我大体保持了那普通的起居室和卧室的原貌。因为我知道黛安娜和玛丽再次看到原来那些亲切的桌椅和床铺，会比看到最时髦、新颖的家具更快乐。然而也有必要增加一些新意，好使得她们回来时可以体会到一种我希望可以实现的新鲜感。漂亮的深色新地毯和新窗帘、精心挑选的瓷器和铜器古董摆设、新罩子和梳状台上的镜子和化妆盒，这些都能派上用场：看上去既新鲜又不显得扎眼。还有一间空出来的客厅和卧室，我用旧红木家具和深红色的帷帘重新装饰了一下。在走廊里铺了粗帆布，楼梯上铺了地毯。所有的工作都完成以后，我觉得在冬季这么凄凉、沉寂的外部环境中，荒原小屋的室内完全是亮丽、质朴而温馨的典范。 Happy at Moor House I was, and hard I worked; and so did Hannah: she was charmed to see how jovial I could be amidst the bustle of a house turned topsy-turvy—how I could brush, and dust, and clean, and cook.And really, after a day or two of confusion worse confounded, it was delightful by degrees to invoke order from the chaos ourselves had made.I had previously taken a journey to S—to purchase some new furniture: my cousins having given me CARTE BLANCHE TO effect what alterations I pleased, and a sum having been set aside for that purpose.The ordinary sitting-room and bedrooms I left much as they were: for I knew Diana and Mary would derive more pleasure from seeing again the old homely tables, and chairs, and beds, than from the spectacle of the smartest innovations.Still some novelty was necessary, to give to their return the piquancy with which I wished it to be invested.Dark handsome new carpets and curtains, an arrangement of some carefully selected antique ornaments in porcelain and bronze, new coverings, and mirrors, and dressing-cases, for the toilet tables, answered the end: they looked fresh without being glaring.A spare parlour and bedroom I refurnished entirely, with old mahogany and crimson upholstery: I laid canvas on the passage, and carpets on the stairs.When all was finished, I thought Moor House as complete a model of bright modest snugness within, as it was, at this season, a specimen of wintry waste and desert dreariness without.
意义非凡的星期四终于到来了。她们预计会在天黑时回来，黄昏之前楼上楼下的炉火都生了起来，厨房非常整洁，我和汉娜都穿戴整齐，一切都准备就绪。 The eventful Thursday at length came.They were expected about dark, and ere dusk fires were lit upstairs and below; the kitchen was in perfect trim; Hannah and I were dressed, and all was in readiness.
圣约翰先到了。我之前已经恳请他在一切都安置好之前不要过来；而且，说真的，光想象一下屋里面一度又脏又乱，一片狼藉的样子，足以吓得他不敢走近了。他在厨房找到我，我正在照管要烘烤的茶点蛋糕。他走近壁炉，问我是不是终于对自己这种女佣的工作感到满意了。作为回答，我邀请他陪我整体视察一下我的劳动成果。我好不容易才让他转遍了整座房子。他仅仅从我打开的房门往里瞧瞧。楼上楼下都溜达了一圈之后，他说我在这么短的时间内就对房子做了这么大的改动，肯定受了不少劳累和麻烦。但他没有用任何言语对自己房间的改变表示出一丝的喜悦。 St. John arrived first.I had entreated him to keep quite clear of the house till everything was arranged: and, indeed, the bare idea of the commotion, at once sordid and trivial, going on within its walls sufficed to scare him to estrangement.He found me in the kitchen, watching the progress of certain cakes for tea, then baking.Approaching the hearth, he asked, “If I was at last satisfied with housemaid’s work?”I answered by inviting him to accompany me on a general inspection of the result of my labours.With some difficulty, I got him to make the tour of the house.He just looked in at the doors I opened; and when he had wandered upstairs and downstairs, he said I must have gone through a great deal of fatigue and trouble to have effected such considerable changes in so short a time: but not a syllable did he utter indicating pleasure in the improved aspect of his abode.
这种沉默真让我扫兴。我以为可能这些改变搅乱了他所珍惜的对于某些往事的联想。我问他是不是这个原因，当然语气有些灰心丧气。 This silence damped me.I thought perhaps the alterations had disturbed some old associations he valued.I inquired whether this was the case: no doubt in a somewhat crest-fallen tone.
“一点也没有。”他说，“正相反，你已经非常小心地考虑到了每一处与过去有关的联想，说实话，恐怕你在这方面花的心思远远超出了它本身的重要性。比如，为了布置这间屋子，你花了多少时间思考啊？顺便问一下，你知道某本书放在哪儿了吗？” “Not at all; he had, on the contrary, remarked that I had scrupulously respected every association: he feared, indeed, I must have bestowed more thought on the matter than it was worth.How many minutes, for instance, had I devoted to studying the arrangement of this very room?—By-the-bye, could I tell him where such a book was?”
我指给他书架上的那本书，他取了下来，退到他待惯了的窗户凹陷处，开始读起书来。 I showed him the volume on the shelf: he took it down, and withdrawing to his accustomed window recess, he began to read it.
现在，读者朋友，我不喜欢他这样。圣约翰是个好人，但是我开始觉得他说自己冷漠无情的时候，说的是实话。生活中的仁爱和舒适对他一点吸引力都没有，生活安宁的享受对他而言没有任何魅力。实际上，他活着只是为了渴求——渴求的当然是优秀、伟大的东西，但是他永远不会安顿下来，也不赞成身边的人满足于安逸。我看着他那高高的额头，像白色的石头一样宁静、苍白，还有他认真读书时英俊的面孔——一时间我明白了他很难成为一个好丈夫，做他的妻子会是件折磨人的事。出于灵感，我仿佛突然明白了他对奥利弗小姐的爱慕之情是什么性质。我同意他的观点，那确实只是一种感官的爱。我理解了他为何会因为自己受到这种狂热的爱慕之情的影响而鄙视自己，为何他希望遏制并摧毁这种感情，为何他不相信这种爱会使他或她得到长久的幸福。我觉得他就是可以被大自然打造成英雄的材料——基督徒或异教徒——立法者、政治家、征服者，是一座可以委以重任的坚固壁垒；但是在家中，他却常常像一根冰冷、笨重的柱子，忧郁沉闷，与周围的环境不协调。 Now, I did not like this, reader.St. John was a good man; but I began to feel he had spoken truth of himself when he said he was hard and cold.The humanities and amenities of life had no attraction for him—its peaceful enjoyments no charm.Literally, he lived only to aspire—after what was good and great, certainly; but still he would never rest, nor approve of others resting round him.As I looked at his lofty forehead, still and pale as a white stone—at his fine lineaments fixed in study—I comprehended all at once that he would hardly make a good husband: that it would be a trying thing to be his wife.I understood, as by inspiration, the nature of his love for Miss Oliver; I agreed with him that it was but a love of the senses.I comprehended how he should despise himself for the feverish influence it exercised over him; how he should wish to stifle and destroy it; how he should mistrust its ever conducting permanently to his happiness or hers.I saw he was of the material from which nature hews her heroes—Christian and Pagan—her lawgivers, her statesmen, her conquerors: a steadfast bulwark for great interests to rest upon; but, at the fireside, too often a cold cumbrous column, gloomy and out of place.
“这间客厅不是他的天地，”我想，“喜马拉雅山脉或是南非丛林，甚至瘟疫肆虐的几内亚海岸的沼泽地可能会更适合他。他完全可以逃离安宁的家庭生活，这不适合他。在这种生活中他的才能会停滞不前，它们得不到发展，也发挥不出作用。只有在斗争和危险的环境中，在勇气得到证明、能力得到锻炼、毅力受到考验的地方，他才会说话，才会行动，成为领导者和优胜者。在家里，一个快乐的孩子都要胜他一筹。他选择做一名传教士是正确的——我现在明白了。” “This parlour is not his sphere,” I reflected: “the Himalayan ridge or Caffre bush, even the plague-cursed Guinea Coast swamp would suit him better.Well may he eschew the calm of domestic life; it is not his element: there his faculties stagnate—they cannot develop or appear to advantage.It is in scenes of strife and danger—where courage is proved, and energy exercised, and fortitude tasked—that he will speak and move, the leader and superior.A merry child would have the advantage of him on this hearth.He is right to choose a missionary’s career—I see it now.”
“她们回来了！她们回来了！”汉娜喊道，并一下推开了客厅的门。这时，老卡洛也快乐地叫了起来。我跑了出去。天已经黑了，但可以听到隆隆的车轮声。汉娜很快点燃了一盏提灯。马车在花园小门口停下，车夫打开了车门。先是一个熟悉的身影走下了车，接着是另一个。刹那间，我就把脸扎进她俩的帽子下边了，我先碰碰玛丽柔软的脸颊，再摸摸黛安娜飘逸的卷发。她们笑着吻了吻我，又吻了吻汉娜，拍了拍由于高兴而近乎发狂的老卡洛。她们急切地询问是否一切都好，肯定的答复使她们放了心，这才匆忙地进了屋。 “They are coming! they are coming!” cried Hannah, throwing open the parlour door.At the same moment old Carlo barked joyfully.Out I ran.It was now dark; but a rumbling of wheels was audible.Hannah soon had a lantern lit.The vehicle had stopped at the wicket; the driver opened the door: first one well-known form, then another, stepped out.In a minute I had my face under their bonnets, in contact first with Mary’s soft cheek, then with Diana’s flowing curls.They laughed—kissed me—then Hannah: patted Carlo, who was half wild with delight; asked eagerly if all was well; and being assured in the affirmative, hastened into the house.
从惠特克劳斯到这里的长途颠簸使她们浑身僵硬，晚上的寒气也把她们冻坏了；但是一看到振奋人心的火光，她们亲切的面容便舒展了开来。当车夫和汉娜把箱子搬进来时，她们问起了圣约翰。这时，他从客厅里走了过来。她们俩立刻搂住了他的脖子。他默不作声地各吻了她们一下，低声说了几句欢迎的话，站了一会儿，让她们同他说话，然后说了句估计她们很快就会在客厅和他会面，就逃难似的退回了客厅。 They were stiff with their long and jolting drive from Whitcross, and chilled with the frosty night air; but their pleasant countenances expanded to the cheerful firelight.While the driver and Hannah brought in the boxes, they demanded St. John.At this moment he advanced from the parlour.They both threw their arms round his neck at once.He gave each one quiet kiss, said in a low tone a few words of welcome, stood a while to be talked to, and then, intimating that he supposed they would soon rejoin him in the parlour, withdrew there as to a place of refuge.
我为她俩点燃了蜡烛好让她们上楼，可黛安娜得先去嘱咐车夫几句好客的话。完事之后，两人跟着我上了楼。她们很高兴地看到自己房间里的新家具和装饰品：新窗帘、新地毯，还有色彩丰富的瓷花瓶。她们由衷地表达了她们的感激之情。我很高兴我的布置正称她们的心意，我所做的工作为她们愉快的回家之旅增添了生动的魅力。 I had lit their candles to go upstairs, but Diana had first to give hospitable orders respecting the driver; this done, both followed me.They were delighted with the renovation and decorations of their rooms; with the new drapery, and fresh carpets, and rich tinted china vases: they expressed their gratification ungrudgingly.I had the pleasure of feeling that my arrangements met their wishes exactly, and that what I had done added a vivid charm to their joyous return home.
那晚真是轻松愉快。我的表姐们兴高采烈，她们滔滔不绝地叙述着、议论着，她们的畅谈淹没了圣约翰的沉默。见到妹妹们，他的确很高兴，但是她们洋溢的热情和流动的喜悦却引不起他的共鸣。那天的大事就是黛安娜和玛丽的归来，这令他高兴。但是随之而来的欢乐的喧闹和喋喋不休、热情的接待使他厌烦。我看得出他希望平静的翌日早些到来。喝完茶后大约一小时，我们晚上的欢乐达到了极点，这时却听到一阵敲门声。汉娜走进来说：“来了一个可怜的小伙儿，在这么个不合适的时候请里弗斯先生去看看他的母亲，她快不行了。” Sweet was that evening.My cousins, full of exhilaration, were so eloquent in narrative and comment, that their fluency covered St. John’s taciturnity: he was sincerely glad to see his sisters; but in their glow of fervour and flow of joy he could not sympathise.The event of the day—that is, the return of Diana and Mary—pleased him; but the accompaniments of that event, the glad tumult, the garrulous glee of reception irked him: I saw he wished the calmer morrow was come.In the very meridian of the night’s enjoyment, about an hour after tea, a rap was heard at the door.Hannah entered with the intimation that “a poor lad was come, at that unlikely time, to fetch Mr. Rivers to see his mother, who was drawing away.”
“她住在哪儿，汉娜？” “Where does she live, Hannah?”
“得到惠特克劳斯坡的最顶上呢，差不多四英里远呢，一路上都是沼泽和苔藓。” “Clear up at Whitcross Brow, almost four miles off, and moor and moss all the way.”
“告诉他我这就去。” “Tell him I will go.”
“我觉得您还是不去为好，先生。天黑以后走那条路最危险了，一片沼泽地，根本就没有路可走。而且，今晚这么冷，你都没感受过这么凛冽的风。您最好还是传个话，先生，说你明天早上再去。” “I’m sure, sir, you had better not.It’s the worst road to travel after dark that can be: there’s no track at all over the bog.And then it is such a bitter night—the keenest wind you ever felt.You had better send word, sir, that you will be there in the morning.”
但他已经在走廊里披他的斗篷了，然后，没有反对也没有抱怨，他出发了。那时已经九点了。他直到半夜才回来。尽管他又饿又累，但是看起来比出发的时候要高兴多了。他完成了一项职责，付出了一份努力。他感到自己有克己奉献的力量，自我感觉好多了。 But he was already in the passage, putting on his cloak; and without one objection, one murmur, he departed.It was then nine o’clock: he did not return till midnight.Starved and tired enough he was: but he looked happier than when he set out.He had performed an act of duty; made an exertion; felt his own strength to do and deny, and was on better terms with himself.
恐怕接下来的一整周他的耐心都会受到考验。那是圣诞周，我们没什么正经的工作要做，只是在家里嬉闹、消遣。荒原的空气、居家的自由、生活富足的曙光就像使人返老还童的灵丹妙药，作用于黛安娜和玛丽的心灵。她们从早上到中午，从中午到晚上都兴致勃勃的。她们可以不停地谈天说地，她们的话语诙谐、精辟、原汁原味，令我非常着迷。我喜欢聆听她们交谈，并且参与其中，而不愿去做任何其他的事情。圣约翰没有对我们的快活加以指责，但是也不参与其中。他很少在家，他管辖的教区很大，人口分散，他把到不同的地方探望穷困的病人作为每天的例行公事。 I am afraid the whole of the ensuing week tried his patience.It was Christmas week: we took to no settled employment, but spent it in a sort of merry domestic dissipation.The air of the moors, the freedom of home, the dawn of prosperity, acted on Diana and Mary’s spirits like some life-giving elixir: they were gay from morning till noon, and from noon till night.They could always talk; and their discourse, witty, pithy, original, had such charms for me, that I preferred listening to, and sharing in it, to doing anything else.St. John did not rebuke our vivacity; but he escaped from it: he was seldom in the house; his parish was large, the population scattered, and he found daily business in visiting the sick and poor in its different districts.
一天吃早饭的时候，黛安娜看上去像是沉思了一小会儿，然后问他：“你的计划是否没有改变？” One morning at breakfast, Diana, after looking a little pensive for some minutes, asked him, “If his plans were yet unchanged.”
“没有改变，也不能改变。”他答道。然后接着他告诉我们说，他离开英国的日子现已确定为来年。 “Unchanged and unchangeable,” was the reply.And he proceeded to inform us that his departure from England was now definitively fixed for the ensuing year.
“那么罗莎蒙德·奥利弗呢？”玛丽问。这句话仿佛是脱口而出的，因为她刚说完就立刻做了个手势，仿佛想要收回去似的。圣约翰手中拿着一本书——吃饭时读书是他不合群的习惯——他合上书，抬起头来。 “And Rosamond Oliver?” suggested Mary, the words seeming to escape her lips involuntarily: for no sooner had she uttered them, than she made a gesture as if wishing to recall them.St. John had a book in his hand—it was his unsocial custom to read at meals—he closed it, and looked up,
“罗莎蒙德·奥利弗，”他说，“就要嫁给格兰比先生了。他家是S城社交最广、最有声望的人家之一，是弗雷德里克·格兰比爵士的孙子和继承人。我昨天从她父亲那里得知这些的。” “Rosamond Oliver,” said he, “is about to be married to Mr. Granby, one of the best connected and most estimable residents in S—, grandson and heir to Sir Frederic Granby: I had the intelligence from her father yesterday.”
他的两个妹妹看看彼此，又看看我，我们三个一齐看着他，他却像玻璃一样平静。 His sisters looked at each other and at me; we all three looked at him: he was serene as glass.
“这种结合肯定是操之过急了，”黛安娜说，“他们彼此不可能认识很久。” “The match must have been got up hastily,” said Diana: “they cannot have known each other long.”
“仅仅两个月，他们是十月份在Ｓ城的一个乡间舞会上认识的。但在目前这种情况下，这门亲事没有任何阻碍，在各个方面都称心如意，没有必要拖延。只要弗雷德里克爵士送给他们的那座Ｓ城府邸整修完毕，可以住人了，他们就会结婚。” “But two months: they met in October at the county ball at S—.But where there are no obstacles to a union, as in the present case, where the connection is in every point desirable, delays are unnecessary: they will be married as soon as S—Place, which Sir Frederic gives up to them, can he refitted for their reception.”
在那次谈话后，第一次看到圣约翰单独一人时，我就很想问问他这件事是否让他感到苦恼，但他好像根本不需要同情，所以我没有再冒昧地表达什么，而是为我之前的冒失感到羞愧。而且，我也已没有跟他交谈的习惯了。他的内敛再次像冰块一样，把我的坦率冻在了下面。他没有像承诺的那样把我当作妹妹看待，还不断在我们之间弄出小小的、令人寒心的区别，根本没有要发展亲情的意思。总之，自从我被认作是他的亲人，和他同住一个屋檐下之后，我觉得我们之间的距离反而比他只把我看作一个乡村女教师时还大。想起他曾一度跟我谈了多少知心话，我就很难理解他现在的冷漠。 The first time I found St. John alone after this communication, I felt tempted to inquire if the event distressed him: but he seemed so little to need sympathy, that, so far from venturing to offer him more, I experienced some shame at the recollection of what I had already hazarded.Besides, I was out of practice in talking to him: his reserve was again frozen over, and my frankness was congealed beneath it.He had not kept his promise of treating me like his sisters; he continually made little chilling differences between us, which did not at all tend to the development of cordiality: in short, now that I was acknowledged his kinswoman, and lived under the same roof with him, I felt the distance between us to be far greater than when he had known me only as the village schoolmistress.When I remembered how far I had once been admitted to his confidence, I could hardly comprehend his present frigidity.
就因为这样，当他突然从低头注视的书桌上抬起头来说话时，我不免吃了一惊。他说： Such being the case, I felt not a little surprised when he raised his head suddenly from the desk over which he was stooping, and said—
“你看，简，战争结束了，并以胜利告终。” “You see, Jane, the battle is fought and the victory won.”
他这么跟我说话，我吓了一跳，因此没有立马回答他。犹豫了片刻，我说： Startled at being thus addressed, I did not immediately reply: after a moment’s hesitation I answered—
“但是，你确定你不是一个付出了极大的代价才获胜的征服者吗？再取得一次这样的胜利不会毁了你吗？” “But are you sure you are not in the position of those conquerors whose triumphs have cost them too dear?Would not such another ruin you?”
“我不这么认为。如果我真是如此，也没多大关系，我再也不会响应号召去为另一次这样的胜利而斗争了。这场斗争是决定性的。我的道路如今已被扫清，我为此感谢上帝！”说完，他又专注于他的文件，沉默不语。 “I think not; and if I were, it does not much signify; I shall never be called upon to contend for such another.The event of the conflict is decisive: my way is now clear; I thank God for it!”So saying, he returned to his papers and his silence.
我们之间的欢乐（即黛安娜、玛丽和我的）平静下来了，我们也各自恢复了以往的习惯和正常的学习。圣约翰在家的时间多了起来，他同我们坐在一间屋子里，有时一坐好几个小时。玛丽画画，黛安娜继续读她的百科全书（让我既敬畏又惊讶），我在吃力地学习德语，他在思考着自己神秘的学问，就是某种东方语言。他觉得学会这门语言对实现他的计划来说是很必要的。 As our mutual happiness (i.e., Diana’s, Mary’s, and mine) settled into a quieter character, and we resumed our usual habits and regular studies, St. John stayed more at home: he sat with us in the same room, sometimes for hours together.While Mary drew, Diana pursued a course of encyclopaedic reading she had (to my awe and amazement) undertaken, and I fagged away at German, he pondered a mystic lore of his own: that of some Eastern tongue, the acquisition of which he thought necessary to his plans.
这么专注地学习着，他坐在自己的那个角落里，看上去安静、入神；但他那双蓝眼睛却常常离开那陌生的语法，到处游离，有时会盯着我们——他的同学们，好奇地观察。如果被我们发现了，他就会马上收回他的目光，然而他的目光又会不时地回到我们这桌，似乎在搜寻着什么。 Thus engaged, he appeared, sitting in his own recess, quiet and absorbed enough; but that blue eye of his had a habit of leaving the outlandish-looking grammar, and wandering over, and sometimes fixing upon us, his fellow-students, with a curious intensity of observation: if caught, it would be instantly withdrawn; yet ever and anon, it returned searchingly to our table.
我琢磨他这是什么意思，我也很纳闷，不知道为什么在我看来不值得一提的小事——就是我每周去一次莫顿学校，他却总是及时地对此表示满意。更使我疑惑的是，遇上天气不好，下雪、下雨抑或刮大风的时候，他的妹妹们劝会我不要去，而他必定会轻视她们的这种关心，鼓励我要不顾天气影响去完成这项任务。 I wondered what it meant: I wondered, too, at the punctual satisfaction he never failed to exhibit on an occasion that seemed to me of small moment, namely, my weekly visit to Morton school;and still more was I puzzled when, if the day was unfavourable, if there was snow, or rain, or high wind, and his sisters urged me not to go, he would invariably make light of their solicitude, and encourage me to accomplish the task without regard to the elements.
“简不是你们想的那么脆弱，”他会说，“她可以禁受住山风或暴雨，抑或是飞雪，不比我们其中的任何一个人差。她的体质不仅健康而且适应性很强，比许多比较壮实的人更能适应天气的变化无常。” “Jane is not such a weakling as you would make her,” he would say: “she can bear a mountain blast, or a shower, or a few flakes of snow, as well as any of us.Her constitution is both sound and elastic;—better calculated to endure variations of climate than many more robust.”
我从学校回到家，有时非常累，经历了风吹雨打，但却从来不敢抱怨，因为我明白只要一嘀咕就会使他厌烦。不管什么时候，表现得坚强总会使他高兴，反之就会让他恼火。 And when I returned, sometimes a good deal tired, and not a little weather-beaten, I never dared complain, because I saw that to murmur would be to vex him: on all occasions fortitude pleased him; the reverse was a special annoyance.
然而，一天下午，我不得不请假呆在家里，因为我确实感冒了。他的妹妹们代替我去了莫顿学校，我坐着读席勒的作品，他则在钻研他那晦涩难懂的东方涡卷形字体。我做完翻译，要做练习时，正好往他那边看了看，却发现自己正被他那双蓝眼睛注视着。这目光把我彻彻底底、反反复复打量了多久了，我不知道。那目光如此锐利，然而又非常冰冷，一时间竟然让我迷信起来——就好像我和某种神秘离奇的东西坐在同一间屋子里。 One afternoon, however, I got leave to stay at home, because I really had a cold.His sisters were gone to Morton in my stead: I sat reading Schiller; he, deciphering his crabbed Oriental scrolls.As I exchanged a translation for an exercise, I happened to look his way: there I found myself under the influence of the ever-watchful blue eye.How long it had been searching me through and through, and over and over, I cannot tell: so keen was it, and yet so cold, I felt for the moment superstitious—as if I were sitting in the room with something uncanny.
“简，你在做什么？” “Jane, what are you doing?”
“学德语。” “Learning German.”
“我想让你放弃德语，改学印度斯坦语。” “I want you to give up German and learn Hindostanee.”
“你不是说真的吧？” “You are not in earnest?”
“我非常认真，而且必须这样，我会告诉你为什么。” “In such earnest that I must have it so: and I will tell you why.”
然后，他接着解释说印度斯坦语就是他自己现在正在学习的语言。可是，他越往后学，就越容易忘记前边学的内容；而要是有一个学生，那对他的帮助可就大了，他可以一遍又一遍地复习那些基础知识，从而把它们彻底记住。他在我和他的两个妹妹们之间徘徊了好久，不知该选谁。但他最终选择了我，因为他发现我是我们三个里边最有恒心的一个。他问我是不是愿意帮他这个忙。也许我用不着做太久的牺牲，因为距离他离开的日子也就仅仅三个月了。 He then went on to explain that Hindostanee was the language he was himself at present studying; that, as he advanced, he was apt to forget the commencement; that it would assist him greatly to have a pupil with whom he might again and again go over the elements, and so fix them thoroughly in his mind;that his choice had hovered for some time between me and his sisters; but that he had fixed on me because he saw I could sit at a task the longest of the three.Would I do him this favour?I should not, perhaps, have to make the sacrifice long, as it wanted now barely three months to his departure.
圣约翰不是个能轻易拒绝的人，你会感到你给他留下的任何印象，不管是痛苦的还是美好的，都会深深地、永久地被刻下来。我同意了。黛安娜和玛丽回来后，黛安娜发现她的学生现在成了她哥哥的学生。她笑了起来，并且和玛丽一致同意圣约翰永远也不可能说服她俩迈出这一步的。他不动声色地回答道：“我知道。”我发现他是个非常耐心、非常宽容，同时也非常严苛的老师。他对我的期望很高，而且一旦我满足了他的期望，他便会以他自己的方式表示充分的赞许。渐渐地，他对我形成了某种影响，使我的头脑失去了自由。他的夸奖和关注比他的冷漠更让人觉得束缚。他在旁边时，我就再也不能谈笑自如了，因为一种缠绕不休的恼人的直觉提醒我，轻松活跃（至少表现在我身上的）会使他反感。我充分意识到只有严肃的情绪和认真地工作才是他所接受的，只要他在，坚持或追求其他别的事情都是徒劳。我感到自己置身于一种令人冻结的魔力之中。他说“走”，我就走；他说“来”，我就来；他说“做这个”，我就照做。但是我不喜欢自己被奴役，我多少次希望他继续如从前一样忽视我。 St. John was not a man to be lightly refused: you felt that every impression made on him, either for pain or pleasure, was deep-graved and permanent.I consented.When Diana and Mary returned, the former found her scholar transferred from her to her brother: she laughed, and both she and Mary agreed that St. John should never have persuaded them to such a step.He answered quietly—“I know it.”I found him a very patient, very forbearing, and yet an exacting master: he expected me to do a great deal; and when I fulfilled his expectations, he, in his own way, fully testified his approbation.By degrees, he acquired a certain influence over me that took away my liberty of mind: his praise and notice were more restraining than his indifference.I could no longer talk or laugh freely when he was by, because a tiresomely importunate instinct reminded me that vivacity (at least in me) was distasteful to him.I was so fully aware that only serious moods and occupations were acceptable, that in his presence every effort to sustain or follow any other became vain: I fell under a freezing spell.When he said “go,” I went; “come,” I came; “do this,” I did it.But I did not love my servitude: I wished, many a time, he had continued to neglect me.
一天晚上，到了睡觉的时间，他的两个妹妹和我围着他向他道晚安，他习惯性地分别吻了她们，又同样习惯性地把手伸向我。黛安娜正好在说笑的兴头上（她没有痛苦地被他的意志所控制，因为从另一个角度来说，她的意志也很强），她喊道： One evening when, at bedtime, his sisters and I stood round him, bidding him good-night, he kissed each of them, as was his custom; and, as was equally his custom, he gave me his hand.Diana, who chanced to be in a frolicsome humour (SHE was not painfully controlled by his will; for hers, in another way, was as strong), exclaimed—
“圣约翰！你常常把简称为自己的三妹，但是你却不那样对待她，你应该也吻她。” “St. John! you used to call Jane your third sister, but you don’t treat her as such: you should kiss her too.”
她把我推向他。我觉得黛安娜真会惹人生气，我感到心里乱糟糟的，很不舒服。正当我这么想着、感觉着的时候，圣约翰低下了头，他那希腊式的脸和我的持平，眼睛穿透般地探究着我的眼睛——他吻了我。因为没有“大理石吻”或“冰吻”这类说法，否则我应当说我担当神职的表哥的这一致意就属于这一类；但是可能有“实验性的吻”这一说法，那么他的吻就是实验性的吻。吻过以后，他看看我，想知道结果如何。结果并不明显：我确定自己没有脸红，也许还显得有些苍白，因为我感觉这吻仿佛是贴在我桎梏上的封条。之后，他再也没有省略过这一仪式，我在接受亲吻时的严肃和安静，对他来说似乎倒为此增添了某种魅力。 She pushed me towards him.I thought Diana very provoking, and felt uncomfortably confused; and while I was thus thinking and feeling, St. John bent his head; his Greek face was brought to a level with mine, his eyes questioned my eyes piercingly—he kissed me.There are no such things as marble kisses or ice kisses, or I should say my ecclesiastical cousin’s salute belonged to one of these classes; but there may be experiment kisses, and his was an experiment kiss.When given, he viewed me to learn the result; it was not striking: I am sure I did not blush; perhaps I might have turned a little pale, for I felt as if this kiss were a seal affixed to my fetters.He never omitted the ceremony afterwards, and the gravity and quiescence with which I underwent it, seemed to invest it for him with a certain charm.
至于我，则是一天一天更想讨他欢心，但是这么做，我日渐强烈地觉得我必须放弃我的一半本性，抑制我的一半才能，改变自己原来的情趣，强迫自己接受没有内在倾向的追求。他想要把我提升到我永远也达不到的高度，我时刻因为渴求达到他给我定下的高度而备受折磨。这是不可能实现的。就如同把我那不规则的五官塑造成他那标准的古典样式，把他眼睛中那海蓝色的、庄严的光彩赋予到我多变的绿眼睛，这都是不可能的。 As for me, I daily wished more to please him; but to do so, I felt daily more and more that I must disown half my nature, stifle half my faculties, wrest my tastes from their original bent, force myself to the adoption of pursuits for which I had no natural vocation.He wanted to train me to an elevation I could never reach; it racked me hourly to aspire to the standard he uplifted.The thing was as impossible as to mould my irregular features to his correct and classic pattern, to give to my changeable green eyes the sea-blue tint and solemn lustre of his own.
然而，不仅仅是他的统治地位使我处于目前这种被奴役的境地。最近，我特别容易表现出一脸的悲伤。一个腐蚀人心的恶魔坐在我的心坎上，把我的幸福之源吸干了——那就是焦虑之魔。 Not his ascendancy alone, however, held me in thrall at present.Of late it had been easy enough for me to look sad: a cankering evil sat at my heart and drained my happiness at its source—the evil of suspense.
读者，也许你认为在环境和命运的这一系列变化中，我已经忘记罗切斯特先生了。其实我一刻也没有忘记。他的思想依然与我同在，因为这不是水蒸汽，可以被阳光驱散，也不是沙堡，可以被暴风雨冲走；而是刻在石碑上的名字，注定要与刻着它的大理石共存亡。无论我走到哪儿，都渴望知道他后来怎么了。在莫顿学校时，我每晚一回到我的小屋就会想念他；现在在荒原小屋，我每晚一进卧室便开始冥思苦想。 Perhaps you think I had forgotten Mr. Rochester, reader, amidst these changes of place and fortune.Not for a moment.His idea was still with me, because it was not a vapour sunshine could disperse, nor a sand-traced effigy storms could wash away; it was a name graven on a tablet, fated to last as long as the marble it inscribed.The craving to know what had become of him followed me everywhere; when I was at Morton, I re-entered my cottage every evening to think of that; and now at Moor House, I sought my bedroom each night to brood over it.
在我关于遗嘱一事而必须与布里格斯先生通信的过程中，我也问过他是否知道任何关于罗切斯特先生现在的住址和身体状况的消息。但是，正如圣约翰猜测的那样，布里格斯先生对罗切斯特先生的情况一无所知。之后我又给费尔法克斯夫人写信，恳求她告诉我相关的情况。我满以为这样肯定会达到目的，我觉得肯定会早早得到答复的。可令我吃惊的是，两周过去了也没有回信。又过了两个月，邮递员天天来，但没有一封信是给我的，无比强烈地的焦虑感深深折磨着我。 In the course of my necessary correspondence with Mr. Briggs about the will, I had inquired if he knew anything of Mr. Rochester’s present residence and state of health; but, as St. John had conjectured, he was quite ignorant of all concerning him.I then wrote to Mrs. Fairfax, entreating information on the subject.I had calculated with certainty on this step answering my end: I felt sure it would elicit an early answer.I was astonished when a fortnight passed without reply; but when two months wore away, and day after day the post arrived and brought nothing for me, I fell a prey to the keenest anxiety.
我又写了一封信，因为有可能第一封信弄丢了没寄到。新的希望随着新的努力而生，跟之前一样，在开始的几周里还闪烁着光芒，之后光芒退却，忽明忽暗。我没有收到一句话，一个字。半年的时间都在我徒劳地期盼中流逝了，我的希望破灭了，我就像是坠入了无边的黑暗中。 I wrote again: there was a chance of my first letter having missed.Renewed hope followed renewed effort: it shone like the former for some weeks, then, like it, it faded, flickered: not a line, not a word reached me.When half a year wasted in vain expectancy, my hope died out, and then I felt dark indeed.
春天闪耀着宜人的光芒将我包围，我却无心享受。夏天将至，黛安娜试图让我振作起来，她说我看上去气色不好，希望陪我去海边走走。圣约翰对此表示反对。他说我不需要消遣，我需要工作；说我目前的生活漫无目的，得找个目标。我想是为了弥补我的不足，他延长了我的印度斯坦语课程，更加迫切地要求我完成学习任务。而我，则像个傻瓜，从来没想过要反抗他——也无从反抗。 A fine spring shone round me, which I could not enjoy.Summer approached; Diana tried to cheer me: she said I looked ill, and wished to accompany me to the sea-side.This St. John opposed; he said I did not want dissipation, I wanted employment; my present life was too purposeless, I required an aim; and, I suppose, by way of supplying deficiencies, he prolonged still further my lessons in Hindostanee, and grew more urgent in requiring their accomplishment: and I, like a fool, never thought of resisting him—I could not resist him.
一天，我去学习时的情绪比以往更低，出现情绪的低潮是因为我感到了一阵痛彻心扉的失望。早晨汉娜告诉我有一封信是给我的，而我下楼去取的时候，内心几乎肯定我期盼已久的消息终于降临了，但我却发现那只是布里格斯先生寄来的不重要的公务短笺。这种令人痛苦的挫败使我落泪。现在，我坐着研读一位印度作家那难以辨识的文字和华丽的比喻，眼泪又一次涌了出来。 One day I had come to my studies in lower spirits than usual; the ebb was occasioned by a poignantly felt disappointment.Hannah had told me in the morning there was a letter for me, and when I went down to take it, almost certain that the long-looked for tidings were vouchsafed me at last, I found only an unimportant note from Mr. Briggs on business.The bitter check had wrung from me some tears; and now, as I sat poring over the crabbed characters and flourishing tropes of an Indian scribe, my eyes filled again.
圣约翰把我叫到他身边朗读，我试着这么做，可是声音却不受控制了，我泣不成声。客厅里当时只有我和他。黛安娜在休息室里练习音乐，玛丽在花园里劳作。那是五月里非常晴朗的一天，空气清新，阳光明媚，微风徐徐。我的同伴对我的情感没有表现出一丝惊异，也没有问我是什么原因，他只是说： St. John called me to his side to read; in attempting to do this my voice failed me: words were lost in sobs.He and I were the only occupants of the parlour: Diana was practising her music in the drawing-room, Mary was gardening—it was a very fine May day, clear, sunny, and breezy.My companion expressed no surprise at this emotion, nor did he question me as to its cause; he only said—
“简，我们停一会儿吧，等你冷静一点再继续。”我赶紧抑制住激动的情绪，他则平静耐心地坐在那儿，倚着书桌，像个医生一样用他那科学的眼光观察着病人病情的突发状况，而这状况是他早已料到并且十分清楚的。我止住了抽泣，擦干了眼泪，小声嘟哝着说那天早上身体不太舒服，便继续研读起来，最后完成了功课。圣约翰把我的书和他的书都放到一旁，锁上抽屉，说道： “We will wait a few minutes, Jane, till you are more composed.”And while I smothered the paroxysm with all haste, he sat calm and patient, leaning on his desk, and looking like a physician watching with the eye of science an expected and fully understood crisis in a patient’s malady.Having stifled my sobs, wiped my eyes, and muttered something about not being very well that morning, I resumed my task, and succeeded in completing it.St. John put away my books and his, locked his desk, and said—
“好了，简，你得去散散步了，和我一起。” “Now, Jane, you shall take a walk; and with me.”
“那我叫上黛安娜和玛丽。” “I will call Diana and Mary.”
“不，今天上午我只想要一个人陪我，那个人必须是你。穿好你的衣服，从厨房门出去，沿着通往沼泽溪谷尽头的那条路走，我一会儿就去找你。” “No; I want only one companion this morning, and that must be you.Put on your things; go out by the kitchen-door: take the road towards the head of Marsh Glen: I will join you in a moment.”
我想不出任何折中的办法。在我有生之年，与同我性格相反、个性武断冷酷的人打交道时，我从来都想不出在绝对服从屈服和坚决反抗之间还有什么折中的办法。我一直都是绝对地服从，直到爆发的那一刻，有时这种爆发就像火山喷发一样，便会转入坚决反抗。然而因为目前的情况不允许我反抗，且我当前的心境也无意反抗，我于是小心地服从了圣约翰的命令。十分钟后，我便与他肩并肩走在溪谷那条荒凉的小径上了。 I know no medium: I never in my life have known any medium in my dealings with positive, hard characters, antagonistic to my own, between absolute submission and determined revolt.I have always faithfully observed the one, up to the very moment of bursting, sometimes with volcanic vehemence, into the other; and as neither present circumstances warranted, nor my present mood inclined me to mutiny, I observed careful obedience to St. John’s directions; and in ten minutes I was treading the wild track of the glen, side by side with him.
微风从西边吹来，掠过群山，带来了欧石南和灯芯草的芳香。天空蔚蓝无云，溪流因为刚刚下过的春雨而涨溢，沿着幽谷向下流淌，充盈清澈，闪烁着太阳金黄的光芒，反射出苍穹蓝宝石般的色彩。我们继续往前走下了小路，踏上了一片柔软的草坪。草坪细如苔藓，青似绿宝石，精致地点缀着一种小白花，闪耀着一簇簇星星般的黄花。群山包围着我们，溪谷的尽头蜿蜒伸入它们的怀抱。 The breeze was from the west: it came over the hills, sweet with scents of heath and rush; the sky was of stainless blue; the stream descending the ravine, swelled with past spring rains, poured along plentiful and clear, catching golden gleams from the sun, and sapphire tints from the firmament.As we advanced and left the track, we trod a soft turf, mossy fine and emerald green, minutely enamelled with a tiny white flower, and spangled with a star-like yellow blossom: the hills, meantime, shut us quite in; for the glen, towards its head, wound to their very core.
“我们在这儿歇会儿吧。”圣约翰说。这时我们已经走到了一个岩石群最靠前的一堆散乱的石头跟前。那岩石群护守着一条隘口，隘口远处，溪水如瀑布般倾泻而下。离这儿再远一点的地方，大山抖掉了身上的草坪和鲜花，只剩下欧石南来作衣服，岩石作珠宝。在那里，大山把荒凉夸张成了蛮荒，把新鲜换成了愁眉不展；在那里，大山独守着无望的希望，还有缄默的最后一处避难所。 “Let us rest here,” said St. John, as we reached the first stragglers of a battalion of rocks, guarding a sort of pass, beyond which the beck rushed down a waterfall;and where, still a little farther, the mountain shook off turf and flower, had only heath for raiment and crag for gem—where it exaggerated the wild to the savage, and exchanged the fresh for the frowning—where it guarded the forlorn hope of solitude, and a last refuge for silence.
我坐了下来，圣约翰站在我旁边。他顺着隘口向上望，又低头看向空谷，目光随着溪流伸向远方，又转回来扫视为溪流染上色彩的晴朗天空。他摘下帽子，任微风吹乱他的头发，亲吻他的额头。他似乎在和这个自己经常造访之地的精灵交流。他用目光和某种东西告别。 I took a seat: St. John stood near me.He looked up the pass and down the hollow; his glance wandered away with the stream, and returned to traverse the unclouded heaven which coloured it: he removed his hat, let the breeze stir his hair and kiss his brow.He seemed in communion with the genius of the haunt: with his eye he bade farewell to something.
“我还会见到它的，”他大声说，“在梦里，当我沉睡在恒河岸边的时候，还有在更早的时候——当我又一次陷入沉睡，在一条更黑暗的小溪岸边。” “And I shall see it again,” he said aloud, “in dreams when I sleep by the Ganges: and again in a more remote hour—when another slumber overcomes me—on the shore of a darker stream!”
古怪的言语，古怪的爱！一个苦行的爱国者对自己祖国的感情！他坐了下来，有半个小时我们都没有说话，他没有对我说什么，我也没有对他说什么。这段沉默过去后，他又开口了： Strange words of a strange love!An austere patriot’s passion for his fatherland!He sat down; for half-an-hour we never spoke; neither he to me nor I to him: that interval past, he recommenced—
“简，我六个星期后就要走了。我已经在‘东印度人’号船上订了舱位，六月二十号出发。” “Jane, I go in six weeks; I have taken my berth in an East Indiaman which sails on the 20th of June.”
“上帝会保佑你的，因为你承担了他的工作。”我答道。 “God will protect you; for you have undertaken His work,” I answered.
“是的，”他说，“这是我的光荣，也是我的快乐。我是永远正确的主的一名奴仆。我的出行并非由凡人指引，不受不完备的法律限制，也不被我软弱的可怜虫同类们错误地控制。我的国王，我的立法者，我的首领是尽善尽美的主。我觉得奇怪的是，周围的人却并不渴望跻身于这一旗帜下来——参加这项共同的事业。” “Yes,” said he, “there is my glory and joy.I am the servant of an infallible Master.I am not going out under human guidance, subject to the defective laws and erring control of my feeble fellow-worms: my king, my lawgiver, my captain, is the All-perfect.It seems strange to me that all round me do not burn to enlist under the same banner,—to join in the same enterprise.”
“不是所有人都有你身上的力量，软弱的人希望同强大的人齐头并进是愚蠢的。” “All have not your powers, and it would be folly for the feeble to wish to march with the strong.”
“我说的不是那些软弱的人，我也没有想到他们。我只是说给那些能够配得上这份工作并且能胜任它的人听的。” “I do not speak to the feeble, or think of them: I address only such as are worthy of the work, and competent to accomplish it.”
“这样的人太少了，而且也很难找到。” “Those are few in number, and difficult to discover.”
“你说得对，然而一旦找到了，正确的做法就是激起他们的热情——敦促、勉励他们付出努力；告诉他们自己有何天赋，以及为什么上天赋予他们这些天赋；把上天的讯息传递到他们耳中；直接代表上帝，在上帝的选民中给他们提供一席之地。” “You say truly; but when found, it is right to stir them up—to urge and exhort them to the effort—to show them what their gifts are, and why they were given—to speak Heaven’s message in their ear,—to offer them, direct from God, a place in the ranks of His chosen.”
“如果这些人真的胜任这项任务，难道是他们的内心不应该在第一时间感知到这一点吗？” “If they are really qualified for the task, will not their own hearts be the first to inform them of it?”
我感觉到仿佛有一种可怕的咒语正在我周身慢慢成形，聚集在我头顶。我颤抖着，怕听到一些致命的话语一下子宣布出来并使这种魔力挥之不去。 I felt as if an awful charm was framing round and gathering over me: I trembled to hear some fatal word spoken which would at once declare and rivet the spell.
“那么你的‘内心’告诉你什么了？”圣约翰问道。 “And what does YOUR heart say?” demanded St. John.
“我的内心不会说话——不会说话。”我答道，心里一惊，感到毛骨悚然。 “My heart is mute,—my heart is mute,” I answered, struck and thrilled.
“那么我必须替它说了。”他那低沉、冷酷的声音继续说道，“简，和我一起去印度吧，做我的助手和同事。” “Then I must speak for it,” continued the deep, relentless voice.“Jane, come with me to India: come as my helpmeet and fellow-labourer.”
溪谷和天空顿时旋转起来，群山也起伏不定了！我仿佛听到了来自上天的召唤，仿佛一位幻象一般的马其顿使者已经宣布：“过来帮助我们！”但我不是使徒，我无法看到那位使者，我也无法接受他的召唤。 The glen and sky spun round: the hills heaved!It was as if I had heard a summons from Heaven—as if a visionary messenger, like him of Macedonia, had enounced, “Come over and help us!”But I was no apostle,—I could not behold the herald,—I could not receive his call.
“噢，圣约翰！”我叫道，“发发慈悲吧！” “Oh, St. John!” I cried, “have some mercy!”
我请求的是一个自以为是在履行职责的人，一个不懂什么是慈悲或同情的人。他继续说道： I appealed to one who, in the discharge of what he believed his duty, knew neither mercy nor remorse.He continued—
“上帝和大自然让你成为一个传教士的妻子。它们赋予你的不是肉体的能力，而是精神上的才能。你生来是为了工作，而不为了爱情。你必须，也应该做一个传教士的妻子。你将会属于我，我要你——并不是为我个人的享乐，而是为我主服务。” “God and nature intended you for a missionary’s wife.It is not personal, but mental endowments they have given you: you are formed for labour, not for love.A missionary’s wife you must—shall be.You shall be mine: I claim you—not for my pleasure, but for my Sovereign’s service.”
“我不适合，我没有这种才能。”我说。 “I am not fit for it: I have no vocation,” I said.
他早已料到我最初的反抗，并未为此而恼火。的确，当他靠在身后的崖壁上，双臂交叉抱于胸前，板起面孔时，我看得出他已经准备好要对付一场漫长而恼人的反抗，而且积攒了足够的耐力坚持到结束。不过，他下定决心要赢得最终的胜利。 He had calculated on these first objections: he was not irritated by them.Indeed, as he leaned back against the crag behind him, folded his arms on his chest, and fixed his countenance, I saw he was prepared for a long and trying opposition, and had taken in a stock of patience to last him to its close—resolved, however, that that close should be conquest for him.
“谦卑，简，”他说，“就是基督教美德的基础。你说自己不适合这一任务，那就对了。谁才是适合的呢？或者说，谁会在真正被召唤时，相信他自己配得上这一召唤呢？比如我吧，仅仅是尘埃之身。相比于圣保罗，我承认自己是最大的恶人。但是我不允许这种个人的罪恶感使我丧失信心。我了解我的首领，他既公正又强大。当他选择了一个软弱的工具去完成一项伟大的任务时，他会借助他那无穷无尽的贮藏，来弥补完成任务所用的手段上的不足。像我一样地思考，简，像我一样去相信。我要你倚靠的是万古的磐石，不要怀疑，它能承受你人性弱点的重压。” “Humility, Jane,” said he, “is the groundwork of Christian virtues: you say right that you are not fit for the work.Who is fit for it?Or who, that ever was truly called, believed himself worthy of the summons?I, for instance, am but dust and ashes.With St. Paul, I acknowledge myself the chiefest of sinners; but I do not suffer this sense of my personal vileness to daunt me.I know my Leader: that He is just as well as mighty; and while He has chosen a feeble instrument to perform a great task, He will, from the boundless stores of His providence, supply the inadequacy of the means to the end.Think like me, Jane—trust like me.It is the Rock of Ages I ask you to lean on: do not doubt but it will bear the weight of your human weakness.”
“我不了解传教士的生活，我从来没研究过传教士要做的工作。” “I do not understand a missionary life: I have never studied missionary labours.”
“有我呢，虽然我很卑微，但我可以在你需要的时候帮助你。我可以不时地给你分配任务，常常支持你，时刻帮助你。这些我在开始的时候都会做，但是不久（我知道你的能力），你就会和我一样强大，一样合适，不再需要我的帮助了。”“但是我的能力——从事这项工作所需的能力在哪儿呢？我感觉不到。你说话时，我内心没有任何想法，也不感到激动。我没有感觉到光芒在闪耀，没有感觉到生命在加速搏动，也没有感觉到声音在劝告或鼓励我。噢，我希望可以让你看到此刻我的心，真像一座不见天日的地牢，我躲在牢底，有的只是畏畏缩缩的恐惧——害怕被你说服，试图去做我无法完成的任务！” “There I, humble as I am, can give you the aid you want: I can set you your task from hour to hour; stand by you always; help you from moment to moment.This I could do in the beginning: soon (for I know your powers) you would be as strong and apt as myself, and would not require my help.”“But my powers—where are they for this undertaking?I do not feel them.Nothing speaks or stirs in me while you talk.I am sensible of no light kindling—no life quickening—no voice counselling or cheering.Oh, I wish I could make you see how much my mind is at this moment like a rayless dungeon, with one shrinking fear fettered in its depths—the fear of being persuaded by you to attempt what I cannot accomplish!”
“我给你想好了答案，听着。自从我们初次相见，我就一直在观察你，我已经研究你十个月了。我用各种各样的考验来考察你，而我从中看到了什么，得到了什么结论呢？在乡村学校，我发现你教学出色，准时准点，公平正直，尽管这工作与你的习惯和兴致不太相符；我看到你工作有能力、有技巧。只要你控制了局面，你就会取得胜利。当你得知自己突然变得富有时表现得那么镇静，我看到了一个完全没有底马那种贪欲的心灵——金钱对你没有太大的影响。你毅然决然要把财产分成四份，只留给自己一份。为了你所说的理论上的公平，你放弃了其他三份，让我认识到了一个以牺牲的热情和兴奋为乐趣的灵魂。按照我的愿望，你顺从地放弃了自己喜欢学的，转而学习我感兴趣的,从那以后便勤勉、不懈地坚持学习。你不屈不挠、泰然自若地应对学习中的困难，我承认从中我看到了我所寻找的所有品质。简，你温顺、勤勉、无私、忠诚、坚定、无畏，你非常温柔又非常英勇。不要再不信任你自己了，我可以完全信任你。你作为印度学校里的一名女督导和印度妇女的帮手，你的帮助对我来说极其宝贵。” “I have an answer for you—hear it.I have watched you ever since we first met: I have made you my study for ten months.I have proved you in that time by sundry tests: and what have I seen and elicited?In the village school I found you could perform well, punctually, uprightly, labour uncongenial to your habits and inclinations; I saw you could perform it with capacity and tact: you could win while you controlled.In the calm with which you learnt you had become suddenly rich, I read a mind clear of the vice of Demas:—lucre had no undue power over you.In the resolute readiness with which you cut your wealth into four shares, keeping but one to yourself, and relinquishing the three others to the claim of abstract justice, I recognised a soul that revelled in the flame and excitement of sacrifice.In the tractability with which, at my wish, you forsook a study in which you were interested, and adopted another because it interested me; in the untiring assiduity with which you have since persevered in it—in the unflagging energy and unshaken temper with which you have met its difficulties—I acknowledge the complement of the qualities I seek.Jane, you are docile, diligent, disinterested, faithful, constant, and courageous; very gentle, and very heroic: cease to mistrust yourself—I can trust you unreservedly.As a conductress of Indian schools, and a helper amongst Indian women, your assistance will be to me invaluable.”
我坚如钢铁的外罩开始紧缩，他劝说的步伐缓慢却坚定地向我逼近。尽管我闭上了眼睛，但他的最后几句话却成功地把看似堵塞了的道路变得相对通畅了。我的工作以前似乎是模糊不清，零散无序的，被他的一席话一说说变得简单明了，在他的塑造下有了确切的模样。他等着我的答复。在我又一次冒险答复他之前，我要求一刻钟的思考时间。 My iron shroud contracted round me; persuasion advanced with slow sure step.Shut my eyes as I would, these last words of his succeeded in making the way, which had seemed blocked up, comparatively clear.My work, which had appeared so vague, so hopelessly diffuse, condensed itself as he proceeded, and assumed a definite form under his shaping hand.He waited for an answer.I demanded a quarter of an hour to think, before I again hazarded a reply.
“非常愿意。”他答道，然后站起身，大步沿着隘口走了一段，在一个长满欧石南的土堆上躺下了，一动不动。 “Very willingly,” he rejoined; and rising, he strode a little distance up the pass, threw himself down on a swell of heath, and there lay still.
“我可以做他想让我做的事，我被迫认识到并承认这一点，”我思考着，“前提是，如果可以让我活下去的话。但是我感到我的生命在印度的太阳下不会持续太久。那又怎样？他又不会在乎。我的死期到来时，他会解除我的任务，平静而神圣地将我交给赋予我生命的上帝。情况在我看来是再明白不过了。离开英国，我也就离开了自己热爱却空荡的土地——罗切斯特先生不在这里。然而即使他在呢，对我来说意味着什么？又能意味着什么呢？我现在要做的是没有他也要生活下去。没有比这日复一日地拖下去更荒唐、更软弱的了，就好像我还在等待情况发生某种不可能的变化，好让我们重聚。当然（如同圣约翰曾说过的那样），我必须寻找生活中其他有趣的事情来代替我失去的。那么他现在提供给我的工作不正是一个人们可以从事或上帝所委派的最光荣的工作吗？从它高尚的关怀和伟大的结果来看，难道不是最适合填补被撕碎的感情和被毁灭的希望所留下的空缺？我确信我必须说，是的。然而，我却浑身发抖。唉！如果我跟随圣约翰，我就是放弃了半个自我。如果我前往印度，我就是提前走向死亡。而离开英国去印度和从印度走向坟墓之间的空隙又该如何填补呢？哦，我知道得很清楚！这一点，我也看得清清楚楚。我竭尽全力来使圣约翰满意，直至浑身酸痛，我一定会满足他——所有的细微要求和远大期望我都会满足他。如果我真跟随他而去，真在他的敦促下作出牺牲，我会彻彻底地做到。我会把我的心灵、重要器官甚至我整个人作为祭品抛上祭坛。他永远不会爱我，但是他会赞赏我。我会向他展示他尚未见过的精力，以及他未曾怀疑过的才华。是的，我可以和他一样努力工作，和他一样毫无怨言。 “I CAN do what he wants me to do: I am forced to see and acknowledge that,” I meditated,—“that is, if life be spared me.But I feel mine is not the existence to be long protracted under an Indian sun.What then?He does not care for that: when my time came to die, he would resign me, in all serenity and sanctity, to the God who gave me.The case is very plain before me.In leaving England, I should leave a loved but empty land—Mr. Rochester is not there; and if he were, what is, what can that ever be to me?My business is to live without him now: nothing so absurd, so weak as to drag on from day to day, as if I were waiting some impossible change in circumstances, which might reunite me to him.Of course (as St. John once said) I must seek another interest in life to replace the one lost: is not the occupation he now offers me truly the most glorious man can adopt or God assign?Is it not, by its noble cares and sublime results, the one best calculated to fill the void left by uptorn affections and demolished hopes?I believe I must say, Yes—and yet I shudder.Alas! If I join St. John, I abandon half myself: if I go to India, I go to premature death.And how will the interval between leaving England for India, and India for the grave, be filled?Oh, I know well!That, too, is very clear to my vision.By straining to satisfy St. John till my sinews ache, I SHALL satisfy him—to the finest central point and farthest outward circle of his expectations.If I DO go with him—if I DO make the sacrifice he urges, I will make it absolutely: I will throw all on the altar—heart, vitals, the entire victim.He will never love me; but he shall approve me; I will show him energies he has not yet seen, resources he has never suspected.Yes, I can work as hard as he can, and with as little grudging.
“那么，同意他的要求是可能的——除了其中一条，那条可怕的要求。那就是——他要求我做他的妻子，而他作为我丈夫的心意并不比远处峡谷中泛着泡沫的小溪趟过的那块嶙峋巨石强多少。他珍惜我，就像士兵珍视一件好武器一样，仅此而已。如果不嫁给他，我也不会为此伤心。但是我能让他了却心愿，冷酷地实施他的计划，完成结婚仪式吗？我能从他手上接过结婚戒指，忍受所有爱的形式（我不怀疑他会严谨地遵守），同时明白爱的实质是不存在的吗？我能忍受自己时刻意识到他所给予的每一份爱都是为原则而做出的牺牲吗？不，这样的殉教太恐怖了。我绝对做不到。作为他的妹妹，我可能会陪他去，但不是作为他的妻子。我就这么对他说。” “Consent, then, to his demand is possible: but for one item—one dreadful item.It is—that he asks me to be his wife, and has no more of a husband’s heart for me than that frowning giant of a rock, down which the stream is foaming in yonder gorge.He prizes me as a soldier would a good weapon; and that is all.Unmarried to him, this would never grieve me; but can I let him complete his calculations—coolly put into practice his plans—go through the wedding ceremony?Can I receive from him the bridal ring, endure all the forms of love (which I doubt not he would scrupulously observe) and know that the spirit was quite absent?Can I bear the consciousness that every endearment he bestows is a sacrifice made on principle?No: such a martyrdom would be monstrous.I will never undergo it.As his sister, I might accompany him—not as his wife: I will tell him so.”
我望向那个土墩，他躺在那儿，一动不动地，像根倒下的柱子。他的脸转向我，眼睛投射出警觉而锐利的目光。他站起身，向我走来。 I looked towards the knoll: there he lay, still as a prostrate column; his face turned to me: his eye beaming watchful and keen.He started to his feet and approached me.
“我准备好了去印度，如果我可以自由地去。” “I am ready to go to India, if I may go free.”
“你的回答需要解释一下，”他说，“答案不清楚。” “Your answer requires a commentary,” he said; “it is not clear.”
“你至今一直是我的义兄，而我是你的义妹。就让我们这样继续下去吧，你和我最好不要结婚。” “You have hitherto been my adopted brother—I, your adopted sister: let us continue as such: you and I had better not marry.”
他摇了摇头。“义兄妹在这种情形下行不通。如果你是我的亲妹妹，那就不同了，我会带你走，不另外找妻子。但事实是，我们的结合要么通过婚姻来神圣化，加以确保，要么便不会存在。任何其他的计划都会面临实际的阻碍。你不明白吗，简？再考虑一下吧，你坚强的意识会指引你。” He shook his head.“Adopted fraternity will not do in this case.If you were my real sister it would be different: I should take you, and seek no wife.But as it is, either our union must be consecrated and sealed by marriage, or it cannot exist: practical obstacles oppose themselves to any other plan.Do you not see it, Jane?Consider a moment—your strong sense will guide you.”
我的确考虑过了。我的理智虽然不过如此，却指出了一个事实，那就是我们并不像丈夫和妻子那样爱着对方，因此，它断定我们不该结婚。我于是如实说了。“圣约翰，”我回答道，“我把你当作哥哥，你把我当作妹妹，所以我们还是继续这样吧。” I did consider; and still my sense, such as it was, directed me only to the fact that we did not love each other as man and wife should: and therefore it inferred we ought not to marry.I said so.“St. John,” I returned, “I regard you as a brother—you, me as a sister: so let us continue.”
“我们不能这样，不能这样，”他简短而坚定地答道，“这样行不通。你已经说了你会跟我去印度，记住——你说过了。” “We cannot—we cannot,” he answered, with short, sharp determination: “it would not do.You have said you will go with me to India: remember—you have said that.”
“那是有条件的。” “Conditionally.”
“好吧，好吧。说主要的——和我一起离开英国，将来与我一起工作，你并不反对。你实际上已经把手放在了犁杖上，你不会出尔反尔再缩回去。你只要保持一个目标——就是如何把自己承担的任务完成得最好。把你复杂的兴趣、感受、思想、愿望和目标统统简化吧，把所有的思考都合并为一个目的：充满力量、有效地完成伟大的主所赋予的使命。要完成这些，你必须有一个助手，不是一个哥哥——这种关系不牢固，而是一个丈夫。同样，我不想要妹妹，妹妹可能随时被人从我身边带走。我需要一个妻子，唯一一个在生活中我可以有效施加影响的伴侣，可以完全拥有她直到死亡。” “Well—well.To the main point—the departure with me from England, the co-operation with me in my future labours—you do not object.You have already as good as put your hand to the plough: you are too consistent to withdraw it.You have but one end to keep in view—how the work you have undertaken can best be done.Simplify your complicated interests, feelings, thoughts, wishes, aims; merge all considerations in one purpose: that of fulfilling with effect—with power—the mission of your great Master.To do so, you must have a coadjutor: not a brother—that is a loose tie—but a husband.I, too, do not want a sister: a sister might any day be taken from me.I want a wife: the sole helpmeet I can influence efficiently in life, and retain absolutely till death.”
他说话时我不禁颤抖，我感到他的影响深入到了我的骨髓，我的四肢像是被他束缚住了。 I shuddered as he spoke: I felt his influence in my marrow—his hold on my limbs.
“去别处另找一个吧，别指望我了，圣约翰。找一个适合你的。” “Seek one elsewhere than in me, St. John: seek one fitted to you.”
“找一个适合我目的的人，你是这个意思吧——适合我职业的人。我再次告诉你，我不是作为微不足道的个人，一个带有自私意识的男人，想要结婚，而是作为一个传教士。” “One fitted to my purpose, you mean—fitted to my vocation.Again I tell you it is not the insignificant private individual—the mere man, with the man’s selfish senses—I wish to mate: it is the missionary.”
“那么我把自己所有的精力都献给这位传教士——这就是他想要的——除了我本人。我对于他无非就是把果壳加到果仁上。他要这个也没用，我要自己留着。” “And I will give the missionary my energies—it is all he wants—but not myself: that would be only adding the husk and shell to the kernel.For them he has no use: I retain them.”
“你不能，你也不应该留着。难道你认为上帝会对半心半意的奉献感到满意吗？他会接受残缺的祭品吗？我宣扬的是上帝的事业，我正是在他的旗帜下招你入伍。我不能代表上帝接受三心二意的忠诚，必须是全心全意的。” “You cannot—you ought not.Do you think God will be satisfied with half an oblation?Will He accept a mutilated sacrifice?It is the cause of God I advocate: it is under His standard I enlist you.I cannot accept on His behalf a divided allegiance: it must be entire.”
“噢！我会把我的心交给上帝，”我说，“但你不需要它。” “Oh! I will give my heart to God,” I said.“YOU do not want it.”
