读者啊，我不能保证我在说这话时，语气和感情没有带着一丝被压制了的嘲讽。我一直到现在都默默地惧怕着圣约翰，因为我一直都不能理解他。他使我敬畏，因为他总是让我拿不准。他身上有几分属于圣人，几分属于凡夫，我至今无法判断。但是这一次的交谈正在逐渐揭露出真相，对他本性的分析正在我眼前展开。我看到了他也是会犯错的，我理解这些错误。我明白，我此刻坐在长满欧石南的山坡上，面前是一个英俊的身躯，我是坐在一个跟我一样会犯错误的男人的脚下。掩盖他的苛刻和专制的面纱落了下来。感觉到他身上存在的这些品质之后，我便知道他并不完美，于是也就有了勇气。我面对的是一个与我平等的人——一个我可以与之争论的人，一个在我觉得适当的时候，可以与之抗衡的人。 I will not swear, reader, that there was not something of repressed sarcasm both in the tone in which I uttered this sentence, and in the feeling that accompanied it.I had silently feared St. John till now, because I had not understood him.He had held me in awe, because he had held me in doubt.How much of him was saint, how much mortal, I could not heretofore tell: but revelations were being made in this conference: the analysis of his nature was proceeding before my eyes.I saw his fallibilities: I comprehended them.I understood that, sitting there where I did, on the bank of heath, and with that handsome form before me, I sat at the feet of a man, caring as I.The veil fell from his hardness and despotism.Having felt in him the presence of these qualities, I felt his imperfection and took courage.I was with an equal—one with whom I might argue—one whom, if I saw good, I might resist.
我说完最后一句话，他没有出声，我不久就大胆地抬头看了一眼他的表情。 He was silent after I had uttered the last sentence, and I presently risked an upward glance at his countenance.
他紧盯着我的目光立刻流露出严厉的惊讶和急切的质问。那目光仿佛在说：“她是在嘲讽吗？嘲讽我？这话是什么意思？” His eye, bent on me, expressed at once stern surprise and keen inquiry.“Is she sarcastic, and sarcastic to ME!” it seemed to say.“What does this signify?”
“我们别忘了这是个严肃的问题。”他没过一会儿说道，“这个问题，我们无论是轻率地考虑或谈论都难免有罪。我相信，简，当你说你会把心交给上帝时是诚恳的。这就是我所要的。一旦你用力把心灵从凡人的世界里脱离出来，放在造物主身上，那么将造物主的精神王国在世间推广将是你最大的乐趣和努力所在。一切能向这个目标推进的事情，你都会立刻去做。你将会看到我们结婚后肉体和精神的结合将会给你我的努力带来多大的动力，只有这样的结合才能永远符合人类的命运和使命。只要你忽略所有微不足道的情绪变化——一切感情方面的困难和敏感，一切仅仅是个人爱好的程度、种类、力量和脆弱的顾虑——你就会立刻急于达成这种结合。” “Do not let us forget that this is a solemn matter,” he said ere long; “one of which we may neither think nor talk lightly without sin.I trust, Jane, you are in earnest when you say you will serve your heart to God: it is all I want.Once wrench your heart from man, and fix it on your Maker, the advancement of that Maker’s spiritual kingdom on earth will be your chief delight and endeavour; you will be ready to do at once whatever furthers that end.You will see what impetus would be given to your efforts and mine by our physical and mental union in marriage: the only union that gives a character of permanent conformity to the destinies and designs of human beings;and, passing over all minor caprices—all trivial difficulties and delicacies of feeling—all scruple about the degree, kind, strength or tenderness of mere personal inclination—you will hasten to enter into that union at once.”
“我会吗？”我简短地说。我看看他的五官，匀称英俊，但是平静严肃，出奇地可怕；他的额头，威严但并不舒展；他的眼睛，明亮、深邃而又锐利，却从不温柔；再看看他那高大、伟岸的身躯；想象着自己是他的妻子。哦！绝对不行！作为他的助理牧师，或他的同事，怎么都可以：我会以这种身份陪着他漂洋过海；以这样的职位在东方的太阳下、亚洲的沙漠中与他一同工作；敬佩并效仿他的勇气、虔诚与活力；默默接受他的主人身份；泰然自若地笑他根深蒂固的雄心；区分他身上属于基督徒和凡人的部分，对前者无比敬重，对后者随意宽恕。毫无疑问，以这种身份附属于他的话，我会常常感到痛苦。我的身体会处于严格的束缚之中，但是我的心灵和思想还是自由的。我还可以求助于未曾受到摧残的自我。在孤独的时刻，我可以同我不受奴役的自然感情交流。 “Shall I?”I said briefly; and I looked at his features, beautiful in their harmony, but strangely formidable in their still severity; at his brow, commanding but not open; at his eyes, bright and deep and searching, but never soft; at his tall imposing figure; and fancied myself in idea HIS WIFE.Oh! it would never do!As his curate, his comrade, all would be right: I would cross oceans with him in that capacity; toil under Eastern suns, in Asian deserts with him in that office; admire and emulate his courage and devotion and vigour; accommodate quietly to his masterhood; smile undisturbed at his ineradicable ambition; discriminate the Christian from the man: profoundly esteem the one, and freely forgive the other.I should suffer often, no doubt, attached to him only in this capacity: my body would be under rather a stringent yoke, but my heart and mind would be free.I should still have my unblighted self to turn to: my natural unenslaved feelings with which to communicate in moments of loneliness.
内心深处有属于我自己的地方，他永远到不了。情感在那里蓬勃生长，被保护得很好，永远不会被他的严酷摧毁，也不会被他武士般从容不迫的步伐践踏。但是作为他的妻子,总是陪在他身边，总是受到束缚，总要克制自己，被迫压制天性之火，迫使它在内心燃烧，且绝不呐喊，即使那被禁锢的火焰把我的脏器一个一个地烧毁——这不是我能忍受的。 There would be recesses in my mind which would be only mine, to which he never came, and sentiments growing there fresh and sheltered which his austerity could never blight, nor his measured warrior-march trample down: but as his wife—at his side always, and always restrained, and always checked—forced to keep the fire of my nature continually low, to compel it to burn inwardly and never utter a cry, though the imprisoned flame consumed vital after vital—THIS would be unendurable.
“圣约翰！”当我考虑到这么多的时候便叫了出来。 “St. John!” I exclaimed, when I had got so far in my meditation.
“怎么了？”他冷冷地答道。 “Well?” he answered icily.
“我再说一遍，我愿意作为你的传教士伙伴跟你走，但不是作为你的妻子。我不能嫁给你，成为你的一部分。” “I repeat I freely consent to go with you as your fellow-missionary, but not as your wife; I cannot marry you and become part of you.”
“你必须成为我的一部分，”他坚定地答道，“否则，所有的商讨都是徒劳。我一个不到三十岁的男人怎么能够带着一个十九岁的姑娘去印度？除非她嫁给我。我们不结婚的话，怎么能够永远在一起——有时身处荒凉之地，有时置身于野蛮部落之中？” “A part of me you must become,” he answered steadily; “otherwise the whole bargain is void.How can I, a man not yet thirty, take out with me to India a girl of nineteen, unless she be married to me?How can we be for ever together—sometimes in solitudes, sometimes amidst savage tribes—and unwed?”
“那好办，”我唐突地答道，“在那样的情形下，你完全可以把我当成你的亲妹妹，或一个男人，一个像你一样的牧师。” “Very well,” I said shortly; “under the circumstances, quite as well as if I were either your real sister, or a man and a clergyman like yourself.”
“大家都知道你不是我妹妹，我不能这样把你介绍给别人。试着这么做会给我们俩招来中伤和怀疑。至于其他假设，虽然你有男人般精力充沛的头脑，但你还是有一颗女人的心——这行不通。” “It is known that you are not my sister; I cannot introduce you as such: to attempt it would be to fasten injurious suspicions on us both.And for the rest, though you have a man’s vigorous brain, you have a woman’s heart and—it would not do.”
“行得通。”我带着几分不屑地断言道，“完全行得通。我是有一颗女人的心，但是它与你无关。对你，我只有同伴的坚定不移，战友的坦率、忠诚和友情。如果你想要的话，还有一个新教士对他圣师的尊敬和服从。仅此而已——不用担心。” “It would do,” I affirmed with some disdain, “perfectly well.I have a woman’s heart, but not where you are concerned; for you I have only a comrade’s constancy; a fellow-soldier’s frankness, fidelity, fraternity, if you like; a neophyte’s respect and submission to his hierophant: nothing more—don’t fear.”
“这就是我想要的，”他自言自语道，“正是我想要的。然而还有许多障碍，必须把它们排除掉。简，你不会后悔嫁给我的，相信这一点吧，我们必须结婚。我再说一遍：没有别的选择了。结婚以后自然会产生足够的感情，使得我们的结合在你看来也是正确的。” “It is what I want,” he said, speaking to himself; “it is just what I want.And there are obstacles in the way: they must be hewn down.Jane, you would not repent marrying me—be certain of that; we MUST be married.I repeat it: there is no other way; and undoubtedly enough of love would follow upon marriage to render the union right even in your eyes.”
“我鄙视你对爱情的认识。”我不禁说道，同时站起身，站在他面前，背靠在岩石上。“我鄙视你的虚情假意。是的，圣约翰，当你说这些的时候，我瞧不起你。” “I scorn your idea of love,” I could not help saying, as I rose up and stood before him, leaning my back against the rock.“I scorn the counterfeit sentiment you offer: yes, St. John, and I scorn you when you offer it.”
他目不转睛地盯着我，紧闭着他那线条优美的嘴唇。他到底是恼怒，还是吃惊，亦或是其他，真不好判断。他完全可以控制自己的表情。 He looked at me fixedly, compressing his well-cut lips while he did so.Whether he was incensed or surprised, or what, it was not easy to tell: he could command his countenance thoroughly.
“我根本没想到会听到你说这么一番话，”他说，“我觉得我做过的事和说过的话没有什么可遭你鄙视的。” “I scarcely expected to hear that expression from you,” he said: “I think I have done and uttered nothing to deserve scorn.”
我被他温柔的口吻所触动，被他傲慢、镇静的神态所震慑。 I was touched by his gentle tone, and overawed by his high, calm mien.
“原谅我说的那些话，圣约翰。但是由于你自己的过错，才激得我这么草率地说话。你谈起了一个我们俩天生看法就不同的话题，一个我们绝不该讨论的话题。爱情这个话题就是我们两个之间的争端所在。要是考虑到实际情况，我们该怎么做？我们会如何感受？我亲爱的表哥，放弃结婚的计划吧——忘了它吧。” “Forgive me the words, St. John; but it is your own fault that I have been roused to speak so unguardedly.You have introduced a topic on which our natures are at variance—a topic we should never discuss: the very name of love is an apple of discord between us.If the reality were required, what should we do?How should we feel?My dear cousin, abandon your scheme of marriage—forget it.”
“不，”他说，“这是一个我长久以来渴望的一项计划，也是唯一能确保我伟大目的得以实现的计划。但是我现在不会再劝你了。明天，我要离开家去剑桥。我有许多朋友在那里，我想去跟他们道别。我会有两周不在家，你利用这段时间考虑一下我的建议。并且不要忘了，如果你拒绝它，你并不是拒绝我，而是上帝。通过我，上帝向你提供了一份高尚的职业，只有做我的妻子你才能从事这一职业。如果你拒绝做我的妻子，你就是永远把自己局限在自私安逸、一无所获、无名卑微的道路中了。你全身发抖，唯恐自己被列为背叛信仰、比不信教的人更糟糕的人！” “No,” said he; “it is a long-cherished scheme, and the only one which can secure my great end: but I shall urge you no further at present.Tomorrow, I leave home for Cambridge: I have many friends there to whom I should wish to say farewell.I shall be absent a fortnight—take that space of time to consider my offer: and do not forget that if you reject it, it is not me you deny, but God.Through my means, He opens to you a noble career; as my wife only can you enter upon it.Refuse to be my wife, and you limit yourself for ever to a track of selfish ease and barren obscurity.Tremble lest in that case you should be numbered with those who have denied the faith, and are worse than infidels!”
他说完了。转过身，他又一次“看看河流，望望山坡”。 He had done.Turning from me, he once more “Looked to river to hill.”
但是这次，他的感情全部堆积在心里，仿佛我不配听到它们被说出来。 But this time his feelings were all pent in his heart: I was not worthy to hear them uttered.
同他并肩往回走时，我从他铁一般冷酷的沉默中，清楚地理解了他对我的感觉。本性严厉专制的他感到了失望，他本以为会得到服从，却遭到了反抗——他冷酷、固执的判断遭到了挫败，无力对另外一个人的感受和观点上产生共鸣。总之，作为一个男人，他本来希望强迫我服从他；只是由于身为一名虔诚的基督徒，他才能如此耐心地忍受我的任性，并给我这么长的时间来考虑和忏悔。 As I walked by his side homeward, I read well in his iron silence all he felt towards me: the disappointment of an austere and despotic nature, which has met resistance where it expected submission—the disapprobation of a cool, inflexible judgment, which has detected in another feelings and views in which it has no power to sympathise:in short, as a man, he would have wished to coerce me into obedience: it was only as a sincere Christian he bore so patiently with my perversity, and allowed so long a space for reflection and repentance.
那晚，他亲吻了两个妹妹之后，觉得即便只是和我握握手也应该忽略，就默默地离开了房间。而我，虽然不爱他，但对他也有很深的友情，我被这种明显、故意的忽略伤到了，伤心得眼泪一下子涌了上来。 That night, after he had kissed his sisters, he thought proper to forget even to shake hands with me, but left the room in silence.I—who, though I had no love, had much friendship for him—was hurt by the marked omission: so much hurt that tears started to my eyes.
“我看出你和圣约翰吵架了，简，”黛安娜说，“就是你们在荒原上散步的时候。可是去追他吧，他正在走廊上徘徊着等你呢——他会同你和好的。” “I see you and St. John have been quarrelling, Jane,” said Diana, “during your walk on the moor.But go after him; he is now lingering in the passage expecting you—he will make it up.”
在这种情形下，我也没什么太多骄傲了，我宁可高高兴兴的，也不要维持面子。我跑出去追他，他在楼梯下站住了。 I have not much pride under such circumstances: I would always rather be happy than dignified; and I ran after him—he stood at the foot of the stairs.
“晚安，圣约翰。”我说。 “Good-night, St. John,” said I.
“晚安，简。”他平静地答道。 “Good-night, Jane,” he replied calmly.
“那么握手吧。”我补充道。 “Then shake hands,” I added.
他留给我手指的是如此冰冷，如此不在意的一握。他因为那天发生的事而感到极其不快，热情友好的举动不能温暖他，眼泪也不能打动他。不可能同他达成愉快的和解了——没有鼓励的笑容，也没有宽容的话语，但是这位基督徒仍然耐心而平静。当我问他是否原谅我了，他回答说他没有记得恼人琐事的习惯，而且他也没什么好原谅的，因为没有受到冒犯。 What a cold, loose touch, he impressed on my fingers!He was deeply displeased by what had occurred that day; cordiality would not warm, nor tears move him.No happy reconciliation was to be had with him—no cheering smile or generous word: but still the Christian was patient and placid; and when I asked him if he forgave me, he answered that he was not in the habit of cherishing the remembrance of vexation; that he had nothing to forgive, not having been offended.
这么回答了之后，他就走了。我宁愿被他打倒在地。 And with that answer he left me.I would much rather he had knocked me down.
第三十五章 CHAPTER XXXV
第二天他并没有像他之前所说的那样去剑桥。他把离开的日期延后了整整一周，在这段时间里，他让我感觉到了一个善良而严格、正直却不宽容的人会给予冒犯了他的人多么严厉的惩罚。没有一下明显带有敌意的举动，也没有一句责备的话，他却设法时刻让我相信我已经不再受他喜欢了。 He did not leave for Cambridge the next day, as he had said he would.He deferred his departure a whole week, and during that time he made me feel what severe punishment a good yet stern, a conscientious yet implacable man can inflict on one who has offended him.Without one overt act of hostility, one upbraiding word, he contrived to impress me momently with the conviction that I was put beyond the pale of his favour.
并非圣约翰怀着非基督徒才有的报复心理，他也不会伤害到我一根头发，即使他完全有能力这么做。他的天性和原则也绝不允许他以卑鄙的报仇为乐。他已经原谅了我说了我鄙视他和他的爱情观的话，但是他没有忘记那些话，并且只要他和我还活着，他就绝不会忘记。他转向我时，我从他的表情就可以看出来，那些话就像是永远写在我们之间的空气里；无论何时我一说话，在他听起来，都会带有那些话的意味，而他给我的回答里也回响着那些话。 Not that St. John harboured a spirit of unchristian vindictiveness—not that he would have injured a hair of my head, if it had been fully in his power to do so.Both by nature and principle, he was superior to the mean gratification of vengeance: he had forgiven me for saying I scorned him and his love, but he had not forgotten the words; and as long as he and I lived he never would forget them.I saw by his look, when he turned to me, that they were always written on the air between me and him; whenever I spoke, they sounded in my voice to his ear, and their echo toned every answer he gave me.
他并不回避与我谈话，他甚至像往常一样每天上午把我叫到他书桌旁一起学习。我害怕他内心里那个堕落的他有一种秘而不宣且不被那个纯粹的基督徒所共享的乐趣，那就是乐于展现他的技巧，言谈举止还跟往常一样，但是从每件事、每句话中都抽掉了原有的关心和赞许的情绪，而这在以前曾显示出他语言和举止中某种严肃的魅力。在我看来，现实中的他已经不是一个有血有肉的人了，而像一块大理石。他的眼睛像是冰冷明亮的蓝宝石，他的舌头也不过是用来说话的工具——仅此而已。 He did not abstain from conversing with me: he even called me as usual each morning to join him at his desk;and I fear the corrupt man within him had a pleasure unimparted to, and unshared by, the pure Christian, in evincing with what skill he could, while acting and speaking apparently just as usual, extract from every deed and every phrase the spirit of interest and approval which had formerly communicated a certain austere charm to his language and manner.To me, he was in reality become no longer flesh, but marble; his eye was a cold, bright, blue gem; his tongue a speaking instrument—nothing more.
所有这些对我来说都是折磨——微妙的、经久不消的折磨。这种折磨燃烧着愤怒的微火和令人颤抖的痛苦烦恼，一齐搅扰着我，使我崩溃。我感到，如果我成为了他的妻子，这个像深不见阳光的水源一样纯洁的好人会怎样在短时间内就要了我的命，而不必从我的血管中抽掉一滴血，也不会在他水晶般干净的良心上留下一丝罪恶的污点。每当我试图同他和解时，我便尤其感受到这一点。我的同情换不来他的同情。他没有对我们之间的疏远感到痛苦，也不渴望和解。虽然，我的眼泪迅速地、不止一次地滴落并弄湿我们埋头阅读的书页上，而他对此却毫无反应，好像他果真是一副铁石心肠。而同时，对于他的妹妹们，他表现得比以往还要亲昵，就好像仅仅对我冷漠不足以让我相信，我是多么彻底地被他排斥在外，他还要加以对比从而打击我。而我相信他这么做并非凭借暴力，而是基于自己的原则。 All this was torture to me—refined, lingering torture.It kept up a slow fire of indignation and a trembling trouble of grief, which harassed and crushed me altogether.I felt how—if I were his wife, this good man, pure as the deep sunless source, could soon kill me, without drawing from my veins a single drop of blood, or receiving on his own crystal conscience the faintest stain of crime.Especially I felt this when I made any attempt to propitiate him.No ruth met my ruth.HE experienced no suffering from estrangement—no yearning after reconciliation; and though, more than once, my fast falling tears blistered the page over which we both bent, they produced no more effect on him than if his heart had been really a matter of stone or metal.To his sisters, meantime, he was somewhat kinder than usual: as if afraid that mere coldness would not sufficiently convince me how completely I was banished and banned, he added the force of contrast; and this I am sure he did not by force, but on principle.
他离家的前一晚，黄昏时分我碰巧看到他在花园里散步。我看着他，想到这个男人，尽管现在疏远于我，毕竟曾经救过我一命，而且我们还是近亲，我便有些感动，想要做最后一次尝试来挽回我们的友情。我走出门，向他走去，他正倚在小门上，我立刻开门见山地说道： The night before he left home, happening to see him walking in the garden about sunset, and remembering, as I looked at him, that this man, alienated as he now was, had once saved my life, and that we were near relations, I was moved to make a last attempt to regain his friendship.I went out and approached him as he stood leaning over the little gate; I spoke to the point at once.
“圣约翰，我不开心，因为你还在生我的气。让我们做回朋友吧。” “St. John, I am unhappy because you are still angry with me.Let us be friends.”
“但愿我们能做朋友。”他无动于衷地回答，同时继续望着正在升起的月亮，之前我走向他时他就在凝望了。 “I hope we are friends,” was the unmoved reply; while he still watched the rising of the moon, which he had been contemplating as I approached.
“不，圣约翰，我们已经不是像以前那样的朋友了。你知道的。” “No, St. John, we are not friends as we were. You know that.”
“我们难道不是吗？你可说错了。就我来说，我并不希望你倒霉，我希望你一切都好。” “Are we not?That is wrong.For my part, I wish you no ill and all good.”
“我相信你，圣约翰，因为我确信你根本不会希望任何人倒霉。但是，因为我是你的亲人，我可以渴望从你那里得到更多的感情，不仅仅是你广泛给予陌生人的博爱。” “I believe you, St. John; for I am sure you are incapable of wishing any one ill; but, as I am your kinswoman, I should desire somewhat more of affection than that sort of general philanthropy you extend to mere strangers.”
“当然了，”他说，“你的愿望合情合理，你在我眼里可远不止一个陌生人。” “Of course,” he said.“Your wish is reasonable, and I am far from regarding you as a stranger.”
这番话，语调冷酷平静，却足以让人痛苦沮丧。如果我听任自己的骄傲和愤怒，我当时会立刻走开。但是我内心深处还有某种比这些感觉更强烈的东西作用于我。我对我表哥的才华和处事原则深为敬重。他的友谊对我来说十分宝贵，失去它会令我非常痛苦。我不会这么轻易就放弃重新赢得他的友谊的尝试。 This, spoken in a cool, tranquil tone, was mortifying and baffling enough.Had I attended to the suggestions of pride and ire, I should immediately have left him; but something worked within me more strongly than those feelings could.I deeply venerated my cousin’s talent and principle.His friendship was of value to me: to lose it tried me severely.I would not so soon relinquish the attempt to reconquer it.
“我们非得以这种方式分别吗，圣约翰？当你要去印度时，你会就这样离开我，连一句比刚才更友好的话都没有吗？” “Must we part in this way, St. John?And when you go to India, will you leave me so, without a kinder word than you have yet spoken?”
这时他转过头，不再看月亮，而是面对着我。 He now turned quite from the moon and faced me.
“当我去印度的时候，简，当我离开你的时候！你说什么！难道你不去印度了吗？” “When I go to India, Jane, will I leave you!What! do you not go to India?”
“你说除非我嫁给你，否则就不能去。” “You said I could not unless I married you.”
“那你不会嫁给我了！你要坚持那个决定？” “And you will not marry me!You adhere to that resolution?”
读者啊，你是否和我一样，知道那些冷酷的人能在他们冰一样冷的问题中添加怎样的恐怖啊？他们一发怒多么像雪山崩塌啊，他们一不高兴又多么像冰海爆裂啊！ Reader, do you know, as I do, what terror those cold people can put into the ice of their questions?How much of the fall of the avalanche is in their anger? of the breaking up of the frozen sea in their displeasure?
“不。圣约翰，我不会嫁给你的。我坚持自己的决定。” “No. St. John, I will not marry you.I adhere to my resolution.”
冰雪有一些晃动，并向前移动了些许，但还没有崩塌。 The avalanche had shaken and slid a little forward, but it did not yet crash down.
“再问一次，为什么要拒绝？”他问道。 “Once more, why this refusal?” he asked.
“之前，”我答道，“因为你不爱我。可现在，我要说，是因为你几乎恨我了。如果我还要嫁给你，你会要了我的命。你现在就在要我的命。” “Formerly,” I answered, “because you did not love me; now, I reply, because you almost hate me.If I were to marry you, you would kill me.You are killing me now.”
他的嘴唇和脸颊顿时变得苍白，十分苍白。 His lips and cheeks turned white—quite white.
“我会要你的命——我现在正在要你的命？你的这些话真不该说出来，既凶狠又不像女人说的，而且还不真实。它们暴露出一种不幸的心灵状态，应当严加责备，并且似乎不可宽恕。但是宽恕同胞是一个人的职责，即使宽恕七十七次。” “I SHOULD KILL YOU—I AM KILLING YOU?Your words are such as ought not to be used: violent, unfeminine, and untrue.They betray an unfortunate state of mind: they merit severe reproof: they would seem inexcusable, but that it is the duty of man to forgive his fellow even until seventy-and-seven times.”
这下我完了。本来满怀希望想把我以前对他的冒犯从他脑海中抹掉，却没想到在那坚韧的表面上刻下了另一个更深的印象，如同烙印一般。 I had finished the business now.While earnestly wishing to erase from his mind the trace of my former offence, I had stamped on that tenacious surface another and far deeper impression, I had burnt it in.
“现在你的确要恨我了。”我说，“试图跟你和解也没用了，我明白我已经把你变成了永远的敌人。” “Now you will indeed hate me,” I said.“It is useless to attempt to conciliate you: I see I have made an eternal enemy of you.”
这些话真是雪上加霜，更要命的是，它们触及到了事实。他那没有半点血色的嘴唇颤抖着抽搐了一下。我知道我已经激起了冷酷无情的愤怒。我心如刀绞。 A fresh wrong did these words inflict: the worse, because they touched on the truth.That bloodless lip quivered to a temporary spasm.I knew the steely ire I had whetted.I was heart-wrung.
“你彻底误解了我的话，”我边说边抓住了他的手，“我本无意让你伤心或痛苦——真的，我没有这个意思。” “You utterly misinterpret my words,” I said, at once seizing his hand: “I have no intention to grieve or pain you—indeed, I have not.”
他无比苦涩地笑了笑，又无比决绝地把手从我的手中抽了出去。“那么现在你要收回你的承诺，绝对不会去印度了，对吗？”在一阵相当长的沉默之后他说。 Most bitterly he smiled—most decidedly he withdrew his hand from mine.“And now you recall your promise, and will not go to India at all, I presume?” said he, after a considerable pause.
“不，我会去印度，作为你的助手。”我答道。 “Yes, I will, as your assistant,” I answered.
接着又是一阵很长的沉默。在这段时间里，他内心在天性和情理之间如何挣扎，我不得而知。只看到奇特的光芒在他眼里闪烁，怪异的阴影掠过他的面庞。终于他开口了： A very long silence succeeded.What struggle there was in him between Nature and Grace in this interval, I cannot tell: only singular gleams scintillated in his eyes, and strange shadows passed over his face.He spoke at last.
“之前我就向你证明过，像你这般年龄的单身女人，跟我这样的单身汉一起出国是荒唐的。我已把话说到了这个份儿上，原本以为可以使你不再谈及那个计划。但是你还是提了，我很遗憾——为你感到遗憾。” “I before proved to you the absurdity of a single woman of your age proposing to accompany abroad a single man of mine.I proved it to you in such terms as, I should have thought, would have prevented your ever again alluding to the plan.That you have done so, I regret—for your sake.”
我打断了他。任何类似明显责备的话都会立刻给我勇气。“请别忘了人之常情，圣约翰，你几乎是在胡言乱语了。你假装对我所说的话感到震惊。你并不真正感到震惊，因为以你那非同一般的头脑，不可能太愚笨或是太自负，以致于误解了我的意思。我再说一遍：我愿意做你的助理牧师，如果你愿意的话；但是决不会做你的妻子。” I interrupted him.Anything like a tangible reproach gave me courage at once.“Keep to common sense, St. John: you are verging on nonsense.You pretend to be shocked by what I have said.You are not really shocked: for, with your superior mind, you cannot be either so dull or so conceited as to misunderstand my meaning.I say again, I will be your curate, if you like, but never your wife.”
他的脸色再次变得苍白无比，但是像之前一样，他完全控制住了自己的感情。他果断而镇静地答道： Again he turned lividly pale; but, as before, controlled his passion perfectly.He answered emphatically but calmly—
“一个不是我妻子的女助理牧师，绝对不适合我。那么，看来你不能同我一起走了。但是如果你的提议是诚心的，那我去镇上的时候会跟一位已婚的传教士谈谈，他的妻子需要一个助手。你自己的财产够用，用不着教会的救济了。这样你也不用因为背弃诺言，抛弃你所应当加入的团体而感到耻辱了。” “A female curate, who is not my wife, would never suit me.With me, then, it seems, you cannot go: but if you are sincere in your offer, I will, while in town, speak to a married missionary, whose wife needs a coadjutor.Your own fortune will make you independent of the Society’s aid; and thus you may still be spared the dishonour of breaking your promise and deserting the band you engaged to join.”
读者明鉴，我从来没有许下任何正式的承诺，也没有处于任何的约定之中。这种情况下，这话说得太无情，太专横了。我答道： Now I never had, as the reader knows, either given any formal promise or entered into any engagement; and this language was all much too hard and much too despotic for the occasion.I replied—
“在这件事上，没有什么耻辱，没有什么食言，也没有什么丢弃。我没有一丁点去印度的义务，尤其是跟着陌生人。跟着你，我愿意冒很大的风险，因为我钦佩你、信任你，并且作为你的妹妹，我爱你。但我相信，不管何时跟谁去，我在那种气候环境下都不会活太久的。” “There is no dishonour, no breach of promise, no desertion in the case.I am not under the slightest obligation to go to India, especially with strangers.With you I would have ventured much, because I admire, confide in, and, as a sister, I love you; but I am convinced that, go when and with whom I would, I should not live long in that climate.”
“啊！你在为自己害怕。”他撇着嘴说道。 “Ah! you are afraid of yourself,” he said, curling his lip.
“是的。上帝赋予我生命不是让我随意浪费的。可是做你想让我做的事情，我开始觉得几乎等同于自杀。再说了，在我下定决心离开英国之前，我必须弄明白是否留下来比离开这里更有价值。” “I am.God did not give me my life to throw away; and to do as you wish me would, I begin to think, be almost equivalent to committing suicide.Moreover, before I definitively resolve on quitting England, I will know for certain whether I cannot be of greater use by remaining in it than by leaving it.”
“你是什么意思？” “What do you mean?”
“解释也没有用。有件事长久以来让我很痛苦，除非用什么方法消除我的疑虑，否则我哪里也不能去。” “It would be fruitless to attempt to explain; but there is a point on which I have long endured painful doubt, and I can go nowhere till by some means that doubt is removed.”
“我知道你的心向着哪里，又依恋着什么。你所关心的事情既不合乎法律，又不是神圣的。你早就该把它摧毁了，你现在应该为再次提到它而脸红。你是不是在想罗切斯特先生？” “I know where your heart turns and to what it clings.The interest you cherish is lawless and unconsecrated.Long since you ought to have crushed it: now you should blush to allude to it.You think of Mr. Rochester?”
的确如此。我默认了。 It was true.I confessed it by silence.
“你要去找罗切斯特先生吗？” “Are you going to seek Mr. Rochester?”
“我必须查明他现在怎么样了。” “I must find out what is become of him.”
“那好，”他说，“我会记得在祷告的时候，真诚地为你向上帝祈祷，不要让你彻底地成为一个弃儿。我原以为我已经认准你是上帝的选民了。但是上帝的眼光跟凡人的不一样，他的才算数。” “It remains for me, then,” he said, “to remember you in my prayers, and to entreat God for you, in all earnestness, that you may not indeed become a castaway.I had thought I recognised in you one of the chosen.But God sees not as man sees: HIS will be done—”
他打开门，走了出去，东拐西拐地走下了山谷。很快就看不见他了。 He opened the gate, passed through it, and strayed away down the glen.He was soon out of sight.
我再回到客厅时，发现黛安娜站在窗边，看起来若有所思的样子。黛安娜比我高许多，她把手放在我肩上，俯下身仔细端详我的脸。 On re-entering the parlour, I found Diana standing at the window, looking very thoughtful.Diana was a great deal taller than I: she put her hand on my shoulder, and, stooping, examined my face.
“简，”她说，“你最近总是焦躁不安，脸色苍白。我确信一定是有什么事。告诉我你和圣约翰之间有什么麻烦事吧。这半个小时我一直从窗户里观察你们，你一定要原谅我这样暗中监视，但是很长时间以来我一直都不知道到底是怎么回事。圣约翰是个怪人——” “Jane,” she said, “you are always agitated and pale now.I am sure there is something the matter.Tell me what business St. John and you have on hands.I have watched you this half hour from the window; you must forgive my being such a spy, but for a long time I have fancied I hardly know what.St. John is a strange being—”
她突然停下，我并没有开口，很快她又接着说道： She paused—I did not speak: soon she resumed—
“我这个哥哥对你的看法非同一般，我确信，他早就待你不同旁人，特别关注和关心你，他从来没有对别人这样过。他的目的何在？我希望他爱上了你——他爱你吗，简？” “That brother of mine cherishes peculiar views of some sort respecting you, I am sure: he has long distinguished you by a notice and interest he never showed to any one else—to what end?I wish he loved you—does he, Jane?”
我把她冰冷的手放到我发热的额头上，说：“不，黛，一点也不。” I put her cool hand to my hot forehead; “No, Die, not one whit.”
“那为什么他的眼睛总是盯着你，老是让你单独和他在一起，还让你一直都陪在他身边？玛丽和我都推断他希望你嫁给他。” “Then why does he follow you so with his eyes, and get you so frequently alone with him, and keep you so continually at his side?Mary and I had both concluded he wished you to marry him.”
“他的确这样——他请求我做他的妻子。” “He does—he has asked me to be his wife.”
黛安娜拍起手来。“这正是我们所盼望的，也是我们已料到的！那你会嫁给他的，简，不是吗？那样他就会留在英国了。” Diana clapped her hands.“That is just what we hoped and thought!And you will marry him, Jane, won’t you?And then he will stay in England.”
“才不是呢，黛安娜。他向我求婚的目的只有一个，就是得到一个合适的伙伴，跟他一起去印度受苦。” “Far from that, Diana; his sole idea in proposing to me is to procure a fitting fellow-labourer in his Indian toils.”
“什么！他想让你去印度？” “What! He wishes you to go to India?”
“是的。” “Yes.”
“简直疯了！”她喊道，“在那儿你活不到三个月，我确定。你绝对不能走，你还没答应他吧，是吗，简？” “Madness!” she exclaimed.“You would not live three months there, I am certain.You never shall go: you have not consented, have you, Jane?”
“我已经拒绝嫁给他了。” “I have refused to marry him—”
“结果就惹他不高兴了？”她联想到。 “And have consequently displeased him?” she suggested.
“很不高兴。恐怕他永远也不会原谅我了，但我还是提出要作为他的妹妹跟他同去。” “Deeply: he will never forgive me, I fear: yet I offered to accompany him as his sister.”
“这么做真是傻得出奇，简。想想你要从事的工作——没完没了的劳累，甚至身体强壮的人也会被累死，何况你这么瘦弱。圣约翰，你知道他这个人，会极力劝说你去做不可能的事。和他在一起，就是大热天里也不得休息片刻；而且遗憾的是，我注意到，无论他要求什么，你都会强迫自己去做。我感到吃惊的是，你竟然有勇气拒绝他的求婚。那么你不爱他，简？” “It was frantic folly to do so, Jane.Think of the task you undertook—one of incessant fatigue, where fatigue kills even the strong, and you are weak.St. John—you know him—would urge you to impossibilities: with him there would be no permission to rest during the hot hours; and unfortunately, I have noticed, whatever he exacts, you force yourself to perform.I am astonished you found courage to refuse his hand.You do not love him then, Jane?”
“不是把他当作丈夫来爱。” “Not as a husband.”
“不过他是个英俊的小伙子。” “Yet he is a handsome fellow.”
“而我却是如此平庸，你瞧，黛。我们绝对不般配。” “And I am so plain, you see, Die.We should never suit.”
“平庸！你？一点也不。你非常漂亮，也非常善良，不能去加尔各答被活活烤死。”她再次真诚地恳求我放弃和她哥哥同去的念头。 “Plain! You?Not at all.You are much too pretty, as well as too good, to be grilled alive in Calcutta.”And again she earnestly conjured me to give up all thoughts of going out with her brother.
“我确实必须去，”我说，“因为刚才我又一次提出要当他的副牧师，他对我的不恭表示感到震惊。他似乎认为我提出不结婚陪而他去有失体统，就好像我一开始就不是希望把他当作哥哥，而且一直是这么看待他似的。” “I must indeed,” I said; “for when just now I repeated the offer of serving him for a deacon, he expressed himself shocked at my want of decency.He seemed to think I had committed an impropriety in proposing to accompany him unmarried: as if I had not from the first hoped to find in him a brother, and habitually regarded him as such.”
“那你凭什么说他不爱你呢，简？” “What makes you say he does not love you, Jane?”
“你应该听听他本人对这件事的说法。他一而再地解释他不是因为自己，而是为了自己的圣职才想结婚的。他告诉过我，我生来是为了劳作，不是为了爱情。这倒是真的，毫无疑问。但是，在我看来，如果说我生来不是为了爱情，由此可以说我也不是生来为了结婚。黛，一生都跟这样一个男人捆在一起，而他只把你看作一件有用的工具，这岂不太怪异了吗？” “You should hear himself on the subject.He has again and again explained that it is not himself, but his office he wishes to mate.He has told me I am formed for labour—not for love: which is true, no doubt.But, in my opinion, if I am not formed for love, it follows that I am not formed for marriage.Would it not be strange, Die, to be chained for life to a man who regarded one but as a useful tool?”
“难以容忍——不近情理——不可能的事！” “Insupportable—unnatural—out of the question!”
“还有，”我继续说道，“虽然我现在对他只有兄妹之情，然而若是被迫做了他的妻子，我能想象得出，自己有可能不可避免地对他怀有一种奇怪又令人痛苦的爱。因为他这么有才华，他的表情、举止和言谈中常常带有一种英雄气概。那样的话，我的命运会悲惨得难以言状。他不会想要我爱他。而且如果我表露感情，他会让我感到这是多余的，他不需要，我也不应该这样。我知道他会这样的。” “And then,” I continued, “though I have only sisterly affection for him now, yet, if forced to be his wife, I can imagine the possibility of conceiving an inevitable, strange, torturing kind of love for him, because he is so talented; and there is often a certain heroic grandeur in his look, manner, and conversation.In that case, my lot would become unspeakably wretched.He would not want me to love him; and if I showed the feeling, he would make me sensible that it was a superfluity, unrequired by him, unbecoming in me.I know he would.”
“不过圣约翰是个好人。”黛安娜说。 “And yet St. John is a good man,” said Diana.
“他是个好人，也很伟大。但可惜的是，他在追求自己伟大目标的时候，忘记了小人物的感情和需求。因此，微不足道的人们还是最好离他远一点，以免在他前进的时候被他踏在脚下。他来了！我得走了，黛安娜。”看到他走进花园，我赶紧上楼去了。 “He is a good and a great man; but he forgets, pitilessly, the feelings and claims of little people, in pursuing his own large views.It is better, therefore, for the insignificant to keep out of his way, lest, in his progress, he should trample them down.Here he comes!I will leave you, Diana.”And I hastened upstairs as I saw him entering the garden.
但是晚饭时候我还是不得不再次见到他。吃饭时候，他看上去就像平常一样泰然自若。我原以为他不会跟我说话，并且确信他已经放弃去实现他的结婚计划了；可接下来的事表明在这两点上我都想错了。他同我说话的态度简直和他通常对我的态度一模一样，或者说和他最近通常对我的态度一样，礼貌中无不透着谨慎。无疑，他已求助圣灵，来抑制我在他心里激起的怒火，并且现在相信自己已经再次原谅我了。 But I was forced to meet him again at supper.During that meal he appeared just as composed as usual.I had thought he would hardly speak to me, and I was certain he had given up the pursuit of his matrimonial scheme: the sequel showed I was mistaken on both points.He addressed me precisely in his ordinary manner, or what had, of late, been his ordinary manner—one scrupulously polite.No doubt he had invoked the help of the Holy Spirit to subdue the anger I had roused in him, and now believed he had forgiven me once more.
晚上祷告前的诵读，他选择了《启示录》的第二十一章。 For the evening reading before prayers, he selected the twenty-first chapter of Revelation.
聆听《圣经》中的语句从他嘴里说出来，一直是件令人愉快的事。当他宣读上帝的神谕时，他的声音从来没有这么动听、饱满，他的举止也从未如此高贵、纯朴，令人印象深刻。今晚，他的语调更加庄严，他的举止也更慑人心魄。他被家人围坐在中间（五月的月光透过没有拉上窗帘的窗户照进屋里，使得桌上燃着的蜡烛都显得多余了）。他坐在那里，低头看着伟大而古老的《圣经》，描述着书里所写的新天堂和新世界的画面——告诉我们上帝会如何来到人间与凡人同住，如何擦去人们的眼泪，承诺不会再有死亡，不会再有悲伤和哭泣，也不会再有任何痛苦，因为这些东西已不复存在了。 It was at all times pleasant to listen while from his lips fell the words of the Bible: never did his fine voice sound at once so sweet and full—never did his manner become so impressive in its noble simplicity, as when he delivered the oracles of God:and tonight that voice took a more solemn tone—that manner a more thrilling meaning—as he sat in the midst of his household circle (the May moon shining in through the uncurtained window, and rendering almost unnecessary the light of the candle on the table):as he sat there, bending over the great old Bible, and described from its page the vision of the new heaven and the new earth—told how God would come to dwell with men, how He would wipe away all tears from their eyes, and promised that there should be no more death, neither sorrow nor crying, nor any more pain, because the former things were passed away.
接下来的话从他嘴里说出来时，我感到一阵莫名的激动，尤其是从他声音难以描述的微妙变化中，我感觉到他在说这番话时，眼睛转向了我。 The succeeding words thrilled me strangely as he spoke them: especially as I felt, by the slight, indescribable alteration in sound, that in uttering them, his eye had turned on me.
“得胜的，必承受这些为业。我要做他的神，他要做我的儿子。但是，”这段读得很慢，字字清楚，“唯有胆怯的、不信的……他们的份，就在烧着硫磺的火湖里，这是第二次的死亡。” “He that overcometh shall inherit all things; and I will be his God, and he shall be my son.But,” was slowly, distinctly read, “the fearful, the unbelieving, &c., shall have their part in the lake which burneth with fire and brimstone, which is the second death.”
自此，我知道圣约翰担心我会有什么样的命运了。 Henceforward, I knew what fate St. John feared for me.
他朗读那一章最后几句辉煌的诗句时，露出一种平静而克制的胜利的喜悦，夹杂着诚挚的渴望。这位朗读者相信他自己的名字已经被写入羔羊生命册中，并盼望着准许他入城的那一时刻。人间的君主们把他们的辉煌和荣誉献给了那座城市，那里也无需太阳或月亮的照耀，因为上帝的光辉照亮了它，羔羊就是那城里的灯。 A calm, subdued triumph, blent with a longing earnestness, marked his enunciation of the last glorious verses of that chapter.The reader believed his name was already written in the Lamb’s book of life, and he yearned after the hour which should admit him to the city to which the kings of the earth bring their glory and honour; which has no need of sun or moon to shine in it, because the glory of God lightens it, and the Lamb is the light thereof.
这章之后的祷告中，他全身心地投入，唤醒了所有严肃的热情，他热忱地向上帝祷告，无比虔诚，并决心要获胜。他恳求上帝给弱者以力量，为脱离了羊群的羔羊指引方向，让那些被世俗和肉欲所诱惑而偏离正道的人幡然悔悟。他请求，他劝说，他要求上帝给予恩典，让他们免受火烙之刑。真诚总是极为庄严。刚开始听他祷告时，我为之惊叹。然后，随着祷告继续下去并且越来越大声，我为之触动，并最终感到敬畏。他也非常真切地感受到了自己目的的伟大和崇高，其他聆听他祈祷的人们也不能不产生同样的感受。 In the prayer following the chapter, all his energy gathered—all his stern zeal woke: he was in deep earnest, wrestling with God, and resolved on a conquest.He supplicated strength for the weak hearted; guidance for wanderers from the fold: a return, even at the eleventh hour, for those whom the temptations of the world and the flesh were luring from the narrow path.He asked, he urged, he claimed the boon of a brand snatched from the burning.Earnestness is ever deeply solemn: first, as I listened to that prayer, I wondered at his; then, when it continued and rose, I was touched by it, and at last awed.He felt the greatness and goodness of his purpose so sincerely: others who heard him plead for it, could not but feel it too.
祷告结束后，我们跟他告别，他要在第二天大清早出发。黛安娜和玛丽亲吻他后，就离开了房间——我想她们是听从了他悄声的暗示。我伸出手，祝他旅途愉快。 The prayer over, we took leave of him: he was to go at a very early hour in the morning.Diana and Mary having kissed him, left the room—in compliance, I think, with a whispered hint from him: I tendered my hand, and wished him a pleasant journey.
“谢谢你，简。我说过，我会在两周后从剑桥回来，那么这段时间，仍要留给你好好考虑。如果我听从自尊，就不会再向你提起结婚的事，但是我听从的是我的职责，始终坚持着我的首要目标——为上帝的荣耀去做一切。我的主长期受苦受难，我也得这样。我不能任由你坠入地狱，遭受上天的惩罚。忏悔吧，下决心吧，趁现在还有时间。记住，我们受到吩咐，要趁白天工作，我们还得到警告‘夜幕降临，就谁也不能工作了’。别忘了今世享尽荣华富贵的财主们的命运。上帝给予你力量去选择好的福份，这样的福份不会被人夺走的！” “Thank you, Jane.As I said, I shall return from Cambridge in a fortnight: that space, then, is yet left you for reflection.If I listened to human pride, I should say no more to you of marriage with me; but I listen to my duty, and keep steadily in view my first aim—to do all things to the glory of God.My Master was long-suffering: so will I be.I cannot give you up to perdition as a vessel of wrath: repent—resolve, while there is yet time.Remember, we are bid to work while it is day—warned that ‘the night cometh when no man shall work.’Remember the fate of Dives, who had his good things in this life.God give you strength to choose that better part which shall not be taken from you!”
他说最后几个字时，把手放在了我的头上。他的话说得真诚而委婉。他的表情确实不像是一个爱人在望着自己的情人，而像是一个牧师在呼唤迷途的羔羊——说得更贴切一点，像一位守护天使注视着他所监管的灵魂。一切有才能的人，不管他们有没有感情，也不管他们是狂热者、追求者，还是暴君，只要他们真诚，在他们征服和统治期间，都有令人崇敬的时刻。我崇敬圣约翰，这种感情无比强烈，以至于它的冲击力一下子把我推到了我一直以来都在回避的那一点上。我很想停止与他抗争，随着他意志的洪流急速而下，流入他生命的港湾，并在那里失去自我。我被他困住了，几乎就像当初被另一个人以另一种不同的方式困住一样。两次我都像个傻瓜一样。那次如果屈服，则会犯原则上的错误；这次如果屈服，就会犯判断上的错误。此时此刻，通过时间这个无声的媒介再去看那场危机，我才认识到是这样的，而当初我并没有意识到自己的愚蠢。 He laid his hand on my head as he uttered the last words.He had spoken earnestly, mildly: his look was not, indeed, that of a lover beholding his mistress, but it was that of a pastor recalling his wandering sheep—or better, of a guardian angel watching the soul for which he is responsible.All men of talent, whether they be men of feeling or not; whether they be zealots, or aspirants, or despots—provided only they be sincere—have their sublime moments, when they subdue and rule.I felt veneration for St. John—veneration so strong that its impetus thrust me at once to the point I had so long shunned.I was tempted to cease struggling with him—to rush down the torrent of his will into the gulf of his existence, and there lose my own.I was almost as hard beset by him now as I had been once before, in a different way, by another.I was a fool both times.To have yielded then would have been an error of principle; to have yielded now would have been an error of judgment.So I think at this hour, when I look back to the crisis through the quiet medium of time: I was unconscious of folly at the instant.
在圣师的触摸下，我一动不动地站着。我忘记了拒绝，克服了恐惧，放弃了抗争。那件不可能的事，也就是我和圣约翰结婚，正在迅速地变得可能。一切都在倏忽之间彻底地改变。宗教在召唤——天使在招手——上帝在指示——生命像书卷一样被卷起——死亡之门打开了，展示出彼岸的永恒。仿佛为了那里的安宁和欢乐，这里的一切都会在瞬间牺牲。昏暗的房间里满是幻象。 I stood motionless under my hierophant’s touch.My refusals were forgotten—my fears overcome—my wrestlings paralysed.The Impossible—I.E., my marriage with St. John—was fast becoming the Possible.All was changing utterly with a sudden sweep.Religion called—Angels beckoned—God commanded—life rolled together like a scroll—death’s gates opening, showed eternity beyond: it seemed, that for safety and bliss there, all here might be sacrificed in a second.The dim room was full of visions.
“你现在可以决定吗？”这个传教士问道。问话的语气很温柔，他还同样温柔地把我拉向他。噢，这种温柔啊！它比强迫还要有力得多！我可以抵御圣约翰的怒火，但在他的温柔面前，我却变得像芦苇一样柔软、顺从了。然而我一直都知道，即使现在屈服了，总有一天他也免不了要让我对以前的反抗懊悔。他的本性不会因为一个小时庄严的祷告而改变，只不过是升华了。 “Could you decide now?” asked the missionary.The inquiry was put in gentle tones: he drew me to him as gently.Oh, that gentleness! how far more potent is it than force!I could resist St. John’s wrath: I grew pliant as a reed under his kindness.Yet I knew all the time, if I yielded now, I should not the less be made to repent, some day, of my former rebellion.His nature was not changed by one hour of solemn prayer: it was only elevated.
“如果我有把握，我就能做决定，”我回答道，“如果能使我相信上帝的旨意就是我应该嫁给你，那么我此时此地就可以宣誓嫁给你，不管以后会发生什么！” “I could decide if I were but certain,” I answered: “were I but convinced that it is God’s will I should marry you, I could vow to marry you here and now—come afterwards what would!”
“上帝听到了我的祷告！”圣约翰突然喊道。他的手更有力地按着我的头部，仿佛他把我要去了。他用胳膊搂着我，几乎像是他爱我（我说“几乎”，我知道其中的不同，因为我曾经有过被爱的感觉。但是，和他一样，我现在已经把爱情置之度外，考虑的只有职责）。我在和心中重重乌云遮挡的昏暗幻象做斗争。我真诚地、深深地、热切地渴望去做正确的事，仅此而已。“指引我，指引我到正确的路吧！”我恳求上天。我比以往任何时候都要激动。之后发生的事是否是激动引起的后果，读者自会判断。 “My I prayers are heard!” ejaculated St. John.He pressed his hand firmer on my head, as if he claimed me: he surrounded me with his arm, ALMOST as if he loved me (I say ALMOST—I knew the difference—for I had felt what it was to be loved; but, like him, I had now put love out of the question, and thought only of duty).I contended with my inward dimness of vision, before which clouds yet rolled.I sincerely, deeply, fervently longed to do what was right; and only that.“Show me, show me the path!”I entreated of Heaven.I was excited more than I had ever been; and whether what followed was the effect of excitement the reader shall judge.
整座房子寂静无声，因为我相信除了我和圣约翰，其他所有的人都已歇息了。唯有的一根蜡烛也即将燃尽，房间里洒满了月光。我的心跳快速而激烈，我能听到它在怦怦跳动。突然，一种难以言状的感觉令我的心为之震颤，并立刻传遍了我的大脑和四肢，我的心也随即停止了跳动。这感觉不像电击，但是它就像电击一样尖锐、奇怪，一样令人心惊肉跳。它作用于我的感官，仿佛目前为止它们最活跃的状态也不过是麻木，而此刻它们受到召唤，被迫从这种状态中醒过来。它们满怀期待地苏醒过来，眼睛和耳朵在等待着，而肌肉在骨头上颤抖着。 All the house was still; for I believe all, except St. John and myself, were now retired to rest.The one candle was dying out: the room was full of moonlight.My heart beat fast and thick: I heard its throb.Suddenly it stood still to an inexpressible feeling that thrilled it through, and passed at once to my head and extremities.The feeling was not like an electric shock, but it was quite as sharp, as strange, as startling: it acted on my senses as if their utmost activity hitherto had been but torpor, from which they were now summoned and forced to wake.They rose expectant: eye and ear waited while the flesh quivered on my bones.
“你听到了什么？你看到了什么？”圣约翰问道。我什么也没看到，但是却听到不知何处有一个声音在叫喊： “What have you heard?What do you see?” asked John.I saw nothing, but I heard a voice somewhere cry—
“简！简！简！”——仅此而已。 “Jane!Jane! Jane!”—nothing more.
“哦，上帝啊！那是什么声音？”我倒抽了一口气。 “O God! what is it?” I gasped.
我应该说：“那声音从哪儿来的？”因为它不像是在屋里，不在这座房子里，也不在花园里；它不是来自空中，不是出自地下，也不是来自头顶上。我听到了那声音。但它从哪儿来，或缘何而来，永远也不可能知道！而且那是人的声音——一个熟悉、喜爱、牢牢记着的声音——是爱德华·费尔法克斯·罗切斯特的声音；那声音痛苦悲哀，狂野怪异，非常急切。 I might have said, “Where is it?” for it did not seem in the room—nor in the house—nor in the garden; it did not come out of the air—nor from under the earth—nor from overhead.I had heard it—where, or whence, for ever impossible to know!And it was the voice of a human being—a known, loved, well-remembered voice—that of Edward Fairfax Rochester; and it spoke in pain and woe, wildly, eerily, urgently.
“我来了！”我喊道，“等着我！噢，我这就来！”我飞快地跑到门边，向走廊里望去，那里漆黑一片。我跑到花园，那里空无一物。 “I am coming!” I cried.“Wait for me!Oh, I will come!”I flew to the door and looked into the passage: it was dark.I ran out into the garden: it was void.
“你在哪儿？”我叫道。 “Where are you?” I exclaimed.
沼泽谷后边的群山送来了依稀可辨的回音——“你在哪儿？”我聆听着。风在冷杉树林里低声叹息，一切只有荒原的孤寂和午夜的肃静。 The hills beyond Marsh Glen sent the answer faintly back—“Where are you?” I listened.The wind sighed low in the firs: all was moorland loneliness and midnight hush.
“去你的迷信！”当那个黑黢黢的幽灵在门口深色的紫杉旁边浮现时，我得出了这个结论,“这不是你欺骗的手段，也不是你的巫术，这是大自然的作品。她被惊动了，然后她做出了最大的努力——虽然不算是奇迹。” “Down superstition!”I commented, as that spectre rose up black by the black yew at the gate.“This is not thy deception, nor thy witchcraft: it is the work of nature.She was roused, and did—no miracle—but her best.”
我挣脱了跟着我出来并想制止我的圣约翰。现在该我处于优势地位了。我的力量在起作用，在发挥效力。我告诉他不要提问，也不要说话，我要求他走开，我必须并且愿意一个人待着。他立刻照办了。只要力量掌握得当，命令总会得到服从。我上楼回到自己的房间，锁上门，双膝跪地，用我自己的方式进行祈祷——不同于圣约翰的祈祷方式，但是自有它的效果。我仿佛已经潜进了一个强大的神灵，我的灵魂感激地冲出去拜倒在他的脚下。我从感恩中站起身来，下定决心，然后躺下来，毫无畏惧并受到了启发。我只盼着白天的到来。 I broke from St. John, who had followed, and would have detained me.It was MY time to assume ascendency.MY powers were in play and in force.I told him to forbear question or remark; I desired him to leave me: I must and would be alone.He obeyed at once.Where there is energy to command well enough, obedience never fails.I mounted to my chamber; locked myself in; fell on my knees; and prayed in my way—a different way to St. John’s, but effective in its own fashion.I seemed to penetrate very near a Mighty Spirit; and my soul rushed out in gratitude at His feet.I rose from the thanksgiving—took a resolve—and lay down, unscared, enlightened—eager but for the daylight.
第三十六章 CHAPTER XXXVI
天亮了。黎明时分我便起床了。我忙碌了一两个小时，收拾屋子里、抽屉里和衣柜里的东西，把它们收拾妥当，以便我短期外出。同时，我听到圣约翰走出了自己的房间。他在我房间的门口停下，我怕他会敲门。但他没有敲，只是从门下的缝隙中塞进来一张小纸条。我拿起纸条。上面写着： The daylight came.I rose at dawn.I busied myself for an hour or two with arranging my things in my chamber, drawers, and wardrobe, in the order wherein I should wish to leave them during a brief absence.Meantime, I heard St. John quit his room.He stopped at my door: I feared he would knock—no, but a slip of paper was passed under the door.I took it up.It bore these words—
“昨晚你离开得太突然了。如果你再多停留一会儿，你也许已经把手放在基督的十字架和天使的花冠上了。两周后的这个时候我回来时，我希望你已做出了明确的决定。与此同时，你要小心并祈祷自己不要被诱惑。我相信你的心灵是乐意的，但是我看到，你的肉体还很软弱。我会时时为你祈祷。——你的圣约翰。” “You left me too suddenly last night.Had you stayed but a little longer, you would have laid your hand on the Christian’s cross and the angel’s crown.I shall expect your clear decision when I return this day fortnight.Meantime, watch and pray that you enter not into temptation: the spirit, I trust, is willing, but the flesh, I see, is weak.I shall pray for you hourly. Yours, ST. JOHN.”
“我的心灵，”我心里回答道，“愿意去做正确的事；我的肉体，我希望它足够强大，可以完成上天的意志，只要我可以清楚地领会到那意志。无论如何，我的肉体坚强得足以使我能够去寻找、探求、摸索出路，冲出疑云，找到一片确定无疑的天空。” “My spirit,” I answered mentally, “is willing to do what is right; and my flesh, I hope, is strong enough to accomplish the will of Heaven, when once that will is distinctly known to me.At any rate, it shall be strong enough to search—inquire—to grope an outlet from this cloud of doubt, and find the open day of certainty.”
那天是六月一日，但是早晨的天气却很阴冷，雨点急速地打在我的窗子上。我听到前门打开了，圣约翰走了出去。透过窗户，我看到他穿过了花园。他走在雾气蒙蒙的荒原小路上，往惠特克劳斯的方向走去，他要在那儿坐马车。 It was the first of June; yet the morning was overcast and chilly: rain beat fast on my casement.I heard the front-door open, and St. John pass out.Looking through the window, I saw him traverse the garden.He took the way over the misty moors in the direction of Whitcross—there he would meet the coach.
“几个小时以后，我就会继你之后踏上那条路，表哥，”我心想，“我也会在惠特克劳斯坐上马车。在我永远离开英国之前，我也有一些人要去拜访，要去问候。” “In a few more hours I shall succeed you in that track, cousin,” thought I: “I too have a coach to meet at Whitcross.I too have some to see and ask after in England, before I depart for ever.”
离早饭时间还有两个小时。这两个小时，我在房间里轻轻踱步，寻思着促成我眼前计划的那件怪事。我回忆起自己内心所经历的感受，因为我能回想起它那难以描述的奇异之处。我想起了听到的那个声音，我再一次疑惑它缘何而来，然而还是像以前一样无解。那个声音彷佛来自我自己，而非来自外界。我问道，难道它仅仅是由于紧张而产生的幻觉？我无法想象，也无法相信。它更像是神灵的启示。 It wanted yet two hours of breakfast-time.I filled the interval in walking softly about my room, and pondering the visitation which had given my plans their present bent.I recalled that inward sensation I had experienced: for I could recall it, with all its unspeakable strangeness.I recalled the voice I had heard; again I questioned whence it came, as vainly as before: it seemed in ME—not in the external world.I asked was it a mere nervous impression—a delusion?I could not conceive or believe: it was more like an inspiration.
情感上的奇妙震撼如地震般袭来，震撼着保罗和赛拉斯所在牢狱的地基。它打开了灵魂的牢门，松开了灵魂的锁链；灵魂被它从沉睡中唤醒，猛地起身，颤抖着，聆听着，惊骇着。喊叫声接二连三地震撼着我受惊的耳朵，穿透了我颤抖的心脏，席卷了我的灵魂。灵魂既不惧怕，也未受到惊吓，反而欢欣鼓舞，好像是为了摆脱笨重肉体的负累，成功地做出一次努力而非常高兴。 The wondrous shock of feeling had come like the earthquake which shook the foundations of Paul and Silas’s prison; it had opened the doors of the soul’s cell and loosed its bands—it had wakened it out of its sleep, whence it sprang trembling, listening, aghast;then vibrated thrice a cry on my startled ear, and in my quaking heart and through my spirit, which neither feared nor shook, but exulted as if in joy over the success of one effort it had been privileged to make, independent of the cumbrous body.
“过不了多少天，”我停止沉思后说，“我就会知道昨晚呼唤我的那个人的情况了。信件已被证明是没用的，我将亲自探访。” “Ere many days,” I said, as I terminated my musings, “I will know something of him whose voice seemed last night to summon me.Letters have proved of no avail—personal inquiry shall replace them.”
早饭时候我向黛安娜和玛丽宣布，我要出行，至少有四天不在家。 At breakfast I announced to Diana and Mary that I was going a journey, and should be absent at least four days.
“一个人吗，简？”她们问道。 “Alone, Jane?” they asked.
“是的。这次出行是为了探望或打听一个朋友，我为他担心很长时日了。” “Yes; it was to see or hear news of a friend about whom I had for some time been uneasy.”
她们本来可能要说，她们以为除了她们以外，我没有任何朋友。我肯定她们是这样想的，而且我确实也经常这样说。但是，因为她们天生敏感、体贴，所以并未发表什么意见，只有黛安娜问我是否确定自己的身体能承受这次出行。她注意到我的脸色非常苍白。我回答说，我没有感到不适，只是心里有些焦虑，希望不久就能得到缓解。 They might have said, as I have no doubt they thought, that they had believed me to be without any friends save them: for, indeed, I had often said so; but, with their true natural delicacy, they abstained from comment, except that Diana asked me if I was sure I was well enough to travel.I looked very pale, she observed.I replied, that nothing ailed me save anxiety of mind, which I hoped soon to alleviate.
接下来的安排就很容易了，因为我不必再为寻根问底、妄自猜测而烦恼。我向她们解释说我现在还不能将我的计划和盘托出，她们非常善解人意地默许了，并保持了沉默，给了我在类似的情况下我也会给予她们的自由行动权。 It was easy to make my further arrangements; for I was troubled with no inquiries—no surmises.Having once explained to them that I could not now be explicit about my plans, they kindly and wisely acquiesced in the silence with which I pursued them, according to me the privilege of free action I should under similar circumstances have accorded them.
下午三点，我离开了荒原小屋。刚过四点，我就站在了惠特克劳斯的路牌下面，等待着将要载我去遥远的桑菲尔德的马车。在偏僻小路和荒芜山脉的寂静中，我听到老远处传来了马车驶近的声音。一年前的一个夏日的傍晚，就在这里，我就是从这辆马车上下来——当时我是多么凄凉，多么无望，又是多么茫然！我招了招手，马车停了下来。我上了车，现在我不必为了车费而花掉我的全部盘缠。再一次踏上去往桑菲尔德的路，我感到自己像一只飞返家园的信鸽。 I left Moor House at three o’clock p.m., and soon after four I stood at the foot of the signpost of Whitcross, waiting the arrival of the coach which was to take me to distant Thornfield.Amidst the silence of those solitary roads and desert hills, I heard it approach from a great distance.It was the same vehicle whence, a year ago, I had alighted one summer evening on this very spot—how desolate, and hopeless, and objectless!It stopped as I beckoned.I entered—not now obliged to part with my whole fortune as the price of its accommodation.Once more on the road to Thornfield, I felt like the messenger-pigeon flying home.
这次的行程用了三十六个小时。 It was a journey of six-and-thirty hours.
我周二下午从惠特克劳斯出发，周四一大早，马车停在路边一家旅馆，给马饮水。这家旅馆周围有翠绿的树篱、大片的田地和低矮的山地牧场（和中北部莫顿严峻的原相比，这里的地貌多么柔和，颜色多么青翠！），这些景色映入眼底，犹如一张似曾相识的面庞。是的，我熟悉这片风景的特点，我确定我已经接近目的地了。 I had set out from Whitcross on a Tuesday afternoon, and early on the succeeding Thursday morning the coach stopped to water the horses at a wayside inn,situated in the midst of scenery whose green hedges and large fields and low pastoral hills (how mild of feature and verdant of hue compared with the stern North-Midland moors of Morton!) met my eye like the lineaments of a once familiar face.Yes, I knew the character of this landscape: I was sure we were near my bourne.
“桑菲尔德府离这儿还有多远？”我问旅馆的马夫。 “How far is Thornfield Hall from here?” I asked of the ostler.
“只有两英里了，小姐，穿过那片田地就到了。” “Just two miles, ma’am, across the fields.”
“我的旅行结束了。”我心里想。下了马车，我把所带的一只箱子交给马夫保管，之后我再回来取。我付了车钱，车夫十分满意，便上路了。渐渐亮起的曙光照在旅馆的招牌上，我看到了几个镀金的字：“罗切斯特纹章”。我的心怦怦直跳，我已经踏上了主人的地界。然而心头一沉，想到： “My journey is closed,” I thought to myself.I got out of the coach, gave a box I had into the ostler’s charge, to be kept till I called for it; paid my fare; satisfied the coachman, and was going: the brightening day gleamed on the sign of the inn, and I read in gilt letters, “The Rochester Arms.”My heart leapt up: I was already on my master’s very lands.It fell again: the thought struck it:—
“你的主人有可能目前在英吉利海峡彼岸。再说，即使他就在你正匆匆赶往的桑菲尔德，他身边又有谁在陪伴着呢？他那疯了的妻子。你和他没有任何关系，你不敢跟他说话，不敢去找他。你徒劳一场，还是别再往前走了。”心里的那个监视者劝道，“向旅馆里的人打听消息吧，他们会告诉你所有你想知道的，他们很快就能解答你的疑惑。到那个男人跟前去，问问他罗切斯特先生是否在家。” “Your master himself may be beyond the British Channel, for aught you know: and then, if he is at Thornfield Hall, towards which you hasten, who besides him is there?His lunatic wife: and you have nothing to do with him: you dare not speak to him or seek his presence.You have lost your labour—you had better go no farther,” urged the monitor.“Ask information of the people at the inn; they can give you all you seek: they can solve your doubts at once.Go up to that man, and inquire if Mr. Rochester be at home.”
这个建议很合理，但是我无法强迫自己照办。我特别害怕听到的答案会令我彻底绝望崩溃。保留疑惑也就是保留希望。我还可以再次看看在希望之星照耀下的那座府邸。面前就是那阶梯——那片田野。那天早晨，我从桑菲尔德府逃出来，什么也看不到，什么也听不到，不顾一切，心烦意乱，复仇的怒火紧跟着我，折磨着我，我当时急匆匆地穿过这片田野。我还不知道决定走哪条路时，我已经置身于田野中了。我走得多快啊！时不时地，我还会拼命地跑。我多盼望一眼就能看到那片熟悉的树林啊！我怀着怎样的感情与每一棵我熟悉的树打招呼，还有树与树之间熟悉的草地和小山啊！ The suggestion was sensible, and yet I could not force myself to act on it.I so dreaded a reply that would crush me with despair.To prolong doubt was to prolong hope.I might yet once more see the Hall under the ray of her star.There was the stile before me—the very fields through which I had hurried, blind, deaf, distracted with a revengeful fury tracking and scourging me, on the morning I fled from Thornfield: ere I well knew what course I had resolved to take, I was in the midst of them.How fast I walked!How I ran sometimes!How I looked forward to catch the first view of the well-known woods!With what feelings I welcomed single trees I knew, and familiar glimpses of meadow and hill between them!
终于，树林出现了。白嘴鸦黑压压地聚成一片，呱地一声打破了早晨的宁静。一阵奇怪的愉悦激励着我急忙前行。又穿过一片田野，走过一条穿行于其间的小路，就看到了院墙，那是后院；正宅本身和白嘴鸦的巢穴依旧看不到。“我第一眼要看到宅子的正面，”我打定主意，“它优雅醒目的墙垛会立刻令我眼前一亮，我可以辨认出主人房间的那扇窗。也许他正站在窗前——他总是起得很早，也许他现在就在果园里散步，又或许他正走在前面的人行道上。我要是能看看他多好啊！一会儿就好！当然了，那样的话，我该不会发了疯似的奔向他吧？我不知道——我不确定。如果我真那样做了——那又怎样？上帝保佑！那又会怎样呢？我再一次感受他的目光带给我的生命力，会伤害到谁呢？我这是胡言乱语。也许此刻他正在比利牛斯山或南方风平浪静的海边观看日出呢。” At last the woods rose; the rookery clustered dark; a loud cawing broke the morning stillness.Strange delight inspired me: on I hastened.Another field crossed—a lane threaded—and there were the courtyard walls—the back offices: the house itself, the rookery still hid.“My first view of it shall be in front,” I determined, “where its bold battlements will strike the eye nobly at once, and where I can single out my master’s very window: perhaps he will be standing at it—he rises early: perhaps he is now walking in the orchard, or on the pavement in front.Could I but see him!—but a moment!Surely, in that case, I should not be so mad as to run to him?I cannot tell—I am not certain.And if I did—what then?God bless him!What then?Who would be hurt by my once more tasting the life his glance can give me?I rave: perhaps at this moment he is watching the sun rise over the Pyrenees, or on the tideless sea of the south.”
我沿着果园较矮的那段围墙走，在拐角处转了弯，那儿正好有扇门，通向草地，门两边是两根石柱，柱顶有石球。从其中一根石柱后边，我可以悄悄地窥视整座府邸的正面。我小心翼翼地探出头，想搞清楚有没有哪扇窗的百叶窗帘是拉开的。从这个隐蔽的地方望出去，墙垛、窗户、府邸长长的正面尽收眼底。 I had coasted along the lower wall of the orchard—turned its angle: there was a gate just there, opening into the meadow, between two stone pillars crowned by stone balls.From behind one pillar I could peep round quietly at the full front of the mansion.I advanced my head with precaution, desirous to ascertain if any bedroom window-blinds were yet drawn up: battlements, windows, long front—all from this sheltered station were at my command.
我在这么眺望的时候，头顶上飞过的乌鸦也许也在注视着我。我好奇它们在想什么。它们肯定认为我一开始时很小心胆怯，但渐渐地，我变得非常大胆鲁莽了。先偷偷地瞥上一眼，然后便久久注视，接着离开我的藏身之处，走进草坪，在高大的府邸正前方突然停下，大胆地长时间盯着它。“起初假装出来的害羞胆怯是怎么回事？”它们可能会问，“现在这种愚蠢的鲁莽行为又是为何？” The crows sailing overhead perhaps watched me while I took this survey.I wonder what they thought.They must have considered I was very careful and timid at first, and that gradually I grew very bold and reckless.A peep, and then a long stare; and then a departure from my niche and a straying out into the meadow; and a sudden stop full in front of the great mansion, and a protracted, hardy gaze towards it.“What affectation of diffidence was this at first?” they might have demanded; “what stupid regardlessness now?”
读者啊，请听我打个比方吧。 Hear an illustration, reader.
一个情人发现他的爱人躺在长满苔藓的山坡上睡着了，他想看一眼她美丽的容颜，但又不想吵醒她。他轻手轻脚地偷偷走上草地，小心翼翼地不发出一点声音。突然他停下了，还以为她被惊动了，他向后退去，决不能让她看见。一切都静悄悄的，他再次走上前去，俯下身去看她。一层薄纱覆盖在她的脸上，他掀起薄纱，近距离地俯视她。他的眼睛期待着看到一张美丽的脸庞——酣睡中温暖亲切、青春焕发、可亲可爱的脸庞。他的第一眼多么迫不及待！然而，他的目光呆住了！他多么吃惊！他又是多么突然，多么猛烈地用双臂紧紧抱住这个身体，而不久之前他连用手指碰碰都不敢。他多么大声地呼喊着她的名字，放下沉重的包袱，疯狂地凝视着她。然后又一把抱住她，哭喊着，凝视着，因为他再也不怕他喊出的话和做出的动作会把她吵醒了。他原以为自己的爱人甜甜地睡去了，却发现她已经彻底死去了。 A lover finds his mistress asleep on a mossy bank; he wishes to catch a glimpse of her fair face without waking her.He steals softly over the grass, careful to make no sound; he pauses—fancying she has stirred: he withdraws: not for worlds would he be seen.All is still: he again advances: he bends above her; a light veil rests on her features: he lifts it, bends lower; now his eyes anticipate the vision of beauty—warm, and blooming, and lovely, in rest.How hurried was their first glance!But how they fix!How he starts!How he suddenly and vehemently clasps in both arms the form he dared not, a moment since, touch with his finger!How he calls aloud a name, and drops his burden, and gazes on it wildly!He thus grasps and cries, and gazes, because he no longer fears to waken by any sound he can utter—by any movement he can make.He thought his love slept sweetly: he finds she is stone dead.
我带着胆怯的喜悦望向那雄伟的宅邸，却看到一片焦黑的废墟。 I looked with timorous joy towards a stately house: I saw a blackened ruin.
没必要再躲在门柱后面了，确实！没必要偷偷地窥视房间的百叶窗，害怕窗后会有人走动！没必要再去听门开的声音，想象有人在人行道或碎石小路上散步！草坪和院落已被踩踏得破败荒芜了，大门敞开着，空空如也。府邸的正面就像我曾在梦中见到的一样，只有一堵像贝壳一样的墙，高高耸立，却不堪一击，上面布满了没有玻璃的窗户；没有屋顶，没有墙垛，也没有烟囱——全都倒塌了。 No need to cower behind a gate-post, indeed!—to peep up at chamber lattices, fearing life was astir behind them!No need to listen for doors opening—to fancy steps on the pavement or the gravel-walk!The lawn, the grounds were trodden and waste: the portal yawned void.The front was, as I had once seen it in a dream, but a well like wall, very high and very fragile-looking, perforated with paneless windows: no roof, no battlements, and no chimneys—all had crashed in.
那景象有一种死亡的寂静，荒野的凄凉。难怪寄到这儿的信件从来没有收到过回复，就好像派人寄送使徒书信到教堂过道的墓穴里。恐怖的黑色砖石倾诉着宅子因遭到了怎样的厄运而倒塌——被大火烧毁了。可大火是怎么燃起来的呢？这场灾难归因于何事呢？除了灰浆、大理石和木制品之外，还造成了什么其他损失吗？财产不幸受损，那人命呢？如果有，那是什么人？这真是可怕的问题，这里没有人可以回答，甚至也无法从无声的迹象、沉默的标志中看出答案。 And there was the silence of death about it: the solitude of a lonesome wild.No wonder that letters addressed to people here had never received an answer: as well despatch epistles to a vault in a church aisle.The grim blackness of the stones told by what fate the Hall had fallen—by conflagration: but how kindled?What story belonged to this disaster?What loss, besides mortar and marble and wood-work had followed upon it?Had life been wrecked as well as property?If so, whose?Dreadful question: there was no one here to answer it—not even dumb sign, mute token.
我在断壁残垣周边徘徊，穿过被烧毁的内府，我发现种种迹象都表明这场灾难不是最近发生的。我推测，冬天的雪随风吹进了空空的拱门，雨雪也击打过凹陷的窗户。因为在一堆堆浸湿的废墟中，春天孕育出了草木，碎石和倒落的椽木之间散乱地长着些野草。噢！与此同时，这片废墟那不幸的主人在哪儿呢？他在哪个国家？又在谁的保护之下？我的眼睛不由自主地转向了大门附近那座灰色的教堂塔楼，自问道：“难道他与罗切斯特夫人一起，同住在他那狭窄的大理石房子里？” In wandering round the shattered walls and through the devastated interior, I gathered evidence that the calamity was not of late occurrence.Winter snows, I thought, had drifted through that void arch, winter rains beaten in at those hollow casements; for, amidst the drenched piles of rubbish, spring had cherished vegetation: grass and weed grew here and there between the stones and fallen rafters.And oh! where meantime was the hapless owner of this wreck?In what land?Under what auspices?My eye involuntarily wandered to the grey church tower near the gates, and I asked, “Is he with Damer de Rochester, sharing the shelter of his narrow marble house?”
这些疑惑必须得到解答。而且也只有在旅馆才能找到答案了。因此，我很快又返回了旅馆。店主亲自把早餐给我送到了客厅。我请他坐下，关上房门，说有些事情想问问他。但他答应了以后，我却一点也不知道该从何说起，我对可能听到的回答是如此地恐惧。不过，刚才离开的那片废墟的景象，在一定程度上让我准备好了去听一段悲惨的故事。店主是个看上去是个很正派的中年人。 Some answer must be had to these questions.I could find it nowhere but at the inn, and thither, ere long, I returned.The host himself brought my breakfast into the parlour.I requested him to shut the door and sit down: I had some questions to ask him.But when he complied, I scarcely knew how to begin; such horror had I of the possible answers.And yet the spectacle of desolation I had just left prepared me in a measure for a tale of misery.The host was a respectable-looking, middle-aged man.
“那么想必您是知道桑菲尔德的事情的？”我终于开口了。 “You know Thornfield Hall, of course?”I managed to say at last.
“是的，小姐，我曾经住在那里。” “Yes, ma’am; I lived there once.”
“你在那里住过？”我心想，至少不是在我在的时候，对我来说你是个陌生人。 “Did you?”Not in my time, I thought: you are a stranger to me.
“我是已故的罗切斯特先生的管家。”他补充道。 “I was the late Mr. Rochester’s butler,” he added.
已故的！我感觉自己一直以来努力避开的打击这会儿重重地落在了我身上。 The late!I seem to have received, with full force, the blow I had been trying to evade.
“已故的！”我喘不过气来，“他死了？” “The late!” gasped. “Is he dead?”
“我指的是如今的老爷，爱德华先生的父亲。”他解释道。我又能正常呼吸了，血液也继续流动起来。这番话令我彻底放心了，爱德华先生——我的罗切斯特先生（不管他在哪儿，愿上帝保佑他！）至少还活着，总之，还是“如今的老爷”。真是令人高兴的话！看来不管之后谈到什么，他会再透露些什么，我都能以比较平静的情绪接受。因为他还没有进入坟墓。于是我觉得，即使得知他在地球的另一端——新西兰或澳大利亚，我也能忍受。 “I mean the present gentleman, Mr. Edward’s father,” he explained.I breathed again: my blood resumed its flow.Fully assured by these words that Mr. Edward—MY Mr. Rochester (God bless him, wherever he was!)—was at least alive: was, in short, “the present gentleman.”Gladdening words!It seemed I could hear all that was to come—whatever the disclosures might be—with comparative tranquillity.Since he was not in the grave, I could bear, I thought, to learn that he was at the Antipodes.
“罗切斯特先生现在还住在桑菲尔德府吗？”我问道，当然知道会得到什么样的回答，但还是不想这么快就直接问他到底在哪里。 “Is Mr. Rochester living at Thornfield Hall now?”I asked, knowing, of course, what the answer would be, but yet desirous of deferring the direct question as to where he really was.
“不，小姐，噢，当然不了！没有人住在那儿了。我猜您对这一带一定很陌生吧，或者您听说了去年秋天这里发生了什么事——桑菲尔德府简直变成了废墟，就在秋收的时候被烧毁了。真是可怕的灾难！那么多值钱的财物都被毁掉了，几乎没有一件家具幸免于难。大火是在深夜着起来的，从米尔科特来的救火车还没到的时候，整座宅子已是一片熊熊大火了。那场面太可怕了，我是亲眼目睹到的。” “No, ma’am—oh, no!No one is living there.I suppose you are a stranger in these parts, or you would have heard what happened last autumn,—Thornfield Hall is quite a ruin: it was burnt down just about harvest-time.A dreadful calamity!such an immense quantity of valuable property destroyed: hardly any of the furniture could be saved.The fire broke out at dead of night, and before the engines arrived from Millcote, the building was one mass of flame.It was a terrible spectacle: I witnessed it myself.”
“在深夜里！”我喃喃道。是啊，那总是桑菲尔德发生大事的时候。“起火的原因弄明白了吗？”我问道。 “At dead of night!” I muttered.Yes, that was ever the hour of fatality at Thornfield.“Was it known how it originated?” I demanded.
“他们猜测的，小姐，只是猜测。其实，我应该说那是确信无疑的。你可能不知道，”他边说边把椅子移近桌子，压低了声音，“有个夫人——一个——一个疯子，被关在宅子里。” “They guessed, ma’am: they guessed.Indeed, I should say it was ascertained beyond a doubt.You are not perhaps aware,” he continued, edging his chair a little nearer the table, and speaking low, “that there was a lady—a—a lunatic, kept in the house?”
“我听说过。” “I have heard something of it.”
“她被严加监管着，小姐。外人甚至好多年都不能完全确定是否有她这个人。没有人见过她，大家只是听到谣传才知道府里还有这么一个人。她是谁，是这府上的什么人，大家很难猜测得到。人们说是爱德华先生从国外把她带回来的，一些人还相信她是他的情人。然而一年前发生了一件奇怪的事情——一件非常奇怪的事情。” “She was kept in very close confinement, ma’am: people even for some years was not absolutely certain of her existence.No one saw her: they only knew by rumour that such a person was at the Hall; and who or what she was it was difficult to conjecture.They said Mr. Edward had brought her from abroad, and some believed she had been his mistress.But a queer thing happened a year since—a very queer thing.”
这会儿我害怕听到有关我的故事。我试图把他拉回到正题上。 I feared now to hear my own story.I endeavoured to recall him to the main fact.
“这位夫人呢？” “And this lady?”
“这位夫人，小姐，”他答道，“结果却是罗切斯特先生的妻子！这个真相发现的过程真是再奇怪不过了。府上有一位年轻的小姐，是家庭教师，罗切斯特先生爱上——” “This lady, ma’am,” he answered, “turned out to be Mr. Rochester’s wife!The discovery was brought about in the strangest way.There was a young lady, a governess at the Hall, that Mr. Rochester fell in—”
“但是怎么发生火灾了？”我提醒道。 “But the fire,” I suggested.
“我就要说到那个了，小姐。罗切斯特先生爱上了那位教师。府里的仆人说他们从来没有见过有谁像他那样坠入爱河，他时刻追随着她。他们常常观察他——仆人们就会这样，您知道的，小姐——他把她看得比什么都重要，尽管除了他，没有人认为她是如此漂亮。她长得很矮小，他们说，几乎像个孩子一样。我从没有亲眼见过她，但是我听女仆利娅说到过她。利娅非常喜欢她。罗切斯特先生都快四十了，而这位家庭教师还不满二十岁。您看看，像他这个年纪的先生们爱上了年轻的女孩子，常常就跟着了魔似的。是啊，他想娶她。” “I’m coming to that, ma’am—that Mr. Edward fell in love with.The servants say they never saw anybody so much in love as he was: he was after her continually.They used to watch him—servants will, you know, ma’am—and he set store on her past everything: for all, nobody but him thought her so very handsome.She was a little small thing, they say, almost like a child.I never saw her myself; but I’ve heard Leah, the house-maid, tell of her.Leah liked her well enough.Mr. Rochester was about forty, and this governess not twenty; and you see, when gentlemen of his age fall in love with girls, they are often like as if they were bewitched.Well, he would marry her.”
“你可以改天再给我讲这一部分，”我说，“而我现在特别想听你说说火灾的事。是不是人们怀疑那个疯子，就是罗切斯特夫人与这事有关？” “You shall tell me this part of the story another time,” I said; “but now I have a particular reason for wishing to hear all about the fire.Was it suspected that this lunatic, Mrs. Rochester, had any hand in it?”
“您说中了，小姐。毫无疑问就是她，除了她没人会放火。她由一个女人照管着，这人叫普尔太太。她在她们这一行是个很能干的人，也能信得过，但是她有一个缺点——这也是她们那些看护和保姆的通病——她私下里藏着一瓶杜松子酒，时不时地会喝上那么一口。这也是能够谅解的，她们的日子真不好过。但是这毕竟还是挺危险的，因为只要普尔太太喝过酒和水，就会沉沉地睡过去，而那个狡猾得像个巫婆的疯女人就会从普尔太太的口袋里掏出钥匙，打开房门溜出去，在宅子里游荡。无论头脑中产生什么荒唐的鬼主意，她都会干得出来。人们说有一次她差点把自己的丈夫烧死在床上，但是那件事我不太清楚。 “You’ve hit it, ma’am: it’s quite certain that it was her, and nobody but her, that set it going.She had a woman to take care of her called Mrs. Poole—an able woman in her line, and very trustworthy, but for one fault—a fault common to a deal of them nurses and matrons—she KEPT A PRIVATE BOTTLE OF GIN BY HER, and now and then took a drop over-much.It is excusable, for she had a hard life of it: but still it was dangerous; for when Mrs. Poole was fast asleep after the gin and water, the mad lady, who was as cunning as a witch, would take the keys out of her pocket, let herself out of her chamber, and go roaming about the house, doing any wild mischief that came into her head.They say she had nearly burnt her husband in his bed once: but I don’t know about that.
然而，就在火灾那天晚上，她先是点火烧着了她卧室隔壁房间的帘子，然后她走下楼，去了家庭教师的房间——（她好像是知道事情的发展似的，并对她怀恨在心）——之后把那儿的床点着了。不过幸运的是，当时没有人睡在上面。家庭教师在两个月前就出走了，尽管罗切斯特先生把她视为这个世界上最宝贵的东西，到处寻找她，也未能得到任何关于她的消息。他变得狂暴，失望令他抓狂。尽管他从来都不是野蛮的人，但是失去她以后，他变得危险起来。并且，他情愿一个人呆着。他打发女管家费尔法克斯夫人去了她远在外地的朋友家，但是他很慷慨，付给她一笔终身年金。这也是她应得的，她可是个非常不错的女人。他监护的阿代勒小姐也被送进了学校。他同所有上流社会的朋友断绝了往来，像个隐居者一样把自己关在了宅子里。” However, on this night, she set fire first to the hangings of the room next her own, and then she got down to a lower storey, and made her way to the chamber that had been the governess’s—(she was like as if she knew somehow how matters had gone on, and had a spite at her)—and she kindled the bed there;but there was nobody sleeping in it, fortunately.The governess had run away two months before; and for all Mr. Rochester sought her as if she had been the most precious thing he had in the world, he never could hear a word of her; and he grew savage—quite savage on his disappointment: he never was a wild man, but he got dangerous after he lost her.He would be alone, too.He sent Mrs. Fairfax, the housekeeper, away to her friends at a distance; but he did it handsomely, for he settled an annuity on her for life: and she deserved it—she was a very good woman.Miss Adele, a ward he had, was put to school.He broke off acquaintance with all the gentry, and shut himself up like a hermit at the Hall.”
“什么！他没有离开英国？” “What! did he not leave England?”
“离开英国？上天保佑，没有！他不愿跨出门槛一步，除了在晚上，他会如幽灵一般，在院子里或果园里游荡，仿佛神经错乱了一样——在我看来他是那样。因为，小姐，你没见过他在遇见那个矮小的女教师之前是什么样啊，没有人比他更有精神，更无畏，更机智了。他不像有些男人那样，沉溺于喝酒、玩牌或赛马，而且他也不是特别英俊，但是他有着男人特有的勇气和意志力。您瞧，我在他还是个孩子的时候就认识他了。就我来说，我常常希望那个爱小姐在来到桑菲尔德府之前还不如就淹死在海里呢。” “Leave England?Bless you, no!He would not cross the door-stones of the house, except at night, when he walked just like a ghost about the grounds and in the orchard as if he had lost his senses—which it is my opinion he had; for a more spirited, bolder, keener gentleman than he was before that midge of a governess crossed him, you never saw, ma’am.He was not a man given to wine, or cards, or racing, as some are, and he was not so very handsome; but he had a courage and a will of his own, if ever man had.I knew him from a boy, you see: and for my part, I have often wished that Miss Eyre had been sunk in the sea before she came to Thornfield Hall.”
“那么火灾发生时，罗切斯特先生就在家中了？” “Then Mr. Rochester was at home when the fire broke out?”
“是的，他的确在家。上上下下都烧起来的时候，他还上到顶楼去，叫仆人们起床，帮他们逃下楼，然后又返回去把他那疯妻子弄出房间。后来他们朝他喊，说她在房顶上，她站在墙垛上，挥舞着手臂，扯着嗓子喊叫，一英里外都能听得到。我亲眼看到她了，听见她喊了。她是个大个头儿，留着长长的黑发。她站在那儿，我们能看到她的长发迎着火焰飘舞着。我亲眼看到，还有另外几个人也亲眼看到，罗切斯特先生从天窗爬上了屋顶，我们听到他喊‘伯莎！’我们看到他走向她，可这时候，小姐，她喊了一声，纵身一跃，接下来瞬间就跌落在了人行道上，摔得粉碎。” “Yes, indeed was he; and he went up to the attics when all was burning above and below, and got the servants out of their beds and helped them down himself, and went back to get his mad wife out of her cell.And then they called out to him that she was on the roof, where she was standing, waving her arms, above the battlements, and shouting out till they could hear her a mile off: I saw her and heard her with my own eyes.She was a big woman, and had long black hair: we could see it streaming against the flames as she stood.I witnessed, and several more witnessed, Mr. Rochester ascend through the sky-light on to the roof; we heard him call ‘Bertha!’We saw him approach her; and then, ma’am, she yelled and gave a spring, and the next minute she lay smashed on the pavement.”
“死了？” “Dead?”
“死了！唉，就跟溅有她的脑浆和鲜血的石头一样，一动不动了。” “Dead!Ay, dead as the stones on which her brains and blood were scattered.”
“老天啊！” “Good God!”
“小姐，真可以这么说，那真是太可怕了！” “You may well say so, ma’am: it was frightful!”
他打了个冷颤。“后来呢？”我催问道。“唔，小姐，后来，整座宅子被烧成了平地，只剩下残缺的几处墙壁还立在那里。” He shuddered.“And afterwards?” I urged.“Well, ma’am, afterwards the house was burnt to the ground: there are only some bits of walls standing now.”
“还有其他人丧命吗？” “Were any other lives lost?”
“没有了。也许如果有的话，倒还更好些。” “No—perhaps it would have been better if there had.”
“你这是什么意思？” “What do you mean?”
“可怜的爱德华先生！”他突然喊道，“我从没想过会看到他这样！一些人说，这对于他的所作所为也是个公平的判决，因为他隐瞒了最初的婚姻，妻子还活着却想再娶一个。但是就我来说，我还是同情他的。” “Poor Mr. Edward!” he ejaculated, “I little thought ever to have seen it!Some say it was a just judgment on him for keeping his first marriage secret, and wanting to take another wife while he had one living: but I pity him, for my part.”
“你是说他还活着？”我叫道。 “You said he was alive?” I exclaimed.
“是的，是的，他还活着。但是很多人都认为他还不如死了的好。” “Yes, yes: he is alive; but many think he had better he dead.”
“为什么？死了怎么就好了？”我的血液再一次变得冰凉。“他现在在哪儿？”我问。“他还在英国吗？” “Why?How?”My blood was again running cold.“Where is he?” I demanded.“Is he in England?”
“对——对——他在英国，我想他也没法离开英国了——现在他是动不了了。” “Ay—ay—he’s in England; he can’t get out of England, I fancy—he’s a fixture now.”
这是何等的痛苦啊！可是这个人仿佛铁了心要吞吞吐吐。 What agony was this!And the man seemed resolved to protract it.
“他眼睛彻底瞎了，”他最后终于说了，“是的，他彻底瞎了，这位爱德华先生。” “He is stone-blind,” he said at last.“Yes, he is stone-blind, is Mr. Edward.”
我原本担心的要更糟糕。我担心他疯了。我于是鼓起勇气问他这个不幸是怎么发生的。 I had dreaded worse.I had dreaded he was mad.I summoned strength to ask what had caused this calamity.
“那都是因为他太勇敢了，也可以说，他太善良了，小姐。他要等所有人都逃出宅子后才肯离开。罗切斯特夫人纵深跳下楼之后，他沿着大楼梯往下走，这时轰隆一声，整座宅子全塌了。他被人从废墟中拖了出来，虽然还活着，但是伤势很重。一根房梁倒了下来，正好把他护住了一部分，但是他的一只眼睛被砸了出来，一只手也被压坏了，卡特医生不得不直接给他截了肢。另一只眼发炎了，也失去了视力。他现在是失望无助啊，确实，又瞎又残。” “It was all his own courage, and a body may say, his kindness, in a way, ma’am: he wouldn’t leave the house till every one else was out before him.As he came down the great staircase at last, after Mrs Rochester had flung herself from the battlements, there was a great crash—all fell.He was taken out from under the ruins, alive, but sadly hurt: a beam had fallen in such a way as to protect him partly; but one eye was knocked out, and one hand so crushed that Mr. Carter, the surgeon, had to amputate it directly.The other eye inflamed: he lost the sight of that also.He is now helpless, indeed—blind and a cripple.”
“他在哪儿呢？现在住在哪里？” “Where is he?Where does he now live?”
“在芬丁，他的农场庄园里，离这儿大概三十英里远，那是个相当荒凉的地方。” “At Ferndean, a manor-house on a farm he has, about thirty miles off: quite a desolate spot.”
“谁跟他一起住着？” “Who is with him?”
“老约翰和他的妻子。他不想要其他任何人。人们说，他彻底垮掉了。” “Old John and his wife: he would have none else.He is quite broken down, they say.”
“你有什么车辆吗？” “Have you any sort of conveyance?”
我们有辆轻便马车，小姐，非常漂亮。” “We have a chaise, ma’am, a very handsome chaise.”
“马上备好马车，如果你那个驿车送信人能在今天天黑之前把我送到芬丁，我会付给你们双份车钱。” “Let it be got ready instantly; and if your postboy can drive me to Ferndean before dark this day, I’ll pay both you and him twice the hire you usually demand.”
第三十七章 CHAPTER XXXVII
芬丁庄园是座年头久远的宅子，中等大小，建筑朴实无华，位于一片树林深处。我以前对它有所耳闻。罗切斯特先生常常说起它，有时也会去那儿。他父亲当初买下这块地产是为了方便打猎。他本来要把宅子租出去，可是因为地方不好，环境对身体不利，所以没有找到租户。于是芬丁庄园一直没有人居住，也没有置办什么家具，只有两三间房子收拾妥当，供这位老爷在狩猎时节小住。 The manor-house of Ferndean was a building of considerable antiquity, moderate size, and no architectural pretensions, deep buried in a wood.I had heard of it before.Mr. Rochester often spoke of it, and sometimes went there.His father had purchased the estate for the sake of the game covers.He would have let the house, but could find no tenant, in consequence of its ineligible and insalubrious site.Ferndean then remained uninhabited and unfurnished, with the exception of some two or three rooms fitted up for the accommodation of the squire when he went there in the season to shoot.
天快黑时，我到了这座庄园。那个傍晚天色阴霾，冷风嗖嗖，细密的小雨不停地下着。正如我之前许诺的，我付了双倍的车钱，打发走了马车和车夫，最后的一英里路我步行向前。即使离庄园已经很近了，你还是什么都看不到，庄园周围的树木粗壮密集，长成了一片幽暗的树林。两根花岗岩柱子之间的铁门给我指明了入口。穿过铁门，便立刻发觉自己已经置身于密林的暮色之中了。林间通道是条杂草丛生的小径，穿行于灰白多节的树木之间、枝条相接的树拱之下。我沿着这条路走，期待着很快就能到达宅子。但是小径不断向前延伸着，越来越远，看不到任何住宅或院落的迹象。 To this house I came just ere dark on an evening marked by the characteristics of sad sky, cold gale, and continued small penetrating rain.The last mile I performed on foot, having dismissed the chaise and driver with the double remuneration I had promised.Even when within a very short distance of the manor house, you could see nothing of it, so thick and dark grew the timber of the gloomy wood about it.Iron gates between granite pillars showed me where to enter, and passing through them, I found myself at once in the twilight of close-ranked trees.There was a grass-grown track descending the forest aisle between hoar and knotty shafts and under branched arches.I followed it, expecting soon to reach the dwelling; but it stretched on and on, it would far and farther: no sign of habitation or grounds was visible.
我以为自己走错了方向，迷了路。夜幕和林子的幽暗笼罩着我。我环顾四周，想找其他的出路。一条也没有找到。两眼所见全是互相交织的树枝，柱子般的树干，夏季茂密的树叶——哪儿也没有出口。 I thought I had taken a wrong direction and lost my way.The darkness of natural as well as of sylvan dusk gathered over me.I looked round in search of another road.There was none: all was interwoven stem, columnar trunk, dense summer foliage—no opening anywhere.
我继续前行，这条路终于有了出口，树林变得稀疏了。不久，我看到了一道围栏，接着是座房子。在昏暗的暮色中，依稀能把它和树林区分开，衰败的围墙潮湿发绿。走进一扇只扣着门闩的大门，我站在围墙之内的空地上。树林在院落四周围成了半圆。院内没有鲜花，没有苗圃，只有被一条宽阔的碎石子铺成的路围绕着的一片草地，嵌在密林之中。宅子正面有两堵尖形山墙，格子窗户非常狭窄，前门也很狭小，前面只有一级台阶。整座宅子看起来正如“罗切斯特纹章”旅馆的店主所说，是个“相当荒凉的地方”。寂静得像是没有人做礼拜的教堂，周围可以听到的只有雨点急速打在树叶上的声音。 I proceeded: at last my way opened, the trees thinned a little; presently I beheld a railing, then the house—scarce, by this dim light, distinguishable from the trees; so dank and green were its decaying walls.Entering a portal, fastened only by a latch, I stood amidst a space of enclosed ground, from which the wood swept away in a semicircle.There were no flowers, no garden-beds; only a broad gravel-walk girdling a grass-plat, and this set in the heavy frame of the forest.The house presented two pointed gables in its front; the windows were latticed and narrow: the front door was narrow too, one step led up to it.The whole looked, as the host of the Rochester Arms had said, “quite a desolate spot.”It was as still as a church on a week-day: the pattering rain on the forest leaves was the only sound audible in its vicinage.
“这里可能有生命存在吗？”我疑惑。 “Can there be life here?” I asked.
是的，这里确有某种生命，因为我听到了一阵响动——那扇狭窄的前门正被打开，有人要从庄园里出来了。 Yes, life of some kind there was; for I heard a movement—that narrow front-door was unclosing, and some shape was about to issue from the grange.
门缓慢地打开了，一个身影走到了暮色中，站在台阶上。一个没带帽子的男人，他伸出手，仿佛在感觉是不是在下雨。虽然暮色暗淡，我还是认出了他——那不是别人，就是我的主人，爱德华·费尔法克斯·罗切斯特。 It opened slowly: a figure came out into the twilight and stood on the step; a man without a hat: he stretched forth his hand as if to feel whether it rained.Dusk as it was, I had recognised him—it was my master, Edward Fairfax Rochester, and no other.
我站定了脚步，几乎也停止了呼吸，站在那里看着他，细细地审视他，不让他看见。唉，他是看不见我的。这是突然的相见，但狂喜已经被痛苦抑制住了。我毫不费力地克制住自己的声音，没有喊出声，止住了脚步，没有匆匆走上前去。 I stayed my step, almost my breath, and stood to watch him—to examine him, myself unseen, and alas! to him invisible.It was a sudden meeting, and one in which rapture was kept well in check by pain.I had no difficulty in restraining my voice from exclamation, my step from hasty advance.
他的身体还是那么健壮、魁梧，站立的姿势依旧直挺，头发还是那么乌黑，面容也没有什么改变或者凹陷。任何悲伤都无法在一年内消蚀他强健的力量，或摧毁他充满活力的青春。但是我发现他的表情有所变化，看上去绝望且忧虑，令我想到受到虐待或被囚禁的野兽或飞鸟，在其愠怒痛苦的时候，接近它是很危险的。关在笼子里的鹰，被残忍地挖去了那镶着金边的眼睛，看上去也许就像是这位失明的参孙。 His form was of the same strong and stalwart contour as ever: his port was still erect, his heir was still raven black; nor were his features altered or sunk: not in one year’s space, by any sorrow, could his athletic strength be quelled or his vigorous prime blighted.But in his countenance I saw a change: that looked desperate and brooding—that reminded me of some wronged and fettered wild beast or bird, dangerous to approach in his sullen woe.The caged eagle, whose gold-ringed eyes cruelty has extinguished, might look as looked that sightless Samson.
然而，读者啊，你认为我会怕他瞎眼后的凶狠吗？如果你这么认为，那就太不了解我了。忧伤中混杂着一种轻柔的希望，不久我就会大胆地吻上那岩石一般的额头，和额下那紧闭的冷峻的嘴唇，但是现在还不行。 And, reader, do you think I feared him in his blind ferocity?—if you do, you little know me.A soft hope blest with my sorrow that soon I should dare to drop a kiss on that brow of rock, and on those lips so sternly sealed beneath it: but not yet.
我现在还不想同他打招呼。他迈下那一级台阶，缓慢地向前走，摸索着往草地那边移动。他原先那昂首阔步的样子如今哪儿去了？接着他停了下来，好像是不知道该往哪个方向走了。他举起手，睁开眼睛，吃力地、茫然地凝视着天空，又望向环绕四周的树木。可以看得出来，他看到的只有空洞洞的黑暗。他伸出右手（被截肢的左臂藏在怀里），看起来想要触摸一下周围有什么，但他摸到的依然是一片空虚，因为树木离他站立的地方还有好几码远。他不再尝试，收回了他的胳膊，默默地在雨中站着，雨点急促地落在他没戴帽子的头上。这时候，约翰不知从哪里出来了，走近他。 I would not accost him yet.He descended the one step, and advanced slowly and gropingly towards the grass-plat.Where was his daring stride now?Then he paused, as if he knew not which way to turn.He lifted his hand and opened his eyelids; gazed blank, and with a straining effort, on the sky, and toward the amphitheatre of trees: one saw that all to him was void darkness.He stretched his right hand (the left arm, the mutilated one, he kept hidden in his bosom); he seemed to wish by touch to gain an idea of what lay around him: he met but vacancy still; for the trees were some yards off where he stood.He relinquished the endeavour, folded his arms, and stood quiet and mute in the rain, now falling fast on his uncovered head.At this moment John approached him from some quarter.
“您要不要挽着我的胳膊，先生？”他说，“一会儿就要下大雨了，您最好还是回屋吧。” “Will you take my arm, sir?” he said; “there is a heavy shower coming on: had you not better go in?”
“别管我。”他答道。 “Let me alone,” was the answer.
约翰回屋去了，没有看到我。罗切斯特先生试着到处走走，但却是徒劳——对一切都没有把握。他摸索着回到屋里去了，进去后随手关上了门。 John withdrew without having observed me.Mr. Rochester now tried to walk about: vainly,—all was too uncertain.He groped his way back to the house, and, re-entering it, closed the door.
我于是走近去敲门，约翰的妻子为我开了门。“玛丽，”我说，“你还好吗？” I now drew near and knocked: John’s wife opened for me.“Mary,” I said, “how are you?”
她吃了一惊，仿佛见到鬼一样。我让她平静下来。她急忙问道：“是你吗，小姐？这么晚了独自来到了这个偏僻的地方？”我握住她的手以示回答，然后跟随她到了厨房，约翰正坐在烧得很旺的火炉边。我三言两语地向他们解释了一下，我听说了自从我离开桑菲尔德后这里发生的一切，这次来是要看看罗切斯特先生。我让约翰往我打发马车回去的关卡跑一趟，取回我放在那儿的箱子。然后，我一边摘下帽子和披肩，一边问玛丽我是否晚上可以在庄园里借住。得知虽然不太容易安排，但也还是可以做到的，于是我告诉她我要留下来。就在这时客厅的门铃响了。 She started as if she had seen a ghost: I calmed her.To her hurried “Is it really you, miss, come at this late hour to this lonely place?”I answered by taking her hand; and then I followed her into the kitchen, where John now sat by a good fire.I explained to them, in few words, that I had heard all which had happened since I left Thornfield, and that I was come to see Mr. Rochester.I asked John to go down to the turn-pike-house, where I had dismissed the chaise, and bring my trunk, which I had left there: and then, while I removed my bonnet and shawl, I questioned Mary as to whether I could be accommodated at the Manor House for the night; and finding that arrangements to that effect, though difficult, would not be impossible, I informed her I should stay.Just at this moment the parlour-bell rang.
“你进去了，告诉主人有个人想同他谈谈，但是不要说出我的名字。” “When you go in,” said I, “tell your master that a person wishes to speak to him, but do not give my name.”
“我觉得他不会见你的，”她答道，“他拒绝接见任何人。” “I don’t think he will see you,” she answered; “he refuses everybody.”
她回来后，我问她他说什么了。“他要你报上名字，说明来意。”她答道。她接着倒了一杯水，放在托盘里，又放上一支蜡烛。 When she returned, I inquired what he had said.“You are to send in your name and your business,” she replied.She then proceeded to fill a glass with water, and place it on a tray, together with candles.
“他按门铃就是要这些吗？”我问道。 “Is that what he rang for?” I asked.
“是的，晚上他总是让把蜡烛拿进去，即使他看不见。” “Yes: he always has candles brought in at dark, though he is blind.”
“把托盘给我吧，我把它端进去。” “Give the tray to me; I will carry it in.”
