我从她手上接过托盘，她给我指了指客厅的门。我端着盘子的手不停地颤抖，于是水从杯子里洒了出来，我的心重重地快速击打着肋骨。玛丽为我打开了门，又在我进去后把它关上了。 I took it from her hand: she pointed me out the parlour door.The tray shook as I held it; the water spilt from the glass; my heart struck my ribs loud and fast.Mary opened the door for me, and shut it behind me.
客厅看起来很昏暗，一小撮火苗无人照管，在壁炉里微微燃烧着。倚在壁炉上，头靠着高高的老式壁炉架的那个人，正是那瞎了眼睛的房子主人。他的老狗，派洛特，躺在一边，畏缩成一团，好像害怕会被不小心踩到似的。我一进去，派洛特就竖起了耳朵，然后一边汪汪地尖叫，呜呜地哀怨着，一边跳了起来，朝着我奔了过来，差点把我手上的盘子打翻。我把托盘放在桌上，然后拍拍派洛特，轻声说道：“卧下！”罗切斯特先生机械地扭过头来想看看这是什么动静，但是什么也没“看见”，他转过头，叹了口气。 This parlour looked gloomy: a neglected handful of fire burnt low in the grate; and, leaning over it, with his head supported against the high, old-fashioned mantelpiece, appeared the blind tenant of the room.His old dog, Pilot, lay on one side, removed out of the way, and coiled up as if afraid of being inadvertently trodden upon.Pilot pricked up his ears when I came in: then he jumped up with a yelp and a whine, and bounded towards me: he almost knocked the tray from my hands.I set it on the table; then patted him, and said softly, “Lie down!”Mr. Rochester turned mechanically to SEE what the commotion was: but as he SAW nothing, he returned and sighed.
“把水递给我，玛丽。”他说。 “Give me the water, Mary,” he said.
我端着剩下的半杯水走近他，派洛特仍然很兴奋地跟在我身后。 I approached him with the now only half-filled glass; Pilot followed me, still excited.
“怎么了？”他问道。 “What is the matter?” he inquired.
“卧下，派洛特！”我又说。他把水送往嘴边的时候突然停下了，好像是在听什么，然后喝了点水，放下了杯子。“是你吧，玛丽，是不是？” “Down, Pilot!” I again said.He checked the water on its way to his lips, and seemed to listen: he drank, and put the glass down.“This is you, Mary, is it not?”
“玛丽在厨房呢。”我答道。 “Mary is in the kitchen,” I answered.
他迅速伸出了手，但是由于看不到我所在的位置，他没有碰到我。“你是谁？你是谁？”他问道，一边似乎试图用那双失明的眼睛去看——徒劳而痛苦的尝试啊！“回答我——快说话！”他急迫地大声命令道。 He put out his hand with a quick gesture, but not seeing where I stood, he did not touch me.“Who is this?Who is this?” he demanded, trying, as it seemed, to SEE with those sightless eyes—unavailing and distressing attempt!“Answer me—speak again!” he ordered, imperiously and aloud.
“你要再来些水吗，先生？我把杯子里的水洒了一半。”我说。 “Will you have a little more water, sir?I spilt half of what was in the glass,” I said.
“你是谁？是什么人？谁在说话？” “WHO is it?WHAT is it?Who speaks?”
“派洛特认得我，约翰和玛丽知道我在这里。我就在今晚来到了这儿。”我回答。 “Pilot knows me, and John and Mary know I am here.I came only this evening,” I answered.
“上帝啊！我这是又产生什么幻觉了？什么样甜蜜的狂热将我控制了？” “Great God!—what delusion has come over me?What sweet madness has seized me?”
“不是幻觉，也没有狂热。先生，您的头脑很坚强，不会产生幻觉，您的身体也很健康，不会发狂。” “No delusion—no madness: your mind, sir, is too strong for delusion, your health too sound for frenzy.”
“说话的人在哪儿？难道这只是声音吗？哦！我看不到，但我得摸一摸，要不然我的心脏就会停止跳动，我的脑袋就会爆裂。不管你是什么——是谁——请让我触摸到，要不然我就活不下去了！” “And where is the speaker?Is it only a voice?Oh! I CANNOT see, but I must feel, or my heart will stop and my brain burst.Whatever—whoever you are—be perceptible to the touch or I cannot live!”
他摸索着，我抓住了他那只胡乱摸索的手，并牢牢攥在我的手里。 He groped; I arrested his wandering hand, and prisoned it in both mine.
“正是她的手指！”他喊道，“她那小巧、纤细的手指！真是这样的话，一定还有别的。” “Her very fingers!” he cried; “her small, slight fingers!If so there must be more of her.”
这只强壮的手挣脱了我双手的束缚。我的胳膊被他紧紧抓住，然后便是我的肩膀、脖颈、腰部——我被他搂住，靠近他。 The muscular hand broke from my custody; my arm was seized, my shoulder—neck—waist—I was entwined and gathered to him.
“是简吗？到底是什么？这是她的体型——她的个头——” “Is it Jane?WHAT is it?This is her shape—this is her size—”
“还有她的声音。”我补充道，“她整个人都在这里，还有她的心。愿上帝保佑你，先生！真高兴又能离你这么近。” “And this her voice,” I added.“She is all here: her heart, too.God bless you, sir!I am glad to be so near you again.”
“简·爱！——简·爱。”他一直这么喊着。 “Jane Eyre!—Jane Eyre,” was all he said.
“我亲爱的主人，”我答道，“我就是简·爱。我找到你了，我现在回到你身边了。”“是真实的吗？是鲜活的她吗？我那活蹦乱跳的简？”“你触摸到了我，先生，你搂着我，还搂得很紧。我并不像尸体一样冰冷，也不像空气那么虚无，不是吗？” “My dear master,” I answered, “I am Jane Eyre: I have found you out—I am come back to you.”“In truth?—in the flesh?My living Jane?”“You touch me, sir,—you hold me, and fast enough: I am not cold like a corpse, nor vacant like air, am I?”
“我活蹦乱跳的爱人！这些确实是她的四肢，这些是她的五官。但是经历了这么多不幸之后，我不会再有这福份了。这是个梦吧。我晚上会做这样的梦，我把她紧紧搂住，贴近我的心，就像现在这样；并且我会像现在这样亲吻她，感觉到她爱我，相信她永远不会离开我。” “My living darling!These are certainly her limbs, and these her features; but I cannot be so blest, after all my misery.It is a dream; such dreams as I have had at night when I have clasped her once more to my heart, as I do now; and kissed her, as thus—and felt that she loved me, and trusted that she would not leave me.”
“我永远不会离开你了，从今天起。” “Which I never will, sir, from this day.”
“永远不会，是幻觉说的吗？但我总是醒来后发现一切只是一场空，是梦在嘲弄人。我孤寂凄凉，我的人生黯淡、孤独、无望，我的灵魂干渴，却不准喝水，我的心灵饥饿，却得不到食物。温柔、舒适的梦啊，这会儿你依偎在我的怀里，一会儿你也会飞走，就像之前你的姐妹们都飞走了一样。但是走之前请亲吻我吧——拥抱我吧，简。” “Never will, says the vision?But I always woke and found it an empty mockery; and I was desolate and abandoned—my life dark, lonely, hopeless—my soul athirst and forbidden to drink—my heart famished and never to be fed.Gentle, soft dream, nestling in my arms now, you will fly, too, as your sisters have all fled before you: but kiss me before you go—embrace me, Jane.”
“这儿，先生，还有这儿！”我的双唇紧贴着他曾经炯炯有神，如今却黯淡无光的双眼，我拨开他前额的头发，也吻了一下。他好像突然清醒了过来，相信这一切都是真实的了。 “There, sir—and there!”‘ I pressed my lips to his once brilliant and now rayless eyes—I swept his hair from his brow, and kissed that too.He suddenly seemed to arouse himself: the conviction of the reality of all this seized him.
“是你，简，是不是？那么你回到我身边了？” “It is you—is it, Jane?You are come back to me then?”
“是的，我回来了。” “I am.”
“你没有淹死在哪条溪流的沟渠里吗？你没有憔悴地流落街头吗？” “And you do not lie dead in some ditch under some stream?And you are not a pining outcast amongst strangers?”
“没有，先生！我现在是个独立的女人了。” “No, sir!I am an independent woman now.”
“独立的！你是什么意思，简？” “Independent!What do you mean, Jane?”
“我在马德拉的叔叔去世了，他留给我五千英镑的遗产。” “My uncle in Madeira is dead, and he left me five thousand pounds.”
“啊！这是实实在在的——是真实的！”他喊道，“我是不会梦到这个的。再说，这就是她那独特的嗓音，这么富有生气，这么活泼有趣，还这么温柔。它振奋了我枯萎的心，赋予了它生命。——什么，珍妮特！你是个独立的女人了？ “Ah! this is practical—this is real!” he cried: “I should never dream that.Besides, there is that peculiar voice of hers, so animating and piquant, as well as soft: it cheers my withered heart; it puts life into it.—What, Janet!Are you an independent woman?
一个富有的女人？”“如果你不让我同你住在一起，我可以在你隔壁盖座房子，你晚上什么时候需要人陪伴了，就可以来找我，在我的客厅坐坐。” A rich woman?”“If you won’t let me live with you, I can build a house of my own close up to your door, and you may come and sit in my parlour when you want company of an evening.”
“但是，既然你现在有钱了，简，你无疑有许多朋友可以照顾你，他们不会让你受苦来伺候我这样一个瞎眼的残废吧？” “But as you are rich, Jane, you have now, no doubt, friends who will look after you, and not suffer you to devote yourself to a blind lameter like me?”
“我告诉你我已经独立了，先生，同时也很有钱，我可以自己做主。” “I told you I am independent, sir, as well as rich: I am my own mistress.”
“那么你要同我呆在一起？” “And you will stay with me?”
“当然了，除非你反对。我会做你的邻居，你的看护，你的管家。我发现你很孤寂，我愿意陪伴你——念书给你听，陪你散步，陪你坐着，伺候你，做你的眼睛和双手。别再呈现那么一副忧郁的表情了，我亲爱的主人。只要我还活着，你就不会再感到孤寂。” “Certainly—unless you object.I will be your neighbour, your nurse, your housekeeper.I find you lonely: I will be your companion—to read to you, to walk with you, to sit with you, to wait on you, to be eyes and hands to you.Cease to look so melancholy, my dear master; you shall not be left desolate, so long as I live.”
他没有回答，看上去很严肃，仿佛另有所思；他叹了口气，张了张嘴仿佛想说些什么，但又闭上了。我感到有些局促不安。也许我太过鲁莽，超出了习俗；而他，就像圣约翰一样，认为我说话不得体，考虑不够周全。我的确是因为认为他希望并会请求我做他的妻子，才会提出上面的建议。这种期望虽然没有说出来，却十分确定，它鼓舞着我，认为他会马上要求我跟了他。但是他没有表露出一丝这样的暗示，表情却变得更加忧郁了。我突然想到自己可能大错特错了，也许无意中扮演了一个傻瓜。于是我开始轻轻地挣脱他的胳膊，但是他急切地把我抱得更紧了。 He replied not: he seemed serious—abstracted; he sighed; he half opened his lips as if to speak: he closed them again.I felt a little embarrassed.Perhaps I had too rashly over-leaped conventionalities; and he, like St. John, saw impropriety in my inconsiderateness.I had indeed made my proposal from the idea that he wished and would ask me to be his wife: an expectation, not the less certain because unexpressed, had buoyed me up, that he would claim me at once as his own.But no hint to that effect escaping him and his countenance becoming more overcast, I suddenly remembered that I might have been all wrong, and was perhaps playing the fool unwittingly; and I began gently to withdraw myself from his arms—but he eagerly snatched me closer.
“不——不——简，你不能走。不——我已经触摸到了你，听见了你的声音，感觉到你的存在对我的慰藉——你甜蜜的安慰，我不能放走这些快乐。我拥有的已经所剩无几了，我必须拥有你。全世界都会笑我，都会说我荒谬、自私，但这些都不重要。我的灵魂需要你，而且必须得到满足，否则它会对身体施加致命的报复。” “No—no—Jane; you must not go.No—I have touched you, heard you, felt the comfort of your presence—the sweetness of your consolation: I cannot give up these joys.I have little left in myself—I must have you.The world may laugh—may call me absurd, selfish—but it does not signify.My very soul demands you: it will be satisfied, or it will take deadly vengeance on its frame.”
“好的，先生，我会留下来陪你，我说过了。” “Well, sir, I will stay with you: I have said so.”
“是的——对于这件事，我的理解和你的理解不是一回事。你也许可以下定决心呆在我的手边和椅子旁，像一个善良的小看护似的照料我（因为你内心充满爱心、为人慷慨，这使得你愿意为那些你所怜悯的人做出牺牲），这无疑已经足够令我满足了。我觉得现在我应该对你只抱有父亲般的感情了，你不这么觉得吗？来——告诉我。” “Yes—but you understand one thing by staying with me; and I understand another.You, perhaps, could make up your mind to be about my hand and chair—to wait on me as a kind little nurse (for you have an affectionate heart and a generous spirit, which prompt you to make sacrifices for those you pity), and that ought to suffice for me no doubt.I suppose I should now entertain none but fatherly feelings for you: do you think so?Come—tell me.”
“你愿意怎么样，我就怎么想，先生。只做你的看护我就很满足了，如果你觉得这样更好的话。” “I will think what you like, sir: I am content to be only your nurse, if you think it better.”
“但是你不能永远都做我的看护啊，珍妮特，你还年轻，总有一天一定会结婚的。” “But you cannot always be my nurse, Janet: you are young—you must marry one day.”
“我不在乎会不会结婚。” “I don’t care about being married.”
“你应该在乎，珍妮特。如果我还像以前那样，我会努力让你在乎。但是，我现在只是一个失明的傻瓜！” “You should care, Janet: if I were what I once was, I would try to make you care—but—a sightless block!”
他又再度陷入了忧郁。相反，我变得更加振奋，多了一些勇气。最后说的这些话让我明白了他的难处在哪里，因为困难不在于我，于是我便从之前的局促不安中解脱了出来。我开始更加愉悦地同他交谈。 He relapsed again into gloom.I, on the contrary, became more cheerful, and took fresh courage: these last words gave me an insight as to where the difficulty lay; and as it was no difficulty with me, I felt quite relieved from my previous embarrassment.I resumed a livelier vein of conversation.
“是时候把你重新变成人了，”我说着，拨开他又密又长、没有理过的头发，“因为我发现你就要变成一头狮子了，或者类似的长毛动物。你看起来有点儿像田野中的尼布甲尼撒，绝对的。你的头发使我想起了老鹰的羽毛，你的指甲是不是也长得像鸟爪了，这我倒还没注意。” “It is time some one undertook to rehumanise you,” said I, parting his thick and long uncut locks; “for I see you are being metamorphosed into a lion, or something of that sort.You have a ‘faux air’ of Nebuchadnezzar in the fields about you, that is certain: your hair reminds me of eagles’ feathers; whether your nails are grown like birds’ claws or not, I have not yet noticed.”
“这只胳膊上既没有手，也没有指甲了，”他说着把那只截了肢的胳膊从怀里抽了出来，伸给我看，“只剩下半截残肢了——真可怕！你不觉得吗，简？” “On this arm, I have neither hand nor nails,” he said, drawing the mutilated limb from his breast, and showing it to me.“It is a mere stump—a ghastly sight!Don’t you think so, Jane?”
“真遗憾看到这胳膊，也很遗憾看到你的眼睛，还有你额头上烧伤的疤痕。最糟糕的是，有人要因为这些而过分爱你，过分重视你了。” “It is a pity to see it; and a pity to see your eyes—and the scar of fire on your forehead: and the worst of it is, one is in danger of loving you too well for all this; and making too much of you.”
“我以为你看到我的胳膊和我这疤痕累累的脸以后，会觉得恶心，简。” “I thought you would be revolted, Jane, when you saw my arm, and my cicatrised visage.”
“你是这么想的？不要对我说这些，不然我会说出一些贬损你判断力的话来。好了，我要离开你一会儿，把火烧旺一些，把壁炉清扫一下。炉火旺的时候，你能判断出来吗？” “Did you?Don’t tell me so—lest I should say something disparaging to your judgment.Now, let me leave you an instant, to make a better fire, and have the hearth swept up.Can you tell when there is a good fire?”
“能，我的右眼可以看到些光亮，朦朦胧胧的一片红。” “Yes; with the right eye I see a glow—a ruddy haze.”
“你能看见蜡烛光吗？” “And you see the candles?”
“非常模糊——每根蜡烛都是一团发亮的云雾。” “Very dimly—each is a luminous cloud.”
“你能看见我吗？” “Can you see me?”
“不能，我的仙女。但是，还能听见你，能感觉到你，我就万分感激了。” “No, my fairy: but I am only too thankful to hear and feel you.”
“你什么时候吃晚饭？” “When do you take supper?”
“我从不吃晚饭。”“但是你今晚得吃点。我很饿，我敢说你也饿了，只是你忘记了而已。” “I never take supper.”“But you shall have some tonight.I am hungry: so are you, I daresay, only you forget.”
我把玛丽叫来，并很快把屋子收拾得明朗了许多，我还为他做了一顿可口的晚餐。我的心情非常兴奋，晚饭时候愉快又轻松地同他聊天，饭后又聊了许久。跟他在一起，不需要恼人的自我约束，也不需要压抑自己的愉悦和活力；和他在一起，我无拘无束，因为我知道我与他很相配，我的言谈举止似乎都能给他安慰和活力。这种感觉真令人高兴！我的本性得以重生，并绽放光彩。有他在，我便能淋漓尽致地活着，同样，有我在，他才能淋漓尽致地活着。虽然他失明了，但脸上绽放出了笑容，额头也呈现出了快乐，表情也变得柔和、热情了。 Summoning Mary, I soon had the room in more cheerful order: I prepared him, likewise, a comfortable repast.My spirits were excited, and with pleasure and ease I talked to him during supper, and for a long time after.There was no harassing restraint, no repressing of glee and vivacity with him; for with him I was at perfect ease, because I knew I suited him; all I said or did seemed either to console or revive him.Delightful consciousness!It brought to life and light my whole nature: in his presence I thoroughly lived; and he lived in mine.Blind as he was, smiles played over his face, joy dawned on his forehead: his lineaments softened and warmed.
晚饭后，他开始问我许多问题，诸如：我去过哪儿，做过什么，怎么找到他的。但是我只是简略地回答了他，因为那晚时间不早了，不能详细作答。而且，我希望不去触及他内心深处激动的情绪，不要在他心里再开掘新的感情之泉，我目前唯一的目的就是让他快乐起来。正如我说的，他很高兴，然而只是一阵一阵的。只要谈话过程中出现了片刻的沉默，他就会变得不安起来，摸一下我，然后说：“简。” After supper, he began to ask me many questions, of where I had been, what I had been doing, how I had found him out; but I gave him only very partial replies: it was too late to enter into particulars that night.Besides, I wished to touch no deep thrilling chord—to open no fresh well of emotion in his heart: my sole present aim was to cheer him.Cheered, as I have said, he was: and yet but by fits.If a moment’s silence broke the conversation, he would turn restless, touch me, then say, “Jane.”
“你完完全全是个人吗，简？你确定是这样吗？” “You are altogether a human being, Jane?You are certain of that?”
“我从心眼儿里肯定是的，罗切斯特先生。” “I conscientiously believe so, Mr. Rochester.”
“可是，在这样一个漆黑阴郁的夜晚，你怎么能够突然出现在我孤寂的火炉边呢？我本来是伸手去接仆人送来的一杯水，却是你递过来的；我问了一个问题，等着约翰的妻子回答我，结果耳朵听到的是你的声音。” “Yet how, on this dark and doleful evening, could you so suddenly rise on my lone hearth?I stretched my hand to take a glass of water from a hireling, and it was given me by you: I asked a question, expecting John’s wife to answer me, and your voice spoke at my ear.”
“因为我代替玛丽把托盘端进来了啊。” “Because I had come in, in Mary’s stead, with the tray.”
“此时此刻跟你一起度过的时光令人心醉神迷。谁会知道，过去的几个月里，我过的是多么黑暗、沉闷、无望的日子啊？什么也不做，什么也不盼，昼夜不分，所有的感觉只是炉火熄灭后的寒冷和忘记吃饭后的饥饿。随后便是无尽的悲伤，有时，还会妄想能再一次看到我的简。是啊，我渴望再次得到她，远远超过渴望再次恢复我的视力。简怎么可能又跟我在一起，还说着她爱我？她不会像突然来临那样又突然离去吧？明天，我害怕又要找不到她了。” “And there is enchantment in the very hour I am now spending with you.Who can tell what a dark, dreary, hopeless life I have dragged on for months past?Doing nothing, expecting nothing; merging night in day; feeling but the sensation of cold when I let the fire go out, of hunger when I forgot to eat: and then a ceaseless sorrow, and, at times, a very delirium of desire to behold my Jane again.Yes: for her restoration I longed, far more than for that of my lost sight.How can it be that Jane is with me, and says she loves me?Will she not depart as suddenly as she came?Tomorrow, I fear I shall find her no more.”
眼下他心烦意乱，我确信，给他一个普通而实在的回答是最好不过的了，最能抚慰他的心。我的手指拂过他的双眉，并说它们都被烧焦了，我要给它们涂点什么药，让它们长得像以前一样又粗又黑。 A commonplace, practical reply, out of the train of his own disturbed ideas, was, I was sure, the best and most reassuring for him in this frame of mind.I passed my finger over his eyebrows, and remarked that they were scorched, and that I would apply something which would make them grow as broad and black as ever.
“对我这么好有什么用呢，仁慈的精灵？到了关键时刻，你会再次抛弃我，像影子一样消失，到哪儿去，怎么去，我都不得而知，从此以后，我就再也找不到你了。” “Where is the use of doing me good in any way, beneficent spirit, when, at some fatal moment, you will again desert me—passing like a shadow, whither and how to me unknown, and for me remaining afterwards undiscoverable?
“你身边有小梳子吗，先生？” “Have you a pocket-comb about you, sir?”
“干嘛用，简？” “What for, Jane?”
“把你这乱蓬蓬的黑马鬃梳一梳啊。我凑近你仔细打量，发现你非常吓人。你把我说成是仙女，但我敢肯定，你更像是个棕仙。” “Just to comb out this shaggy black mane.I find you rather alarming, when I examine you close at hand: you talk of my being a fairy, but I am sure, you are more like a brownie.”
“我是不是很丑，简？” “Am I hideous, Jane?”
“非常丑，先生。你一直都这样，你知道的。” “Very, sir: you always were, you know.”
“哼！不管你在什么地方呆过，还是改不掉那顽皮的本性。” “Humph! The wickedness has not been taken out of you, wherever you have sojourned.”
“不过我可是跟好人呆在一起的，比你好多了。他们比你好上一百倍，他们的思想和见解，你这辈子都没有过，他们比你更文雅、更高贵。” “Yet I have been with good people; far better than you: a hundred times better people; possessed of ideas and views you never entertained in your life: quite more refined and exalted.”
“你到底跟谁在一起呆过？” “Who the deuce have you been with?”
“如果你再这样扭动，会害我把你的头发揪下来的。我想，到时你就不会再怀疑我是不是真实存在的了。” “If you twist in that way you will make me pull the hair out of your head; and then I think you will cease to entertain doubts of my substantiality.”
“你跟谁在一起呆过啊，简？” “Who have you been with, Jane?”
“你今晚就别想从我这儿得到答案了，先生。你得等到明天了，你知道，故事只讲一半，会保证我明天早晨出现在你饭桌旁来接着讲完啊。顺便说一下，我明天务必不能只端着一杯水出现在你的壁炉旁，我至少得拿个鸡蛋，更不用说煎火腿了。” “You shall not get it out of me tonight, sir; you must wait till tomorrow; to leave my tale half told, will, you know, be a sort of security that I shall appear at your breakfast table to finish it.By the bye, I must mind not to rise on your hearth with only a glass of water then: I must bring an egg at the least, to say nothing of fried ham.”
“你这个爱捉弄人的丑孩子——真是仙人生，凡人养的！你让我尝到了这一年来从没有尝到的滋味。如果扫罗有你做他的大卫，不需要竖琴的帮助就能把恶魔赶跑了。” “You mocking changeling—fairy-born and human-bred!You make me feel as I have not felt these twelve months.If Saul could have had you for his David, the evil spirit would have been exorcised without the aid of the harp.”
“好了，先生，现在把你收拾得整整齐齐，像模像样了。这会儿我要离开你了，这三天我一直在旅途上奔波，感觉真的是累了。晚安。” “There, sir, you are redd up and made decent.Now I’ll leave you: I have been travelling these last three days, and I believe I am tired.Good night.”
“再问一句话，简，你之前呆过的地方是只有女士吗？” “Just one word, Jane: were there only ladies in the house where you have been?”
我笑着跑开了，一边往楼上跑，一边笑着。“好主意！”我高兴地想道，“我看以后的日子里，我有办法让他着急得忘掉自己的忧愁了。” I laughed and made my escape, still laughing as I ran upstairs.“A good idea!”I thought with glee.“I see I have the means of fretting him out of his melancholy for some time to come.”
第二天一大早，我就听到他起床走动的声音了，从一个房间走到另一个房间。玛丽一下楼，我就听到他问：“爱小姐在这儿吗？”然后又问：“你们把她安排到那间屋子了？屋子干燥吗？她起床了没？去问问她是否需要什么东西，什么时候下来？” Very early the next morning I heard him up and astir, wandering from one room to another.As soon as Mary came down I heard the question: “Is Miss Eyre here?”Then: “Which room did you put her into?Was it dry?Is she up?Go and ask if she wants anything; and when she will come down.”
一想到就要吃早餐了，于是我赶紧下了楼。我轻手轻脚地走进了房间，他还没察觉到我来了，我就先看见了他。说真的，看到朝气蓬勃的精神屈服于虚弱的身体，真够令人伤感的。他坐在自己的椅子上，一动也不动，但并不安宁，显然是有所期盼。如今，习惯性的忧愁在他桀骜的面孔上刻下了纹路。他的表情令人想到一盏熄灭了的灯，等待着被重新点亮——唉！他自己如今已不能够重新恢复泛着光泽、充满生气的表情了，他得依赖他人来完成。我本想表现得高高兴兴、无忧无虑的，但是这个强者如今无能为力的样子，触到了我内心的痛处。但我还是尽可能快活地同他打了招呼。 I came down as soon as I thought there was a prospect of breakfast.Entering the room very softly, I had a view of him before he discovered my presence.It was mournful, indeed, to witness the subjugation of that vigorous spirit to a corporeal infirmity.He sat in his chair—still, but not at rest: expectant evidently; the lines of now habitual sadness marking his strong features.His countenance reminded one of a lamp quenched, waiting to be re-lit—and alas!it was not himself that could now kindle the lustre of animated expression: he was dependent on another for that office!I had meant to be gay and careless, but the powerlessness of the strong man touched my heart to the quick: still I accosted him with what vivacity I could.
“真是个阳光明媚的早晨啊，先生。”我说，“雨过天晴了，你很快就能出去走走了。” “It is a bright, sunny morning, sir,” I said.“The rain is over and gone, and there is a tender shining after it: you shall have a walk soon.”
这话唤醒了他脸上的光华，他顿时容光焕发了。 I had wakened the glow: his features beamed.
“噢，你的确还在这儿，我的云雀啊！到我这里来。你没走，没有消失掉？一个小时之前，我听见你的一个同类在树林上方歌唱。但是它的歌声对我来说没有乐感，就像初升的太阳没有光芒。世界上所有美好的旋律都集中在我的简对我说的话里（真庆幸它从来都不沉默），凡是我能感受到的阳光全在她身上。” “Oh, you are indeed there, my skylark!Come to me.You are not gone: not vanished?I heard one of your kind an hour ago, singing high over the wood: but its song had no music for me, any more than the rising sun had rays.All the melody on earth is concentrated in my Jane’s tongue to my ear (I am glad it is not naturally a silent one): all the sunshine I can feel is in her presence.”
听到他如此坦率地表示对我的依赖，我不禁热泪盈眶。就好比一只高贵的老鹰，被锁链栓在了树桩上，不得不请求一只麻雀为它供食。但是我不是个爱哭的人，于是我匆匆抹去咸咸的泪水，忙着去准备早饭了。 The water stood in my eyes to hear this avowal of his dependence; just as if a royal eagle, chained to a perch, should be forced to entreat a sparrow to become its purveyor.But I would not be lachrymose: I dashed off the salt drops, and busied myself with preparing breakfast.
大半个上午是在户外度过的。我领着他走出潮湿、荒凉的树林，走进一片令人心旷神怡的田野。我向他描述着田野是多么碧绿，花儿和树篱是多么生气盎然，天空是多么湛蓝。我在一处隐蔽的好地方给他找到了坐的地方，是一个干燥的树墩。他坐下后，拉我坐在他腿上，我也没有拒绝。干嘛要拒绝呢？我们两个相互依偎总比分开要开心得多。派洛特躺在我俩旁边。一切都是那么宁静。他搂着我，突然开口道： Most of the morning was spent in the open air.I led him out of the wet and wild wood into some cheerful fields: I described to him how brilliantly green they were; how the flowers and hedges looked refreshed; how sparklingly blue was the sky.I sought a seat for him in a hidden and lovely spot, a dry stump of a tree; nor did I refuse to let him, when seated, place me on his knee.Why should I, when both he and I were happier near than apart?Pilot lay beside us: all was quiet.He broke out suddenly while clasping me in his arms—
“好狠心，好狠心的逃跑者啊！噢，简，我发现你从桑菲尔德逃走了，到处找你都没有结果，查看了你的房间，确信你没有带钱，也没有带任何能当钱使的东西，当时我是怎样的感受啊！我送给你的珍珠项链你原封不动地放在小首饰盒里，你的箱子还跟之前准备结婚旅行时一样，捆着绳子，上着锁。我自问，我心爱的人如今穷困潦倒、身无分文，她能怎么办呢？她都做了些什么呢？说给我听听吧。” “Cruel, cruel deserter!Oh, Jane, what did I feel when I discovered you had fled from Thornfield, and when I could nowhere find you; and, after examining your apartment, ascertained that you had taken no money, nor anything which could serve as an equivalent!A pearl necklace I had given you lay untouched in its little casket; your trunks were left corded and locked as they had been prepared for the bridal tour.What could my darling do, I asked, left destitute and penniless?And what did she do?Let me hear now.”
就这么被他催促着，我开始讲述过去这一年的经历。我轻描淡写地讲述了四处流浪、忍饥挨饿的那三天，因为对他和盘托出会给他带来不必要的痛苦。可我所讲的那一点经历也撕破了他那颗忠实的心，比我想的要严重得多。 Thus urged, I began the narrative of my experience for the last year.I softened considerably what related to the three days of wandering and starvation, because to have told him all would have been to inflict unnecessary pain: the little I did say lacerated his faithful heart deeper than I wished.
他说我不该就这么离开了他，两手空空，什么盘缠都不带，我应该把我的意图告诉他。我应该对他坦白，他绝对不会强迫我做他的情人。尽管他因为绝望而显得有些暴躁，但事实上，他太爱我了，对我太温柔了，不会变成我的暴君。他情愿把一半的财产都赠与我，甚至连一个吻都不要我回报他，也不愿意让我孤零零地逃到茫茫人海中。他确信，我忍受的磨难远不止我讲给他听的这些。 I should not have left him thus, he said, without any means of making my way: I should have told him my intention.I should have confided in him: he would never have forced me to be his mistress.Violent as he had seemed in his despair, he, in truth, loved me far too well and too tenderly to constitute himself my tyrant: he would have given me half his fortune, without demanding so much as a kiss in return, rather than I should have flung myself friendless on the wide world.I had endured, he was certain, more than I had confessed to him.
“好吧，不管我受过什么苦，时间都不长。”我答道，然后继续给他讲我怎样在荒原小屋被收留，怎样做了女教师等等。后来便是如何得到了遗产，找到了我的亲戚。当然了，在我讲述的过程中，不断地提到圣约翰·里弗斯的名字。我一讲完，他立刻就提起了这个名字。 “Well, whatever my sufferings had been, they were very short,” I answered: and then I proceeded to tell him how I had been received at Moor House; how I had obtained the office of schoolmistress, &c.The accession of fortune, the discovery of my relations, followed in due order.Of course, St. John Rivers’ name came in frequently in the progress of my tale.When I had done, that name was immediately taken up.
“那么，这个圣约翰，是你的表哥了？” “This St. John, then, is your cousin?”
“是的。” “Yes.”
“你常常提到他，你喜欢他吗？” “You have spoken of him often: do you like him?”
“他人非常好，先生，我忍不住要喜欢他。” “He was a very good man, sir; I could not help liking him.”
“一个好人。意思是不是说，他是个值得敬重、品行端正的五十岁男人啊？或者还是别的什么意思？” “A good man.Does that mean a respectable well-conducted man of fifty?Or what does it mean?”
“圣约翰不过才二十九岁，先生。” “St John was only twenty-nine, sir.”
“‘Jeune encore'(依然年轻)，就像法国人说的那样。他是不是个子矮小，冷淡迟钝，长相平庸啊？是那种优点就在于没犯过什么过错，而并非品格出众的人吧？” “‘Jeune encore,’ as the French say.Is he a person of low stature, phlegmatic, and plain.A person whose goodness consists rather in his guiltlessness of vice, than in his prowess in virtue.”
“他非常活跃，不知疲倦。他生来就是为了完成伟大而崇高的事业。” “He is untiringly active.Great and exalted deeds are what he lives to perform.”
“但是他的头脑呢？大概比较软弱吧？他的本意很好，但是你听他讲话时会耸肩。” “But his brain?That is probably rather soft?He means well: but you shrug your shoulders to hear him talk?”
“他话很少，先生。但只要开口就会一语中的。他的头脑是一流的，我想应该是不易被影响，却十分活跃。” “He talks little, sir: what he does say is ever to the point.His brain is first-rate, I should think not impressible, but vigorous.”
“那么，他是个能干的人了？” “Is he an able man, then?”
“真的很能干。” “Truly able.”
“是个接受过良好教育的人？” “A thoroughly educated man?”
“圣约翰学术很精，是个造诣很深的学者。” “St. John is an accomplished and profound scholar.”
“他的举止，我想你曾说过，不合你的品味？自负，一副牧师的腔调？” “His manners, I think, you said are not to your taste?—priggish and parsonic?”
“我从没提到过他的举止，但是除非我的品位很差，不然他倒是很合我的品位。他举止文雅、沉着，很有绅士风度。” “I never mentioned his manners; but, unless I had a very bad taste, they must suit it; they are polished, calm, and gentlemanlike.”
“他的外表——我忘了你是怎么形容他的外表了——一个不成熟的副牧师，白色的领口几乎能把他勒得半死，穿着厚底的高帮靴子，像踩高跷似的，嗯？” “His appearance,—I forget what description you gave of his appearance;—a sort of raw curate, half strangled with his white neck cloth, and stilted up on his thick-soled high-lows, eh?”
“圣约翰穿着十分得体。他长得很英俊：高个子，白皮肤，蓝眼睛，希腊式的面部轮廓。” “St. John dresses well.He is a handsome man: tall, fair, with blue eyes, and a Grecian profile.”
（冲着一旁说）“见他的鬼！”（转向我）“你喜欢他吗，简？” (Aside.) “Damn him!”—(To me.) “Did you like him, Jane?”
“是的，罗切斯特先生，我喜欢他。你之前已经问过我了。” “Yes, Mr. Rochester, I liked him: but you asked me that before.”
我当然明白了问话者的意图。嫉妒已经将他控制，并且刺痛了他，但是这对他有好处，可以让他从忧伤的咬噬中暂时解脱出来。因此，我不会立即降服这条嫉妒之蛇。 I perceived, of course, the drift of my interlocutor.Jealousy had got hold of him: she stung him; but the sting was salutary: it gave him respite from the gnawing fang of melancholy.I would not, therefore, immediately charm the snake.
“也许你不想再坐在我的腿上了，爱小姐？”接着他却说了这番有些出乎我意料的话。 “Perhaps you would rather not sit any longer on my knee, Miss Eyre?” was the next somewhat unexpected observation.
“为什么不想呢，罗切斯特先生？” “Why not, Mr. Rochester?”
“你刚才描述的这幅画面使人联想到一个反差非常强烈的对比。你的语言非常巧妙地勾勒出了一个优雅的阿波罗。他出现在你的想象中：高个子，白皮肤，蓝眼睛，有着希腊式的面部轮廓。你的眼睛看到的却是一个伍尔坎，一个真正的铁匠：褐色的皮肤，宽阔的肩膀，瞎了眼睛，还是个残废。” “The picture you have just drawn is suggestive of a rather too overwhelming contrast.Your words have delineated very prettily a graceful Apollo: he is present to your imagination,—tall, fair, blue-eyed, and with a Grecian profile.Your eyes dwell on a Vulcan,—a real blacksmith, brown, broad-shouldered: and blind and lame into the bargain.”
“我以前从来没想过这些，不过你的确非常像伍尔坎，先生。” “I never thought of it, before; but you certainly are rather like Vulcan, sir.”
“好吧，你可以离开我了，小姐。但是在你走之前（他把我抱得更紧了），请你再回答我一两个问题。”他打住了。 “Well, you can leave me, ma’am: but before you go” (and he retained me by a firmer grasp than ever), “you will be pleased just to answer me a question or two.”He paused.
“什么问题，罗切斯特先生？” “What questions, Mr. Rochester?”
接着便开始了这一连串的盘问。 Then followed this cross-examination.
“圣约翰还不知道你是他的表妹，就让你做了莫顿学校的老师？” “St. John made you schoolmistress of Morton before he knew you were his cousin?”
“是的。” “Yes.”
“你会常常见到他？他时不时地会到学校拜访？” “You would often see him?He would visit the school sometimes?”
“每天都去。” “Daily.”
“他会同意你的计划吗，简？我知道你的计划一定都很明智，因为你是个有才气的姑娘！” “He would approve of your plans, Jane?I know they would be clever, for you are a talented creature!”
“他赞同我的计划，是的。” “He approved of them—yes.”
“他会在你身上发现许多他所没有想到的东西吧？你身上的某些才能可不一般啊。” “He would discover many things in you he could not have expected to find?Some of your accomplishments are not ordinary.”
“这个我不知道。” “I don’t know about that.”
“你说你在学校附近有一间小屋，他会到那儿去看你吗？” “You had a little cottage near the school, you say: did he ever come there to see you?”
“时不时地会去？” “Now and then?”
“晚上会去吗？” “Of an evening?”
“去过一两次。” “Once or twice.”
他停顿了一下。 A pause.
“当发现你们是表亲后，你跟他还有他的两个妹妹又在一块儿住了多久？” “How long did you reside with him and his sisters after the cousinship was discovered?”
“五个月。” “Five months.”
“里弗斯花很多时间同他家里的女士们呆在一起吗？” “Did Rivers spend much time with the ladies of his family?”
“是的，后客厅既是他的书房，也是我们的书房。他坐在窗户旁边，我们坐在桌子旁边。” “Yes; the back parlour was both his study and ours: he sat near the window, and we by the table.”
“他研究得多吗？” “Did he study much?”
“很多。” “A good deal.”
“都研究些什么？” “What?”
“印度斯坦语。” “Hindostanee.”
“那当时你在做什么？” “And what did you do meantime?”
“我开始的时候学习德文。” “I learnt German, at first.”
“他教你吗？” “Did he teach you?”
“他不懂德文。” “He did not understand German.”
“他什么也没教过你？” “Did he teach you nothing?”
“教了一点印度斯坦语。” “A little Hindostanee.”
“里弗斯教你印度斯坦语？” “Rivers taught you Hindostanee?”
“是的，先生。” “Yes, sir.”
“他也教他的妹妹们了吗？” “And his sisters also?”
“没有。” “No.”
“只教你？” “Only you?”
“只教我。” “Only me.”
“是你要求学的吗？” “Did you ask to learn?”
“不是。” “No.”
“他想去教你？” “He wished to teach you?”
“是的。” “Yes.”
又一阵停顿。 A second pause.
“他为什么想教你？学印度斯坦语对你有什么用？” “Why did he wish it?Of what use could Hindostanee be to you?”
“他打算让我跟着他一起去印度。” “He intended me to go with him to India.”
“啊！我终于触及到问题的关键了。他想让你嫁给他？” “Ah! here I reach the root of the matter.He wanted you to marry him?”
“他请求我嫁给他。” “He asked me to marry him.”
“这准是虚构的，胡编乱造出来想要气我的。” “That is a fiction—an impudent invention to vex me.”
“请你原谅，这确确实实是真的。他不止一次请求我嫁给他，他坚持自己的意图，就像你一样固执。” “I beg your pardon, it is the literal truth: he asked me more than once, and was as stiff about urging his point as ever you could be.”
“爱小姐，我再说一遍，你可以离开我了。还要我把这句话说多少遍呢？既然我已经通知你可以走了，你为什么还这么固执地坐在我腿上？” “Miss Eyre, I repeat it, you can leave me.How often am I to say the same thing?Why do you remain pertinaciously perched on my knee, when I have given you notice to quit?”
“因为我在这儿很舒服。” “Because I am comfortable there.”
“不，简，你在这儿不舒服，因为你的心不在我这儿，而在那位表哥身上——就是圣约翰。哦，直到刚才，我还以为我可爱的简完全属于我！我相信即使她离开了我，她还爱着我，这个念头是我无尽痛苦中的一丝甜蜜。虽然我们长时间分离，虽然我为此挥洒热泪，但我从来没有想到在我为她悲伤落泪之际，她却爱着另一个人！不过，难过也没有用了。简，离开我，去嫁给里弗斯吧。” “No, Jane, you are not comfortable there, because your heart is not with me: it is with this cousin—this St. John.Oh, till this moment, I thought my little Jane was all mine!I had a belief she loved me even when she left me: that was an atom of sweet in much bitter.Long as we have been parted, hot tears as I have wept over our separation, I never thought that while I was mourning her, she loved another!But it is useless grieving.Jane, leave me: go and marry Rivers.”
“那么，甩掉我吧，先生，把我推走吧，因为我是不会主动离开你的。” “Shake me off, then, sir,—push me away, for I’ll not leave you of my own accord.”
“简，我一直都喜欢你的声音，它仍然可以唤醒希望，听起来那么真诚。听到它，我仿佛被带回到一年前。我忘了你已经结识了新朋友。但我不是个傻瓜——你走吧——” “Jane, I ever like your tone of voice: it still renews hope, it sounds so truthful.When I hear it, it carries me back a year.I forget that you have formed a new tie.But I am not a fool—go—”
“我能走去哪儿呢，先生？” “Where must I go, sir?”
“走你自己的路——跟你选择的丈夫一起。” “Your own way—with the husband you have chosen.”
“那是谁？” “Who is that?”
“你知道的——那个圣约翰·里弗斯。” “You know—this St. John Rivers.”
“他不是我的丈夫，也不会成为我的丈夫。他并不爱我，我也不爱他。他爱着（他会爱，但是和你的爱不同）一位漂亮的女士，名叫罗莎蒙德。他想娶我仅仅是因为他认为我适合做传教士的妻子，而她却不行。他很善良，很伟大，却非常冷峻，并且对我像冰山一样冷。他可不像你，先生。在他身边、靠近他或跟他在一起，我都不会高兴。他对我并不迷恋，也不喜爱。他在我身上看不到任何魅力，甚至连青春也看不到——他只看到了精神上一些有用的地方。那么，先生，我还是必须离开你，到他那儿去吗？” “He is not my husband, nor ever will be.He does not love me: I do not love him.He loves (as he CAN love, and that is not as you love) a beautiful young lady called Rosamond.He wanted to marry me only because he thought I should make a suitable missionary’s wife, which she would not have done.He is good and great, but severe; and, for me, cold as an iceberg.He is not like you, sir: I am not happy at his side, or near him, or with him.He has no indulgence for me—no fondness.He sees nothing attractive in me; not even youth—only a few useful mental points.—Then I must leave you, sir, to go to him?”
我不由自主地打了个寒颤，本能地把我亲爱的瞎眼主人抱得更紧了。他笑了。 I shuddered involuntarily, and clung instinctively closer to my blind but beloved master.He smiled.
“什么，简！这是真的吗？这真的就是你和里弗斯之间的情况吗？” “What, Jane!Is this true?Is such really the state of matters between you and Rivers?”
“绝对是真的，先生！噢，你不必嫉妒！我只是想逗一下你，让你少一些伤心，我以为生气总比悲伤好。可是，如果你希望我爱你，你只要看看我是多么爱你，你就会感到骄傲和满足了。我的心全部都是你的，它属于你，并且永远跟随着你，即使命运会把我身体的其他部分从你身边永远带走。” “Absolutely, sir!Oh, you need not be jealous!I wanted to tease you a little to make you less sad: I thought anger would be better than grief.But if you wish me to love you, could you but see how much I DO love you, you would be proud and content.All my heart is yours, sir: it belongs to you; and with you it would remain, were fate to exile the rest of me from your presence for ever.”
他吻我的时候，痛苦的思绪又一次令他脸色阴沉。“我烧毁的视力啊！我伤残的体魄啊！”他遗憾地咕哝着。 Again, as he kissed me, painful thoughts darkened his aspect.“My scared vision!My crippled strength!” he murmured regretfully.
我爱抚着他，想让他平静下来。我知道他在想什么，想替他说出来，却又不敢。他把脸转过去了片刻，我看到一滴泪从他那闭合的眼皮里滑了出来，顺着富有男子气的脸颊往下淌。我心潮澎湃。 I caressed, in order to soothe him.I knew of what he was thinking, and wanted to speak for him, but dared not.As he turned aside his face a minute, I saw a tear slide from under the sealed eyelid, and trickle down the manly cheek.My heart swelled.
“我比桑菲尔德果园里被雷击中的老栗树好不到哪儿去。”他很快说道，“那堆残败的枝叶有什么权力要求一株正发芽的忍冬用自己的新绿去覆盖它的腐朽呢？” “I am no better than the old lightning-struck chestnut-tree in Thornfield orchard,” he remarked ere long.“And what right would that ruin have to bid a budding woodbine cover its decay with freshness?”
“你不是残败的枝叶，先生，不是被雷击中的栗树。你绿意盎然，充满活力。不管你是否要求，新鲜的植物都会从你的根部长出来，因为它们在你的浓荫遮蔽下感到很快乐。随着它们不断长大，它们会向你靠拢，缠绕在你身上，因为你的力量为它们提供了可靠的支撑。” “You are no ruin, sir—no lightning-struck tree: you are green and vigorous.Plants will grow about your roots, whether you ask them or not, because they take delight in your bountiful shadow; and as they grow they will lean towards you, and wind round you, because your strength offers them so safe a prop.”
他又笑了，我给了他安慰。 Again he smiled: I gave him comfort.
“你说的是朋友吧，简？”他问道。 “You speak of friends, Jane?” he asked.
“是的，说的是朋友。”我极不情愿地答道。因为我知道我说的意思超出了朋友，但又不知道该用什么其他的字眼。他帮我说出来了。 “Yes, of friends,” I answered rather hesitatingly: for I knew I meant more than friends, but could not tell what other word to employ.He helped me.
“啊！简，可我需要的是一个妻子。” “Ah! Jane. But I want a wife.”
“是吗，先生？” “Do you, sir?”
“是的，这对你来说是新闻吗？”“当然，你以前从来没说过。” “Yes: is it news to you?”“Of course: you said nothing about it before.”
“这是个不受欢迎的新闻吗？” “Is it unwelcome news?”
“那得看情况了，先生,要看你的选择。” “That depends on circumstances, sir—on your choice.”
“你为我做选择吧，简。我绝对遵从你的决定。” “Which you shall make for me, Jane.I will abide by your decision.”
“那么选择最爱你的人吧，先生。” “Choose then, sir—HER WHO LOVES YOU BEST.”
“我最起码会选择——我最爱的人。简，你愿意嫁给我吗？” “I will at least choose—HER I LOVE BEST.Jane, will you marry me?”
“愿意，先生。” “Yes, sir.”
“一个贫穷的瞎子，你还得牵手领着他走的人？” “A poor blind man, whom you will have to lead about by the hand?”
“愿意，先生。” “Yes, sir.”
“一个残废的人，比你大二十岁，你得时时伺候着他的人？” “A crippled man, twenty years older than you, whom you will have to wait on?”
“愿意，先生。” “Yes, sir.”
“真的吗，简？” “Truly, Jane?”
“千真万确，先生。” “Most truly, sir.”
“哦，我亲爱的！愿上帝保佑你，恩赐你！” “Oh! my darling! God bless you and reward you!”
“罗切斯特先生，如果我这一生曾做过一件好事,如果我曾有过一个好的想法,如果我曾做过一次诚恳、没有瑕疵的祷告,如果我曾有过一个正当的愿望,那我现在已经得到了恩赐。做你的妻子，对我来说就是世界上最大的幸福。” “Mr. Rochester, if ever I did a good deed in my life—if ever I thought a good thought—if ever I prayed a sincere and blameless prayer—if ever I wished a righteous wish,—I am rewarded now.To be your wife is, for me, to be as happy as I can be on earth.”
“因为你乐于做出牺牲。” “Because you delight in sacrifice.”
“牺牲！我牺牲什么了？牺牲挨饿时得到食物？牺牲期待时得到满足？享有特权搂着我最珍视的人，亲吻我爱的人，依赖于我所信任的人，这些算是做出牺牲吗？如果是的话，那我当然乐于牺牲了。” “Sacrifice!What do I sacrifice?Famine for food, expectation for content.To be privileged to put my arms round what I value—to press my lips to what I love—to repose on what I trust: is that to make a sacrifice?If so, then certainly I delight in sacrifice.”
“你还得忍受我的体弱，简，还得忽视我的缺陷。” “And to bear with my infirmities, Jane: to overlook my deficiencies.”
“对我来说，这些都不存在，先生。我现在比以前更加爱你了，因为我确实能对你有所帮助。以前你很骄傲，不依赖任何人，你除了做施与者和保护者，不屑于任何别的角色。” “Which are none, sir, to me.I love you better now, when I can really be useful to you, than I did in your state of proud independence, when you disdained every part but that of the giver and protector.”
“一直以来，我讨厌靠别人帮助，让别人引领；从今往后，我觉得我不会再讨厌了。我不喜欢把手放在仆人的手里，但是感觉自己的手被简那小小的指头握着，会很愉快。我以前宁愿独守孤寂，也不愿让仆人一直在旁侍奉，但是简的温柔照顾却始终是一种享受。简适合我，那我适合她吗？” “Hitherto I have hated to be helped—to be led: henceforth, I feel I shall hate it no more.I did not like to put my hand into a hireling’s, but it is pleasant to feel it circled by Jane’s little fingers.I preferred utter loneliness to the constant attendance of servants; but Jane’s soft ministry will be a perpetual joy.Jane suits me: do I suit her?”
“非常称心如意，先生。” “To the finest fibre of my nature, sir.”
“既然是这样，还等什么呢，我们得马上结婚。” “The case being so, we have nothing in the world to wait for: we must be married instantly.”
他表情和语气都非常急切，看来他性急的老毛病又犯了。 He looked and spoke with eagerness: his old impetuosity was rising.
“我们必须结为一体，一刻都不能耽搁，简。只需办一张证书，然后我们就结婚。” “We must become one flesh without any delay, Jane: there is but the licence to get—then we marry.”
“罗切斯特先生，我刚刚发现太阳早已从最高点落下，派洛特已经回家吃晚饭了。让我看看你的表。” “Mr. Rochester, I have just discovered the sun is far declined from its meridian, and Pilot is actually gone home to his dinner.Let me look at your watch.”
“把它系在你的腰带上，珍妮特，今后你就留着它，我用不着了。” “Fasten it into your girdle, Janet, and keep it henceforward: I have no use for it.”
“现在将近下午四点了，先生。你不觉得饿吗？” “It is nearly four o’clock in the afternoon, sir.Don’t you feel hungry?”
“从今天算起，第三天就该是我们结婚的日子了，简。现在，别去在乎精美的衣服和珠宝首饰了，这些东西都一文不值。” “The third day from this must be our wedding-day, Jane.Never mind fine clothes and jewels, now: all that is not worth a fillip.”
“太阳把雨珠都晒干了，先生。微风也停了，天真热啊。” “The sun has dried up all the rain-drops, sir.The breeze is still: it is quite hot.”
“你知道吗，简，此刻，我领带下面古铜色的脖子上正戴着你的那串小小的珍珠项链。自从我失去了唯一的宝贝，我就一直戴着它，以此来纪念它的主人。” “Do you know, Jane, I have your little pearl necklace at this moment fastened round my bronze scrag under my cravat?I have worn it since the day I lost my only treasure, as a memento of her.”
“我们要穿过树林回家了，这样走最阴凉。” “We will go home through the wood: that will be the shadiest way.”
他没有注意到我的话，继续他自己的思路。 He pursued his own thoughts without heeding me.
“简！我敢说，你可能认为我是条没有信仰的狗吧，但就在此刻，我的心对主宰世界的仁慈的上帝充满了感激。他看事物跟凡人不一样，要清楚得多；他判断事物也跟凡人不一样，要明智得多。我犯了错，我差点儿玷污了我那纯洁的花朵，使它的纯洁沾染罪恶，结果全能的上帝把它从我这儿夺走了。我呢，顽固地反抗，甚至诅咒上天的安排。我没有俯首听命，反而公然违抗。神圣的审判继续进行，灾难沉重地降临到我身上，我被迫穿过了死亡的幽谷。上帝的惩罚威力无边，其中的一次打击使我永远甘于谦卑。你知道我曾为自己的力量感到自豪，然而如今呢，我不得不依靠他人的指引，就像孩子一样孱弱。最近，简，就在最近，我才开始明白并且承认上帝之手对我命运的改变。我开始感到自责与懊悔，希望能同造物主妥协。时不时地，我开始祈祷。祷告非常简短，却非常真诚。 “Jane! you think me, I daresay, an irreligious dog: but my heart swells with gratitude to the beneficent God of this earth just now.He sees not as man sees, but far clearer: judges not as man judges, but far more wisely.I did wrong: I would have sullied my innocent flower—breathed guilt on its purity: the Omnipotent snatched it from me.I, in my stiff-necked rebellion, almost cursed the dispensation: instead of bending to the decree, I defied it.Divine justice pursued its course; disasters came thick on me: I was forced to pass through the valley of the shadow of death.HIS chastisements are mighty; and one smote me which has humbled me for ever.You know I was proud of my strength: but what is it now, when I must give it over to foreign guidance, as a child does its weakness?Of late, Jane—only—only of late—I began to see and acknowledge the hand of God in my doom.I began to experience remorse, repentance; the wish for reconcilement to my Maker.I began sometimes to pray: very brief prayers they were, but very sincere.
几天前，不，我能数出来是四天前，那是礼拜一的晚上，我产生了一种奇怪的情绪，忧伤取代了狂暴，悲哀取代了愠怒。我一直以来都认为，既然哪儿也找不到你，你一定已经死了。那天深夜，也许是在十一点到十二点之间，在我闷闷不乐地去睡觉之前，我恳求上帝，如果他觉得妥当，那就可以尽快把我从尘世带走，让我进入来世，在那儿还有希望能和简相聚。 Some days since: nay, I can number them—four; it was last Monday night, a singular mood came over me: one in which grief replaced frenzy—sorrow, sullenness.I had long had the impression that since I could nowhere find you, you must be dead.Late that night—perhaps it might be between eleven and twelve o’clock—ere I retired to my dreary rest, I supplicated God, that, if it seemed good to Him, I might soon be taken from this life, and admitted to that world to come, where there was still hope of rejoining Jane.
我当时在自己的房间里，坐在窗前，窗子是开着的，清香的晚风吹来，我感到心旷神怡。虽然我看不见天上的星星，只能通过一团模糊、发光的薄雾，知道还有月亮。我渴望你，珍妮特！噢，我的灵魂和肉体都在渴望着你！我怀着痛苦和谦卑问上帝，我忍受的凄凉、痛苦和折磨是不是不够久，我还不可以再次品尝欢乐与安宁？我经历的全部苦难都是应得的，我承认这一点。我只是请求，我实在不能再忍受下去了。我心中全部的愿望不由自主地转化成这些字眼，脱口而出——‘简！简！简！’” I was in my own room, and sitting by the window, which was open: it soothed me to feel the balmy night-air; though I could see no stars and only by a vague, luminous haze, knew the presence of a moon.I longed for thee, Janet!Oh, I longed for thee both with soul and flesh!I asked of God, at once in anguish and humility, if I had not been long enough desolate, afflicted, tormented; and might not soon taste bliss and peace once more.That I merited all I endured, I acknowledged—that I could scarcely endure more, I pleaded; and the alpha and omega of my heart’s wishes broke involuntarily from my lips in the words—‘Jane! Jane! Jane!’”
“你是大声喊出来的吗？” “Did you speak these words aloud?”
“是的，简。任何人听见了，都会认为我疯了。我发了狂似的喊出那几个字。” “I did, Jane.If any listener had heard me, he would have thought me mad: I pronounced them with such frantic energy.”
“那是礼拜一晚上半夜时分？” “And it was last Monday night, somewhere near midnight?”
“是的，不过时间不重要，接着发生的事才是奇怪呢。你可能会认为我迷信，我天生就是有些迷信，一直是这样；然而这次是真的，至少真的是我亲耳听到了我现在所说的。 “Yes; but the time is of no consequence: what followed is the strange point.You will think me superstitious,—some superstition I have in my blood, and always had: nevertheless, this is true—true at least it is that I heard what I now relate.
就在我喊‘简！简！简！’的时候，一个声音——我不知道它从哪儿来，但却知道那是谁的声音——回答说：‘我来了，等着我’，过了一会儿，清风又送了轻声细语——‘你在哪儿？’ As I exclaimed ‘Jane! Jane! Jane!’ a voice—I cannot tell whence the voice came, but I know whose voice it was—replied, ‘I am coming: wait for me;’ and a moment after, went whispering on the wind the words—‘Where are you?’
如果可以，我会告诉你这些话在我心中所展现的思想和画面，然而要表达出我想说的真的很难。正如你看到的，芬丁庄园深藏在茂密的树林里，声音到了这里会很沉闷，没有回音地消失掉。‘你在哪儿？’这句话却像是在群山中发出来的，因为我听到了山的回音重复着这句话。当时拂过我额头的风仿佛也变得更加凉爽清新，我认为在某个荒凉、偏僻的地方，我与简正在相会。我相信，我们在精神上已经相会了。那个时候，你无疑正在毫无意识地酣睡，简。然而也许你的灵魂游离了躯体，过来安慰我的灵魂，因为那些话是你的口音，我以生命担保，那就是你说的话！” I’ll tell you, if I can, the idea, the picture these words opened to my mind: yet it is difficult to express what I want to express.Ferndean is buried, as you see, in a heavy wood, where sound falls dull, and dies unreverberating.‘Where are you?’ seemed spoken amongst mountains; for I heard a hill-sent echo repeat the words.Cooler and fresher at the moment the gale seemed to visit my brow: I could have deemed that in some wild, lone scene, I and Jane were meeting.In spirit, I believe we must have met.You no doubt were, at that hour, in unconscious sleep, Jane: perhaps your soul wandered from its cell to comfort mine; for those were your accents—as certain as I live—they were yours!”
读者啊，就是在礼拜一的晚上，午夜时分，我听到了这神秘的召唤,而那些话也正是我的回复。我倾听着罗切斯特先生的讲述，却没有接过话来向他透露什么。这一巧合令我感到太可怕了，太难以解释了，因此无法言传，也无需讨论。如果我说出什么来，我的故事必然会在听者的心灵上留下深刻的印象。而他的心灵在经过了这么多的苦难之后，很容易忧郁，不需要再用这种超自然的现象给它添加更深重的阴影了。于是我保留了这些事情，在心里细细琢磨。 Reader, it was on Monday night—near midnight—that I too had received the mysterious summons: those were the very words by which I replied to it.I listened to Mr. Rochester’s narrative, but made no disclosure in return.The coincidence struck me as too awful and inexplicable to be communicated or discussed.If I told anything, my tale would be such as must necessarily make a profound impression on the mind of my hearer: and that mind, yet from its sufferings too prone to gloom, needed not the deeper shade of the supernatural.I kept these things then, and pondered them in my heart.
“你现在也就不该再纳闷，”我的主人继续说道，“当你昨晚那么出人意料地出现在我面前时，我很难相信你不仅仅只是一个声音，一个幻象，不只是某种会突然销声匿迹的东西，就像之前午夜的轻声细语和群山回音那样会消失无踪。现在，我感谢上帝！ “You cannot now wonder,” continued my master, “that when you rose upon me so unexpectedly last night, I had difficulty in believing you any other than a mere voice and vision, something that would melt to silence and annihilation, as the midnight whisper and mountain echo had melted before.Now, I thank God!
我知道这回可不是那样了。是的，我感谢上帝！”他把我从腿上抱下来，虔诚地把帽子从头上摘了下来，俯身将失明的眼睛对着大地，虔诚而静默地站着。我只听到了他对上帝表示崇拜的最后几句话。 I know it to be otherwise.Yes, I thank God!”He put me off his knee, rose, and reverently lifting his hat from his brow, and bending his sightless eyes to the earth, he stood in mute devotion.Only the last words of the worship were audible.
“我感谢我的造物主，在他的审判中还记着慈悲。我谦卑地恳求我的救赎者赐予我力量，从此以后过上一种比以往更加纯洁的生活！” “I thank my Maker, that, in the midst of judgment, he has remembered mercy.I humbly entreat my Redeemer to give me strength to lead henceforth a purer life than I have done hitherto!”
然后他伸出手，让我牵着他。我握住了那只亲爱的手，放在我的唇上吻了一会儿，然后让它搂住我的肩膀。我个头比他矮很多，所以我既做他的支撑，又当他的向导。我们走进了树林，往家的方向走去。 Then he stretched his hand out to be led.I took that dear hand, held it a moment to my lips, then let it pass round my shoulder: being so much lower of stature than he, I served both for his prop and guide.We entered the wood, and wended homeward.
第三十八章——结尾 CHAPTER XXXVIII—CONCLUSION
读者们，我嫁给了他。我们举行了一场安静的婚礼，在场的只有他和我，牧师和教会文书。我们从教堂回来后，我走进了庄园的厨房，玛丽正在做晚饭，约翰正在擦拭刀具，于是我说： Reader, I married him.A quiet wedding we had: he and I, the parson and clerk, were alone present.When we got back from church, I went into the kitchen of the manor-house, where Mary was cooking the dinner and John cleaning the knives, and I said—
“玛丽，今天上午我同罗切斯特先生结婚了。”这位女管家和她丈夫两人都是礼貌、冷静的规矩人，你可以在任何时候放心地对他们说出惊人的消息，而不用担心你的耳朵会有被尖叫声刺破的危险，或是被随后喋喋不休的大惊小怪搞得不知所措。玛丽还是抬起了头，也的确盯着我看了看，她手中拿着正在给两只火上烤着的鸡涂油的勺子，也的确在空中停了三分来钟。与此同时，约翰正在擦拭的刀具的手也停了下来。然而，玛丽又开始俯身涂烤鸡，仅仅说道： “Mary, I have been married to Mr. Rochester this morning.”The housekeeper and her husband were both of that decent phlegmatic order of people, to whom one may at any time safely communicate a remarkable piece of news without incurring the danger of having one’s ears pierced by some shrill ejaculation, and subsequently stunned by a torrent of wordy wonderment.Mary did look up, and she did stare at me: the ladle with which she was basting a pair of chickens roasting at the fire, did for some three minutes hang suspended in air; and for the same space of time John’s knives also had rest from the polishing process: but Mary, bending again over the roast, said only—
“是吗，小姐？噢，那当然了！” “Have you, Miss?Well, for sure!”
过了一小会儿，她继续说道：“我看到你和主人出去了，但是我不知道你们是去教堂结婚了。”说完她便接着给烤鸡涂油。我转向了约翰，他正咧着大嘴笑呢。 A short time after she pursued—“I seed you go out with the master, but I didn’t know you were gone to church to be wed;” and she basted away.John, when I turned to him, was grinning from ear to ear.
“我告诉过玛丽事情会是这样的，”他说，“我知道爱德华先生（约翰是位老仆人，从主人还是家里的小少爷时就认识他了，因此，他经常用教名称呼他）——我知道爱德华先生会怎么做，我相信他也不会等太久的，也许他做得很对。我祝你快乐，小姐！”他礼貌地扯了一下自己的额发。 “I telled Mary how it would be,” he said: “I knew what Mr. Edward” (John was an old servant, and had known his master when he was the cadet of the house, therefore, he often gave him his Christian name)—“I knew what Mr. Edward would do; and I was certain he would not wait long neither: and he’s done right, for aught I know.I wish you joy, Miss!” and he politely pulled his forelock.
“谢谢你，约翰。罗切斯特先生让我把这个给你和玛丽。”我把一张五英镑的钞票塞进他手里。没有再等他们说什么，我便走出了厨房。之后我又一次经过这间属于他俩的私室时，不经意听到了这些话： “Thank you, John.Mr. Rochester told me to give you and Mary this.”I put into his hand a five-pound note.Without waiting to hear more, I left the kitchen.In passing the door of that sanctum some time after, I caught the words—
“她没准儿比任何阔小姐都更适合他呢。”还有，“即使她还算不上最漂亮的，倒也不丑，性格也好。在他眼里，她可是相当好看啊，谁也看得出来。” “She’ll happen do better for him nor ony o’t’ grand ladies.”And again, “If she ben’t one o’ th’ handsomest, she’s noan faal and varry good-natured; and i’ his een she’s fair beautiful, onybody may see that.”
我立刻给荒原小屋和剑桥写了信，告诉他们我都做了些什么，同时也详细地解释了我为什么这么做。黛安娜和玛丽直言不讳地对此表示赞同。黛安娜表示她只会给我留出度蜜月的时间，之后她就会过来看我。 I wrote to Moor House and to Cambridge immediately, to say what I had done: fully explaining also why I had thus acted.Diana and Mary approved the step unreservedly.Diana announced that she would just give me time to get over the honeymoon, and then she would come and see me.
“她最好不要等到那时候，简，”当我把黛安娜的信念给罗切斯特先生听时，他说道，“如果她等到那时候，那就太晚了。因为我们的蜜月会照耀我们一辈子，直到你我其中一个进了坟墓，它的光芒才会渐渐褪去。” “She had better not wait till then, Jane,” said Mr. Rochester, when I read her letter to him; “if she does, she will be too late, for our honeymoon will shine our life long: its beams will only fade over your grave or mine.”
圣约翰收到这个消息后作何反应，我不得而知，他一直没有回复我的信。然而六个月后，他给我写了封信，但却只字未提罗切斯特先生的名字和我的婚姻。他的信很平静，虽然非常严肃，但还是很友好。从此他虽然不是经常给我写信，却也会定期写。他希望我快乐，并且相信我不是那种活在世上，只留意俗事而忘了上帝的人。 How St. John received the news, I don’t know: he never answered the letter in which I communicated it: yet six months after he wrote to me, without, however, mentioning Mr. Rochester’s name or alluding to my marriage.His letter was then calm, and, though very serious, kind.He has maintained a regular, though not frequent, correspondence ever since: he hopes I am happy, and trusts I am not of those who live without God in the world, and only mind earthly things.
你还没有完全忘记小阿代勒吧，是不是，读者？我没有忘，不久我就请示罗切斯特先生，并得到他的许可，去当初他安置小阿代勒的学校看望她。再次见到我，她欣喜若狂的样子令我感动。她看上去既苍白又瘦弱，她说她一点也不快乐。我发现对她这般年纪的孩子来说，学校的规章制度太严格了，课程也太紧张了。我于是把她带回了家。我打算再次做她的家庭教师，但很快便发现这个想法不切实际。现在还有另一个人需要我的时间和关心——我的丈夫完全占据了它们。所以我另找了一所管理比较宽松的学校，并且非常近，让我可以常常去看她，有时还可以把她带回来。我仔细照顾她，确保她过得舒适，不缺任何东西。她很快就在新的住所安顿了下来，在那儿过得很快乐，学习上也取得了很大进步。随着她渐渐长大，健全的英国式教育在很大程度上纠正了她的法国式缺点。她从学校毕业时，我发现她成了一个招人喜爱、乐于助人的好伙伴，温顺、和气、守原则。她满怀感激地关心着我和我的家人，早已经回报了我为她提供的力所能及的帮助。 You have not quite forgotten little Adele, have you, reader?I had not; I soon asked and obtained leave of Mr. Rochester, to go and see her at the school where he had placed her.Her frantic joy at beholding me again moved me much.She looked pale and thin: she said she was not happy.I found the rules of the establishment were too strict, its course of study too severe for a child of her age: I took her home with me.I meant to become her governess once more, but I soon found this impracticable; my time and cares were now required by another—my husband needed them all.So I sought out a school conducted on a more indulgent system, and near enough to permit of my visiting her often, and bringing her home sometimes.I took care she should never want for anything that could contribute to her comfort: she soon settled in her new abode, became very happy there, and made fair progress in her studies.As she grew up, a sound English education corrected in a great measure her French defects; and when she left school, I found in her a pleasing and obliging companion: docile, good-tempered, and well-principled.By her grateful attention to me and mine, she has long since well repaid any little kindness I ever had it in my power to offer her.
我的故事接近尾声了。再说一两句我的婚姻生活，再简略地提一下那些在我故事中频频被提到名字的人们的命运，我就讲完了。 My tale draws to its close: one word respecting my experience of married life, and one brief glance at the fortunes of those whose names have most frequently recurred in this narrative, and I have done.
我如今已经结婚十年了。我懂得了全心全意跟自己最爱的人一起活着，为他而活着是多么幸福的事。我自认为太有福气了，这种福气不是言语可以表达的，因为就如同我丈夫完全是我的生命一样，我也完全是他的生命。再没有第二个女人能比我更贴近自己的爱人了，比我更完全地成为他的骨中之骨，肉中之肉了。与我的爱德华相守，我永远不会厌倦，他同我相守也是一样，就像我们不会厌倦各自胸膛里心脏的搏动一样。所以，我们永远相守。对我们来说，相守像独处时一样自由，又像相聚时一样快乐。我感觉我们整天都在交谈，相互交谈不过是另一种更活跃的、有声的思考。我对他无话不说，他对我推心置腹；我们性格完全相投，因此达到了完美的统一。 I have now been married ten years.I know what it is to live entirely for and with what I love best on earth.I hold myself supremely blest—blest beyond what language can express; because I am my husband’s life as fully is he is mine.No woman was ever nearer to her mate than I am: ever more absolutely bone of his bone and flesh of his flesh.I know no weariness of my Edward’s society: he knows none of mine, any more than we each do of the pulsation of the heart that beats in our separate bosoms; consequently, we are ever together.To be together is for us to be at once as free as in solitude, as gay as in company.We talk, I believe, all day long: to talk to each other is but a more animated and an audible thinking.All my confidence is bestowed on him, all his confidence is devoted to me; we are precisely suited in character—perfect concord is the result.
我们婚后前两年，罗切斯特先生仍然失明，也许正是这个情况使我们两个得以如此贴近彼此，让我们紧密地交织在一起。因为那时我就是他的眼睛，正如我现在还是他的右手一样。我的确是他的眼珠（他常常这么称呼我）。他通过我看大自然，看书。我永不厌倦地替他观察，然后用语言向他描述田野、树木、城镇、河流、云朵、阳光，我们面前的一切景色，还有周围的天气——用声音使他的耳朵感受眼睛无法通过光线感受到的景象。我还不知厌倦地读书给他听，领他去想去的地方，总之就是做所有他想做的事情。为他服务我感到快乐，虽然有些悲伤，但却充实而微妙——因为他要我帮忙时并不痛苦地感到羞愧，或是沮丧地感到屈辱。他爱我至真至纯，欣然地接受我的照顾，他感觉得到我爱他如此之深，接受我的照顾就是满足我最甜蜜的愿望。 Mr. Rochester continued blind the first two years of our union; perhaps it was that circumstance that drew us so very near—that knit us so very close: for I was then his vision, as I am still his right hand.Literally, I was (what he often called me) the apple of his eye.He saw nature—he saw books through me; and never did I weary of gazing for his behalf, and of putting into words the effect of field, tree, town, river, cloud, sunbeam—of the landscape before us; of the weather round us—and impressing by sound on his ear what light could no longer stamp on his eye.Never did I weary of reading to him; never did I weary of conducting him where he wished to go: of doing for him what he wished to be done.And there was a pleasure in my services, most full, most exquisite, even though sad—because he claimed these services without painful shame or damping humiliation.He loved me so truly, that he knew no reluctance in profiting by my attendance: he felt I loved him so fondly, that to yield that attendance was to indulge my sweetest wishes.
婚后第二年年末的一天早晨，我正在听他口授，写一封信。他走过来俯身看着我，问道：“简，你脖子上是不是带着一件闪闪发光的饰品？” One morning at the end of the two years, as I was writing a letter to his dictation, he came and bent over me, and said—“Jane, have you a glittering ornament round your neck?”
我戴着一条金表链，于是答道：“是的。” I had a gold watch-chain: I answered “Yes.”
“你是不是穿着一件浅蓝色的衣裳？” “And have you a pale blue dress on?”
我确实是如此。然后他告诉我，这段时间以来，他觉得蒙蔽着一只眼睛的那层云翳在渐渐变薄，然而现在他确信无疑了。 I had.He informed me then, that for some time he had fancied the obscurity clouding one eye was becoming less dense; and that now he was sure of it.
我和他去了趟伦敦。他听从了一位有名的眼科医生的建议，最终恢复了那只眼睛的视力。现在他虽不能看得特别清楚，不能过多地看书或写字，但走路不用再牵着别人的手了。对他来说，天空不再是一片空白，大地也不再是一种空虚。当他的第一个孩子放进他怀里时，他可以看见那孩子继承了他从前的那双眼睛——又大，又亮，又黑。在那一刻，他又一次全心地感激上帝赐予了他怜悯，减轻了惩罚。 He and I went up to London.He had the advice of an eminent oculist; and he eventually recovered the sight of that one eye.He cannot now see very distinctly: he cannot read or write much; but he can find his way without being led by the hand: the sky is no longer a blank to him—the earth no longer a void.When his firstborn was put into his arms, he could see that the boy had inherited his own eyes, as they once were—large, brilliant, and black.On that occasion, he again, with a full heart, acknowledged that God had tempered judgment with mercy.
之后，爱德华和我便过着幸福的生活。更让我们感到幸福的是，我们最爱的人们也都一样幸福。黛安娜·里弗斯和玛丽·里弗斯都结婚了。我们一年一次轮换着，要么他们来看我们，要么我们去看他们。黛安娜的丈夫是名海军上校，一个英勇的军官，是一个好人。玛丽的丈夫是名牧师，他哥哥的一个大学朋友，无论是成就还是品行，都配得上这门亲事。菲茨詹姆斯上校和沃顿先生都非常爱他们的妻子，他们的妻子也爱他们。 My Edward and I, then, are happy: and the more so, because those we most love are happy likewise.Diana and Mary Rivers are both married: alternately, once every year, they come to see us, and we go to see them.Diana’s husband is a captain in the navy, a gallant officer and a good man.Mary’s is a clergyman, a college friend of her brother’s, and, from his attainments and principles, worthy of the connection.Both Captain Fitzjames and Mr. Wharton love their wives, and are loved by them.
至于圣约翰·里弗斯，他离开英国，去了印度。他走上了自己所规划的道路，并在这条路上继续走了下去。一个更加坚定、永不疲惫的先驱者，在岩石和危险中奋力前行。他坚定、忠实、虔诚、精力充沛、热情真诚，为同胞任劳任怨；他为他们艰难地开辟前进的道路，像个巨人一般，砍倒阻碍道路的教义和种族偏见。他也许很严厉，也许很苛刻，也许仍然雄心勃勃。但他的严厉是属于武士大心的严厉，保护他的朝圣者们不受亚玻伦人的袭击。他的苛刻是属于使徒的苛刻，使徒只代表基督说话，他说：“若有人要跟随我，就当舍己，背起他的十字架来跟随我。”他的雄心是属于崇高的主的精神之雄心，旨在成为尘世被救赎者行列中的前茅——他们毫无过错地站在上帝的宝座前，分享耶稣最后的伟大胜利，他们都是受主召唤，被主选中的人，忠心耿耿。 As to St. John Rivers, he left England: he went to India.He entered on the path he had marked for himself; he pursues it still.A more resolute, indefatigable pioneer never wrought amidst rocks and dangers.Firm, faithful, and devoted, full of energy, and zeal, and truth, he labours for his race; he clears their painful way to improvement; he hews down like a giant the prejudices of creed and caste that encumber it.He may be stern; he may be exacting; he may be ambitious yet; but his is the sternness of the warrior Great heart, who guards his pilgrim convoy from the onslaught of Apollyon.His is the exaction of the apostle, who speaks but for Christ, when he says—“Whosoever will come after me, let him deny himself, and take up his cross and follow me.”His is the ambition of the high master-spirit, which aims to fill a place in the first rank of those who are redeemed from the earth—who stand without fault before the throne of God, who share the last mighty victories of the Lamb, who are called, and chosen, and faithful.
圣约翰没有结婚，现在再也不会结婚了。他一直以来都满足于这种劳苦，而这劳苦即将结束了，他那辉煌的太阳正在匆匆落下。他写给我的最后一封信使我落下了凡人的眼泪，然而心里却充满了神圣的喜悦。他预想到了自己必得的回报，他那不朽的花冠。我知道接下来我会收到由陌生人的手写来的信，告诉我这位善良、忠诚的仆人最终被召唤去享受主的欢乐了。那么为什么还为此哭泣呢？圣约翰临终时不会被死亡的恐惧所罩，他的头脑不会糊涂，他的心灵也不会畏惧，他的希望十分明确，他的信念坚定不移。他自己的话证明了这一切： St. John is unmarried: he never will marry now.Himself has hitherto sufficed to the toil, and the toil draws near its close: his glorious sun hastens to its setting.The last letter I received from him drew from my eves human tears, and yet filled my heart with divine joy: he anticipated his sure reward, his incorruptible crown.I know that a stranger’s hand will write to me next, to say that the good and faithful servant has been called at length into the joy of his Lord.And why weep for this?No fear of death will darken St. John’s last hour: his mind will be unclouded, his heart will be undaunted, his hope will be sure, his faith steadfast.His own words are a pledge of this—
“我的主，”他说，“已经预先警告过我。他日复一日更加明确地宣布：‘是了，我必快来！’我每时每刻都更加迫切地回答：‘阿门，主耶稣啊，我愿跟你来！’” “My Master,” he says, “has forewarned me.Daily He announces more distinctly,—‘Surely I come quickly!’and hourly I more eagerly respond, ‘Amen; even so come, Lord Jesus!’”
